# 道德真经广圣义

**The *Dao De Zheng Jing Guang Sheng Yi* (Extensive Explication of the Profound Meaning of the *Dao De Zheng Jing*)**

**Title:** The *Dao De Zheng Jing Guang Sheng Yi* (Extensive Explication of the Profound Meaning of the *Dao De Zheng Jing*).
**Author:** Composed by Master Guang Cheng of the Tang dynasty, Du Guangting.
**Total Volumes:** Fifty.
**Source of the Base Text:** *Zheng Tong Dao Zang* (Canonical Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era), in the *Dong Shen* (Cavernly Divine) section, *Yu Jue* (Jade Precepts) category.

---

**Volume One of the *Dao De Zheng Jing Guang Sheng Yi***
**Narrated by Tang Master Guang Cheng (Du Guangting)**
**Preface Explaining the Grand Meaning of the Scripture**

Now, I shall elucidate this scripture in two major parts: first, clarifying the composition of the commentary, and then expounding upon the original text itself. Today, I initially recount the origins of this commentary.

In the past, the Great Tang Emperor Xuanzong (玄宗皇帝), during his moments of leisure, pondered the wondrous gates of the Dao, considering the Great Way as the primordial root of heaven and earth. Laozi (老君) is the Supreme Ancestor of Primordial Mystery. Through the two scriptures (*Daodejing* and *Zhuangzi*), his teachings unfolded over countless years, tracing back to the reign of Shun (舜朝) and transmitted through the Zhou dynasty (周代). Over sixty commentaries and elucidations have been penned, interpreting its principles.

For matters of governance and statecraft, the strictures of **Yan Shi** (严氏) and **He Gong Yang Jiao** (河公杨镳) were self-realized. In terms of cultivating personal virtue, the teachings of **Song Ling** (松灵) and **Xiang Er Yi** (想尔逸) were profound, their paths difficult to follow.

Among these, in the Southern dynasties (南朝), the luminaries **Emperor Wu of Liang** (梁武), **Emperor Jianwen of Liang** (简文), **Seng Zhao** (僧肇), **Luoshitong** (罗什), **Zang** (臧), **Tao** (陶), **Gu** (顾), and **Meng** (孟) were esteemed. Meanwhile, **Ren** (任), **Li** (黎), and **the two Zhangs** (二张) shone like stars across **Western Shu** (西蜀). Yet, despite their contributions, the commentaries diverged in quality—some were flawed, others incomplete—and none fully penetrated the depths of its hallowed teachings. Who could truly fathom its profound mysteries?

In the **Kaiyuan** (开元) year **11**, I personally undertook this commentary. The Emperor decreed:

*"In ancient times, the Primordial Sage forcefully expounded upon the Mysterious Words."*

**Explication:** The term *zhao* (诏) is a royal edict. For the Son of Heaven (天子), it is called *zhao*, *gao*, *chi*, or *zhi*; for the Empress, Crown Prince, and nobles, it is called *jiao* (教) or *ling* (令)—all terms signifying the sovereign’s command descending upon his subjects or superiors unto inferiors.

The term *yue* (曰) is said to be from the mouth, representing speech or utterance, as in opening one’s mouth and extending the tongue to speak. The *Shuo Wen* (Explanation of Script) states: *"Yue (曰) is discourse. It is composed of the radical 'mouth' (口) and the phonetic 'yi' (乙), symbolizing the breath issuing from the mouth and forming articulate speech."* Hence, it is called *yue*.

*"In ancient times"* (昔者) means "in the past."
*"Zai"* (在) means "to exist."
*"Yuan"* (元) means "the beginning."
*"Sheng"* (圣) denotes the virtue of "enlightened penetration" (灵通之德). As the *Book of Documents* (书) states: *"Rui (睿) creates Sheng (圣)."*
*"Qiang"* (强) means "to exert force."
*"Zhuo"* (着) means "to compose or write."
*"Xuan"* (玄) signifies "profound and subtle."
*"Yan"* (言) is "discourse."

Laozi is the origin of Daoist transformation, the utmost virtue of the Primordial Sage. He expounded upon the ineffable, nameless Way, crafting forceful and resonant words to revive and propagate the Mysterious Teachings, guiding all generations. His understanding was profound, hence the term *"Xuan Yan"* (玄言, Mysterious Words). As the first among all sages, he is called the *"Yuan Sheng"* (元圣, Primordial Sage).

The Emperor decreed:
*"Establish the True Doctrine as the foundation,"*
**Explication:** *"Quan Yu"* (权舆) means "the beginning." *"Zhen"* (真) signifies "pure and unadulterated." *"Zong"* (宗) is "to honor." Thus, the decree establishes the *Daodejing* as the foundational, pure, and honored doctrine.

The Emperor decreed:
*"Illuminate and guide the future generations."*
**Explication:** *"Qi"* (启) means "to open." *"Di"* (迪) means "to advance." *"Tong"* (通) means "to reach." *"Lai"* (来) refers to "the future." *"Yi"* (裔) means "heirs" or "boundaries." This decree signifies that the two chapters of the *Daodejing* endure through all ages, serving as a model for future rulers and broadly transforming both humanity and the heavens, eternally disseminating its profound mysteries.

The Emperor decreed:
*"Though his writings remain, the refined meaning has strayed."*
**Explication:** *"Yi"* (遗) means "to leave behind." Laozi, having completed his Mysterious Transformation, ascended to the **Nine Pure** (九清), leaving behind the True Scripture for all ages. The sages and kings of every era revere it, and it persists through the ages. *"Cheng"* (诚) means "truthful," denoting an unalterable standard. *"Jing"* (精) signifies "pure, refined, and profound." *"Yi"* (义) refers to the principles and meanings of the scripture. *"Po"* (颇) means "extremely." *"Kui"* (乖) means "to deviate." Thus, though the scripture’s profound and pure principles remain, the world has yet to fully exhaust their depths. Even with sixty commentaries, the refined meaning still strays far from its original intent—referring to the following sentence.

The Emperor decreed:
*"Though I condense its essence, even Shu Yan’s work is still deficient."*
**Explication:** *"Cuo"* (撮) means "to select and compile." *"Zhi"* (指) means "direction or intent." *"Gui"* (归) means "the convergence of principles." Shu Yan (蜀严), the Daoist adept **Yan Junping** (严君平), resided in Shu (蜀) and authored the *Dao De Zhi Gui* (指归, *The Direction and Convergence of the Dao De*), a work of fourteen volumes, expansive and vast, highly praised in his time. In the Han dynasty (汉朝), the eminent scholar **Yang Ziyun** (杨子云) of Shu declared: *"Shu Yan’s understanding of the Dao De is profound and abstruse."* His insight was deep, his Mysterious Virtue concealed, far beyond the comprehension of the common folk. Yet, even his work is still deficient.

At that time, it was believed that the teachings of the *Dao De* were confined to five thousand characters in the text, yet the interpretations of its principles and intent could reach tens of thousands. When applied to the world, they were deemed abundant and expansive; when reasoned through, they were criticized for their sprawling and excessive proliferation.

Hence, it was said: *"Though Shu Yan’s work is profound, it still falls short."*

The Emperor decreed:
*"Select its key passages, and even River Master’s exposition is still deficient."*

**Explication:** *"Select"* (摘) refers to choosing and distinguishing. *"Passages"* (章) means to measure and judge the words and tones. *"Sentence"* (句) is where speech naturally pauses. *"From"* (自) means *"since"* or *"beginning with."* River Master (河公) is **River Master** (河上公), a Daoist sage of the **Taiji** (太极) lineage, **Ge Xuan** (葛玄), who authored *The Preface and Essentials of the Dao De Jing* (《道德经序诀》). It was recorded that River Master’s true name was unknown. During the reign of **Emperor Wen of Han** (汉孝文皇帝), he constructed a thatched hut by the riverbank, where he habitually studied the *Dao De Jing* of Laozi. Today, in the vicinity of the **Yellow River in Shaanxi** (今陕州黄河之侧), there stands a temple dedicated to River Master. To the left of the path, there remains the **Wanxian Platform** (望仙台) of Emperor Wen of Han. Since people of that time did not know his name, they often saw him engaged in the craft of sandal-making, dwelling by the river, hence the title **River Master**.

*"Even River Master’s exposition is still deficient"* (而犹病耳): The Imperial decree held that the *Dao De Jing*, being the most revered scripture encompassing all teachings, governs the Three Realms (三才), the foundation of statecraft and family governance, and the essence of self-cultivation and Daoist practice—omnipotent and all-encompassing. Yet River Master divided it into **eighty-one chapters**, constrained by the **nine-nine** (九九) numerical scheme, which failed to capture the boundless, effortless profundity of the Sage. Hence, it was said: *"Though beginning with River Master, the exposition is still deficient."*

The Emperor decreed:
*"The rest are merely subtle and obscure, not worth counting."*

**Explication:** *"The rest"* (其余) refers to the interpretations of the over fifty schools beyond Shu Yan and River Master. *"Subtle"* (浸微) means distant and refined. *"Obscure"* (微细) means minute and trivial. *"Count"* (数) means to enumerate or calculate. Though Shu Yan’s work still falls short, it suffices for discussion on the **Heavy Mysterious** (重玄). Though River Master’s exposition is deficient, it still illuminates the utmost subtlety. The interpretations of the other schools are distant, refined, and trivial, unworthy of comparison—indeed, they are not within the scope of the Imperial decree’s enumeration.

The Emperor decreed:
*"Then my profound and wondrous essence of the Dao—how could it ever be lost?"*

**Explication:** *"My"* (我) is the Emperor’s self-reference. *"Profound and wondrous essence"* (玄元妙旨) pertains to the profound and wondrous intent of the **Two Scriptures** (二经). The Imperial decree lamented the hidden profundity of the *Dao De* text and the subtle, ineffable essence of its upper and lower teachings, which had yet to be fully illuminated. Those who interpreted it after Shu Yan and River Master, with their commentaries and annotations, grew ever more distant from the Sage’s original intent, their elucidations of the Dao ever more obscure. How could such a vital teaching ever be abandoned, buried, or fail to flourish for generations to come?

The Emperor decreed:
*"I am indeed limited in virtue and shallow in understanding; I often feel the weight of this grand tradition, fearing I may lose the principle of the Effortless Dao."*

**Explication:** *"I"* (朕) is the Emperor’s self-reference, a convention established since **Emperor Qin Shihuang** (秦始皇) adopted the term for the sovereign. *"Limited"* (寡) means the Dao is not yet widely spread. *"Shallow"* (薄) means my virtue is not yet abundant—this is the language of self-deprecation by the Imperial decree.

Every time I reverently contemplate this scripture, I fear its profound truths may be suppressed and lost, failing to enlighten all people. Yet I inherit the Sage’s hidden Dao, occupying the supreme position among ten thousand households—how could I allow the Effortless Way’s teachings to stagnate and not flow freely, or let the Dao’s instructions grow dim and remain unseen?

*"Having successors"* refers to how the Venerable Lord’s blessings descended, illuminating the Sacred Tang Dynasty.

Moreover, even the sons of archers and smiths do not lose their noble lineage, while humble woodcutters may still fear neglecting their duties. How much more so for one whose virtue shines like Yao and Yu, whose sacred writings surpass the ancients?

I must surely refine and perfect this most profound work, ensuring its brilliance endures through the ages.

**The Emperor decreed:**
*"Whenever I hold a solemn banquet, I invariably ponder the Mysterious Pass, and whatever insights arise, I record them as annotations. This is not to establish a single school of thought, but to supplement what may have been overlooked in prior commentaries."*

**Explication:**
*"The Emperor, in moments free from state affairs, delves deeply into the Mysterious Pass, seeking silence for its resonance, exploring ultimate truths and profound mysteries to align with the subtle and elusive principles. The sacred text elucidates the empty and tranquil passages, derived from divine intuition, harmonizing with ancestral teachings. 'Annotations' (笺) mean 'tablets,' 'explanations,' and 'commentaries.' Out of humility, I do not wish to emulate Lü Buwei or Confucius in crafting a singular interpretation, but merely to address the unresolved meanings left by others."*

**The Emperor decreed:**
*"Now, I cease my pen, deferring instead to the collective wisdom of ministers, officials, and the Daoist and Buddhist communities."*

**Explication:**
*"Ceasing the pen" means the text’s arrangement is complete, its teachings fully articulated—setting down the brush and ending the writing. Just as Confucius, returning from Wei to Lu, entrusted the Ru historians to compile the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, covering the twelve rulers from Duke Huan to Duke Ai (242 years), until Duke Ai’s fourteenth year (501 BCE), when, during a spring hunt in the Great Wilds, the carriage of the Zongsun clan struck a qilin. Deeming it an omen, he ordered it buried and given to the park keepers."*

**The Master observed and said:**
*"It is a qilin—only then should it be taken.*
*The qilin and phoenix are among the Five Auspicious Spirits, omens of the Sage-King’s virtue.
*Now the qilin appears untimely, its response unfulfilled, its destiny lost—
*this is why the Sage is moved.
*The cessation of the pen at the mention of the qilin arises from this very sentiment,
*and is thus the fitting conclusion.

*Now that the commentary is complete,
*I issue this decree to promulgate the Sage’s work,
*seeking wisdom from all worthy scholars.
*The meaning of ‘ceasing the pen’ remains the same,
*yet unlike before, it is not born of lamentation,
*but rather to demonstrate the Sage’s virtue in humility—
*consulting the princes, ministers, and assistants,
*extending even to the Daoist and Buddhist traditions,
*seeking out those of broad learning and discernment,
*awaiting further elucidation of profound principles.*

**The Emperor decrees:**
*'Let those who can awaken my understanding as Bo Shang did with his mastery of poetry,
*or as Zuo Qiuming did in clarifying the *Spring and Autumn*—
*should they fulfill this expectation,
*they shall be richly rewarded.*

**Explication:**
*Bo Shang, styled Zixia, was a disciple of Confucius.
*In the *Analects* (Book of *Eight Augments*), it is recorded:
*Zixia asked the Master:
*‘Graceful smile, lovely eyes—
*why is white used to adorn it?’
*The Master replied:
*‘First the colors are applied, then the white.’
*Zixia then asked:
*‘Is it the same with ritual?’
*The scholars’ commentaries state that the first two lines appear in the *Odes* (*Wei Wind: The Stately Woman*), Chapter Two—
*a poem lamenting Min’s wife, Lady Jiang.
*The third line is lost.
*It compares Lady Jiang’s radiant beauty with her adherence to ritual,
*as in embroidery or painting—
*first the colors are arranged, then the white is used to define them,
*making each detail distinct.
*‘Embroidery’ refers to the finished design of silk, ‘painting’ to the finished design of ink.
*The Master rejoiced that Zixia, upon hearing ‘first the colors, then the white,’
*understood that beauty must be tempered by ritual.
*Thus he said:
*‘Gifted in awakening my words on poetry!’
*Now he may truly discuss the *Odes* with me.’

*Zuo Qiuming was Zuo Qiu, the author of the *Zuozhuan*.
*The Master composed the *Spring and Autumn*,
*and Qiuming transmitted it.
*Where the text was unclear, Qiuming corrected it—
*sometimes prefiguring the events, sometimes concluding their meaning.
*The *Spring and Autumn* benefited from Qiuming as a physician cures illness.
*The Emperor’s decree now awaits the gathering of talents,
*to fully expound the profound principles,
*as Confucius did with Zixia,
*or as the *Spring and Autumn* relied on Qiuming—
*welcoming frank speech, valuing only the virtuous,
*with an open heart and generous rewards.
*This shows the utmost sincerity in adopting good counsel,
*and in repaying merit with honor.*

**The Emperor decrees:**
*'As for flatterers who claim their own sageliness,
*this is not their kind.*

**Explication:**
*The flatterer who claims his own sageliness is found in the *Book of Documents* (*Yugong*):
*‘The servant praises his lord, saying, “He is a sage.”’
*When the worthy are in office, there are no flatterers.
*With the brilliant and enlightened ruling,
*how could there be such folly?
*This is not their way.*

**The Emperor decrees:**
*'Those who boast like Lü Buwei, hanging their works in the marketplace,
*are but petty schemes.
*Since I do not conceal my intent,
*all may speak freely.*

**Explication:**
*Lü Buwei, as Qin Chancellor, was granted a marquisate of ten thousand households,
*his prestige unmatched in the land.
*He gathered scholars to compile a text,
*which, upon completion, he hung in the marketplace with this proclamation:
*‘Whoever alters a single word shall receive a thousand pieces of gold.’
*It was titled the *Lüshi Chunqiu*,
*and he greatly boasted of it in his time.
*Now that the commentary is finished,
*I seek out the talented,
*opening the path for direct speech,
*and granting the grace of candor.
*Thus, the boasting of Lü Buwei is truly a petty affair.
*Later, he fell into disgrace under the First Emperor and was exiled to Shu.*

**The Emperor decrees:**
*'Let none mock my shortcomings,
*lest they weigh upon my lack of virtue.*

**Explication:**
*‘Lack of virtue’ refers to failing in the Way of *wuwei* (non-action).
*The profound teachings are now fully expounded,
*yet I still invite further discourse and reward those who contribute.
*Thus, within the nine boundaries and beyond the eight extremes,
*who would not revere the Sage’s enlightenment
*and align with the Supreme Dao?"*

**The text continues:**

*«In the following year, the Emperor then inscribed the Four Stone Stele Commentary on the Daoist Canon,*
*and erected them at the Left Street Xingtang Observatory and the Right Street Jinxian Observatory.*
*Additionally, the governors and prefects of all the prefectures*
*each established stone platforms at the auspicious sites of their respective Longxing and Kaiyuan Observatories,*
*to ensure its enduring transmission.*

*Furthermore, he sought out and composed this Explication,*
*and proclaimed it throughout the world.*

**The Imperial Edict states:**
*'The Five Thousand Daoist Teachings*
*are truly the foundation of familial instruction.*
*To govern the state, they bring forth the Way of enduring peace and prosperity,*
*and to cultivate the self, they accord with the path of eternal life.*
*They encompass all dharmas without distinction,*
*and surpass the Six Classics, standing as the foremost.*

*It is fitting to elevate *The Daoist Teachings of Virtue and Power* above the Nine Classics,*
*and place it above *The Zhou Yi* [Book of Changes].*
*Let *The Daoist Teachings*, *The Zhou Yi*, and *The Zhuangzi* be considered the Three Profound Studies,*
*and further, let *The Zhuangzi* be known as *The True Dao of Nan Hua*,
*let *The Wenzzi* be known as *The True Dao of Communion*,
*let *The Lizi* be known as *The True Dao of the Void*,
*and let *The Gengsangzi* be known as *The True Dao of the Cavernous Spirit*.*

*Conforming to the established precedents of the Confucian Classics,*
*when taking the imperial examinations, one must select the transmission of Laozi,*
*and exclude Han Fei, not allowing them to be studied together.*

*Having thus explained the origin of this Explication,*
*I now proceed to elucidate the main text.*

*The Explication is divided into two parts:*
*The first part expounds the title of the Explication,*
*and the second part interprets the doctrinal categories within.*

*Now, at the outset,*
*I first expound the title of the Explication:*
*The *Explication of the Daoist Teachings of Virtue and Power* is the title,*
*which is also the title of the Classic itself.*

*Below, I will clarify the term "Explication":*
*It signifies the interpretation and elucidation of profound meaning,*
*referring to the Classic containing myriad teachings,*
*deep and mysterious in their subtlety,*
*though commentaries and annotations may have concluded,*
*yet the text’s full meaning remains unexplored.*
*Thus, this Explication is composed to open the hidden traces,*
*to elucidate the profound mysteries,*
*and to clarify the meanings,*
*so that they may be readily understood—*
*hence the term "Explication."*

*Alternatively, "Explication" may be termed "Classification,"*
*as it systematically organizes the Classic’s teachings,*
*making them easily comprehensible.*
*Or it may be termed "Record,"*
*as it records the Classic’s principles.*
*This naming varies according to the times,*
*but all share the intent of encompassing meaning and principle.*

*"Expounding the title and its instruction" refers to*
*the act of expounding,*
*which means to clarify and resolve the Classic’s title.*

*The title is the first guide for study,*
*and all scriptures, histories, and treatises*
*first mark their primary themes,*
*so that they may be understood at a glance.*
*This is why the term "title" is used—*
*it signifies the proclamation of fundamental principles.*

*"Instruction" means doctrinal teaching,*
*and its purpose is to elucidate the text’s meaning,*
*as the Six Scripts [of Chinese writing] differ in their interpretations.*
*Generally, the origins of writing*
*are said to begin with the ancient seal script,*
*which was transmitted from the celestial realm,*
*and the Compière [Cangjie] later modeled it,*
*bringing it into human use.*

*Its fundamental categories are six:*
*1. Symbolic representation [xiàngxíng], as in the characters for sun and moon.*
*2. Indicating events [zhǐshì], as in the characters for above and below.*
*3. Phonetic borrowing [jiǎjiè], as in the character for "walk" [xíng].*
*4. Compound phonetic and semantic [xíngshēng], as in the characters for river and stream.*
*5. Composite meaning [huìyì], such as "stop" + "halberd" = "martial" [wǔ],*
*"person" + "speech" = "trustworthy" [xìn],*
*"inverted" + "upright" = "exhausted" [fá].*
*6. Derivative explanation [zhuǎnzhù], as in the characters for "old" and "left" [lǎo].*

*Since the Six Scripts differ in their meanings,*
*and characters like compound phonetic, phonetic borrowing,*
*and derivative explanation are formed through these distinctions,*
*they must be elucidated by instruction,*
*so that their meanings and principles may be clarified.*

*The *Er Ya* [Classic of Categories] has its Explications,*
*and the *Mao Shi* [Mao Commentary on the Classic of Poetry] has its Glosses,*
*which are of the same nature.*

*As for "Explication of the Imperial Composition,"*
*its meaning has already been clarified above.*

*Now, I proceed to elucidate the Explication itself,*
*which is the Imperial Composition’s own elucidation.*

*The Sage refers to Emperor Xuanzong of the Tang Dynasty,*
*who was the thirty-sixth descendant of the Supreme Daoist Laozi,*
*the third son of Emperor Ruizong,*
*and the sixth emperor of the Great Tang.*

*He bore the celestial signs of the Dragon and the Sun,*
*and his birth marked the fulfillment of auspicious omens.*
*His reign aligned with the *Taiping* [Great Peace] era,*
*and he ascended the throne in the year of *Renchen* [the auspicious cycle].*
*His mother was the illustrious Empress Dowager Zhaocheng Shunsheng of the Wu Clan.*

*Born on the fifth day of the eighth month,*
*of the year *Yǒuyǒu* [Stele] in the *East Capital* [Luoyang],*
*he was from his birth endowed with keen intelligence and wisdom.*
*As he grew,*
*he was magnanimous and kind, filial and fraternal,*
*fond of learning and skilled in composition,*
*valiant and decisive,*
*particularly adept at calligraphy,*
*and also proficient in horsemanship and archery.*

*In the third year, during the intercalary month,*
*on the day *Dīngmǎo* [Wood Sheep],*
*he was ennobled as the Duke of Chu.*
*In the second year of Tianzuo [Heavenly Assistance],*
*on the tenth month, the day *Wùxū* [Wood Hare],*
*he was appointed to the Grand Council and established his own bureaucracy,*
*with officials and attendants in place.*

*In the second year of Changshou [Long Life],*
*he was ennobled as the Duke of Linzi,*
*and resided at the Xingqing District.*

*In the second year of Jinglong [Auspicious Dragon],*
*he was dispatched to serve as the Deputy Governor of Lu Prefecture.*
*At that time,*
*the prefecture’s borders were marked by the daily rising of the sun and the moon’s double revolutions,*
*the hunting of deer and crossing of rivers,*
*the red dragon perched upon its walls,*
*the fine grains clustering in the fields,*
*the yellow dragon ascending the city,*
*the celestial caves opening spontaneously,*
*the children’s songs echoing in response,*
*the reappearance of the yellow dragon,*
*the red carp leaping from the waves,*
*the twin Li trees intertwining,*
*the divine divination stalks standing tall,*
*the auspicious vapors in the sleeping hall,*
*the purple mist at the Jar’s Mouth,*
*the hidden dragon lingering in the mountains,*
*the giant footprints left behind,*
*the breath of Xia Yu [legendary sage] manifest,*
*the golden bridge of the Sage,*
*and the blessings passed down by the divine man—*
*a total of nineteen celestial omens,*
*all recorded in the annals of history.*

*In the first year of Tang Long [Tang’s Prosperity],*
*he entered to execute the punishment of Empress Wu,*
*quelling the internal rebellion,*
*and escorted Emperor Ruizong to the throne.*

*By the first year of Kaiyuan [Opening of the Way],*
*he ascended as the Chancellor Ping Wang,*
*and ruled for forty-four years.*
*In the fourteenth year of Tianbao [Heavenly Treasure],*
*he abdicated the throne to the Crown Prince.*

*In the first year of Baoying [Treasure Response],*
*on the day *Rénchén* [Metal Tiger],*
*he passed away at the age of seventy-eight.*

*"Imperial"* [御] refers to the sovereign’s personal attendance,*
*as in "Imperial Residence" or "Imperial Heaven."*
*"Composition"* [制] means to create or establish,*
*as in "Establishing Rituals and Music."*

*Having thus expounded the title of the Explication,*
*I now proceed to the main text.*

Now I shall expound the following text, summarizing the *cishu* [commentary] in two broad sections:

1. **The overarching exposition of the Daoist intent**
2. **The opening chapter’s elucidation of the text**

Within the overarching exposition, there are two further divisions:
1. **The principle being expounded**—namely, the two characters *Dao* and *virtue*.
2. **The teaching that expounds it**—namely, the single character *jing* [Classic].

The full explanation lies within; distinctions shall be made in the subsequent chapter titles below.

As for these two characters, *Dao* and *virtue*, they encompass the origin of all things born and nurtured, the subtlety of governing the realm and cultivating the self—all are contained herein.

In antiquity, Master Ge Xuan, the Immortal Sage, spoke to Sun Quan, King of Wu:
*"The* Dao De Jing *is the utmost subtlety of Heaven and Earth. Within it are the Way of Heaven, the Way of Humanity, and the Way of the Divine. It encompasses all without exclusion, penetrates all without omission—it is fitting to follow."*

Within this doctrine’s broad intent, there are thirty-eight distinct teachings:

**First**, it teaches *wuwei* [non-action] as the principle of governance.
The *Classic* says:
*"Abandon the sage, discard wisdom—human benefit increases a hundredfold;
Abandon benevolence, discard righteousness—humanity returns to filial piety and compassion;
Abandon cleverness, discard profit—thieves and robbers vanish."*
It also says:
*"To love the people and govern the realm—how can one not practice* wuwei?"
And again:
*"I practice* wuwei*, yet the people transform spontaneously."*

**Second**, it teaches cultivating the Dao in the world.
The *Classic* says:
*"Cultivate it in the world, and its virtue becomes universal."*
It also says:
*"Hold fast to the ancient Way to govern the present."*
And again:
*"Hold to the Great Image—all under Heaven will follow."*

**Third**, it teaches governing the realm with the Dao.
The *Classic* says:
*"Govern the world with the Dao—its spirits shall not be numinous.
If its spirits are not numinous, its numinous shall not harm the people."*
It also says:
*"When the world lacks the Dao, warhorses arise in the suburbs."*

**Fourth**, it teaches *wuwei* as the method of aligning with Heaven.
The *Classic* says:
*"Humanity follows Earth; Earth follows Heaven."*
It also says:
*"The Dao constantly does nothing yet nothing remains undone.
If lords and kings could uphold this, all things would spontaneously transform."*

**Fifth**, it teaches that one should not, by virtue of exalted status, hold the world lightly.
The *Classic* says:
*"To hold the world with one’s person—how could it be entrusted to the world?
To love the world with one’s person—how could it be committed to the world?"*
It also says:
*"How can a sovereign of ten thousand chariots hold the world lightly?
Lightness leads to losing ministers; haste leads to losing the realm."*
And again:
*"The Sage does not seek greatness—thus can greatness be achieved."*

**Sixth**, it teaches not to exalt the worthy, not to treasure riches.
The *Classic* says:
*"Not to exalt the worthy—so that people do not contend;
Not to treasure acquired wealth—so that people do not become thieves."*
It also says:
*"Desire what is not desired—do not treasure what is hard to obtain."*

**Seventh**, it teaches cultivating the people with *wuwei* and *wu yu* [non-desire].
The *Classic* says:
*"Always keep the people without knowledge and without desire—so that those with knowledge dare not act.
To act in* wuwei *is to govern without fail."*
It also says:
*"I do nothing, yet the people grow rich;
I desire nothing, yet the people return to simplicity."*
And again:
*"By not desiring, one attains stillness—the world will spontaneously rectify itself."*

**Eighth**, it teaches equanimity toward all things, without clinging to fame and gain.
The *Classic* says:
*"Heaven and Earth are not benevolent—they treat all things as straw dogs.
The Sage is not benevolent—they treat the people as straw dogs."*
It also says:
*"Practice the teaching of non-action."*
And again:
*"Act without claiming merit; achieve without dwelling on it."*

**Ninth**, it teaches non-attachment and non-obstruction.
The *Classic* says:
*"To act is to ruin it; to grasp is to lose it."*
It also says:
*"Abandon excess, abandon extravagance, abandon excessiveness."*
And again:
*"The Sage has no fixed heart—taking the people’s heart as their own."*

**Tenth**, it teaches humility as the foundation.
The *Classic* says:
*"The noble takes the base as its root; the high takes the low as its foundation."*
It also says:
*"The seas and rivers become kings of the valleys because they excel in descending."*
And again:
*"To bear the filth of the state is to be called the sovereign’s guardian.
To bear the state’s misfortunes is to be called the king of the world."*
It also says:
*"Great states should act as the lowly."*
And again:
*"The good use of people lies in being lowly."*
And again:
*"Great states subjugate small states by being lowly—thus they take the small states."*
All these are spoken from the perspective of the Son of Heaven.

**Eleventh**, it teaches the feudal lords to govern rightly.
The *Classic* says:
*"Govern with rectitude."*
It also says:
*"To govern with wisdom is to harm the state; not to govern with wisdom is to bless the state."*
And again:
*"The people are difficult to govern because their cleverness is excessive—thus they are difficult to govern."*

**Thirteenth**, it teaches the feudal lords to assist the Son of Heaven with the **Dao/Way**, not to prize martial prowess.
The *Classic* says:
*"To assist the ruler with the **Dao/Way**, not to compel the world with arms."*
And again:
*"Arms made strong shall not prevail."*
And again:
*"The good use of soldiers is not to contend."*
And again:
*"Though there be armor and weapons,
There is no place to deploy them,
So that men return to using knotted cords."*
And again:
*"Weapons are instruments of ill omen;
One must not use them unless compelled."*

And again:
*"To prevail without glory."*

**Fourteenth**, it teaches the feudal lords to uphold the **Dao/Way** and transform the people.
The *Classic* says:
*"The ancients who were good at cultivating the **Dao/Way** were subtle and profound, penetrating the mysteries."*
And again:
*"Their governance was unassuming and serene,
Their people were pure and simple."*

**Fifteenth**, it teaches the feudal lords not to trifle with arms nor indulge in martial aggression.
The *Classic* says:
*"When using arms, there is a saying:
'I dare not be the aggressor but only the defender;
I dare not advance an inch but retreat a foot.'*
And again:
*"When armies clash and add to their woes,
The compassionate shall prevail."*
And again:
*"No calamity is greater than underestimating one’s enemy."*
And again:
*"The good use of soldiers is not to contend."*
And again:
*"Repel without arms,
Seize without weapons."*
And again:
*"The **virtue/power** of not contending."*

**Sixteenth**, it teaches the feudal lords not to indulge in licentious extravagance, to impose light labor and meager taxes, and to nourish the people.
The *Classic* says:
*"The people’s hunger comes from their rulers taking too much in taxes—
Thus they hunger."*
And again:
*"When men are numerous and skilled in artifices,
Strange things multiply and arise."*

**Seventeenth**, it teaches the feudal lords not to display their advantageous weapons.
The *Classic* says:
*"Fish cannot be taken from the spring—
A state’s advantageous weapons should not be displayed to the people."*
And again:
*"The ancients who were good at cultivating the **Dao/Way**
Did not seek to enlighten the people,
But rather to keep them in ignorance."*

**Eighteenth**, it teaches the three treasures of governing rightly, cultivating oneself, and honoring conduct.
The *Classic* says:
*"I have three treasures, which I hold and protect.
The first is **compassion**,
The second is **frugality**,
The third is not daring to be first in the world."*

**Nineteenth**, it teaches that cultivating oneself by bending and yielding preserves life, while upholding softness ensures victory.
The *Classic* says:
*"Bending preserves completeness."*
And again:
*"Softness overcomes hardness,
Weakness overcomes strength."*
And again:
*"The soft and weak overcome the hard and strong."*
And again:
*"The soft and weak are the disciples of life,
The hard and strong are the disciples of death."*
And again:
*"The overbearing shall not meet their end."*

**Twentieth**, it teaches that cultivating oneself requires non-action and non-desire.
The *Classic* says:
*"Ever without desire, one observes its subtleties."*
And again:
*"See no desirable thing,
So that the heart remains undisturbed."*

**Twenty-first**, it teaches that cultivating oneself means preserving the **Dao/Way**, nurturing **qi**, and completing life.
The *Classic* says:
*"Attain the utmost emptiness,
Guard steadfast stillness."*
And again:
*"Focus the **qi** to achieve softness."*
And again:
*"For the belly, not for the eyes—
Discard that, take this."*
And again:
*"Know its white, but guard its black."*
And again:
*"Know its child, but guard its mother."*
And again:
*"I alone differ from others,
And value seeking from the mother."*
And again:
*"Continuous and enduring,
Used without exhaustion."*

**Twenty-second**, it teaches that cultivating oneself means exalting goodness and discarding evil.
The *Classic* says:
*"When all under heaven know beauty as beauty,
Then ugliness is already discarded;
When all know goodness as goodness,
Then wickedness is already discarded."*
And again:
*"Ever good in saving men,
Thus there are no abandoned men.
Ever good in saving things,
Thus there are no abandoned things."*
And again:
*"The good man is the teacher of the wicked."*
And again:
*"Dull their sharpness,
Unravel their confusion."*
And again:
*"The highest goodness is like water."*

**Twenty-third**, it teaches that cultivating oneself means accumulating **virtue/power** as the foundation.
The *Classic* says:
*"The depth of containing **virtue/power**."*
And again:
*"The highest **virtue/power** is like a valley."*
And again:
*"The great man dwells in its depth,
Not in its shallowness.
Dwells in its substance,
Not in its splendor."*
And again:
*"The gentleman walks all day,
Never departing from his provisions."*

**Twenty-fourth**, it teaches that cultivating oneself means diligently striving in the **Dao/Way**.
The *Classic* says:
*"The superior man, hearing the **Dao/Way**,
Is industrious in practicing it."*
And again:
*"To be brave in not daring is to live."*

**Twenty-fifth**, it teaches that cultivating oneself means abandoning fame and function, not indulging in worldly learning.
The *Classic* says:
*"To sever learning is to have no worries."*
And again:
*"When success and fame are achieved, withdraw and retire."*
And again:
*"Success achieved, yet not retained."*
And again:
*"Daily practice of the **Dao/Way** brings daily loss."*
And again:
*"Fame and life, which is more dear?"*

**Twenty-sixth**, it teaches that cultivating oneself means not coveting worldly gain.
The *Classic* says:
*"Life and wealth, which is more abundant?
Gain and loss, which is more harmful?"*
And again:
*"The more one cherishes, the greater the expenditure;
The more one hoards, the greater the loss."*
And again:
*"Hard-to-obtain wealth
Causes men to act imprudently."*

**Twenty-seventh**, it teaches that cultivating oneself means cutting off superficial competition and not flaunting one’s abilities.
The *Classic* says:
*"Not self-displaying, one becomes clear;
Not self-praising, one achieves merit;
Not self-exalting, one endures."*
And again:
*"Great eloquence seems taciturn,
Great skill seems clumsy."*
And again:
*"Ample **virtue/power** seems insufficient."*
And again:
*"Great sound is scarce in tone."*
And again:
*"He who knows himself is clear,
He who masters himself is strong."*

**Twenty-eighth**, it teaches that cultivating oneself means not seeking honor and favor.
The *Classic* says:
*"Honor and disgrace are like sudden alarms."*
And again:
*"Rich and noble yet arrogant—
One brings ruin upon oneself."*
And again:
*"To hold and fill is not as good as to cease;
To grasp and sharpen cannot be long preserved."*

**Twenty-ninth**, it teaches that cultivating oneself means having little knowledge and speaking cautiously.
The *Classic* says:
*"To know one’s ignorance is superior,
To not know one’s knowledge is harmful."*
And again:
*"Much speech leads to exhaustion,
Better to guard the center."*
And again:
*"Light promises bring few believers,
Many changes bring many difficulties."*
And again:
*"Stop its mouth,
Close its door,
And one shall never exhaust oneself."*

**Thirtieth**, it teaches those who leave home that the **Dao/Way** opposes the worldly.
The *Classic* says:
*"The worldly are bright and clear,
I alone am like the benighted.
The worldly are sharp and discerning,
I alone am unassuming and serene."*
And again:
*"Clarity in the **Dao/Way** is like obscurity,
Advancing in the **Dao/Way** is like retreating."*

**Thirty-first**, it teaches that those who leave home to nourish the spirit shall not die.
The *Classic* says:
*"The spirit of the valley does not die,
This is called the mysterious female."*

And again:
*"Deep roots and firm foundations—
The Dao/Way of enduring life and long vision."*

And again:
*"Well-established, it cannot be uprooted;
Well-embraced, it cannot slip away."*

**Thirty-second**, it teaches that those who embody life’s essence shall attain longevity and not perish.
The *Classic* says:
*"To die yet not perish is longevity."*

**Thirty-third**, it teaches that one who cultivates the self beyond the self shall act without doing.
The *Classic* says:
*"Place the self behind, and the self shall lead;
Set the self apart, and the self shall be preserved."*

**Thirty-fourth**, it teaches that one who governs the heart with emptiness shall attain the Dao/Way.
The *Classic* says:
*"Empty the heart,
Weaken the will."*

**Thirty-fifth**, it teaches that in the world one should harmonize one’s luminosity with all things.
The *Classic* says:
*"Harmonize one’s luminosity,
Blend with the dust of the world."*
And again:
*"The Great Dao/Way flows freely—
How could it be confined to left or right?"*
And again:
*"Clad in coarse cloth yet holding jade."*

**Thirty-sixth**, it teaches that one should govern the body by severing desires and cultivating awe, caution, humility, and luminosity.
The *Classic* says:
*"The five colors blind the eyes,
The five tones deafen the ears,
The five flavors dull the palate,
Hunting and galloping drive the heart to madness."*
And again:
*"If the people do not fear great authority,
Then great authority shall arrive."*

**Thirty-seventh**, it teaches that one should gather abundance to aid scarcity.
The *Classic* says:
*"With what is sufficient, nourish what is lacking."*
And again:
*"When one gives to others, one’s own becomes more abundant;
When one gives to others, one’s own becomes greater."*

**Thirty-eighth**, it teaches that those who embody the Dao/Way and cultivate the self shall surely reap their reward.
The *Classic* says:
*"Traveling by land, one does not encounter rhinoceros or tigers;
Entering battle, one is not struck by weapons."*
And again:
*"Because one abides in the place of no-death."*

These thirty-eight distinctions are set forth to elucidate the great intent of the *Classic*.
Yet this *Classic* is vast—encompassing all without exclusion, and minute—penetrating to the finest hairs.
How could thirty-eight gates exhaust its essence?
To preserve its teachings, I broadly outline its principles,
Yet even this is but a fraction of a fraction compared to the autumn hair’s tip.

The *Records of Rites* says:
*"The Dao/Way—one cannot for an instant depart from it.
If one can depart, it is not the Dao/Way."*

If a ruler lacks virtue/power, it is like gazing without two eyes.
If a minister lacks virtue/power, it is like a chest without five viscera.
If one governs a household without virtue/power, it is like a corpse stiff with no breath.

Thus, the Dao/Way is indispensable to humanity.
If one abandons spoken teachings and rejects explicit instruction,
Mysterious beyond mystery, wondrous beyond wonder,
It can be divinely illuminated yet cannot be spoken of—
This is the ultimate of the Dao/Way.

The above summary is now complete.
Below, the text unfolds to elucidate the words.

Moral and Virtue Classic: Broad Explication of Sacred Meaning, Volume Two begins.*

*Explication of the *Dao De Jing* by Master Du Guangting of the Tang Dynasty: Clarifying the Lineage, Descent, and Era of the Venerable Lord Lao*

**Commentary:**

The Venerable Lord Lao is the inner title of the *Tai Shang Xuan Yuan Huang Di* [Supreme Primordial Emperor of the Dao]. In meaning: first, he is the one who expounds upon the teachings; second, he is the Sage who can expound upon the sacred. The Sage who can expound upon the sacred is none other than the Venerable Lord Lao. The *Tai Shang* denotes his attainment of the highest fruit and exalted position. The *Xuan Yuan Huang Di* signifies his manifest sovereignty and august name, with the inner title recorded in the *Zhen Jing* [True Classic].

Now, with regard to the Venerable Lord Lao’s titles and ranks, these are divided into thirty sections to elucidate their origins.

**First, the Originator of the Boundless Dao:**
The Venerable Lord Lao was born from the formless, arising from the causeless. He is the first of all Dao/Way and the ancestral origin of primordial *qi*. Without luminosity or form, without sound or voice, without hue or texture—profound and obscure, within him lies the essence, the essence most true, pervading all without boundary, hence he is called the Great Dao. The Great Dao’s manifestation is the Venerable Lord Lao, the parent of all transformations, the ultimate sovereign of Nature.

**Second, the Embodiment of Naturalness:**
The Great Dao and primordial *qi*, forming and transforming naturally, takes shape in a constrained manner—this is the Venerable Lord Lao. His essence is the void, his nature is spontaneity; none can compel him to be, none can compel him not to be. He neither knows how he is nor how he is not. Thus, he is called *Zi Ran Er Ran* [So of Himself, Thus of Himself]. Master Ge Xuan’s *Preface to the Secret Teachings* states: “The Venerable Lord Lao embodies *Zi Ran Er Ran*, born before the Ultimate Non-Being, arising from the causeless, traversing the beginning and end of heaven and earth—this is what cannot be named or spoken.”

**Third, the Perceiver of the True Form:**
The Venerable Lord Lao is the ultimate essence of the non-born, the most refined spirit of the manifest. Once, within the emptiness, he condensed *qi* and solidified the true essence, taking constrained form though his body is vast beyond measure, his features complete, the sovereign of Nature. Above, none can be his equal; below, none can follow his footsteps. Dwelling in the void, he radiates like the light of the sun and moon.

**Fourth, the Responder to the Law’s Titles:**
The Venerable Lord Lao, rising from the emptiness, transforming naturally, with boundless wisdom and complete virtue, his form unmeasurable, his name limitless. In heaven, he is the master of all heavens; among the Sages, he is the lord of all Sages; among the Immortals, he is the total of all Immortals; in the True, he is the first of all True; among the stars, he is the Heavenly Sovereign Emperor; in teaching, he is the *Tai Shang Lao Jun* [Supreme Venerable Lord Lao]. Sometimes he bears a thousand and two hundred titles; sometimes he reveals a hundred and eighty names. He is called the Father of the Non-Doing, the Mother of All Things, harmonizing with the Great Dao, establishing the roots of heaven and earth. His vast and boundless essence cannot be named. To summarize: there are ten titles bestowed upon him after his descent, by the ten-directional Sages in the void. These are detailed in the section on his descent.

**Fifth, the Initiator of the Master-Disciple Lineage:**
When the Venerable Lord Lao was about to reveal the Great Teaching and spread its transformation across all directions, he declared: “The Dao cannot lack a revered master, the teaching cannot lack a宗主 [*zong zhu*, ‘lineage lord’].” Thus, he became a disciple of the *Tai Shang Yu Chen Da Dao Jun* [Supreme Morning Great Dao Lord]. The Great Dao Lord is the disciple of the *Yuan Shi Tian Zun* [Primordial Beginning Heavenly Sovereign], who discerns the foundation of the Dao and penetrates its origin, born before countless eons, the ancestral *qi* of the Dao. The Heavenly Sovereign is the master of five billion heavens, the lord of countless Sages, also born before countless eons, the root foundation of the Dao’s *qi*.

Thus, the Great Dao Lord is the Venerable Lord Lao’s master, and the Heavenly Sovereign is the master of the Great Dao Lord. With the two Sages established, he is called the Venerable Lord Lao—*lao* for his abiding in longevity, *jun* for his lordship over the lineage. Since the Venerable Lord Lao, above and below the heavens, traverses transformations without end, born before countless eons and enduring beyond them, revered by all emperors and followed by all masters, he is thus granted the title *Tai Shang Lao Jun* [Supreme Venerable Lord Lao]. The three Sages, mastering one another, thereby establish the foundation of teaching’s hierarchy.

Zhuangzi says: *“My master, my master! He nourishes all things yet does not deem it virtue, benefits countless ages yet does not deem it benevolence, surpasses the ancient sages yet does not deem himself old, encompasses heaven and earth, carves all forms yet does not deem it skillful, precedes the Supreme Ultimate yet does not deem himself exalted, dwells beneath the six extremes yet does not deem himself profound, is born before heaven and earth yet does not deem himself eternal—this is he!”*

**Sixth, the Traverser of Eons:**
The Venerable Lord Lao was born before all things, arising before the formless. He has traversed countless eons, his existence most ancient. The *effort* [劫, *jie*] is the name for the formation and destruction of heaven and earth, the measure of the exhaustion of yin and yang. When yang is exhausted, yin is born—thus, it is the Great Water. When yin is exhausted, yang is born—thus, it is the Great Fire. Yang reaches its peak at nine, hence it is called *Yang Jiu* [Nine Yang]. Yin reaches its peak at six, hence it is called *Bai Liu* [Six Hundred]. The smallest eon is three thousand three hundred years; the next is nine thousand nine hundred years; the greatest is the *Jiu Jiu Da Shu* [Ninety-Nine Great Number], eighty-one million years, marking the end of an eon. The Venerable Lord Lao’s longevity and transformations traverse these eons beyond count.

The *Western Ascension Scripture* states: *“Since the beginning of this past age, the changes have been as numerous as grains of sand. When the eons shift, the records are renewed—only then does one realize the depth of his toil.”*

**Seventh, the Creator of Heaven and Earth:**
The Venerable Lord Lao is the root foundation of heaven and earth; all things originate from him and are formed. Thus, he stands upon the path of non-haste, wanders in the field of no-dependence, ascends and descends in the void, riding yin and yang to refine and transform. He distributes the pure and turbid, opens the expanse of heaven and earth, suspends the Three Luminaries [日月星, *ri yue xing*] and nourishes all beings. Heaven and earth rely upon him for their distinction, the sun and moon move by his decree, the four seasons gain from him their succession, the five phases [五行, *wu xing*] derive from him their generation. Thus, at the beginning of the nine trillion nine hundred trillion nine hundred trillion nine hundred trillion nine hundred billion years of *qi*, he moves the *Xuan Yuan Shi* [Primordial Beginning Three *qi*] to form heaven, above establishing the Three Pure Ones and Three Realms.

At the outset, the *Shi* *qi* becomes the **Jade Purity Realm**, the *Yuan* *qi* the **Upper Purity Realm**, and the *Xuan* *qi* the **Supreme Purity Realm**.

Again, from the three Purity *qi*, each generates three *qi* and three Realms, together forming nine *qi* to constitute the **Nine Heavens**:
1. **Yùdān Wúliàng Heaven** (Idle Solitude Boundless Heaven),
2. **Shàngshàng Chánshàn Wúliàngshòu Heaven** (Supreme Meditative Bliss Boundless Longevity Heaven),
3. **Fánjiān Xūyán Heaven** (Brahmanic Monitor Mustard-Field Heaven),
4. **Jìrán Dōushù Heaven** (Silent Tranquility Enclosure Heaven),
5. **Bōluónímì Bùjiāolè Heaven** (Brahma’s Secret Non-Arrogant Bliss Heaven),
6. **Dòngyuán Huàyīngshēng Heaven** (Void-Origin Transforming Responsive-Sound Heaven),
7. **Línghuà Fánfǔ Heaven** (Spiritual Transformation Brahmanic Auxiliary Heaven),
8. **Gāoxū Qīngmíng Heaven** (Lofty Void Luminous Heaven),
9. **Wúxiǎng Wújié Wù’ài Heaven** (Non-Conceptual Non-Knot Non-Love Heaven).

Each of these Nine Heavens generates three *qi*, each *qi* forming one Heaven, totaling **Twenty-Seven Heavens**. Together, these Nine Heavens constitute **Thirty-Six Heavens**.

Below them, the **Four Classes and Three Realms** ascend to the utmost of the Three Purity Realms.

The first six Heavens below are the **Realm of Desire**:
1. **Tàihuáng Heaven** (Great Yellow Heaven),
2. **Tàimíng Heaven** (Great Bright Heaven),
3. **Qīngmíng Heaven** (Clear Bright Heaven),
4. **Xuántāi Heaven** (Mysterious Embryo Heaven),
5. **Yuánmíng Heaven** (Primordial Bright Heaven),
6. **Qīyào Heaven** (Seven Luminaries Heaven).

Next, the **Eighteen Heavens of the Realm of Form**:
1. **Xūwú Heaven** (Voidless Heaven),
2. **Tàijí Heaven** (Supreme Pole Heaven),
3. **Chìmíng Heaven** (Crimson Bright Heaven),
4. **Gōnghuá Heaven** (Resplendent Splendor Heaven),
5. **Yàomíng Heaven** (Luminous Brilliance Heaven),
6. **Huángjiā Heaven** (Royal Horn Heaven),
7. **Xūmíng Heaven** (Void-Bright Heaven),
8. **Duānjìng Heaven** (Serene Tranquility Heaven),
9. **Xuánmíng Heaven** (Mysterious Bright Heaven),
10. **Jíyáo Heaven** (Extreme Jade Heaven),
11. **Yuánzǎi Heaven** (Primordial Load Heaven),
12. **Tài’ān Heaven** (Great Tranquility Heaven),
13. **Jífēng Heaven** (Extreme Wind Heaven),
14. **Shǐhuáng Heaven** (First Sovereign Heaven),
15. **Tàihuáng Heaven** (Great Yellow Heaven),
16. **Wúsī Heaven** (Non-Thought Heaven),
17. **Shàngxiéruǎnlè Heaven** (Upper Exalted Softness Bliss Heaven),
18. **Wújí Tánshì Heaven** (Boundless Meditation Heaven).

Next, the **Four Heavens of the Realm of Formlessness**:
1. **Xiāngdù Heaven** (Lofty Measure Heaven),
2. **Yuándòng Heaven** (Primordial Cavern Heaven),
3. **Miǎochéng Heaven** (Wondrous Completion Heaven),
4. **Jìnshàng Heaven** (Forbidden Upper Heaven).

These **Twenty-Eight Heavens** are called the **Three Realms**.

Where the eons unfold and yin-yang refine, where *qi* reaches its limits and human lifespans are measured, the first, **Tàihuánghuángzēng Heaven**, grants mortals a lifespan of **nine hundred million years**. Each successive Heaven adds a doubling of years, so across the Twenty-Eight Heavens, the maximum lifespan reaches **one trillion two hundred seventy-nine thousand seven hundred seventy-five million five thousand two hundred years**.

Descending to where the sun and moon intersect, there are **four thousand four hundred forty-four billion four hundred forty-four billion *qi***, each *qi* spanning **three thousand *li***.

Above these, there are four more Heavens, called the **Four Kinds of Human Heavens**:
1. **Chángróng Heaven** (Ever-Melting Heaven),
2. **Yùlóng Heaven** (Jade Dragon Heaven),
3. **Fándù Heaven** (Brahmanic Measure Heaven),
4. **Jiáyù Heaven** (Jade Jade Heaven).

These Four Heavens transcend the Three Realms, neither generating nor perishing, without measure of years or ruin by calamity. At the interchange of great eons, their disasters do not reach them.

The lesser Heavens and Earths below follow the eons in their ruin; when the eons reopen, the chaos redivides, and the people of these Heavens, bearing the command of the **Most High**, descend to transform the mortal world, teaching the age and practicing the Dao—just as at the beginning of this eon, the **Three Sovereigns** succeeded in governance.

Above these, there are three more Heavens, the **Three Purity Realms**:
1. **Dàchì Heaven** (Great Vermilion Heaven),
2. **Yǔyú Heaven** (Yu’s Remnant Heaven),
3. **Qīngwēi Heaven** (Pure Mists Heaven).

The highest is the **Dàluó Heaven** (Great Net Heaven), encompassing all Heavens, supremely exalted without peer. The **Playful Metropolis of Jade** is stationed at its summit, where the **Three Venerables** reside, and all saints assemble in reverence—this is the domain of the **Ultimate Dao**, the root of transformation.

Having divided the Heavens, the residual yin *qi* of the Thirty-Six Heavens descends to form the **Thirty-Six Earths**. Each Heaven establishes a **Heavenly Sovereign**, each Earth a **Terrene Emperor**, and the **Seventy-Two Lords** all receive their commands from the **Old Lord**.

The domains of these Heavens vary in number by **five hundred million**, all generated by the *qi* of the Thirty-Six Heavens. Within the Earth are **Thirty-Six Cavern Heavens**, corresponding to those above. The sun and moon refine their essence, their luminous radiance permeating between them, so that celestial patterns and terrestrial geography, the **Six Celestial Stems and Five Phases**, the transformations of yin and yang—all are wrought by the **Old Lord’s** subtle operations, generated and perfected, moved and transformed by them.

Thus it is said: The **Dao** is the **Primordial Source** of all things; Heaven attains clarity through it, Earth attains tranquility, beings attain birth, spirits attain numinousness, the seas and mountains attain stability, kings attain the Great Peace, Daoists attain immortality, and the withered attain rebirth.

The **Most High Old Lord** is the **Master of Yin-Yang**, the **Sovereign of All Spirits**, the **Parent of Primordial *Qi***, the **Root of Heaven and Earth**, the **Teacher of the Ancient Kings**, and the **Soul of All Beings**. He molds the void, transforms and responds to things, girds the Eight Extremes, suspends the Earth and upholds the Heaven, rides the sun and moon, drives the stars, breathes the Six Celestial Stems, commands the Heavenly Poles, shifts the Four Seasons, adjusts cold and warmth, summons winds and rains, drums the thunderclouds, distinguishes the Mysterious Yellow, reckons the void and fullness—his **subordinate and superior, father and son, all observe propriety and righteousness**.

Thus, though yin-yang be vast and Heaven and Earth great, without the **Dao’s *qi** nurturing them and the **Great Sage** moving them, there would be no generation or transformation, no establishment or completion.

**Eighth: The Ascension to Sovereign Rule.**
The **Old Lord’s** great sagehood—generating and transforming Heaven and Earth, moving and nurturing all things—how could it lack rank or name? Yet above him stands the **Primordial Beginning’s** exaltation, below him the **Dao Sovereign’s** sanctity. The **Old Lord** ranks beneath the **Dao Sovereign**, yet through his transformations and deeds, having moved the three *qi* to circulate and the myriad Heavens to spread, all laws manifesting, his **mysterious merit** accomplished, he ascends to certify the **Ultimate Dao’s** fruit, residing in the **Three Venerables’** station. He inherits the **Most High’s** task, becoming the **Law King’s** exaltation, governing all saints above, regulating all true ones within, commanding all immortals below, and thus overseeing the **Thirty-Six Heavens**, the **Thirty-Six Earths**, the **Seventy-Two Lords**, the stars, sun, and moon, the mountains and rivers, all spirits—all transformations of yin and yang, all divine manifestations—he rules over **Heaven above and below, Earth above and below, the Five Hundred Million Heavenly Realms**, beings with and without sentience, with and without cognition, with and without form—all are under the **Most High Old Lord’s** dominion.

「Thus, he eternally abides within the **Tàiqīng** domain in the **Tàijí** Palace, the **Dāntái** Purple Portal, and the **Yùtáng** Jade Hall, where the **Three Great Immortals**, the **Nine Most High Emperors**, the **Twenty-Seven Heavenly Lords**, the **Eighty-One Coasts and Ministers**, the **Thousand-Two-Hundred Immortal Officials**, the **Twenty-Four-Thousand Spirit Attendants**, the **Seventy-Thousand Immortal Boys and Jade Girls**, and the **Five-Hundred-Million Heavenly Soldiers and Divine Kings**, along with the **Lúowèi** Cloud Street, **giant qióng** (虬) serpents, **lions**, **golden-winged peacocks**, **phoenixes**, **spiritual beasts**, **celestial horses**, and **qílín** (麒麟), all stand guard at his sides.

At times, the **Old Lord** also ascends to the **Yuánshǐ** (元始) court, submitting petitions on **sin and fortune**, paying homage to the **Yùchén** (玉宸), overseeing the **Nine Palaces**, and regulating the records of **birth and death in the Three Realms**. All divine officials and ghostly ministers—those who inspect and investigate, the **immortal officials of the spirit caves**, and those who dispense **blessings and sustenance**—whether in the depths or the hidden, all reverently submit to his authority.

Sometimes, he descends to govern the **Nine Heavens**, residing in the **Tàiwēi** (太微) and **Gōuchén** (勾陈) Six Stars as the **Heavenly Sovereign Great Emperor**, wielding the **Yào Pò** (曜魄) Gem of Radiance. He holds the **Three Messengers**, the **Six Guards**, and the **Nine Pivotal Mechanisms**, overseeing the **One-Five-Twenty-Thousand** (万一千五百二十) beings. He wields the **immortal talismans**, commanding the **divine humans, true humans, immortals, sages, virtuous ones, and wayfarers**, all bound under his rule.

One sees the **Hundred-Billion Heavenly Kings** bowing in homage before him, seeking counsel on matters of **wind, rain, drought, flood, abundance, scarcity, fortune, misfortune, life, death, good, and evil**. He roams the **Ten-Thousand Worlds**, transforming through the **mysterious Dao**. In his essence, he remains **Most High and Unchanging**, forever dwelling in the **Tàiqīng** Palace.

**Ninth**, he responds to circumstances and attends to feelings.
The **Old Lord** is **Ultimate and Sacred**, overseeing all transformations. His manifestations appear according to the needs of each realm, and his **virtue descends** to adapt his form. From the beginning of **countless kalpas** to the dawn of **Húndùn** (混沌), through the **Xī-Wā** (羲娲) **Eighteen Dynasties**, the **Three Eons**, the **Fifty-Eight Administrations**, and the **One-Hundred-Eighty-Nine Generations**, he serves as **National Teacher** in each age. In the era of **Shénnóng** (神农), he sometimes becomes **National Sovereign**, sometimes **Teacher Lord**, sometimes **Guest and Friend**, or even a **human subject**, bearing titles such as **Yùhuá** (郁华) or **Lùtú** (录图), and through **moral precepts and profound teachings**, he enlightens all.

What is called **"responding to all without discrimination"** is the **Dao**; what is called **"attending to feelings and circumstances"** is **Sainthood**. He always applies **scriptures, diagrams, and precepts** to transform all beings, adapting his form to their needs—boundless and infinite. Yet the **Old Lord’s** essence remains **perfect, still, and without action**, forever dwelling in the **Tàiqīng** Palace.

**Tenth**, he promulgates the **Upper Pure Dao**.
In the time of the **Upper Three Sovereigns**, when humanity was still **simple and unrefined**, the **Old Lord** took the title **Xuánzhōng** (玄中) **Way Master** in the **Long Hàn** (龙汉) year. He taught the **Upper Pure Sacred Doctrine’s** **Twelve Great Vehicles**, enlightening both **humans and heavens**.

**Eleventh**, he transmits the **Soul Treasure**.
In the time of the **Middle Three Sovereigns**, the **Old Lord** bore the title **Yǒugǔ** (有古) **Mr. Ancient** in the **Chìmíng** (赤明) year. He descended with the **Soul Treasure True Scripture’s** **Twelve Middle Vehicles**, transforming all and saving **myriad people**.

**Twelfth**, he issues the **Cave Spirit Scripture**.
In the time of the **Lower Three Sovereigns**, when human hearts were **simple yet scattered**, the **Old Lord** took the title **Jīnquè** (金阙) **Imperial Lord** in the **Kāihuáng** (开皇) year. He promulgated the **Cave Spirit Scripture’s** **Twelve Minor Vehicles**, enlightening all **ten-thousand kinds**.

**Thirteenth**, he reveals the **Primordial Yang Scripture**.
In the time of **Fúxī** (伏羲), when people had grown **corrupt yet lacked laws**, the **Old Lord** assumed the title **Yùhuá Zǐ** (郁华子) in the **Qīngzhuó** (清浊) year. He descended as a **teacher**, expounding the **Primordial Yang Scripture** and instructing **Fúxī** to draw the **Eight Trigrams**, thereby **communicating the virtue of the divine** and **categorizing the emotions of all things**. He looked upward to **observe the patterns in Heaven**, and downward to **take lessons from Earth**, establishing **marriage rites** and **ordering human relationships**.

**Fourteenth**, he demonstrates the **Good Life**.
In the time of **Shénnóng**, when people ate **raw flesh and drank blood**, the **Old Lord** bore the title **Dàchéng Zǐ** (大成子) in the **Qīnghàn** (清汉) year. He descended as a **teacher**, expounding the **Primordial Essence Scripture** and teaching the **Dao of transformation and nurturing**. He spread **hundred grains** to replace **cooking and slaughtering**, and harmonized **hundred medicines** to heal **hundred ailments**. He showed that **tasting mulberry yields rice**, **tasting willow yields grain**, **tasting elm yields millet**, **tasting locust tree yields beans**, **tasting peach yields small wheat**, **tasting apricot yields large wheat**, and **tasting hemp yields hemp fiber**. With the **five grains** flourishing, **beasts and birds** were spared from harm, and killing ceased—thus **lengthening goodness and eliminating evil**, **preserving life and ensuring well-being**. By not consuming **blood and flesh**, people were free from **sickness and suffering**; by the **five grains nourishing their nature**, people were free from **past karma**. His benefits to humanity were vast.

**Fifteenth**, he instructs in **Pottery and Crafting**.
In the time of **Zhùróng** (祝融), when people ate **raw and cold food**, unaware of **cooked meals**, the **Old Lord** took the title **Guǎngshòu Zǐ** (广寿子) in the **Tiānhàn** (天汉) year. He descended as a **teacher**, expounding the **Pressing and Melting Scripture to Nurture Essence** and instructing in **pottery and crafting vessels**, thereby **transforming raw and cold food**, and **prolonging human life**.

**Sixteenth**, he establishes **Laws and Ordinances**.
From the time of the **Lower Three Sovereigns** onward, until **Fúxī**, there were no **rituals or laws**, and **birds and beasts** lived in the same groups. The **Old Lord**, through the **Dao**, gradually **awakened their hearts**, distinguishing **forms and flavors**, aligning with the **Five Phases**, and widely applying **scriptures and methods**, guiding and transforming **myriad people**.

**Seventeenth**, he creates **Forms and Utensils**.
After **Fúxī**, the **Old Lord** demonstrated **worldly methods**, establishing **ritual music** to **order hierarchy**, crafting **garments and insignia** to **distinguish nobility and commonality**, building **palaces and dwellings** to **replace nests and dens**, creating **boats and carriages** to **traverse impassable terrain**, setting up **coffins and burial chambers** to **replace wrapping in cloth and kindling**, forging **bows and arrows** to **intimidate the disobedient**, instituting **legal punishments** to **deter violence**, and devising **writing and contracts** to **replace knotted cords**. He taught **riding oxen and horses**, **pulling heavy loads**, and **midday markets**—where **trade concluded and people returned home**—though **plowing, grinding, and double-door locks** were not yet known. All these teachings were imparted to **worldly rulers**, transforming **all things** in their time.

**Eighteenth**, he expounds the **Dao on Kōngtóng Mountain**.
In the time of **Huángdì** (黄帝), the **Old Lord** was known as **Guǎngchéng Zǐ** (广成子), dwelling on **Kōngtóng Mountain**. **Huángdì** visited him and took him as **teacher**, receiving the **Scripture of Dao Precepts**. He was taught the **method of governing the body**. **Huángdì** practiced it, and in broad daylight ascended to **Heaven**.

**Nineteenth**, in the time of **Zhuànxū** (颛顼), the Old Lord descended as teacher, bearing the name **Chìjīng Zǐ** (赤精子), dwelling on **Héngshān**. He imparted to the emperor the *Scripture of Subtle Speech* (《微言经》), teaching the **Dao of loyalty and compliance**.

**Twentieth**, the **Dao manifested at the riverside**. In the time of **Yù** (帝舜), the Old Lord descended as teacher, bearing the name **Lùtú Zǐ** (录图子), dwelling by the riverside. He imparted to the emperor the *Yellow Court Scripture* (《黄庭经》), teaching the **Dao of purity and harmony**.

**Twenty-first**, the **Dao proclaimed its truth on Gūshè**. In the time of **Emperor Yáo** (唐尧), the Old Lord descended as teacher, bearing the name **Wùchéng Zǐ** (务成子), dwelling on **Gūshè Mountain**. He imparted to the emperor the *Scripture of Political Separation and Union* (《政事离合经》), teaching the **Dao of frugality and caution**.

**Twenty-second**, the **transmission of Dao and virtue**. In the time of **Emperor Shùn** (帝舜), the Old Lord descended as teacher, bearing the name **Yǐnshòu Zǐ** (尹寿子), dwelling at **Héyáng**. He imparted to Shùn the *Scripture of Dao and Virtue* (《道德经》), expounding the **Dao of filial piety and fraternal duty**. These two scriptures originated from this point.

**Twenty-third**, the **teaching of water regulation**. In the time of **Xià Yǔ** (夏禹), the Old Lord descended as teacher, bearing the name **Zhēnxíng Zǐ** (真行子), dwelling on **Shāngshān**. He imparted to Yǔ the *Scripture of Virtuous Precepts* (《戒德经》), teaching the **Dao of diligence and frugality**. He also transmitted the **Five Sacred Talismans of Lingbao**, summoning spirits and ghosts, dredging the Nine Rivers, connecting the Yellow River and the sea, and opening the Hundred Streams.

**Twenty-fourth**, the **recitation of longevity**. In the time of **Yīn Tāng** (殷汤), the Old Lord descended as teacher, bearing the name **Xīzé Zǐ** (锡则子), dwelling on **Zhènshān**. He imparted the *Scripture of Longevity* (《长生经》), teaching the **Dao of reverence and benevolence**.

**Twenty-fifth**, the **conception of divine wisdom**. The Old Lord, pitying the decay of the age, wished to return in divine form and be reborn. In the seventeenth year of **Yángjiǎ** (阳甲), the eighteenth king of Yīn, in a year of **Gēngshēn**, he took conception in the **Playful Mystic Jade Maiden**. From this gate, five branches emerged:

1. The **Great Dao manifested in transformation**, taking human form, embodying the five colors of solar essence to illuminate **yang virtue**.
2. He rode the **Nine Dragons’ Chariot**, condensing and transforming, his five-colored essence merging with the **Playful Mystic Jade Maiden**, thus revealing the **Nine Dragons’ yang essence**.
3. He dwelled in the womb, nurturing wisdom, differing from the common way. After **eighty-one years**, completing the **ninefold number of the Great Sun**, he was born.
4. After the **Playful Mystic Jade Maiden** conceived through a divine dream, her beauty increased, her spirit serene, and for over eighty years, she rejoiced without compare, demonstrating the **divine traces of the Sage’s descent**.
5. The **Playful Mystic Jade Maiden’s** dwelling was ever harmonious in the four seasons, the six *qì* balanced—no winter cold, no summer heat. Auspicious light filled the chamber, sacred winds swept the courtyard, evils did not approach, and all spirits guarded unseen. For eighty-one years, time passed unnoticed, until in the ninth year of **Wǔdīng** (武丁), the twenty-second king of Yīn, in a year of **Gēngchén**, he was born.

**Twenty-sixth**, the **manifestation of his birth**. From this gate, seventeen further divisions arise:

1. The Old Lord’s birth surpassed all mortal kind. Though conceived by the **Holy Mother**, he was born by **splitting her left armpit**.
2. Upon birth, he walked nine steps, each step bearing a lotus. The earth opened beneath him, displaying his divine marvel.
3. At his birth, the **Sun Child shone radiant**, the **Moon Consort scattered flowers**, the **Seven Stars aligned their light**, auspicious clouds sheltered him, the **Four Spirits guarded**, and the **Jade Maiden bore him**. The Holy Mother, reaching for a **plum tree**, suddenly gave birth.
4. At his birth, the **Nine Dragons spewed water** to bathe his sacred form. Where the dragons emerged, **nine wells** formed. These still exist today in **Zhēn Yuán County’s** (真源县) **Tàiqīng Palace** in **Bózhōu**.
5. After birth, he walked nine steps, his left hand pointing to Heaven, his right to Earth, declaring: *"Above Heaven, below Earth, I alone am sovereign."* The sufferings of the age were unworthy of mention.
6. The Old Lord descended to birth, for he saw the age’s **crude simplicity scattered**, the **Great Dao unwalked**, and thus took mortal form to **save the world**.
7. Knowing the people were confused and the true path hard to proclaim, at his birth he displayed **auspicious omens** to awaken faith and understanding.
8. To reveal the **Mystic Dao**, he demonstrated **elixir refinement**, encouraging practice. Today, **Bózhōu Palace** holds the **Elixir-Refining Well** and the **Elixir-Refining Cypress**.
9. The Old Lord taught that **inner and outer cultivation** must both be practiced—refining the **Golden Elixir** and nurturing **true *qì***. Today, the **Hall of Emptiness and Nothingness** in **Bózhōu Palace** is where *qì* was cultivated.
10. The Old Lord made clear that mastering this **Mystic Dao** would surely lead to Heaven. He demonstrated this by **ascending lightly upon completion**. Today, the **Deer-Track Cypress** in **Bózhōu Palace** marks where he rode the **White Deer** to ascend. The tree remains.
11. The Old Lord’s birth year was the **ninth year of Wǔdīng (Gēngchén)**, the **fifteenth day of the second month**. Today, it is clarified that in the **Yīn and Zhōu eras**, the **month of *Zǐ* was the year’s beginning**, so the second month corresponds to the **modern twelfth month (*Chǒu*)**.
12. His birthplace was in the ancient **region of Chǔ**, in **Kǔ County**, later named **Lèxiāng** after its walls, and **Qǔrénlǐ** after its waters, beside **Língxī Stream** to the west of the **Nine Wells**. Originally **Kǔ County**, it became **Gǔyáng County** under the **Hàn and Wèi dynasties**. In **Buyan’s first year**, it was renamed **Zhēn Yuán County**.

The **Zhōnghé Era’s second year**, it was elevated to **Chìxiàn County**.

**13.** After the Old Lord’s birth, within nine days, his stature grew to nine *chǐ*, with seventy-two auspicious marks (*xiāng*) and eighty-one virtues (*hǎo*). He walked with five strides to ten paces, possessed beautiful arched brows and a square mouth, dual pillars and triple leaks, a sun-like horn and moon-like eyes—endowed with the great sage’s features.

**14.** The Holy Mother, **Xuānmiao Yùnǚ**, after the Old Lord’s birth, ascended to heaven in the **Bājǐng Yùyú**, attended by celestial hosts, in broad daylight. The **Great Tang** posthumously honored her as **Xiāntiān Tàihòu**. Today, there exists a palace in **Zhēn Yuán County**, north of **Tàiqīng Palace**, and another on **Lóuguān Shèngtiān Tái**.

**15.** After the Old Lord’s ascension, successive emperors revered his true traces. The **Hàn Emperor Huán** and **Sū Emperor Wén** both grandly restored his temples, commanding literati to carve steles to commemorate his **virtue/power**. Thus, the **Biān Shào Stele** of Hàn and the **Xuē Dàohéng Stele** of Sū endure to this day.

**16.** In the year the **Holy Tang** received its mandate, the ancient residence’s withered cypress revived in **Bózhōu**, signifying the prosperity of descendants and boundless blessings. The tree remains, known as the **Revival Cypress**.

**17.** In **Zhēn Yuán’s** ancestral village, divine omens repeatedly descended: sweet dew fell suddenly, auspicious clouds dispersed, or the true form manifested to dispel calamity; mist congealed in the sky to guard the halls; divine birds bore arrows, or sudden snowflakes flew; a spirit dragon leapt within the **Nine Wells**, or sacred script appeared upon the three cypresses. These marvels were recorded in the annals.

During the **Hàn Emperor Huán’s** reign, he dreamed of the Old Lord and, upon building the shrine, saw auspicious clouds hovering above. In the **Sū Emperor Wén’s** **Kāihuáng fifth year**, auspicious clouds and a white deer appeared in the temple courtyard, prompting imperial restoration of the halls. In **Wǔdé’s third year**, the withered cypress revived, and auspicious clouds appeared above it. In **Shàngyuán’s first year**, the phrase **"Buānyuán Hénlì Zhen"** appeared in crimson on the cypress branches, clearly layered. In **Tàijí’s first year**, auspicious clouds manifested above. In **Tiānbǎo’s seventh year**, a **phoenix** gathered upon the **Xūwú Hall**. In **Bǎoyìng’s first year**, a purple cloud connected to heaven, its divine light shining at night. The next day, a dragon appeared over the **Nine Wells**. In **Dàlì’s third year**, auspicious clouds appeared over the palace, and sweet dew descended upon the cypress. In **Huìchāng’s second year**, sweet dew fell upon the courtyard trees. In **Xiàntōng’s tenth year**, the rebel **Páng Xún** of **Xúzhōu** sought to seize **Tàiqīng Palace** with his forces, but the Old Lord manifested—black qi spread across the valley, and the rebels lost their way, vanquished that day.

Later, during the **Zhōnghé and Guāngmíng eras**, **Huáng Cháo** besieged the palace, setting it ablaze. Dark clouds rose, rain extinguished the fire, and the rebels scattered in defeat. Elsewhere, rebels surrounded **Bózhōu** with blades, but black qi and heavy snow froze them to death, lifting the siege. Again, **Huáng Cháo’s** remnants attacked, but a divine bird circled the city bearing arrows, and black qi emerged from the palace. The rebels fled in terror, the siege lifted.

In the **Zhōnghé Era’s second year**, the official **Pán Chóu** reported that since **Huáng Cháo’s** march into **Guānzhōu**, eighteen times had rebels besieged the palace or encircled the county—each time met with portents, causing the rebels to scatter. Near and far, households fled to the palace for refuge, all emerging unharmed. He petitioned to relocate the county to the palace grounds, but the edict was denied, and it was instead elevated to **Chìxiàn County**.

In the **Guāngqǐ Era’s first year, seventh month**, five clouds formed a canopy over the **Nine Dragon Well**, rising a thousand *zhàng* in height—such manifestations occurred three times. Illustrations were sent from **Biànzhōu** and recorded in the imperial annals.

**Chapter Twenty-Seventh: Declaring the Sacred Appellation**

The **Venerable Lord’s** jade embryo bore wisdom, and at the eighty-first year of his sacred birth, he was born with white hair. The **Sage Mother** established his name to reveal this to the world.

Within this gate, five divisions are made:

1. **The Sage’s descent into the world, differing from the common.** The Sage Mother wished to call him *Old* (老), yet he was newly born, so she wished to call him *Child* (子). Since he was already aged, she combined both terms, thus establishing the name **Laozi**.

2. **The Dao opposes convention.** *Old* refers to advanced years, *Child* to infancy. Mortals age after youth, but the Venerable Lord was aged before youth—this to show the return to the origin after tracing the path.

3. **The *Old* denotes examination of all sages, the *Child* signifies the proliferation of all things.** Thus, the Venerable Lord is the parent of all things and the ancestral progenitor of all sages, bearing the name of examination and proliferation, as **Laozi**.

The two characters *Laozi* arose at this time, but the title **Laojun** predates countless eons—it was not established solely in this age.

4. **The Sage’s name reverses the end to return to the beginning.** *Old* is the end, *Child* the beginning. Mortals begin before ending, but the Venerable Lord ends before beginning, urging the world to cultivate the Dao, returning to infancy from old age—thus the name **Laozi**.

5. **Hiding one’s traces and blending with the world, following the path of the age.** The Venerable Lord, born with white hair, was thus named **Laozi**—a common male appellation, like **Kongzi, Mengzi, Zhuangzi, Liezi**, who took their surnames as names. **Laozi, Heguanzzi, Baopuzzi, Huainanzi** took names based on their deeds. The *Sequence of Precepts* states:

*"The name **Laozi** originated in countless eons past, obscure and distant beyond measure. It was not because he aged at birth that he was named **Laozi**, but because he existed eons before, thus bearing the name **Laozi**.*
