*He was borne by the divine Li Mother, emerging from her left armpit, already radiant, and thus named **Laozi**. The name **Laozi** arose from the Mysterious, before Heaven and Earth, without the limits of aging. Hence, he is called **Laozi**—as attested in the *Sequence of Precepts*."*

Now examining all accounts, it is clear that the name **Laozi** was not established solely because of his birth. Throughout countless eons, he manifested teachings, embodied form, and perpetually appeared in aged guise—thus the name **Laozi**.

---

**Chapter Twenty-Eighth: Clarifying the Lineage**

The *Laozi Original Record* and various histories all state that he was born beneath a **plum tree**, and he pointed to the tree, declaring it his surname—this reasoning is correct.

According to the *Great Enunciation Jade Register of the Tang Dynasty*, he descended from **Zhuānxū**, who begot **Dàyè**, who begot **Wā**, who married a daughter of the **Qiáo clan**, conceiving **Jiǔliáo** through the moon’s light piercing **Mǎo**. **Jiǔliáo** begot **Bóyì**, whose descendants served as **shìshī** (judicial officials). When **Lǐ** fled the chaos of **Jiè**, he took refuge in the ruins of **Yīhóu**, sustaining himself on **plum fruit** and thus changing his surname to **Lǐ**.

This refers to the descendants of **Jiǔxiàn**, who earned their surname **Lǐ** through judicial service. Later descendants sometimes changed it to **Lǐ** (里), and upon fleeing to **Yīhóu’s ruins**, they altered it to **Lǐ** (李), signifying *prosperity and sincerity*—this was during the time of **Tāng**. **Lǐ** begot **Chāngzǔ**, who served as a **dàfū** in **Chén**, residing in **Kǔ County**. **Chāngzǔ** begot **Míng**, who became **Chén’s chancellor**, and was buried north of **Làxiāng**, where a temple was erected, giving rise to **Xiàngchéng**. **Míng** begot **Qìngbīn**, who begot **Língfēi** (also called **Qiánhuì**). Both **Qìngbīn** and **Língfēi** ascended to heaven in broad daylight.

The **Chén** spoken of here is the ancient **Chén state**, not the one later granted to **Hú Gōng Mǎn** by the **Zhōu**.

From **Tāng** to **Yángjiǎ**, eighteen sovereigns reigned over **250 years**. From **Lǐ Zhēng** to **Qiánhuì**, five generations succeeded one another, aligning with this era—when the **Tàixuàn** period was already under **Chén’s rule**. When the **Zhōu** enfeoffed **Shùn’s descendants**, this was the same **Chén**. After its destruction, **Hú Gōng** was enfeoffed there.

**Língfēi’s** wife, **Xuánmiào Yùnǚ**, conceived the **Venerable Lord** after dreaming of the sun’s essence. This is the first account.

Again, the *Original Record* states: **Laozi**, born speaking, pointed to the **plum tree** and said, *"This is my surname."* Thus, he took **Lǐ** as his surname. Hence, **Xuē Dàohéng**, a **Lǐshì** of the **Sui**, inscribed on the **Laojun Temple Courtyard Stele**:

*"Conceived by the sun’s radiance at birth, his origin in qi is unfathomable. He pointed to the tree as his surname—this is the true source of the *blowing of the flute*."*

The *Lóuguān Xian Shī Zhuan* states: **Laojun**, after the **Sage Mother** ascended the **plum tree**, declared, *"This is your surname."*

These three accounts are fully recorded in scripture and tradition; now they are all clarified to illuminate the **national surname and ancestral lineage**.

The **Sage Mother**, according to the *Record of the Mysterious Center*, was **Lǐ Língfēi** of the **Yīn dynasty**, whose father and son successively cultivated the **Dao of longevity**. **Qìngbīn**, over a hundred years old, retained youthful appearance, wandering the **Five Sacred Peaks**. One day, in his dwelling, a **cloud-dragon** descended to welcome him, and he ascended to heaven in broad daylight. **Língfēi**, moved by his father’s ascension, secluded himself in deep retreat, cultivating within, and took **Yīn Shì** of **Tiānshuǐ** as his wife, residing in **Làxiāng**. His wife, while napping at noon, dreamed that Heaven opened wide, and celestial beings bore the sun from that place. After some time, the sun shrank and fell from Heaven, transforming into a **five-colored pearl** the size of a **bullet**. She swallowed it in the dream and became pregnant.

Eighty-one years later, her complexion grew ever younger, resembling a maiden. **Língfēi**, also over a hundred years old, ascended to heaven. After **Laojun** was born, **five-colored cloud chariots** descended to welcome him, bearing him away to Heaven.

The *Great Ancestral Lineage of the Lǐ Clan* states: The **Lǐ** surname originated from **Huángdì’s** descendants, surnamed **Gōngsūn**, known as **Xuānyuán**.

The **Yuanfei** of the Xīlíng clan bore **Chāngyì**, whose wife, **Fāngléi** of the **Fāngléi** clan, was called **Nǚjié**. She conceived **Shàohào**, known as the **Qīngyáng** clan, by sensing the **Tāiguāng** (Celestial Radiance) piercing the sun.

**Shàohào’s** secondary wife, named **Xiūfáng**, bore **Dàyè**. **Dàyè’s** wife, named **Fūshǐ**, conceived **Gāoxiàn** by sensing the **white clouds** enveloping her. **Gāoxiàn** bore **Bóyì**, also known as **Yì**. The **Emperor Shùn**封封 him at **Yíng**, and thus he took the surname **Léi** (as **Yíng** was transformed into **Léi**).

**Yì’s** wife, **Yáo**, bore **Ruòshuǐ**, who bore **Chāngguì**, who bore **Jǐngpú**, who bore **Zhòngxíng**. **Zhòngxíng** served as a vassal of the **Zhōu Chéngwáng**, and was posthumously named **Fēigōng**.

By the time of **Emperor Xuānwáng**, he was granted the surname **Kēi**. **Kēi’s** grandson, **Tíngjiān**, had a daughter, **Zhēnjié**, who remained unwedded in her chastity. Residing in **Làxiāng**’s **Rénlǐ** hamlet of the **Chǔ** realm, she ate **Lǐ** fruit and conceived. After **eighty-one years**, she bore without suffering, and divine spirits subtly guarded her. On the **fifteenth day of the second month** during the reign of **King Huì of Zhōu**, while climbing a **Lǐ** tree, she gave birth from her **left flank**.

The child was born with **white hair**, and in his **left palm** was a **jade seal** with a character, while in his **right palm** were **seventy-two volumes of scripture** with characters. Beneath his **left foot** was the character **jiù** (救, *rescue*), and beneath his **right foot** was the character **zhì** (治, *govern*). He could speak upon birth and asked his father where he was.

His mother answered: *"I have remained chaste and unwedded, and now I am old. I conceived by eating the **Lǐ** fruit, so you have no father. I bore you as a maiden, fearing ridicule from our neighbors. I wanted to drink poison and end myself, but a divine being warned me not to swallow the medicine. Now, eighty-one years have passed. You were born from the **Lǐ** fruit, so **Lǐ** shall be your surname."* Though she was aged, he was called **Lǎozi** (老子).

**Lǎozi** composed the **seventy-two canons** to record the names of **Heaven, Earth, and the spirits**, and expounded the **Dao of effortless longevity**. He wedded the daughter of the **Yīn** clan from **Tiānshuǐ**, and bore a son named **Zhēnlì**, who would later serve as **Jìngdìng’s** teacher—this is one account.

Now, **Yǐnxǐ** was a minister of **Kāngwáng** and served as the **Guān** prefect during **Zhāowáng’s** reign. **Lǎojūn** had already crossed the **Guān** pass and transmitted the **scriptures**, so the timeline and order differ. Though the lineage records may be in error, the origin of the **Lǐ** surname is still documented here.

The *Transmission of the Mysterious Jade Maiden Yuanjun* states: In Heaven, **Lǎojūn** was revered as the **Celestial Sage**, and long before the **eon**, he began his teachings. With the **Dao of effortless persistence**, he transformed among **Heaven and humanity**. He was the sovereign of all **sages** before the **eon**, and thus the **Celestial Sage, Dao Emperor** granted him his true title: **Lǎojūn**.

Even before the **Five Celestial Sovereigns**, he bore this name through the **eons**. Though his teachings were passed down through generations as the **preceptor of emperors**, he had not yet descended to the mortal realm. At the **Nine Pure** (highest celestial realm), the **Mysterious Jade Maiden** was commanded to descend to earth as the daughter of the **Yīn** clan from **Tiānshuǐ**, and marry **Lǐ Língfēi**.

**Lǎojūn** then rode upon the **essence of the sun**, driving **Nine Dragons**, and transformed into a **five-colored pearl**, descending into the **Mysterious Jade Maiden’s** mouth, where he took root and gestated for **eighty-one years**. Climbing the **Lǐ** tree, she bore **Lǎojūn** from her **left flank**. During her pregnancy, divine spirits guarded the **sage-mother**. After his birth, the **Jade Maiden** cradled him, and **auspicious clouds** filled the courtyard, while **sun-children** scattered their radiance, and **Moon Empress** cast her flowers. All **sages** gathered.

**Lǎojūn** then pointed to the **Lǐ** tree and said: *"This is my surname."* He had **nine names** among mortals:
1. **Ēr** (耳), with the style **Bóyáng**.
2. **Yǎ** (雅), with the style **Bózōng**.
3. **Zhōng** (忠), with the style **Bóguāng**.
4. **Shí** (石), with the style **Mènggōng**.
5. **Zhòng** (重), with the style **Zǐwén**.
6. **Dìng** (定), with the style **Yuányáng**.
7. **Yuán** (元), with the style **Bóshǐ**.
8. **Xiǎn** (显), with the style **Yuánshēng**.
9. **Dé** (德), with the style **Bówén**.

Some say he had **thirty-six titles**, others claim **seventy-two names**, or that his names and styles are countless, spanning **eon to eon** beyond mortal record. **Lǎojūn** possessed **nine transformations**, mirroring the **Law of the Sun’s** generative function. He had **seventy-two forms** and **eighty-one virtues**, thus making him the **sage among sages**, the **true among truths**.

The **Sage-Mother** in Heaven was called the **Mysterious Jade Maiden**. After giving birth to the **Great Sage**, she became the **Tāiyī Yuánjūn** (太一元君). **Yuánjūn** then instructed **Lǎojūn** on the purpose of his descent to teach mortals. Within the **Nine Chambers of Three Unity** (内修九室三一之门), she observed the **precepts of ten thousand virtues and ten thousand evils**, the **formulas of a hundred diseases and a hundred remedies**, the **rules of emptiness and purity**, and the **refinements of the nine elixirs**. She intended to reveal these to humanity, establishing a **transmission of teachings from master to disciple**.

Yet, the **Supreme Sage of the Highest Dao** (太上大圣) was the **master of all transformations**—why would he await instruction from a teacher? After completing his **Dao**, celestial music resounded through the void, and **auspicious clouds** veiled the wilds. **Ten thousand chariots and a hundred thousand riders**, along with the **Five Emperors and the Highest Truths**, surrounded the **Nine-Light Eight-Banner** carriage, welcoming **Yuánjūn** back to the **Jade Pure** realm. Henceforth, she was the **Tāiyī Yuánjūn**.

The **Song dynasty** (国朝) honored her as the **Primordial Empress**. The details are as previously explained, and further accounts appear in other texts. The **Sage-Mother’s** original descent was as the **Mysterious Jade Maiden**, **Lǎojūn’s** mother, and her deeds as **Tāiyī Yuánjūn** were most authentic. The **Song dynasty’s** veneration, however, identifies **Mǔ Yìshòu** (母益寿氏) as the **Primordial Empress**, as clearly stated in the lineage records. No such account is found in **Dao scriptures**, and the birth era is traditionally placed during the reign of **Yīn Wǔdīng**. Other accounts vary, with discrepancies in timing and details, and thus are not adopted here.

**The Twenty-Ninth [Section]:** Those who **prospers the Emperor’s lineage**. **Lǎojūn’s** **Dao** encompasses all existence, and its blessings extend to all **Heavenly Beings**. He passed down his **virtue** to his descendants, and his **light** shone upon the **Great Treasure**. Thus, his **thirty-first generation** descendant, **High Ancestor Shényáo**, illuminated the **land** and **founded the Tang dynasty**.

The **Heavenly Manifestation** flows with **auspicious grace**, its source from the **Upper Pure** (上清). The **Jade Sea’s** clarity radiates, nurturing all within the **Ten Thousand Abodes**.

**The Thirtieth [Section]: Those Who Record the Great Name**

The Emperor of **Virtue-Brightness** aided **Yáo** and assisted **Shùn**, while the **Holy Emperor** grasped the **sacred calendar** and acted in due time.
His **light** first shone between **Táng** and **Yú**, then flourished anew in the **Qín** and **Liáng** lands.
Compared to the **virtue** of **Hòuxì** and **Ancient Gōng**, or the **ascendancy** of **Wénchāng** and **Wǔfā**, divining succession and reign—his imperial lineage, branch and leaf, was no less noble than that of the **Ji-Zhōu**.

**The Thirty-First [Section]: Those Who Bear the Auspicious Title**

Now, it is made clear below.
In the first year of **Jiānfēng**, the **sacred title** was bestowed.
Previously, the two characters **"Lǎo"** and **"Zǐ"** were broadly interpreted across the **Thirty Gates**, to manifest the **omens** and bestow the **title**.

**Explication of the Sacred Title "Tàishàng Lǎojūn"**
The term **"Tàishàng"** is the **sublime name** of the **Universal Teaching**, the **ultimate fruit of sainthood**.
**"Tài"** means **"Great"**, and **"Shàng"** means **"High"**.
**"Tài"**—none surpasses the **Greatness of Tàishàng**.
**"Shàng"**—none exceeds the **Height of Shàng**.
Thus, **"Tàishàng"** is the **ultimate designation** of **cultivation’s cause and enlightenment’s fruit**.
Mortals who practice attain **Dao** from **ordinariness**, **immortality** from **Dao**, **veritable reality** from **immortality**, and **sainthood** from **veritable reality**.
The **highest stage of sainthood** ascends to **Tàishàng**.
**Tàishàng** possesses **six transcendences** and **ten thousand virtues**, none lacking.
He inherits the **Law’s sovereign throne**, governing all **saints**, and thus attains this **sublime station**.
His name, like that of the **Emperors of each dynasty**, is passed down through succession, all bearing the title.

Since **Yuánshǐ Tiānzūn**, there have been:
**Tàishàng Dàdào Jūn**, **Tàishàng Lǎojūn**, **Tàishàng Zhàngrén**, and **Tàishàng Gāohuángdì**—all attaining this **ultimate rank**.
Yet **Tàishàng Zhàngrén** and **Gāohuángdì**, though bearing the **sublime title**, did not propagate the **Teaching**.
Only **Dàodào Jūn** and **Lǎojūn** transmitted the **imperial lineage** and became **sovereigns of the Ten Thousand Heavens**.

**"Xuán"** means **profound**, **wondrous**, and also **Dao**, **Heaven**.
The **Supreme Dao** is too high and subtle for speech.
Condensing the **profound** and the **wondrous**, **"Xuán"** serves as its **manifestation**, declaring the **profound, wondrous, and distant** to illuminate the **Dao’s essence**.
Thus, it is called **"Xuányuán"**—**Origin**, **Beginning**, **Ancestor**.
*The **Ěryǎ** states:* **"The root of the Dao’s emergence, the ancestral source of all things."**
Both **worldly** and **transcendent** methods stem from this **foundation**.
Hence, it is called **"Yuánhuáng"**—**"Great"** refers to the **Great Dao**; the **Dao**, when great, is called **"Huáng"**.
*The **Preface to the *Shàngshū*** says:* **"The writings of the Three Sovereigns are called *Sānfén*."**
This speaks of the **Great Dao**.
**"Dì"** means **Heaven**; his **virtue** aligns with **Heaven**, second only to the **Dao**.
**"Great virtue"** is called **"Dì"**; combining **virtue** and **Dao**, it is termed **"Huángdì"**.
It is also said: **"Following the Dao and conforming to Heaven"**—thus, **"Huángdì"**.
When **Qín Shǐhuáng** unified the world and established laws for posterity, he adopted the **sublime names** of the **Three Sovereigns** and the **beautiful titles** of the **Five Emperors**, combining them as **"Huángdì"**.
*The **Preface to the *Shàngshū*** says:* **"The writings of the Five Emperors are called *Wǔdiǎn*."**
This speaks of the **constant Dao**.

**"Nèihào"** is the **hidden name**.
**Lǎojūn** has **ten thousand names and titles**, too numerous to exhaust.
At that time, the world called him **"Lǎozǐ"**.
This was due to the **Dao’s eminence** and **virtue’s nobility**, making it improper to name him directly.
Both **Heaven** and **mankind** reverently called him **"Lǎozǐ"**—this was his **hidden name**.

Our **Great Tang Emperor Gāozōng Tiānhuángdì**, the **thirty-third sacred descendant** of **Lǎozǐ**, was the **third son** of **Tàizōng Wénhuángdì**, the **third emperor of Great Tang**.
He inherited the **peaceful succession**, grasped the **sacred calendar**, and displayed the **numinous brilliance** of the **Immortal Lǐ**.
He expanded the **auspicious rites of prosperity**, returned to the **capital from Gùxìan**, and paid homage to the **Sacred True Source**.
He demonstrated **filial piety** in honoring the **ancestors** and **elevated the Sacred Title** of **Xuányuán**.
In the first year of **Jiānfēng**, on the **twenty-eighth day of the second lunar month**, in the year of **Bingyín**, he issued a decree:

*"The **Great Dao** of the **Eastern Platform** blends into unity, established before **Yīn** and **Yáng**.
The **Perfect Man**, emptying himself, speaks of **ten thousand things** with subtlety.
As for **Lǎojūn**, he is my **original lineage**.
From **Fúxī’s** beginning to the **end of the Ji-Zhōu**, his **numinous responses** were formless, his **transformations** manifold.
He ascended beyond **Yuánqì**, descended through **solar essence**, sometimes drifting through the cosmos, inhaling and exhaling **wind and clouds**, sometimes instructing and befriending **emperors**, his **divine brushstrokes** immortal.
Like **Yīn** and **Yáng**, he was unfathomable; with **sun and moon**, he hung suspended.
During the **Jīnxīng** period, he concealed his traces beneath the **pillars**, expounding **elegant teachings** and setting examples for future ages.
Though his **heart aligned with the Great Void**, his **principles returned to the True Sovereign**.
As for those who **abandon sainthood and discard wisdom**, arrange **few desires**, and in the **silent, distant void** surpass **sight and sound**—
**Detached and effortless**, naturally content,
**Drawn upon without depletion**, used without exhaustion,
**Holding the Great Image** while returning to **primordial purity**,
**Purifying the Mysterious Mirror** and casting off **entanglements**,
**Transcending Heaven and Earth** to endure eternally,
**Straddling the Potter’s Wheel** to nurture all—
**How sublime!**
Indeed, he is beyond all naming."*

The **Supreme Sage’s** blessings were indeed abundant, his **virtue/power** flourishing with boundless fortune.
The **highest virtue** walked its path, truly entering an age of auspicious repose.

I, inheriting the sacred mandate, govern the myriad myriads with reverent care.
Guiding the luminaries of **San Guang** [Sun, Moon, Stars], I rise in solemn awe at dawn’s first light,
Bearing the weight of the **Four Great Elements**, yet rest with vigilant dread.
I exhaust my **filial piety and respect** toward my ancestral roots,
And pour forth boundless kindness to both the living and the departed.

I uphold the **pure and virtuous transformation**, continuing the **Great Peace’s** legacy.
Ascending the **Jie Hill** to display my **auspicious omens**, seated in the **Bright Court** to receive my **destined title**—
Smoke ascends in celebration, and blessings descend in abundance;
The **Nine Ghosts** of the **Gao** respond with cranes, while mountains proclaim **Ten Thousand Years**.
Exceeding ancient precedents in **auspicious signs**, surpassing even the **Emperors of old** as the foremost sovereign.

With the **Great Rites** now complete, I return my carriage to the capital,
Taking a circuitous route through **Lai Village**, personally offering **sacrificial wine** to the **Sacred Precincts**,
Gazing upward at the **auspicious cypress** in lingering reverence,
And drawing from the **Divine Spring** in eternal sigh.

My thoughts of his enduring presence grow ever deeper,
And my reverence for the **beginning of respect** grows ever more profound.

It is fitting to proclaim the **mystic origins** of his essence,
Thus illuminating the **play of the Mysterious Sage’s** **virtue/power**.

Therefore, I decree his posthumous title as **Emperor Xuanyuan** [玄元皇帝].
Moreover, let **Guyang County** be renamed **Zhenyuan County**,
And grant the county’s **sacred lineage** an additional year of tax exemption.
May this honor the **loyal and reverent devotion**, fulfilling the **duty to venerate the ancestors**.

Proclaim this edict to all within and without,
That all may know.

The Sovereign shall implement this decree.

Moreover, in the second year of **Yongchun** [永淳], on the fourth day of the twelfth month, the **Emperor** issued an edict:

*"The **Way/Dao** is revered by the **Sovereign**,
And his abode is beneath the **Purple Enclosure** [紫微], from which his teachings descend.*

*The **virtue/power** of the **ministers** is cultivated,
And their **loyal hearts** [丹心] are exhausted in polishing themselves.*

*If the **superior** upholds **righteousness/義** [义],
And the **inferior** honors **propriety/禮** [礼],
Then **naming and teaching** [名教] shall flow in purity,
And **loyalty and trustworthiness** [忠信] shall grow ever more refined.*

*In ancient times, the **Buxu Court** [胥庭] was vast and boundless,
And **Nüwa** and **Fuxi** transformed the world without slaughter.*

*Even **Xuanyuan** [轩顼] of **Emperor Yao** and **Emperor Shun**,
Though their governance was just, their **deep benevolence** [深仁] still accumulated.*

*Yet when **Qin** seized the **Son of Heaven’s position** [润位],
The **decadent and extravagant** [奢泰] trends began to flourish,
And when **Han** inherited the **conqueror’s schemes** [霸图],
The **mystic and humble** [玄默] customs were already in decline.*

*Looking far to the **Wei** and **Jin** dynasties,
And near to the **Northern Zhou** and **Sui**,
The **age** [代] grew ever more chaotic,
And the **people** [人] indulged in **usurpation and excess** [僭侈].*

*Examining the **corruptions** of a hundred **Sovereigns** [百王],
And the **calamitous trends** of a thousand years,
After the **Great Disorder** [大乱],
Now arises the **Great Sage’s** [大圣] **era** [期].*

*Having surpassed the **time of mourning** [交丧],
It is necessary to foster the **harmonious succession** [交泰] of **virtue/power**.*

*My **High Ancestor**, the **Divine Sage Emperor** [神尧皇帝],
Received the **august mandate** [景命] from the **Palace of the Son of Heaven** [镳宫],
And dispelled the **wild and chaotic** [妖氛] of the **outer lands** [野].
He **reestablished** the **heavenly luminaries** [日月],
And **rectified** the **four quarters** [宇宙] of the world.*

*The **Great Sage Emperor** [太宗文皇帝],
Unfurled the **map** [图] at the **Yellow River** [汶水],
And wielded the **great axe** [钺] across the **four directions** [参墟].
He **descended** the **divine celestial troops** [斗极神兵],
And **cleansed** the **great flood** [巨浸] of **Huai and Xiang** [怀襄].
He **extended** the **four cardinal directions** [四维],
And **secured** the **Red Land** [赤县].
Through **countless battles** [百战],
He **sacrificed** for the **people** [苍生].
His **teachings and influence** [声教] spread far,
And his **boundaries and protection** [堤封] extended afar.
His **grand achievements** [洪业] are vast,
And none can equal them.*

*With my **limited understanding** [寡昧],
I **shamefully inherit** [忝膺] the **great legacy** [丕绪],
Yet never have I ceased to **diligently seek the Dao/Way** [访道],
And **tremble at my responsibilities** [临人].
Each day I am more cautious than the last,
And **thirty-four years** [三十四载] have now passed.

*Moreover, when the **people below are at ease** [下安],
Then the **Sovereign above rests** [上逸],
And when the **times are corrupt** [时弊],
The **Sovereign’s** [君] **concerns multiply** [忧].
Though I reside in the **ninefold palace** [九重],
My **care extends to all the people** [万姓].

*My **resolve to establish the foundation** [建本之怀] grows ever stronger,
And my **restraint toward superficial matters** [抑末] **is now profound** [念遽深].
Though the **people’s affairs** [庶绩] are settled,
The **pure origins** [淳源] of the **Way/Dao** are not yet fully realized.*

*My **lineage** [绵系] **traces back** to **Xuanyuan Emperor** [玄元].
I **constantly desire** to **extend** [远叶] the **ancestral rules** [先规],
And **propagate** the **Dao/Way’s** **transformations** [道化].
To **change the land** into a **domain of longevity** [寿域],
And to **deliver the people** to a **forest of blessings** [福林].

*Reflecting upon the **Land of Harmony** [华胥],
And **laboring in my dreams** [寤寐],
I **hope** that all within and without the **court** [内外寮寀]
Shall **exhaust their sincerity** [竭乃诚],
And **encourage** the **virtuous** [梨萌] to **revere simplicity** [简质].
Those **tainted by old customs** [旧染] shall **abandon corrupt trends** [薄俗],
And **all shall return to the new** [惟新].
Relying on the **Great Dao/Way** [大道],
We **usher in the beginning** [开元],
And **together renew the world** [更始].

*It is fitting to **broaden** the **imperial grace** [霈泽],
And **extend** its **far-reaching blessings** [绂埏].
Therefore, I **grant a great amnesty** [大赦] to all under heaven,
And rename the second year of **Yongchun** [永淳] as the first year of **Hongdao** [弘道].

*Furthermore, I command all states across the land to establish **Dao/Way Observatories** [道干观],
Three in the **upper states** [上州],
Two in the **middle states** [中州],
And one in the **lower states** [下州].
Each observatory shall **ordain** [度] seven **Daoists** [道士],
To **manifest** the **wind of purity** [清净之风],
And to **await** the **harmonious transformations** of the **Dao/Way’s** **non-action** [无为之化].

The Sovereign shall implement this decree.
Thus, it fulfills the **intent to honor the ancestors and venerate the first** [奉先尊祖],
And to **return to simplicity and purity** [复朴还淳].

**The Second Scroll of *The Daoist Classic with Grand Explanations of the Sages’ Meaning*** [道德真经广圣义卷之二] is complete.
**The Third Scroll of *The Daoist Classic with Grand Explanations of the Sages’ Meaning*** [道德真经广圣义卷之三] is complete.

**Tang Master Guangcheng Du Guangting’s *Exposition on the Imperial Commentary—Preface to the Commentary (Upper Section)***

**Commentary:**
The **Supreme Dao/Way’s Root** [玄玄道宗] descended and took birth in **Yimò** [伊亳].

**Explanation:**
*"Xuan"* [玄] means profound and mysterious, also unobstructed.
*"Zong"* [宗] means master, also revered.
It speaks of **Laozi, the Venerable Lord on High**, as the master of the profound and mysterious Dao/Way.

Since the Venerable Lord on High is neither bound to existence nor to non-existence,
He transcends both cause and effect, casting off both coarse and refined.
As the **Primordial Sovereign** [先天] and **Posterior Sovereign** [后天] of the kalpas,
He is revered as the **Teaching Sovereign** [教主], hence the term **Supreme Dao/Way’s Root**.

*"Jiangsheng"* [降生]—from above to below is called *jiang* [降].
It means the Venerable Lord on High, dwelling in the **Three Realms’ Heaven** [三境之天],
as the master of the Great Dao/Way, out of compassion for the mortal realm,
descended to manifest in the human world.
With boundless mercy, He assumed a form and displayed auspicious signs—
riding the **Nine Dragons’ Chariot** [九龙之驾],
transforming the essence of the **Morning Sun** [旭日],
entering the dream of the **Mysterious Jade Maiden** [玄妙玉女],
thus taking human form through her conception and birth into the world.
To demonstrate His kinship with the common folk,
He took on the appearance of birth,
marking the beginning of His manifestation.
Hence, it is called *"descended birth"* [降生].
This clarifies His manifestation at the threshold of transformation.

**Yimò** [伊亳]:
*"Yi"* [伊] refers to the ruins of **Yihou** [伊侯], where the Venerable Lord’s ancestor fled to avoid the tyranny of **Jie** [桀].
This land lies between the cities of **Ku** [苦] and **Xiang** [相].

*"Mò"* [亳] refers to the **Mò Society’s land** [亳社之地], anciently called **Mò** [亳], later known as the **ruins of Yin** [殷墟].
From **King Tang’s** [汤] receipt of the Mandate of Heaven to the **nineteenth Yin king, Pan Geng** [盘庚],
who relocated the capital eight times before finally establishing it at **Mò**—this was the capital of Yin.
Some say it was the state of **Chen** [陈], the descendants of **Taixu** [太皡]’s lineage,
called **Chen Ruins** [陈墟], located beside **Ruan Hill** [宛丘].

According to the **Nine Provinces divided by Yu** [禹别九州],
**Ku County** [苦县] was part of **Yuzhou** [豫州].
After **King Wu’s** [武王] conquest of **Zhou** [纣],
he granted **Hupang Man** [胡公满], a descendant of **Shun** [舜], the state of **Chen**.
This was the ancient lineage of **Taixu’s** descendants, already ruling **Chen**.
The descendants of **Shun** had also become the **Hu State** [胡国].
**Hu** was small, while **Chen** was large;
**Hu** lay between **Shen and Cai** [沈蔡之间],
while **Chen** was in present-day **Yingchuan** [颖川].
**King Wu**, honoring **Shun’s virtue** [舜德],
rewarded his descendants by relocating them to **Chen**.
From **Hupang Man** onward, through the **Spring and Autumn Period** [春秋],
**Chen** endured for over forty generations before being conquered by **Chu’s heir** [楚子].
When **Han Gaozu** [汉祖] destroyed **Qin**,
he renamed **Chen** as **Huaiyang Commandery** [淮阳郡].
Since commanderies were large and counties small,
and counties were administered by commanderies,
**Huaiyang** encompassed the four counties of **Yangxia** [阳夏],
**Ningping** [宁平], **Ruò** [若], and **Zhè** [柘].
Later, **Emperor Zhang of the Later Han** [后汉章帝] renamed **Huaiyang** as **Chen Commandery** [陈郡].

Some say it was the state of **Chu** [楚],
with **Xiong Yi** [熊绎] as its first ruler, whose capital was at **Jing** [荆].
**Chen**, though separated by the **Huai River** [淮],
shared borders with **Chu**.
During the **Spring and Autumn Period**,
**Chu’s heir** conquered **Chen** and annexed it as a county,
thus making it part of **Chu**, and it became **Chu territory**.

Some say **Chu County** [楚县], others say **Chen Commandery** [陈郡].
In the **Spring and Autumn Period**, commanderies were small while counties were large,
so commanderies were subordinate to counties—hence **Chu County**.
When **Qin** unified **Chu County**,
it established **thirty-six commanderies**, making commanderies large and counties small,
so counties were subordinate to commanderies—hence **Chu County**.

Some say **Qiao State** [谯国]:
Today, **Laozi’s former residence**, **Taqing Palace** [太清宫], has **Qiao City** [谯城] forty *li* northeast of it.

Some say **Xiangren** [相人]:
Beside the palace lies the ancient city of **Xiang** [相城].

Some say **Ku County** [苦县] was also a **Spring and Autumn-era administrative county** [春秋统郡之县].
Thus, **Ku County’s** city stood east of the **Lai River** [濑水], its foundations still extant.
Later, **Ku County** was renamed **Guyang County** [谷阳县].

In **Tang Emperor Gaozong’s** [高宗] **Kianyun Year 1** [乾封元年],
he ascended **Mount Tai** [东岳] and, upon his return,
visited **Laozi’s former residence**, bestowing an imperial title and renaming the county **Zhenyuan** [真源县].

In **Tianhe Year 3** [中和三年], on the **gengmǎo year** [癸卯],
**Magistrate Pan Chou** [潘稠] of **Mò Prefecture** [亳州] submitted a memorial to the **Imperial Court in Chengdu** [成都行在],
stating that **Taqing Palace** had repeatedly demonstrated miraculous signs.
Since the **Huang Chao Rebellion** [黄巢大寇],
bandits had attacked eighteen times,
yet each time, **thunderous winds** [迅雷烈风] struck them,
causing them to stumble and lose their way,
or suffer utter defeat—none dared approach the palace.
Thousands of nearby residents took refuge there and survived unharmed.
He requested relocating the county to the palace grounds for protection.
The Emperor decreed that, though the request was well-intentioned,
moving the county would profane sacred ground,
and thus it was not permitted.
Instead, **Zhenyuan County** was elevated to **Chì County** [赤县],
since **Taqing Palace** lay within its jurisdiction.
An imperial envoy was dispatched to perform **ritual fasting and prayers** [斋御词修斋告谢].

Though ages have passed and names have changed,
the origins of these places remain the same.

The **Later Han Emperor Huan** dreamed of **Laozi**, and by imperial decree summoned **Chen Xiang’s** official **Bian Shao** to construct a shrine and erect a stele at the **Master’s** birthplace and ancestral home. Beside the shrine stood the **Temple of Lady Li**, and within the shrine, there was an ancient **Hall of Emptiness-Nothingness**. Before the hall grew three **Chinese windmill pines** [桧] and a thousand additional pines, the **Nine Dragon Well**, the **Alchemical Elixir Well**, and the **Ascension Deer-Track Tree**. These ancient traces remain unchanged.

To its left flows the **Spiritual Stream** [灵溪], and to its right encircles the **Swirling Water** [涡水]. The site is open and splendid, truly a **venerable location**.

The **Lai Water** flows to the west of the palace, and since water names the district, it is known as **Lai County**. Some call it **Li County** [厉乡], but this is a textual error.

Across generations, successive emperors and kings have repeatedly embellished this estate. In the **sixth year of Emperor Wen’s reign in the Sui Dynasty**, the **Sui Emperor Wen** ordered **Xue Daoheng**, the **Inner Historian’s Attendant**, to erect a stele and restore the temple. In the **seventh year of Tianbao** [天宝七年], in the year **Wuzhi** [戊子], the **Taqing Palace** was renamed, with the **Sammyan Prefect of Bianzhou** appointed as its **Palace Attendant** and the **Magistrate of Bozhou** as its **Deputy Attendant**. The **six sacred statues** of the **Later Zhou Dynasty**—the **Highest Ancestors** of **Emperor Gaozu, Emperor Taizong, Emperor Gaozong, Emperor Zhongzong, Emperor Ruizong, and Emperor Xuanzong**—were all enshrined to serve at **Laozi’s** side.

**Commentary:** *"Awe-inspiring, the august Ancestor,
ordained the surname of our Tang."*
**Explanation:** *"Awe-inspiring"* [肃肃] denotes **reverence, solemnity, and respect**. *"August"* [皇] means **great**. *"Ancestor"* [祖] refers to the **origin**. Thus, **Laozi** is the **revered and august origin** of the **Great Tang Dynasty**. *"Ordained the surname"* [命氏] pertains to **clan lineage**, explaining the **source of the surname**. *"Our Tang"* [我唐] signifies that the **establishment of the Tang Dynasty** began with the **sacred Ancestors’ blessings**, making **Laozi** their **descendant**. Initially, **Laozi’s surname was derived from pointing at a **plum tree** [李树], as the **origin of the Li surname** is already detailed in the previous **Explanation of Meaning**.*

Thus, it is said: *"The surname of our Tang was ordained."* The **Xue Daoheng Stele** states: *"Twice born from the sun’s radiance,
ineffable source of the received **qi**."*
Pointing to the tree as the surname’s origin remains unclear; **Laozi’s** lineage was established by **Zhang Yansheng** [京房] through **wind-and-reed divination** [吹律].

**Commentary:** *"The blessings of the august Ancestor,
endless and far-reaching."*
**Explanation:** *"Blessings"* [裕] means **bestowing virtue upon the worthy**. *"Endless"* [无疆] describes **boundless expanse and vastness**. *"Far-reaching"* [祉] is **blessing**. **Laozi’s** virtue nurtures **endless blessings**, spreading **vast and enduring prosperity**, illuminating the **imperial enterprise** and **reviving our Great Tang**. *"Blessings"* [垂裕] also means **teaching and guidance**.

**Commentary:** *"In the **Long Hair** ode, the **auspicious signs** endure,
rooted in the **ancestral lineage** of **bottle gourd and calabash**."*
**Explanation:** *"Long Hair"* [《长发》] is a **poem from the Shang Dynasty**, recorded in the **Book of Songs**. *"The virtuous and wise King of Shang,
his long hair marked by **auspicious signs**."* *"Auspicious signs"* [祥] means **virtue**. It states that the **virtue of the Shang clan**, through **longstanding manifestations of good fortune**, aligned with the **Five Teachings**, demonstrating **benevolent and expansive virtue**—the **initial portents of their sovereignty**. From the **Yu, Xia, and Shang dynasties**, **Tang** gained the **Mandate of Heaven**, and the **Tang lineage endured unbroken**. *"Bottle gourd and calabash"* [瓜瓞] refers to the **poem *The Descendants of King Wen*** [《文王之什□绵绵篇》], where *"bottle gourd"* [瓜] symbolizes **successive generations**, while *"calabash"* [瓞] represents **the unbroken transmission of virtue**. The **bottle gourd’s** fruit **inherits its predecessor’s form**, and the **calabash’s** young shoots **resemble the older ones**, thus *"bottle gourd and calabash"* [瓜瓞] signifies **unbroken continuity**, like the **enduring virtue of the later generations**. **Houji**, the **earliest ancestor of the Zhou clan**, was **enshrined at Tai** [邰], but later **Duke Liu** lost his position and **migrated to Bin** [豳], dwelling at **Qizi** [漆沮]. His **virtue endured**, flourishing under **King Wen of Zhou**, who won the **people’s hearts** and **established the Zhou Dynasty**. This recounts the **long-lasting rise of the Yin and Zhou dynasties** to illustrate **Laozi’s** enduring blessings. The **Tang Dynasty’s** ascension, too, was **not the work of a single day or night**; it was **accumulated virtue and transmitted blessings**, a **process stretching far back**, that enabled it to **seize the Mandate of Heaven**, just as the **Yin and Zhou dynasties** had done.

**Commentary:** *"Its traces of origin and lineage
are now fully recorded in the registers."*
**Explanation:** *"Now"* [方] refers to **current records**; *"registers"* [册] are **bamboo-bound annals**, measuring **two inches longer than a foot**, used to **document state affairs**. The *Spring and Autumn Annals* states: *"Major events are inscribed in registers,
minor ones in slips of bamboo."* *"Origin"* [出] signifies **public service**, such as **Laozi’s descendants** serving as **national tutors**, **keepers of archives**, **pillar historians**, **grand historians**, or as **Master Yang’s father** [伯阳父], all **distinguished in the imperial court**. *"Lineage"* [处] denotes **seclusion and retreat**, such as **Laozi’s guidance in the western deserts**, **eastern pilgrimages to the azure seas**, and **hidden transmission of scriptures**. Though **obscure in name and withdrawn from the world**, his **conduct and influence**, his **transformative guidance**, are **fully chronicled** in the **official histories**, **bamboo registers**, and **Daoist classics**.

The *I Ching* says: *"Sometimes it emerges, sometimes it retreats"*—this is the case.

**Commentary:** *"The Daoist school holds that **jade mornings** [玉晨] correspond to **Laozi’s** title."*
**Explanation:** *"Daoist school"* [道家] follows **Sima Qian’s** classification in *Six Schools*, where **Daoism precedes the Six Classics**. Among them, **Daoism is the most refined and harmonious**. **Sima Qian** said: *"Yin-Yang is elaborate yet perplexing,
Confucianism is extensive yet burdensome,
Mohism is arduous yet stifling,
Naming is ornate yet shallow,
Legalism is harsh yet lacking compassion.
Only **Daoism** embodies the **Great Way**."* Its **teaching is pure and effortless**, allowing **the mind to focus**, **actions to align with the unseen**, and **all things to flourish**. Its **practice** follows **Yin-Yang** to **achieve great harmony**, **adapts to the times**, **responds to phenomena**, and **transforms with them**—always fitting. **Simple yet profound**, **few in precepts yet vast in effect**, its **principles are easy to enact**, its **language difficult to grasp**. Rooted in **Emptiness-Nothingness**, it **relies on natural flow**, without fixed **forms or rigid structures**, thus **penetrating the essence of all things**. Neither **preceding nor following**, it **stands as the sovereign of all things**. This is what is meant by **Daoism**.

The *Huainanzi* states: *"**Daoism** governs **reason and emotion**,
harmonizes **mind and method**,
maintains **equilibrium and appropriateness**,
finds joy in the **Way** and forgets **humiliation**,
cherishes **virtue** and endures **poverty**."*

The **venerable sages** hold it in highest esteem,
the **foundation of states and families** relies upon it.
Thus it is called **Daoism**.

**Yùchén** is another appellation of the **Supreme Dao/Way Lord**.
*The Old Lord’s Biography* states:
Some call him **Celestial Venerable**,
some call him **Supreme Venerable**,
some call him **Great Dao**,
some call him **Old Lord**.
Thus, **Yùchén Lord** is also an appellation of the Old Lord.
The **Supreme Void Emperor** (Xūhuáng) dwells in the **Purple Jade Palace**,
above **Mysterious Capital, Jade Metropolis** (Xuándū Yùjīng),
also named the **Purple Dawn Palace**,
also named the **Jade Dawn Palace**—
this is the **Yùchén Dao Lord**, another name for the Old Lord.

**Annotation:** *Does Sima Qian call him the "Hidden Gentleman"?*
**Explanation:** Sima Qian—
Surname Sima, given name Qian, courtesy name Zǐcháng,
a native of Wēn, Hénán, grandson of Sīmǎ Xǐ, chancellor to Zhōngshān Wáng,
and son of Tán, the Grand Historian.
Born in Lóngmén, at ten he recited the *Ancient Text Classic of Documents*,
at twenty he wandered through Jiānghuái and Jiǔyí, near Yǔ’s tombs.
He served the Han as a **Lángzhōng** (courtier),
and was dispatched to **Xīshǔ**.
After his father’s death, he became **Grand Historian** and composed *Records of the Grand Historian*.
For speaking in defense of Lǐ Líng, who was falsely accused and his family harmed,
he was slandered, imprisoned, and subjected to **cruel mutilation**.
*The Western Capital Miscellany* says he composed *Records of the Grand Historian* in fury,
and scholars praised his talent as a **fine historian**.
His accounts of **Qū Yuán** and **Jiǎ Yì** were eloquent and expressive—
truly a **great talent of his age**.
Huán Tán’s *New Discourses* states:
*"Sima Qian’s* Records of the Grand Historian *was not yet circulated in his time.
Later, his great-grandson Yáng Róng titled it* The Grand Historian’s Work.
Some say it was named after his ancestor Tán, who held the post of Grand Historian,
and Qian inherited the office, yet suffered mutilation—
fearing disgrace to his ancestors, he took the name of a courier in the Grand Historian’s bureau,
thus calling it* The Grand Historian’s Work *instead."*
Qian died as **Middle Book Order** and left behind **two volumes of collected works**.
*The Records* state:
*"The Old Master sometimes concealed himself, sometimes revealed himself,
for over two hundred years,
then entered the Western Sands and vanished—
truly a **Hidden Gentleman**."*

**Explanation of "Child":**
*"Child"* is an honorific for one of **Dao**.
Ancients called teachers *"Child"*—
as with **Confucius** and **Listed Child** (Lièzǐ).

**Explanation of "Gentleman":**
A **Gentleman** is a **Lord and Teacher**.
*The Records of Rites* says:
*"One who studies must first be broad in analogies,
then can be a teacher.
Only a teacher can be a leader,
only a leader can be a Lord.
As a Lord and Teacher, his **virtue/power** is vast and luminous—
thus he is called a **Gentleman**."*

**Further Explanation:**
*"Though among the common folk, if one is revered for **virtue/power and Dao**,
he is called a **Gentleman**.
Lacking **Dao** and **virtue/power**, even in high station, he is called a **petty man**.*
Thus, **Dao** compares to **Lordship**, **virtue/power** to **teaching**—
only then is he called a **Gentleman**.
All people in the world follow this principle—
how much more so the **Mysterious Primordial Old Lord**,
**Master of Virtue/Power and Dao**, **Teacher of Emperors**,
rightly called a **Gentleman**!"

**Hidden Dragon in lowly station**—
thus called **"Hidden."**

**Annotation:** *Yet Zhòngní revered him.*
**Explanation:** Zhòngní—
Confucius, given name Qíu, courtesy name Zhòngní.
His lineage traced to the descendants of **Yīn**.
According to *Records of the Grand Historian’s* **Yīn Dynasty Biography**:
*"Emperor Yù’s consort swallowed a swallow’s egg and gave birth to **Jié**,
who served Yáo as **Minister of Population**.
For his merits, he was enfeoffed in **Shāng** and granted the surname **Zǐ**.
Jié’s descendant **Tāng**, named Tiānyǐ or Lǚ,
overthrew Xià and became **Son of Heaven**.
By the thirty-seventh generation of Tāng’s descendants,
the king was named **Jīnxīn**, called **Zhòu**,
who ruled without **Dao**—
**Wǔ of Zhōu** raised an army to destroy him,
and enfeoffed his collateral descendant **Wěizǐ’s son Qǐ** in **Sòng**.
Sòng Mǐn Gōng’s son **Fúfǔ Hé** was the eldest and should have inherited,
but he yielded to his younger brother **Lì Gōng**.
Hé’s son was **Sòng Fù Zhōu**, Zhōu’s son was **Shèng**,
Shèng’s son was **Zhèng Kǎofǔ**,
who held three offices in Sòng and was praised in the *Spring and Autumn Annals* for his reverence:
*"One command makes me stoop,
two commands make me bow,
three commands make me kneel.
I cling to the wall and flee—
none dare to insult me.
With three commands, my reverence grows ever greater."*
Zhèng Kǎofǔ’s son was **Kǒng Fù Jiā**,
who branched into the **Kǒng clan**.
Some say: *"He swallowed a yin egg and was later granted the surname Zǐ,
pairing Zǐ with Yǐ (乙), meaning ‘swallow’—thus Kǒng (孔)."*
This is one account.
Another claims the Kǒng surname originated from **dripping water eroding stone**.
This is baseless and rejected here.

Kǒng Fù Jiā served as **Sòng’s Marshal**,
his son was **Mù Jīn Fù**,
Mù Jīn Fù’s son was **Gāoyí Fù**,
Gāoyí Fù’s son was **Fáng Shū**,
who fled to **Lǔ** and fathered **Bó Xià**,
Bó Xià’s son was **Shū Liáng Hé**—
Confucius’s father.

Confucius resided in **Quēlǐ, Zōu Xiāng, Lǔ**.
In the **21st year of King Líng of Zhōu**,
the **22nd year of Duke Xiāng of Lǔ**,
on the **13th day of the 10th month, Gēngshèn**,
he was born.
He died in the **16th year of Duke Aí of Lǔ**,
the **41st year of King Jìng of Zhōu**,
**Gēnshēn year, 18th day of the 4th month**,
at age **73**.

Initially, in the **7th year of Duke Zhāo**,
the **Chu ruler** built **Chénghuá Terrace**,
intending to summon the feudal lords to a feast.
He invited Duke Zhāo, **Mèng Xìzǐ**, and **Zhòngsūn Jué** as escorts,
and proceeded to **Chu**.
In the **3rd month**, they passed through **Chéng**.
Duke Chéng of Chéng honored them,
but Mèng Xìzǐ failed to observe proper etiquette.
Upon arriving in Chu, he could not respond to the **ritual welcome**.
In the **4th month**, the Chu ruler hosted Duke Zhāo at the **New Terrace**.
In the **9th month**, they returned from Chu,
and Mèng Xìzǐ, ill, could not perform the farewell rites.
Thus, he began **teaching**, and those who could follow his **rituals** did so.
In the **24th year**, as Mèng Xìzǐ lay dying,
he called his officials and said:
*"Ritual is the **pillar of humanity**.
Without ritual, one cannot stand.
I have heard that there will arise a **great scholar**—
**Kǒng Qiū**, descendant of a **sage**,
who was exterminated in **Sòng**.
His ancestor **Fúfǔ Hé**, though eldest in Sòng,
yielded the throne to his younger brother **Lì Gōng**.
Later, **Zhèng Kǎofǔ** assisted **Duke Wǔ** and **Duke Xuān**,
and with three commands, his reverence grew ever greater."*

His reverence was thus. Zāng Sūn Xiè said:

*"A sage with manifest virtue,
if his time does not suit him,
his descendants will surely produce a great scholar.
Now, will this great scholar be Kǒng Qiū?
When I die, I entrust [my teachings] to Nángōng Jìngshū.
And to Hé Jì Mèngyìzi—
both are my sons.
As for the Master [Kǒng Qiū],
have them serve him and study ritual,
so that he may establish his station.
Thus, Hé Jì and Jìngshū took Zhòngní as their teacher.

Zhòngní said to Jìngshū:
*'I have heard that Lǎo Dān was well-versed in antiquity and insightful about the present,
mastered the origins of ritual and music,
and understood the ultimate purpose of virtue and the Way.
Thus, he is my teacher.'*

Jìngshū spoke to the Rú ruler:
*'Kǒng Qiū is a descendant of a sage,
and he is the great scholar to come.
He received the command of my late lord,
and I, as his subject, must take him as my teacher.
Now, Confucius is about to travel to Zhōu,
to observe the institutions of the ancient kings,
and examine the ultimate standards of ritual and music—
this is a great undertaking.
My lord, why not provide him with a carriage and provisions?
I request to accompany him.'*

The Rú ruler gave a carriage with two horses, two sets of armor, and Jìngshū went with him to Zhōu.
They inquired about ritual from Lǎo Pèng,
studied music from Cháng Hóng,
inspected the sites of the ancestral altars and suburbs,
examined the models of the Bright Hall,
observed the measures of the court,
and surveyed the four gates of the Bright Hall—
each bore the likenesses of Yáo, Shùn, Jié, and Zhòu,
with their respective virtues and vices,
and the lessons of their rise and fall.
There was also the scene of Zhōu Gōng assisting Chéng Wáng,
carrying him and holding the axe and screen,
facing south to receive the feudal lords.
[Jìngshū] sighed:
*'Now I truly understand Zhōu Gōng’s sagacity
and how Zhōu came to rule.'*

As they prepared to leave Zhōu, Lǎo Jūn sent them off:
*'The wealthy send others away with wealth,
but the virtuous send others away with words.
I claim the title of the virtuous,
so I send you away with words.
All scholars of the age,
though sharp and discerning, are near death—
they delight in criticizing others.
Those who are eloquent and expansive yet perilous—
they delight in exposing others’ faults.
As a subject, one must not presume to act alone.
As a son, one must not presume to act against one’s father.
Since returning from Zhōu, the Master’s Way has grown ever more honored,
and distant disciples have flocked to him—
more than three thousand in number.*

Confucius sighed:
*'Since Nángōng Jìngshū provided me with his carriage,
my Way has flourished.
Otherwise, my Way would have nearly perished.
Now, the *Records of Ritual* that cite what I heard from Lǎo Dān—
these are the essentials of ritual that I learned from my teacher, Lǎo Jūn.*

**Citation:**
*'The *Records of Ritual* say:
*"The Master went west and stored books in the Zhōu archives,
and since Lǎo Jūn had once been the archivist,
he questioned him about them.
Lǎo Jūn refused, so the Master took the Six Classics
and arranged them to please Lǎo Jūn.
Lǎo Jūn said: *"Too chaotic! Let me hear the essentials."
The Master replied:
*"The essentials lie in virtue and righteousness."
Lǎo Jūn asked:
*"Are virtue and righteousness human nature?"
The Master said:
*"Indeed.
A gentleman without virtue cannot stand,
and without righteousness, he cannot live.
Virtue and righteousness are the true nature of the Perfect Man."*

Lǎo Jūn said:
*"Ah, nearly a falsehood!
A mosquito or flea biting the skin
keeps one awake all night.
But virtue and righteousness, cold and stern,
disturb my heart—
no greater chaos exists.
This condemns Confucius for not following the Great Way
but instead adhering to artificiality."*

**Citation:**
*"When the Master asked about ritual, he sighed at the Dragon’s virtue."*

Lǎo Jūn said:
*"A bird does not turn black by avoiding the sun,
nor does a crane turn white by avoiding bathing.
The distinction between black and white is not enough to prove anything,
nor is praise and blame sufficient to broaden one’s perspective.
When a spring dries up, fish gather on the land,
they pant to moisten each other,
they splash to wet each other—
yet this is not as good as forgetting each other in the rivers and lakes.
What you speak of is already the decayed bones of a man,
only his words remain.
A skilled merchant hides his wealth as if empty,
a gentleman of great virtue appears as if foolish.
Abandon your arrogance and excessive desires,
your mannerisms and licentious intentions—
these bring no benefit to your body.
This is what I tell you."*

When Confucius returned, he spoke for three days.
His disciples, puzzled, asked:
*"Master, what did you discuss with Lǎo Dān?"*

Confucius said:
*"When I was in Lǔ with you,
there were those whose intentions soared like flying geese—
I shaped my thoughts like bows and arrows to shoot them down,
and never failed to strike and surpass them.
There were those whose intentions drifted like wandering deer—
I shaped my thoughts like hounds to chase them,
and never failed to overtake and subdue them.
There were those whose intentions sank like fish into the ninefold depths—
I shaped my thoughts like hooks and lines to catch them,
and never failed to retrieve and control them.
But when I saw the Dragon,
I could not comprehend it.
The Dragon, when gathered, forms a complete body;
when dispersed, forms patterns.
It rides the clouds and is nourished by yin and yang,
wandering in the boundless purity—
I could not follow it.
When I saw Lǎo Jūn,
my mouth opened but could not speak,
my tongue extended but could not retract,
my form and spirit were exhausted and confused—
I could not know where I stood.
How could I question Lǎo Dān further?"*

**Citation:**
*"He remained in Zhōu for a long time."*

The *Yì* states:

Lǎo Jūn was born in the year *Gēnchén* (Regnal Year 9) of Emperor Wǔdīng of the Shang Dynasty in Kǔ County, Chu State. By the year *Dīngmǎo* (Regnal Year 21) of King Zhòu, he resided on the southern slopes of Qíshān, where he was known as *Xièyì’s Child*. The Wind Spirit led the way, and Pángzǔ followed as his attendant, to observe the transformations of the Western King. When the Western King heard of this, he summoned him to serve as the Keeper of the Treasury. Lǎo Jūn composed the *Chìjīng Jīng*, teaching the Way of *rén* and *xìn*. The Western King practiced it, honoring the worthy and cherishing virtue, and thus the mountains bowed. Hence, the *Lǐjì* states: *"The rise of the Zhou began at Qíyáng"*—this was the very time. Thereafter, Qíshān became the name of the prefecture, and Fèngxiáng the name of the commandery. This was indeed his work. The place where Lǎo Jūn resided was eighteen *lǐ* north of Fèngxiáng City. After the Tang received the Mandate, it established the *Qǐshèng Gōng* at his former dwelling.

When King Wǔ conquered the Shang, Lǎo Jūn was titled *Yùchéng’s Child* and composed the *Xuánjī Jīng*, which King Wǔ took as his teacher. During King Chéng’s reign, he was called *Jīngchéng’s Child*, and in King Kāng’s reign, *Guōshū’s Child*, still serving as the *Zhùxià Shǐ*. In lowly guise, he aided the Zhou until King Zhāo’s twenty-fifth year, when he crossed the Pass to civilize the Flowing Sands. From the year *Gēnchén* of Wǔdīng to the year *Guǐchǒu* of King Zhāo—two hundred and fifteen years—this is the same as Sīmǎ Qiān’s account of Lǎo Jūn residing in Zhou for over two hundred years.

**Commentary:** *He was about to open the Dao to the Western Extremity.*

The *Běnxiàng Jīng* states: In ancient times, the Wondrous *Fán* Heavenly King, greedy for pleasure and neglecting virtuous deeds, descended to be born as the *Fándúlì* King of *Jí*. Again, he indulged in hunting and slaughter without restraint. Thus, in King Zhāo’s time, Lǎo Jūn entered the Flowing Sands to the west, teaching him the *Fútú* methods and guiding him across.

Moreover, the Western barbarians were licentious and bloodthirsty, practicing perverse illusions and worshipping evil spirits. Lǎo Jūn went among them, transforming eighty-one kings of the Hu and ninety-six kinds of heretical external paths. Hence, it is said he *opened* and *guided* them. *Opening* means enlightening, *guiding* means transforming. The *Western Extremity* refers to the lands west of China—the eighty-one kingdoms of the Flowing Sands and beyond.

**Commentary:** *The Prefect of the Pass, Yìn Xǐ, requested the writing of the scriptures.*

Yìn Xǐ was a native of Tiānshuì, well-versed in the Five Classics, celestial omens, *wéi* divinations, and the books of *yīnyáng*, with none he did not master. Serving the Zhou, he became a minister under King Kāng. By King Zhāo’s twenty-fourth year, knowing that a sage would cross westward, he requested to be appointed Prefect of Hán Gǔ Pass to await Lǎo Jūn’s arrival.

There were eight divisions to this encounter:

1. **Manifesting Auspicious Omens** – In King Zhāo’s time, the *Tiān Lǐ* star moved westward into the constellation *Mǎo*, its true *qi* taking the form of a dragon-serpent, crossing the Han and bringing three gusts of warm wind. Purple clouds hovered over the Pass. Yìn Xǐ, seeing this, requested to be made Prefect to await the sage. The *Xiān Gōng* sequence states: Yìn Xǐ’s fate was bound to the Dao; he foreknew the purple clouds advancing westward and knew a sage would cross.

2. **Testing Yìn Xǐ with Pretenses** – On the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month, *Rénzǐ* year (King Zhāo’s twenty-fourth year), Lǎo Jūn rode a green ox in a light carriage, with Xú Jiā as his driver, approaching the Pass. He said, *"My home is east of the Pass, my fields west. Tomorrow is the winter solstice; the cold demands firewood."* Yìn Xǐ bowed twice and called himself his disciple, saying, *"Today I see you—you are a sage! I beg you to stay a little longer."* Again, Lǎo Jūn said, *"In the land of Zhú Qián there is an ancient master; I wish to ascend to him."* These were mere pretexts to test Yìn Xǐ.

3. **Transmitting the Dao and Virtue** – The *Dàodé Xù Jué* states: Lǎo Jūn told Yìn Xǐ, *"You should do this: benefit the world, abandon the realm of the worthy, propagate the Great Dao, and you shall become divine and immortal."* On the twenty-eighth day of that month, at noon, he transmitted the *Tàishàng Dàodé Jīng*. Thus, in the year *Guǐchǒu* (King Zhāo’s twenty-fifth year), on the fifth month’s *Rénwǔ* day, he departed Zhou. On the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month, he crossed the Pass, and on the twenty-eighth day, he transmitted the scripture. From his birth in the year *Gēnchén* of Wǔdīng to the year *Dīngmǎo* when King Wén received the Mandate, this was one hundred and eighty years. From King Zhāo’s twenty-fifth year, *Guǐchǒu*, another one hundred and seventy years—totaling two hundred and fifteen years—when he departed westward and crossed the Pass. The *Shǐjì* states that Lǎozi resided in Dài for over two hundred years before entering the Flowing Sands.

4. **Displaying Divine Powers** – The man who drove Lǎo Jūn’s carriage, Xú Jiā, was originally a withered corpse exposed in the grass. Moved by pity, Lǎo Jūn cast a *Tàixuān* talisman of life upon him, and he became a man, following Lǎo Jūn for over two hundred years. Lǎo Jūn had agreed to pay him one hundred *jīn* of gold per day, and when they reached Dà Qín and Ānxī, he would repay him in gold. Jiā, upon reaching the Pass, took pleasure in a woman and did not wish to follow Lǎo Jūn westward. He wrote a petition to Yìn Xǐ, accusing Lǎo Jūn and demanding his daily wages. Lǎo Jūn said to Jiā, *"You were once a withered corpse; I saved you with the *Tàixuān* talisman of life, making you a man. Now return the talisman, and I will repay your gold."* As he spoke, the talisman emerged from Jiā’s mouth, and he reverted to a withered corpse. Yìn Xǐ, seeing this, was terrified, kowtowed, and begged for mercy. Lǎo Jūn then cast the talisman upon him again, and Jiā resumed his former form. Yìn Xǐ, witnessing these divine transformations, became even more reverent.

5. **Returning Together to Lóuguān** – Yìn Xǐ, as Prefect of Hán Gǔ Pass, was stationed at the ruins of the ancient pass twelve *lǐ* south of Táolín County, Shǎnzhōu. In the first year of *Tiānbǎo* (742 CE), on the seventh day of the first month, *Rénwǔ*, Lǎo Jūn descended to the *Dānfèng Lóu* and revealed himself to the *Shǐmù* of Chén Wáng’s palace, Tián Tóngxiù. He produced the *Tiānbǎo Língfú*, stating that it was buried beneath the withered mulberry tree in the old residence of Yìn Xǐ at the ancient Hán Gǔ Pass. By imperial decree, Daoists and palace officials were sent to excavate beneath the tree, where a stone chest was found containing the *Tiānbǎo Língfú*, accompanied by purple clouds and a white rabbit. The emperor then granted a general amnesty and renamed Táolín County *Língbǎo County*.

At that very site, the **Língfú Guān** was established, and an imperial inscription was composed and inscribed on a stele, which remains to this day.

On the twenty-eighth day, Yìn Xǐ received the *Dàodé* and *Èrjīng*. Later, he returned with Lǎo Jūn from Hán Gǔ Pass to tidy his dwelling in the shadow of Zhǒngnán Mountain, where Yìn Xǐ had once resided. The dwelling was the very place where he had built a thatched pavilion to **observe the stars and divine the qi**.

After Yìn Xǐ ascended to heaven, it was traditionally called **Lóuguān**.

King Mù of Zhōu summoned the recluse Dù Chōng and Yìn Xǐ’s younger brother, Yìn Xuān, to dwell there. Within the precincts stood Lǎo Jūn’s **chariot board** and the **supporting-leather tree**. Across successive dynasties of Qin and Hán, emperors paid homage to the board, and even the brushstrokes of Qín Shǐhuáng’s ink remain preserved.

**Sixth [section]: Ascending into Tàiwéi**

When Lǎo Jūn expounded the scriptures to Yìn Xǐ and completed the transmission of the **Jiǔdān** and other precepts, on the twenty-sixth year of Zhāo Wáng, *Jiǎyín* month, fourth day, he ascended from Yìn Xǐ’s residence on South Mountain into Tàiwéi.

The *Xī Shēng Jīng* states:
*"After expounding the scriptures, Lǎo Jūn suddenly vanished. In a moment, the halls and lodgings blazed with radiant light—five colors mingling with dark and bright yellow. Yìn Xǐ stepped into the courtyard, knelt, and prayed: ‘O Divine Sage, grant me one more glimpse! Let me grasp a single essential principle to preserve the Primordial One.’*

*Suddenly, he beheld a golden figure—now alive, now fading, ever shifting between youth and age. Lǎo Jūn again addressed Yìn Xǐ: ‘Eliminate defilements, cease fixation, quiet the mind, and hold fast to the One. When all defilements are purged, all matters are complete. This is the essence of my Dao.’"*

Seventh, **the Meeting with the Green Sheep** was appointed. As Lǎo Jūn prepared to ascend into Tàiwéi, he told Yìn Xǐ: *"When the thousand-day practice is complete, seek me at the Green Sheep Market in Shù."* Yìn Xǐ then feigned illness and abandoned his position, eliminating defilements, ceasing fixation, quieting the mind, and holding fast to the One.

In the twenty-ninth year of Zhāo Wáng, on a *Dīngwèi* day, he entered Shù and met Lǎo Jūn at the Green Sheep Market. The Green Sheep Market lay five *lǐ* southwest of Chéngdū County, facing the great river. Ancient traditions recounted that it often displayed divine responses. In the second year of Zhōnghé, on a *Rén yín* day, when the Emperor Xī Zōng halted his procession in Shù, he obtained a sacred brick with ancient inscriptions. The auspicious signs moved the court, and the emperor personally visited the site, offering reverence and decreeing the establishment of the Green Sheep Palace. The brick bore the inscription: *"Supreme Sovereign Pacifies the Zhōnghé Calamity"* (六字: *Tàishàng píng zhōnghé zāi*).

Following the acquisition of the brick, the next year saw the recovery of Cháng'ān, and the year after, the emperor returned to the capital. **Eighth, both ascended to the Western Extreme.**

Three years after their separation, Yìn Xǐ’s thousand-day practice was complete. In the *Dīngwèi* year, he entered Shù and met Lǎo Jūn at the Green Sheep Market. Together, they rode upon clouds, traversed the celestial waters, ascended the Three Caverns, passed through the Nine Heavens, and finally transformed westward into the Flowing Sands, encompassing over eighty realms.

In the ninth month, twelfth day of the second year of Zhōnghé, due to the auspicious signs of the sacred brick, the emperor issued a decree: *"In ancient times, the Holy Ancestor, the Emperor Xiānyuán, expounded the True Scriptures with his disciple, the Master Wénshǐ, on the platform of Lóuguān. They agreed to reunite at the Green Sheep Market, riding upon clouds and transforming together into the Flowing Sands—a record passed down in immortal annals and marked upon terrestrial maps. From the time of Emperor Zhāo Wáng down to this day, spanning nearly two thousand years, their divine forms have faded into obscurity, and their traces have vanished. Now, with the imperial procession traversing the land, the radiant signs are manifest: pearly light leaping in the courtyard, sacred inscriptions revealed beneath the trees, the brick bearing ancient hues, and the characters verifying the auspicious omens. The Zhōnghé calamity is nearing its end, and the grand celestial blessings have now appeared. This demonstrates the descent of Heavenly favor and the Supreme Sovereign’s gracious portents, destined to annihilate the bandit’s arms and perpetually illuminate the cause of the Renewed Prosperity. It is fitting to inscribe these texts, proclaiming them to all regions and the military, and to bestow internal and external treasury funds upon this site. The Green Sheep Palace shall be established to honor these auspicious signs. Those entrusted with recording this in the Imperial Archives shall verify the transformations into the Flowing Sands, making them even more evident."*

**Annotations:**
*"Zhuó"* (着) here means **recorded or inscribed**—both the act of documenting and the resulting text.
It is also said that this was the time when the scriptures were composed, though they were originally expounded during the reign of Emperor Shùn and later granted to Yìn Xǐ. This is not a later composition but a reaffirmation of the teachings.

**Commentary:**
*"Thus, two treatises were expounded."* **Explication:** *"Thus"* marks the beginning of a new sentence. *"Expounded"* means to **elucidate and broaden the principles** of the Dao. The *"two treatises"* refer to the **Dàodé Jīng** and **Lǎozǐ’s other scriptures.**

The *Wáng Zǐ Nián Shíyí Jì* states:
*"Lǎo Jūn dwelled upon the Jǐngshì Mountains, cutting off all traces with the world. Only five ancient elders—some riding resonant cranes, others clad in feathered robes—discussed the numbers of Heaven and Earth. Their compiled scriptures amounted to ten thousand words. Two men from the Fútí realm offered pure ink, appearing now old, now young, vanishing into formlessness when unseen, concealing themselves when heard. At times, they emerged from a golden vessel containing a black fluid, resembling thick lacquer, which inscribed upon wood and stone the characters of the Eight Trigrams and Sixteen Hexagrams, recording the origins of creation and human kind. All the scriptures authored by Lǎo Jūn were inscribed upon jade tablets, bound with golden cords, and stored in jade cases. When the black fluid in the golden vessel was exhausted, the two men sought to carve their hearts and drip their blood as ink. This was the Jǐngshàn of Luózhōu, including the Lesser and Greater Caverns. The scriptures they spoke of—such as those on the Nine Transformations and Longevity—numbered a million, most hidden in sacred mountain chambers and kept secret. Now, the revealed texts amount to roughly six thousand volumes, all containing profound teachings for the realm and grand applications for nurturing life—not merely the two treatises on Dao and Virtue. These two scriptures are indeed the ones granted to Yìn Xǐ at the Hángǔ Valley."*

**Explication:**
*"Illuminating the source of Dao and the nurturing of Virtue, none escape its completeness."* **Meaning:** The Dao generates Virtue, which is the foundation of transformation. All laws arise from the Dao, hence it is called the **source**. It also likens the Dao to an endless spring, whose waters flow without depletion. *"Wǎng"* (罔) means **none** or **not**. The scriptures here record the origin and foundation of all transformations, exhaustively and without end.

**Explication:**
*"Its essence lies in harmonizing the body and rectifying the realm."* **Meaning:** The *Wénzǐ* in the *Tōngxiān Zhēnxīng Jīng* asked Lǎo Jūn: *"How does one rectify the realm?"* Lǎo Jūn replied: *"Rectification begins with harmonizing the self. One who has not first rectified the self cannot rectify the realm, nor can one whose self is disordered rectify the realm. The foundation of rectifying the realm lies in tranquility to cultivate the self and completeness to nurture life, thus preventing the people from disturbance. When the people are undisturbed, they do not grumble. The foundation of rectifying the realm lies in sufficient resources; the foundation of sufficient resources lies in not taking from others; the foundation of not taking lies in reducing affairs; the foundation of reducing affairs lies in moderation; the foundation of moderation lies in discernment of priorities—*"*

「The foundation of *going and staying* lies in *wuwei*—non-action. The heavens achieve their height, the earth their depth, the sun and moon shine, the stars follow their courses, and yin and yang harmonize—all without deliberate effort.

To align with the *Dao*, things naturally transform. This is the essence of *absolving pride and ostentation* and *discarding superficiality for simplicity*—the principle of *wuwei* and *non-speech* as teaching.

The opening passage of the *Lower Canon* states: *"A true gentleman dwells in substance, not in superficiality; in reality, not in ornamentation."* The second passage of the *Upper Canon* says: *"Thus, the Sage acts in non-action and governs through non-speech."* Teaching here means to *instruct and transform* people, so that guidance may endure eternally.

The *Analects* says: *"The Master employed four methods of teaching."* The *Preface to the Book of Songs* says: *"Teaching transforms through cultivation."* The *I Ching* says: *"The Sage establishes teaching through the mysterious *Dao*."* Speech-teaching means to *instruct* people.

Yet the multitude of teachings in the world all take *attachment and deliberate action* as their foundation. Now, the *Dao* of Lǎo Jūn is rooted in *wuwei* and *non-speech* as transformation—thus it is held in esteem by all teachings and prized by those who understand the *Dao*.

The *Comprehensive Explication of the Daoist Canon of Virtue and Way* concludes its third and fourth volumes.»

Du Guangcheng of the Tang Dynasty, annotated by Master Yu Liu, *Commentary on the Lower Section*:

**On cultivating the body:**
To cultivate the body, one must minimize private desires and reduce cravings, striving for an empty heart and a filled belly.
*Explanation:* Minimizing private desires and reducing cravings, achieving an empty heart and a filled belly—this is as the *Upper Scripture*, Chapter 19, states: *"Manifesting simplicity, embracing purity, minimizing private desires, reducing cravings."* The *Upper Scripture*, Chapter 3, states: *"Empty the heart, fill the belly."* The preceding scriptural references are all elucidated in the *Authentic Scripture*. Below, further distinctions shall be made.
*Matter* refers to the general term for all undertakings. The *Analects* states: *"The gentleman attends to the root"*—this is the same.

*Commentary:* Here lies the essential meaning, which can be articulated.
*Explanation:* *Essence* means the critical principle; *meaning* refers to the ultimate aim. This Scripture is the ultimate aim for cultivating the body and the critical principle for governing the state. It can be spoken of, and thus it can be articulated.

**On exhausting principles and fulfilling nature, severing attachments and stilling thoughts:**
*Explanation:* The *I Ching* states: *"Exhausting principles and fulfilling nature, until one reaches the utmost"*—meaning to penetrate the profound mysteries of all things, exhausting the inherent nature bestowed upon living beings. When the principles of things are exhausted and the true nature is fulfilled, one reaches unity. Another interpretation states: *"Exhausting principles"* means reaching the ultimate mysterious principles; *"fulfilling nature"* means investigating true nature. These mysterious principles and true natures are too profound and subtle to be articulated by words, though they can be discerned by the divine insight.

*Severing attachments and stilling thoughts* refers to desires arising from engaging with phenomena—this is called *attachment*; fixations arising from mental clinging—this is called *thought*. Within this doctrine, these are divided into four categories:
1. When the mind follows virtuous phenomena and generates virtuous desires, this is called *virtuous attachment*.
2. When the mind follows malevolent phenomena and generates malevolent desires, this is called *malevolent attachment*.
3. When the mind fixates on virtuous thoughts and generates virtuous contemplations, this is called *virtuous thought*.
4. When the mind fixates on malevolent thoughts and generates malevolent contemplations, this is called *malevolent thought*.

Though all arise from engaging with phenomena, they are divided into virtuous and malevolent. Beginners in the Dao must first sever malevolent attachments and still malevolent thoughts, thereby calming the mind. When the mind is serene and the *qi* is steady, thoughts and contemplations become genuine, gradually entering the Dao. Even virtuous attachments and thoughts are forgotten. When the profound principles are exhausted and true nature is fully realized, attachments and thoughts are both forgotten—only then can one attain the Dao. Hence it is said: *"Exhaust principles and fulfill nature, sever attachments and still thoughts."*

**On dwelling in reality and employing expedient means:**
*Explanation:* *Dwelling* means abiding. *Reality* refers to true truth and profound subtlety—the Dao of wondrous origin and the path of the Great Vehicle. *Expedient means* refers to adapting to circumstances, establishing teachings according to the times—this is the Middle Vehicle’s path to induce enlightenment, akin to the principles of governing the state and cultivating the body. First, one relies on expedient teachings, then enters the Great Dao.

*Teachings of reality* are as the *Upper Scripture*, Chapter 35, states: *"Hold fast to the Great Image, and all under heaven will come."* It also states: *"I shall govern it with the nameless Purity."* And again: *"From ancient times to the present, its name does not depart."* *Expedient teachings* are as the *Upper Scripture*, Chapter 36, states: *"When one seeks to contract it, one must first expand it; when one seeks to abolish it, one must first establish it."*

**On seated forgetting and abandoning illumination:**
*Explanation:* *Seated forgetting* means collapsing limbs, abandoning sensory perception, discarding form and wisdom, reaching Great Harmony. This is called *seated forgetting*. The ultimate Dao is too profound and subtle to be proclaimed in words; it can only be discerned by the mind. Once enlightenment is attained through illumination, even the illumination is forgotten. Hence it is said: *"Seated forgetting, abandoning illumination."* These are all teachings of the Great Vehicle.

**On diminishing again and again, making profound again and again, nearly beyond articulation or transmission:**
*Explanation:* Those who practice the Dao abandon the coarse to attain the subtle, diminishing again and again, gradually entering profound subtlety. Making profound again and again—this is ascending to true aspiration. The *Lower Scripture*, Chapter 48, states: *"Diminish again and again, until reaching non-action."* The *Upper Scripture*, Chapter 1, states: *"Making profound again and again, the gate of all mysteries."* This is attaining the profound and aligning with non-action—words cannot articulate it, nor can phrases describe it. Laozi said: *"If the Dao could be offered, I would offer it to my lord. If the Dao could be transmitted, I would transmit it to my son."* Indeed, it is not something that can be transmitted through words. *Diminishing* means annihilation; *profound* means deep subtlety.

**On its teachings being complete:**
*Explanation:* There are five teachings, divided into five categories:
1. *Dulling sharpness and resolving conflicts, blending light and harmonizing with dust*—this is the initial teaching.
2. *Manifesting simplicity and embracing purity, emptying the heart and filling the belly*—this is the gradual teaching.
3. *Externalizing the self while preserving it, yielding the self while advancing it*—this is the intermediate teaching.
4. *Diminishing again and again until reaching non-action, in non-action doing all things*—this is the complete teaching, where nothing is left unattended.
5. *Serene and ever-present, using it without exertion. Heaven and Earth have an end, but the Great Dao does not change*—this is the complete teaching.

Together, these form the teachings, encompassing all five categories, embracing all practices—hence it is said: *"Its teachings are complete."* *Complete* means universally permeating, the Dao being nowhere absent.

**On its text being concise:**
*Explanation:* *Concise* means limited and succinct. Within two scrolls, it encompasses all laws. Is this not concise?

**On its meaning being expansive:**
*Explanation:* *Expansive* means comprehensive. My words are easy to know, easy to practice—words have their origin, affairs have their master. Is this not expansive?

**On its speech being near:**
*Explanation:* *Near* means close. Observing oneself through oneself, observing the family through the family—without leaving the door, one knows the world; without peering through the window, one sees the Dao of Heaven. Is this not near?

**Thus, those who wander in its outer halls**
*Explanation:* *Halls* refers to the veranda; *regions* refers to the porch beneath the hall; *inner chambers* refers to the innermost sanctum, specifically the southwest corner.

「The scholars of the world and those who practice the Dao,
upon first seeing this scripture, claim to have fathomed the principles and exhausted the nature,
to have reached the utmost subtlety of the mysterious.

**Commentary:** But when they delve deeply and ponder thoroughly,
they realize that even at the tip of an autumn hare’s hair,
they have yet to grasp one ten-thousandth of its essence.

**Explanation:** Through profound inquiry and rigorous contemplation,
they examine the essence and ponder its workings,
explore the Dao’s deepest mysteries and trace its origins,
annotate and elucidate to seek the Sage’s intent—
the principles they uncover grow ever scarcer,
while the Sage’s meaning deepens beyond measure.

Guo Xiang says: The tip of an autumn hare’s hair is fine indeed,
yet they have not even attained one ten-thousandth of it.

The autumn hare’s hair refers to the fur a rabbit grows in autumn.
The *end* is its tip.

**Commentary:** The scripture states: *"There is a formless substance, born before Heaven and Earth."*

I do not know its name,
so I call it **Dao** and forcefully name it **Great**.
**Explanation:** Here, it cites the *Dao De Jing*’s twenty-fifth chapter
to validate the wondrous name of the Dao.

*"There is a formless substance"*—
a presence without a medium,
a vague and indistinct entity.
*"Mixed and unified"*—
before Heaven and Earth were divided,
it was called **Hun Dun** (Chaos).
Heaven was contained within Earth,
a boundless, formless void—
Heaven and Earth floated upon water,
accumulated within **Qi**,
thus it is called **Hun Yuan** (Primordial Chaos).
For it was from the Dao’s **Qi** that transformation and birth arose,
distributing forms and portents,
and thus Heaven and Earth came to be.
Yet the Dao’s **Qi** existed before Heaven and Earth,
while Heaven and Earth emerged after the Dao’s **Qi** was generated.
Hence, it says: *"There is a formless substance, born before Heaven and Earth."*
