Zhuangzi says: *"The Great Dao—
before Heaven and Earth existed, it has eternally endured from antiquity."*

*"I"*—
the self-reference of Laozi.

The state of *"mixed and unified"*—
a hazy, indistinct form—
stands before Heaven and before Earth,
independent and boundless,
without a name proclaimed,
silent where words should be.
Thus Laozi forcefully establishes a character,
names it **Dao**,
and forcefully establishes a title,
calls it **Great**.
Its Dao is vast and boundless,
encompassing Heaven and Earth,
penetrating all things,
hence the name **Great Dao**.

**Commentary:** Thus, one knows that the **Great Dao** is a forceful name
for the **supreme void** and **mysterious origin**,
speaking to its universal generative power.

**Explanation:** The Dao has **emotion** and **truth**,
yet is **non-action** and **formless**.
It can be transmitted but not bestowed,
obtained but not seen—
existing beyond the **Great Polarity** yet not elevated,
beneath the **Six Extremes** yet not deep.
Hence, it is called the **supreme void’s mysterious origin**.

Because it gives birth to Heaven and Earth,
to spirits and divine emperors,
it is said to be the universal generative power.
The Dao is **universal**.
The **void** is **utter emptiness**.
The **extreme** is **utter height**.
The **mysterious** is **utter profundity**.
The **origin** is the **source of transformation**.

**Commentary:** Zhuangzi says:
*"At the beginning of all, there is the Void and the Non-Void.
The Non-Void without name—
this is before any forceful naming."*

Thus the scripture says:
*"The unnamed is the beginning of Heaven and Earth."*

**Explanation:** Zhuangzi, of the surname Zhuang and given name Zhou,
was from Mengyi in the state of Song.
During the reigns of King Wen of Zhao, King Xuan of Qi, and King Hui of Liang,
he studied under Master Sang Gongzi,
received his subtle teachings,
and retired to Baoxie Mountain,
where he ingested the **Great Elixir** and ascended to Heaven,
holding the title **Weibian Officer of the Great Polarity**,
serving the Celestial Sovereign in the morning court.

Jì Kāng says:
*"He also studied under Master Qián Zǐ,
and during his lifetime served as a **lacquer-garden official**,
composing thirty-three works,
all expounding the Dao’s boundless, effortless principles."*

In the fourth year of Tianbao in the **Great Tang Dynasty** (April),
he was posthumously enshrined as **Zhenren of Nan Hua**,
and his works were titled *The Nan Hua Zhen Jing*.
This passage cites the twelfth chapter, *"The Heaven and Earth."*

The **"beginning of all"**—
this is before **Qi** manifested.
The **"Void and Non-Void"**—
the Non-Void lacks name because it is without form.
This refers to the Dao before any forceful naming was established—
the Great Dao was unnamed,
and only when named was it called **Dao**.
The initial forceful naming marks the beginning of Heaven and Earth.

**Commentary:** The Dao is forcefully named as the **universal generative principle**,
thus the scripture says:
*"The named is the mother of all things."*

**Explanation:** The Dao is **universal**.
It generates and transforms all things through **one Qi**,
and because it gives birth to things,
it is called the **mother of all things**.
The term *mother* signifies **nurturing abundance**.
The scripture’s words point to its opening chapter,
citing this passage to validate the Dao’s name.

**Commentary:** Zhuangzi also says:
*"When things obtain the Dao, they are called virtue."*

**Explanation:** This is from the *"Heaven and Earth"* chapter of *Zhuangzi*.
The **void** alone cannot generate things,
but when things obtain the Dao’s subtle and mysterious **Qi**,
they can self-generate—
this is **self-attainment**.
Left to their own self-attainment,
it is called **virtue**.

**Commentary:** Virtue is **attainment**.
Heaven and Earth undergo ten thousand changes,
permeating all categories of things,
all relying on the mysterious origin to manifest and thrive—
attaining generation is virtue.

**Explanation:** Virtue is what humans attain.
The Three Realms and all things draw upon the Dao’s wondrous applications,
each attaining their own generation and fulfillment,
none failing to align with their nature—
hence it is called **virtue**.

*"Permeating all"*—
meaning **all-encompassing**.
*"Categories of things"*—
all things.
*"Relying"*—
taking, utilizing.
*"Mysterious origin"*—
the Dao.

**Commentary:** Thus the scripture says:
*"The Dao gives birth to them; virtue nourishes them."*

**Explanation:** This is from the fourteenth chapter below.
It cites the main text to reiterate the meaning of **Dao** and **virtue**,
aligning with Zhuangzi’s principle that *"things obtain the Dao to generate."*
This clarifies that the **void** is the root,
while the **non-void** is its function.
**Dao** and **virtue** are interdependent,
serving as the themes for the upper and lower chapters.

**Commentary:** Thus, one knows that **Dao** is the **substance of virtue**,
and **virtue** is the **function of Dao**.

**Explanation:** The **true and solid** is called **substance**,
while **adaptive response** is called **function**—
the **Dao’s profound and boundless** transformations
generate and fulfill all things,
leaving no trace,
hence it is called **substance**—
the **wondrous substance**.
Zhuangzi says:
*"Its coming is without trace,
its departure is without limit—
no gate, no side,
the sovereign of fourfold reach, majestic and boundless."*

「Through this wondrous substance, life and death unfold in endless cycles,
and all living things transform naturally—
their existence visible yet not controlled,
hence it is called **function**.
This is the **wondrous function**.
Zhuangzi says:
*"The luminous arises from the obscure,
the manifest from the formless*—
this is the case.

**Commentary:** And thus the scripture divides into upper and lower chapters.
**Explanation:** The obscure Dao is the upper.
The luminous virtue is the lower.
The Great Sage expounds the scripture,
originally making no distinction between Dao above and virtue below.
Yet those who interpret it forcibly divide it,
claiming that **Dao** without **virtue** lacks manifestation,
and **virtue** without **Dao** lacks clarity—
**Dao** being formless and without action,
thus precedes the transformation of things;
**virtue** being active and purposeful,
thus follows after life and transformation.
Since **Dao** precedes, it is placed above;
since **virtue** follows, it is placed below.
Thus, the upper and lower chapters are divided,
just as the clear heaven resides above,
and the turbid earth below.

**Commentary:** First, **Dao** is clarified, then **virtue** follows.
**Explanation:** The wondrous void generates the wondrous non-void,
from the subtle to the coarse.
The "following" refers to what is secondary—
the order of precedence.
**Commentary:** Yet the names of substance and function may be dispersed.
**Explanation:** The subtle and coarse, the precedence and sequence,
may be spoken of in pairs.
Substance is subtle as the root—
the uncarved block;
function is coarse as the end—
the vessel.
Hence it is said to be dispersed.
**Commentary:** But the reality of substance and function cannot be dispersed.
**Explanation:** They are in harmony with the void,
hence cannot be dispersed.
Dispersed refers to division and distinction.
Though distinctions arise through function,
in the beginning and end of life and transformation,
where they rely on and complement each other,
returning to the source of their true nature,
they cannot be truly dispersed.
All forms differ yet contain the wondrous Dao.
**Commentary:** Therefore, the scripture states:
*"Same origin, different names—
same called the Mysterious."*
**Explanation:** The wondrous substance and function arise from the wondrous void—
this is their same origin.
From subtle to coarse—
this is their differing names.
Merged as one—
this is why they are called the Mysterious.
**Commentary:** When spoken of as arising, they are divided into two;
when observed in their essence, they merge as one.
**Explanation:** Divided into two refers to substance and function.
Merged as one refers to returning to the wondrous source.
Zhuangzi says:
*"Majestic and vast—
its end is but the beginning again."*
**Commentary:** Hence it is said that they may be dispersed yet cannot be.
**Explanation:** Though substance and function differ,
how can they be truly dispersed?
They illuminate each other—
thus they cannot be dispersed.

**Commentary:** The upper chapter states:
*"This is called the Mysterious Virtue,"*
*"The vast container of Virtue,"*
*"Virtue is aligned with Virtue,"*
*"Constant Virtue does not depart."*
**Explanation:** In the *Dao* scripture,
these passages clarify that **virtue** illuminates **Dao**.

**Commentary:** The lower chapter states:
*"Lost the Dao, then Virtue appears,"*
*"Reversion is the movement of the Dao,"*
*"The Dao generates One,"*
*"The Great Dao is most easy."*
**Explanation:** In the *Virtue* scripture,
these passages clarify that **Dao** is the foundation of **virtue**.

**Commentary:** This is their mutual exposition,
each revealing the essence in turn.
**Explanation:** **Dao** illuminates **virtue**, **virtue** aligns with **Dao**—
this is their mutual exposition.
Mutual means reciprocal, differing yet complementary.
Exposition means to unfold.
Examining their principles together,
all reach the utmost subtlety—
this is what is meant by "cannot be dispersed."

**Commentary:** They need not be rigidly named as upper or lower.
**Explanation:** Though externally **Dao** and **virtue** differ,
the scripture’s mutual exposition means
one cannot designate the *Dao* scripture as upper
and the *Virtue* scripture as lower.
Those who now distinguish them
do so by force, not by the true essence of the Mysterious.

**Commentary:** The scripture is a path.
**Explanation:** It is the way to practice the Dao,
the gate to ascend to the True.
Left Ru says:
*"The scripture is the unalterable book."*
The essence of the Dao is conveyed through this path.
**Commentary:** It is also the constant way.
**Explanation:** Through the scripture, the Dao is conveyed,
and thus the Dao is forever illuminated.
Hence it is called the constant way.
From the mundane to the immortal,
from the extreme of immortality to eternal fruit,
the teachings descend in writing through endless ages,
universally saving all without end—
eternal peace, long life—
all stem from this teaching.
Thus it is said to be the constant path of practice.

**Commentary:** The Sage’s ancestors imparted their teachings,
passing them to their descendants.
**Explanation:** *Every* means repeatedly, *incumbency* means reverence.
The Sage’s ancestors—Laozi the Old Master—
imparted their teachings,
bestowing them upon their descendants.
As in the *Book of Songs* ["King Wen’s Odes" – *"King Wen’s Odes"* is a placeholder for the exact title, likely **《文王有声》**]:
*"Passing their plans to their descendants,
to shelter and nurture them with their wings."*
This means that King Wu could expand King Wen’s teachings,
enhance his achievements,
and transmit the realm to his descendants.
It speaks of the Mysterious Origin,
the Sage’s ancestors imparting the teachings of
effortless stillness and clarity,
reaching our Tang descendants,
and with this imperial plan,
propagating and magnifying the Dao’s transformation.

**Commentary:** In moments of rest from governing,
the Emperor diligently studies and expounds.
**Explanation:** The Son of Heaven sits enthroned facing south,
listening to the affairs of the realm.
Governance is also *principle*.
In the leisure of listening to affairs,
he studies the two scriptures,
just as Yi did in the night.
The term *file* refers to reading,
*commentary* to expounding.
Having read the text,
he expounds its meaning,
thus creating annotations and commentaries.
Diligently studying means
unceasingly searching and elucidating.
The *remainder* is the time of leisure.

**Commentary:** Now, I again briefly expound the annotations.
**Explanation:** *Expound* means to evaluate.
To elucidate the true meaning,
to examine the Mysterious subtleties,
and to unfold these two teachings—
this captures the essence of
governing the realm and cultivating the self,
effortless stillness and clarity.

**Commentary:** The most essential and wondrous points
cannot be fully conveyed by writing.
**Explanation:** *Essential* means the utmost subtlety,
*wondrous* means the Mysterious profundity.
The utmost subtlety and Mysterious profundity
cannot be transmitted through books.
The principles transcend words and arguments,
hence it is said that books cannot exhaust the meaning.

The *Yijing* says: "Books cannot exhaust words, words cannot exhaust meaning."
Indeed, the unspoken words are the ultimate words,
and the principles that reach their full extent are the ultimate principles.
Only then can one penetrate the Mysterious and fathom the profound,
achieve enlightenment and forget words—
this is why such teachings cannot be fully conveyed by mere texts.

**Commentary:** Here I merely outline the broad strokes,
to aid and assist those who study.

**Explanation:** *Merely* means not thorough, *outline* means to summarize briefly.
*Aid* means to benefit, *assist* means to support.
*Broad strokes* refers to the main threads—
like the cords that bind a net, from which all its strands hang,
or the collar that holds a garment together.
The *Huainanzi* says: "Raise the main threads, and all the strands unfurl."
This is the term for summarizing the multitude of threads.
By raising the main threads, all the strands become visible.
This commentary is meant to support and benefit those who lecture and study,
expanding their knowledge and insight.

I humbly reflect that the Heavenly Scriptures shine resplendent,
displaying the sun and moon to harmonize their brilliance,
while the Saintly Teachings are profound and subtle,
coexisting with Heaven and Earth in eternal motion.
They enter deeply into the realm of Nature,
and open vast the doors to all wonders.
They elevate the peaks of words to tower above the masses,
and plumb the depths of meaning to reach the ocean’s vastness.
Those lost in error dissolve their doubts at a mere glance,
and those straying return to the path upon hearing the teachings.
The True Ancestor expounded the utmost subtlety in the beginning,
and the Wise Descendant praised the Mysterious profundity thereafter.
The two Saints composed their works,
unmatched through all ages,
yet still they speak of aiding and assisting,
demonstrating their humility and modesty,
further illuminating their Saintly Intent.

**Commentary:** In total, there are six volumes.

**Explanation:** *In total* refers to the general outline, a sweeping overview.
The *Chunqiu xu* says: "To generalize is to state the rules."
The two main sections (upper and lower) each have three volumes of commentary,
also roughly illustrating the meaning of "one life, three stages."
Six is the number of Yin, while three is the number of Yang.
Three symbolizes *Qian*—when *Qian* combines with *Qian*, it becomes *Kun*.
Separated, it is Yang; combined, it is Yin.
This commentary encompasses the essentials of Heaven and Earth,
and exhausts the subtleties of Yin and Yang’s transformations—
thus it forms six volumes.

Moreover, *in total* is also the name for the birth of the upper and the rise of the lower.

---
The *Dao/Way and Virtue/Power True Scripture* – *Expounding Saintly Teachings* (Volume IV completed)
The *Dao/Way and Virtue/Power True Scripture* – *Expounding Saintly Teachings* (Volume V completed)

The *Dao/Way and Virtue/Power True Scripture* – *Expounding Saintly Teachings* (as expounded by Master Guangcheng of the Tang, Du Guangting)
*Explication of the Title: The Dao/Way and Virtue/Power Scripture*

**Explication of the Meaning:**
The *Laozi* is the inner title of the *Taishang Laojun*. The interpretation has already been fully explained in the preceding section.

The *Dao/Way Scripture* refers to these two scrolls of the text, with the Upper Scroll taking *Dao/Way* as its heading. The *Dao/Way* permeates and guides all living beings, penetrates and transcends all *dharma/law*, and stands at the forefront of all *dharma/law*—thus the Three Sovereigns revered its *Dao/Way*. It precedes all teachings, hence the Great Performance (of the Dao) manifests its boundless essence. Therefore, "one" is the count of *Dao/Way*, and *Dao/Way* is the origin of "one." The Lower Scroll states, *"The Dao/Way gives birth to One"*—this is the same meaning.

As for its *Dao/Way*, it exhausts the wondrous subtleties of boundless emptiness and fulfills the divine function of transformation and salvation. Its principles permeate the process of generation, and its meaning encompasses cause and effect. When applied to oneself, it leads to the simultaneous transcendence of self and object; when embraced in the heart, it achieves the dual absolution of existence and non-existence.

The *Dao/Way* and *Virtue/Power* share a reciprocal and interdependent meaning—thus it is called the *Dao/Way and Virtue/Power Scripture*. Here, within the *Dao/Way and Virtue/Power Scripture*, we elucidate three categories:

1. **Explicating the Nameless Name**—to clarify the profound teachings of the Dao/Way. Hence the Scripture says, *"The constant emptiness naturally endures;"* yet, to name the Great Dao/Way, we must assign a label. Thus, the Dao/Way’s essence is in the "Nameless," while its practical application may appear flawed; *Virtue/Power*’s essence is in the "Having," yet it resolves all worldly doubts. Hence, the *Zang Xuanjing* says: *"The Dao/Way’s meaning lies in its ability to penetrate all things through emptiness."* Now, to clarify the Dao/Way’s threefold meaning:

   - **Principle** (*li*), for discerning the reality of emptiness and distinguishing good and evil.
   - **Guidance** (*dao*), for leading adherents to forget their attachments and guiding the common into the saintly.
   - **Penetration** (*tong*), for generating all *dharma/law* and achieving transformation without obstruction.

The Upper Scroll embodies Yang’s celestial symbolism, hence its thirty-seven chapters. The *Laojun* did not originally distinguish the Upper Scroll as *Dao/Way* and the Lower as *Virtue/Power*—rather, the tradition of past sages divided them as such. Thus, *Dao/Way* precedes *Virtue/Power*, though their texts mutually illuminate and verify one another, as detailed in the preface.

Next, the decline of *Dao/Way* gave rise to *Virtue/Power*, and the decline of *Virtue/Power* led to the Five Constants (*wuxing*). This demonstrates that *Dao/Way and Virtue/Power* are the foundation of all practices, the root of the Five Constants. Hence, the *Dao/Way Scripture* comes first, followed by the *Virtue/Power Scripture*.

Now, in accordance with the title, we elucidate *Dao/Way* as the **Principle**, **Penetration**, and **Guidance**—as stated in the preface. The threefold explication of *Dao/Way and Virtue/Power* consists of:

1. **Explicating the Name**—the Dao/Way is profound and absolute, naturally deserving the "Nameless." Yet, to initiate teachings and guide the common, we must establish a designation. Thus, we borrow the "Nameless" as a label to convey its true principle, so that one may recognize the "Nameless" within the name and truly grasp the Dao/Way’s profound designation as *Dao/Way and Virtue/Power*. What is its meaning? The *Zang Xuanjing* says: *"The Dao/Way’s function is to penetrate all things through emptiness."* *Virtue/Power* means not losing—its function is in the "Having." The Dao/Way’s emptiness can dispel the burdens of material existence; *Virtue/Power*’s having can remove all worldly doubts.

Now, we clarify the Dao/Way’s threefold meaning: **Principle**, **Penetration**, and **Guidance**. *Virtue/Power*’s threefold meaning is: **Attainment**, **Fulfillment**, and **Non-Loss**.

The meaning of **Principle** is to discern the reality of emptiness—speaking of all things as empty, hence it says, *"The Dao/Way dwells within all that has."* The explanation is that **Principle** encompasses both good and evil. Good is also called the Dao/Way, evil is also called the Dao/Way, yet the nature of good and evil is empty—this does not contradict the meaning. However, calling evil the Dao/Way is not correct; it is merely a conventional designation, not a true elucidation of the principle. If one says that evil is close to the principle in its circumstances, this interpretation is acceptable.

The meaning of **Penetration** is the ability to generate all things and achieve transformation without obstruction. The *Heshang Gong* says: *"The Dao/Way is fourfold penetration."*

The meaning of **Guidance** is to lead adherents to forget their attachments and guide the common into the saintly. The *Scripture of Natural Endurance* says: *"Guide the end to return to the root; the root is true nature, the end is delusive emotions."*

*Virtue/Power* has threefold meaning:

The meaning of **Attainment** is that *Virtue/Power* is the fruit obtained from the Dao/Way. The *Taiping Scripture* says: *"Virtue/Power is the name for the proper attainment."*

The meaning of **Fulfillment** is to fulfill and save all beings, leading them to attain the Dao/Way’s ultimate perfection. This is the name given to the fruit, also relying on the fulfillment of emptiness in the cause—hence the Scripture says, *"It matures and fulfills."*

The meaning of **Non-Loss** is that *Virtue/Power* does not lose—hence it says, *"Non-loss."* The *Taiping Scripture* says: *"Constant Virtue/Power does not lose"*—this is the same meaning.

These six meanings can be mutually interrelated. The *Scripture of Western Ascension* says: *"Dao/Way and Virtue/Power are mixed and boundless, their profound mystery is the same."* Within the Dao/Way, there is the meaning of *Virtue/Power*—the *Scripture of Ascending the Mysterious* says: *"Virtue/Power is equal to the Dao/Way’s equality; equality is the Dao/Way’s equality"*—hence it says, *"The Dao/Way has the meaning of attainment."* The Dao/Way has the meaning of **Fulfillment**—the *Heshang Gong* says: *"Not only does it give birth, but it also nurtures and fulfills."* The Dao/Way has the meaning of **Non-Loss**—since it speaks of the "constant Dao/Way," constant implies non-loss.

Within *Virtue/Power*, there is also the meaning of **Principle**—the *Scripture of Life’s Divine Mystery* says: *"Response and correspondence are the constant principle of Virtue/Power; response is Virtue/Power itself"*—hence it says, *"Virtue/Power has the meaning of principle."*

*Virtue/Power* has the meaning of **Penetration**—the *Heshang Gong* says: *"Virtue/Power is one;"* when one reaches the stage of distributing *qi* and nurturing all things, it is called **Penetration**."

*Virtue/Power* has the meaning of **Guidance**—this refers to the *Virtue/Power* of opening and guiding, as the *Analects* says: *"Guide them with Virtue/Power"*—this is the same.

Within the **Penetration** category, it is as previously explained. But the Dao/Way’s **Penetration** means it permeates all without obstruction, yet nothing is excluded from its reach. *Virtue/Power*’s **Attainment** means it attains all without limitation, yet nothing is excluded from its grasp. Hence, it can forget self and function, yet generate and fulfill all things.

Now, within this category, we further divide into five distinctions:

1. **Explication by Name**—as previously explained.
2. **Explication by Cause and Effect**—to clarify that without *Virtue/Power*, there is no way to speak of *Dao/Way*; without *Dao/Way*, there is no way to speak of *Virtue/Power*. *Dao/Way* and *Virtue/Power* are interdependent; hence we establish provisional names. Thus, without *Dao/Way*, there is no *Virtue/Power*; without *Virtue/Power*, there is no *Dao/Way*. *Dao/Way* is the essence of *Virtue/Power*; *Virtue/Power* is the essence of *Dao/Way*. The Scripture says: *"Long and short define each other"*—this is the same.
3. **Explication by Manifestation**—*Dao/Way and Virtue/Power* serve as teachings, properly illustrating the principle of neither *Dao/Way* nor *Virtue/Power*. Hence, when speaking of *Dao/Way*, it says, *"What can be spoken of is not the constant Dao/Way"*—and when clarifying *Virtue/Power*, it says, *"The highest Virtue/Power is not Virtue/Power."* Thus, neither *Dao/Way* nor *Virtue/Power* is the true meaning of *Dao/Way and Virtue/Power*.

**4. The Release of Boundlessness**—
The single *Virtue/Power* encompasses boundless meanings. Just as effects arise from causes, so too do its meanings unfold. The *Dao/Way* pervades all things; how then could it be confined to a single designation? Thus, it is called "boundless" to elucidate its essence.

**5. The Release of Non-Release**—
Since it is not named, it is also called "meaningless" as its meaning. Thus, the natural essence is termed *non-possession*. Tracing its origin, it is the very meaning of *non-meaning*. It is said:
*The Dao/Way* is named by its generative function;
*Virtue/Power* is named by its teachings.
The Dao/Way is the universal principle of *Virtue/Power*;
*Virtue/Power* is the manifestation of the Dao/Way.
When *Virtue/Power* is present, it is called the Dao/Way;
When the Dao/Way is present, it is called *Virtue/Power*.
The meaning of *Virtue/Power* is taken from its substantial yet non-doing nature;
The meaning of the Dao/Way is taken from its non-substantial yet doing nature.

*The Scripture of Master Lu* states:
*"The Dao/Way’s essence is emptiness and stillness—
void of substance, uncommunicating;
silent, unresponsive."*

*Zang Xuanjing* says:
*"Wisdom is the Dao/Way’s essence;
Divine penetration is its function."*

It is further said:
*The Dao/Way and Virtue/Power* are one in essence yet two in meaning—
one yet not one, two yet not two.
Two yet not two, because of the one;
One yet not one, because of the two.
It cannot be said to have substance or lack it,
to have function or lack it.
For the substance is non-substance—
substance without substance;
The function is non-function—
function without function.

Thus, no single *Virtue/Power* is not its substance,
No single function is not its manifestation.
Seeking its substance, it transcends emptiness and being,
neither yin nor yang—
unseen by sight, untouched by sense.
Seeking its function, it adapts to circumstances,
can be left or right, small or great,
containing the great within the small, the small within the great.
Its substance is without end, hence unthinkable and unutterable.
Its function is without effort, hence revealed only in its place.

Now this is not different—
only that the Dao/Way and *Virtue/Power* differ yet do not differ,
are the same yet differ.
Through discourse, distinctions arise—
different yet the same in body,
one in essence when examined.

That which is not different yet differs—
the Scripture says: *"The Dao/Way generates it; Virtue/Power nourishes it."*
That which is different yet the same—
*The Scripture of Western Ascension* says: *"The Dao/Way and Virtue/Power are mixed and mysterious, identical in essence."*

Knowing that which is not different yet differs—
there is nothing to differentiate.
Knowing that which is different yet the same—
there is nothing to unify.
There is nothing to unify, hence nothing to differentiate;
There is nothing to differentiate, hence nothing but differentiation.

Now, seven meanings are further expounded to elucidate them:

**1. Origin and Trace**—
The origin is the Dao/Way; the trace is *Virtue/Power*.
The origin as Dao/Way—
its essence is the eternal, true, and still source of great wisdom.
The trace as *Virtue/Power*—
its essence is the sovereign *Virtue/Power* of the Supreme One’s responsive body.

**2. Principle and Teaching**—
The principle is the Dao/Way; the teaching is *Virtue/Power*.
The principle as Dao/Way—
its essence is the awakening to true nature.
The teaching as *Virtue/Power*—
its essence is the awakening to true scripture.

**3. Realm and Wisdom**—
The realm is the Dao/Way; wisdom is *Virtue/Power*.
Wisdom as Dao/Way’s essence;
Principle-wisdom as *Virtue/Power*’s essence.

**4. Person and Law**—
The person is the Dao/Way; the law is *Virtue/Power*.
The person as Dao/Way—
its essence is the dual bodies of origin and trace.
The law as *Virtue/Power*—
its essence is the dual teachings of principle and doctrine.

**5. Generation and Completion**—
Generation is the Dao/Way; completion is *Virtue/Power*.
The Dao/Way generates all things through responding to *qi*—
its essence is the responsive *qi* itself.
Completion as *Virtue/Power*—
its essence is the fulfillment of beings through teachings and laws.

**6. Being and Non-Being**—
Non-being is the Dao/Way; being is *Virtue/Power*.
Non-being as Dao/Way—
its essence is the empty observation of the fruit-ground yielding empty wisdom.
Being as *Virtue/Power*—
its essence is the observant wisdom of the fruit-ground arising from the seed-ground’s being.

**7. Cause and Fruit**—
The fruit is the Dao/Way; the cause is *Virtue/Power*.
The fruit as Dao/Way—
its essence is the ten thousand *Virtues/Powers* of the fruit-ground.
The cause as *Virtue/Power*—
its essence is the ten thousand actions of the seed-ground.

These seven meanings interweave mutually—
two yet not two, one yet not one.
Thus, the Dao/Way and *Virtue/Power* are the true essence,
neither fruit nor cause, neither origin nor trace.
Neither origin nor trace, yet opening origin and trace—
to clearly reveal the origin through the trace.
Neither fruit nor cause, yet opening cause and fruit—
to guide cultivation from cause to fruition.

The remaining five pairs need not be spoken of;
their meanings are evident in the third.
*Virtue/Power* is the "having" of non-possession—
capable of ordering the non-existent, also ordering the existent.
The Dao/Way is the "non-non-being"—
capable of ordering the existent, also ordering the non-existent.

The deluded say: *"The Dao/Way is like jade’s form and gold’s appearance—
a real, substantial existence."*
Now it is clarified that the Dao/Way is emptiness—
this is the delusion of ordering the existent.
*Riverbank Master* says: *"The Dao/Way is emptiness."*
*Wang Fusi* says: *"The Dao/Way is the naming of non-being."*

The deluded also say: *"The constant Dao/Way is the supreme Virtue/Power—
truly emptiness and non-being."*
Now it is clarified that this is *Virtue/Power* in possession—
thus removing the delusion, as the Scripture says:
*"In the dim and obscure, there is essence—
this is the mutual reversal of names, dispelling delusion through hearing."*

As understanding deepens, the meaning grows clearer:
The Dao/Way’s non-being is also not this non-being;
*Virtue/Power*’s being is also not this being.
Thus, there is no non-being of non-being—
the delusion is entirely exhausted,
only then does one align with the *Heavy Mysterious*—
the dual transcendence.

Hence the Scripture says: *"The Dao/Way of the Immortal is neither non-being nor being."*

Thus, the Dao/Way must rely on *Virtue/Power*,
*Virtue/Power* must draw from the Dao/Way.
Laozi’s teachings do not rigidly divide
the upper scroll as Dao/Way, the lower as *Virtue/Power*.
The two scriptures’ meanings mutually contain each other;
later sages, in transmission, forcibly partitioned their meanings—
thus, *The Dao/Way Scripture* contains *Virtue/Power*,
*The Virtue/Power Scripture* contains the Dao/Way,
as the sacred intent already clearly states within its sequence.

As for the over five thousand words,
they are not fixed in number.
Balancing form and substance, harmonizing meaning and principle—
one must not constrain the text by letter count,
nor prune its flow to fit a number,
lest the grand intent be lost.

The Sima Qian says that the text of over five thousand words is not fixed to five thousand characters. Those who truncate the wording and reduce the count, forcing the text to four thousand nine hundred ninety-nine words by splitting the thirty *rú* characters into thirty to reach five thousand characters—this is like binding oneself to a pillar and carving boats into stone, clinging to error and failing to grasp the truth.

The interpretations of the *Scripture* by various scholars encompass four meanings in total:
1. **By cause**—the Three Worlds Celestial Sovereigns and the Ten Directions Great Saints derive from the *Scripture*, attain enlightenment, and realize the True.
2. **By path**—they open and reveal the Dao/Way’s principles, guide all beings, and serve as the bridge for scholars to traverse the path to the True.
3. **By law**—they embody the True essence and profound mysteries, the utmost principles and subtle truths, which can regulate and model all beings, setting the standard for countless sages.
4. **By eternal constancy**—they hold the profound and distant principles, the silent and mysterious Dao/Way, as unalterable norms for all ages and rulers.

Together, these four meanings constitute the *Scripture*. Some say it was formed by condensing *qi*, written in cloud-like seals, with characters a yard in size and eight angles descending like rays. Others claim it was inscribed in purple characters on jade tablets, as the *Dragon Scriptures* and *Phoenix Writings*, descending at the beginning of a *kalpa* and returning to Heaven at its end. Still others say it was engraved on jade, chiseled in gold, or written on bamboo, wood, silk, or paper, transmitted through the ages in evolving scripts—whether rough or refined, all are the True Secrets of the Mysterious Sage, the perfect remedy for spiritual ailments, and the wondrous gate to transcendence.

Even if the ages change and the *kalpa* shifts, if gold melts and stone dissolves, yet this *Scripture* endures its teachings, perpetually spread among humans and deities, lasting through countless *kalpas*—thus, it is called the *Scripture*.

Hence, the title is given as *Commentary on the Dao/Way and Virtue/Power Scripture of Laozi*, the uppermost scroll of the first volume.

As for these two chapters, they are profound and mysterious, with five thousand words of subtle depths, encompassing all laws and crowning all scriptures. Yet the accounts of their era, the timing of crossing the pass, their birth order, and the core intent of their teachings remain unclear among the various interpretations. Now, I elucidate the four gates to dispel confusion.

**First**, clarifying the matter of descent and birth. Laozi is the origin of the Ultimate Dao/Way, the root of Primordial Transformation. He existed in the distant antiquity yet was not its first, and was born in the final age yet was not its last. How much more so, given that he already propagated the Dao/Way before countless *kalpas*—how could one claim his birth depended on the womb and call that *birth*?

Now, when speaking of descent and birth, it is but a manifestation in the mortal realm, showing the appearance of a beginning. He took form from the Holy Mother, demonstrating birth. The Mother was devoted to the Primordial Lord, showing reverence. Today, according to the *Scripture*’s records, after the oaths of allegiance and the ritual of *liè* (sacrificial branding), there are three instances of descent and birth:

1. In the year *Gēngyín* (Regina) of the seventh year of *Shànghé* (Upper Harmony), on the third day of the ninth month, the *jiǎzǐ* (day-stem-branch) combination of *Jiazi* (甲子), he was born between the Li Valley and the Northern Mysterious Woman’s realm in the Heavenly Gorge, on the Lingjing Mountain. His Holy Mother was named the Mother of *Xuányú* (玄虚). When he was born, for three days the sun shone from the east, and nine dragons spat water to bathe his form. He took the surname Li from the Li Valley, given name *Xuānyuán* (玄元), and title *Zǐguāng* (子光). He was the supreme crown of the Highest Sage, the descendant of the Jade Emperor, and held the rank of *Lǎngshēng Dàzhǔ Tàipíng Zhèngzhēn Tàiyī Jūn Jīnquè Hòushèng Jiǔ Xuán Dìjūn* (长生大主太平正真太一君金阙后圣九玄帝君). Upon careful examination, this was before the beginning of the *kalpa*, with *Zhūlíng Shànghé* (朱灵上和) as the year title of the prior *kalpa*.

2. In the year *Gēngchén* (Regina) of *Yīn Wǔdīng* (殷武丁), on the fifteenth day of the second month, at the *chǒu* hour (卯), he was born in the *Léxiāng* (濑乡) of *Kǔ Xiàn* (苦县) in the state of Chen. His Holy Mother was named the *Xuānmiaò Yùnǚ* (玄妙玉女). He was the teacher of the Supreme Lord, later ascending to the rank of *Yuánjūn* (元君). Upon careful examination, this aligns with the year and month of his descent in *Bózhōu* (亳州). According to the *Chánglì* (长历) by *Huángfǔ Shì’ān* (皇甫士安), the *jiǎzǐ* (甲子) cycle confirms that the *Tàisù* (太岁) of *Dīngmǎo* (丁卯) was the teacher of the Zhou. This corresponds to the *Zhòu* (纣) year of *Dīngwèi* (丁未), the twenty-first year of *Dīngmǎo* (丁卯), when Laozi dwelled at Qíshān (岐山) and served as the teacher of the Western Earl of Zhou. From the ninth year of *Wǔdīng* (武丁) in the *Gēngchén* (庚辰) cycle to the *Zhòu* (纣) year of *Dīngmǎo* (丁卯), spanning one hundred eighty years. Then, in the twenty-fifth year of *Zhāowáng* (昭王) in the *Guǐchǒu* (癸丑) cycle, he crossed the pass and departed westward, totaling one hundred seventy years. Altogether, this sums to two hundred fifteen years. Sima Qian’s account of over two hundred years is correct.

Those misled claim Laozi descended during the reigns of *Píngwáng* (平王), *Dìngwáng* (定王), *Yōuwáng* (幽王), or *Lìwáng* (厉王). These are all false assertions, utterly erroneous. Why? If he had descended during the reigns of *Yōu* (幽) and *Lì* (厉), or *Píng* (平) and *Dìng* (定), he would not have been able to meet with *Wénwáng* (文王) and *Wǔwáng* (武王).

**Third**, when Laozi departed from the *Lóuguān* (楼观) and took leave of *Yǐn Xǐ* (尹喜), it was in the *Jiǎyín* (甲寅) year of the twenty-sixth year of *Zhāowáng* (昭王). They met at the *Qīngyáng* (青羊) market in Shu, and thus he descended in Shu, in the *Dīngsì* (丁巳) year of the twenty-ninth year of *Zhāowáng* (昭王). After a thousand days, *Yǐn Xǐ* (尹喜) arrived in Shu, marking the time of their reunion. These three instances of descent are fixed in meaning.

**Second**, the timing of crossing the pass. Laozi crossed the pass westward in the *Guǐchǒu* (癸丑) year of the twenty-fifth year of *Zhāowáng* (昭王), meeting with the pass warden *Yǐn Xǐ* (尹喜) and thereby transmitting the two *Scriptures* of Dao/Way and Virtue/Power. After completing the transmission, in the *Jiǎyín* (甲寅) year of the twenty-sixth year, in the fourth month, he parted from *Yǐn Xǐ* (尹喜) at *Lóuguān* (楼观) and ascended to *Tàiwéi* (太微). In the *Dīngsì* (丁巳) year of the twenty-ninth year, *Yǐn Xǐ* (尹喜) entered Shu and sought Laozi, meeting him again at the *Qīngyáng* (青羊) market. In the *Wùwǔ* (戊午) year, he entered the *Liúshā* (流沙) region, marking the year and month of his crossing the pass.

Why? *Yǐn Xǐ* (尹喜) was a great official of King Kang, and by the time of *Zhāowáng* (昭王), he was the pass warden, meeting with Laozi. If we follow *Zāng Xuánjìng* (臧玄静), who claims Laozi crossed the pass westward during the reign of *Yōuwáng* (幽王), this contradicts the account of the Heavenly Treasure’s *Língfú* (灵符) descending, as the pass locations differ. Moreover, the first year of *Yōuwáng* (幽王) was *Gēngshēn* (庚申), and the eleventh year was *Gēngwǔ* (庚午), already destroyed—there is no *Guǐchǒu* (癸丑) within that year, making this claim erroneous.

Again, *Wén Rúhǎi* (文如海) states that Laozi crossed the pass in the *Guǐchǒu* (癸丑) year of the twenty-second year of *Chéngwáng* (成王), which contradicts the meeting with *Yǐn Xǐ* (尹喜), and is also incorrect.

Others claim he crossed the pass in the *Guǐchǒu* (癸丑) year of the forty-third year of *Píngwáng* (平王), which is far later in time and does not align with *Yǐn Xǐ*’s (尹喜) era—all these are mistaken accounts.

Now, upon careful examination of both ancient and modern accounts, the year **Guǐchǒu (癸丑)** of **Zhāowáng (昭王)**’s twenty-fifth year is established as the definitive time of Laozi’s crossing of the pass—this aligns chronologically without doubt.

**Third, regarding the timing of the *Sutra’s* transmission:**
*The Inner Transmission of Gé Xiān Gōng (葛仙公内传)* states that during the time of the Yellow Emperor, Laozi, as Guǎngchéngzǐ (广成子), expounded the *Dàodéjīng* and the Five *Jiā* (茄) methods.

Again, *The Five-Sage Appellation Diagram (应号五圣图)* and *The Inner Transmission of the Venerable Laozi (纪圣老君内传)* claim that during the reign of Shùn (舜), Laozi was known as Yín Shòuzǐ (尹寿子), residing in Héyáng (河阳), where he expounded the *Dàodéjīng* and taught the Dao of filial piety and fraternal respect (*xiàtì* 孝悌). Shùn practiced these virtues, retreated from power, and honored the Way while valuing virtue, thereby transforming the people of the realm. Thus, he established sixteen clans, exiled the Four Evildoers, attained the Four Hearings, and clarified the Four Sights. Externally, he pacified the common folk, and internally, he cherished the nine clans. He attained the Dao in the wilds of Chāngwú (苍梧) and Jiǔyí (九疑) Mountains.

Moreover, various accounts all state that during the reign of Zhāowáng (昭王) in the year **Guǐchǒu (癸丑)**, at Hán Gǔ Guān (函谷关), Laozi composed the two *Dàodé* treatises—*Upper* and *Lower Scriptures*—for Yǐn Xǐ (尹喜). The *Records of the Grand Historian (Shǐjì)* also states that Laozi, as the Overseer of Hán Gǔ Guān, Yǐn Xǐ, authored a book of over five thousand words.

Again, *The Lost Records of Wáng Zǐnián (王子年拾遗)* states that during the Zhou dynasty, Laozi resided on Jǐngshì Mountain (景室之山), often discussing the creation of Heaven and Earth with five senior sages, composing a work of ten thousand words, which he later condensed into five thousand words.

Now, according to the transmission from Héshànggōng (河上公) to Emperor Wéndì (文帝) of the *Upper* and *Lower Scriptures* with annotations, he said to the Emperor: *"Since I began annotating this *Sutra*, it has been over seventeen hundred years, passed down through three men, and now four generations."* He warned, *"Do not reveal it to those unworthy."*

Master Chéng Xuányīng (成玄英) explained: *"The three transmitters refer to Mù Guāng (务光), Xiànmén Zǐ (羡门子), and Gāoqiū Zǐ (高丘子)."*

From this, it is clear: *Zhuāngzǐ* states: *"Tāng (汤) conquered Jié (桀), then abdicated in favor of Mù Guāng, but Mù Guāng refused and drowned himself in the Qīnglíng Spring (清泠之泉) by embracing a stone."* Since Mù Guāng died during the time of Tāng, the transmission of the *Sutra* must have occurred before Jié’s reign. This sufficiently proves that the *Sutra* was not composed during Zhāowáng’s **Guǐchǒu (癸丑)** year or in Jǐngshì Mountain.

Again, referring to *The Yellow Emperor’s Book (黄帝书)*, it states: *"The Valley Spirit is immortal—this is called the Mysterious Female (玄牝)."* Since this entire chapter is preserved, it confirms that the *Sutra* was expounded during the Yellow Emperor’s time—that is why the Yellow Emperor’s writings cite this very chapter.

Furthermore, examining the chronology: if the *Sutra* were composed at Hán Gǔ Guān during Zhāowáng’s reign, by the time of Emperor Wéndì (文帝), less than a thousand years would have passed—this contradicts the claim that annotations had been made for over seventeen hundred years. Thus, it is clear that the *Sutra* was expounded during the Yellow Emperor’s time and annotated during Shùn’s reign, not specifically composed at Hán Gǔ Guān for Yǐn Xǐ’s five-thousand-word text.

Scholars of discernment should carefully consider this.

**Fourth, regarding the doctrinal intent and ultimate aim:**
The *Dàodé* scripture, revered as the supreme text, encompasses myriad meanings, its intent and direction varying with its adherents. Héshànggōng (河上公) and Yán Jūnping (严君平) elucidated the Way of governing the state, while Sōnglíng Xiānrén (松灵仙人), Sūn Dēng (孙登) of the Wèi dynasty, Táoyǐnjū (陶隐居) of the Liáng dynasty, and Gù Huān (顾欢) of the Nán Qí all expounded the Way of cultivating the self. Fú Jiān’s (符坚) time saw Luóshì (鸠摩罗什), Túdēng (图澄) of the Hòuzhào (后赵), Emperor Wǔ of the Liáng (梁武帝), and the Liáng Daoist Dòuliè (窦略), who clarified the principles of cause and effect in affairs. Daoists such as Mèng Zhìzhōu (孟智周), Zāng Xuánjìng (臧玄静) of the Liáng, Zhū Ráo (诸糅) of the Chén, Liú Jìnxǐ (刘进喜) of the Suí, Chéng Xuányīng (成玄英), Cài Zǐhuǎng (蔡子晃), Huáng Xuānnì (黄玄赜), Lǐ Róng (李荣), Chē Xuánbì (车玄弼), Zhāng Huìchāo (张惠超), and Lí Yuānxīng (黎元兴) of the Táng all expounded the *Chóngxuān* (重玄) Dao.

Hé Yàn (何晏), Zhōng Huì (钟会), Dù Yuánkǎi (杜元凯), Wáng Fǔsì (王辅嗣), Zhāng Sì (张嗣), Yáng Yòu (羊佑), Lú Shì (卢氏), and Liú Rénhuì (刘仁会) elucidated the principles of *Xūjí Wúwéi* (虚极无为)—both for personal cultivation and governance.

This demonstrates that the annotators’ intentions varied.

Moreover, the schools of learning and doctrinal foundations differ: Yán Jūnping (严君平) took *Xūxuān* (虚玄) as his core, Gù Huān (顾欢) took *Wúwéi* (无为), Mèng Zhìzhōu (孟智周) and Zāng Xuánjìng (臧玄静) took *Dàodé* (道德), Emperor Wǔ of the Liáng (梁武帝) took *Fēiyǒu Fēiwú* (非有非无), and Sūn Dēng (孙登) took *Chóngxuān* (重玄). Among these doctrinal stances, Sūn’s (孙氏) is the most profound.

Again, this *Sutra* takes *Zìrán* (自然) as its essence and *Dàodé* (道德) as its function. Those who cultivate it govern the state with *wúwéi* (无为) and *wúshì* (无事), thereby achieving *Tàipíng* (太平). For the self, they embrace *Bǎoyī* (抱一) and maintain *Shǒuzhōng* (守中), thus attaining Daoic fruition. Those who attain it transcend the void and ride the shadows, enduring longevity through prolonged vision.

For the state, the loss of *Dàodé* (道德) leads to inevitable ruin; for the self, its loss results in annihilation. Thus, the superior sage diligently upholds it as their standard.

Moreover, the *Mystic Preface to the Dàodé (道德玄序)* was issued in the twenty-first year of *Kāiyuán* (开元), dividing the text into:
- The **Upper Volume** (上卷), 49 chapters in 36 sections, corresponding to *Spring, Summer, Autumn, Winter*;
- The **Lower Volume** (下卷), 59 chapters in 45 sections, corresponding to *Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth*.

Thus, the **Upper Volume**, from the first to the ninth chapter, takes *Wúxíng Wúmíng* (无形无名) as its core, elucidating the *Spring Dao*; from the tenth to the eighteenth chapter, it takes *Wúzhī Hūhuǎng* (无知惚恍) as its core, elucidating the *Summer Dao*;

From the nineteenth to the twenty-seventh chapter, it takes *Yǒujīng Yǒuxìn* (有精有信) as its core, elucidating the *Autumn Dao*; from the twenty-eighth to the thirty-sixth chapter, it takes *Níngzhòng Qīngjìng* (凝重清静) as its core, elucidating the *Winter Dao*.

In the **Lower Volume**, from the first to the ninth chapter, it elucidates *Réndé* (仁德); from the tenth to the eighteenth chapter, it elucidates *Lǐdé* (礼德); from the nineteenth to the twenty-seventh chapter, it elucidates *Yìdé* (义德); from the twenty-eighth to the thirty-sixth chapter, it elucidates *Zhìdé* (智德); from the thirty-seventh to the forty-fifth chapter, it elucidates *Xìndé* (信德).

*Rén* proceeds through *Lǚxū Bàoyī* (履虚抱一), *Lǐ* relies neither on *shì* (恃) nor *zǎi* (宰), *Yì* harmonizes through *róuruò hé tóng* (柔弱和同), *Zhì* remains in *wúshí bùxiào* (无识不肖), and *Xìn* adheres to *zhíqì bùzhēng* (执契不争).

Its overarching principle likewise takes *Xuānhū Huìkuò* (玄虚恢廓), *Chōngjì Xīwēi* (冲寂希微) as its essence, though nominally it comprises *Wǔ Yǒu Sì* (有五有四). In alignment with *lǐ* (理), it transcends *zhí* (执) and *wéi* (为).

Yet among those who expound, adherence to the text often leads to errors, and the interpretations of scholars past and present are sometimes incomplete. Now, by broadly citing diverse texts and exhaustively examining their intent, the discerning may adopt what is clear, thereby illuminating the chronological order, doctrinal tendencies, and distinctions between right and wrong in the *Dàodé Zhēnjīng Guāngshèngyì* (道德真经广圣义).

**End of Volume Five of the *Dàodé Zhēnjīng Guāngshèngyì***
**Volume Six of the *Dàodé Zhēnjīng Guāngshèngyì***

**Volume Six of the *Dàodé Zhēnjīng Guāngshèngyì* (Continued)**

**Commentary on the First Chapter: "The Dao That Can Be Spoken" (道可道)**

This chapter elucidates the origin of the **Dao/Way** (道) and the root of all transformations. ○
**Explanation:** This (此) is that (斯). Chapter (章) means to clarify (明), to distinguish sections and divisions so that principles and meanings become evident. The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) states: "A completed song is called a chapter." The character 章, composed of 音 (sound) and 十 (ten), signifies the completion of a count from one to ten. When referring to writing, 章 means that whenever the *Classics of Poetry* (《Shījīng》) or *Odes* (《Yǎ》) have distinct passages, they are called chapters. To clarify (明) is to make it bright and pure, to reveal it clearly. The **Dao/Way** (妙本), as the essence of all mysteries, stands at the beginning of the *Scripture*, marking the origin of the **Dao/Way**.

Origin (由) means to follow (从); rise (起) means to flourish (兴). Ten thousand (万) denotes the vastness of numbers (数). Transformation (化) refers to responding to changes (应变), meaning that all things arise and change from the **Dao/Way**. Root (宗) means master (主); source (源) means origin (本). Since all transformations arise from the **Dao/Way**, knowing the **Dao/Way** is the root and master of all transformations. This chapter begins, giving rise to all phenomena, like the source of water flowing endlessly without depletion.

**Commentary:** The opening marks the **strong name** (强名) of *Ultimate Void* (虚极), summarizing the return of all mysteries to their source. ○
**Explanation:** The opening (首) is the beginning (元), the start (始). The *Ěryǎ* (尔雅) states: "The first is the foundation (首基), the beginning (始)." To mark (标) is to raise (举). *Ultimate Void* (虚极) is the **Dao/Way** (妙本). The **strong name** (强名) is the **Dao/Way** (道). This chapter first establishes the **Dao/Way** that can be spoken (可道) as its essence (体), and the **Dao/Way** that can be named (可名) as its function (用). In the final passage, it gathers all mysteries into this gate, tracing their manifestations back to their root. To return (趣) means to incline toward (向), to return once again to the **Dao/Way**'s origin. Within this gate, it is divided into seven distinctions:

1. **The Dao/Way that can be spoken and named** (可道可名) clarifies essence and function. **Explanation:** Essence and function (体用) are mutually dependent. Essence has no fixed form, and function has no fixed application; without function, essence cannot be revealed, and without essence, function cannot stand. Sometimes essence is absent, sometimes present; sometimes it is real, sometimes latent; sometimes manifest, sometimes empty; sometimes named, sometimes symbolized. They mutually constitute essence and function, alternating to clarify each other. Essence (体) refers to form (形) and surface (肤); function (用) refers to dependence (资) and application (以).

2. **The Dao/Way that has no name and yet can be named** (无名有名) clarifies root and trace. **Explanation:** Root and trace (本迹) are mutually generative. When there is a root (本), the trace (迹) arises; the trace reveals the root, and without a root, the trace cannot be shown, nor can the root be sought without the trace. The trace is established through phenomena (事), serving as the root and trace. The root (本) is the foundation (根); the trace (迹) is the end (末). The *Master Guāngchéng* (广成先生) said to *Comrade Nǐ* (仲尼): "The Six Classics (六经) are the traces of ancient sages (先王)." The trace (迹) is what remains after walking (履), but the trace is not the walking itself. The trace arises from walking, yet if one takes the trace as walking and further makes others walk upon it, one only grows more distant from the **Dao/Way**. Thus, the trace is the end (末).

3. **Clarifying the presence and absence of desire** (有欲无欲) elucidates the two perspectives. **Explanation:** Perspective (观) is the path one treads (行). To observe (观) with the eyes is called *official observation* (音官); to perceive (观) with the spirit is called *piercing observation* (音贯). One attends to all external things, while the mind concentrates inward; inwardly, one illuminates the singular heart (一心), and outwardly, one forgets all phenomena (万象)—this is called perspective (观). It serves as the initial step in Daoist practice (习道) and the gradual path to cultivating the True (修真). First, one relies on observation and practice (观行), then enters the mysterious gate (妙门). The **Dao/Way** cannot be obtained by naming or sought through form, so observation and practice become the means of cultivation. It is said: "Desire leads to death (有欲归於死), absence of desire aligns with life (无欲契於生)," thus the perspectives on life and death diverge (归趣不同).

4. **The same origin, different names** (同出异名) clarifies how the **Primordial Simplicity** (大朴) disperses into forms. **Explanation:** The **Primordial Simplicity** (大朴) is the **Dao/Way** (道). The **Dao/Way** disperses into *Spirit Manifest* (神明), flows into sun and moon (日月), differentiates into the Five Phases (五行), and gives rise to all things (万物). Forms (器) possess shape and function. The *Yìjīng* (易经) states: "What transcends form is called the **Dao/Way**; what is beneath form is called the form."

5. **Calling it the Dao/Way is called *Ultimate Void*** (同谓之玄) clarifies how forms return to the **Primordial Simplicity**. **Explanation:** *Spirit Manifest* (神明), sun and moon (日月), the Five Phases (五行), and all things (万物) have shape and form, yet all converge back into the **Dao/Way**, hence it is said they return to the **Primordial Simplicity** (复朴).

6. **The Dao/Way beyond the Dao/Way** (玄之又玄) distinguishes the duality of discernment and forgetting. **Explanation:** When forms arise (为器), the **Primordial Simplicity** (朴) must still be preserved. After returning to the **Primordial Simplicity**, even this is forgotten, and one aligns with the **Dao/Way**. Thus, it is called the **Dao/Way beyond the Dao/Way**. Dual forgetting (兼忘) means both form and **Primordial Simplicity** are forgotten.

7. **The gate of all mysteries** (众妙之门) shows the path of completed practice and transcendence. **Explanation:** When both form and **Primordial Simplicity** are forgotten, one clearly aligns with the **Dao/Way**, then returns to the beginning of life and transformation—the gate of all mysteries. Humans and all things share the same origin in the **Dao/Way**; if one acts with contrivance (有为) or clings to desire (有欲), one loses the **Dao/Way** and harms life. If one removes desire and maintains harmony (守和), one returns to the root and origin. This is called the essential gate of knowing the **Dao/Way**.

**Commentary:** The **Dao/Way** (道) is the **strong name** of *Ultimate Void* (虚极) and *Mysterious Origin* (妙本), encompassing both thoroughfares (通) and paths (径).
**Explanation:** The **Dao/Way** (道) is the *Ultimate Void* (至虚至极), neither shape nor sound. It precedes all ages and transformations (后劫运), yet is neither the beginning nor the end before heaven and earth (先天地). It is *Round and Passable, Pure and Tranquil* (圆通澄寂), without beginning or end. The sages reveal its function of giving rise to all things (通生之用), and by tracing its traces (寻迹), one may awaken to its origin (本). Thus, the **Dao/Way** is named by its virtue of giving rise to all things (通生之德).

**Commentary:** The single character *Dao/Way* (道) marks the central principle.
**Explanation:** The opening character *Dao/Way* (道) in the *Scripture* marks and raises the central principle.

**Commentary:** The **Dao/Way that can be spoken** (可道) indicates that this *Mysterious Origin* (妙本) gives rise to all things, thus all things follow this path and can be called the **Dao/Way**, hence *the **Dao/Way that can be spoken***.
**Explanation:** The character *Dao/Way* (道) marks the central principle—*non-action* (无为) and *non-form* (无形), the essence of the **Dao/Way**. The two characters *可道* signify *giving rise to life and transformation* (有生有化), the function of the **Dao/Way**. Within these three characters, essence and function are inherently established: essence is ineffable, function boundless.

「Thus, it is the *Mysterious Origin* of the *Void’s Extremity* (虚极).  **Explanation:** *The Dao/Way that is not constant* (非常道) signifies that the *Mysterious Origin* (妙本) gives rise to transformation (生化), its function unbounded (用无定方), and thus it is given a name that cannot be exhaustively enumerated. Hence, it appears sometimes as vast (大) and sometimes as fleeting (逝), sometimes as distant (远) and sometimes as returning (返)—this is the *Dao/Way that is not constant*.

**Explanation:** It disperses as all things (散为万物), yet does not adhere to a single form. Therefore, its function is without fixed direction (用无定方). Yet it is rooted in the singular *Dao/Way*, so it is made clear that all things derive from *Dao/Way’s transformation* (道化). Hence, it is not confined to exhaustive enumeration. It is lofty yet without limit (高而无上), encompassing all without exclusion (无不包容)—this is *vastness* (大). It is lofty yet without limit (高而无上), not lingering above (不滞於上), boundless yet without external constraint (大而无外), not lingering externally (不滞於外)—this is *fleeting* (逝). *Fleeting* (逝) means *to depart* (往). It reaches the limitless (穷於无穷), penetrating everywhere (无所不通)—this is *distant* (远). It maintains a *Void-heart* (虚心) and abides in the singular (守一), the *Dao/Way* returning to its source (道复归之)—this is *returning* (返). *Returning* (返) means *to restore* (还).

This passage draws from the *Dao/Way Scripture* (《道经》), Chapter Twenty-Five: *"From the *Mysterious Origin* (有物), all things arise."* Thus, it is proven that *the Dao/Way that is not constant* (非常道) is the *Dao/Way* that does not abide in a fixed place (不常厥所).

**Explanation:** The *Dao/Way* (道) is the *Mysterious Origin* of boundless function (虚极之妙用); the *Name* (名) is the designation by which things attain it (物得之所称). Its function can be applied to all things (用可於物), hence it is called *the Dao/Way that can be spoken* (可道). Names arise from its function (名生於用), hence it is called *the Dao/Way that can be named* (可名). Since its application is without fixed form (应用者无方), it is not constant in one *Dao/Way*; since things differ and names vary (物殊而名异), it is not constant in one *Name*. Thus, it is given the name *Dao/Way*, yet *the Dao/Way* itself is ever without name.

**Explanation:** *Name* (名) is the proper designation (正言). The opening character *Dao/Way* (道) is the root of naming. The two characters *可名* signify the traces of naming. These traces disperse among things (迹散在物), and all things are designated differently (称谓万殊). When the traces return to the root, they align with the *Dao/Way*. Thus, *the Dao/Way* is the root of naming, and naming is the manifestation of the *Dao/Way*. Root and manifestation mutually give rise, completing transformation (化).

**Explanation:** *The Dao/Way that can be named* (可名) signifies that names arise from function (名生於用), and thus can be established. *The Dao/Way that is not constant in name* (非常名) appears as *Clear* (清) in Heaven, *Tranquil* (宁) on Earth, *Responsive* (灵) in the Spirit, and *Fulfilling* (盈) in the Valley. Though *the One* is attained without distinction, its application yields varied names. Hence, it is not constant in one *Name*, and thus it is called *the Dao/Way that is not constant in name*.

**Explanation:** Without function, the *Dao/Way* congeals (无用则道凝); with function, names are established (有用则名立). Heaven attains the *Dao/Way* and manifests the *Clear* (清明); Earth attains the *Dao/Way* and becomes *Firm and tranquil* (确然安静); the Spirit attains the *Dao/Way* and transforms without ceasing (变化不歇); the Valley attains the *Dao/Way* and is *fulfilled without deficiency* (盈满无亏). This passage draws from the succeeding Chapter Two to elucidate its meaning. Names disperse without limit—this is *the Dao/Way that is not constant in name*.

*The Dao/Way without name* (无名) is the origin of Heaven and Earth. **Explanation:** *The Dao/Way without name* (无名) is the *Mysterious Origin* of the *Void’s Extremity* (虚极妙本), before any name was imposed. The *Mysterious Origin* (妙本) at its beginning was not *without name* (无名); from the root, *qi* descends (从本降气), and the division of Heaven and Earth commences (开辟天地). Heaven and Earth rely on this origin (天地相资以为始), hence it is called *the Dao/Way without name* (无名) at the beginning of Heaven and Earth.

**Explanation:** The *Great Dao/Way* (大道) emits *qi*, spreading through the *Void* (布於虚无), as the foundation of Heaven and Earth (为天地之本). At the beginning, there was no *Dao/Way without name*—as the *Zhuangzi* states in *"The Heaven and Earth"* (□天地篇): *"In the beginning of the beginning (泰初), there was the *Void* (有无); the *Void* had no name (无名)."* The *Void* (无) being without name (无名), it cannot be interrogated by names; it is obscure and tranquil (混漠寂寥), boundless as the master of transformation (邈为化主). The *Original Qi* (元气) draws upon it as the origin (资之以为始), and the *Dark Transformation* (玄化) receives it to attain life (禀之而得生). Hence, it is called *the Dao/Way without name*.

Heaven and Earth, at their beginning, had no name and no master (无名无氏). Then, traces descended (然后降迹), gradually forming signs (渐令兆形), and thus Heaven and Earth were born (由此而天地生), and the *qi* of phenomena established (气象立矣).

**Explanation:** The *Great Ultimate* (太极) of the *I Ching* (《易》) gives rise to the *Two Principles* (两仪), the *Two Principles* to the *Three Talents* (三才), and the *Three Talents* to all things (万物). According to the *Er Ya* (《尔雅》), *"The beginning"* (权舆) is the origin. The *Er Ya*, created by Duke Zhou (周公) to instruct King Cheng (成王), is a compendium of knowledge on birds, beasts, grasses, and trees, elucidating the meanings and correspondences of words, distinguishing those that are similar in reality yet differ in designation. It serves as the bridge for the Nine Schools (九流) and the key for the Six Arts (六艺), a deep well for those who survey learning and a garden of flowers for those who wield the brush.

This text flourished in the *Middle Antiquity* (中古), reaching its zenith under the Han (隆於汉氏). *Middle Antiquity* refers to the era between the Five Emperors (五帝) and the Three Kings (三王). Hence, the *Systematic Commentary* (《易□系》) of the *I Ching* says: *"The author of the *I Ching* was in the Middle Antiquity."*

*The Dao/Way with name* (有名) is the mother of all things (万物之母). **Explanation:** *The Dao/Way without name* (无名) is the *Mysterious Origin* (妙本). When the *Mysterious Origin* manifests *qi*, Heaven and Earth emerge (见气权舆天地). Heaven and Earth rely on this origin (天地资始), hence it is called *the Dao/Way without name*. *The Dao/Way with name* (有名) is the application and cultivation of phenomena (应用匠成), nurturing all things (茂养万物). Things receive their nourishment, hence it is called *the Dao/Way with name*.

**Explanation:** *The Dao/Way with name* (有名) is the application of function (应用), and the application establishes a name (匠成). Once all transformations are complete (万化既作) and phenomena take form (品物生成), the *Mysterious Origin* (妙本) permeates through all, providing sustenance to humanity. Thus, it is called the *mother*—for its nourishing abundance (母以茂养为义). Yet, whether named or unnamed, the sages distinguish the *Dao/Way* by its function to clarify the unity and diversity of root and trace (本迹之同异), for the *Dao/Way* is not confined to having or not having a name.

**Explanation:** *All transformations* (万化) refer to the myriad changes (举其多). *Phenomena* (品物) are the myriad things (众物). Among all things, the *Dao/Way* is present without exception (道无不在), even in the finest hair of an autumn deer (秋毫之细). Thus, it can generate the *Three Talents* (三才) and be the mother of all things (万物). When the *Dao/Way* is present in all things, they live; when the *Dao/Way* departs, they die. The utmost nourishment is contained—is it not called the *mother*?

The *Great Dao/Way* is without distinction or similarity (无异无同), without root or trace (无本无迹). Yet, through imposed teachings, root and trace are made manifest (强立言教，而本迹彰矣). To observe its mystery, one must be without desire (常无欲以观其妙); to observe its limits, one must have desire (常有欲以观其徼).

**Explanation:** Humanity is born in stillness (人生而静), this is the nature of Heaven (天之性); when stirred by phenomena, it moves (感物而动), this is the nature of desire (性之欲).

If one constantly upholds **cleanness and stillness** (清静), frees the mind and releases the spirit (解心释神), and returns to reflect upon one’s true nature (反照正性), then one perceives the **wondrous root** (妙本).

If one does not restrain its passions (不性其情), follows desire and moves with it (遂欲而动), the nature is lost to desire (性失於欲), and one is bewildered by the **source of the Dao/Way** (道源). When one seeks to observe the wondrous root through desire, only its **boundaries** (边徼) are seen.

**Explanation:** Desire is the movement of nature (欲者，性之动), meaning the mind arises as one pursues the phenomena.

It is said that when humanity is without desire (常无欲), its nature is pure and still (正性清静), returning to reflect upon the Dao’s source (反照道源), then one perceives and observes the wondrous root (观见妙本矣).

If one is always with desire (常有欲), pursuing phenomena and giving rise to the mind, then nature is disrupted by desire (性为欲乱). When one observes the root through desire, lacking **harmony and balance** (冲和), only its boundaries are seen (但见边徼矣).

**Boundary** (徼) is the **edge** (边).

**Explanation:** The mechanical mind (机械之心) resides within the chest; though it is not entirely pure (纯白), it is not entirely impure (不粹), and the spirit’s **virtue/power** (神德) is not complete. One who merely preserves the body (存身者) is not in harmony (不和), and this is the state of having desire (此有欲也).

If the mind of harming desire (欲害之心) is forgotten within, then one may walk upon a tiger’s tail (虎尾可履), and what more of humanity (况於人乎)! This is the state of being without desire (此无欲也).

Those with desire (有欲者) rely on the ears and eyes for perception and hearing (任耳目以视听), labor the mind and thoughts to reason (劳心虑以为理). The more they perceive and hear, the more they are lost in confusion (视听逾迷); the more they reason, the more they are disordered (为理愈乱). This may be called seeing only the boundaries (可谓见边徼矣).

Those without desire (无欲者) allow their spirit to merge with emptiness (神合於虚), their **qi** to merge with nothingness (气合於无). They reach everywhere without obstruction (无所不达), penetrate everywhere without hindrance (无所不通), and align their function with that of Heaven and Earth (与天地同功). This is the **Great Harmony** (大通), and it may be called observing its wondrousness (可谓观其妙矣).

**Observation** (观) involves externally surveying with the eyes (外以目周览) and internally illuminating with the spirit (内以神照微). Surveying with the eyes distinguishes the presence and absence of things (目览则辩乎有无); illuminating with the spirit aligns with the **profound silence** (契乎冥寂).

The phrase **"Humanity is born in stillness"** (人生而静) is from the *Record of Music* (《乐记》篇). It states that nature is originally pure and still (性本清静), without desire or scheming (无欲无营). When moved by external phenomena (为物所感), desire arises from the conditions (因境生欲). The movement comes from the outside (感於外), yet the stirrings are within (动於内). How could one not be cautious of what moves them?

Thus, the **Sage** (圣人) establishes **law** (法) to curb its **evil** (邪), **rites** (礼) to curb its **disorder** (乱), **punishments** (刑) to curb its **transgressions** (过), and **music** (乐) to curb its **excesses** (淫). To govern desire with the Dao/Way (以道制欲) is how one teaches the people to **revere virtue and diligently seek good** (崇德务善).

These two are **of the same source but different names** (同出而异名).
**Explanation:** Both of these (as mentioned above) originate from the Dao/Way (本於道), hence they are said to be of the same source (故云同也). Movement arises from application (动出应用); names are established according to their use (随用立名), hence the names are different (则名异矣).

**Explanation:** This refers to the matters discussed above. The two (可道可名、无名有名，无欲有欲) are each their own pair (各自其两), hence called the two (两者). They both receive the wondrous root (俱禀妙本), hence they are of the same source (同出). From the root downwards, names are established according to their use, hence they are different (名异).

**Explanation:** When **One Qi** (一气) divides, the **Ten Thousand Transformations** (万化) arise. When forms and signs are established (形兆立), the **Ten Thousand Things** (万有) manifest. The variations of these three (三者之变) each produce their own pair (各而两之), emerging from **nothingness** (无), as is said here.

The Dao/Way becomes manifest (道显) and names are established (名立); names are established (名立) and desire arises (欲生). This is the Dao/Way that can be spoken of and named (有道可言，有名可谓). Desire’s impulse (有欲之机) is generated here (兴於此矣). This is how **trace** (迹) arises from **root** (本).

If one who **retrieves the trace** (摄迹) abandons desire and forgets names (弃欲忘名), returning to the wondrous root (复归妙本), then in the Dao/Way one forgets the Dao/Way (於道忘道), and in names one forgets names (於名忘名). This is called **returning to the root** (还本).

Those who **follow their emotions** (徇情者) chase desire and forget the root (逐欲忘本), sinking into **slippery excess** (沦滑). If they can return to the **initial state of things** (物初), they may speak of the **Supreme Dao/Way** (至道).

They are called **profound** (玄).
**Explanation:** When they emerge, their names are different (出则名异); when they are of the same source, they are called **profound** (同则谓玄). **Profound** (玄) means **deep and wondrous** (深妙).

**Explanation:** **Profound** (玄) means **deep and wondrous** (深妙). When discussing their emergence, their names differ (自出而论则名异), meaning they descend from root to trace (是从本而降迹也). When discussing their unity, they are deep and wondrous (自同而论则深妙), meaning they retrieve the trace and return to the root (是摄迹以归本也). Returning to the root is deep and wondrous, hence it is called **profound** (归本则深妙故谓之玄).

**Explanation:** People with and without desire (有欲无欲之人) all receive **qi** from Heaven and Earth (受气於天地). If they receive **harmonious and balanced** (中和) **qi** and **nourishing fluids** (滋液), they become **virtuous and Sage-like** (贤圣) and **without action** (无为). If they receive **polluted and disordered** (浊乱) **qi**, they become **confused and foolish** (昏愚) and **filled with desire** (多欲).

If one can **purify the mind and change their thoughts** (洗心易虑), **clarify desire and embrace emptiness** (澄欲含虚), then they are those who retrieve the trace and return to the root (摄迹归本之人).

If humanity can **refine and cultivate** (修炼), transforming the **coarse into the pure** (俗变淳和), then the **wind of returning to simplicity** (返朴之风) may reach the **Great Antiquity** (太古).

**Profound yet again profound** (玄之又玄), the **gateway to all wondrousness** (众妙之门).
**Explanation:** If the **causal factors** (因) do not arise, then they are unified in **profound wondrousness** (同乎玄妙). Yet fearing that one might cling to **profound** as a fixed state (执玄为滞), not reaching **dual forgetting**, one speaks of **profound yet again profound** (又玄) to dispel **profound**, demonstrating **desirelessness within desirelessness** (示明无欲於无欲).

Those who can do this perceive all **Dharma/Law** (万法) arising from it (由之而了出), hence it is called the **gateway to all wondrousness** (众妙之门).

**Explanation:** Retrieving the trace and returning to the root is called **deep wondrousness** (深妙). If one dwells in this wondrousness (住斯妙), the trace still exists (其迹复存), and though its name differs (与彼异名), it is equal without distinction (等无差别). Hence, **profound yet again profound** (又玄) is spoken to dispel **profound**, so that one does not cling to **profound** (不滞於玄). When root and trace are both forgotten (本迹两忘), this is called **non-abiding** (无住). Non-abiding leads to **perception** (了出).

**Explanation:** The phrase **"causal factors"** (意因) is from the *Western Ascension Scripture* (《西升经》), which states: **"Of the same source but different names"** (同出异名色), each generating its own **causal factors** (各自生意因). If one does not generate **causal factors** (令不生意因), then they are unified in **profound wondrousness** (同於玄妙). **Desirelessness within desirelessness** (无欲於无欲) means that one seeks to eliminate desire (欲求无欲), yet has not yet left the mind of desire (未离欲心). When desire is truly gone (既无有欲), even the idea of desirelessness is forgotten (亦无无欲). To dispel even the dispelling (遣之又遣), this may be called **completely forgetting the mind** (都亡心).

**Explanation:** Retrieving the trace and forgetting names (摄迹忘名) has already attained its wondrousness (已得其妙). Yet fearing that one might cling to this wondrousness (於妙恐滞), one forgets it again (故复忘之), meaning root and trace are both forgotten (是本迹俱忘).

Again forgetting this forgetting (又忘此忘), one **kisses and aligns with the Dao/Way** (吻合乎道). Desire, once dispelled (有欲既遣), and desirelessness, once forgotten (无欲亦忘), neither clings to presence or absence (不滞有无), nor to the **middle path** (不执中道). This is the **fulfillment of complete forgetting** (契都忘之者尔).

**Explanation:** When observing is done as such (正观若斯), this is called **all wondrousness** (众妙). Though its wondrousness is manifold (虽众), they all emerge from this gateway (皆出此门). Hence it is called the **gateway to all wondrousness** (众妙之门).

**Explanation:** The **gateway to all wondrousness** (众妙门) is the **Heavenly Gate** (天门). The **Heavenly Gate** (天门) is the **collective name for the origin of all Dharma/Law** (万法所生之总名). Though it is called **without presence** (无有), it is said that all things emerge from **nothingness** (无有), return to **nothingness** (入乎无有), gathering and scattering, hiding and appearing (聚散隐显), hence it has the name of **emerging and returning** (故有出入之名尔).

It is merely a name in form (徒有其名), yet in reality there is no such gate (实无其门). Hence it is called the **Gate of Non-Action** (无为之门), meaning there is no gate (则无门也). Without gate or room (无门无房), it is the **vast and boundless** (四达之皇皇), returning to the **wondrous Dao/Way** (归於妙道).

Through **progressive contemplation** (正观), one ascends the stages of Dao/Way realization—from initial cultivation to ultimate enlightenment. What was earlier called **visible perception** (目见) is the **contemplation of the Official of Vision** (观音官览之观). **Divine illumination** (神照) is the **pervasive contemplation of the Official of Vision** (观音贯行之观).

The Dao/Way progresses through **the Three Vehicles’ teachings** (三乘之法), guiding beings in stages from their first awakening to the ultimate Dao/Way. Discarding the mundane to attain sainthood, it establishes **the Fourteen Grades of Contemplation and Practice** (一十四等观行之门).

The **Small Vehicle’s** initial contemplations comprise **three methods** (三观法):
1. **Contemplation of False Dharma** (假法观) — this is **holding fast to relative appearances** (对持);
2. **Contemplation of True Dharma** (实法观) — this is **the mind’s self-illumination** (心照);
3. **Contemplation of Pervasive Emptiness** (遍空观) — entering **Non-Action** (无为).

The **Middle Vehicle’s** contemplation and practice consist of **four stages** (四观):
1. **Contemplation of Impermanence** (无常观);
2. **Contemplation of Permanence** (入常观);
3. **Contemplation of Non-Impermanence** (入非无常观);
4. **Contemplation of Non-Permanence** (非常观).

The **Great Vehicle’s** contemplation and practice also comprise **four stages** (四观):
1. **Contemplation of Wondrous Existence** (妙有观);
2. **Contemplation of Wondrous Non-Existence** (妙无观);
3. **Contemplation of Double Mystery** (重玄观);
4. **Contemplation of Non-Double Mystery** (非重玄观).

Within the **Saints’ Gate** (圣何门), there are **three further contemplations** (三观):
1. **Contemplation of True Emptiness** (真空观);
2. **Contemplation of True Permeation** (真洞观);
3. **Contemplation of True Non-Existence** (真无观).

Through these contemplations, one refines the mind—**from existence to non-existence** (从有入无), ascending from coarse to wondrous. Upon attaining the wondrous, one **forgets its wondrousness** (忘其妙), thus aligning with the **Gate of Non-Action** (无为之门).

**Non-Action** (无为) and **Action** (有为), **Dao/Way** (可道) and **Constant Dao/Way** (常道), **Substance** (体) and **Function** (用)—these dualities are clearly articulated. Now, within the **Gate of Substance and Function** (体用门), they are divided into **five distinctions** (五别):

1. **Non-Existence as Substance, Existence as Function** (以无为体，以有为用):
   **Dao/Way** (可道) is the **Substance-Dao/Way** (体道), which is **fundamentally non-existent** (本无);
   **Name** (可名) is the **Functional Name** (用名), which **entails relative existence** (涉有).

2. **Existence as Substance, Non-Existence as Function** (以有为体，以无为用):
   **Chambers, carriages, and instruments** (室车器) are **Substance of Existence** (有为体), while their **utilization** (以无为用) is **Non-Existence** (无).

3. **Non-Existence as Substance and Function** (以无为体，以无为用):
   **Naturalness** (自然) is the **Substance of Non-Existence** (无为体), while **interdependent causes and conditions** (因缘) are its **Functional Non-Existence** (无为用).
   All this is **pure Non-Existence** (此皆无也).

4. **Existence as Substance and Function** (以有为体，以有为用):
   **Heaven and Earth** (天地) are the **Substance of Existence** (有为体), while **all things** (万物) are its **Functional Existence** (有为用).
   All this is **pure Existence** (此皆有也).

5. **Non-Existence-Non-Existence as Substance and Function** (以非有非无为体，非有非无为用):
   **Dao/Way** (道) is the **Substance of Non-Existence-Non-Existence** (非有非无为体), while **virtue/power** (德) is its **Functional Non-Existence-Non-Existence** (为用).
   This is **the Dao/Way as Substance, Virtue/Power as Function** (道为体，德为用也).

Again, within the **Gate of Origin and Manifestation** (本迹门), they are divided into **two distinctions** (二别):
1. **Non-Existence as Origin, Existence as Manifestation** (以无为本，以有为迹):
   **Non-Naming** (无名) is **the Origin of Existence** (有名也).
2. **Existence as Origin, Non-Existence as Manifestation** (以有为本，以无为迹):
   **Mutual Clarification** (互相明也).

All things **originate from Existence and return to Non-Existence** (自有而终，归於无也). The **Mysterious Source** (玄源) is **serene and quiescent** (澄寂), the **Wondrous Origin** (妙本) is **profoundly obscure** (杳冥). It is **not a form or image that can be sought** (非言象可求), nor **Non-Existence that can be substantiated** (非无有可质). Indeed, it is **the end of all logical inquiry** (讨论理绝), **the exhaustion of all speculative discourse** (拟议道穷), yet still, **the teachings are established to guide the mundane** (设教引凡), **demonstrating these stages** (示兹阶级).

However, **in the realm of intuitive understanding and spontaneous resonance** (冥心感契), **gradual or sudden realization follows individual capacity** (顿随机), and one **must not cling to teachings or fixate on words** (不可滞教执文), nor **be constrained by scholastic appearances** (拘於学相). Aspiring **to purify the heart and bathe in virtue/power** (澡心浴德之士), **be diligent and earnest in your efforts** (勤乎勉哉).

**Conclusion of Volume Six of *The True Scripture of Dao and Virtue/Power: Expounding the Sacred Meaning*** (道德真经广圣义卷之六竟)
**Beginning of Volume Seven of *The True Scripture of Dao and Virtue/Power: Expounding the Sacred Meaning*** (道德真经广圣义卷之七)

「The Master Guangcheng of the Tang Dynasty, Du Guangting, expounds:

**Chapter Twenty: All Under Heaven Know**

Explication: The previous chapter elucidates the subtle source of generation and transformation, distinguishing between the two contemplations. This chapter clarifies the undifferentiated and dispersed with varied names.
