**The myriad distinctions arise from attachment to phenomena, and attachment leads to wandering.** (因万殊而逐境，逐境则流浪) **Yet true transformation returns to the root.** (善化则归根) Hence, it first marks the delusions of desire as beautiful, good, or false; then shows the inclinations toward being or non-being; and concludes with the sage’s principle, hoping to swiftly restore the original simplicity. (冀速还淳之由)

The text states: The vast and teeming paths of existence, the myriad living beings in their restless motion,—when they enter phenomena, emotions arise, and the farther they stray from the Dao, the more distant they become. The sage pities their forgetfulness of return and opens this wondrous gate.

The previous chapter distinguished the two contemplations, entering from non-being into being. This chapter reveals the six delusions, arising from attachment to events and their shifting appearances. If one knows the error of chasing phenomena and does not follow the changes of wandering, then one may speak of the gradual cultivation of an empty heart and a full belly.

**All under Heaven know beauty as beauty, and thus it is not evil.** (天下皆知美之为美，斯恶已) **All know goodness as goodness, and thus it is not ungood.** (皆知善之为善，斯不善已)

**Annotation:** Beauty and goodness arise from the heart of desire. If the heart seeks what it desires, even evil may be deemed beautiful or good. Hence, it is said that all know what they deem beautiful as beauty and what they deem good as goodness.

Without an inherent master, both beauty and goodness are false emotions, arising from distinctions of being and non-being, ease and difficulty, the divine and the profane, the fragrant and the foul—all competing to sway and deceive. The Great Sage, through profound discernment, knows these as empty illusions, hence, **"thus it is not evil."** (恶已)

**Explication:** "All under Heaven" refers to the great multitude, speaking of all beneath the heavens. Beauty is what the heart finds pleasing; goodness is what the body practices. It says that all people know what their hearts find pleasing as beauty and what their bodies practice as goodness. Hence, the discussion of preferring sweet over bitter, favoring red over plain—these mutual inclinations give rise to contention and disputes, all stemming from the stirring of desire, which in turn leads to the sequential formation of beauty and evil.

The sage knows that beauty and evil have no inherent master, that both are false emotions, and since false emotions are not constant, it is said, **"thus it is not evil."** (恶已) "Already" (已) is a grammatical particle. The annotation mentions "the divine and the profane" (神奇臭腐), which is from Zhuangzi: *"What is deemed beautiful is the divine and the fragrant; what is deemed evil is the profane and the foul."* (所美为神奇，所恶为臭腐)

The text states: Among all under Heaven, those who know the Dao are few, while the common and vulgar are many; those who know self-cultivation are few, while those who follow external things are many. (天下之人知道者稀，常俗者众；知修身者寡，徇物者多)

All know that beauty and virtue are right, yet none can practice them;
All know that vice and evil are wrong, yet none can abandon them.
The sage laments this, hence it is said: *"Evil is already past," "Vice is already past."*

To bear virtue and conceal righteousness,
To embrace the Dao and maintain humility,
To be loyal and filial toward sovereign and kin,
To cherish harmony among friends and kin—
These are the deeds of beauty and virtue,
Yet all know them yet cannot perform them.
To act contrary to these is vice,
Yet all know them yet cannot reform.

How much more so in cultivating the Way of *wuwei*?
Thus, it is worthy of lamentation.

*"Mao"* (妄) means that which is not true and real.
When stirred by circumstances, thoughts arise;
When following things, emotions are born.
If one does not abide by the Dao or conform to constancy,
Then one is deluded.

*"Divine and fragrant, foul and putrid"*—
From *Zhuangzi*, *Northern Expedition*:
The Yellow Emperor said to Zhi:
*"All things are one.
What is deemed divine and fragrant is what is deemed beautiful;
What is deemed foul and putrid is what is deemed evil.
Foul and putrid transform into divine and fragrant,
Divine and fragrant transform into foul and putrid—
Thus it is said: ‘It is the unified *qi* that pervades all under Heaven.’
The sage values unity."*

This clarifies that divine and fragrant, foul and putrid
Are the partial natures of things.
A hundred schools differ in doctrine,
Nine currents vary in name,
Sequentially grasping right and wrong,
Mutually generating praise and blame.

Those who govern the body and the realm,
If they practice *wuwei* and follow things,
With unity as their thread,
Then divine and fragrant, foul and putrid
Naturally become one—no duality.

Thus, *you* and *wu* (having and non-having) generate each other.
*Commentary:* This clarifies the emptiness of *you* and *wu*.
That which is has no self-nature;
It arises through *wu*, yet the vulgar claim *wu* generates *you*.
That which is not has no self-nature;
It arises through *you*, yet the vulgar claim *you* generates *wu*.
Thus it is said they generate each other,
But the duality of *you* and *wu* is not their true nature—
The name "generation" arises from delusion,
Just as beauty and evil do not arise from inherent nature—
All are empty.
Thus the sage, desiring to rescue those lost in confusion,
Speaks of these six delusions.

*Commentary:* Laozi laments that the common folk are lost in the true Dao,
Deluded by false attachments,
Entangled in illusory emotions,
Hence this meaning is made clear to dispel their fixation.

*"Existence"* (执) means attachment.
To cling to *you* is to reject *wu*;
To cling to *wu* is to reject *you*;
To cling to difficulty is to reject ease;
To cling to ease is to reject difficulty;
To cling to shortness is to reject length;
To cling to length is to reject shortness;
To cling to high is to reject low;
To cling to low is to reject high;
To cling to what comes after is to reject what comes before;
To cling to what comes before is to reject what comes after.
Because of this attachment, none reach ultimate truth,
Hence the scripture says: *"The attached lose."*

But without partial attachment,
One naturally aligns with the Middle Way,
And enters the gate of profound and true observation.

Difficulty and ease generate each other.
*Commentary:* This clarifies the emptiness of difficulty and ease.
Because of this difficulty, that becomes ease;
Because of this ease, that becomes difficulty.
Just as the artisan finds wood easy but clay difficult,
While the potter finds clay easy but wood difficult.
Thus it is said: difficulty and ease arise together.
If one aligns with what is difficult, there is no ease;
If one aligns with what is easy, there is no difficulty—
Difficulty and ease are not real;
Names arise from delusion—this is emptiness.
Thus those who comprehend it
Forget skill and clumsiness alike,
And difficulty and ease cease in name—
Just as beauty and evil have no fixed nature.

*Commentary:* Difficulty arises from ease;
Without ease, one cannot know difficulty.
Ease arises from difficulty;
Without difficulty, one cannot manifest ease.
They cycle and rely upon each other,
Sequentially serving their function.
If examined and understood clearly,
One is unobstructed by difficulty,
Unattached to ease,
And thus can speak of *equating things*,
Unifying with the Middle Way.

*"Artisan"* refers to skilled craftsmanship;
*"Potter"* refers to shaping earth into vessels.
Each excels in their craft—thus it is easy,
But if forced to do the other—it becomes difficult.

Length and shortness define each other.
*Commentary:* This clarifies the emptiness of length and shortness.
Because of length, shortness is revealed;
Because of shortness, length is revealed.
Thus it is said: length and shortness define each other—
Just as the duck’s shank is not short,
Yet compared to the crane’s length, it seems deficient,
And the crane’s shank is not long,
Yet compared to the duck’s shortness, it seems excessive.
Seeing length and shortness define each other,
Like beauty and evil, they lack fixed substance—
All are delusive emotions.
Since their forms are empty, their names are also empty—
Thus they are indeterminate.

*Commentary:* Things have forms of length and shortness;
Matters arise with laws of difficulty and ease;
Transformations emerge with changes of *you* and *wu*—
All are natural.
If one is bound by vulgar perceptions,
Then length cannot but be long,
Shortness cannot but be short.
Difficulty, ease, *you*, and *wu* lie here.
To be obstructed by them is attachment;
To transcend them is the Dao.
Only those who follow the Dao can avoid obstruction.

The analogy of the duck and crane
Is also from *Zhuangzi*, *Overlapping Thumbs*—
Saying each has its proper measure,
And one cannot adjust the other to benefit or harm.
This condemns those who do not follow nature.

The high and low in mutual inclination—
*Commentary:* This illustrates that the names "high" and "low" are empty.
The names "high" and "low" mutually incline and usurp one another.
Thus, when one speaks of "high," it depends upon the "low," yet there is still one who is higher;
When one speaks of "low," it depends upon the "high," yet there is still one who is lower.
Moreover, if one is high, that which is called "high" is not truly high;
If one is low, that which is called "low" is not truly low.
Like the substitutions in the *Dàjiān*[代间],
All these named positions, as they alternate like servants and concubines,
Are also without constancy—
All this is because they are empty, hence without fixed rank.

*Commentary:* The establishment of high and low—
Names of form, posture, rank, innate wisdom, talent, and achievement—
Amidst myriad differences, all possess high and low,
Yet it is not merely confined to named ranks.
But if one forgets their highness and forgets their lowness,
Each abides in their proper measure,
Guarding the natural order,
Then there will be no mutual usurpation.

"Servant" is the humble designation for men;
"Concubine" is the humble designation for women.
They are submissive to others, hence called "servant" and "concubine."
*Commentary:* This elucidates the doctrine of ranks,
Expanding the warning to all common sentiments.
The Way of eminence and humility—
Each abides in their proper measure,
Without mutual usurpation,
Then they preserve their beginning and end.
If one abandons humility and covets exalted titles,
Or despises lowliness while scheming for high rank,
Not content with their original station,
Disaster will follow.
Thus the *Sutra* says:
*"Knowing sufficiency brings no disgrace,
Knowing when to stop brings no peril—
Thus one endures forever.
How could one not be warned?"*

The harmony of sounds—
*Commentary:* This illustrates that harmony is empty.
When the five tones harmonize to form a melody,
Who unifies these myriad sounds to compose the measure?
As the *Dàjiān*’s methods are all harmonized,
Their essence is not true—
All this is empty.
Thus, to determine their beauty or ugliness,
How could it be the discourse of one who perceives thoroughly?

*Commentary:* Heaven and Earth exhale *qi*, and myriad sounds arise;
The *lǜ* and *lè* harmonize, and myriad melodies are born.
When sounds arise, beauty and ugliness follow,
Thus there are distinctions of tranquil joy, resentment, anger,
Sorrow, contemplation, and *xīn* and *xiàn*[惉懘].
Yet these distinctions arise from human affairs and follow them,
Governance and transformation respond accordingly.
To one who perceives thoroughly,
Good and evil are forgotten.
To follow changes while blaming reality is deluded emotion.
Forgetting beauty and ugliness alone is the Dao of thorough perception.
Those who attain the Dao of thorough perception,
Though vast as Heaven and Earth, though teeming as myriad things,
Hold nothing at all.

The *Yuelè Jì* says:
*"All sounds arise from the human heart;
The heart is moved by things and manifests in sound.
Sounds resonate, thus forming variations—
When variations form, they are called sound.
Comparing sounds to make music,
And using *gānqí*, *yǔmáo*—
This is called music.
Thus, when the sorrowful heart is moved,
Its sound is mournful and sharp;
When the joyful heart is moved,
Its sound is smooth and slow;
When the delighted heart is moved,
Its sound is bright and dispersed;
When the angry heart is moved,
Its sound is coarse and fierce;
When the reverent heart is moved,
Its sound is upright and austere;
When the loving heart is moved,
Its sound is harmonious and gentle.
Thus, the ancient kings were cautious in what moved them,
Hence they used *lǐ* to guide their intentions,
Music to harmonize their hearts,
Governance to unify their actions,
And law to prevent deceit.
*Lǐ*, music, law, and governance—
Their ultimate aim is one."*

The Dao of sound is aligned with governance.
*Gōng* is the sovereign,
*Shāng* is the minister,
*Jiǎo* is the people,
*Zhēng* is affairs,
*Yǔ* is things.
If these five are not disordered,
Then it is the sound of *xīn* and *xiàn*.
The music of a well-ordered world is tranquil and joyful—
Its governance is harmonious;
The music of a chaotic world is resentful and angry—
Its governance is discordant;
The music of a doomed state is sorrowful and contemplative—
Its people are suffering.
If *gōng* is disordered, it becomes wild—
Its sovereign grows arrogant;
If *shāng* is disordered, it becomes biased—
Its officials are corrupt;
If *jiǎo* is disordered, it becomes anxious—
Its people are resentful;
If *zhēng* is disordered, it becomes sorrowful—
Its affairs are laborious;
If *yǔ* is disordered, it becomes perilous—
Its wealth is depleted.
If all five are disordered, successively oppressing one another,
It is called *màn*.
The music of *Zhèng* and *Wèi* is the chaotic world’s sound,
Comparable to *màn*.
The music of *Sāngjiān* and *Púshàng* is the doomed state’s sound—
Its governance is scattered, its people dispersed.

Those who know sounds but not music are like beasts.
Those who know music but not the *Lè* are the common folk.
Only the noble knows *Lè*.
To discern sounds and know music,
To discern music and know *Lè*,
To discern *Lè* and know governance—
Those who do not know sounds cannot speak of music,
Those who do not know music cannot speak of *Lè*.
Those who know *Lè* are nearly aligned with *lǐ*.

Zǐ Xià replied to Wèi Wén Hóu:
*"The music of Zhèng seduces and indulges the mind,
The music of Sòng is leisurely and drowns the mind,
The music of Wèi is intricate and vexes the mind,
The music of Qí is arrogant and boasts.
These four harm virtue—
They are not proper music."*

In the *Chūnqiū*, Yàn Zǐ replied to Jǐng Gōng of Qí:
*"The ancient kings blended the five flavors
To harmonize the five tones,
To tranquilize the heart,
To perfect governance—
Music is like flavor.
First, *qì* must be stirred by *qì*—
Second, *tǐ* dances, emulating Wǔ and Wū—
Third, it follows the *fēng*, *yǎ*, and *sòng*—
Fourth, it uses the four directions’ things to make instruments.
The five tones are *gōng*, *shāng*, *jiǎo*, *zhēng*, and *yǔ*.
The six *lǜ* are: *Huángzhōng*, *Tàizhù*, *Gūxǐ*, *Ruìbīn*, *Yízé*, and *Wúshè*.
The six *lǘ* are: *Jiāzhōng*, *Línzhōng*, *Zhònglǘ*, *Yìngzhōng*, *Nánlǘ*, and *Dàlǘ*.
*Lǜ* governs the yang, *lǘ* governs the yin.
The seven tones were established by Wǔ Wáng when he subdued Jiè.
From *wǔ* to *zǐ*, seven days were set as the seven tones.
The eight winds are the winds of the eight directions:
East is *Míngshù*,
Southeast is *Qīngmíng*,
South is *Yǐngfēng*,
Southwest is *Liángfēng*,
West is *Yánhé*,
Northwest is *Bùzhōu*,
North is *Guǎnghàn*,
Northeast is *Róngfēng*.
The *Jiǔgē* are the songs of the six ministries and three affairs,
The nine functions in song.
Pure and impure, small and great,
Short and long, swift and slow,
Sorrowful and joyful, rigid and yielding,
Fast and slow, high and low—
Entering and exiting, dense and sparse—
They intermingle and assist one another."

The Noble One listens with equanimity to harmonize the heart.
When the heart is balanced and virtue is in accord, then one approaches the Dao.

Shun crafted the five-stringed *qín* to sing of the South Wind,
while Qí first instituted music to bestow upon the feudal lords the Way of governing the realm.
Through sound, one discerns order and chaos—
thus, the Prince of Wu, Zǐzhā, traversed and listened to the ancient and modern music of the Three Dynasties,
and thereby knew their rise and fall.

The cultivated scholar, closing the eyes and turning inward to listen to the unsounded,
may then speak of the Dao.

**On "Before and After":**
The six [principles] interpenetrate, sequentially establishing their names.
Just as beauty and ugliness do not arise from inherent nature,
but from false projections—
thus, these names exist.
**Commentary:** This clarifies the emptiness of the three times.
Day and night succeed one another;
the new arises from the passing.
Like lifting the foot—
which is before, which is after?
Thus, the distinction of "before and after" is a name given by their succession.
Names are arbitrarily established—
who can grasp their essence?

The past, future, and present—
the three empty times.
Thus, in constant transformation,
beauty and ugliness have no fixed names.

**Meaning:** The distinction of before and after arises from change.
Without change or movement,
who comes after, who comes first?
Once there is succession,
then before and after are divided.
The enlightened observer transcends them all.
Worldly laws emphasize their differences.
"Lifting the foot" means taking a step—
which comes first, which follows?
Those who understand this
cease the striving of before and after.

The Venerable Master, pitying the world’s drift and forgetfulness,
pointing to the Six Matters to awaken the confused.
The Middle Way is neither yin nor yang—
it has no partial name.
Standing between Heaven and Earth,
unbound and free,
resting where met,
without concern for merit or fame,
returning to the origin of the Dao.

Though the differences between Yáo and Jié,
the shifts of life and death,
the divisions of right and wrong,
the disparities of longevity and short life,
the separations of honor and disgrace,
the stirrings of sorrow and joy,
the succession of past and present—
all are forgotten.

Not knowing the difference between Yáo and Jié—
forgetting beauty and ugliness.
Not knowing the shifts of life and death—
forgetting existence and nonexistence.
Not knowing the divisions of right and wrong—
forgetting difficulty and ease.
Not knowing the disparities of longevity and short life—
forgetting long and short.
Not knowing the separations of honor and disgrace—
forgetting high and low.
Not knowing the stirrings of sorrow and joy—
forgetting sound and voice.
Not knowing the succession of past and present—
forgetting before and after.

Dwelling in the realm of "not this,"
standing on the path of "no haste,"
encountering without resistance,
passing without clinging—
responding in accordance with the Dao,
adding without excess,
subtracting without loss—
this is the one who comprehends the Middle Way,
forgetting distinctions of before and after,
forgetting the mechanisms of change.

Thus, the Sage acts in *wuwei* affairs,
practices speechless teaching.
**Note:** *Wuwei* affairs are no affairs.
The term is borrowed for naming, hence "acts in."
Speechless teaching is forgetting speech;
the term is borrowed for naming, hence "practices."

**Commentary:** "Thus" explains the following to clarify the preceding.
Though the cunningly clever may remain silent,
they are not *wuwei*.
Those who follow their natural state,
though they issue commands all day,
remain ever at ease.

Thus, the Sage, knowing the emptiness of all dharmas,
without arrogance or attachment,
governs the world by abandoning pretense,
employing pure virtue—
the people transform,
each content in their place,
contentment brings no disturbance—
is this not *wuwei*?

Words issuing from the Sage
all align with the hearts of the people—
thus, though they speak all their lives,
they never truly speak—
is this not speechless teaching?

**Meaning:** The Sage harmonizes with Heaven and Earth in virtue,
with the sun and moon in luminosity,
with the four seasons in order,
with spirits and gods in auspiciousness and calamity—
this is the Sage.

Briefly stated, there are five kinds:
1. The Sage who attains the Dao—
the Most High Venerable Lord and the Heavenly Great Sages.
2. The Sage who holds the Mandate of Heaven and attains immortality—
Fuxi, the Yellow Emperor, Zhuanxu, Shàohào, Yáo, and Shùn.
3. The Sage who holds the Mandate of Heaven but does not attain immortality—
Tang of Shang and Wén and Wǔ of the Zhou.
All cleared the Six Directions without speaking of ascending to Heaven.
4. The Sage of comprehensive excellence,
without the Mandate of Heaven—
Zhōugōng and Kǒngzǐ, who established rites and music,
setting examples for a hundred kings,
though lacking the Five-August position,
yet possessing the beauty of harmonizing with Heaven and Earth.
5. The Sage of singular excellence,
without comprehensive renown,
nor possessing the virtues above—
such as Bó Yá and Shī Wén as Sages of the *qín*,
Zǐqīng and Suīmíng as Sages of the *xiàng*,
Zhōngqí and Yánzhōu as Sages of harmony,
Hán Ér and Qín Qīng as Sages of song,
Gōng Shū and Wén Zhì as Sages of insight,
Lí Zhū and Shī Guāng as Sages of sight and hearing,
Zhāng Zhě and Zhōng Shī as Sages of calligraphy.

The Sages mentioned in the Classics
refer to those who govern the world.
The Sage who governs the world
merely sits in reverence, facing south—
what does this entail?
It is the practice of *wuwei* affairs,
observing the beauty of Heaven and Earth,
penetrating the principles of all things,
following the course of the four seasons—
the ruler does nothing above,
yet all things transform below—
this is the practice of speechless teaching.

Governance thus:
the people rest content in their dwellings,
delight in their customs,
and align with the Dao.

All things act without complaint.
**Note:** The Sage’s benevolent transformation
leaves the people unaware—
they wander and rejoice,
each moving naturally,
without complaint to the Sage.

**Commentary:** *Zuò* means movement.
*Ci* means complaint.
The Sage’s governance is effortless and without action;
the people, unaware, move freely,
each finding their natural motion,
without complaint to the Sage.

Thus, when the people strike the earth and pat their bellies while forgetting the Sovereign’s power,
this is how the people forget the Sage’s merit.

**Explanation (義):**
The Sage’s relation to all things:
All things have existed since antiquity—
why should they require the Sage’s creation before they exist?
They naturally attain their own birth, growth, and motion.

*"Yuan you yu yu"*—words from the *Tai Xuan Jing*.
It means that when the ruler above does nothing,
those below naturally thrive—
thus, they are at ease.

*"Strike the earth"*—*ruǎn* (壤) means soil.
The *Zhuangzi* ["Lost Chapter on the Horse’s Hoof"] says:
In the time of Hu Xi Shi,
the people carried food in their mouths and played,
drummed their bellies and wandered.
They knew nothing of the Sovereign’s power.

The Master Charged [Wang Chong] said in *Lunheng*:
When Yao ruled,
his governance was vast—
no one could name his deeds.
At fifty years old, a man struck the earth on the road,
drummed his belly and wandered,
singing:
*"Dig wells to drink,
plow fields to eat.
The sun rises, we work;
the sun sets, we rest.
What has the Sovereign’s power to do with me?"*
This is how the common people forget the Sage’s merit.

Born yet not possessed,
acting yet not relying,
merit accomplished yet not claimed.
**Note:**
Let all things fulfill their nature—
not taken as one’s own,
each attaining their own actions without dependence.
Thus, the Great Peace’s merit is achieved.

Yet one must still be cautious each day,
never daring to rest complacent.
**Commentary:**
Let all things fully realize their natural order—
the Sage does not claim them as his own.
Let all things fulfill their own endeavors—
the Sage does not rely on them as his merit.
Thus, the Great Peace’s merit spreads ever farther,
yet one must still remain as vigilant as at the beginning,
never daring to rest.

This is how the Sage forgets his own merit.
The note says *"each day cautious"*—words from the *Shujing*.

**Explanation:**
The Sage governs things without harming them;
things fulfill their own life.
Things fulfill their own life—
the Sage does not possess them yet relies on their merit,
trusting in Nature alone, abiding in perfect harmony.

Merit has many forms:
Royal merit is called *xūn* (勋)—
like the Duke of Zhou aiding the King.
State merit is called *gōng* (功)—
like Yi Yin preserving the state.
People’s merit is called *yōng* (庸)—
like Hou Ji teaching the people.
Labor merit is called *láo* (劳)—
like Yu the Great stabilizing the land.
Administrative merit is called *jì* (绩)—
like Jiu Xian establishing laws.
Martial merit is called *duō* (多)—
like Han Xin defeating enemies.
The primordial merit of creating all things is called *xuán gōng* (玄功)—
its depth and reach are profound.

Merit accomplished yet not claimed—
thus preserving the merit of *wuwei*.

Each day cautious, each day explained—
the Sage’s transformative merit is not self-praised or relied upon,
only fearing loss, lest his merit fail.
Thus, he grows ever more vigilant,
never daring to rest.
*Ning* (宁) means ease.
*Shèn* (慎) means caution.

The Sage’s *wuwei* yields vast merit—
things fulfill their nature without losing their proper place.
Heaven is clear above,
Earth is tranquil below,
the Four Seas unified in peace—
serene and at ease—
this is called Great Peace.

Only by not claiming merit does it not depart.
**Note:**
Only by not daring to rest complacent and ever refining virtue
does the Sage forget his merit while it remains—
thus, not claiming it yet it does not vanish.

**Commentary:**
The Sage’s sincerity is as straight as hair,
vigilant to the end as at the start,
neither beginning nor end decaying,
never resting in ease or indulgence.
Thus, each day renewing his great virtue,
forgetting merit while it does not depart,
his light abiding as the world finds peace.

Hence it is said:
Only by not claiming does it not depart.

**Explanation:**
*Fu wei* (夫唯)—opening words of the passage.
It speaks of the Sage above not possessing or claiming.
The Sage’s influence extends to the Four Quarters yet he does not claim it,
his benevolence covers all things yet he does not call it favor,
his merit benefits the world yet he does not take it as his own,
his virtue surpasses the Four Seas yet he does not rule as master.
He forgets himself in the Dao,
harmonizes his will with the Void,
governing above yet the people do not burden him,
leading before yet the people do not harm him—
the world delights in promoting him without exhaustion.

Thus, his virtue does not depart.

The King does not err in joy or anger—
then punishments and rewards are not excessive,
and arms do not rise.
He does not err in seeking or taking—
then taxes and levies are not heavy,
and provisions are not excessive.
He does not err in love or hatred—
then appointments and dismissals are just,
and the worthy and unworthy are distinguished.
He does not err in favoring attendants—
then those before and behind are all upright.
He does not err in claiming land—
then arms do not march,
and soldiers do not toil.
He does not err in governing the people—
then the world is at peace.

Things attain their proper place,
not relying on his merit—
*wuwei* without reliance yields its benefits.

Truly vast and profound!
*"Straight as hair"*—words from the *Shijing* ["Small Odes: The People of the Capital"].
It speaks of emotions sincere and conduct upright,
like hair’s roots and ends unbroken.

---
*End of Volume Seven of the Broad Explication of the Daoist Classic*
*(Note: The character "則" in "則為" should be "無" according to the Shiji’s "Yueji.")*
---
*Volume Eight of the Broad Explication of the Daoist Classic*
*Attributed to Master Guangcheng of Tang, Du Guangting*

**Chapter Three: Not Exalting the Virtuous**

**Explication:**
The previous chapter illuminated how myriad distinctions return to their root through benevolent transformation. This chapter clarifies that the Sage’s nobility lies not in outward display, but in *wuwei*—thus attaining the fundamental truth. It begins by rejecting the traces of arrogance and flattery, proceeds to demonstrate the Sage’s method of teaching through natural principle, and concludes with *wuwei*, showing how cultivation returns to simplicity once harmony is achieved.

**Meaning:**
The Sage establishes the Way; the virtuous assist it. Fish and water depend on each other—how could one do without the other? From the sovereigns of the Three Dynasties to the kings who conquered, those who founded states and achieved great deeds relied on the virtuous as their foundation. To "not exalt" means to reject the conduct of pride and flattery.

When the virtuous are employed, the people govern themselves; when flattery is employed, disputes arise. By not exalting pride and display, there are no disputes. By not valuing ornate appearance or precious goods, the people have no greed. This aligns with the Sage’s ideal: a heart empty of vanity, a belly full of sincerity—*wuwei* without knowledge or desire.

To not exalt the virtuous is to prevent the people from striving. **Annotation:** Exalting the virtuous leaves traces; following those traces breeds contention. If the virtuous and the unvirtuous each fulfill their proper roles, there will be no contention.

**Explication:**
*Shang* means to elevate and honor. *Xian* refers to talent and ability. When a ruler elevates and honors talent, traces of flattery emerge. Following those traces distorts truth, and distorting truth inevitably stems from exalting the virtuous. Flattery gives rise to the vice of contention.

Better than this is the Sage’s mysterious transformation—letting *wuwei* take its course, so that clouds naturally follow the dragon and winds always follow the tiger. Then, in the reigns of Tang and Yu, there will be no shortage of ministers like Yuan Kai; Yi Yin and Lu Jia will rise in court, fulfilling the hopes of the state. Each in their proper place, none coveting what is not theirs—thus, no contention arises.

**Translation:**

**Explication:**
*"Xún jì"* refers to the act of feigning and deceit. Once the principle of honoring the virtuous is established, those who feign and deceive will inevitably arise. Why is this so? The virtuous are difficult to discern—crafty words breed doubt, flattery obscures loyalty. How easily can one distinguish truth?

The Classics say: *"Wisdom’s emergence brings great deceit."* Thus, when the ruler favors wisdom, the people respond with deceit; when the ruler favors the virtuous, the people respond with falsehood.

Better than this is to rectify one’s own conduct and lead by example, employing *wuwei* to govern the people, nurturing them with the Great Harmony, and transforming them through purity and stillness. Then, those who assist in governance will naturally be the virtuous, and they will serve their purpose.

This is what is meant by *"the dragon’s clouds and the tiger’s winds."* When clouds follow the dragon and winds follow the tiger, it is as the *Yijing* explains in the *Qian* hexagram: the *"Flying Dragon in Heaven"* (九五) broadens its influence over all things, so water flows to dampness, fire seeks dryness, clouds follow the dragon, and winds follow the tiger—each responding to its kind by natural affinity.

This illustrates the Sovereign ascending to the *"Flying Dragon"* position, where all underheavens gather like clouds. When the Sage appears, all things behold him. Those rooted in Heaven draw near above, those rooted in Earth draw near below. This speaks of water as yin—when it flows to Earth, it seeks dampness—and fire as yang—when it burns in kindling, it seeks dryness. Though these two lack awareness or sentiment, they are drawn together by *qi* alone. Yet even more so, the dragon—a water creature—and clouds—water’s *qi*—when the dragon roars, mist arises. The tiger, a fierce beast, and wind, a vibrating force—when the tiger howls, valley winds stir. These two possess awareness and sentiment, yet because their *qi* and kindred nature align with the insensate, they too respond in kind.

How much more so when the Sage descends into the world, the *"Flying Dragon in Heaven"*! The virtuous and wise mutually reinforce each other, and all things resonate in harmony. Thus, the Sage’s deeds are broadly proclaimed.

**The Reign of Tang and Yu:**
Emperor Yao, surnamed *Tao Tang*, of the *Yiqi* clan, named *Fangxun*, was the son of Emperor *Yu*. His mother, *Qingdu*, was the secondary consort of Emperor *Yu*, who conceived after being visited by a red dragon. She bore Yao at fourteen months.

From youth, Yao possessed sage virtue. At sixteen, he ascended as the Duke of Tang. He ruled for seventy years from *Jì*, dying at eighty-six. Knowing his son, *Dan Zhu*, was unworthy, he openly sought talent and ultimately selected *Shun*, testing him for two years before betrothing him to his two daughters to observe his virtue. After two years, Yao abdicated in favor of Shun.

Shun ruled for twenty-eight years before Yao’s death. Yao lived to 117, buried at *Jìyīn Chéngyáng*. The posthumous title reads: *"Yao"*—*"the one who proclaims virtue and transmits the Dao."*

Emperor Shun of the *Yú* clan descended from *Zhuānxū*, grandson of *Qiōngniú*, son of *Gǔsōu*. His mother, *Wòdēng*, conceived after seeing a great rainbow. Shun was born at *Yáoqiū*, hence his clan name *Yáo*, given name *Zhònghuá*. Renowned for filial piety, he was tested and ruled for two years before ascending the throne. After Yao’s death at twenty-eight years of reign, Shun was thirty when appointed, tested for two years, and ruled as regent for twenty-eight years before a three-year mourning period. He reigned as Sovereign for fifty years, died in *Cāngwú* while inspecting the southern lands, and lived to 112. He commanded *Yǔ* to succeed him and was buried at *Jiǔyí’s Línglíng*. Since his son, *Shāngjūn*, was unworthy, Shun did not transmit the throne to him.

After Shun’s ascent to *Cāngwú* and his refusal to return, his two consorts gazed after him. The nine peaks of *Jiǔyí* all resembled one another, and they could not determine where he had gone. Each peak became a subject of doubt, and their tears stained the bamboo, hence its name, *Jiǔyí*. The *Shū* says: *"Shun ascended the heights and died."* The *Shǐ* says: *"Shun mounted the distant."* This speaks of his ascent to a lofty, unreachable place. The *Dao Learning Transmission* says: *"Yao became the True Lord of *Tàiwéi*, Shun the True Lord of *Tàijí*."* The *Record of Jiǔyí Mountain* says: *"Shun descended into the mountain."* This confirms their exalted station as true sages, their virtue surpassing mortals—thus, they attained the Dao, ascended to immortality, and became divine.

In antiquity, *Yúfú* played at *Zhānshān*, soaring aloft. The *Wàngdì* resided at *Shíniǔ*, swiftly ascending. The *Xuānhuáng* ascended the dragon at *Dǐnghú*, and *Xià Yǔ* rode the breeze at *Jìngshuǐ*. The *Zhuāngzi* [*Great Master*] says: *"The *Píwéi* clan obtained it to lift Heaven and Earth; the *Fúxī* clan obtained it to inherit the *Qi* Mother; the Yellow Emperor obtained it to ascend to the Cloud Sky; *Zhuānxū* obtained it to dwell in the *Xuángōng*; thus, *Shénnóng* oversaw the South Pole, *Yīntāng* governed the North Mysterious, *Wǔdīng* held the Purple Bureau, *Yángjiǎ* held the Azure Origin, *Wénwáng* held the Great Void, *Wǔwáng* held the Great Peace, *Kāngwáng* held the Lesser Summit, *Mùwáng* held the Nine Mysterious, *Hàn Jǐng* held the Great One, *Hàn Wén* held the Perfected Mysterious, the Eight Emperors held the Eight Stars, and *Hàn Wǔ* held the Mysterious Completion. These were all rulers who governed the realm, attained the True, and ascended to their divine stations."*

Thus, Yao and Shun’s ascension to immortality was indeed fitting.

**The Ministers Like Yuan Kai:**
These were the *Bāyuàn Bākǎi*. In the time of *Gāoxīn*, there were eight talented sons: *Bófèn, Zhòngkǎn, Shùxiàn, Jìzhòng, Bǎohǔ, Zhòngxióng, Shūbào, Jìlí*. They were loyal, reverent, respectful, and beautiful in virtue, kind and harmonious in benevolence—thus, the people called them the *Bāyuàn*. *"Yuàn"* means *"reverent,"* and *"yì"* means *"beautiful."*

---
*(Note: Some minor gaps in the original text, such as the missing character in *Zhuāngzi*, were inferred from context.)*

The **Eight De** were thus named:
*"Xuān"* means *"pervasive,"* and *"yuàn"* means *"virtuous."* The **Gāoyáng** clan had eight talented sons: **Cāngshū, Tuígǔ, Dǎojí, Dàlín, Lóngjiàng, Tíngjiān, Zhòngróng, and Shūdá**. They were harmonious with the Sage, broad and profound in wisdom, sincere and trustworthy in virtue—thus the people called them the **Eight Kai**.

*"Qí"* means *"central,"* *"yuān"* means *"deep,"* *"yǔn"* means *"trustworthy,"* *"dǔ"* means *"thick,"* and *"kǎi"* means *"harmonious."* These sixteen clans perpetuated their excellence, never losing their renown.

Emperor **Yáo** did not trust them, yet he appointed **Shùn** as his minister and dispatched the **Eight Yuàn** to propagate the **Five Teachings** across the lands. The **Five Teachings** were:
- **Father’s righteousness (fǔ yì),**
- **Mother’s kindness (mǔ cí),**
- **Elder brother’s friendship (xiōng yǒu),**
- **Younger brother’s reverence (dì gōng),**
- **Child’s filial piety (zǐ xiào).**

Within, harmony was achieved; without, success was realized.

The descendants of **Gāoxīn**, the **Eight Yuàn**, were the lineage of **Jì Qì**—those of the **Jú, Xì, Xióng, and Pí** clans. The **Eight Kai** were entrusted to govern the **Earthly Sovereign**, overseeing all affairs in due order. Thus, the land was leveled, and the heavens were perfected.

The title **Gāoyáng Zhūnxū** belonged to the descendants of the **Eight Kai**. When **Rú, Yǔ, Jiùxiào, and Yì** arose—among whom **Jiùxiào** was **Tíngjiān**—**Gāo** served as **Sītú**, broadening the **Five Teachings**, and thus was counted among the **Eight Yuàn**. **Yǔ** became **Sīkōng**, leveling the waters and lands, succeeding the **Earthly Sovereign’s** office, and thus was counted among the **Eight Kai**.

*"Nèi píng"* meant harmonizing the **Zhōushà** (central states), while *"wài chéng"* meant subduing the **Róng-Dí** (barbarians). **Shùn** appointed the sixteen clans, and the realm was ordered. Both within and without, peace prevailed—this was referenced in the *Spring and Autumn Annals* when **Jǔ Pú** assassinated his lord and fled to **Lǔ**, and **Jì Sūn Xíngfǔ** cited this event to admonish **Lǔ Xuān Gōng**.

**Yī Lǚ**—that is, **Yī Yǐn**, born in the hollow of **Kōngsāng** beside the **Yī River**, who aided **Yīn** as prime minister, assisting **Tàijié** as **Āhéng**. His ancestor, **Yī Zhí**, had helped **Tāng** establish the state, achieving great peace. **Yī Yǐn’s** son, **Yī Lù**, served **Tàijié’s** grandson, **Tàiwù**. The deeds of these three ministers were recorded in the **Yīn dynasty**.

**Lǚ** refers to **Tàigōng Wàng**—surname **Jiāng**, given name **Zǐyá**, who fished in **Pánxī**, split a great fish, and found a **jade huáng** within, its center containing a **war bell**. **Zǐyá** mastered it, and by eighty years of age, **Zhōu Wén Wáng**, when divining a hunt along the **Wèi River**, received the omen: *"Not a bear, not a tiger—only the teacher of a king."* He captured **Zǐyá**, took him home, and later, with military strategy, aided **Wǔ Wáng** in conquering **Yīn**, founding the **Zhōu dynasty**.

Initially, he was enfeoffed at **Lǚ**, or sometimes at **Fǔ**. Thus, in the *Book of Documents*, during **Mù Wáng’s** reign, there was a **Lǚ Hóu**, or sometimes a **Fǔ Hóu**, his descendant.

After **Tàigōng** defeated **Zhòu**, he was enfeoffed in **Qí**, and the **Kāng Gōng** summoned him, saying: *"Five marquises, nine hegemonies—you shall truly lead them, aiding the **Zhōu court**."* He was granted territory from the **East Sea** to the **Hé River**, from **Mùlíng** in the south to **Wúdì** in the north. Later, **Huán Gōng Xiǎobái** became the hegemon among the feudal lords. By the end of the **Spring and Autumn**, his minister **Tián Hé** deposed **Qí Kāng Gōng** and exiled him to the sea, seizing his state.

**Tāihéng’s** grandeur was that the **Son of Heaven** established the **Three Ministers’** offices to symbolize the **Three Altars**. The **Three Altars and Six Palaces** were the **Tàiyuè, Sītú, Sīkōng, Tàishī, Tàizuàn, and Tàibǎo**. The **Three Altars and Six Stars**—each of the **Upper, Middle, and Lower Altars** had two stars—lay south of **Zǐwēi**, guarding the **Emperor’s** seat, rising from **Wénchāng** to **Tàiwēi**. The **Celestial Stairs** governed the **Three Ministers, Nine Ministers, and commoners**, and the **Nine Regions’** colors and ranks aligned—then the **sovereign and ministers** were harmonious, and the laws were just.

From the **Upper Altar** to the **Middle Altar** was sixteen degrees; from the **Middle Altar** to the **Lower Altar**, also sixteen degrees. The stars were half a degree apart—too dispersed was extravagance, too narrow was oppression. The **upper star** represented the **Son of Heaven**, the **middle star** the **marquises, dukes, and earls**, and the **lower star** the **ministers and great officials**. If they were **small and clear**, it was auspicious; if they **shaken or changed color**, it was ominous. If one star vanished, the realm was in peril. If two stars vanished, the realm was in chaos. If three stars vanished, the realm was beyond governance.

The **Tàishī** was the **master of rites**, setting the model for all under heaven. The **Tàizuàn** taught with **virtue and righteousness**, the **Tàibǎo** protected the **sovereign’s** person, the **Tàiyuè** commanded the military, the **Sītú** reverently promulgated the **Five Teachings**, and the **Sīkōng** governed the leveling of waters and lands. These three ministers corresponded to the **Three Altars above**.

**Āhéng**—*"Ā"* meant *"lean upon,"* and *"héng"* meant *"balance."* The **Son of Heaven** leaned on the **Three Ministers** to govern the realm justly. The *Book of Documents* states that **Yī Yǐn** aided **Yīn** as **Āhéng**.

**Qíyú** meant *"aspiration."* One should not value **difficult-to-obtain treasures**, lest the people become thieves. **Difficult-to-obtain treasures** were those beyond one’s natural endowment. To seek the unattainable is why they are called **difficult-to-obtain**. If one does not rest in their natural portion, aspiring to what they lack, they lose their inherent nature—how is this not theft?

To let things fulfill their nature and affairs accord with their capacities, then **difficult-to-obtain treasures** will not be prized, and the **essence of life** will not be stolen.

**Commentary:** A person’s birth is endowed with a portion—what they inherit is their **body and treasures**. To covet beyond one’s portion, seeking the unattainable, is why they are called **difficult-to-obtain**. If one does not rest in their natural endowment, aspiring to cleverness, they lose their **true nature**, becoming entirely private thieves.

Now, if the **wise and foolish** follow their nature, and the **able and incapable** act according to their capacities, with no exceeding of bounds, they will naturally disregard **difficult-to-obtain treasures**. All will attain their natural portion—who would be a thief?

Thus, **Zhuāngzi** said: *"The unvirtuous person severs the **essence of life**, gluttonously coveting wealth and rank."*

**Further Explanation:** If the **sovereign** does not prize **jade, rhinoceros horn, or treasures**, his governance will be **clear and tranquil**. The people will follow his example, naturally abandoning greed. Each will know contentment, and thus, none will be thieves.

**Doctrine:** When a person is born, they inherit the **refined essence of Heaven and Earth**, obtaining **clear, pure, and luminous qi** to become **Sages or Worthies**, or **muddled, turbid qi** to become **foolish or lowly**.

The **Sages and Worthies** possess boundless wisdom and clarity, while the foolish and ignorant are shrouded in dimness and confusion. This arises from the inherent differences in one’s **nature and portion**.

**Laozi** told **Confucius**: *"The **Dao/Way** generates all people and myriad creatures—birds, beasts, insects—each with their unique pairings, for their **qi** differs. Yet common folk know not their true nature, only those who grasp **Dao/Way and virtue/power** can trace it to its source."*

**Wénzǐ** said: *"Clear **qi** is Heaven, turbid **qi** is Earth, harmonious **qi** is humanity. Within this harmonious **qi**, there is brightness and darkness, thus there are the **Worthy** and the foolish. The foolish covet the **Worthy’s** brilliance, thus they exceed their portion. The dim covet to replace the bright, thus they indulge in vain desires. This is what is called severing the **essence of life** and gluttonously craving wealth and rank—words from *Zhuāngzi’s* **‘Overgrown Thumbs’** chapter.*

Wealth and rank may be craved, yet still there are those who hold them in esteem. But if there is nothing to admire, people will content themselves with their portion, accepting tasks according to their capacity. Who would dare to sever their own nature and imitate others, gluttonously seizing what is beyond their due?

When the **sovereign** does not prize jade, rhinoceros horn, or treasures, the people below cease their greed. Each finds contentment—this is what it means to be without theft. When there is nothing desirable to be seen, the heart remains undisturbed.

**Explanation:** Without aspiring to **Worthy** status or seeking rare treasures, there is nothing visible to desire, and thus the heart does not stray.

**Commentary:** Coveting brilliance is seeing what is desirable. When desire stirs, what else is it but confusion? Now, if one neither extols the **Worthy** nor seeks beyond their portion, then there is nothing desirable to be seen, and the heart remains undisturbed.

**Explanation:** Coveting is the same as longing. With limited **nature and insight**, yet longing for brilliance, this is exceeding one’s portion—this is called **desire**.

Moreover, those who cultivate the **Dao/Way** in their early stages, though their practice is incomplete and their refinement unripe, fear what is desirable and are drawn by external influences. Thus, they retreat to mountains and forests to avoid the clamor of the world. But when their mind is tranquil and their resolve steadfast, external influences cannot seduce them. Throughout the day, they move with ease, never troubled.

This is what is meant by *"small concealment in the mountains, great concealment in the world."* Unable to sever **desire** entirely, they still fear being drawn by external influences, so they remain hidden in the mountains and forests to avoid what they see. Yet when their heart is serene, their thoughts still, and their true essence untainted—when external distractions cannot disturb them and their inner harmony remains unshaken—even amidst the bustling markets and the pursuit of fame and gain, these matters hold no sway over their heart; amidst the world’s chaos and disputes, right and wrong do not sway their intentions. Merged into the city’s throng, how could this hinder their pursuit of **True Essence**?

Thus, the **Sage’s** governance—**Commentary:** Teaching the **Dao/Way** of governing the self and the realm as its foundation—what else is there to governing the realm but governing the self? Therefore, with a **vacant heart and full belly**, severing **desire** and forgetting knowledge in **non-action**, there is nothing that cannot be governed.

**Explanation:** The **Yellow Emperor** said to **Shénzhen Rén**: *"I have never heard of a case where the self was not governed yet the realm was."* The human body is a microcosm of the realm. The chest and abdomen are like palaces and halls. The limbs are like borders and territories. The bones and joints are like officials. The **spirit** is like the sovereign. The blood is like ministers. The **qi** is like the people. To govern the self is to govern the realm. Loving the people secures the realm. Hoarding **qi** preserves the body. When the people scatter, the realm perishes. When **qi** is exhausted, life ends. The dead cannot be revived, the lost cannot be restored. Thus, the **Perfect Ones** eliminate afflictions before they arise and address illnesses before they manifest. **Qi** is difficult to nurture yet easy to corrupt; the people are difficult to gather yet easy to disperse. Govern before there is chaos; do not wait until it has passed.

**Assisting this principle:** Vacate the heart—**Note:** When the heart is not disturbed by what is desirable, it is vacant. **Commentary:** When the mind is enslaved to external influences, worldly affairs obscure it; when thoughts are still and **True Essence** is preserved, **desire** does not arise. When **desire** does not arise, the heart is vacant. **Zhuāngzi** said: *"A vacant chamber births purity."* This means that when the heart is vacant, pristine whiteness naturally emerges. Thus, it is said: *Vacate the heart.*

**Explanation:** Only the **Dao/Way** gathers in the vacant. When the heart is vacant, the **Dao/Way** gathers within. When the **Dao/Way** gathers within, the **spirit** plays with transformation, the heart communicates with Heaven, and all things beneath naturally transform, while the **Sage** remains serene above. This is the ultimate principle.

*"A vacant chamber births purity"*—words from *Zhuāngzi’s* **‘Between Heaven and Earth’** chapter. The chamber refers to the heart. To see yet not see is to vacate the heart. When the heart is vacant, pristine whiteness naturally emerges. Pristine whiteness is the appearance of boundless clarity.

The *Inner Observation Scripture* says: *"The heart is neither green nor red, neither white nor yellow, neither long nor short, neither round nor square. It encompasses Heaven and Earth, yet enters the finest hairs. Restrain it, and it stops; release it, and it rages. When pure, it lives; when turbid, it perishes. It illuminates the eight extremes, yet can be darkened in a single region. Of all things, the heart is the hardest to subdue. Therefore, teaching people to cultivate the **Dao/Way** is to teach them to cultivate the heart. Teaching them to cultivate the heart is to teach them the **Dao/Way**. The heart cannot be stilled by mere thought; the **Dao/Way** stills it. The heart is invisible; the **Dao/Way** reveals it. Good and evil, all worldly affairs—these arise from the heart and perish in the heart. Those who practice the **Dao/Way** extinguish the heart to align with it. Those of the world indulge the heart and endanger themselves. When the heart arises, there is chaos; when it is extinguished, there is order.

Thus, the **Son of Heaven** establishes officials, clarifies laws, institutes punishments and rewards, and hangs omens of fortune and misfortune to guide the people—all because the heart is difficult to govern. Without the heart, there are no commands. When the heart is steadfast, commands are not doubted. When the heart is stilled, commands are not acted upon. When the heart is restrained, commands are not chaotic. When the heart is rectified, commands are not perverse."*

「The purified heart ensures commands remain unstained.
The empty heart ensures commands do not cling.

Understanding these seven principles,
one may speak of the **Dao/Way**,
one may speak of cultivating the heart.

**Fill the belly**—
*When virtue/power fills within, there is no arrogance or flattery;
it is like satiety, halting desire and extinguishing greed.*

*Explanation:* The belly signifies capacity and sufficiency, thus not coveting.
To ensure virtue/power fills within and greed does not arise,
it is said: **fill the belly**.
The note "satiety halts desire" comes from the *Spring and Autumn Annals*’ account,
where **Yán Mò and Rú Kuān** admonished **Jìn Wǔzǐ**—
using the commoner’s belly as a metaphor for the noble’s heart:
when sated, there is enough, and no greed remains.

*Meaning:* The heart’s desires are boundless,
but the belly’s capacity is finite.
Thus, the heart must be emptied,
and the belly filled.
An empty heart prevents all cravings,
a filled belly halts acquisitiveness.
Nurturing loyalty and sincerity,
embracing simplicity—
this is virtue/power made complete within.

*The *Spring and Autumn Annals* is the name for the chronicles of Lǔ.
It records events by day, days by month, months by season, seasons by year.
Since the year has four seasons, it is named thus.

The **Son of Heaven** has imperial historians,
the feudal lords have state historians—
Chǔ called theirs *Táo Wú*,
Jìn called theirs *Chéng*,
Lǔ called theirs *Spring and Autumn*.
Confucius compiled the *Classic*,
Zuǒ Qiū Míng wrote the *Transmission*,
beginning in the 48th year of King Píng of Zhōu,
the 1st year of Duke Hùn of Lǔ,
when the Celestial Stem was *Dīng*,
the Heavenly Branch *Yǒu*,
the Year Star in *Jiàngliú*,
corresponding to the 2nd year of Jìn’s Duke Cuò,
the 13th year of Wèi’s Duke Huán Wán,
the 28th year of Cái’s Duke Xuān Kǎofǔ,
the 22nd year of Zhèng’s Duke Zhuāng Wèishēng,
the 35th year of Cáo’s Duke Huán Zhōngshēng,
the 9th year of Qí’s Duke Xī Lùfǔ,
the 19th year of Chǔ’s King Wǔ Dá,
the 44th year of Qín’s Duke Wén,
the 7th year of Sòng’s Duke Mù Hé,
the 23rd year of Chén’s Duke Huán Bào,
and the 18th year of Yān’s Duke Mù—
this marks the *Spring and Autumn*’s first year.

Until the 14th year of Duke Āi of Lǔ,
the 39th year of King Jìng of Zhōu,
when the Celestial Stem was *Wù*,
the Heavenly Branch *Wǔ*,
spanning 242 years in total.
It encompassed 14 kings of Zhōu,
12 dukes of Lǔ,
and recorded events concurrent with:
Jìn’s Duke Dìng Wǔ’s 31st year,
Wèi’s Duke Chù’s 12th year,
Cái’s Duke Chéng Yí’s 10th year,
Zhèng’s Duke Shēng Shèng’s 20th year,
Qí’s Duke Jiǎn Jiā’s 4th year,
Chǔ’s King Huì Zhāng’s 8th year,
Qín’s Duke Dào’s 11th year,
Sòng’s Duke Jǐng Tóuman’s 36th year,
Chén’s Duke Mǐn Yuè’s 21st year,
Yān’s Duke Jìng’s 6th year,
and Wú’s Fú Chà’s 15th year—
this is the year the *Spring and Autumn* ended with the "Deer in the Park" entry.

The text comprises 30 scrolls,
352,225 words,
194,590 characters in the base text,
157,966 characters in annotations,
commented by Dù Yǔ, *Zhèngnán Jiāngjūn* of Jìn, styled *Yuán Kǎi*.

**Yán Mò and Rú Kuān’s admonition** appears in the 28th year of Duke Zhāo of Lǔ:
Jìn’s Wèi Xiànzǐ Shū governed, appointing his son Wù as *Dàfū* of Gěngyáng—now Jìnyáng.
In winter, a case arose in Gěngyáng that the magistrate could not judge,
so he reported it to Xiànzǐ.
The plaintiff’s ancestor, Tàizōng, had been given a concubine as tribute,
and Wèi Zǐ was about to accept it.
Wù said to Wèi Zǐ and the two ministers Yán Mò and Rú Kuān:
*"Our lord is renowned among the feudal lords for refusing bribes.
If he accepts Gěngyáng’s tribute, his greed will be unmatched.
My lord must surely advise against it."*
Both agreed to do so.»

After the court session, he waited in the hall. The tribute arrived,
and Wèi Zǐ summoned the two ministers to dine.
He set the dishes before them in order,
and sighed three times.

After the meal, he had them sit.
Wèi Zǐ said: *"I have heard from my elder brothers and uncles
that the common saying is: ‘Only in eating does one forget sorrow.
My lord sighed three times during the meal—why?"*

They replied in unison: *"When others grant us two small cups of wine,
we do not eat at night.
When the tribute first arrived,
I feared it might not be enough,
so I sighed once.
When it was placed in the middle,
I reproached myself: ‘Could it be that the General’s meal
is not sufficient?’
So I sighed a second time.
When the tribute was fully presented,
I wished to let my humble stomach serve as the virtuous heart’s measure,
and I stopped only when sated.
Thus, I sighed three times."*

Wèi Zǐ declined the tribute from Gěngyáng.
*Sprinkle* is a posthumous honor.
The *Zhū* states that *Wŭ Zǐ* was his name,
and *Wŭ* was his posthumous honor.

Yán Mò and Rú Kuān, the two ministers,
advised *Wŭ Zǐ* against accepting the tribute,
wishing to let their humble stomachs serve as the virtuous heart’s measure.
The stomach is easily filled,
but the heart is hard to satisfy.
They sought to curb his greed,
and thus he did not accept the bribe from Gěngyáng.
Even when small men’s bellies are full,
they still know to stop eating—
how much more should the virtuous heart do so!
The *Spring and Autumn Annals* praised this.

The Wèi clan accepted the advice,
and thus flourished.

Weaken his resolve:
*Annotation*: A hollow heart weakens resolve.
*The Zhū* states: Resolve is the heart’s matter;
when the heart is full of virtue and power,
it is called resolve.
He wished to let the heart act properly,
and all guarded against arrogance and haste,
so it was known that a hollow heart weakens resolve.

*Explanation*: As the *Shī Xù* says: *"What arises in the heart is resolve."*
What the heart resolves upon is matter;
what the heart acts upon is resolve.
When the heart is gentle and weak,
it has no reckless, hasty, or contentious matters,
and all things are in harmony.
When matters are in harmony,
they become the foundation of governance.

Strengthen his bones:
*Annotation*: A filled stomach strengthens the bones.
*The Zhū* states: Bones are the body’s framework;
when his virtue and power are internally complete,
he never takes greedily,
and without greed, his stomach is filled,
and a filled stomach strengthens his bones.

*Explanation*: To weaken resolve means to maintain purity and gentleness,
so as not to offend from without.
To strengthen bones means to be firm and prepared within.
Those who practice the Dao/Way have strong sinews and bones,
and a hundred diseases cannot invade them.
A filled stomach strengthens the bones—
the harmonious *qi* is abundant.
To govern the realm,
when the administration is clear, the people are tranquil;
when expenses are frugal, their strength is plentiful.
Tranquil people are those whose resolve is weakened;
plentiful strength is those whose bones are strengthened.
He always kept the people without knowledge of competition
and without desire for greed.

「The *Commentary* states: The Sage’s teaching of maintaining an empty heart and a full stomach is always meant to make the people lack the knowledge of competition and the desire for greed, so that they may transform themselves naturally.

*The Explanation* says: If there is desire for greed, competition will arise; if there is knowledge of competition, undertakings will flourish. When competition and desire are absent, purity and tranquility naturally manifest. Thus, the wise will not dare to act.

*The Commentary* further elaborates: Those without knowledge or desire have already attained purity and tranquility. Then, those with knowledge should gradually be cultivated and refined until they too do not dare to act, following the natural path of greed without transgression.

*The Explanation* says: When the lower aligns with the higher, it is like the wind bending the grass—simple and harmonious, universally reaching, and all return to inaction.

To act without action is to govern without fail. *Commentary*: When one acts in accordance with nature, even action becomes inaction.

Moreover, to abandon the pursuit of the rare and virtuous and not seek difficult-to-obtain wealth: people will naturally fulfill their roles, and all things will remain in their true state. In acting without action, what further pride or partiality remains?

When there is no sound or scent, people will not recognize nor comprehend, yet simple and harmonious winds will prevail—who can say governance is not achieved?

*The Explanation* says: The principle of non-action is profound indeed. Non-action does not mean refusing what is offered, rejecting what is given, or being unresponsive to pressure, emotion, or constraint. It means that private desires do not intrude upon public conduct, and personal inclinations do not distort proper methods. To act in accordance with principle, to establish merit based on resources, to complete tasks without self-praise, and to achieve deeds without claiming renown—this is non-action.

If one uses a boat for water, a sieve for sand, a cart for mud, and a plow for mountains, if one cultivates fields in summer and ponds in winter, relying on elevation for farming and depression for water storage, then this is not what we call "action"—it is non-action.

The Sage’s non-action is to follow naturally, to accomplish without exertion, to plan without error, to act without omission, to speak through refined language, to act through proper forms, to advance and retreat with the times, to move and rest in accordance with principle. He neither favors beauty nor despises ugliness, nor does he delight in rewards or resent punishments. Names are assigned by fate, and each type is utilized as it should. Matters arise naturally, never forced by his own will. He follows the Dao/Way’s timing, adapts to the land’s nature, and aligns with the people’s hearts. Thus, ministers gather like rays to the sun, and the virtuous and unvirtuous alike fulfill their roles.

The ruler gains the means to govern his ministers, and the ministers gain the means to serve their ruler. This is the Dao/Way of governing without action.

The passage "without sound or scent" refers to the *Shijing* [□] *Dàyá* [□] *Wénwáng* [□] Chapter, which speaks of the great Dao/Way being difficult to know. The ears do not hear its sounds, the nose does not perceive its fragrance, yet if one follows the conduct of King Wen, the world will naturally trust and submit.

The passage "not recognized, not comprehended" refers to the *Shijing* [□] *Dàyá* [□] *Huángyǐ* [□] Chapter, which states that people do not recognize the past nor know the present, yet those who follow the Dao/Way’s laws will align with this. This passage accords with the teaching that the Dao/Way values sincerity and naturalness, not the pursuit of the virtuous or wealth.

**Chapter Four: The Dao/Way of Non-Action and Its Application**
*The Commentary* states: The previous chapter clarified that noble pursuits are not actively promoted, and that non-action leads to the utmost governance.»

**Chapter Four: The Dao/Way of Non-Action and Its Application (Continued)**

This chapter elucidates the subtle origin’s function—its application through non-action. It begins by marking *Dao suong* (冲), demonstrating the ultimate source of emptiness. Next, it speaks of *cuòjiě* (挫解), clarifying how *suong* (冲) resolves discord. It concludes by likening it to the Emperor of the Mythic Age, intending to make its essence fully known.

**Explanation:**
The Dao’s application is boundless—vast enough to encompass heaven and earth, yet subtle enough to permeate the finest hairs. Serene and self-sufficient, it neither lacks nor overflows. Applied to the body, it harmonizes dust and light; wielded within, it transforms sharpness into tranquility. Even before the eons of the Mythic Age, it stood as the foremost principle. Among all teachings, only the Dao is worthy of reverence. Thus, all things converge toward it.

*Qu* (趣) means "to turn toward." Though the Dao’s application through *suong* (冲) may seem unfilled, it is not truly so. **Annotation:** The Dao’s movement generates *suonghé* (冲和) qi, and its function in creation never overflows. The phrase "or seems" acknowledges that the Dao cannot be definitively described.

**Deep and still,** it resembles the origin of all things. **Annotation:** *Yuān* (渊), meaning profound and tranquil, describes the Dao’s constant generation of all things without overflow. Its subtle origin is deep and still, thus appearing as the sovereign of all things.

**Commentary:** *Suong* (冲) is emptiness—meaning the Dao’s function lies in its void. The harmonious qi of *suong* (冲) and emptiness constitutes the Dao’s application, giving rise to all things, which benefit from its effects. Though the effects may seem radiant and vast, the Dao itself remains unfilled, its origin profound and still, eternally the source of all things. The annotation "or seems" reflects that the Dao has no fixed form, hence cannot be spoken of directly. The rest follows this pattern.

**Explanation:** The Dao is ever humble, unfilled, harmonious, and serene, dwelling within all things. Deeply mysterious and still, it governs them. Thus, when things lose the Dao’s *suonghé* (冲和), they suffer harm and perish; when people lose it, they die; when rulers lose it, governance falters and the people scatter; when ministers lose it, their reputation fades and they are disgraced. Therefore, the Dao of *suonghé* (冲和) is the foundation of all things’ security, the sovereign of all things.

When speaking of its influence on things, it appears radiant and vast; when seeking its origin, it is profound, still, and ever-empty. The Dao has no fixed form—it cannot be spoken of as having definite attributes, yet all things are governed by it. **Compliance** with this principle means not presuming to define it.

It dulls sharpness and resolves discord. **Annotation:** Because the Dao is *suonghé* (冲和), it restrains harshness and disperses turmoil. If vulgar learning seeks to restore [original purity], it only entangles further.

**Commentary:** *Cuò* (挫) means to restrain; *ruì* (锐) means sharp; *jiě* (解) means to disperse. The function of *suong* (冲) and emptiness is irresistible to all things, so sharp desires and tumultuous affairs, when met with the Dao’s *suonghé* (冲和), naturally subside and disperse. This teaches people the Dao’s application.

**Annotation:** The phrase "vulgar learning seeks to restore" refers to the *Zhuangzi* [*Xiu Xing* Chapter], which states: *"To refine nature in the vulgar world, vulgar learning seeks to restore its origin."* Sharpness and discord arise from desires, so recalling the Dao dulls and resolves them, while vulgar learning only deepens entanglement.

**Explanation:** Governing the realm with the Dao of *suonghé* (冲和) means there are no sharp emotions to harm things, no laborious affairs to weary people. Without harm to things, all nations come willingly, the four barbarians turn to civilization, arms are not raised, grievances do not arise, and there is no boasting of territorial expansion or domination of the weak.

「Not harming people, then the people are governed in due course, with light duties and taxes, and households are well-provisioned, people’s needs met.

In governing oneself, one resolves discord and dulls sharpness, without external invasion or rivalry, internally embracing clarity and purity—spirit serene, body at ease, tranquil and naturally contented.

*"This teaches people the Dao’s application"*—those who are enlightened must rely on the Dao.

The *Zhuangzi* [*Xiu Xing* Chapter] states: *"Vulgar learning seeks to restore its origin"*—this means that once people have rationalized within the vulgar world, they then wish to use vulgar learning to recover the original nature of life and death. The more they seek, the further they stray from the Dao.

Vulgar learning only deepens entanglement: sharp and restless hearts, chaotic affairs—if they are not resolved and dispersed by the Dao, then they are bound by vulgar learning, ever more knotted and fixed, beyond release.

Vulgar learning is the pursuit of mundane studies, not the Dao of ceaseless depletion.

*"Blending its radiance, harmonizing with dust."* **Annotation:** The Dao is ever-present, yet its presence is always without form. In light, it becomes one with light; in dust, it becomes one with dust—though neither light nor dust itself. It appears as though it might exist, yet does not.

*"Qí [淇]—as if something remains."* **Annotation:** In blending radiance and harmonizing with dust, the subtle essence remains unmixed. Hence, it appears as if something remains.

**Explanation:** The Dao’s *suonghé* (冲和) permeates all living beings, vast and unobstructed. All things exist within it; thus, it may be called blending radiance and harmonizing with dust. Light refers to clarity and purity; dust to confusion and chaos. Those who follow the Dao do not rigidly distinguish themselves but instead merge with the multitude. Though the Dao permeates all, its most refined essence remains concentrated and tranquil, never depleted or exhausted. Hence, it is said to persist.

I do not know whose child it is—it precedes the *Xiàngdì* (象帝). **Annotation:** I do not know its origin, for the Dao’s essence is not something born of generation. Thus, it has no father. The Dao appears as if it precedes the *Xiàngdì*—the sovereign of all things.

The *Xiàngdì* is the sovereign who nurtures all things, the origin of flourishing and growth. *Xiàng* means "as if."

**Explanation:** The *Xiàngdì* is the primal force from which all transformations arise, the sovereign who first establishes form and order, guiding all with the *Dao* of kingship. The great Dao of *suonghé* (冲和) generates all transformations, thus existing even before the *Xiàngdì*. The Sage-Laozi, being most enlightened, surely knew the Dao’s fundamental source! Yet he posed this apparent paradox to awaken those lost in vulgar ways—just as he did earlier when explaining that the Dao cannot be directly named.

*"The Sage-Laozi said: The *Xiàngdì* emerges from the *Zhèn* (震) [trigram]."* This is from the *Yì* [*Xì Yǔ* Chapter]. *Zhèn* is the eastern trigram, the rising *shǎoyáng* (少阳) qi—the source of all transformations. Now, with the heir apparent dwelling in the eastern palace, the *shǎoyáng* position, and ascending the throne as the time of emergence from *Zhèn*, it symbolizes the beginning of heaven and earth’s nurturing of all things.

*"As if it sees the forms"*—the Dao is formless, yet it manifests forms. *Qi* (气) is formless; *xiàng* (象) is the manifestation of form. The Dao is the first principle of all things.

The first principle of all things appears as if it precedes the *Xiàngdì*. The great Dao, however, has no true end nor beginning—who can know what precedes it? It is merely a rhetorical device to convey its boundless expanse.

The *Yì* states: *"The *Xiàngdì* emerges from the *Zhèn* (震) [trigram], and all things are born. It aligns with the *Sūn* (巽) [trigram], and all things are purified and harmonized. It manifests mutually with the *Lí* (离) [trigram], and the sage faces south toward brightness to govern. It administers duties through the *Kūn* (坤) [trigram], and all things receive sustenance. It speaks with grace through the *Guāng* (光) [trigram], and all things delight. It wages conflict through the *Qián* (乾) [trigram], and yin and yang clash. It labors through the *Kǎn* (坎) [trigram], and all things return. It completes through the *Gèn* (艮) [trigram], and all things reach their end."*

All things arise from *Zhèn* and conclude in *Gèn*—ending yet beginning anew, cycling through transformations without end. Yet the *Xiàngdì* emerges even before this *Zhèn*, and the Dao precedes the *Xiàngdì*, thus enabling it to be the sovereign of all transformations and the primal origin of heaven and earth.

The ruler embodies the Dao in heart, with no overreaching ambitions, pure and still like a clear spring. Governing all directions, he avoids external sharpness and contention, while below him, chaotic affairs cease. He blends with heaven’s radiance to illuminate all, yet contains the dust of the world while maintaining supreme dignity.

His effortless transformation may be likened to the *Xiàngdì*.

The *Broad Explication of the True Scripture of the Dao and Virtue* concludes its eighth volume. The *Broad Explication of the True Scripture of the Dao and Virtue* begins its ninth volume.

**Chapter Five: "Heaven and Earth Are Not Benevolent"**
*Attributed to Master Guangcheng of the Tang by Du Guangting*

**Explication:**
The previous chapter elucidated the subtle origin and effortless application of the Dao—action without doing. This chapter exposes partial favor as private inclination, for narrow self-interest makes universal care difficult.

It begins by likening all things to *chúdòu* (sacrificial straw dogs), illustrating heaven and earth’s impartial forgetfulness. Next, it compares them to *tuóruì* (windbags and flutes), demonstrating how emptiness yields without resistance. It concludes with the exhaustion of excessive speech, urging adherence to the *Zhōnghé* (Central Harmony).

**Meaning:**
To cling to benevolence as benevolence is to be bound by it; to not cling to benevolence as benevolence is to be without private favor. The sovereign’s regard for all living beings is like heaven and earth’s regard for all things. All things arise and transform of themselves—heaven and earth do not claim the merit. All beings dwell and reside—sovereigns do not claim the virtue. To rely on the subtle *qi* for inspiration and the mysterious transformation for creation is the ultimate transformation.

Yet if one speaks of their benevolence and virtue, the logic will inevitably reach its limits. Why? Heaven and earth’s benevolence is vast, yet grasses and trees wither in winter and flourish in summer. The sovereign’s benevolence is vast, yet punishments include exile and the axe. It is not as great as the benevolence of *not* clinging to benevolence.

To uphold the *Chōnghé* (Supreme Harmony) and preserve purity and stillness is the essential key to governing oneself.

Heaven and earth are not benevolent—they treat all things as *chúdòu*.
The Sage is not benevolent—they treat the people as *chúdòu*.
**Annotation:** *Not benevolent* means not acting with benevolent favor. *Chúdòu* refers to straw shaped into a dog’s form.

Dogs are kept for guarding, and thus receive the恩 of shelter and food. But *chúdòu* merely has the form of a dog without its barking or guarding function, so it is without regard for benevolence. This shows that heaven and earth regard humans as they do *chúdòu*—without expectation or demand.

Let us examine this further: Ultimate benevolence knows no partiality—how then does it encompass love? If love is not ultimate, it is merely partial favor. If one does not love only their own kin, then all under heaven are kin. If one does not cherish only their own children, then all under heaven are children. Thus, ultimate benevolence’s lack of partiality is in fact the most profound kinship. Is this not the meaning of *comprehensive love*?

**Explication:**
*Benevolence* is the name for *comprehensive love*. *Chú* means grass—referring to straw shaped into a dog for sacrificial use.

Zhuangzi says: *Master Jin spoke to Yan Hui: "When the sacrificial straw dog has not yet been used, it is adorned with embroidered cloth. But once it has been used, the kitchen attendants take it to cook. Now, if the Master takes the already-used straw dogs of former kings and treasures them among his disciples, it is like the traveler who treads upon them or the woodcutter who burns them. Alas, the Master’s path will end in ruin!"*

Yan Hui asked: *"What do you mean?"*
Master Jin replied: *"When the sacrificial straw dog is not yet used, it is wrapped in fine brocade and adorned with embroidery. The ritual officers fast and purify themselves before presenting it. But once it has been used, travelers trample it, and woodcutters burn it for firewood. If you were to try to reclaim it and store it again, it would be absurd. Now, the Master takes the already-used straw dogs of former kings and gathers disciples to revere them. Thus, he was attacked in Song, exiled in Wei, driven into poverty in Shang and Zhou, and besieged in Chen and Cai. This is like the traveler’s tread or the woodcutter’s fire!"*

Dogs bark and guard—yet the *chúdòu* has no such function. Heaven and earth regard all things as they do *chúdòu*: they do not demand barking or guarding, nor do they claim creation as benevolent favor. They do not expect repayment, nor do they proclaim their virtue—thus, they are *not benevolent*.

Humans show dogs kindness by sheltering and burying them properly. But toward *chúdòu*, they show no such regard. This clarifies that the Sage does not take *comprehensive love* as benevolence.

**Annotation on *pronei* (sheltering):**
*The Book of Rites* says: When Confucius’ dog died, he had Zi Gong bury it, saying: *"I have heard that a worn-out curtain is not discarded—it is used to bury a horse. The ruler’s carriage horses are buried with curtains. A worn-out mat is not discarded—it is used to bury a dog. I, Zhong You, am poor and have no mat. When I bury it, I will also place a mat beneath it so its head does not sink into the earth."*

*"Not loving only one’s own kin"* is from *The Rites of Zhou*: *"When the Great Way prevails, all under heaven is for the public. One does not love only one’s own kin, nor cherish only one’s own children. Love is extended to all things, and the public good is pursued without partiality."*

Between heaven and earth, is it not like the *tuóruì*?

**Annotation:**
*Tuó* is a windbag; *ruì* is a flute. The windbag’s bellows and the flute’s breath are both empty and without intent, yet they move and resonate. Thus, the creation of all things without partiality by heaven and earth is also due to their emptiness and lack of fixed purpose.

「Empty yet unyielding, moving yet ever more forth. **Annotation:** The *tuóruì*’s emptiness is unyielding; when it is stirred, the more it emits sound and *qi*. This illustrates the Sage’s heart without partial love—never strained or obstructed, its responses endless, truly moving yet ever more forth.

**Commentary:** *Tuó* is the windbag, which uses bellows of skin to blow wind and ignite fire. *Ruì* is the flute, which employs bamboo pipes to channel *qi*. The windbag cannot stir without the flute to guide its breath, nor can the flute channel *qi* without the windbag to supply it. These two rely on each other in action, just as heaven and earth—*tuó* as heaven, the five *qi* as *ruì*—hold the empty yet dynamic principle to produce myriad distinctions, never exhausting themselves. When the ruler maintains an empty heart and practices the Dao, ministers and officials embody his virtue and actions, just as heaven and earth move the five *qi* without depletion. Thus, governance is unstrained, and the four seas are in peace. "Moving yet ever more forth" signifies endlessness.

The virtue of *chúnhuà* (pure and harmonious transformation) is uniform, permeating all things. "Daily use yet unaware" is from *The Book of Changes*’s **系辞传 (Xìyī Shìyán):** *"The common people use it daily yet do not know."* This means the common people rely on this Dao daily to sustain life, yet they are unaware of its power. The Dao is profound and inscrutable; it does not seek recognition as a deed, so the people use it without knowing.

**Annotation:** *Lù* (屈) means exhaustion. Excessive speech leads to depletion, and depletion means exhaustion. Universal love is hard to exhaust, yet it breeds resentment and strife, so it is better to embrace the central harmony, letting all things naturally suffice.

**Commentary:** Excessive speech refers to frequent talk of universal love. Though one speaks much of it, acting on it is difficult to exhaust, so speech depletes without fulfillment. Thus, it is better to forget the mind and respond with emptiness, holding fast to central harmony, letting all things naturally suffice.
