Their virtue is vast as an empty valley—**旷**, spacious; their virtue and capacity are vast and boundless, able to contain all things, like that empty valley.

The **virtue** is both sincere and vast—**敦** thick and steadfast, **量** boundless in scope—
it contains all good and evil without discrimination,
and upholds all right and wrong without obstruction,
spacious as an empty valley, swallowing all things whole.

Mixed and indistinct as turbid water.
**Annotation:** Blending with the world’s luminous chaos,
like turbid water that yet holds clarity within.
**Explication:** The virtuous one’s heart is pure yet receptive,
harmonizing with the world like dust in the light,
undistinguished in their blending,
so indistinct as turbid water—
their presence is seen, but their essence remains unfathomable.

**Meaning:** When water is clear, it reflects all virtues and vices,
yet others measure its depth and shallowness.
But in autumn’s flood, when muddy waves surge,
the tumult of rushing currents confounds even cattle and horses—
deep and shallow become unknowable,
gazing upon them leaves one in bewilderment.
Who could dare to wade through such depths?

The ultimate person blends with the world’s luminosity,
mixing their traces like flowing water,
not revealing their subtlety,
like turbid water—
their form is visible, yet their path remains unseen.

The sovereign governing the realm, riding the times,
must first manifest their **virtue**.
They should not indulge in minute scrutiny,
but instead present the **Dao**’s broad and simple ways,
so the people remain unaware and unknowing,
following the **Way**’s natural order—
this is the **Dao**’s transformation,
and no greater good exists.

Who can then, in the midst of turbid longing,
with stillness settle the waves,
and let clarity arise slowly?

**Annotation:** Who can, in this enduring clarity,
still seek higher methods,
stirring and refining their practice,
so that the pure nature does not stagnate in **Dao**,
but moves forth gently?

**Explication:** This teaching is without obstruction.
Who can, with their clear and still nature,
settle the stirrings of love and desire,
as if water’s turbidity, once stilled,
now flows pure?
Yet if one lingers too long in this clarity,
stagnation sets in—
unawakened, still unmanifest—
then they must pursue even greater methods,
stirring and refining their practice,
as the **Dao**’s essence is both diminished and restored,
and actions arise then fade away—
so the pure nature does not stagnate in **Dao**,
but moves forth gently.

**Meaning:** The Great **Dao** delights in birth,
luring people with its teachings.
Through myriad methods, one refines their nature,
through myriad practices, one cultivates their heart—
awakening leads to practice, practice leads to realization.
The principles of cultivation and realization,
broadly outlined,
include breathing the primal harmony,
swallowing and rinsing the celestial fluid,
eating pine and chewing bark,
forsaking grains to nourish on fungi.
Some retreat to the **Upper Celestial**,
secretly watching the **Mysterious Dipper**,
some forge **Five Metals** and **Eight Stones**,
some purify **Water Jade** and **Flowing Pearls**,
employing **Yin Cauldron** and **Yang Furnace**,
through **Five Phases** and **Nine Transformations**.
Some compose **Pure Texts** and **Elixir Scrolls**,
summoning spirits with **Golden Buttons** and **Green Threads**,
pledging oaths to heaven and earth—
then there are the **Orthodox Unity** of **Dao**,
the **Ascending Mysterious** and **Nurturing Spirit**,
the **Soul Treasure** and **Manifesting True**,
the **Three Celestials** and myriad **Dao**’s laws,
all discarding the mundane to attain the **Way**,
realizing the stages of **Dao**’s fruit.

There are also those who chase the **Two Sceneries**,
worship the **Five Celestial Stems**,
climb to the **Pole Star** and grasp the **Handle**,
soaring beyond the **Netherworld** and **Celestial Records**,
swallowing the sun and moon,
seizing the soul and binding the spirit,
gazing at the **Eight Paths** toward the clouds,
receiving the **Nine Truths**’s blessings,
ascending the **Mysterious** to rest in the **Dipper**,
dwelling in the **Hall of Perfection**,
left and right in **Spirit Flight**,
embracing **Yin** and **Yang** in the **Six Jia**,
the **Three Departments** and **Eight Sceneries**,
the **Twenty-Four Truths**,
preserving the **Three Elements**,
fixing the **Triple Unity**,
entering the **Purple Chamber** at the **Yellow Gate**,
beholding the **Vermilion Scene** in the **Red Cradle**.
The **Purple Void** scriptures of **Southern Peak**,
the **Green Boy**’s **□** [missing character] **East Sea** **Dao**,
internal gazing at the **Five Viscera**,
subduing the **Six Heavens** below,
guiding and inhaling the **Symbols**,
riding the wind to nourish the **qi**—
the methods of soaring transcend the **True Scripture**,
and some may attain the **Way** through a single practice,
thus able to rescue the **Primordial Ancestor** from eternal night,
and fly their body through the **Great Void**,
crossing the **Nine Terraces** in an instant—
who would dare to shame the **Dao**’s worthies?
Or, with a glance, encompass the **Six Directions**—
who would dare to rival **Hongmeng**?

Yet the world’s great deluded ones cannot savor this,
and they say: *"The affairs of the immortals*
*are not sought through mere accumulation of learning."*
They also claim: *"Those who attain the **Way***
*all have a set lifespan,*
*when their fate is exhausted, they sink back into decay."*
But they fail to know—
those who attain the **Way** naturally ascend to immortality,
from immortality realize **Sainthood**,
ascend to **Sainthood**’s ultimate fruit,
and merge with the **Way**’s true essence—
no span of life is measured,
no fate is exhausted—
in a breath, they traverse billions of **kalpas**,
with a gesture, they surpass ten thousand heavens.
The *Wen Xuan* says: *"A brief parting of a thousand years,*
*a fleeting journey of ten thousand miles."*
The *Step-on-the-Void Words* declare: *"The Eight Heavens span a finger’s reach,*
*the Six Directions are but a palm’s breadth."*
All are their deeds.

But when practice is attained,
one forgets its cultivation—
cultivation and forgetting alternate,
without lingering or attachment—
this is the marvel.

The **Dao** is what the **methods** elucidate,
yet realizing the **Dao** means forgetting the **methods**.
Words are what the **mind** observes,
yet grasping the **mind** means forgetting the words.
If one lingers in the **methods**,
the **Dao** cannot flow freely.

「If one lingers in **words**,
then the **mind** cannot be fully realized.

Thus, when one does not cling to the **methods**,
one turns to deeper cultivation,
and when one does not cling to **words**,
one renews understanding and insight.

*"Successive arising and successive extinction"*—
the *Sutra of the Western Ascension* states:
*"If you can follow the practice,*
*then successive arising and successive extinction."*

This analogy illustrates the **Hinayana**’s conditioned **dharma**,
used to instruct beginners.
Once the door is obtained,
gradually apply **Mahayana**’s intermediate **dharma**,
to refine the practice.
When the practice is refined,
then apply the **Mahayana**’s ultimate **dharma**,
to abandon fixation—
thus, the ordinary attain realization,
layered realizations ascend to sainthood.
Though the fruits of **sainthood** and **Dao** attainment span twenty-seven grades,
the practiced **deeds** must not be clung to or fixed upon—
this is the meaning of *"gradual growth and gradual purity, successive arising and successive extinction."*

Those who uphold this **Dao** do not wish to be full.

**Note:** To preserve this **Dao** of gradual purity and gradual growth,
one must cling to nothing.
If one fixates on purity and seeks life,
this is called **excess**—
one will lose this **Dao**.

Thus it is said: *"Do not wish to be full."*

**Commentary:** Lingering in **methods** and fixating on purity
is what is called **excess**.
Thus, if one wishes to fully preserve this **Dao** of gradual purity and gradual growth,
one must not cling to anything,
and attain **non-attainment**.

Now, if one lingers in purity while seeking life,
this is damaging **excess**.
**Excess** obstructs the **Dao**—
thus it is said: *"Do not wish to be full."*

**Explication:** The ability to grasp the **dharma** of successive arising and successive extinction
is the key to attaining the essence of gradual purity and gradual growth.
To uphold this principle,
one must not be fixed in **excess**—
this aligns with the reasoning of the following verse.

Only those who are not full
can thus avoid **newly attained** fixations.

**Note:** Only those who do not cling to **excess**
can continually apply newly realized **dharma**,
considering their **deeds** as insufficient,
not fixating on their **new attainments**.

**Commentary:** Those who can abandon all desire and fixation,
reaching the state of **non-doing** (*wuwei*),
and do not cling to or become full of the **dharma**,
always regard their newly realized **dharma** as **imperfect**,
seeking higher attainment—
not fixating on their **newly attained** state.

**Explication:** Having mastered old **methods**,
one attains new **dharma**.
This refers to entering the **intermediate vehicle** from the **Hinayana**.

The **intermediate vehicle**’s **Dao** is either provisional or real—
still, one lingers in practice.
Abandoning this provisional and real path of practice,
one seeks entry into the **ultimate vehicle**’s **non-doing** realm.
If one fixates on practice,
not realizing **non-doing**,
this is called **new attainment**—
yet it remains **excess**, and one will lose the **Dao**.
Thus, one must diminish it again and again,
ascending from coarse to subtle.

As for governance—
the ancient **sage-rulers** and virtuous ministers,
called *"skilled officials"* (*shànwéi shìzhě*),
were **profoundly** in harmony with **Dao** and **virtue**,
their **virtue** beyond measure.

Yet they were still like one crossing a river in winter,
fearing the ice—
trepidatious of neighboring states’ taboos,
as if a guest in **non-doing**,
adapting to circumstances, following the people,
flexing and extending without fixation,
and the ice melts.
Their **virtue** was vast as a valley,
their embrace pure and simple.

To govern with **Dao**—
though outwardly **impure**,
the heart is **pure** and inwardly luminous,
without the **Dao**’s obstruction of **excess** or arrogance,
upholding the rule of **imperfection** without **new attainment**—
their lineage will endure through the **great floods** (*yánhóng*),
and the people will thrive in **serenity and peace**.

The traces of **ancient purity**—
how distant are they?

**Chapter Sixteen: *Zhì Xūjí* – "Extending to the Ultimate Void"**

**Exegesis:**

The preceding chapter illuminated the **Dao**-communing sage, ever preserving the **Way** yet never replete. This chapter expounds upon those who cultivate stillness, returning to their root and restoring their vital breath—restoring breath being the key to knowing constancy, while guarding stillness is the path to attaining the Void.

The text unfolds in sequence, revealing that though principles converge in the practice of the **Dao**, knowing constancy brings clarity, and walking the **Dao** ensures endurance.

**Exposition:**

In the prior chapter, we saw the **Dao**-aligned sage embodying the gradual, tranquil generation of **virtue**. Here, we turn to the constancy of returning to one’s root and restoring breath.

Though one may govern as a sovereign, one must align with Heaven and embody the **Dao**; embodying the **Dao** ensures longevity, thus averting peril.

**Extending to the Ultimate Void**—
**Guarding stillness** with unwavering devotion.

**Annotation:**
*"Extending to the Ultimate Void"*—this is the **Mystic Source**.
It is said that all human life originates from this **Ultimate Void**, this **Mystic Source**. Yet once form receives and assimilates, the **Mystic Source** scatters. To restore the **Ultimate Void** within oneself, one must sever all entanglements with the profane world, steadfastly preserving this **feminine stillness** with depth and sincerity—then the **Dao** of the **Ultimate Void** will naturally manifest within.

**Exegesis:**
*"Extending to the Ultimate Void"*—this is the **Mystic Source** of the **Dao**.
Human life originates from the **Dao** as its foundation. That which is received is pure, untrammelled, and free of defilement—hence, it is called *"the Rectified."* Yet after birth, this Rectified nature drifts into error, becomes stained by worldly habits, and loses itself in mundane existence. The **Dao** is abandoned, and delusion encroaches daily.

The **Venerable Master Lao** admonishes: *"Those who cultivate the **Dao** must extinguish the impulses of desire and return to the profound stillness, only then may they govern the **Dao** of the **Ultimate Void**."*

**Annotation:**
*"Devotion"* means *"depth."*

**Exegesis:**
After birth, the six senses are stained, and the five desires contend—thus the Rectified nature scatters, and the **Mystic Source** is lost.

**Exposition:**
The nature received from the **Dao** is inherently pure and still. Yet after birth, it becomes obscured by defilements, clouding the mind and obscuring the true **Way**.

The six senses are:
1. The **eye-sense**, perceiving all forms;
2. The **ear-sense**, hearing all sounds;
3. The **mind-sense**, generating attachment and speculation;
4. The **nose-sense**, discerning aromas and foul odors;
5. The **tongue-sense**, tasting flavors;
6. The **body-sense**, experiencing afflictions.

From these six arise all karmic causes, cyclically generating and obscuring the true nature—
like plants bearing flowers and fruit, endlessly proliferating, yet all originating from these six roots, hence called the *"six senses."*

The five desires are:
- The **eye’s** desire for colors,
- The **ear’s** for sounds,
- The **nose’s** for fragrances,
- The **mouth’s** for tastes,
- The **heart’s** for myriad cravings.

These obstruct the five faculties, entangling in afflictions—all arising from here.
When the inner heart is pleased, it is called *love*.
When external objects seize the mind, it is called *staining*.
When objects evoke the mind, it is called *desire*.
When desire is not restrained, it is called *rampant*.
When thoughts and speculations invade, it is called *contention*.
Thus the Rectified nature disperses, and with each thought, evil arises. Because evil arises, the true root is abandoned.

**Exegesis:**
To restore the **Ultimate Void** and the **Mystic Source** within oneself, one must preserve this **feminine, still, profound, and sincere** nature while severing desire—neither constricting nor indulging—then the **Mystic Source** will naturally manifest.

**Exposition:**
When thoughts generate evil, it is said one has lost the **Dao**. To restore the **Mystic Dao** within, one must cultivate **feminine, steadfast, and tranquil** conduct, nurturing a **profound, sincere, and serene** nature to govern one’s passions.

Passions are the *branches*; nature is the *root*.
If nature generates passions, they follow objects as desires.
If passions nourish nature, they still the mind and return to the Origin.
Returning to the Origin, the five desires do not arise, the six senses remain undisturbed—
neither constricting the breath nor narrowing the heart—
then the **Dao** of the **Mystic Source** will naturally manifest within.

*"Neither constricting one’s dwelling nor satiating one’s birth"*—
words from *Chapter Thirty-Four* of the *De Jing*.

The *Xī Shēng Jīng* states:
*"When the heart is void, harmonious breath returns."*

**Exegesis:**
This is also like water flowing to dampness, fire drawn to dryness.

*"Extending"* means to let it come of its own accord—
as in *The Spring and Autumn Annals*, where *"extending"* refers to summoning troops.

**Exposition:**
Water and fire are senseless yet respond to their nature—
water flows to dampness, fire consumes dryness.
Even without awareness or sentiment, they respond thus.
How much more so should a void heart and tranquil contemplation attract the **Dao**?
It will come without seeking.

*"Extending troops"*—from *The Spring and Autumn Annals*, *Year Twelve of Duke Xiang*:
When the King of Chu besieged Zheng for seventeen days, the people of Zheng divined for surrender, but it was inauspicious. The citizens gathered in mourning, and the King of Chu withdrew his forces. The people of Zheng then repaired their city walls.

The siege lasted three months, and Zheng was captured. The Marquis of Zheng, bare-chested and leading a sheep, went to meet the King of Chu, who then agreed to peace. Pan Nang entered into the alliance, and Zi Liang was sent as a hostage. In the sixth month of summer, the army of Jin came to rescue Zheng. At the border of Enhuo, the King of Chu sought peace with Jin, and an alliance was agreed upon for a set day.

The King of Chu appointed Gu Yu as charioteer and Le Bo as right-hand warrior, with She Shu as his driver, intending to challenge Jin in single combat to feign unwillingness to make peace and provoke the Jin army. Gu Yu said, *"I have heard that to provoke an army, one should drive the chariot without flags or whips and return."* Le Bo said, *"To provoke an army, one should shoot an arrow to the left with a bow, then exchange places with the charioteer to hold the reins, descend from the chariot, strike the horses, and return."* She Shu said, *"To provoke an army, one should enter the enemy camp on the right, cut off the enemy’s banner, and return with captives beheaded."* Each acted according to what they had heard and returned.

The Jin army pursued them. Le Bo shot the horses on the left and the men on the right, driving them back so they could not advance. At that time, Wei Xie and Zhao Zhan bore grudges against Jin and requested envoys to Chu, all hoping for Jin’s defeat. Ji Zi also failed to prepare defenses, and at Qi, the Jin army was utterly defeated.

Thus, to provoke an army leads to enmity. Likewise, if one seeks the Dao through stillness, the Dao must be attainable.

When all things move in concert, I observe their return.
**Commentary:** The Venerable Master asks: How does one know that by guarding this feminine stillness, one can attain the utmost emptiness? Simply observe how all things move and act, and how they return—this is always rooted in stillness, and thus it is known.

**Exposition:** This clarifies that steadfastly guarding stillness will surely lead to the utmost emptiness. All things, in their myriad forms and movements, return to their origin. Meaning: Though things move and act in countless ways, they inevitably return to their source. If one cultivates an empty heart and contemplates the Dao, the Dao will gather within that emptiness. Hence, the warning to maintain an empty heart and ponder the Dao.

**Exposition:** The *Classic of Changes* says: *"Thunder returns within the earth."* Returning refers to restoring to one’s origin. Thus, stillness brings return, while movement loses its root. Meaning: The *Classic of Changes*’ *Hexagram of Returning* states: *"Thunder returns within the earth."* Thunder is a moving force, and the hexagram emphasizes the cessation of movement, hence *"thunder within the earth."* The ancient kings, on the winter solstice, closed the gates, halted commerce, and did not inspect the provinces—all to embody the principle of movement’s cessation and restore to the root.

When all things move in concert, that is movement;
Observing their return is stillness.
If one moves when stillness is due and stirs when stillness is required,
then one loses the root.

All things, teeming and thriving, each return to their origin.
**Commentary:** It is also said that one knows all things return to stillness because, though flowers and leaves teem and flourish, their nature is to return to their roots. Some say *"thus and so"*—that is, movement and action. It means that all things, though teeming in movement, return to their roots in the end.

**Exposition:** This uses analogy to clarify the meaning of observing return. The root is where one receives *qi* and gives birth. Now, observe how all things—flowers, leaves, and teeming growth—by their very nature return to their roots to regenerate. Meaning: *Ke yun* (芸芸) describes lush abundance. All grasses and trees, teeming and flourishing, wither and fall, then return to their roots to regrow and flourish anew. Returning to the root is returning to stillness. This is the natural principle of all things.

Humans receive the Dao and are born, their source pure and still. Once born into the world, desires and ambitions drag them—beauty and ugliness, prosperity and decline, wealth and poverty, myriad paths and countless schemes—wearing out the body and exhausting the spirit. Some overturn the earth and heaven, wielding extraordinary might; others establish deeds and achievements, earning names unmatched in the age.

Some bear the celestial cauldron and uproot mountains, others stretch iron hooks to draw the heavens;
some ride swift chariots with sleek steeds, others ride in lofty carriages with crimson wheels.
Their influence eclipses that of the **Xǔ Shǐ Jīn Zhāng** (许史金张)—the mighty and noble—
and their splendor surpasses the **Wǔ Hóu Qī Guì** (五侯七贵)—the five marquises and seven exalted houses.
Yet even the most flourishing of all must, when their fate is spent and their power shifts,
suddenly become mere mounds of earth.

This is returning to the root and attaining stillness.

If one can renounce worldly glory and truly comprehend the transient nature of splendor,
emptying the mind and nurturing the **spirit** (*shén* 神),
quieting the thoughts and pondering the Dao/Way,
why could they not attain the Dao/Way?

**Commentary:** The **Mystic Origin** (*xiūjí miàoběn* 虚极妙本) is what humans inherit and by which they are born.
Now, observe how **lustful desires** (*xìngyù xīxī* 性欲熙熙) flourish;
if one can preserve stillness and attain emptiness,
then one aligns with their true nature,
restores their inherent vitality (*mìngguāng* 命光),
and achieves lasting endurance.

The preceding words are explained as follows:
**Familiar abundance** (*xīxī*) signifies carefree joy.
Humans’ passions and desires flourish like blooming flowers and verdant leaves.
When luxuriance is at its peak, it soon withers and falls;
when desires are unrestrained, they inevitably harm life.
Thus, one must abandon desires and close the heart
to return to the Dao/Way.

The words above may also describe **multitude** (*qúnshù* 群数).
Returning to the root is stillness; stillness is restoring vitality (*fù mìng* 复命).

**Note:** Flowers and leaves—when their nature returns to the root, they cease in motion.
Humans who return to the root and attain perfect stillness
can be said to restore their inherited vitality (*xìngmìng* 性命).

**Commentary:** All things return to their roots and find peace;
humans who uphold stillness attain emptiness.
What humans inherit to be born is the **Mystic Origin** (*miàoběn* 妙本).
If they can uphold stillness and attain emptiness,
they restore their vitality (*fù mìng* 复命),
and this is called attaining the **Constant** (*cháng* 常).

**Commentary:** Those who can guard **feminine stillness** (*cíjìng* 雌静) with sincerity and depth,
attaining emptiness and the **Mystic Origin** (*miàoběn*),
restore their vitality (*fù mìng*) and attain the **Constant** (*cháng*).

The meaning is:
Abandoning passions and guarding **harmony** (*chōnghé* 冲和),
one returns to the **original teaching** (*zhāngshǒu* 章首)—
emptiness and stillness—
and thereby attains the **Constant**.

Knowing the **Constant** is called **clarity** (*míng* 明).

**Note:** Guarding stillness and restoring vitality is attaining the **Constant**.
Those who know and guard the **Constant** grow ever more enlightened.

**Note:** Those who do not uphold their **virtue/power** (*dé* 德) may invite shame.
**Commentary:** Losing the **Constant** and acting recklessly is extreme folly (*qióngxiōng* 穷凶).
**Commentary:** Those who know and uphold the **Constant** are enlightened (*míngliǎo* 明了).
Losing the **Constant** and acting recklessly is called **lacking constancy** (*wúhéng* 无恒).
Those who lack constancy in their **virtue/power** (*dé* 德) must surely invite extreme folly (*qióngxiōng* 穷凶).

The **Book of Changes** (*Yì* 易) states in the **Héng** (恒) hexagram:
*"Those who do not uphold their **virtue/power** (*dé* 德) may invite shame."*
**Héng** (恒) is the **Constant**.
To be in a position without moderation,
to advance and retreat without certainty—
though one may dwell in the **Héng** (恒) hexagram,
they defy its essence (*héngtǐ* 恒体),
and thus are truly shameful and wicked,
hence *"may invite shame."*

The **Appended Images** (*Xiàng* 象) say:
*"Those who do not uphold their **virtue/power** (*dé* 德) have no place to dwell."*
Knowing the **Constant** (*zhī cháng* 知常) is called **clarity** (*míng* 明).
**Clarity** (*míng*) discerns all things,
and when things come, they must respond—
nothing is excluded from its embrace (*hánróng* 含弘).
Thus it is said: *"Knowing the **Constant** (*cháng*) is called **clarity** (*míng*)."*

The meaning is:
Upholding the **Constant** (*cháng*) in one’s **virtue/power** (*dé* 德)
is to have nothing excluded—
this is the opposite of the earlier **Appended Images** (*Xiàng* 象).
Attaining the **Constant** and embodying the Dao/Way,
one’s **mystic insight** (*xuānjiàn* 玄鉴) leaves nothing behind.
Responding to things in accordance with the **Constant**,
one’s embrace (*hánróng* 含弘) is vast and luminous.

**Embrace** (*róng* 容) is **impartiality** (*gōng* 公).
**Note:** To embrace all things and respond without bias,
to respond without personal scheming—
this is **impartiality** (*gōngzhèng* 公正), free from private or perverse motives.

**Impartiality** (*gōng* 公) is **sovereignty** (*wáng* 王).
**Note:** Those who are impartial and without private motives
are the ones all things naturally turn toward.

**Commentary:** To embrace all things and respond without bias
is to be impartial and without private motives—
then the world turns toward them,
and this is called **sovereignty** (*wáng* 王).

The meaning is:
Knowing the **Constant** and following the Dao/Way,
one attains **impartiality** (*gōngzhèng* 公正)
and thereby becomes **sovereign** (*wáng* 王).
The **sovereign** (*wáng*) does not speak yet transforms,
does not summon yet comes—
thus the world turns toward them.

**Sovereignty** (*wáng* 王) is the **Dao** of the world (*shì* 世).
**Note:** All things joyfully submit,
as if to the sky’s embrace—
thus they align with the **virtue/power** (*dé* 德) of the **Heavenly** (*tiān* 天).

The **Heavenly** (*tiān* 天) is the **Dao** (*dào* 道).
**Note:** The **sovereign’s virtue/power** (*wángdé* 王德) is like the **Heavenly** (*tiān* 天),
and thus they embody the Dao/Way (*dàohuà* 道化).

**Commentary:** Only the **Heavenly** (*tiān* 天) is great,
and only the **sovereign** (*wáng* 王) follows its pattern.
Their **virtue/power** (*dé* 德) is the same as the **Heavenly** (*tiān* 天),
and nothing is left uncovered—
hence *"**sovereignty** is **Heavenly**."*
The **sovereign’s virtue/power** (*wángdé* 王德) aligns with the **Heavenly** (*tiān* 天),
and thus they govern without action (*wúwéi* 无为).
The Dao/Way’s transformations (*huà* 化) are carried out—
hence *"the **Heavenly** is the **Dao**."*

The meaning is:
To have all things turn toward one,
is to nurture the myriad realms (*zǐyù wànfāng* 子育万方),
and declare to the **Supreme Sovereign** (*shàngdì*上帝).
To follow the **Heavenly** (*tiān* 天) in vast embrace,
to follow the **Earthly** (*dì* 地) in effortless governance (*wúwéi* 无为).
The **sovereign** follows the **Heavenly** (*tiān* 天),
and the **Heavenly** follows the **Dao** (*dào* 道).

The **Dao** (*dào* 道) is **enduring** (*jiǔ* 久).
**Note:** The Dao/Way is carried out under the **Heavenly** (*tiān* 天),
and thus one can enjoy enduring blessings (*fúzuò* 福祚).
**Note:** To align with the **Heavenly** and embody the Dao/Way,
one’s life may end, yet their vitality is unharmed (*bùdài* 不殆).

**Commentary:** It is said that guarding stillness and attaining emptiness,
returning to the root and restoring vitality (*fù mìng* 复命),
their **virtue/power** (*dé* 德) is thus—
they can become **sovereign** (*wáng* 王).
The **sovereign’s virtue/power** (*wángdé* 王德) aligns with the **Heavenly** (*tiān* 天),
and thus they embody the Dao/Way.
The Dao/Way is carried out, and this is enduring blessings (*jiǔxiǎng fúzuò* 久享福祚).
All under the **Heavenly** (*tiān* 天) flock toward them like the sun,
revere them like the sky,
nurture them like the rain,
and await them like the spring—
thus, when their life ends, what danger or harm can there be?
Hence *"their vitality is unharmed."*

This teaching speaks of how a sovereign accumulates **virtue/power** (*dé*).

Though a sovereign may enjoy peace, hold the reins of governance, and rule over the people,
if they stray from **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power**, how could they endure long?
Thus, they must first empty their mind,
then guard their stillness.
When emptiness and stillness bring forth the **Dao/Way**, they return to their natural state,
and thus act with impartiality and without selfishness—
the people flock to them,
their actions align with **Heaven** and the **Dao/Way**.

When the **Dao/Way** is practiced to transform the people,
and its transformation spreads widely,
all under **Heaven** rejoice and revere them,
and so they endure blessings and longevity without danger or harm—
like the sun’s radiant presence,
like the sky’s nurturing embrace,
like rain’s nourishing dew,
like spring’s gentle warmth.
Though their life may end,
their **virtue/power** does not fade.

Thus do people today sing of Yao and Shun,
and celebrate Xī and Nóng through music and dance.

*"Revered like the sky, drawn to like the sun"*—
this is the **virtue/power** of Yao.

**End of Volume Fifteen of the *Broad Explication of the *True Scripture of Dao/Way and Virtue/Power***
**Volume Sixteen of the *Broad Explication of the *True Scripture of Dao/Way and Virtue/Power***
Narrated by Master Du Guangting of the Tang,
*"The Supreme Sovereign’s Chapter of Knowing Below"* (第十七)

「Commentary: This chapter first discusses the pure customs of antiquity, then extends to the corrupt habits of the later ages, intending to clarify the gradual loss of the Dao/Way and to analyze the origins of its decline. Hence, the previous chapter expounded that guarding stillness leads to attaining emptiness, while this chapter demonstrates that non-action returns one to simplicity. When simplicity disperses, the praise of virtue naturally arises; when non-action is practiced, it is said that "I act naturally." The common people’s rulers who embody the Dao/Way rely solely on this silent teaching.

**Meaning:** In the Supreme Ancient Age and the Great Ancient Age, there was no governance or artificial intervention; the ruler entrusted himself to nature, and the people embraced the Great Simplicity. The Supreme Ancient Age refers to the very beginning of Heaven and Earth. *Liézǐ* states: "In ancient times, the Sage followed the interplay of yin and yang to harmonize Heaven and Earth, thus giving rise to form from the formless." Therefore, before Heaven and Earth, there was the **Supreme Ease** (太易), where *qi* had not yet appeared; then the **Supreme Beginning** (太初), where *qi* first emerged; then the **Supreme Commencement** (太始), where form first took shape; and finally the **Supreme Purity** (太素), where matter first solidified. Collectively, these are called the **Supreme Pole** (太极), hence the term "Five Supremes" (五太) for the Supreme Ancient Age. When *qi*, form, and matter were all present but not yet separated, it was called **Hun Dun** (混沌), indicating that all things were in a state of undifferentiated chaos. Later, Hun Dun separated: the light and pure ascended as Heaven, the heavy and turbid descended as Earth, thus establishing the division of above and below and fixing yin and yang. Human beings received the harmonious *qi* of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang, dwelling between them, illuminated by the sun and moon, shaped by cosmic phenomena, nurtured by yin and yang, and regulated by cold and heat. Alongside Heaven and Earth, they were collectively called the **Three Talents** (三才). The **Three Sovereigns of the Highest Age**, the **Three Sovereigns of the Middle Age**, and the **Three Sovereigns of the Lower Age** successively governed and shepherded the people—this is what is called the Great Ancient Age.

Heaven’s duty was to nurture life, Earth’s duty was to bear form, the Sage’s duty was to teach and transform, and all things fulfilled their natural roles in this cycle of generation and transformation. Initially, they relied on **Dao/Way and Virtue/Power**; later, they turned to **ren and yì** (仁義). Thus, excessive praise and fear of blame arose, and trust in benevolence and sincerity waned, necessitating a return to ancient simplicity and the restoration of pure harmony. In the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, during the twenty-fourth year of Duke Lǐ (僖公), King Zhou of the Zhou wished to attack Zheng with the help of the Di tribesmen, but Fù Chén advised: "The most exalted ruler governs by **virtue/power**, without distinction between near and far. The next level favors the near and extends to the far. This means first treating the near with affection and then extending benevolence to the far, thereby establishing righteousness." The most exalted ruler—this is what "knowing below" (下知) refers to.

**Annotation:** The exalted ruler is the pure ancient sovereign. "Knowing below" (下知) means that the ministers only know their lord exists above them, revering him like Heaven, yet without any trace of artificial governance or instruction. Thus, the people have no way to praise him. **Commentary:** The exalted ruler is the pure ancient sovereign. "Exalted" (太上) signifies supreme reverence. It describes the sovereign of the Supreme Ancient Age who engaged in non-action and practiced silent teaching. Ministers merely knew that their lord was above them, great and high, embodying the principle of nurturing all things through the four seasons. They did not know how to name his **virtue/power**, hence the saying "knowing below" (下知有之). **Meaning:** *Tài* (太) means great, and *shàng* (上) means high. The name "Supreme Sovereign" (太上) reflects his ultimate greatness and elevation. The rulers of the Great Ancient Age had no posthumous titles; they cultivated pure and thick harmony to transform the people, acting without coercion and letting their **virtue/power** naturally permeate. They did not impose laws or punishments to sway the hearts of the people. Thus, ministers knew their lord was above them but did not hear his commands or instructions. His dwelling was serene, his rising was unhurried, his movements were measured, and his gaze was distant. Mountains had no paths carved through them, marshes had no bridges built across them. People ate what they cultivated and wore what they wove, while the four seasons followed their course above and all things flourished below. His **virtue/power** was profound and distant, beyond naming, hence "Supreme Sovereign" (太上).

Some say the sovereigns of the Supreme Ancient Age and Great Ancient Age included the **Clans of Róngchéng** (容成氏), **Dàtíng** (大庭氏), **Fǔ** (栢氏), **Zhōngyāng** (中央氏), **Lǐlù** (栗陆氏), **Lìlián** (丽连氏), **Xuānyuán** (轩辕氏), **Hèxiū** (赫胥氏), **Wúhuái** (无怀氏), **Hàoyīng** (昊英氏), **Zūnlú** (尊卢氏), **Gětīan** (葛天氏), **Yīnyīng** (阴襄氏), **Zhùróng** (祝融氏), **Lièshān** (列山氏), **Fúxī** (伏羲氏), and **Shénnóng** (神农氏)—all belonging to the age of knotted cords and non-action. The **Yellow Emperor** (黄帝) was the second son of the sovereign of the **Clan of Xióng** (有熊国), surnamed **Gōngsūn** (公孙氏). From birth, he was divine and intelligent, and as he grew, he became earnest and wise. His mother, **Jiāo Shì** (乔氏), named **Fùbǎo** (附宝), saw the radiance of lightning encircle the Northern Dipper and the **Pivot Star** (枢星) illuminate the wilds, and was thus conceived. Fourteen months later, the Yellow Emperor was born. When the **virtue/power** of Shénnóng declined and **Chīyóu** (蚩尤) became tyrannical, the feudal lords launched invasions. The Yellow Emperor cultivated his **virtue/power**, raised an army, and defeated Chīyóu in the wilds of **Zhuólù** (涿鹿). The people revered him and established him as the **Son of Heaven**, naming him the Yellow Emperor, to succeed Shénnóng.

He **Mastered Du Guangtíng** (广成子) taught on the **Kōngtóng Mountain** (崆峒山), imparting the principles of governance. He extracted the essence of Heaven and Earth to nourish the myriad people. He invented writing, domesticated cattle and horses, and introduced boats and carriages. He created pestles and mortars, palaces and dwellings, bows and arrows, and regulated the **lǘ** (律吕) [musical pitch pipes]. He cast tripods and crafted zithers.

**End of Volume Sixteen of the *Broad Explication of the *True Scripture of Dao/Way and Virtue/Power***
**Volume Seventeen of the *Broad Explication of the *True Scripture of Dao/Way and Virtue/Power***
**Chapter of Knowing Below** (下知章)」

**Volume Seventeen of the *Broad Explication of the *True Scripture of Dao/Way and Virtue/Power***
**Chapter of Knowing Below** (下知章)」

His dwelling bore the **auspicious sign of the *Zhēnyún* Cloud** (缙云), and sometimes he was called the *Zhēnyún* Clan (缙云氏), marking his officials by the **cloud insignia** (以云纪官). When the rites and music were established, his minister **Dàyuǎo** (大挠) created the calendar, **Róngchéng** (容成) devised calculations, **Cāngjié** (仓颉) invented writing, **Fēnghòu** (风后) forged the five weapons, and **Wànlǜ** (万虑) and others made their marks known. The Emperor rode upon a **flying dragon** (飞龙), traversing the four seas and all the great mountains and rivers, leaving traces everywhere.

Then, he took the copper from **Chóushǒu Mountain** (首山), casting the **tripod** (鼎) at **Jīngshān** (荆山) to blend the **nine elixirs** (九丹). When the elixir was complete, a dragon with **pendant whiskers** (垂胡髯) descended to greet him. The Yellow Emperor ascended upon the **Yellow Dragon** (黄龙) and departed to Heaven. Among his great ministers, **seventy-two** (七十二) ascended with him, while lesser officials, some clinging to the dragon’s whiskers and falling, others wailing while clutching the Emperor’s bow, were thus called **Bird-Wailing Bow** (鸟号弓). The place where he ascended to Heaven is now **Huángtiān Yuán** (皇天原) in **Guó State** (虢州), also known as **Dǐng Lake** (鼎湖).

The Emperor **Yáo** (尧) harmonized the **nine clans** (九族) and cherished the common folk. He was taught by **Mùchéngzǐ** (务成子), regulating the seasons, standardizing the **lǘ** (律吕) and measures, and thus transforming the realm. The Emperor **Shùn** (舜) was instructed by **Yǐnshòuzǐ** (尹寿子), whose **filial virtue** (孝德) shone brightly, allowing him to succeed Yáo as the Son of Heaven. His biography is detailed in the **third chapter** (第三章).

The Yellow Emperor, Yáo, and Shùn established laws and measures, and the people, moved by their **virtue/power** (德), praised their deeds—this was **true praise** (真誉). It was not that the Yellow Emperor, Yáo, and Shùn forced the people to praise them; rather, the people **voluntarily** (自) praised them. Later generations were not so. They **emulated and falsified** (矫) the traces of the past, giving rise to **deceptive praise** (矫誉) and **plagiarized virtue** (矫亲), thus fostering the **calamity of false pretenses** (矫窃之患).

**Cushion:** (疏) Therefore, *Zhuāngzi* says: *"I tell you, the root of great chaos must arise between the ages of Yáo and Shùn."* Why so? Because their **legacies** (迹) endure a thousand years later. The meaning is: the **traces of true praise and virtue** (亲誉之迹) began with the Yellow Emperor, Yáo, and Shùn, but a thousand years on, people **coveted their legacy** (慕其迹), leading to **deception and flattery** (矫徇).

In *Zhuāngzi*, **Gēngsāng Chǔ** (庚桑楚) told his disciples: *"What is there to commend in Yáo and Shùn? They **passed the throne through mutual respect and yielding** (揖让相禅), and later generations **imitated their practice** (法). But when one **elevates the virtuous**, people **vie to compete**; when one **trusts the wise**, people **scheme to deceive**. Such methods **cannot truly benefit the people** (厚民). Sons **murder their fathers**, ministers **assassinate their rulers**, thieves **operate openly at midday**, and **bandits lurk in broad daylight** (日中穴阫). The root of great chaos must arise between the ages of Yáo and Shùn. Its **outcome** (末) lingers a thousand generations later, when people will **devour one another** (相食). This speaks of how **honoring the virtuous and trusting ability** (尊贤任能) eventually leads to **great corruption** (大弊), where **mutual encroachment** (更相蚕食) began in the **era of Táng and Yú** (唐虞之间). As **flattery and deception** (矫徇) never cease, people lose their **true nature** (真性), thus descending into great chaos.

Next, they **feared and scorned** (畏之侮之) them.

**Annotation:** (注) When **virtue/power** (德) declined, rulers multiplied **corrupt governance** (弊政), and the people **could not endure their fate** (不堪命), so they were **driven by punishments** (刑罚) and thus **feared** them. They **harbored resentful emotions** (怀情) and **deceived one another** (相欺), while rulers **lacked insight** (明不能察), so they were **scorned**.

**Cushion:** (疏) After the Yellow Emperor, Yáo, and Shùn passed away, the **Three Sovereigns** (三王) and **Five Hegemons** (五霸) followed. Gradually, **harsh laws and severe punishments** (严刑峻制) grew, so the people **feared** them. Rulers **lacked insight** (明不能察), so they were **scorned**. Inferior officials **fabricated crimes to seek rewards** (下议罪而求功), while superiors **granted favors to the deceitful** (上赏奸而生诈), leading to **mutual deception** (相蒙). This is enough to **chill the heart** (寒心).

The meaning is: After Yáo and Shùn died, the **Three Sovereigns** succeeded them. The **Three Sovereigns** are the **Xìa, Yīn, and Zhōu** (夏殷周). **Yǔ** (禹) of the **Xìa** (夏) bore the surname **Yú** (姓) and given name **Wénmìng** (文命), being the grandson of **Gāoyáng** (高阳). His mother was called **Xiūjǐ** (修己), and at the **stone knot of the mountain** (石纽山) below a spring, she **conceived from the moon’s essence** (得月精如鸡子) like a chicken’s egg, birthing Yǔ. His left hand bore the **character for water** (水字), and his right hand bore the **character for platform** (台字), together forming the **character for governance** (治字). Yǔ’s father, **Gǔn** (鲧), served Yáo in **draining the waters** (治水) for nine years, but his efforts **failed to complete the task** (绩用不成). Shùn **executed Gǔn at Yǔshān** (羽山), raised Yǔ to replace his father, and commanded him to **drain the waters**. Yǔ **dug the nine rivers** (通九江), **deepened the hundred streams** (浚百川), and when all the valleys were **harmonized** (百谷既同), the **four seas flowed without obstruction** (四海无壅). His **hands and feet were calloused** (手足胼胝), and he **dug through the Dragon Gate** (凿龙门), **cleared the pass at Yī** (辟伊阙), and **deepened the nine rivers**. In his travels, he **visited seven hundred states** (七百余国), riding the **four vehicles** (四载) to **inscribe the names of mountains and rivers** (奠名山大川), leaving no place unexplored.

As a man, his **benevolence** (仁) was **approachable** (可亲), his words **trustworthy** (可信). His **voice set the standard for pitch** (声为律), and his **person embodied measure** (身为度). He was taught by **Zhēnxíngzǐ** (真行子), who obtained the **Five Talismans of the Primordial Treasure** (太上灵宝五符), summoning **ghosts and spirits** (檄召鬼神) to **move mountains and block rivers** (移山塞川). After completing the **waterworks** (治水), Heaven **bestowed the dark jade** (玄珪) upon him as a **token of success** (告成功). Shùn then **transferred the throne** (禅位), creating the **nine tripods** (九鼎) and establishing the **nine regions** (九州). The **Five Sacred Mountains** (五岳) and named peaks were all **carved with inscriptions** (刻石科斗篆文), marking their **heights and depths** (以表其高下). He ruled for **forty-one years** (四十一年), reaching the age of **one hundred years** (一百岁). His descendants held the throne for **sixteen generations** (十六代), capitalizing at **Píngyáng** (平阳), beginning in the **year Gǎnghài** (癸亥) and ending in **year Jǐwèi** (己巳), for a total of **four hundred eighty-seven years** (四百八十七年).

Yǔ having abdicated, he himself deemed his virtue insufficient to match that of Yáo and Shùn, and thus relinquished the title of Emperor, assuming that of King—thereby becoming one of the **Three Sovereigns** (三王).

Later, Xià Jié’s tyranny led to **Táng of Yīn** rising as a vassal lord to overthrow Jié and assume his throne. Táng was a descendant of **Yì**, the seventeenth-generation grandson of **Huángdì**. His given name was **Lǚ**, also called **Tiānyǐ**. He aided Xià in conquering **Gěbó**, earning merit, and abolished the **three-sided net** (三面之网), returning thirty-six states to their virtuous rulers.

When Xià Jié’s cruelty provoked rebellion, Táng defeated him at **Míngtiáo**, exiling him to **Náncháo**, where a white wolf appeared as an auspicious omen. The **Supreme Lord** (太上) bestowed upon him the **Five Sacred Talismans** (五符), and he appointed **Yíyǒu** as his prime minister. During a seven-year drought, he offered his own body as a sacrifice, and Heaven sent great rains. The Four Seas praised his virtue. He ruled for thirteen years, reaching the age of one hundred and nineteen. His descendants held the throne for twenty-one generations, thirty kings, with their capital at **Bó**. He ascended the throne in the year **Gēngwǔ** after defeating Jié, and perished in **Yǐyǒu** when **Zhòu** arose, ruling for six hundred and fifty-six years—thus becoming the **second of the Three Sovereigns**.

Later, **Zhòu of Yīn**’s tyranny reached its height: he severed **Zhāoché’s** legs, pierced **Bǐgān’s** heart, instituted the **páo-luò torture**, and disemboweled pregnant women. The world rebelled. **Zhōu Xībó**, the Western Duke of Zhōu, dominated the region in **Dīngmǎo**, and his son, **Wǔwáng**, succeeded him in **Jǐmǎo**. In **Yǐyǒu**, he defeated Zhòu at **Mùyě**, vanquishing him and establishing the Zhōu dynasty in place of Yīn.

A descendant of **Hòulì**, surnamed **Jī**, Hòulì’s given name was **Qì**. His mother, **Jiānglìng**, was the favored consort of **Yúdì**. While walking in the wild, she saw the footprints of a giant, delighted, and stepped into them, conceiving. After a year, she bore him, fearing it an omen, and abandoned him in a ditch. Cattle and horses shied away, and he was moved to an icy patch, where birds sheltered him with their wings. Jiānglìng, believing him divine, raised him and named him **Qì**. As a child, he was fond of surveying landforms and excelled in agriculture. **Yáo** appointed him **Master of Agriculture**, and the world benefited. He was ennobled at **Hé**, earning the title **Hòulì**.

His tenth-generation descendant, **Gǔgōng Dànfù**, accumulated virtue and righteousness, and the people revered him. Dànfù married **Dàjiāng**, fathering **Jìlì**, who wed **Dàrèn**, producing **Wénwáng Chāng**. Chāng became the Western Duke. When **Zhòu of Yīn** suspected his virtue, he imprisoned him at **Yǔlǐ**. His minister **Húnqiú** sought the **black horse of Yǒuxiǒng**, the **maiden of Yǒushēn**, and exotic treasures to present to Zhòu. Zhòu pardoned the Western Duke, gifting him bows, arrows, axes, and battle-axes, granting him authority over military campaigns. The **Master of the Yellow Court** (老君) appeared on the southern slope of **Qíshān**, with the **bìnglì bird** as an omen. Two-thirds of the world’s people aligned with Zhōu’s virtue.

The Western Duke received the bow and arrows in **Dīngmǎo**, the twenty-first year of Zhòu’s reign. His son, **Wǔwáng**, defeated Zhòu in **Yǐyǒu**, assuming the throne. He released cattle into **Táolín** and returned horses to the southern slope of **Huáshān**, inverting weapons to show they would never be used again. With ten loyal ministers, he brought order to the realm. He ruled for nine years. **Wénwáng** lived to ninety-seven, **Wǔwáng** to ninety-three. His descendants held the throne for thirty-seven generations, forty-one kings, from **Yǐyǒu** to **Rángwáng** in **Rénzǐ**, ruling for eight hundred and sixty-eight years—thus becoming the **third of the Three Sovereigns**.

The **Five Hegemons** (五霸) operated within the Three Sovereigns’ era, among the vassal lords. They subdued the Four Quarters with arms, presided over alliances, internally supported the Son of Heaven, and externally intimidated the vassals. They wielded **ritual and music** in warfare, holding authority in their time but not equaling the Sovereigns, hence called **Hegemons**.

The Hegemons of Xià included **Kūnwú**, a descendant of **Huángdì**. Those of Yīn included **Dàpēng** and **Shǐwéi**, descendants of **Yáo**. The Hegemons of Zhōu included **Qí Huán**, the younger brother of **Lǐ Xīgōng**, named **Xiǎobái**. Established in **Lǔ Zhuānggōng’s** ninth year, he was advised by **Guān Zhòng**, uniting the vassals nine times and rectifying the world once—during the reigns of **Zhōu Huìwáng** and **Zhōu Xiāngwáng**.

**Jìn Wēngōng**, son of **Xiàngōng**, named **Zhòng’ěr**, was established in **Lǔ Xīgōng’s** twenty-second year. Fleeing **Lìjī’s** treachery in **Lǐ Xīgōng’s** fourth year, he wandered through **Qí, Cáo, Wèi, Chén, Chǔ, Zhèng, and Qín** for eighteen years. The **Qín Bó** restored him to Jìn with an army, and **Zhōu Xiāngwáng** bestowed the **Nine Sacrificial Offerings** (九锡): crimson bows and arrows, jade tablets, **gǔshèng wine**, and authority over the vassals. After teaching the people for two years, **Zǐfán** advised him to govern by righteousness. He first stabilized **Zhōu Xiāngwáng**, then prioritized the people’s welfare, attacking **Yuán** to demonstrate sincerity and **Sōu** to uphold ritual. Thereafter, he was employed. After defending **Gǔyù**, he lifted the siege of **Sòng**, conquering in a single battle to achieve hegemony. His success lay in his mastery of **ritual and wisdom**, wielding arms to secure dominance. His strength came from **mobilizing armies and forming alliances**—hence, **Hegemon** (霸) means to **grasp** (把), to **gather heroes and achieve might**.

**Virtue, righteousness, ritual, and wisdom** are the **Dao of warfare**. Harsh punishments bind the heart, stringent laws gag speech—yet the finer the laws, the more chaotic the people; the denser the nets, the greater the crimes. Disaster arises unnoticed, deceit flourishes unseen. Rulers and subjects deceive each other, inspiring fear in some, contempt in others. The **Dao-adherent** witnesses these dangers and trembles—**a chilling of the heart**.

In the *Chōngxū Zhēnjīng*, **Kǒngzǐ** spoke to **Shāng Tàizǎi**:
*The Three Sovereigns excelled in adapting to the times, aligning with nature, and governing.
The Five Emperors mastered **virtue and righteousness**, clarifying goodness to achieve success.
The Three Kings excelled in **wisdom and courage**, deciding with wisdom and acting with courage.
The Five Hegemons mastered **opportunity and strategy**, adapting to circumstances, leveraging advantage, and completing tasks—yet still constrained by ritual and bound by trust. When ritual or trust falters, the **Dao of the Hegemon** emerges.*

Trust proves insufficient, then distrust arises.
**Note:** Those who fear or scorn [the ruler] stem from the ruler’s lack of trustworthiness.
Thus, those beneath him become distrustful.

**Exegesis:** This explains why the people fear the ruler’s laws and scorn his decrees—all because the ruler lacks trust from below, causing those beneath him to be distrustful.

**Meaning:** When words are spoken but not kept, that is trust. Yet if rewards are given to the undeserving and punishments meted out to the innocent, that is distrust.
When decrees lose their trustworthiness, the people may deceive [the ruler] in return.

As a body bends, its shadow distorts; as a source is muddied, its flow becomes foul. The ruler sets the example, and those below follow suit—such is their response.

In the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Duke Xuan of Jin, Year 11, the Marquis of Chu attacked Zheng, reaching Liang. The Zheng minister Zi Liang said:
*"Chu and Jin do not uphold virtue but wage war. If they come, let them come.*
*Chu and Jin lack trust—how can we have trust?"*
And so Zheng sided with Chu.
In summer, the Marquis of Chu allied with Zheng at Chenling, displaying Zheng’s submission.
This was a case of trust proving insufficient, and distrust arising.
Yet even the noble value words.

「Annotations: *注* – A gloss explaining the reasoning behind the text.
*疏* – A commentary elaborating on the *注*’s interpretation.

The people who hold you in esteem and praise you—
it is because you possess **virtue/power** and **teachings** that are worthy of respect,
and thus they value your words and hold you in esteem and praise.

The common folk love and cherish your benevolence and goodness,
and acclaim your achievements and deeds—
this stems from your **virtue/power** and **teachings** that are worthy of respect,
so they honor your words and extol them.

*Ancient* **字 (zì)** and **由 (yóu)** were interchangeable in usage.

**Explanation:** If a ruler’s decrees are inconsistent,
the people fear his harshness.
If a ruler’s decrees are benevolent and good,
the people cherish and praise him.

The *Book of Documents* states:
*"The people’s hearts never waver—
they are steadfast when there is benevolence."*
And again:
*"If you nurture me, I will follow you;
if you oppress me, I will seek vengeance."*

Thus, the people despise his cruel and violent decrees,
and they honor his benevolent and virtuous teachings.

**犹 (yóu)** means *still*, *moreover*, or *follow*.
Ancient texts sometimes omitted characters,
so they were used interchangeably.

When achievements are fulfilled and undertakings accomplished,
the common folk say, *"It was done by nature."*

**Annotations:** *注* – When achievements are fulfilled without arrogance,
and undertakings accomplished without coercion,
the people go about their daily lives unaware,
saying, *"It was done by nature."*

This is how the **Dao/Way** of the *Tao Shang* [太上, Supreme Sage] is understood by those above and below alike.
**Commentary:** *疏* – This elaborates on the *Tao Shang*’s principle of non-action.

The pure and unadorned do not harm others—
who would then sacrifice them as vessels?
If **virtue/power** and **Dao/Way** are universally practiced,
praise and honor arise naturally.

Thus, in the age of the *Tao Shang*,
the land was so fertile that it required no tilling—
*抔抔 (póupóu)*, *步侯 (bùhóu)* [both variants of *不耕 (bùgēng)*].
Water flowed freely for drinking,
yet he did not favor his own kin,
nor did he show partiality to his own children.

The ruler had the merit of bringing life into being,
of completing and nurturing it,
yet he did not boast of this to those below.
When the people saw things in their proper place,
they did not know the ruler’s transformative **Dao/Way**,
but assumed it was simply the natural order.

The pure and unadorned do not harm others—
as the *Zhuangzi* [*Tianxia (天下) or *Ma Shui (马蹄)*] chapter says:
*"The pure and unadorned do not harm others—
who would then sacrifice them as vessels?
White jade left uncarved—
who would then shape it into ritual tablets?"*
If **virtue/power** and **Dao/Way** are not abandoned,
why seek after benevolence and righteousness?"

Emotions and innate nature remain undivided—
why then employ rites and music?

Colors do not stray—
who would then seek after patterns and dyes?
Sounds do not stray—
who would then conform to the six **Lü**?

To mar the pure and unadorned for vessels—
that is the artisan’s fault.
To abandon **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power** for benevolence and righteousness—
that is the sage’s error.

The *Book of Liang* recounts Master **Du**’s explanation: In ancient times, ritual vessels were all carved from wood in the shapes of birds and beasts, with holes drilled in their heads and backs for pouring and receiving wine. In the **Wei** dynasty, a man found in the wilds of **Lu** County a **Ziwei** vessel belonging to a **Qi** official, shaped like a sacrificial cow. During the **Yongjia** era of the **Jin**, bandit **Cao Yi** raided the tomb of **Qi Jing Gong** in **Qing** State and uncovered two such vessels, also cow-shaped. Thus, it became known that all were ancient **Ziwei** designs.

In the **Great Ancient** age, the **Dao/Way** prevailed—
**virtue/power** was not yet **virtue/power**,
and people knew only that their ruler was a sovereign.
In the **Middle Ancient** age, the **Dao/Way** faded—
benevolence and **virtue/power** became apparent,
and kindness and grace extended to the people.
Thus arose the praise of personal favor.

In the **Later Ancient** age, **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power** were both obscured—
teachings and commands grew convoluted,
faith and trust grew thin.
The ruler above lost trust,
and those below responded with distrust.
Thus, when they saw stern decrees, they feared them,
and when they heard of broken faith, they scorned them.

**Laozi**’s warnings sought to urge future emperors and kings
to discard the superficial trappings of rites and wisdom,
to emulate the ancient customs of **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power**,
to abandon merit and forget fame,
and to return once more to the **Great Simplicity**.

Personal favor arises when—
there are traces of benevolence, they are called *personal*;
there are traces of goodness, they are called *favor*.
Reciprocal kindness is when—
the ruler bestows his grace, it is called *reciprocal*;
the people perform their labor, it is called *kindness*.

In the **24th year of Duke Lǔ** of the *Spring and Autumn Annals*,
King **Shuang** of **Zhou** sent the **Di** to attack **Zheng**, achieving success.
**Fu Chen** admonished the king:
*"Reciprocal kindness* leads to exhaustion,
*kindness* does not yet tire."
He spoke of the king’s labor and the people’s demands—
when labor is demanded, expectations for *reciprocal kindness* become excessive.

This was **Fu Chen**’s reproach to the king of **Zhou**,
who sought to attack **Zheng** out of resentment,
and who, after the **Di**’s victory, wished to wed his daughter as a reward.
The people’s daily needs, unrecognized—
that is the language of the *Zhouyi*.

The *Dao/Way* and **virtue/power**’s true essence, **Volume 16** of the *Guangshengyi* concludes.
**Volume 17** of the *Dao/Way* and **virtue/power**’s true essence, **Du Guangcheng**’s account of the **Tang** Master.

**Chapter Eighteen: The Great Dao in Decay**

**Exegesis:**
The previous chapter revealed how the Dao’s steps diverge with time—
yet the Dao endures, preserving its pristine simplicity.
This chapter reveals how customs decay and morals corrode—
when the Dao is lost, *ren* and *yi* arise in its place.
Like one bald yet seeking hair to adorn,
or sick yet seeking medicine for cure—
though they claim to heal, they only worsen the affliction.
Thus, eight lines are cited to expose their accumulated harm,
hoping to swiftly restore the ancient purity.

**Explanation:**
Earlier, the pure and simple gradually dispersed,
while the vulgar and shallow took root.
Tracing the source of this corruption,
we see the Dao’s decline.
The *Way* of the Sage moves gently with the natural order,
while the *Way* of the Emperor rushes toward forced achievement.
When customs decay and morals crumble,
*ren* and *yi* emerge—
grasping *ren* and *yi* to adorn one’s nature,
establishing punishments and rewards to discipline the people—
just as the bald adorn their heads or the sick seek medicine,
hoping for cure.

The *Huainanzi* says:
*"Counting grains and combing hair bring only greater trouble—
how much more so when actions are forced!"*
What difference is there
between scratching one’s back with the knee
or untangling knots with the heel?
If one understands the error of these four things,
then the hope of returning to purity may be realized.

**Annotations:**
*Hair (髱)*—hair.
*Decay (颓)*—ruin.
*Decadent (靡)*—tilted, unsteady.
*Comb (栉)*—to comb.

When the Great Dao decays,
*ren* and *yi* arise.
**Commentary:**
When purity disperses and simplicity scatters,
the Great Dao does not prevail—
thus *ren* and *yi* emerge as lesser achievements.
Deficiency breeds greed,
and artificiality sparks decay.
Yet the Sage’s concern for the age remains unchanged,
though the paths to salvation differ.

**Exegesis:**
When the Great Dao decays,
customs become vulgar and shallow,
the people compete in frivolity,
the subtle *Way* fades,
and the serene, pure transformation vanishes—
the Dao of effortless perfection is lost.
Thus it is called *decay*.

**Explanation:**
*Decay* means the Sage’s *Way* and the Emperor’s virtue are far gone.
Rulers strive for dominion, scheming and deceitful.
Time has strayed from truth,
and hearts are consumed by empty competition.
The deep, tranquil *Way* of natural ease fades daily,
while the harmonious, still transformation erodes.
When the Great Dao does not prevail,
this is called *decay*.
As the *Great Rites* says:
*"When the Great Dao is hidden, the world becomes a family."*

*Vulgar (浇)*—to moisten, like water soaking earth.
*Shallow (漓)*—water seeping into the ground.
The ancient purity was like water absorbed by the earth—
once scattered, it cannot be recovered.
Thus it is called *vulgar and shallow*.

**Exegesis:**
When the Dao decays,
there arises *ren* of universal love,
and *yi* of righteous judgment—
yet these only bind the people in artificiality.

**Explanation:**
*Ren* is the awkward posture of forced benevolence,
*yi* is the strained stance of fabricated righteousness—
both are constrained in form,
striving in appearance,
not vast and free.
The farther one strays from the Dao,
the clearer the Sage’s traces become—
*ren* and *yi* are not genuine,
ritual and music distort nature,
and only their rigid, artificial forms remain—
none reflect the true, unified sincerity.

**Exegesis:**
Thus *Zhuangzi* says:
*"The Dao is hidden in petty achievements."*
By *petty achievements*, he means *ren* and *yi*,
each claiming partial success,
yet failing to unite in the Great Way.
Thus they are called *petty achievements*.

**Explanation:**
When the Great Dao is hidden,
the highest virtue collapses.
The *ren*-ous act only for *ren*,
the *yi*-ous act only for *yi*—
they cannot merge into one harmonious transformation,
each establishing a separate name.
Compared to *virtue/power*,
they are already small.
How much smaller still compared to the Great Dao!

*"The Dao is hidden in petty achievements"*—
as in *Zhuangzi’s* ["Amalgam"] where Nan Guo Ziqi tells Zi You:
*"The Dao is hidden yet has truth and falsehood,
words are hidden yet have right and wrong.
The Dao departs yet does not vanish,
words remain yet cannot be relied upon."*
The Dao is hidden in petty achievements,
words are hidden in empty ornamentation.
This refers to the petty achievements of *ren* and *yi*,
and the empty ornamentation of false distinctions.
Those who cling to words and teachings
only deepen confusion—
thus the Sage says there are *Rujia* and *Mojia*,
each condemning what the other upholds.
In this tangled dispute,
none can reach true certainty,
and chaos arises from it.

When wisdom emerges,
great deception follows.
**Commentary:**
Those who rely on wisdom
will inevitably establish laws.
Once laws are made, deceit flourishes—
thus great deception arises.
How could counterfeiting seals and measures
be any different?

**Exegesis:**
When wisdom emerges,
later generations use intelligence to legislate,
establish codes to curb vice,
and create seals and measures to ensure trust.
Fearful of injustice, they invent standards of weight and measure.
Yet the unvirtuous steal official seals and alter weights—
thus, the very laws meant to curb deceit
only encourage greater fraud.
Hence, it is said that great deception follows.

**Explanation:**
*Wisdom*—the mind’s insight.
*Insight*—discernment and understanding.

「**Commentary:**
*Check* means to bind and restrain.
*Responsibility* means to censure.
*Seals* mean to verify trust.
*Impressions* mean stamps.

When **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power** are concealed,
**ren** (benevolence) and **yi** (righteousness) are practiced.
When **ren** and **yi** flourish,
**wisdom** is employed.
Laws multiply like autumn’s thistle,
nets tighten like congealed fat,
yet people grow ever more chaotic.

When the **Dao/Way** of cunning devices—
crossbows, snares, and traps—
is excessive,
birds are disturbed in the sky.
When the **Dao/Way** of hooks, baits, and nets
is excessive,
fish are disturbed in the waters.
When the **Dao/Way** of snares, pitfalls, and nooses
is excessive,
beasts are disturbed in the marshes.

As **deception** and **craftiness** spread,
words become twisted, falsehoods hardened,
and interpretations diverge—
then the common folk are bewildered by sophistry.

Thus, when the world is in great disorder,
the fault lies in the love of **wisdom**.

**Exegesis:**
*Laws*—standards.
They are established to restrain the people.
*Codes*—eternal.
They are enacted to censure deceit.

*Seals*—engraved texts that match for verification,
like the **gold tiger-bamboo soldier** seals of trust.
*Impressions*—the **Son of Heaven** uses *zhi* (impressions),
lords use *yin* (seals).
The hierarchy of ranks ensures trust through them.

The origin of *hu* (斛):
It begins with *gui* (圭).
Sixty-four grains of millet make one *gui*,
ten *gui* make one *chao* (抄),
ten *chao* make one *cuo* (撮),
ten *cuo* make one *shao* (勺),
ten *shao* make one *he* (合),
ten *he* make one *sheng* (升),
ten *sheng* make one *dou* (斗).
Five *dou* and four *sheng* make one *hu*,
used to measure goods.

Those with **wisdom** set these seals, measures, and codes,
to limit and restrain,
to detect theft—
yet who knows they may not become the greatest thieves themselves?

**Tian Chang** of Qi falsely upheld **ren** and **yi**,
and in a single day assassinated his lord,
seizing the kingdom for twelve generations.
Qi’s seals, measures, and codes—
the **sage’s wisdom**—
were all in Tian Chang’s hands.
Thus, **wisdom** in making laws
only breeds great deception.

Later, those who stole kingdoms
often relied on the laws of the Tian lineage.

**Wang Mang** stole the throne from Han,
**Sima Xianwang** from Wei,
**Emperor Wu of Liang** from Qi,
**Emperor Wen of Sui** from Zhou.
Would it not be better to burn the seals,
break the impressions,
and let the people be simple and uncontentious?
To discard the measures,
fold the balances,
and abolish all the **sage’s laws**,
so the people might deliberate on the **Dao/Way**?

**Six Kinships** in discord,
yet there are filial and kind children.

**Six Kinships**—father, son, husband, wife, brother, sister—
are estranged, lacking order.
Yet each has their own filial and kind actions,
all due to straying from the **Dao/Way**,
hence the partial names.

**Filial**—serving one’s parents.
*The Book of Rites* (礼□祭统) says:
**Filial** is to cherish.
*The Explanation of Names* (释名) says:
**Filial** is to love.
*The Law of Posthumous Names* (谥法) says:
Perfect compliance is called **filial**.

In summary,
**filial** is the enduring **Dao/Way** of serving parents,
exhausting all care and nurturing,
delighting in their contentment,
and obeying without resistance.

*The Classic of Erya* (尔雅) says:
To serve parents well is **filial**.

**Kind**—to provide care when they leave,
and return when they come.

Those who bear the names of **filial** and **kind**
boast of their virtues,
yet they fail to see
that in the age of the **Great Dao/Way**,
the world is a single household.
The ruler above nurtures those below,
a natural order—
to treat others as oneself,
not just cherishing one’s own kin,
then all people could be **filial**.
To treat others as one’s own children,
not just raising one’s own offspring,
then all the young could be **kind**.

Where then could the names of **filial** and **kind** apply?
*The Doctrine of the Mean* (礼运篇) states:
Confucius served in Lu,
participating in the **sacrificial guests** (蜡宾),
and after the rites concluded,
he visited the **Xianwei Pavilion** (象魏之观),
where he saw the sacrificial rituals were incomplete.
Gazing upon the ancient site,
he sighed deeply.
His disciple **Zigong** (言偃) asked,
and Confucius replied:
*The Great Dao/Way* in practice,
the brilliance of the **Three Dynasties**,
I have not yet witnessed it—
yet I strive for it.

*The Great Dao/Way* in practice:
The world is held in common.
The worthy and capable are selected,
trust is honored, and harmony cultivated.
No one cherishes only their own kin,
no one raises only their own children.
The aged have a place to rest,
the able find purpose in life,
the young grow and thrive,
the widowed, orphaned, elderly, disabled, and sick all have sustenance.
Men are allotted their share,
women find their home.
Wealth is hated when cast aside,
not hoarded for oneself.
Strength is hated when unused,
not monopolized for oneself.
Thus, scheming is nonexistent,
and theft, robbery, and disorder do not arise.

Hence, outer doors are left unclosed—
this is called **Great Harmony**.

In such an age,
acts of **filial** care—
fanning pillows, warming beds,
providing for parents when they leave and return—
have no place to be applied.
All are treated as kin—
where would partial names arise?
It is merely self-aggrandizement.

When a state is in decline,
there are **loyal ministers**.
**Commentary:**
In times of peace,
when ruler and subjects are settled,
what need is there for such names?
Yet in days of chaos,
when danger is seen,
**loyal ministers** arise.

**Exegesis:**
*Loyal*—the duty of a subject,
yet why say there are **loyal ministers**?
How could there be such a distinction?
In times of decline,
when peril is evident,
they risk their lives—
thus, **loyal ministers** appear.
Yet *loyal* is the natural role of a subject—
why then does it become a special name?
」

When the sovereign fails to govern his ministers properly,
then flatterers gain favor,
plotting to mislead the ruler into folly,
and thus bring about calamity.
Yet those who see peril and risk their lives—
dying in hardship to save the state—
are hailed as **loyal ministers**.

**Exegesis:**
*Loyal* means upright and correct—this is **loyalty**.
The *Spring and Autumn Annals* says:
**"Loyalty** is the foundation of the state’s stability."
Serving the ruler as a subject,
**loyalty** must be the foundation.
If one is filial to their parents,
then they will be **loyal** to their ruler.

Flattery is **flatterer’s art** (*nìng*),
obscuring truth is **folly** (*hūn*),
and disorder between ruler and subjects is **chaos** (*luàn*).
When **flatterers** stand beside the throne,
the ruler’s discernment is clouded,
unable to banish flatterers and promote the virtuous,
thus plunging himself into **folly and chaos**.

Once **chaos** takes root,
strife erupts.
Externally, there are invading foes,
internally, there are palace rebellions.
Thus, worthy ministers risk their lives,
resolving crises and aiding peril—
some gain fame and renown,
others die in service to the state.
It is through such deeds that the title of **loyal minister** is established.

Had **Emperor Tang** ruled as sovereign,
and **Yu Shun** served as minister,
with the ruler governing properly above,
and ministers aiding harmoniously below,
then the distinction of **loyal ministers** would have no place to shine.

**Exegesis:**
When the **Dao**’s transformation is widespread,
and **non-action** reigns in purity,
the multitude of virtuous scholars arise—
all are **Qí-Lóng** worthies.
The natural order is preserved,
and all things are rightly governed.

**Exegesis:**
The **Dao**’s transformation spreads like a boundless wind,
the ruler does nothing, yet all beneath are serene.
As the *Odes* say:
*"Jì-jì, many worthies—
King Wen thereby found peace."*
**Many worthies** are the multitude of ministers.
**Qí-Lóng** were Shun’s ministers.
The *Book of Documents* says:
*"Qí composed the music of rites,
the eight tones harmonized.
Striking stone with stone,
all beasts danced in rhythm.
The *Xiao* and *Shao* reached perfection,
and the phoenix came in procession.
The dragon served as speech-bearer,
transmitting the sovereign’s commands."*
**Sim**—law,
**Lún**—equality,
**Yóu**—where,
**Shù**—order,
**Yì**—harmony.
The *Book* says: *"Sim Lún Yóu Shù,"*
meaning Shun obtained worthy ministers
and the laws remained unerring.

**Exegesis:**
Then the names of **loyalty** and **filial piety** fade,
while the **Dao** of sincerity and simplicity flourishes—
what need then for **loyal ministers**?
These four are the extremes of decay—
how could they not return to sincerity?

**Exegesis:**
*Decay*—to fall,
*Privation*—to decline.
The four refer to:
**benevolence**, **righteousness**, **filial piety**, and **loyal ministers**.
When the **Dao** is abandoned, cleverness arises;
families contend, states fall—
and these four become prominent.
Because they emerge from the extremes of decay,
their names are established.
As **Great Simplicity** crumbles,
pure winds distort,
**virtue** wanes, the **Dao** is lost—
what more can be said?
Thus, when the **Dao** is hidden,
**lower virtue** takes action,
**benevolence** and **righteousness** are employed,
and clever stratagems flourish.
**Loyal ministers** gain renown in **chaos**,
**filial piety** shines in discord—
when decay reaches its peak,
the wind returns to simplicity.
The return to simplicity is fully elaborated in the next chapter:
*"Abandon the Sage, Discard Wisdom"* (Chapter Nineteen).

**Exegesis:**
The previous chapter revealed how customs decay
when the **Dao** is lost and **benevolence** and **righteousness** prevail.
This chapter explains how abandoning these paths
restores simplicity and eliminates thieves and bandits.
The first six sentences address abandoning **self-aggrandizement**,
the next three outline establishing proper teachings,
and the last four demonstrate the path’s progression.

**Exegesis:**
When the **Dao** is abandoned and customs distort,
partial names arise.
To restore simplicity,
one must abandon these partial names.
Since the four virtues of the previous chapter are ineffective,
this chapter advocates abandoning three:
**filial piety** and **compassion** return naturally,
thieves and bandits cease,
thus reviving the **Dao** of simplicity
and eliminating private desires—
what greater benefit to the world could there be?

**Abandon the Sage, Discard Wisdom—**
the people gain a hundredfold benefit.

**Commentary:**
Abandon the traces of the **Sage**’s teachings,
then transformation follows **non-action**.
Discard the cunning of ordinary wisdom,
then people return to sincerity.
Sincerity eliminates deceit,
**non-action** eradicates **self-aggrandizement**.
Humans align with **Heaven’s harmony**,
and all things flourish without harm.
Thus, the people gain a hundredfold benefit.

**Exegesis:**
The **Sage** is one who acts and creates.
The **wise** are those who rely on cunning stratagems.
The **Sage**’s actions leave traces,
the **wise**’s cunning is not genuine.
Losing genuineness breeds deceit,
following traces leads to losing the root—
both must be abandoned to preserve sincerity.
When **Heaven’s harmony** flows freely,
**self-aggrandizement** ceases,
and the people gain a hundredfold benefit.

**Exegesis:**
The **Sage** of **non-action** possesses inner clarity,
their wisdom responds to all things,
adapting effortlessly to each moment.
Compared to the **Sage** and the **wise**,
their ways are profound and trace-less.
The **Sage** who acts and the **wise** who scheme
leave behind their traces—
people cling to these traces,
yet what they cling to is not the means of adaptation.
If they rigidly apply these traces,
they drift further from the **Dao**.
Why?
Because the **Sage** and the **wise** establish laws
to defend the state.
When great thieves arrive,
they steal the **Sage**’s laws to seize the state.
How so?
If they do not steal the **Sage**’s laws,
they have no way to take the state.
Thus, the **Sage**’s laws,
originally meant to guard the state,
become, in their extreme cleverness,
the very tools by which the state is stolen.
**Laozi** warns:
*"Forgotten, the **Sage** becomes principle;
pursued, the **Sage** becomes chaos."*
If one forgets the traces of the **Sage**,
discards the artifice of wisdom,
then sincerity returns and deceit ceases.
People return to joy and harmony,
unharmed and unspoiled,
customs revert to simplicity,
with no grievances or strife—
each preserves their life,
and the people gain a hundredfold benefit.

**Abandon Benevolence, Discard Righteousness—**
the people return to **filial piety** and **compassion**.

**Commentary:**
Abandon the **benevolence** of universal love,
discard the **righteousness** of judging others,
then people return to **great filial piety** and **compassion**.

**Exegesis:**
The previous chapter stated:
*"When the **Dao** is abandoned, **benevolence** and **righteousness** arise."*
This chapter says:
*"Abandon **benevolence**, discard **righteousness**,
and the people return to **filial piety** and **compassion**."*
It clarifies that in the age of the **Dao**’s return—
what is called **primordial unity**—
the people have no private kin,
yet all are filled with **compassion** and **filial piety**.

Thus, when **principles** reach their fullness, all **artifice** vanishes,
and when **affairs** are rightly ordered, their **names** are cast aside.

**Explanation:**
The six bonds of kinship are discordant,
then the **names** of **filial piety** and **compassion** stand alone.
When the **Dao** prevails in the world,
the **virtue** of **primordial simplicity** is restored.
Once **simplicity** and **purity** are restored,
all are **filial** and **compassionate**—
this is called having no private kin.

So, it is the **renunciation** of **artificial** **benevolence** and **righteousness**
that restores the **primordial unity** of **filial piety** and **compassion**.
The absence of private kin
is not the same as favoring one’s own kin.

**Exegesis:**
Now, when the six bonds of kinship are abandoned,
the **names** of **filial piety** and **compassion** become prominent.
If one abandons the **universal benevolence** of **Dao**,
discards the **judicial righteousness** of **Dao**,
then there is no **artificial** advancement of **virtue** in the **six bonds**,
and **filial piety** and **compassion** arise naturally.
Hence, the people return to **great filial piety** and **compassion**.

**Explanation:**
The six bonds of kinship—
also called the six relations—
are those of **sovereign-subject**, **father-son**, **husband-wife**.
When these six relations are harmonious,
all are **filial** and all are **compassionate**.
When they are discordant,
there are some who are **filial** and some who are not,
some who are **compassionate** and some who are not.
The unfilial are many,
so the **filial** stand out in their **virtue**.
The uncompassionate are many,
so the **compassionate** shine in their **beauty**.
This is why:
**Benevolence** and **righteousness** are imposed between them,
and their **names** are thus exalted and advanced.

If one governs with the **Dao**,
stirs the people with **primordial simplicity**,
and discards **artificial** **benevolence** and **righteousness**,
then the people return to being all **filial** and all **compassionate**.

Fish on land,
moisten each other with saliva,
nourish each other with dew—
yet this is not as good as
