forgetting each other in the rivers and lakes.

Why?
Moistening with saliva and nourishing with dew
are but ways of expressing mutual love.
To forget each other in the rivers and lakes
is to each find their own ease—
why wait for the small love of moistening and nourishing?

**Partial filial piety** and **partial compassion**
are but the love of moistening and nourishing.

In the *Zhuangzi* ["Heavenly Culture" chapter],
**Laozi** told **Confucius**:
*"If you apply the **Dao** of **benevolence** and **righteousness** to the world,
no greater chaos will arise."*

Indeed, **benevolence** and **righteousness**,
when practiced in this way,
only provoke resentment in my heart—
why not instead
let the people of the world retain their **primordial simplicity**,
move with **spontaneity**,
and uphold **virtue** as a whole,
rather than
be like one who beats a drum to search for a lost son?

The **primordial simplicity** of black and white
is insufficient for **discrimination**,
the **appearance** of fame and reputation
is insufficient for **expansion**,
fish moistening and nourishing each other
is not as good as forgetting each other in the rivers and lakes,
and people practicing **mutual benevolence**
is not as good as forgetting each other in **Dao/Way** and **art**.

**Renounce artifice, discard profit**—
then thieves and robbers will have none.

**Commentary:**
When men value **partial virtue** and **artificial skill**,
and harbor **desires for gain**,
then thieves and robbers arise.
Hence, to **renounce artifice** means people no longer compete,
and to **discard profit** means people find self-sufficiency—
so thieves and robbers will have none.

**Exegesis:**
To **renounce artifice** means to abandon **excessive craftsmanship**,
**illegal adornments**, and **debaucherous excesses**.
To **discard profit** means to abandon **pursuit of wealth**,
**exploitation through monopolies**,
and **fraudulent transactions**.
Thieves and robbers arise from **envy** and **insatiable desire**.
Now, if one **renounces artifice**, people no longer compete,
and if one **discards profit**, people find self-sufficiency—
when each is self-sufficient,
who would still be a thief or robber?
Thus, it is said that there will be none.

**Explanation:**
**Excessive craftsmanship** and **debaucherous excesses**,
though **artful**, serve no true purpose—
why indulge in them?
Even the **carving of monkeys** on wood by the **Wei** people,
or the **engraving of mulberry leaves** by the **Song** people,
though pleasing to the eye,
ultimately disturb the heart—
these are the sorts of things that should be abandoned.

**Pursuit of wealth** obstructs **conduct**,
**exploitation through monopolies** deprives others,
and **fraudulent transactions** involve deceit.
If any of these exist,
what is not theft?
To reject and discard them,
and to follow one’s proper share,
is to have enough—
why would there still be thieves and robbers?

Moreover, those who cultivate the **Dao**,
should **renounce artifice**—
the **artifice** of **internal desires** and **external luxuries**,
the **artifice** of **sharp emotions** and **sensory attachments**—
then the **three poisons** are purified,
and the **six thieves** will have none.

**Commentary:**
These three **renunciations**—
though they are stated,
do not yet show how to **cultivate**—
thus, they are insufficient for **instruction** in the text.
Therefore, further **cultivation** is prescribed,
as seen in the following passage.

**Exegesis:**
The three **renunciations** are:
**1.** Renounce the **Sage** and discard **wisdom**,
**2.** Renounce **benevolence** and discard **righteousness**,
**3.** Renounce **artifice** and discard **profit**.
Though these three are to be abandoned,
they do not yet prescribe **cultivation**—
thus, they are insufficient for **instruction** in the text,
and further **cultivation** is prescribed,
as in the passage on **"seeing simplicity"** and the rest.

**Explanation:**
The **Sage** and **wisdom** abandoned,
the people enjoy their **benefits**.
**Benevolence** and **righteousness** abandoned,
all return to **filial piety** and **compassion**.
**Artifice** and **profit** abandoned,
the people have no thieves or robbers.
Once these three are abandoned,
the **Dao** will show how to **cultivate** and restore antiquity.
Thus, it is said that this is insufficient,
and the following passage is prescribed.

**Prescribed Cultivation:**
*"See simplicity, embrace purity,
reduce selfishness, diminish desire."*

**Commentary:**
See **true simplicity**,
embrace **primordial purity**,
reduce **private evil**,
diminish **greedy desire**.

**Exegesis:**
To seek to **renounce the Sage** and **discard wisdom**,
one must always **see true simplicity**.
**Explanation:**
To be in accord with **non-desire** is to be **simple and pure**,
and **simple and pure** is to restore the **nature of the people**.
The absence of **knowledge** and **desire** is to merge with **true simplicity**,
and when **true simplicity** is merged,
the **traces of the Sage** and **wisdom** are abandoned.

**Exegesis:**
To seek to **renounce benevolence** and **discard righteousness**,
one must **embrace primordial simplicity**.
**Explanation:**
To guard one’s heart with **sincere simplicity** and **unadorned purity**,
then the **benevolence of universal love** and the **righteousness of judging others** are abandoned.

**Exegesis:**
To seek to **renounce artifice** and **discard profit**,
one must **reduce selfishness** and **diminish desire**.
**Explanation:**
When **private evil** does not spread in **nature**,
and **greedy desire** does not arise in the heart,
then **debaucherous artifice** and **exploitative profit** are abandoned.

**Exegesis:**
Though the three **renunciations** are insufficient in the text,
the four **practices** provide ample **cultivation** for the body.
To prevent **evil** from arising in the heart,
one must rely on **internal cultivation**.
**Explanation:**
The **Sage**, **wisdom**, **benevolence**, **righteousness**, **artifice**, and **profit**—
these six things,
when first practiced, serve to **save the people**,
but when clung to, they **obstruct the Dao**.
Thus, **deceitful schemes** and **theft** arise from them.
To **renounce** and **discard** them,
one may restore **true simplicity**.
Once **true simplicity** is restored,
then **internal cultivation** is applied.

To reveal the four **practices** at their conclusion,
is the **essential subtlety** of the **true Dao**.

**Explanation:**
When **artificial traces** of the **Sage** appear,
then **deceitful schemes** and **cunning intelligence** arise.
**Benevolence** arises from **non-benevolence**,
**righteousness** comes from **non-righteousness**,
**filial piety** is prominent when **unfilial** actions exist,
and **compassion** shines when **non-compassion** is present.

---

**能绝有迹有为，自复至慈至孝。**
When one severs all traces and artificial actions,
one restores **true simplicity**—
**ultimate compassion** and **filial piety** emerge naturally.

**斥淫巧则私利息，私利既息，盗贼不生，然后凝旒於朴素之乡，杜念於私欲之境，人登富寿，国致遐长。**
To reject **deceitful schemes** and **artifice** is to still **private gain**;
when **private gain** subsides, **theft and banditry** cease.
Then, **refined simplicity** takes root in the land,
and **selfish cravings** are extinguished in the heart.
Thus, the people attain **wealth and longevity**,
and the realm achieves **enduring prosperity**.

This is the **effect** of the **ruler’s practice of the Dao**.

**若夫心除嗜欲，身荡浮华，翦锐进之情，锄耽着之本，六贼不作，三元坦夷，四行克修，久视何远。**
As for those who **purge desire from the heart**,
**cast off superficiality from the body**,
**sever ambitious strivings**,
and **uproot the roots of attachment**—
the **six malevolent influences** vanish,
the **Three August Ones** [1] dwell in tranquility,
and the **Four Virtues** are fully cultivated.
How distant can **longevity** be?

This is the **effect** of the **practitioner’s cultivation**.

---
*Moral Canon of the True Dao: Broad Explication of the Sacred Meaning*
*Volume Seventeen Complete*
*Volume Eighteen*
*Attributed to Master Guangcheng of Tang by Du Guangting*
*Chapter Twenty: "The Chapter on Severing Learning to Know No Worry"*

**疏：**
The previous chapter clarified **severing and abandoning** the myriad paths,
restoring **primordial simplicity**—
thus, **theft and banditry** vanish.
This chapter elucidates **fearing and eliminating** worldly learning,
for the **enlightened** alone differ from the **common**.

The first sentence **marks the path** to demonstrate **severance**,
the next seven **offer analogies** to clarify principle,
another seventeen **contrast the common and the sage**,
and the final two **conclude with the solitary practitioner**.

**○义曰：**
**Sever** the learning of **artificial gain**,
to cultivate **serenity and harmony**.
Eliminate **superficial pursuits**,
and **worry and calamity** will not arise.

Using the analogy of **"Yes" and "Ah"** [2] to illustrate,
it serves to distinguish **severance** from **not severing**.

**Severance** and **not severing** both originate in the heart;
**"Yes"** and **"Ah"** both emerge from the mouth.
**Severance** aligns with **emptiness and stillness**, returning to the Dao,
while **not severing** leads to **drowning**—
**intellect** obscures **truth**,
**"Yes"** brings **reverence and caution** without blame,
**"Ah"** breeds **arrogance and defiance**, inviting punishment.
Though both arise from **heart and speech**, their outcomes differ—**auspicious or inauspicious**.

What people fear is **inviting punishment** and **losing truth**,
yet they cannot **sever knowledge and perception** to remain reverent.
Once they **know this**, they **must** fear it.
This is an **exhortation to sever learning**.

The common follow **contrary to the Dao**,
while the **sage** stands **uniquely apart**.
They **abandon** the **rich feasts of the Tailao** [3],
**withdraw** from the **spring pavilion’s distractions**,
**remove** the **harm of keen discernment**,
and **reject** **artificial contrivance**.

**Bound and stifled**, they **embrace the Mother of Qi** [4] like an infant’s movement,
thus **containing the Ultimate Truth**.

**Severing Learning Knows No Worry.**

**注：**
Severing **artificial worldly learning** preserves **primordial simplicity**;
with **few desires and little private gain**, there is **no worry**.

**疏：**
**Severing learning** means **severing artificial worldly learning**.
All people are born with **true simplicity and purity**,
but **exceeding their natural measure** in learning **harms their nature**.
If one **completely severs all action**, one **lacks cultivation**.
Now, we **sever only the excessive artificial learning**.

**义曰：**
**Sever**—this means **removal and cessation**.
The **Venerable Laozi** wished later generations to **gradually emulate simplicity and harmony**,
to **sever false habits**,
hence the text on **severing learning**.

**Artificial worldly learning** refers to the **worldly, contrived studies** of the age.
From the **Three Dynasties onward**, people were **frantic**,
ultimately relying on **rewards and punishments**—
how could they have **leisure to nurture their true nature and life**?

Those who delight in **clarity** indulge in **lust for color**;
those who delight in **acuity** indulge in **lust for sound**.
Delighting in **benevolence** confuses **virtue**,
delighting in **righteousness** defies **principle**,
delighting in **rites** aids **deceit**,
delighting in **music** aids **lust**,
delighting in **sageliness** aids **artifice**,
delighting in **knowledge** aids **flaws**.

These eight are the **greatest of studies**.
If one **rests content** in their **natural endowment**,
they **avoid excessive cravings**.

If they **exceed their measure**, **pursue beyond their nature**, and **indulge** in these,
they **invite excess and perversity**,
**injuring their innate harmony**,
**disrupting their natural disposition**.

If one **completely severs** all,
they **lose what should be cultivated**.
But if one **only severs the excessive artificial learning**,
**trusting in the true and constant**,
this aligns with **principle**.

**疏：**
This is what **Zhuangzi** called **"worldly learning seeking to restore its origin."**
If one’s learning is **within their natural measure**,
and they **follow their nature**—
even the **superior sage** exerts effort without **transgressing severance**,
hence **"Severing Learning Knows No Worry."**

**义曰：**
*Zhuangzi’s* **"Chapter on Nurturing Life"** states:
*"Worldly learning seeking to restore its origin"*—
those in the world have already **cultivated their nature and life** in **worldly ways**,
yet they wish to **use worldly learning to restore their original nature and life**—
this is **even more contrary to the Dao**.
Such are the **deluded masses**, far from the **Way**.

Why not **abandon contrived knowledge** and **trust spontaneous awareness**?
Even if one’s **intellect encompasses all things**,
they remain **serene and self-sufficient**.

**Within one’s measure** means **following one’s nature** and **trusting in true simplicity**.
To **trust in truth**—
**wisdom** is **wisdom**, but **forcing beyond one’s measure** becomes **deceit**.
To **trust in truth**—
**rites** are **rites**, but **forcing beyond one’s measure** becomes **chaos**.
To **trust in truth**—
**loyalty** is **loyalty**, but **forcing beyond one’s measure** becomes **flattery**.
To **trust in truth**—
**benevolence** is **benevolence**, but **forcing beyond one’s measure** becomes **ingratiation**.
To **trust in truth**—
**righteousness** is **righteousness**, but **forcing beyond one’s measure** becomes **theft**.
To **trust in truth**—
**sincerity** is **sincerity**, but **forcing beyond one’s measure** becomes **deception**.

**Forcing beyond one’s measure** leads to **loss and worry**,
while **resting in one’s measure** brings **truth and no fear**—
hence, **"Severing Learning Knows No Worry."**

The **superior sage’s diligent practice** is to **guard true simplicity** and **avoid artificiality**.

**"Yes" and "Ah"**—how distant are they?
**Good and evil**—how far apart are they?

**注：**
**"Yes"** is **reverent response**,
**"Ah"** is **arrogant response**.
Both emerge from the mouth—
hence, **"how distant are they?"**
**Reverence** brings **good fortune**,
**arrogance** brings **calamity**—
this illustrates that **severing worldly learning** brings **no worry**,
while **not severing** invites **suffering**—
the difference lies only in **the mind’s reflection**, not in **physical distance**.

**疏：**
**"Yes"**—this is **reverent response**.
*The Book of Rites* says: *"When the elder summons, do not answer ‘Yes’; respond with ‘Yes’ and rise."*

**义曰：**
**"Yes"**—**voice is solemn**, **demeanor is respectful**.
**Response**—this means **answering appropriately**.

---

**The Master** refers to one’s father, elder brothers, teachers, and elders.
**Challenging** means summoning.
When a father or elder brother summons, if one answers with *"No"* (諾), there is still fear of delay—
upon hearing the call, one should immediately rise, hence the *"Yes"* (唯) and rising.

*The Analects* states:
*"When there is wine and food, the master is served first."*
**Note:** *"Master"* here refers to father and elder brothers.
One must not overstep the Dao when following the master,
and when speaking with others, one must be respectful and deferential.
All these illustrate the same principle of **reverence and propriety**.

**Commentary:**
*"Ah"* (阿) is an **arrogant response**.
*The Book of Han* says: *"Who dares question me?"* (不誰何) —
*"Who"* (誰) here means *"dare to question."*

This is an illustrative analogy.
*"Yes"* and *"Ah"* both emerge from the mouth—
*"Yes"* with reverence brings **good fortune**,
*"Ah"* with arrogance brings **evil**.
Whether one **severes worldly learning** or not lies only in the mind—
if severed, there is **no worry**;
if not severed, **suffering arises**.

Both *"Yes"* and *"Ah"* originate from the mouth,
yet their **distance** lies in the heart—
thus, *"how distant are they?"*
Their **difference** lies in the mind—
thus, *"how far apart are they?"*

If one truly understands **learning without learning**,
where all attachments to learning are emptied,
and in **knowing, forgets knowing**—
no distinctions arise—
then *"Yes"* and *"Ah"* become unified,
and **good and evil are both forgotten**.

**Meaning:**
This clarifies that **reverent response** and **arrogant response**,
though both emerging from the mouth,
differ in **virtue and vice**—
while **severing worldly learning** or not
depends on the mind,
yet severing brings **serenity**,
while not severing brings **toil**.

Not severing invites **anxious thoughts and labored contemplation**,
while severing brings **tranquil spirit and harmonious virtue**.

**Learning without learning** means **daily diminishing** it.
*The Scripture of Transforming the Barbarians* says:
*"The origin of learning is non-learning;
it can subdue the fierce and the proud."*
This means that through the **Dao of non-action**,
one can subdue the **coarse and unruly** of the world.

*The Scripture of Western Ascension* states:
*"I learn without learning,
and thus can clarify the natural."*
*The Dao De Jing* says:
*"Learning without learning,
one avoids the errors of the multitude."*
All these convey the essence of **severance**.

If one comprehends this meaning,
then all attachments to learning will be emptied.

All worldly phenomena are **artificial**—
artificial things must decay and perish,
hence, they are **empty**.
Only **non-action and non-doing** bring
**clarity, stillness, and ease**—
internally aligning with the **True Constant**,
externally free from distinctions—
thus, *"Yes"* and *"Ah"* become unified,
and **good and evil are both forgotten**.

What people fear,
one must indeed fear.
**Note:**
What people generally fear are **arrogance and evil**.
The virtuous fear **worldly learning and artificiality**.
All must be severed—
thus, one must indeed fear them.

**Commentary:**
What people fear are **arrogance and evil**.
Arrogance leads to **transgression**,
while evil invites **disdain**.
To incur disdain is to be **abandoned by others**,
while transgression invites **blame and resentment**.
By analogy, **worldly learning and artificiality** breed **discord and conflict**—
if one does not fear and sever them,
they will **violate propriety and harm nature**,
thus, one must indeed fear and sever them.

**Meaning:**
People fear **arrogance and evil**,
yet they do not fear how **worldly learning** fuels **discord**,
generates **regret and blame**,
and exhausts the mind and spirit—
thus, they fail to sever it.

Therefore, those who follow the **Dao** fear
how **worldly learning** oversteps bounds and harms nature,
and they abandon and sever it—
this surpasses the common fear of **arrogance and evil**.

**How vast and endless it is!**
**Note:**
If one does not fear and sever worldly learning,
then the **true nature of all beings** will be **ruined**,
and there will be **no end to it**.

**Commentary:**
*"Ruined"* means **decayed**.
Arrogance and evil lead to **transgression**,
while worldly learning **loses its true essence**—
all are worthy of fear,
thus, they must be abandoned and severed.
If not severed and abandoned,
then the **true nature will be ruined**,
and there will be **no end to it**.

**Meaning:**
*"End"* (央) means **center**, **dawn**, or **halt**.
Worldly learning, when **clear**, breeds **pedantry**;
when **wise**, breeds **discord**;
when **perverse**, breeds **licentiousness**;
when **deceitful**, breeds **boastfulness**;
when **scanty**, breeds **ambition**;
when **excessive**, breeds **exhaustion**;
when **bold**, breeds **contention**;
when **skilled**, breeds **superiority and inferiority**.
The evil overcome others while seeking victory,
the ambitious seek vast knowledge while seeking more,
and they **toil endlessly**, exhausting the mind and harming nature—
this **deviates from the true and pure**,
hence, it is said to **lose its true essence**.

Once deviating from the true and pure,
the **natural virtue is ruined**—
just as fertile soil, originally free of filth,
becomes overgrown with weeds and thorns,
ruining its purity and harming its true nature.
Worldly learning **ruins human nature**,
just as weeds **spread unchecked**—
thus, it is called **ruined**.

*The Spring and Autumn Annals* says:
*"Do not allow it to spread unchecked—
it will be difficult to uproot."*
Weeds, once spread, cannot be easily removed—
this is its meaning.

**Commentary:**
*The Odes* says: *"The night is not yet over"*—
meaning the **clocks still chime**.
Here, *"not yet over"* means that **worldly learning harms nature**,
with **no end in sight**—
the path ahead remains long,
hence, *"not yet over."*

**Meaning:**
Worldly learning, once encountered, **proliferates**—
if not severed, it will **grow daily**,
spreading chaos endlessly,
with **no halt in sight**.

*The Zhou Poetry [□Small Odes□Ting Liao]* says:
*"The night is not yet over"*—
*"Over"* (央) means **dawn**.
*"Not yet over"* means the night has not yet reached dawn.
Worldly learning, if not severed,
cannot be exhausted.

The multitude **rejoices and thrives**,
like feasting on **oxen and sheep**,
or ascending to the **Spring Terrace**.
**Note:**
The multitude, engaged in **worldly learning and artificiality**,
**pursues sensory gratification**,
like one about to feast on **oxen and sheep**,
or ascending the **Spring Terrace** to gaze—
every movement stirs **greed and attachment**.

**Commentary:**
*"Rejoicing and thriving"* describes the **unrestrained movement of desires**.
This illustrates those who **do not fear severing learning**.

Worldly learning and artificiality
stir **desires and emotions**,
and they **pursue sensory objects**,
toiling endlessly in life.
Like a **hungry man feasting on oxen and sheep**,
indulging in flavors,
or a **beautiful woman ascending the Spring Terrace**,
gazing and stirring **lust and attachment**.

**Meaning:**
*"Beautiful woman"*—
*The Book of Changes [□Commentary]* says:
*"Suave appearance leads to licentiousness"*—
meaning a woman’s **alluring beauty**,
though elegant, lacks **moral restraint**,
and stirs **lustful desires**.
How much more so when ascending the Spring Terrace to gaze!

*"Rejoicing and thriving"* describes **harmony and delight**.
Those immersed in worldly learning
**drown in their nature**,
rejoicing in themselves without awareness,
yet **toiling endlessly**—
their **desires drag them**, **discord plagues them**,
and **fortune and misfortune arise from this**.

Then there are those with **six seals hanging at their waist**,
five palaces interlinked—
one outburst makes the feudal lords tremble,
one settled abode brings the world to rest.

They revel in fleeting splendor, sated by their ambitions,
find joy in transient wealth and noble rank.
Five cauldrons arrayed for feasting,
sated by the excess of **ox, sheep, and swine**;
a profusion of fragrant flowers delighting the senses,
taking pleasure in the unrestrained gaze from the **Spring Terrace**.

Some indulge in **Yan’s sisters and Luo’s beauties**,
dance to Chu’s rhythms and Wu’s songs—
the **Eight Tones** dull their hearing,
the **Five Colors** dazzle their vision.
Though they revel, what end awaits them?
Perhaps **prosperity fades into adversity**,
fortune turns to misfortune,
shifting **harmony’s joy into trembling dread**.

**Confucius said to Yan Hui:**
*"Once, I thought embracing Heaven’s will and knowing fate brought no sorrow—
now I see that embracing Heaven’s will and knowing fate bring **great sorrow** indeed."*
Even the Sage struggles thus—
how much more so the ordinary?

**Better to let the spirit roam in self-realization’s field,**
the nature find ease in the realm of forgotten knowing.

---
**Annotations:**
**Six seals (六印):** Symbols of imperial authority (seals of office).
**Five palaces (五府):** Likely refers to the five central ministries of the Han dynasty (or metaphorically, five key domains of power).
**Five cauldrons (五鼎):** Symbol of supreme authority (only the Son of Heaven could legitimately possess five).
**Ox, sheep, and swine (太牢):** As annotated below—ritual sacrifices.
**Yan’s sisters and Luo’s beauties (燕妹洛艳):** Allusions to legendary beauties (Yan being the state of Yan, Luo the Luo River region).
**Eight Tones (八音):** The eight musical categories in Chinese music theory.
**Five Colors (五色):** The five traditional colors (blue, green, red, white, black), symbolizing sensory overload.
**Tai (台):** Elevated platform, often associated with leisure and observation (as in the Spring Terrace).
**Comangora (倉庚):** The oriole, a bird whose song marks spring.
**Scholion (疏):** Explanatory commentary on ritual and natural phenomena.

The mind longs to wed with the noble prince, hence the phrase *"return together."* According to ritual, the second month is the month for pairing—when the maiden’s heart is wounded by spring, yearning for a match. These are the words of the *Yán Shī* [邠诗]—*Odes of the Guó* [国风]—in the *"Seventh Month"* [七月篇].

The *Comangora* [倉庚]—the *Pénjiàn* [笺] says it is the *Pénghuáng* [鹏黄, oriole].

*"I alone am tranquil, yet no signs have yet emerged,
Like an infant before it can laugh."*

**Commentary:** *"I alone am tranquil and still—when it comes to greed and desire, there is not even the faintest trace. Like that infant brother who cannot yet smile."*

**Scholion:** *"I"* refers to the Old Master [老君] speaking of himself. *"I fear to sever from worldly learning, embracing the Dao and containing harmony, alone able to remain tranquil and still. Toward the affairs of the age—all deeds of ambition and desire—there is not even the faintest trace, like that infant brother who cannot yet distinguish or smile, without differentiation."*

*"Kids"* [孩] means to distinguish others. *Zhuāngzi* says: *"Not until one reaches the stage of differentiation does one begin to know."*

**Meaning:** *"Tranquil"* [怕兮] is the appearance of stillness and non-action. *"Signs"* [兆] are the initial forms of things.

The Old Master, observing the transformations of the age’s people—how they gallop after fame and profit, indulge in worldly learning, cling to desires, and waste the harmony of Heaven—all return to emptiness, not for the sake of enlightenment, but to teach them to quiet their senses, sever the roots of thought, and make them like that infant brother, undifferentiated, unaware, deeply containing the mysterious void.

An infant is one who does not yet distinguish others. *"Kids"* [孩] means to distinguish. All things without form or trace are utterly forgotten.

In the *"Heaven’s Course"* [天运篇] of *Zhuāngzi*, the Old Master told Zǐgōng: *"The governance of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors differed. When Shùn ruled the world, he made men’s hearts competitive."* Thus, a pregnant woman bears a child in ten months, and the child speaks at five months—not until it can distinguish does it begin to know. This speaks of *"competitive hearts"*—differentiation. Once differentiation arises, the harmonious *qi* begins to disperse. Speaking at five months is when urgency grows. From then on, things grow greatly disordered.

The *"Family Sayings"* [家语] in the *"Original Command"* [本命篇] says: *"A person at three months begins to blink, then the eyes can see. At eight months, teeth grow, then they can eat. At ten months, the knees firm, then they can walk. By three years, speech coalesces. Now, speaking at five months—harmony scatters and urgency intensifies."*

*"Buoyant, buoyant, as if having nowhere to return."*

**Commentary:** *"The Perfect Man has no heart; his movements follow things without taking or giving, like a traveler with nowhere to go."* *"Buoyant, buoyant"* is the appearance of motion.

**Scholion:** *"Buoyant, buoyant"* is the appearance of motion. Common people, when they act, become attached and always seek something, so it seems as if they have a destination. I, with no heart, tranquil and still, drift with the flow and halt at obstacles—like a traveler on the Dao, with no fixed aim, no haste.

**Meaning:** Common people, attached to their pursuits, always have desires—whether for worldly learning, the will to excel, indulgence in worldly desires, or schemes of action. Their movements of heart and thought chase after what they seek, so it seems as if they have a destination. But if the heart is without attachment to appearances, drifting freely and content, where would it linger? It is like water—unblocked, it flows; obstructed, it stops. It does not contend with things nor seek anything, so it seems to have nowhere to return.

*"All others have excess,
Yet I alone seem abandoned."*

**Commentary:** *"Excess"*—clinging to dusty affairs, boasting of cleverness and wisdom, claiming to have abundance to display their brilliance. *"Abandoned"*—constantly as if lacking, as if forgotten.

**Scholion:** Common people, clinging to worldly learning, boast of cleverness and wisdom, all grasping at methods, claiming to have excess. I alone diminish them, never lingering, the heart untouched by love or defilement, so it seems forgotten.

**Meaning:** Common people boast of worldly learning to establish fame, vie in cleverness, compete in wealth and profit—each claims excess in worldly affairs. The Old Master, forgetting the heart and stilling wisdom, without attachment or boasting, vague and yielding, seems abandoned.

*"I, a fool’s heart, am pure and simple."*

**Commentary:** *"Am I truly a fool’s heart, forgotten to this degree? But my heart is pure and simple, so it seems abandoned."*

**Scholion:** Speaking of my non-attachment to all things, thus seeming forgotten. Would that I were truly a fool’s heart? But my heart is pure and simple, unadorned by love or desire, so it seems abandoned.

**Meaning:** The Old Master is the origin of transformation, the sovereign of Heaven and Earth, possessing all wisdom, with virtue and mystery unfathomable. Yet he feigns a heartless state, merging with the Dao, teaching the people to simplify their wills, return to their natural purity, quiet their senses, and restore themselves to virtue and the Way. It is not that he was originally dull and forgotten.

*"The vulgar are bright and clear,
Yet I alone seem dim."*

**Commentary:** *"Bright and clear"*—boasting of cleverness and wisdom. *"Dim"*—self-effacing.

*"The vulgar are sharp and discerning,
Yet I alone am muddled."*

**Commentary:** *"Sharp and discerning"*—establishing laws to govern others. *"Muddled"*—only broad and magnanimous.

**Scholion:** *"Bright and clear"* is boasting of cleverness and wisdom. *"Dim"* is like being in darkness, undifferentiated. *"Sharp and discerning"* is in teaching laws to measure others. *"Muddled"* is the intent of a heartless, magnanimous mind. The reason they are bright and sharp, teaching and governing—all stem from not severing worldly learning and action. Thus, the Sage fears to be dim and silent.

**Meaning:** From the Son of Heaven down to the common people, they follow the hearts of worldly learning, forgetting the original simplicity. Governing the state, they boast of their sage wisdom, sharpen their laws and ordinances—yet the sharper the wisdom, the more troubled the governance; the clearer the laws, the more exhausted the people. The Old Master is dim and silent, transforming without action.

Zhuangzi said: At the utmost extreme of the Dao, it is dim and silent.

*"Dim"* is concealing one’s brilliance;
*"Silent"* is not speaking.

Sudden as if obscured, tranquil as if without attachment.

**Commentary:** The appearance suddenly becomes obscured, while the heart is tranquil, severed from worldly learning, as if without any fixation.

**Exegesis:** One who abandons learning and action is carefree and without concern, ever dim and tranquil, the heart utterly still, never entangled—unattached to any law, thus appearing without fixation.

**Meaning:** *"Obscured"* is dim and dark. *"Tranquil"* is empty and still. Having abandoned worldly learning, one does not boast of wisdom, does not cling to action, does not dwell in any law, does not fixate on being or non-being—both emptiness and substance forgotten, penetrating the profound essence.

The multitude all have their ways,
**Commentary:** The common folk in every age have their reasons, following the inclinations of worldly learning.

I alone am stubborn and crude.
**Commentary:** *"Stubborn"* means without distinction. *"Crude"* means lacking sufficiency. Yet my heart is truly enlightened, outwardly appearing insufficient, hence the saying.

**Exegesis:** Ordinary people do not fear worldly learning; they always have their reasons, indulging in the pursuit of external phenomena, never resting. I alone, in this age, am without distinction, having what is crude and lacking. *"Stubborn"* means without distinction. *"Crude"* means lacking sufficiency. Yet my heart is truly enlightened, hence the saying.

The multitude bustle below, all seeking clarity.

**Meaning:** The common folk in the world move according to customary laws, all clinging to action, hence they have their ways. *"Ways"* means *"doing."* The Old Master inwardly comprehends all laws, deeply penetrating the source of the Dao, outwardly appearing dim and foolish, as if crude and vulgar.

The *Classic* below states: *"All under heaven say my Dao is great, yet I seem unworthy."* If I were worthy, it would have long been refined.

This is the same meaning.

From *"The multitude bustle below,"* the sixfold Sagely conducts contrast with worldly learning as worldly, clearly showing that one must abandon it and return to the Great Dao.

I alone differ from others,
**Commentary:** Others have desires; I have no attachments. Others oppose the Dao; I align with it.

And yet I value seeking nourishment from the Mother.
**Commentary:** Seeking nourishment from the Mother means valuing simplicity, like an infant without care for drink.

Thus, the earlier text says *"like an infant before it speaks,"* and the *Classic* below says *"the depth of virtue compares to an infant."* This is why I alone differ from others.

The phrase *"without seeking"* was added here.

Moreover, the Sage expounds the *Classic*; originally, there was no avoidance of taboo. Now, when teaching for the age, there may be suspicions. The logic is clear, so the meaning cannot be altered. When facing the text, the phrasing must be stable and convenient. Conveniently preserving the ancient, this is what we should strive for.

Again, Sima Qian said the Old Master spoke over five thousand words, thus clearly showing the depth of his understanding while ceasing speech—not necessarily fixing five thousand as a definite number.

**Exegesis:** These two sentences conclude the passage.

I alone differ from others—differing from the common folk who do not abandon worldly learning, thus contrasting with the earlier *"all seek clarity."*

Ordinary people are attached to desires and action; I alone forget desires and distinctions. Others differentiate among laws; I alone am equal to non-duality, hence the saying.

**Meaning:** At the outset, the two characters *"abandon learning"* are emphasized, lest people fail to suddenly comprehend. Sequentially contrasted, there are eleven distinctions in total:

1. Abandoning learning brings no worry; not abandoning it brings many worries.
2. *"Yielding"* means respectfully responding and doing good; *"flattering"* means arrogantly responding and doing evil.
3. Good is what people praise; evil is what people condemn.
4. The multitude has the splendor of grand feasts and lofty towers; I guard the simplicity of an infant’s conduct.
5. The multitude has destinations; I have nowhere to return.
6. The multitude boasts of excess; I alone seem to have forgotten.
7. The common folk shine brightly and clearly; I alone am dim and dark.
8. The common folk sharpen laws and ordinances; I alone am broad and magnanimous.
9. The multitude has fixations; I alone have no attachments.
10. The multitude all have actions; I alone seem insufficient.
11. The multitude indulge in honor and taste; I alone nourish the Original Harmony.

These eleven distinctions contrast with the worldly, clearly showing that worldly learning can be abandoned and *wuwei* can be practiced.

Thus, the exegesis says: The multitude has attachments; I alone forget desires. The multitude distinguishes among laws; I alone have no duality—this is why I differ from others.

**Exegesis:** The Old Master warns people to preserve simplicity and wholeness, reduce private desires, cut off indulgence in sights and sounds, and block the pursuit of fame—ordering them to be like infants, only seeking nourishment from the Mother.

Thus, it says *"and yet I value seeking nourishment from the Mother."*

**Meaning:** Conduct like an infant’s—no external entanglements, only knowing to seek nourishment from the Mother, without the burden of strife.

This is the Sage’s explanation; now its logic is detailed.

*"Mother"* is *qi*. Human nature, endowed by *qi*, is nourished by *qi*, hence called Mother.

Among the eleven distinctions, all clarify that worldly learning is unbeneficial to the body—those practicing the Dao must all abandon it, acting differently from the worldly.

Thus, it says *"I alone differ from others."*

Having already abandoned worldly learning, one only feeds on *qi* and harmonizes, returning to the root and reviving the vital breath—this is the method of practice.

The *Huangting Classic* says:
*"All eat grains and the five flavors,
I eat the Great Harmony of yin and yang."*

Again:
*"The grains and fruits are the earth’s essence,
The five flavors’ external beauty is demonic and rank—
Their stench disrupts the spirit’s clarity, wasting the prenatal breath.
How could one reverse aging and return to infancy?
Why not eat the pure *qi* of Great Harmony,
Thus able to never die and enter Yellow Tranquility?"*

*The Family Sayings* states: *"Those who eat *qi* are spiritually clear and long-lived."* The logic is without doubt.

In summary, governing the state lies in guarding stillness and silence, removing licentiousness and harshness.

The sovereign who follows the Dao dwells in simplicity, while ministers uphold virtue and expand the Way.

What precedes is the principle of cultivating one’s self; this is the rule for governing the state.

*Comprehensive Commentary on the True Scripture of Dao and Virtue, Volume Eighteen complete*
*Comprehensive Commentary on the True Scripture of Dao and Virtue, Volume Nineteen*
*Narrated by Master Guangcheng Du Guangting of the Tang Dynasty*
*Chapter Twenty-One: The Form of Great Virtue*

**Exegesis:**
The previous chapter clarifies the fear of severing worldly learning, as if in darkness, thus standing apart from others. This chapter elucidates that following the true Dao in its utmost sincerity allows one to transcend the multitude.

The opening two lines, *"The Form of Great Virtue,"* declare that the virtuous person conforms to the Dao. The ten lines following, *"The Dao as such,"* expound upon the profound essence of its truth. The five lines beginning *"From ancient times,"* distinguish the names of application and conclude with the virtue of spontaneous generation.

**Meaning:**
Previously, worldly learning was contrasted as stagnant, demonstrating the path of abandonment. Here, the supreme Dao is revealed as neither vague nor fleeting—it is the ultimate refuge of the true, the origin of the multitude. The Form of Great Virtue follows the Dao alone.

**Annotation:**
*Kong* means "uttermost."
*From* means "to conform."

When asked of one possessing the utmost virtue—what is their bearing?—it is said that their conduct follows only the Dao of utmost emptiness.

**Exegesis:**
*Kong*, utmost.
*From*, to conform.
*Container*, bearing.

To elucidate how one of profound virtue aligns with the Dao, it is asked: *"How does one of utmost virtue manifest?"*

The answer is: *"Their bearing follows only the Dao of utmost emptiness."*

**Meaning:**
The Dao has no name—only virtue reveals it. Virtue has no origin; it arises from the Dao itself. Those who attain the Dao can conform to it, and thus their virtue becomes manifest.

Therefore, one of utmost virtue is simply one who can conform to the Dao.

When the Sage-Emperor or sovereign rules the world, they rely on conforming to the Dao to attain exalted status, governing all within the realm, and must embrace the Dao to establish their foundation.

Thus, the *Book of Documents*—both the *Yao De* and *Shun De*—state: *"If one examines the ancient Dao,"* meaning to follow the Dao of antiquity.

The Dao, as a thing, is but **formless and elusive**.

**Annotation:**
This clarifies that the Dao from which utmost virtue arises is neither existent nor nonexistent—its boundless application defies naming—hence, it is called formless and elusive.

**Exegesis:**
The Dao, as a thing, is formless and elusive—how does it move and shape? It is said that this profound origin is neither existent nor nonexistent, and its nature is difficult to name. If one says it is existent, it is **still and without form**; if one says it is nonexistent, it **permeates like a presence**.

As it is nonexistent yet difficult to name, it is called formless and elusive.

**Meaning:**
Formless and elusive—neither nonexistent nor existent, neither existent nor nonexistent. If one calls it existent, it cannot be grasped; if one calls it nonexistent, it responds to myriad transformations.

**Meaning:**
The Dao is the term for **uttermost emptiness**. Though utterly empty, it opens and connects with all things, hence it is called the Dao—nothing is excluded, nothing is obstructed. If it were to exist as a thing, it would be hindered by materiality and could not persistently connect.

The Dao, being utter emptiness in essence, is not truly nonexistent—yet it envelops heaven and earth, illuminates sun and moon, brings winter cold and summer heat, births spring and ends autumn, and all phenomena move in accordance with the Dao. Thus, it cannot be said to be nonexistent.

But when one probes its operations and examines its generation, does one see what it accomplishes, or know how it transforms? It cannot be said to be existent.

It is **existence within nonexistence, nonexistence within existence**—one cannot point to it and define its name, hence it is called formless and elusive.

**Elusive and formless**, yet within it are traces.

**Annotation:**
Elusive—nonexistence. Formless—existence. The appearance of traces means that from nonexistence, it descends into existence, revealing all things within.

**Exegesis:**
This reveals the origin of generation. Elusive—nonexistence. Formless—existence. The appearance of traces: the profound origin is without form, hence called elusive. Generation and transformation bring forth existence, hence called formless.

Thus, from nonexistence it descends into existence, revealing all phenomena within—from origin to trace.

**Meaning:**
From above to below is called descent. The Dao of the profound origin emerges from utter emptiness. The body of utter emptiness is clear and insubstantial, yet when it generates and transforms all things, it deploys the Dao’s divine function—within the boundless mystery, it births wondrous existence.

Wondrous existence, fused and transformed, descends from above to below into the human world, revealing all phenomena. The profound origin is the root, wondrous existence is the trace—root everlastingly present, trace ever the means of generation and use.

Thus, all phenomena arise from the Dao, all forms are its offspring.

**Elusive and formless**, yet within it are things.

**Annotation:**
Things—referring to the Dao’s formless and elusive nature, as previously described. From existence, they return to nonexistence, thus restoring the Dao—hence, *"within it are things."*

**Exegesis:**
Things—referring to the Dao’s formless and elusive nature, meaning the profound origin. The profound origin descends to generate, revealing all phenomena. When one cultivates their nature and returns to virtue, they revert to nonexistence.

Nonexistence is the Dao itself.

**Meaning:**
Things are the traces of the formless and elusive origin, the traces of wondrous existence. Having descended from root to trace, the Dao generates all dharmas. Following the trace to return to the root, all dharmas revert to the Dao.

It is said that wondrous existence returns to formless and elusive nonexistence—without beginning or end, ever generating and ever transforming.

**Exegesis:**
When one cultivates their nature and returns to virtue, they do not depart from the profound origin. From existence, they return to nonexistence, merging once more with the Dao—hence, *"within it are things."*

It is said that there is wondrous substance, which encompasses the traces to return to the root.

**Meaning:**
The nature one receives from the Dao is called innate nature; the shifts of nature are called emotions. If one restrains emotions and severs thoughts, returning to innate nature and the source, they become a paragon of utmost virtue.

The root of utmost virtue is the wondrous Dao. Hence, it is said that cultivating nature and returning to virtue is to go from existence to nonexistence.

Emotions are existence; restraining emotions and returning to the root is nonexistence. Having severed false emotions and returned to true nature, true nature preserves all virtue—virtue is the Dao’s stage.

This is to merge once more with the Dao. Merging—契合—is to align perfectly.

Wondrous substance is the Dao, hence *"encompassing traces to return to the root."* This is to encompass the traces of existence and return to nonexistence as the root.

**Obscure and merged**, yet within it is essence.

**Annotation:**
Formless and elusive—existence and nonexistence. Obscure and merged—profound mystery, beyond measure. The profound origin descends to generate, cultivates nature and returns to virtue, encompassing traces to return to the root—wondrous substance abides in nonexistence. Obscure and merged are profound mysteries, unquantifiable.

Yet within them, the utmost essence is contained. Hence, *"within it is essence."*

**Exegesis:**
**Meaning:**
First, the profound origin descends to generate, revealing existence from nonexistence. Then, it encompasses traces and returns to the root, reverting existence to nonexistence.

This concludes the two phases as beginning and end, lest the world be confused: the Dao does not cease. If one clings to existence, nonexistence must follow; if one clings to nonexistence, existence must arise. Both sides are stagnant—one fails to grasp the Middle Way.

Thus it is shown: *"Within it is essence"*—most true, most trustworthy.
This reveals the wondrous Dao, ever-present yet neither beginning nor ending.

When one penetrates the profound words, one attains the Middle Way.

Further elucidating the gate of generation and transformation:
The *huanghu* [恍惚] form—this is the clear and void *qi*.
Above, it becomes Heaven.
The *huanghu* substance—this is the thick and turbid *qi*.
Below, it becomes Earth.
The *yaoming* [杳冥] essence—this is the pure and harmonious *qi*.
These three *qi* interact and coalesce, forming humanity.

Humanity—among the Three Powers, the most refined and intelligent.
They follow Heaven’s law and Earth’s model, capable of all things,
Yet they too arise from the wondrous origin’s divided *qi*.
If they lose their nature and indulge their passions, they stray from their root and perish;
If they cultivate their nature and return to virtue, they attain the Dao and ascend.

The pure and harmonious *qi* inhered within them—when cultivated, it endures.
Its essence is most true; within it is trustworthiness.

**Exegesis:**
The *yaoming* essence is originally unadulterated.
When things respond, it manifests; its responses are never amiss.
Thus it is said to be trustworthy.

**Commentary:**
The supreme Dao’s wondrous substance is inherently unadulterated.
Its transformations are most refined, hence its essence is most true.
Its generative function pervades all beings;
when things respond, it never fails to manifest—never errs.
Thus it is said to be most trustworthy.

**Meaning:**
*"Being"* refers to reaching; *"difference"* means deviation; *"err"* means failure.
The Dao’s utmost subtlety is profound and penetrating—
it cannot be ascribed to existence, nor can it be likened to nonexistence.
Beyond this, it is not called the Dao—how could any *dharma* be mixed within it?
It may truly be called *Dao*.

Its transformative function is boundless, its responses unfathomable.
Thus it is most refined, most trustworthy.

The *Shang Shu* says: *"Human heart alone is perilous; Dao-heart alone is subtle.
Only the refined, the singular—this is it."*

From ancient times to today, its name does not fade.

**Exegesis:**
The Dao, from ancient times to today, generates all things.
Things obtain the Dao’s use, and through use, names are established.
The generative use is the same through ages;
the names of its responses thus do not fade.
This is to measure all origins.

**Commentary:**
*"Measure"* means to survey and assess; *"origin"* means beginning.
The supreme Dao’s responses survey all things’ origins,
allowing each to fulfill its generative use.

**Commentary:**
The Dao’s generative function is rooted in the true, refined, and trustworthy.
Its beginning and end are boundless, unchanging through ages.
Thus, the names and uses of things—whether Heaven’s clarity or Earth’s tranquility—
remain constant from ancient times to today.
Hence it is said: *"The generative use is the same through ages."*

By this true, refined, and trustworthy essence,
all things’ origins are surveyed,
each fulfilling its generative use.

**Meaning:**
As previously explained: Heaven’s canopy, Earth’s load,
the sun’s illumination, the moon’s attendance—
all are the Dao’s use with them.
Heaven’s clarity, Earth’s tranquility, valleys’ fullness, things’ growth—
all are the Dao’s names bestowed upon them.
These names and uses remain unaltered through ages;
its trustworthiness and refinement are ever-present from ancient to modern times.
It does not proclaim its function over all beings,
but rather bestows its use upon all things—
yet who among them perceives its beginning and end?
It is the master of transformation—profound, wondrous.
How do I know the origins are thus?
*By this.*

**Exegesis:**
*By this*—that all things today inherit the Dao’s wondrous use in generation.

**Commentary:**
Further elaborating: How do I know that all things’ origins
rely on inheriting from the Dao, which surveys and assesses them,
allowing each to fulfill its generative use?
The answer is: *By this.*
*By this*—by its most true, most trustworthy nature.
All things today inherit the wondrous use in generation—
thus I know it.

**Meaning:**
The Dao nurtures myriad differences,
surveys all classes,
as the origin of things, the first of transformations.
Heaven is clear through it, Earth is tranquil through it,
all things live through it, the sun and moon shine through it.
It is thus—how do I know?
Because its refinement and trustworthiness are unchanging through ages,
and things inherit the Dao as their origin.

Thus, the greatest *virtue* is Heaven and Earth;
the most luminous symbol is the sun and moon;
those who use the Dao to model Heaven are the sovereigns.

Sovereigns, rich with all under Heaven,
enthroned in the central realm,
nurturing myriad lives,
leading all things,
calm and tranquil like Earth,
broad and encompassing like Heaven,
their officials modeling the Four Seasons,
their rewards and punishments clear like autumn and summer,
yet they embody the Dao’s purity and non-action,
governing with utmost benevolence,
demonstrating utmost trustworthiness,
teaching all beings that the Dao is the origin,
each abandoning superficiality to return to the root,
knowing the Dao as their ancestral lineage,
yearning to restore sincerity and return to simplicity.
Their grand designs are firmly established,
their profound transformations flourish.

---
**Chapter Twenty-Two: *Qu* [曲] as the Whole**

**Commentary:**
The previous chapter clarified that following the Dao’s true nature comprehensively
enables one to survey all origins.
This chapter demonstrates that embracing unity as the standard—
not contending—is how *qu* [曲] achieves completeness.
The first six lines show the conduct of sincerity and completeness,
which then illuminate the sage’s conduct below.
The next four lines further explain how *qu* leads to completeness and avoids ruin.

Only by ceasing contention does one achieve completeness and return.

**Meaning:**
Having already expounded the wondrous Dao’s vast and expansive transformative function,
this now demonstrates the principle of completeness,
teaching the method of cultivation.
*Qu* [曲], bending; *wang* [枉], crookedness; *wa* [洼], depression; *pi* [弊], exhaustion—
all arise from humility yet increase brilliance.
Embracing unity as the law,
we now clarify that minimal ability governs the multitude.

Abandon the traces of self-perception and self-righteousness,
eliminate the faults of self-conceit and self-praise—
only then can one achieve sincerity and completeness,
far surpassing those who contend.

**曲则全**
*Commentary:* Bend oneself to meet the demands of duty, and thus achieve completeness.
*Exegesis:* *Qu* [曲] means to yield flexibly and comply.
When one can yield flexibly and comply with others,
not opposing them in their ways,
then one can preserve oneself—
hence, *qu* then *quan* [全].

**Meaning:**
The Way of governing oneself begins with governing the heart.
The governance of the heart lies in the Dao.
When one attains the Dao, the heart is governed;
when one loses the Dao, the heart is disordered.
A governed heart practices humility and yielding,
a disordered heart engages in contention and self-justification.
Humility and yielding mean bending oneself to comply with others,
while contention means adornment of the self and denial of faults.
Those who bend themselves and comply do not oppose others,
and others will comply in turn.
Bending oneself preserves others,
and others will preserve one in return.
Not contending with others is the Way of preserving oneself.

The *Shàngshū* [尚书] states:
*"If all under heaven have faults, let them rest with me alone.
If I alone have faults, I cannot impose them upon all under heaven."*
This is the Way of the sovereign bending himself and taking responsibility.

**枉则直**
*Commentary:* Bend oneself to rectify others, and thus become straight.
*Exegesis:* *Wang* [枉] means to endure wrong from others.
*Zhi* [直] means to correct what is bent.
The *Chūnqiū* [春秋] says: *"To correct what is bent is to be straight."*
Though one does not oppose others,
when others wrong them and they endure it,
the wrongdoer will feel shame and self-correct—
thus, one’s straightness can rectify what is bent,
hence, *wang* then *zhi* [直].

**Meaning:**
The heart of one who attains the Dao does not oppose others.
When others wrong them and they endure it,
the wrongdoer will inevitably feel shame
and self-correct.
As with Lián Pó [廉颇] and Lìn Xiàngrú [蔺相如] serving together in Zhào [赵],
Lián Pó held a lower rank than Xiàngrú,
and in anger said:
*"I have served the state with merit,
yet I am placed beneath Xiàngrú—
this is my shame.
When I see him, I will surely humiliate him."*
Xiàngrú, hearing this, always avoided him in his carriage.
His attendants wondered:
*"The Prime Minister fears not mighty Qin,
yet fears Lián Pó—why?"*
Xiàngrú replied:
*"Qin does not dare lightly attack Zhào
because it fears me and Lián Pó.
If I and Lián Pó were to meet,
two tigers would fight—
neither would survive.
This would endanger Zhào and benefit Qin.
I avoid him to preserve the state,
not for my own sake."*
When Lián Pó heard this,
he bore a willow branch and bared his chest in apology.
This is how the wrongdoer was made to fear and self-correct,
demonstrating how one’s straightness can rectify what is bent.

The *Chūnqiū* states:
*"To correct what is bent is to be straight."*
In the seventh year of King Xiāng [襄公],
winter, tenth month,
Jìn’s minister Hàn Xiànzǐ [韩献子] announced his retirement,
and his son Mùzǐ [穆子] Wújì [无忌], though disabled,
was to be established in his place.
Mùzǐ declined, saying:
*"The *Shī* [诗] states:
*'Is it not that I rise early and retire late?*
*It is because my deeds are often exposed.'*
And again:
*'If one does not personally attend to it,*
*the common people will not trust it.'*"*

Mùzǐ said, *"I am unworthy—can I truly decline? Let me instead establish my son Qǐ. He consorts with Tián Sū and Yóu, yet speaks of loving virtue. The *Shī* says:
*'Calm and respectful in your station,
Loving what is straight and upright,
The spirits hear you,
And great blessings attend you.*
To care for the people is virtue,
To be straight and upright is correctness.
This is rectifying one’s own heart.
To rectify what is bent is to be straight—
To rectify others’ crookedness.
The three harmonies constitute virtue.
Virtue, straightness, and correctness—
These three complete humanity.
Thus, the bright spirits hear you,
And great blessings descend upon you.
Would it not be fitting to establish him?"*

On the day *Gēngxū*, the Jin ruler sent Hàn Qǐ to pay respects to Xiànzǐ, who then formally requested retirement. The Jin ruler said that Mùzǐ was virtuous and appointed him as a great officer of the public clan.

*"The low becomes full."* **Note:** *"He who holds to humility is ever full."*
**Citation:** *"Dàowù"* explains: *"Dàowù"* means "hollowed and low." *"Yíng"* means "full." This is a metaphorical saying.
The earth’s hollows and lows—water flows to fill them.
A man who guards humility and yielding—his virtue grows ever brighter.
To be able to bend and yield is to be low;
To be complete and straight is to be full.
Thus it is said: *"The low becomes full."*
**Meaning:** The Dao of the earth transforms fullness into humility, flowing like valleys and streams.
The high gradually lowers, while the low rises higher—
Thus, fullness is transformed, and humility spreads.
Fullness invites change, and height cannot be relied upon;
Humility spreads, and lowliness can be steadfast.
The earth’s hollows gather water to become full;
A man’s humility gathers virtue to shine ever brighter.
*"Guarding humility"* refers to bowing, yielding, and letting—
Never failing in modesty, never violating propriety,
Ever acting with meekness and gentleness—
Thus virtue gathers to him,
Like water filling the earth’s hollows.
Those who can bend and yield, who are low—
All speak of lowering their hearts.
Those who are complete, straight, and full—
All speak of increasing their virtue.
A ruler who governs the state
Accepts filth and embraces impurity,
Honors the lowly and respects the worthy,
And thus all near and far flock to him—
The state then thrives and grows great.

*"Worn becomes new."* **Note:** *"To guard what is worn and thin is to renew daily."*
**Citation:** *"Pí"* means "thin and flawed."
Crookedness, bending, and lowliness—
All are self-imposed thinness and flaw.
To dwell in thinness and flaw,
Others will surely honor you first—
Thus your virtue and conduct renew daily.
Hence it is said: *"Worn becomes new."*
**Meaning:** To dwell in what is thin and flawed—
What people reject.
Yet if I embrace it,
And place myself in what is thin and flawed,
Then all will praise and admire me.
The practitioner of the Dao
Walks where others do not walk,
Learns what others do not learn,
Finds rest where others do not rest,
Takes joy where others do not take joy,
Does what others do not do,
Gains what others cannot gain.
What he walks and does—
Nothing but humility, stillness, simplicity, and contentment—
Thus his virtue shines, and the Dao is fulfilled.
This may be called *virtue and conduct renewing daily.*

*"Few gains, many losses."* **Note:** *"Clinging to One without separation ensures no loss."*
*"Many gains, much confusion."* **Note:** *"Many paths lead to confusion and disorder."*
Thus the Sage embraces One as the model for all under Heaven. **Note:** *"The Sage guards the pure and singular, thus becoming the law for all under Heaven."*
**Citation:** *"This means taking little for oneself."*
He who takes little for himself loses nothing—
Hence *"few gains."*
He who gives much to others invites contention—
Hence *"many losses."*
To cultivate the self is thus;
To cultivate the Dao is likewise—
One must guard the pure and singular,
Preserve the true and unadulterated.
If one seeks many divergent paths,
Confusion and disorder will come—
Thus the lost sheep wanders down many forks,
And life is forfeited through many pursuits.
Therefore the Sage embraces One without separation,
And thus becomes the law for all under Heaven.

**Meaning:** A frugal man can share his wealth—
This shows he takes little for himself.
He who takes little has no greedy heart;
He who has no greedy heart invites no contention;
He who invites no contention gains what he seeks.
He who takes much will not be equitable;
The inequitable invite contention;
Contention leads to loss—
Thus confusion arises.
This parable illustrates the path of cultivation.

The methods of cultivating the Dao are manifold,
Yet the attainment of the Dao lies in guarding One.
He who guards One without loss—
In governing the self, he attains the Dao;
In governing the state, he acts without action.
Without action, things settle into ease.
Thus the Sage embraces One as the law for all under Heaven.

In governing the self, one should not multiply affairs;
In cultivating the Dao, one should not multiply paths.
To multiply affairs—
A myriad thoughts swarm, harming one’s life.
Can life remain unharmed?
Ten thousand archers bend their bows to strike one target—
Can the target remain unhit?
To multiply paths—
Mystic teachings branch in myriad ways,
Alchemical scriptures fill countless volumes.
With one man’s heart burdened by the teachings of sages past,
His form wearies without, his spirit frays within—
Thus he strays ever farther from the Dao.

In governing the state, to multiply affairs—
Jìn’s policies branched in many directions,
Thus the feudal lords did not rally to it;
Qín’s nets were tangled and dense,
Thus all under Heaven’s hearts turned away.
One state, three dukes—
Naturally difficult to govern;
Ten sheep, nine herders—
How can one hope to transform the people?
He who loses his sheep laments the many forks;
He who loses his life blames his many pursuits.
This is the natural order.
*"Not self-aware, yet clear."*

---

**Annotations:**
注：If one does not reveal one’s own abilities,
and always bends oneself to meet the demands of duty,
then virtue is preserved and clarity naturally arises.

**Commentary (疏):**
This is the inverse explanation of *"curved, thus whole."*
It means: If one does not reveal one’s own excellence,
and always yields and conforms to things,
then one’s complete virtue grows ever clearer—
hence, *"thus clarity."*

**Meaning (义曰):**
If one reveals what is not beautiful,
there will inevitably be a heart of contention and rivalry,
and thus one cannot yield and conform to things.

But if one yields and conforms to things,
never revealing one’s own excellence,
then virtue is preserved and clarity grows ever brighter.

When virtue is complete, the form is complete;
when the form is complete, the *qi* is complete;
when the *qi* is complete, the spirit is complete.

The spirit of one who is wholly complete
has no inner or outer separation—
penetrating the eight extremes,
the clarity of not revealing oneself is vast.

---
**Not self-righteous, thus illustrious.**
**Annotations:**
If one does not presume to be correct,
and instead bends oneself to uphold others,
then one’s rectitude naturally becomes manifest.

**Commentary (疏):**
This is the inverse explanation of *"bent, thus straight."*
It means: If one bears wrongs for others,
never asserting oneself as correct,
there will be no blame.
Thus one’s rectitude naturally becomes evident—
hence, *"thus illustrious."*

**Meaning (义曰):**
If one insists on being correct in a matter,
there will inevitably be a heart of attachment,
and thus one cannot bend oneself to submission.

But if one bends oneself to submission,
never clinging to being correct,
then rectitude shines forth and becomes ever more illustrious.

When rectitude is illustrious, goodness is illustrious;
when goodness is illustrious, virtue is illustrious.

The virtuous one—
all things gather to them;
virtue grows ever brighter,
and the illustriousness of not presuming correctness is vast.

---
**Not self-praising, thus meritorious.**
**Annotations:**
If one does not praise oneself,
then merit returns to them.

**Commentary (疏):**
This is the inverse explanation of *"hollow, thus full."*
It means: If one does not praise oneself,
and instead practices humility,
others will not compete for merit.
Merit returns to them, like earth assisting water—
fullness arises—
hence, *"thus meritorious."*

**Meaning (义曰):**
To boast of one’s own goodness is called *"praising."*
If people love to praise themselves,
they will inevitably have a heart of greed and competition,
and thus cannot humble themselves and guard modesty.

But if one humbles themselves and guards modesty,
never praising their own goodness,
then goodness becomes evident and merit arises.

The meritorious one—
people bear their kindness,
all things receive their blessings;
wherever goodness and merit extend,
who would not rejoice and follow?
Thus the merit of not praising oneself is great.

Yán Huí said: *"May I not praise goodness."*
The *Shàngshū* says: *"You alone do not praise [yourself],*
*and none under Heaven will contend with you for merit."*

This is what is meant.

---
**Not self-glorifying, thus enduring.**
**Annotations:**
If one long endures their own deficiencies,
never glorifying themselves,
then others will extol their virtues.

**Commentary (疏):**
This is the inverse explanation of *"worn, thus renewed."*
If one endures their own deficiencies,
never glorifying themselves,
others will inevitably yield,
and good deeds will grow ever more enduring—
hence, *"thus enduring."*

**Meaning (义曰):**
*"Glorify"* means *"rely upon."*
If one relies on their own virtues,
they will inevitably have a heart of boasting,
and thus cannot place themselves in deficiency.

But if one places themselves in deficiency,
others will naturally extol and beautify them,
and thus the beauty of not glorifying oneself grows ever more enduring.

The *Shàngshū* says: *"You alone do not glorify [yourself],*
*and none under Heaven will contend with you for ability."*

It is only because one does not contend
that none under Heaven can contend with them.

**Annotations:**
Not contending with things—
who would contend with them?

**Commentary (疏):**
All the previous conduct—
bending to wholeness, yielding to rectitude,
humbling to fullness, enduring deficiency—
are all acts of yielding and not contending.
Since gentleness and weakness overcome harshness and strength,
and humility naturally returns to what is straight,
who under Heaven could contend with one who does not contend?

Thus, *"none can contend with them."*

**Meaning (义曰):**
Those who love to contend are not in accord with the Dao.
The virtue of not contending is the greatest virtue.

The four prior acts—
bending to wholeness, yielding to rectitude,
humbling to fullness, enduring deficiency—
are the practices of cultivation.
The four inverses—
not revealing oneself, not presuming correctness,
not praising oneself, not glorifying oneself—
are the manifest fruits of response.
Those who practice the four acts
are humble, gentle, and do not contend with things,
and thus none under Heaven can contend with them,
while attaining the four blessings:
*"thus clarity," "thus illustrious," "thus meritorious," "thus enduring."*

Was the ancient saying *"curved, thus whole"*
an empty phrase?
Indeed, it is whole and returns to its root.

**Annotations:**
The ancients spoke of *"curved, thus whole"*—
was this not an empty claim?
Only those who truly bend
will have the logic of wholeness return to them.

**Commentary (疏):**
This draws upon the ancient saying to conclude *"curved, thus whole."*
It means: The ancients have spoken of this *"curved, thus whole"*—
was this not a true saying without substance?
If one truly yields and conforms without resistance,
then the logic of wholeness naturally returns to them—
hence, *"indeed, whole and returns to its root."*

*"Sincere"* means *"truth."*

**Meaning (义曰):**
The *"curved"* spoken of here
is the curved of gentleness and submission,
not the curved of deceit.

The Sage embraced this *"curved, thus whole"* Dao
to establish it as law under Heaven.
When Heaven is ordered,
the Sage does not reveal their own excellence,
does not presume their own actions,
does not praise their own merit,
does not glorify their own abilities—
all things return to the Sage’s virtue.

The Sage governs with humility and submission,
and thus the virtue of *"curved, thus whole"*
naturally returns.

From ancient times to today,
this saying has endured,
and when practiced, it is certain to take effect—
truly not empty.

But if the ruler embraces one *"bent"* humility,
returns to the root of tranquility,
they will surely display the virtue of wholeness
and attain the Great Peace.

---
**End of *The Broad Explication of the Daoist Classic’s Sacred Meaning*, Volume Nineteen**
**End of *The Broad Explication of the Daoist Classic’s Sacred Meaning*, Volume Twenty**

「The *Broad Explication* by Master Du Guangting of the *Tang* [Dynasty] elucidates *The Daoist Classic’s Sacred Meaning* in the chapter *"Hesitant Speech, Natural Way"* (Chapter Twenty-Three):

**Explication:** The chapter expounds *"embracing the One"* as the model—
not striving, hence *"curved, thus whole."*

This chapter elucidates *the Dao’s* transcendent silence,
for clinging to words is akin to losing *the Way.*

The first sentence establishes the principle,
the next five employ analogies to clarify instruction—
thus, the meaning is derived from the examples below.

**Meaning:** The Sage’s teaching is not elaborate,
but aligns with *the Way’s* natural order.

When winds and rains rage violently,
they cannot long endure—
*Hesitant Speech* [thus] approaches forgetting speech.

To admonish against violence is to urge its cessation,
and when violence ceases, stillness returns—
*the Way* responds accordingly.

If trust is insufficient,
the people will not heed—
how then can they believe?

Heaven’s violent storms do not persist,
nor can winds and rains be constant—
blaming those who forget speech,
gradually attuning to *the Way’s* natural principle.

Moreover, no vessel is greater than Heaven and Earth,
no authority heavier than the divine.
Even violent winds and sudden rains cannot endure—
how much less can rulers, relying on their exalted station and wealth,
despise the world and oppress the people,
for this is not a lasting path.

Why so? The First Emperor of Qin conquered the four seas,
unified the nine regions,
treated the people of the south like livestock,
regarded the common folk as grass,
and built labyrinthine palaces for his own indulgence.
In his arrogance and excess,
he unleashed violence and ruled with reckless folly,
pursuing boundless luxury and honor—
yet his fate collapsed in an instant.

Xiang Yu [Item] roared across the Central Plains,
devoured the six directions,
with no sovereign above him,
no rival before him—
yet his defeat at the Wu River came swiftly.

The *Laozi* warns against such tyranny,
commanding adherence to *the Way’s* natural, non-action principle.

**Hesitant Speech, Natural Way.**
**Annotation:** *Hesitant Speech* means forgetting speech.
Yet it does not say *"forgetting speech"* but *"hesitant"*—
for *the Way* is articulated through speech,
and cannot be entirely forgotten.

When *the Way* is understood, speech is forgotten—
hence, *"hesitant."*

If one can grasp *the Way* through speech,
not clinging to words,
they will harmonize with *the Way’s* natural order.

**Explication:** This clarifies that teaching cannot be rigidly clung to.
*Hesitant Speech* means forgetting speech.

Speech exists within *the Way*—
those who cling to words have not grasped the teaching.

*The Way* must be conveyed through speech,
and forgetting it entirely would lose the path to enlightenment—
thus, it is said that *the Way* is articulated through speech,
and cannot be entirely forgotten.

When *the Way* is understood, speech is forgotten—
hence, *"hesitant."*

If one can perceive the teaching’s subtle essence
through its spoken form,
not fixating on its superficial aspects,
they will align with *the Way’s* natural order.

Therefore, it is called *"Hesitant Speech, Natural Way."*

**Meaning:** Teaching must rely on speech,
and speech serves to elucidate *the Way.*

Clinging to words while neglecting the teaching
is not the path of enlightenment—
the key lies in forgetting speech to abandon fixation.

Once *the Way* is attained,
not clinging to words reveals the true purpose of speech.

**Annotation:** *"Signs and traps"* [筌蹄]—
*Zhuangzi* says: *"Signs"* are the tools to catch fish,
but once the fish is caught, the signs are forgotten.
*"Traps"* are the tools to catch rabbits,
but once the rabbit is caught, the traps are forgotten.

Speech is the tool to grasp *the Way*’s intent—
when *the Way* is attained, speech is forgotten.
How then could I speak to one who has forgotten speech?

*"Signs"* are made of bamboo,
the implements for catching fish.
*"Traps"* are made of rope,
the implements for catching rabbits.

Once fish and rabbits are obtained,
the signs and traps may be discarded.
If one clings to the signs and traps,
they are no longer fish or rabbits.

If one clings to speech,
it is no longer the teaching’s intent.

Violent winds do not last a morning,
sudden rains do not endure a day.

**Annotation:** When winds and rains are violent and abrupt,
they harm things and cannot persist—
just as clinging to speech obscures *the Way* and breeds confusion.

**Explication:** Violent winds and sudden rains
are metaphors for the teaching’s intent.

Winds disperse, rains nourish—
if they are violent and sudden,
they harm things and cannot endure.

*Qi* sustains the body,
the heart governs the spirit—
if *qi* is violent and sudden,
it harms the body itself.

Governance orders the people,
commands regulate the people—
if governance is harsh and violent,
commands rigid and sudden,
the people scatter and the state falters.

Speech elucidates *the Way*,
and *the Way* propagates the teaching—
if one clings to speech and resists *the Way*,
the teaching will not be implemented,
and *the Way* will not be understood.

**Explication:** This likens speech to the tools of *the Way*—
if one clings to words and resists the teaching,
there is no path to enlightenment,
and one will surely lose *the Way* while falling into confusion.

Thus, winds and rains cannot rage violently,
nor can speech be rigidly clung to.
The analogy of violent winds and sudden rains
illustrates that forgetting speech aligns with *the Way’s* natural order.

**Meaning:** Clinging to speech and teaching
leads to obstruction,
losing the ultimate principle of *the Way*,
and bewilderment in the teaching’s intent.

If one comprehends the purpose of *"signs and traps,"*
they will neither be trapped by fixation
nor harmed by violent excess,
but will manifest the virtues of dispersion and nourishment.

Who embodies this? Heaven and Earth.
Even Heaven and Earth cannot endure violence—
how much less can mortals?

**Annotation:** Heaven and Earth are vast,
yet violent and sudden acts harm things
and cannot persist—
how much more so for humans
who cling to speech and resist the teaching,
losing *the Way* and seeking enlightenment?
Can it be attained?

**Explication:** *"Who"* [孰]—
a rhetorical question asking who could endure violent winds and sudden rains.
The answer: Heaven and Earth.

Heaven and Earth, though vast,
cannot long sustain violent excess—
how much less can ordinary people,
clinging to speech and teaching,
be violent and sudden,
unable to let go and forget,
gradually reaching their limits,
yet still seeking enlightenment?
Can it be attained?

**Meaning:** The *Laozi* illustrates that violent winds and sudden rains cannot last,
using this as an analogy for those who govern, cultivate, and teach.

Fearful that people may not grasp this intent,
it poses the question and answers it itself,
thus clarifying the principle.»

The vastness of Heaven and Earth, though formed, cannot endure violent excess even for a single day. A ruler governing a kingdom, if violent, will harm the people. A practitioner of the *Dao*, if violent, will harm their own cultivation. All such actions are untenable.

Ordinary people, indulging their nature and unrestrained in their hearts, governing with wild ferocity and haste, clinging to speech and fixating on teaching, rigid and unadaptable, confined to a single corner—how could they achieve national prosperity and personal tranquility? It cannot be done.

Thus, those who pursue the *Dao* must not cling to speech and teaching.

**Explication:** *"From"* [从]—to follow, to align with.
The *Dao* is boundless and spontaneous, responding without fixed form. In things, it flows through without obstruction. Therefore, those who seek to embody this mystery and act in accordance must not fixate on anything. Hence, it says, *"those who pursue the *Dao*."*

**Meaning:** The Great *Dao* is harmonious and responsive. Through humility, gentleness, and yielding, one attains it. Rulers who are harsh, fierce, and violent, like the reckless winds and sudden rains, have already lost the *Dao*.

Thus, when a ruler governs with the *Dao* to guide the people, they follow what arises and respond to what moves—all things naturally conform. Great conduct brings great blessings; lesser conduct brings lesser blessings. The depth of response depends on one’s attunement, as seen below.

Those who embody the *Dao* are one with the *Dao*.
**Explication:** Those who follow the *Dao* in their actions are called *"those who embody the *Dao*."* They do not fixate; they transcend speech and teaching, becoming one with the *Dao*. Hence, *"one with the *Dao*."*

**Meaning:** The *Dao* is empty, effortless, serene, yielding, pure, and unadorned—these six are its essence. The empty is its unity; the effortless, its nature; the serene, its mirror; the yielding, its function; the pure and unadorned, its foundation. To embody these six is to embody the *Dao*. When a person’s actions align with the *Dao*, they follow without obstruction, transcend speech, and become one with the *Dao*.

Those who embody *virtue* are one with *virtue*.
**Explication:** *Virtue* is the name for the *Dao* in action. When one embodies the *Dao* without attachment to merit, their deeds align with the *Dao*’s function. Those who truly understand follow the *Dao*, not only liberating themselves but also benefiting all beings. The people receive their *virtue*, yet the practitioner forgets their own merit—all their deeds align with the *Dao*’s function. Hence, *"those who embody *virtue* are one with *virtue*."*

**Meaning:** *Virtue* is the *Dao* in action, thus it follows the *Dao*. The *"great conduct that brings great blessings"* refers to those who align with the *Dao* above. Those who practice moderately benefit all life, their merit extending to the realm, yet they do not reach the highest *Dao* but surpass conventional *ren* (benevolence) and *yi* (righteousness).
