The *Spring and Autumn Annals* (春秋) state: *The Dao/Way* generates and gives rise to *qi* (气), *qi* generates and then gives rise to *vital nourishment* (滋), *vital nourishment* generates and then gives rise to *forms* (象), *forms* generate and then give rise to *numbers* (数). From this, the art of reckoning flourishes.

To comprehend the *measures of Heaven and Earth* (天地之度), to discern the *categories of things* (品物之数), to examine the *transformations of yin and yang* (阴阳之变), to fathom the *origins of music and calendar* (律历之元)—all these require reckoning to determine their excess or deficiency. Thus, the general principles of reckoning include *numbers* and *measures*, *quantities* and *weights*.

Numbers begin from *one* to *ten*, *ten* to *hundred*, *thousand* to *ten thousand*, *ten thousand* to *hundred million*, *hundred million* to *trillion*, *trillion* to *quadrillion*, *quadrillion* to *quintillion*, *quintillion* to *sextillion*, *sextillion* to *septillion*, *septillion* to *octillion*, *octillion* to *nonillion*, *nonillion* to *decillion*. In reckoning, *ten* is the point of variation for lower numbers, *ten thousand* for middle numbers, and *ten thousand ten thousand* for higher numbers.

Measures begin with the *inch* (忽), ten *inch* make a *sī* (丝), ten *sī* make a *lín* (厘), ten *lín* make a *háo* (毫), ten *háo* make a *fēn* (分), ten *fēn* make a *cùn* (寸), ten *cùn* make a *shǐ* (尺), ten *shǐ* make a *zhàng* (丈). Three *shǐ* make a *kuǐ* (跬), six *shǐ* make a *bù* (步), seven *shǐ* make a *rèn* (仞), eight *shǐ* make a *xún* (寻), double *xún* makes a *cháng* (常), three hundred *bù* make a *lǐ* (里), and two thousand nine hundred thirty-two *lǐ* make a *dù* (度).

Quantities begin with the *jī* (圭), six *millet grains* (粟) make a *jī*, ten *jī* make a *cuō* (抄), ten *cuō* make a *zuō* (撮), ten *zuō* make a *sháo* (勺), ten *sháo* make a *hé* (合), ten *hé* make a *shēng* (升), ten *shēng* make a *dǒu* (斗), ten *dǒu* make a *dàn* (石). Four *shēng* make a *dòu* (豆), four *dòu* make a *ōu* (瓯), four *ōu* make a *fǔ* (釜), four *fǔ* make a *zhōng* (钟). Sixteen *dǒu* make a *yú* (庾), six *dǒu* four *shēng* make an *hú* (斛), sixteen *dǒu* also make a *sǒu* (薮), and sixteen *hú* make a *bǐng* (秉). The *Book of Rites on Plenary Tributes* (聘礼) further states: ten *dǒu* is an *hú*, sixteen *dǒu* is a *sǒu*, and ten *sǒu* is a *bǐng*. Zheng Xuan (郑玄) also says: a *dǒu* with two *shēng* is an *hú*.

Weights begin with the *glutinous millet grain* (黍), ten *pí* (黍) make a *lěi* (累), ten *lěi* make a *zhū* (铢), twenty-four *zhū* make a *liǎng* (两), six *zhū* make a *fēn* (分), sixteen *liǎng* make a *jīn* (斤), thirty *jīn* make a *jūn* (钧), four *jūn* make a *shuò* (硕), and twenty *liǎng* make a *yì* (镒).

These four categories of reckoning are the methods of calculation used among people. The grandest reckoning measures Heaven and Earth, examines yin and yang—*creation* (造化) cannot conceal its mechanisms, and *spirits* (鬼神) cannot evade its numbers.

If those who cultivate the *Dao/Way* (修道之士) do not calculate divergent gates (不计异门) but merely uphold *oneness* (守一), why would they need calculation techniques (计术)?

*Oneness* (一) is the *Dao/Way* (道), the most noble and without pair. *Oneness* without *duality* (不二) is the origin of all transformations (万化之首), and nothing does not arise from it. Heaven attains *oneness* and thus achieves clarity (清), Earth attains *oneness* and thus achieves tranquility (宁). The elusive *phenomena of yin and yang* (恍惚之象) and the profound essence of the *Dao/Way* (杳冥之精) are all referred to as *oneness*.

The *sage* (圣人) embraces *oneness* to govern the world (法天下), the *perfected one* (至人) attains *oneness* to ascend to the heavens (升云天). Thus, *oneness* can preserve and can vanish, can obscure and can shine, can be round and can be square, can be soft and can be hard.

The thirsty seek *oneness*, and *oneness* grants them a ladle (桨). The hungry seek *oneness*, and *oneness* grants them grain (粮). By guarding *oneness*, one attains completion (守一以成). The *Dao/Way* is thus *virtuous calculation*—it does not rely on reckoning tools yet is inherently virtuous.

**Virtuous closure lacks gates and keys yet cannot be opened** (善闭无关键而不可开):
**Commentary:** When one does not calculate divergent gates, the *desire-heart* (欲心) naturally closes.

*Horizontal* (横) is called *gates* (关), *vertical* (竖) is called *keys* (键). *Virtuous conduct* (善行) and *virtuous speech* (善言) are without attachment or obstruction (不耽不滞), the mind is clear and pure (心照清净), and no dust of phenomena arises. Hence it is said: *Virtuous closure*, though lacking gates and keys, cannot be opened.

Thus it is said: *Virtuous closure lacks gates and keys yet cannot be opened*. The meaning is: gates and keys are established to limit what is *internal* and *external*. The *Appendix to the Book of Changes* (易□系) states: "Double gates and striking the *gè* (柝) to await violent guests," meaning gates and keys restrict and regulate opening and closing.

If a state practices *virtuous closure*, then it harmonizes with the *mysterious transformation* (玄化), achieving great unity (大同) near and far (遐迩). There are no external weapons (干戈), no frontier alarms (烽燧), and no need for gates or barriers (关堑) yet no one invades or encroaches. When the world follows the *Dao/Way*, the virtue lies in the four quarters (四夷)—this is the case.

If a state does not practice *virtuous closure*, then its four borders are fortified with ramparts (四郊多垒), and it raises armies to weary the land (厌境兴师). Though it has the natural defenses of mountains and rivers (山川之险) and the strongholds of gates and barriers (关防之固), its guardianship is not rooted in *virtue* (守之非德), conflicts arise within its walls (衅生墙庑), enemies emerge from within (敌起舟中). Though it has gates and barriers, none can control them. How could this be called *virtuous closure*?

Those who practice *virtuous cultivation* (善修行) guard the *true essence* (真), embrace *oneness* (抱一), have no desires nor schemes (无欲无营), and know that all dharma are *gates* (万法之门), marking the stages of cultivation (阶修之渐). They are not obstructed by dharma, nor attached to speech, do not calculate divergent gates, nor seek broad knowledge. They close the *three gates* (三关) and naturally attain stillness (闭而自静), dispel all thoughts (祛众念) and naturally find peace (而自安). Sensual pleasures cannot deceive their hearts, and noble titles cannot stir their ambitions. This is *virtuous closure*—how could it be opened?

The *virtuous knot* is tied without cords or bonds, yet cannot be undone.
**Note:** When one fully realizes true nature, it is originally rooted in emptiness and forgetting. If one can empty and forget, then the heart aligns with the Dao. Though no cords or bonds restrain it, how could it be undone and scattered?

**Culling:** This illustrates that those who practice *virtuous closure* align their hearts with the Dao.

*Knot* means *to bind*; *cord* means *rope*; *bond* means *to restrain*; *undone* means *scattered*.

Those who practice *sitting-forgetting* and abandon illumination, deeply resonating with the Dao’s source, are able to remain unentangled in all dharma. Binding their hearts to this, it is said to be *virtuous knotting*.

Those who use cords and bonds—when the cords slacken, the bonds are undone. But when the Dao binds, the heart grows still, and the Dao becomes profound. Even as myriad afflictions arise, one remains utterly unstained. Though no cords or bonds restrain it, how could it be undone and scattered? Thus it is said: *The virtuous knot has no cords or bonds, yet cannot be undone.*

**Meaning:** The knots of cords and bonds can be undone and scattered—this is the common way of the world. Binding people’s hearts may bring separation or union—this is the common way of human relations. But the *virtuous knotting* of governing the realm is like the *virtue* of Heaven, covering all things without exception; like the *benevolence* of Earth, bearing all things without exception; like the clarity of the Sun, illuminating all things without exception; like the fluidity of Water, nourishing all things without exception. Then the hearts of the myriad realms and the countless people can be knotted together, yet cannot be scattered.

Those who do not practice *virtuous knotting* rule with threats, enforce with decrees, constrain with laws, and coerce with force. Though people may fear them, the knot is only temporarily tied and will scatter. Once scattered, even if lured with rewards, enticed with benefits, honored with titles, or elevated with rank, the scattered heart cannot be knotted again.

For those bewildered in *self-cultivation*, they seek extensive knowledge, pursue esoteric arts and divinations, and though their learning increases daily, their hearts scatter more. Though they strive for simplicity to knit their hearts, it cannot be achieved.

Those who practice *virtuous cultivation* abandon all thoughts, maintain single-mindedness, remain still in alignment with the Dao, and merge with the true. No afflictions can intrude, no illusions can seduce. This *virtuous knotting*—how could it be undone?

Thus, the Sage always practices *virtuous salvation*, and so there are none abandoned.

**Culling:** *Thus* introduces what follows to clarify what precedes. Though the Sage’s heart is profound and tranquil, their teachings flow freely. They always employ the *Five Virtues* to save others, ensuring their words are naturally clear and reach the great compassion of equality, without partiality or exclusion. All people are guided with *virtuous inducement*, hence it is said: *The Sage always practices virtuous salvation, and so there are none abandoned.*

**Meaning:** The Sage refers to those who embody the Dao. The Sage always broadly induces people with *virtuous teachings*, and those who hear the Dharma all awaken to understanding. According to their depth, they inevitably gain benefit. The gates of awakening are numerous—some awaken through speech, some through teaching, some through scriptures, some through seeing forms. The paths to awakening vary, and the methods of inducement are many. With great compassion and equanimity, without favor or aversion, they guide each being into the Dharma gate. Once entered, they abandon evil and become virtuous. All become virtuous, and so there are none abandoned.

Those who are abandoned are those who commit evil deeds and harbor harmful intentions. When harmed, they become enemies. If evil is manifest, people may punish them. If evil is hidden, spirits may punish them. Those punished by humans and spirits are abandoned by both.

Now, if all practice virtuous deeds, free from evil and blame, all transform into virtuous beings—how could there be abandonment?

The *Five Virtues* refer to virtuous speech, virtuous action, virtuous calculation, virtuous closure, and virtuous knotting. The *Analects* states: *Confucius was skilled in inducing others.* *Inducing* means guiding and leading. He always practiced *virtuous salvation*, and so there were none abandoned.

**Note:** Thus, the Sage always employs these five *virtuous teachings* to guide others, and so there are none abandoned.

**Culling:** *Things* encompasses both sentient and insentient beings. By saving people with virtuous teachings, none are abandoned. By saving things with benevolent intent, none are abandoned. Thus, all living beings flourish naturally, without withering or injury. Hence it is said: *The Sage always practices virtuous salvation, and so there are none abandoned.*

**Meaning:** The Sage who embodies the Dao teaches the five *virtues* to guide people toward goodness, and all transform into virtuous beings, so there are none abandoned. Again, through non-action and non-doing, they do not labor over things, and all fulfill their nature without harm or injury—extending even to pigs and fish, benefiting grass and trees. All transform into virtuous beings, causing no harm to things. This illustrates the Sage’s salvation of things. Since nothing is harmed and all follow their natural course, it is said there are none abandoned. This is called *cloaked clarity.*

**Note:** *Cloaked* refers to subtle, hidden use.

The five *virtues* lie in forgetting and letting go, and forgetting and letting go leaves no trace, hence *cloaked use.* Cloaked use leads to awakening, hence *clarity.*

**Culling:** *Cloaked* means subtle use; *clarity* means awakening. Virtuous deeds save others through forgetting and letting go. If one clings to teachings or boasts of them, traces will remain. Though the Sage always practices virtuous salvation, they ultimately ensure the mind is unobstructed. Thus, through subtle use, one attains awakening, hence it is called *cloaked clarity.*

**Meaning:** The Sage’s intent lies in subtly employing virtuous deeds, achieving awakening without obstruction, leaving no traces—this is called *cloaked clarity.*

Again, *cloaked* means *continuation.* The human mind’s inherent nature is originally clear and pure, but obscured by defilements, veiling its true nature. Now, through the five *virtues*, the heart is internally purified, and true nature shines forth as originally. With wisdom’s illumination restored, one must constantly practice virtuous salvation, generating no false defilements. Continuing this luminous wisdom, preventing it from being obscured by darkness, without boasting of traces or clinging to conventions—this is *cloaked clarity.*

Thus, the virtuous person is the teacher of the non-virtuous.

**Annotation:** Teacher (*师*), here means **Dao/Way** (*法*).

The virtuous person, detached from all attachments and defilements, possesses a pure heart. Without obstruction in the Dao/Way (*於法无滞*), their teachings flow naturally and harmoniously. Taking water as an analogy: when objects approach, it reflects them. What it reflects are their forms and images (*照形而有象*), yet the water itself remains unperturbed, without clinging to any image (*能鉴者见象而无心*). The virtuous person’s wisdom is just like this—thus, they can serve as the Dao/Way (*师法*) for the non-virtuous.

**Explication:** The one who does not commit evil deeds, abides by the Dao/Way (*法*), follows the natural order (*循常*), harms neither others nor things (*无侵於人，无伤於物*)—this is the virtuous person. When people practice virtue, Heaven and Earth cherish them, and the divine spirits (*神明*) protect them. Though they do not study the Dao/Way and yet their actions align with it (*不习道而行合於道*), though they do not explicitly know the Dao/Way and yet their hearts resonate with it (*不明法而心契於法*), they harm neither things nor people, and thus things and people do not harm them (*不伤於物，物亦不伤之；不害於人，人亦不害之*). In this way, their every movement and stillness, their every action and reaction, consistently bring forth sincerity and good fortune (*常获贞吉*). The wicked, admiring their steadfast virtue and fortune, should also transform and become virtuous—thus, the virtuous can indeed be the teacher of the non-virtuous.

The *Spring and Autumn Annals* (*《春秋》*) records: When the people of Zheng gathered at the village school to discuss their rulers, Duke Mu of Zheng (*郑穆公*) wished to destroy the school for its criticism of governance. Child Xuan (*子产*) replied: If I were to visit it daily, hearing of the rulers’ virtues and faults (*闻执政之善否*), I would follow what is good (*其所善者，吾则行之*) and reform what is evil (*其所恶者，吾则改之*). This is my teacher (*是吾师也*).

The *Spring and Autumn Annals* further records: **"How could one destroy it? I have heard that loyalty and virtue diminish grievances, but I have never heard of using coercive power to prevent them. If one were to abruptly suppress it, that would be like blocking a river. When a river is dammed, the flooding will be severe, and it cannot be contained. It is better to allow a small breach so that it may flow naturally."** Thus, Child Xuan (*羊舌职*) rejoiced in his words.

Confucius said: **"People say that Child Xuan is not benevolent (*仁*), but I do not believe it."**

The *Book of Documents* (*《书》*) states: **"Those who can find their own teachers are sages (*圣人*)."** For a teacher is one who provides a model to follow (*有法可范之*).

The *Records of Learning* (*《学记》*) says: **"When one is settled in their studies and close to their teacher, when they delight in their companions and trust in the Dao/Way, even if they depart from their teacher’s guidance, they will not stray far. But if one conceals their learning while resenting their teacher, or if they perceive their difficulties without understanding their benefits, that is the opposite (*#1*)."**

The gentleman knows how teaching flourishes and how it perishes, and only then can they truly be a teacher to others. To study alone without companions is to be narrow and ill-informed; thus, selecting a teacher must be done with utmost care.

The *Spring and Autumn Annals*’s commentary states: **"I have heard that when Yu (*禹*) raised the virtuous, the non-virtuous were driven far away."** The *Book of Songs* (*《诗》*) says: **"Trembling and cautious, as if standing at the edge of a deep abyss, as if walking on thin ice. This is the virtuous in high position (*善人在上*), for when the virtuous lead, the state prospers without misfortune (*国无幸人*). The proliferation of the non-virtuous brings ruin to the state (*人之多幸，国之不幸*)—this is what is meant by the absence of the virtuous."**

Thus, the virtuous are the treasures of the state (*邦国之宝*), not merely teachers. The non-virtuous are the raw materials (*资*) of the virtuous.

**Annotation:** Teacher (*师*) refers to the law (*法*); raw materials (*资*) means to take (*取*). The virtuous can be emulated as teachers, while the non-virtuous can be utilized for service.

**Explication:** Raw materials (*资*) means to take (*取*). Fire has its heat, and cold and warmth depend on it. One who diligently practices the Dao/Way must rely on masters and craftsmen (*资宗匠*). If they take pleasure in the virtues of their elders, they must also submit to the labor of their juniors. Thus, the non-virtuous can be taken and employed by the virtuous.

The commentary further states: **"The virtuous, through their virtuous conduct, can transform the non-virtuous, who will then admire and submit to them, serving as their laborers."** The *Analects* (*《论语》*) says: **"When there is work, the juniors serve with labor (*有事弟子服其劳*)."** The elders are the father, elder brothers, teachers, and leaders (*先生者，父兄师长也*).** Therefore, the juniors serve their teachers with reverence and follow their instruction (*事师，服膺从教也*).

In a person’s conduct, there are three reverences (*三尊*).** They serve their parents with filial piety (*事父母以孝*), their ruler with loyalty (*事君以忠*), and their teacher with respect (*事师以敬*).** The body and its limbs are given by their parents (*身体发肤，父母生之*);** virtue, power, rituals, and music are taught by their teacher (*道德礼乐，师以教之*);** and rank, honors, and status are bestowed by their ruler (*爵禄品位，君以荣之*).** Even if the Dao/Way exists, one may still seek instruction from a teacher without fixed reverence—any ritual of requesting benefit will naturally evoke the threefold respect.

If one does not honor their teacher, they will not cherish their raw materials. **Annotation:** This chapter’s profound meaning lies in the teaching of mutual forgetting. If one retains the distinction between teacher and student, that is not the ultimate goal. Now, honoring the teacher is to preserve the relationship of learning. Once that relationship is dissolved, there is nothing left to honor. Cherishing raw materials is to preserve the relationship of teaching. When teaching is forgotten, one no longer cherishes raw materials. To honor and cherish while forgetting both is for the Dao/Way to naturally transform. Though it seems like great confusion (*大迷*), this is called the essential mystery (*要妙*).**

**Annotation:** Forgetting both teacher and student is called *mysterious virtue* (*玄德*). The common mind does not understand this, deeming it great confusion. Observed through the Dao/Way, it is called the essential (*要*).**

**Explication:** In the early stages of cultivation, one retains the duality of teacher and student, unable yet to forget the spoken teachings. Therefore, they honor and cherish their teacher and raw materials. If one attains true insight into the path of practice, then study becomes effortless. Once the names of teacher and student are lost, the distinctions of honor and cherishment vanish.

The commentary states: **"Those in the early stages of cultivation—meaning those who awaken from the mundane and turn toward the true Dao/Way, abandoning the mundane for faith in the path—are called those of the initial stage. The *Sutra of the Original Source* (*《本际经》*) says: 'For those who study, the initial ten practices form the steps. Like a person ascending a ladder, from the first rung to the second, up to the top, those ascending must first practice these ten methods before entering deep meditation.

1. Those of the initial stage first cultivate wholesome desires (*善欲*), with a heart that delights in good and seeks it, thus able to advance.
2. They associate with virtuous companions (*善友*), who guide their hearts, deepening their faith in the true Dao/Way.
3. They approach a wise teacher (*明师*), who possesses profound methods and can broadly proclaim them, revealing the essential techniques.
4. Having heard the true teachings, they accept and recite them.
5. They are able to leave home, practicing gentleness and humility, permanently severing worldly attachments, and freeing themselves from all shackles (*永断有为，离诸桎梏*).**"**

Sixth, they receive the true precepts (*正戒*), guarding body, speech, and mind.

Seventh, they retreat into secluded mountains and forests, dwelling alone in solitude, seeking to escape the clamor of the world and cultivate a tranquil mind (*寂静志*).

Eighth, they should reflect that the Great Dao/Way is the true *Dharma King* (*法王*), capable of delivering all beings, crossing the sea of birth and death, just as a shipmaster rescues the drowning.

Ninth, they should reflect that the scriptures are the wondrous medical prescriptions (*妙医方*), able to show all beings the remedies for their afflictions (*烦恼*).

Tenth, they should reflect that the *Dharma Master* (*法师*) is the true parent, skillfully giving birth to the *Dharma-body* (*法身*) and the wisdom of life.

These ten methods form the stages of practice.

Those of the initial stage first cultivate the *Hīnayana* methods of gentle subjugation (*小乘柔伏之法*), then advance to the *Madhyamaka* methods of cultivation (*中乘进修之法*), and finally enter the *Mahayana* practice of insight and conduct (*大乘观行之法*).

Because of these methods, one should hold teachers in high regard.

The teacher is like a father.

Without a teacher, one cannot attain the Dao/Way.

Therefore, one should follow and attend to them, near or far, keeping them ever before the mind and eyes, never wavering for an instant, without any other distracting thoughts. Without a teacher, one cannot be enlightened; without a teacher, one cannot become transcendent (*不仙*).

Once one has attained self-realization, all learned forms and teachings are seen as empty.

All skillful means are beyond words.

Having understood the Great Dao/Way, one transcends both reverence and attachment.

Entering the gates of supreme mystery, one attains the realm of true constancy (*真常境*).

**Commentary:**
This chapter teaches the principle of letting go and forgetting.

Through gradual and sudden methods, it establishes stages.

When discussing ultimate realization, all teachings are empty.

Thus, earlier it speaks of honoring teachers and valuing teachings to show the path of cultivation.

Later, it speaks of neither honoring nor valuing, guiding one toward awakening and realization.

Therefore, the reason to honor the teacher is to uphold the forms of learning.

Once learning’s forms are seen as empty, there is nothing to honor.

The reason to value teachings is to uphold their forms.

When both teaching and learning are forgotten, there is no attachment.

When forms are forgotten, all traces vanish.

At first hearing, the common and unenlightened may not understand, clinging to learning and teachings, and thus deem this as great delusion.

Hence, Laozi’s measured words: *"Though the common may call this great delusion, in terms of the Dao/Way, this is called the supreme mystery."*

**Explanation:**
The teacher’s path and the interdependence of teacher and student are like this:

Jade is shaped into a vessel through polishing; humans awaken to the Dao/Way through the teacher.

It is said that in terms of teachings, there are methods of remembering and honoring the teacher, established to instruct people. Across ages, these precepts have varied, and those unskilled may temporarily rely on them for guidance.

Thus, the Son of Heaven performs the *Dingdian* ritual for the ancestral teacher, and the heir apparent visits the ancestral teacher at the Grand Academy—all to preserve the Dao/Way and pass it down.

Yet, from the perspective of ultimate insight, one forgets heaven and earth, forgets the self within, and forgets all distinctions between self and other—how much more so would one forget the limits of teacher and student?

As when *Nièqué* (*啮缺*) questioned *Bìyī* (*被衣*), who said:
*"Rectify your form, unify your gaze—*Heaven’s harmony* (*天和*) is near.
Concentrate your knowing, unify your measure—*the Spirit* will come to dwell.
Virtue will become your adornment, the Dao/Way your abode.
Your pupils will shine like those of a newborn calf, yet you will not seek its cause."

Before he finished speaking, *Nièqué* fell into deep sleep.
*Bìyī* rejoiced greatly, sang as he walked, and departed, saying:
*"Your form is withered like dead wood, your mind like ashes—
True and real knowing, not clinging to the past.
Obscure and indistinct, without thought, yet beyond counsel.
Who is this person?
He is one who, in the midst of transformation, alone achieves change."

At that moment, *Nièqué* had forgotten both his body and the heavens and earth—how much more so would he forget his teacher?

Thus, the principle of honoring and valuing teachers is fully realized.

In governing the realm, one does not establish virtue in people nor flaunt benevolence toward things.
The common folk live their daily lives without knowing it,
and naturally there is no reverence for teachers or valuing of teachings—
this aligns with the ancient Dao/Way of the unspoken.

Most do not understand; initially, this seems great delusion.
Yet when realized, it is indeed the supreme mystery.

*"Móu mò"* (*濡沬*)—this is Laozi’s response to Confucius in the *"Tian Yun"* (*天运*) chapter of the *Zhuangzi*.

**End of Volume Twenty-Three of *The Broad Explication of the Dao De Jing’s Sacred Meaning*.**

**Volume Twenty-Four: The Duke Guangcheng of Tang, Master Du Guangting’s Commentary.**

**#1** If it says *"difficult"* (*难*), it should be *"bitter"* (*苦*), as in the *Records of Rites* (*礼记*).

**Volume Twenty-Four: The Duke Guangcheng of Tang, Master Du Guangting’s Commentary**

**#28** *"Knowing Its Heroic Virtue"* (*知其雄章*)
**Commentary:** The previous chapter expounded that actions and words do not cling to fixed goodness; thus, it saved people. This chapter reveals that humility and yielding are the way, and virtue/power returns to its original simplicity. It first marks the three stages of knowing heroic virtue, showing that through practice, one gradually attains the ultimate. Then it speaks of simplicity and scattering in the next two lines, illustrating that attaining the ultimate must lead to fruition. Finally, it concludes with *"Great Measure"* (*大制*), discussing the sage’s governance and purpose in exploring its meaning.

**Meaning:** The previous chapter stated that neither clinging to goodness in actions nor goodness in words is the way to save people; saving people and things through such means is merely external assistance. This chapter emphasizes knowing heroic virtue and knowing purity to preserve harmony in one’s qi. Returning to simplicity and innocence is the key to success—internal cultivation’s essence. External actions manifest the Five Virtues; as stated above. Internal cultivation reaches the three stages of knowing—its ultimate state, as explained below. When cultivation returns to simplicity, one need not rigidly uphold simplicity to remain unshaken, then scattering and manifesting all differences to display the profound and boundless workings of the Dao, only the sage can govern this with perfect measure, without harm or injury.

Knowing its heroic virtue, upholding its yielding nature—this is the way to be the valley of the world.
**Commentary:** Knowing (*知*) means discernment. Heroic (*雄*) refers to rigidity and impetuosity. Yielding (*雌*) signifies gentleness and tranquility. Things value complete harmony; methods seek the middle Dao/Way. Rigidity (*雄*) is excessive, yielding (*雌*) is too weak; neither aligns with the proper path of virtuous action. One must follow deep sincerity as the guiding principle. Thus, knowing its rigidity and impetuosity, one must uphold its gentleness and tranquility. Upholding gentleness and tranquility also requires knowing rigidity and impetuosity. If one upholds yielding but does not know heroic virtue, it leads to ruin; ruin obstructs action. Therefore, one must maintain precepts and uphold yielding. To uphold yielding gentleness is to embody the virtue of humility, which all things naturally gravitate toward—like water flowing to valleys.

**Meaning:** In internal cultivation, discerning rigidity and impetuosity, one knows they must lead to ruin and injury. Thus, one must govern them with the Dao of yielding gentleness. *Excessive* (*亢*) means extreme; *sincere* (*笃*) means thick or profound. If one’s nature is rigid and impetuous, it tends toward extremes; extremes bring ruin and excess. Therefore, one must cultivate a profound and sincere gentle nature to govern the heroic and rigid disposition, thereby avoiding extreme ruin. A valley is where all streams converge because of its humble and lowly nature. If a person is humble and lowly, things gravitate toward them; if the earth is humble and lowly, water gathers. In the upper simplicity, there is the Dao of the One Yielding, and also the methods of the Three Flees and Five Yieldings—all of which weaken the will, harmonize the spirit, and lead to longevity.

To govern the realm with humility and tranquility means all things follow in accord, like water rushing to valleys. To be the valley of the world is to never depart from constant virtue/power, returning once more to the innocence of the infant.

**Annotation:** Heroic virtue (*雄*) suffers from excessive vigor; thus, knowing its heroic nature means one must uphold yielding gentleness. Humility attracts things, making one the valley of the world. Constant virtue/power does not scatter, embracing Dao and harmony, and returning to the innocent actions of the infant.

**Commentary:** Knowing heroic virtue and upholding yielding nature is the path of virtuous action, which all things gravitate toward—making one the valley of the world. Those who can do this will never see their constant virtue/power depart or scatter. If virtue/power does not scatter, it is complete harmony. Those with complete harmony think little and desire little, their stillness unmarked—like an infant. Hence it says, *"returning once more to the innocence of the infant."*

**Meaning:** Governing the realm lies in humility and tranquility; governing oneself lies in yielding gentleness. If all things follow in accord and all virtues converge, one will constantly enjoy their blessings and preserve their body. The infant represents one who has not yet distinguished good from evil or right from wrong, whose harmony in qi is always complete, and whose stillness is profound and concentrated—an analogy for a virtuous ruler or one who embodies the Dao. Such virtue aligns with the true Dao. In governing oneself, the spirit converges; in governing the realm, the people gather in harmony.

「Knowing its clarity, preserving its obscurity, one becomes the model for all under Heaven.

**Commentary:** Clarity is illumination. Obscurity is dimness. Model is law/pattern.
He who can preserve the gentle stillness of the female principle will have virtue and conduct made manifest.
Though virtue be manifest, he does not boast before others.
When in a state of dimness, he guards his simplicity and harmony.
If one can thus act, he may be taken as the model for all under Heaven.

**Meaning:** A ruler’s unique insight is his virtue; the Way’s luminous power is its conduct.
Both must be like the dim and obscure—unassuming, not vainglorious—
Then the common folk will flock to him, his simplicity and harmony sufficient within.
Thus he becomes the model for all under Heaven.
In the *Records of the Grand Historian*, the Old Master told Confucius:
“A gentleman of great virtue appears as if foolish”—this is it.
He who has virtue yet does not boast, who has insight yet does not display it,
Not only fills his inner being with the Way’s conduct,
But also attains the harmony of sound and light.

To be the model for all under Heaven,
One’s virtue must never falter,
And returns once more to the boundless.

**Commentary:** He who can preserve the gentle stillness,
His virtue will never scatter.
Though virtue be clear, he must act as if obscure,
Thus he becomes the model for all under Heaven.
Virtue applied without fail,
Never deviates or errs—its use is boundless.
Hence it returns once more to the boundless.

**Translation:** Falter is error. Boundless is the utmost.
Knowing clarity yet preserving obscurity—this is called virtue complete.
The man of complete virtue may be the model for all under Heaven.
Then the true virtue, ever constant,
Follows and applies without fail—
Its application never errs, its use is boundless.
Hence it says, *returns once more to the boundless.*

**Meaning:** In ruling and in the Way,
He veils his brilliance outwardly,
Yet accumulates his virtue within.
Once simplicity and harmony are established,
All under Heaven transforms accordingly.
For the realm, the sage’s virtue is boundless;
For oneself, longevity is without end.
Knowing its glory, preserving its humiliation,
One becomes the valley for all under Heaven.

**Commentary:** Glory is honor and elevation.
Humiliation is lowliness and disgrace.
He who is the model for all under Heaven
Has his virtue in a state of honor and elevation.
Though virtue be honored and exalted,
He must always guard against humiliation,
Using harmony as his measure—
All things are contained without exclusion.
Like an empty valley, where all things come and are answered,
Hence it says, *he is the valley for all under Heaven.*

**Meaning:** A ruler’s wealth is the eightfold perfection,
His dominion extends to the ninefold boundaries—
This is his honor and elevation.
Yet he calls himself “lonely and bereaved,” not the valley—
This is his humiliation.
The titles he assumes are the ancient institutions.
If one can govern while in chaos,
Reside in peace yet fear danger,
Be ever vigilant and humble,
Daytime earnest and nighttime watchful,
Then his virtue is vast, his body broad—
Like an empty valley.

The man of the Way outwardly displays his virtue’s praise,
Yet inwardly guards his humility and gentleness,
Like Gang Sang who avoided the mountain and feared the mountain shrine.
Zhuangzi sighed over the swollen, useless tree—
Its material and virtue were not displayed,
Yet its heart was empty, its virtue complete—
Like an empty valley.

To be the valley for all under Heaven,
His virtue is ever sufficient,
And returns once more to the uncarved.

**Commentary:** Though virtue be honored and exalted,
He must always guard against humiliation.
Things respond as they sense him—
Like a valley echoing sound.
Empty yet receptive without end,
His virtue is whole and complete.
Thus he returns once more to the Dao.

**Translation:** Uncarved is the Dao.
Empty yet receptive, answering all things—
Like the spirit of the valley,
The true virtue is whole and complete.
Whole, it returns once more to the uncarved.

The Dao is the body of virtue;
Virtue is the application of the Dao.
Speaking of its application, it says, *“His virtue is ever sufficient.”*
Speaking of its body, it says, *“Returns once more to the uncarved.”*
Returning to the uncarved, its wondrous origin is pure and clear;
Ever-sufficient virtue follows and applies without end.
Is there not the utmost harmony under Heaven,
Who could join with this?

**Meanary:** Once rich in virtue, he aligns with the Dao.
The Dao as virtue’s body is tranquil and without action.
Virtue as the Dao’s application is active and transformative.
A ruler, with the fivefold harmonies of governance,
Lures the people toward non-action,
With the boundless virtue of broad relief,
Accumulating merit to align with the Dao.
Hence it says, *“Returns once more to the uncarved.”*

The Dao is without action yet does nothing it does not act upon,
Generating all things, responding to change without measure.
Hence it is called the utmost harmony under Heaven.
*The Book of Changes* says:
“That which is above form is called the Dao;
Pushing it forth to action is called harmony.”
This is it.

In the sage’s governance of the realm,
And the noble man’s cultivation of himself,
They must know that the three—heroic strength, clarity, and glory—
Are not lasting benefits,
But rather grasp the three conducts—gentleness, obscurity, and humiliation—to regulate them.
Then the fivefold harmonies outwardly transform the people,
While these three conducts inwardly refine oneself—
The people transformed, the Way grows ever broader;
The self refined, virtue flourishes ever more.
The Way broadens, virtue flourishes—
This is the utmost essential in governing the realm and oneself.

The uncarved disperses and becomes the vessel;
The sage employs it, and it becomes the official and leader.

**Commentary:** Containing virtue within, harmonized,
It returns once more to the uncarved.
Ever-sufficient virtue applied,
Disperses and becomes the vessel.
Once involved in form and function,
There must be distinctions of fine and coarse.
Hence the sage employs it,
And it becomes the chief of all materials and officials.

**Translation:** Vessel is form and function.
Self-aware of heroic strength below,
Discussing nature and refining virtue,
Returning, it once more aligns with the Dao.
This says, *“The uncarved disperses and becomes the vessel,”*
Illuminating that virtue complete aligns with the Dao—
Then he can follow and apply.
Applied, its traces are coarse, involved in form and function,
Hence it says, *“The uncarved disperses and becomes the vessel.”*
The sage’s broad relief,
Becomes the chief of all materials and officials.

**Meaning:** That which is above form is called the Dao;
That which is below form is called the vessel.
The Dao is the void—
Not the visible or tangible essence,
But the wondrous origin of emptiness and tranquility.
The vessel involves the having—
The knowable and describable application,
Not the obstructed or fixed form.
The sage governs all under Heaven,
Employs the people and their virtues,
Entrusting them to shepherds,
Sharing the profound winds together,
To broaden the Way’s transformation.
Hence it says, *“Becomes the official and leader.”*

The vastness of the four seas,
The multitude of the myriad folk,
Cannot be governed by one man alone—
Thus officials, teachers, and leaders are established,
Each assuming their proper tasks.
In ancient times, Tang and Yu established only a hundred officials;
The Xia, Shang, Zhou, and Han increased them further,
Appointing men by their virtue,
Assigning them tasks by their abilities,
Each fitting their vessel—
And thus all directions were governed.»

「If one is a practitioner of the Dao/Way, then they spread virtue and bestow kindness,
rescue beings and establish merit—
just as vessels serve their function,
to benefit the people.

To govern a state, one employs talent and transforms beings;
to practice the Dao/Way, one applies merit and aids humanity—
this aligns with the pure transformation of the Dao/Way.

The *Shàngshū* says, *“Learn from the ancients to enter office,”*
and the *Zuǒzhuàn* states, *“One who governs the people without covetous intent.”*
This is the principle.

In the autumn of the seventeenth year of Duke Zhāo of *Chūnqiū*,
the Lord of Tán came to Lǔ and spoke to Zhāo:
“The Yellow Emperor appointed officials by the *yún* (cloud),
the Yán Emperor by fire,
Gònggōng by water,
Tàihào by dragons,
Shàohào by birds—
using the *fèng* (august) bird as the Keeper of the Calendar,
the *xuānnǐao* (dark) bird as the Keeper of the Seasons,
Bózhào as the Keeper of the Solstices,
Qīngniǎo as the Keeper of the Opening,
Dānniǎo as the Keeper of the Closing,
and Zhùjiū as the Grand Minister,
Suījiū as the Marshal,
Shījiū as the Director of Works,
Shuǎngjiū as the Censor,
and Hújiū as the Keeper of Affairs.
The five *jiū* (birds) were entrusted to govern the people,
the five *zhì* (pheasants) were appointed as the five Craftsmen,
and the nine *hù* (helpers) as the nine Agricultural Overseers.
*Hù* means “to restrain,”
restraining the people so they do not indulge in excess.”

Since the time of *Zhuānxū*,
the mandate could not be sustained at a distance—
thus, the role of “People’s Teacher” was established,
and the people themselves were appointed as officials.
The division of offices to restrain and guide
is an ancient practice.

It is for the purpose of proclaiming the Dao/Way and enacting virtue,
to teach the people.
If officials are not the right men,
harm befalls the beings.
How can one entrust them lightly?
The *Shū* says: *“Offices need not be complete; only their people matter.”*
This is its meaning.

Hence, the “Great Measure” does not involve cutting or harming.
**Annotation:** The sage employs the Dao/Way,
the Great Measure governs all beings—
warm like spring, beneficent without ceasing,
animals and plants all flourish,
yet nothing is cut or harmed.
**Commentary:** This illustrates the sage’s use of the Dao/Way.

The sage’s virtue is complete;
the Great Measure governs all things—
following the application of Heaven and Earth,
bestowing the恩 of rain and dew,
each attaining its harmony,
unaware of its force.
The sage ensures that all moving and rooted beings flourish,
yet nothing is cut or harmed for their own use.
Hence it says, *“The Great Measure does not involve cutting.”*

**Meaning:** The holy sovereign rules the extremes,
governing all directions.
Their virtue covers all beings,
each attaining its nature.
Thus, animals and plants,
sentient and insentient,
grow and complete themselves naturally—
neither slaughtered nor cut.
In the age of *Xuāndé* (Mysterious Virtue),
the *Tàishàng* (Supreme Sage) does not speak or transform,
only remaining serene and still,
while those below recognize their sovereign above
yet do not hear the laws of their governance.
This is what is meant by:
*“The Great Measure is the sovereign ruler,
yet does not involve cutting or harming.”*

A practitioner of the Dao/Way
does not obsess over the *zhù* (sacrificial rites),
nor toil endlessly over *shùyàn* (ritual mouth-washing);
without action or desire,
they preserve their natural harmony—
and thus may ascend to the Dao/Way.

**Chapter Twenty-Nine: *“On Those Who Would Seize the World”***

**Commentary:** The previous chapter expounds on the conduct of humility,
demonstrating that enduring virtue must return to simplicity.
This chapter reveals that arrogance and grasping will inevitably fail—
thus, the divine vessel cannot be forced.

First, the six sentences under *“On those who would seize”* establish
the reality that power has its proper place,
warning against deceitful and turbulent officials.
Next, *“The one who grasps”* shows that numerical cycles do not interfere with the constant,
admonishing the licentious and dissolute sovereign.
Hence, the following passage distinguishes the patterns of dependence and subjugation—
thus, the sage warns the ruler against extreme tyranny.

**Meaning:** The previous section clarified how the sage governs all beings.
Here, one fears that officials may disrupt the constant,
so this passage is raised to warn against their deceitful schemes.
Again, one worries that a ruler may arrogantly claim divine authority,
oppressing the people—
thus, it is shown that dependence and subjugation are not constant,
and that ruin lies in departing from virtue.
Avoiding extravagance and excess,
one may preserve the enduring mandate.

Hence it says:
*“To warn against deceitful officials below,
and to admonish the licentious sovereign above.”*

If one seeks to seize the world and do so,
I see that they cannot achieve it.

**Annotation:** The world is the position of the great treasure.
Those who practice the Dao/Way must await the numerical cycles aligning with their person.
If it is one who disrupts the order by force,
seeking to seize the world as their sovereign—
the Old Master warns: *“I see that they cannot achieve it.”*
**Commentary:** The world is the position of the great treasure.
The august Heaven commands the Emperor,
the Great Measure governs all beings—
this must await the numerical cycles aligning with their person,
before they rule over the ten thousand realms.
Yet deceitful rebels and violent men,
who seek to seize the world by force and claim sovereignty,
will have neither time to exterminate nor hope to inherit Heaven’s mandate.
Thus, the Old Master warns:
*“I see that such a person will inevitably fail in their undertaking.”*
*Yǐ* is a grammatical particle.

**Meaning:** Under all Heaven,
the sovereign governs.
The sovereign’s position is granted by Heaven’s command,
where numerical cycles converge,
the will of Heaven responds,
and the people’s aspirations align—
only then may they rule the four seas,
nurture all beings,
and serve as sovereign.

All have inherited traditions of accumulated virtue,
and borne extraordinary omens in their persons.
*Yùxī* (Great Track) was born from the divine turtle’s tracks,
and *Yánhuáng* (Flame Sovereign) was conceived by the dragon’s presence.
*Xuānyuán* (Yellow Emperor) was surrounded by lightning as he circled the Dipper,
and *Shàohào* (Minor Sovereign) was adorned with starry hues flowing like a rainbow.
*Zhuānxū* (High-Sin) and *Gāoxīn* (High-Xin) were endowed with wisdom and sagacity,
while *Yáo* (Emperor Yao) and *Shùn* (Emperor Shun) exhibited divine omens beyond mortal kind.
*Yáo*’s fire virtue manifested in the red dragon,
and *Shùn*’s earthly virtue in the rainbow’s auspicious sign.
The moon’s essence bestowed upon *Yǔ* (Yü the Great),
and the swallow’s egg upon *Tāng* (Tang of Shang).
Purple vapor gathered over *Yángshān* (Yang Mountain),
and red light shone upon the Han dynasty—
these are all cases of extraordinary omens in their persons.

Accumulating mysterious merit, *Huángxuán* (Yellow Emperor) received the mandate,
and observing the past’s achievements, *Zhuānxū* (High-Sin) was confirmed in his succession.
The Yellow Emperor’s lineage endured seventeen generations before *Yīntāng* (Tang of Yin) inherited the blessing,
and *Hòujì* (Later Ji) flourished in the thirteenth generation after *Xībó* (Western King).
These are all cases of accumulated merit over generations.

Some are born with divine holiness,
others emerge speaking with wisdom—
with a sun-like mark on their foreheads,
or dragon-like features and crane-like steps.
With double pupils and eight colors,
or reversed feathers and strange fur.
With a jade dipper across their bodies,
or scales covering their forms.
Some remain whole within prison walls,
others escape from ditches and sewers—
yet still respond to Heaven’s omens,
their virtue harmonizing with the people’s wishes,
before they drive noble steeds,
command great heroes,
rescue the drowning,
save the burning,
and bring prosperity to the common folk,
thus fulfilling the mandate to expand the imperial enterprise.
This may be called the fulfillment of all beings’ hopes,
where numerical cycles align with their person.»

The *Shan Shu* declares: *"Heaven’s numerical cycles rest upon your person alone."*

If one lacks divine appointment, if talent is not Heaven-endowed,
if accumulated virtue does not shine through ancestors,
if no strange omens herald their birth—
relying on mere brute strength,
harboring the heart of a wolf,
using sly allure to seize state power,
exploiting favoritism to covet the sacred throne—
plotting to question the cauldron’s fate,
scheming to steal the imperial seals—
then Wang Mang and Dong Zhuo meet their doom in slaughter,
while Hou Jing and Sun En perish in defeat.
Their infamy lingers through the ages,
mocked by all under Heaven.
To force such a path—can it succeed?

Even if one boasts of divine favor,
claims strength to uproot mountains,
whose very voice makes ghosts cower and gods tremble,
whose command shatters armies—
yet still, their ships founder in vain,
their necks meet the blade in treachery.
No blessings gather at the well,
only the rewards of the Five Dukes.
If they fail to reach this mark,
how dare they usurp what they never deserved?

The Venerable Master warned: *"I see their desperation."*

The Great Treasure’s seat—its meaning is already explained.
Heaven’s sacred instrument cannot be seized.
To seize it brings ruin.
*Note: The Great Treasure’s seat is the divine instrument of Heaven and Earth; thus, it cannot be taken by force.*

Therefore, it is said: *"To seize it brings ruin."*
This warns the treacherous ministers.

The *Exposition* states:
The Great Treasure’s seat cannot be seized by force,
for it is the divine instrument of Heaven and Earth,
meant for the eternal ruler of virtue,
to spread the harmonious and joyful transformations,
not to let a cruel tyrant wield it and poison the realm.
Thus, to seize it is impossible—
and if attempted, it must fail.
This warns the treacherous ministers who would usurp.

The *Meaning* explains:
*"Heaven’s spirit"* is called *shen*,
*"Earth’s spirit"* is called *zhi*,
*"The radiance of sun and moon"* is called *ming*.
Between Heaven and Earth, all things flourish under governance.
Thus, Heaven and Earth’s divine authority governs this,
bestowing the Great Seat upon the virtuous ruler,
to spread the transformations of joy and ease,
nurturing the people.
*Kai* means joy.
*Ti* means ease.
In the *"Dongzhao"* of the *Great Odes*, the Duke of Zhou admonished King Cheng:
*"The joyful and easy ruler—
the people’s parents."*
For joy strengthens their teachings,
ease brings comfort to the people,
so the people revere their ruler as father and mother.
Thus, it is called the transformation of *kai-ti*.

But if a cruel tyrant seizes the realm by force,
he must rule with brutal armies,
slaughtering and harming the people—
like Wu Zixu, the boar and serpent,
or Xiang Yu, the wolf devouring sheep.
Then the people suffer their venom.
Poison from the mouth is called *shi*,
poison from the tail is called *chi*.
This shows that such tyrants,
poisoning the realm,
can never claim the Great Treasure’s seat
without bringing ruin upon themselves.
Thus, it is said: *"To seize it brings ruin."*

Those who grasp at it will lose it.

「**Annotations:**
#1□ – Likely refers to "过" (guò, faults/crimes), though context suggests a missing or corrupted character (possibly "过" or "祸").

---

**Translation:**

**Commentary:** When calamities befall one’s person,
already having obtained the ruler’s seat,
yet still grasping at this position,
oppressing and harming the sovereign’s spirit,
the Dao/Way will bring ruin and misfortune—
it will surely cause one to lose it.
This is a warning to emperors and kings.

**Exegesis:** A ruler may either
restore order and rectify chaos,
or uphold tradition and guard the Way.
Both must strive to reveal virtue and block faults,
relieve the hidden and seek out suffering.
If instead one grasps at this position,
oppressing and harming the sovereign’s spirit,
while allowing the country to fall into disorder without remedy,
then the Dao/Way will bring ruin and misfortune,
the gods will be enraged and the people will resent—
thus disasters arise like sand,
chaos and exile spread.
Who will still serve as their ruler?
They will surely lose this seat.
This is also a warning to emperors and kings.

**Meaning:** When a ruler inherits the Mandate of Heaven (*tian*),
yet does not act with virtue,
poison flows throughout the land,
disaster erupts within the world—
their commands are not obeyed,
weapons turn inward against them.
Once the realm is in chaos,
the seas and mountains boil.
The true sovereign, in response to the times,
will arise to save the people,
restore order and rectify chaos—
such as Xia Yu, Shang Tang, Zhou Wu, and Han Zu,
the founders of dynasties.

When the realm is settled,
it is passed to their descendants.
Thus, the succeeding ruler upholds the bright Way,
guards tradition and continues the succession—
like Xia Jie, Shang Zhou, Zhou Liang, and Han Xian,
the rulers who inherit the throne.

Indeed, the founders of dynasties
must rely on sacred virtue,
block faults and make amends,
reveal virtue and manifest benevolence,
attract the loyal and rescue the lost,
seek out the suffering and the sick.
At first, they hold the Great Treasure’s seat,
rarely meeting ruin or defeat.
For they strive diligently to seek the Way.

But those who inherit the throne,
unfamiliar with the labor of tilling and reaping,
grown in women’s hands,
born in deep palaces,
with the eight melodies and five colors
disturbing their hearts,
luxurious attire and seductive sounds
corrupting their nature—
some exhaust military strength at the borders,
spread poison across the nine regions,
regard their own children as enemies,
view the people as grass to be trampled,
and their actions bring only slaughter.
They do not follow constitutional norms,
but instead reverse the Dao/Way and defy Heaven,
oppressing and harming the sovereign’s spirit.
The sovereign’s spirit refers to the people,
and thus wars erupt in all four directions,
floods and droughts come untimely,
the gods are enraged, the people abandon,
ghosts weep and the people resent—
leading to exile at Nan Chao,
or the fall at Mu Ye,
dying among the common folk,
losing power to treacherous tyrants,
their grand designs forever gone,
their great achievements never returned.
This clearly illustrates *"To grasp it brings ruin,"*
a lesson for future rulers.

Those who reveal virtue and block faults—
in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Duke Huan of the second year,
Song Hua Du killed Kong Jia Fu,
then assassinated Duke Zheng,
and installed Gong Zi Ping as Duke Zhuang.
He placed the Guo tripod as a bribe before Duke Heng of Lu,
who accepted it in the ancestral temple.
The minister Zang Ai Bo remonstrated:
*"A ruler must reveal virtue and block faults,
to govern over all officials,
yet still fear losing it.
Now you place this bribe-tripod in the great ancestral temple,
making it clear to all officials.
If the officials follow this example,
what need is there for punishment?
In ancient times, King Wu conquered Shang
and moved the Nine Tripods to Le Yi.
Even the virtuous still criticized this,
how much more so to place a tripod that reveals faults and violates rites
in the great ancestral temple?
What crimes will this ruler commit?"*

**Annotations:**
呴 (wū) – Warmth/heat.
吹 (chuī) – Coldness/chill.
强 (qiáng) – Vigorous/strong.
羸 (léi) – Weak/feeble.
载 (zài) – To bear/undertake.
隳 (huī) – To ruin/destroy.
纆 (lěi) – Great rope/cord.
准 (zhǔn) – Target/aim.
绳 (shéng) – Standard/measure.
巠 (xián) – Likely refers to "厌" (yàn, to weary/sicken).

---
**Translation (continued):**

Things may either move forward or follow behind,
warm or chill,
strengthen or weaken,
succeed or fail.

**Commentary:** To reveal virtue leads to ruin,
to grasp leads to loss—
thus things either move forward before you,
or follow behind you,
or warm you with their breath,
or chill you with their wind,
or support you and make you strong,
or suppress you and make you weak.
When there is the Dao/Way, they bear undertakings,
when there is no virtue, they bring ruin.

**Exegesis:** This shows that all things are not constant,
but shift and depend.
How can one long preserve them?

Thus, *"To grasp it brings ruin,"*
*"To seize it leads to loss"*—
sometimes those who come later take precedence,
sometimes those who were first fall behind,
sometimes the cold turns warm,
sometimes the warm becomes cold,
sometimes the weak grow strong,
sometimes the strong grow weak,
sometimes the successful bring ruin,
sometimes the ruined achieve wholeness.
Like tangled ropes, without a fixed standard or measure.

A ruler without the Dao/Way
makes people follow their desires,
while a ruler with the Dao/Way
makes desires follow the people.

Those who make desires follow the people—
the realm rejoices and honors them,
never wearying of their virtue.

Those who make people follow desires—
as recorded in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Duke Xi of the twentieth year,
Duke Sheng of Song wished to unite the feudal lords,
and Zang Wen Zhong heard this and said:
*"To make desires follow the people is possible,
but to make people follow desires will rarely succeed."*
He meant to yield one’s own desires
and follow the good of the many.

The following autumn,
Duke Sheng of Song allied with Chu, Chen, Cai, Zheng, Xu, and Cao at Meng.
The feudal lords seized Duke Sheng of Song
and attacked Song together.
This shows that Duke Sheng of Song,
lacking virtue, sought to form the alliance,
and the many seized him in punishment.
As Zang Wen Zhong had spoken.
Zang Wen Zhong was a minister of Lu.**

The Sage removes excess, removes extravagance, removes excessiveness.
**Note:** The Sage, observing how things follow their course, knows that those who cling will inevitably lose, hence he avoids what is overdone.

**Commentary:** Thus, the Sage who governs the world, seeing that what follows its course is not constant, knowing that arrogance and clinging will inevitably lead to loss, restrains himself, disciplines his body, curtails greed, and controls desires. He rejects the most extreme forms of artificiality, avoids the most extravagant adornments. Though the names are divided into three categories, their essence aligns with a single principle.

Excess, extravagance, and excessiveness—all are forms of overindulgence.
**Meaning:** The Sage, in his governance of the world, observes the interplay of rise and fall, discerns the mechanisms of change. In all his actions, he avoids overindulgence. He knows that excess leads to extremity, extravagance leads to greed, and excessiveness leads to arrogance. Extremity will inevitably reverse, greed will inevitably breed resentment, and arrogance will inevitably invite sorrow. If any of these take root, ruin will follow—thus, he rejects them all.

Those who cultivate the Dao understand the folly of clinging, recognize the harm of extravagance and excess, and through humility and restraint, preserve their inner emptiness. Thus, they may attain the True.

**#1 On the word "君" (jūn):** According to the *Zuozhuan*, "君" should be read as "若" (ruò).

**The Broad Explication of the *Dao De Jing* by Master Guangcheng of Tang, as recorded by Du Guangting**
*(Volume 25)*

「**Chapter Thirty: On Using the Dao to Assist the Sovereign**
Explication:

The preceding chapter illustrates that pride and arrogance lead to loss, hence the rejection of extreme extravagance and self-satisfaction. This chapter warns that military strength and aggressive conquests will inevitably provoke retaliation, making decisive warfare unwise.

It begins by stating that one should use the Dao to admonish the ministers, not rely on military force as an auxiliary. The passage below clarifies that those who love war will surely invite misfortune. Therefore, the virtuous minister employs force only when absolutely necessary.

The section on "fruit of strength" further argues that reliance on military power will inevitably lead to defeat. For the meaning:

The preceding chapter taught the sovereign how to govern by rejecting extravagance and self-satisfaction to become a true ruler. This chapter admonishes ministers to serve the sovereign through **virtue/power (德)** and cultural refinement, rather than through military might. If they cling to arms and valorize warfare, they will inevitably provoke enemies to rise in conflict—this is why it is said that military strength and aggression will provoke retaliation, and such conduct cannot be the basis of governance.

The opening passage directly warns ministers, then explains that wielding arms is not virtuous, as it disrupts agriculture and harms the harvest, leading to years of calamity. Then it concludes with the principle of avoiding force: force, when used, will bring ruin and defeat, and military strength is not the Dao—it should be quickly abandoned.

To use the Dao to assist the sovereign means not to employ military force to dominate the world; such actions will provoke retaliation. Annotation:

For ministers to use the Dao in assisting the sovereign, they must yield with humility and **virtue/power (德)**, not rely on the coercive might of arms to dominate the world. Why? Because arms are instruments of violence, and war is a perilous undertaking. If one provokes another with military threats, the other will surely respond in kind. Since such actions invite retaliation, the outcome of victory or defeat cannot be reliably determined.

Explication:
*以 (yǐ)* means *to use*.
*佐 (zuǒ)* means *to assist*.
*还 (huán)* means *retaliation*.

It states that ministers should use the Dao—transformative, non-coercive guidance—to assist the sovereign, thereby achieving a governance akin to that of Yao and Shun. This is called being the sovereign’s **supporting limbs (股肱)**—his feet and hands. The sovereign is the head, and the ministers are his limbs, just as in a single body. How can the Dao of sovereign and minister be neglected?

The *Shu* says: *"The head is clear, the limbs are strong"*—this is the case.

*"Dancing the dry and feathered"* refers to the *Shangshu □ Great Yu’s Discourse* (《尚书□大禹谟》), which states: Shun, recognizing Yu’s merit, appointed him as successor. At that time, the Miao tribes frequently rebelled against the king’s punishment, so Yu was ordered to lead a campaign against them. Thus, he assembled the armies of the feudal lords, swore them to obedience, and marched forth, bearing the mandate to punish crimes.

After thirty days, the Miao tribes defied the command. Yu’s aide, Yi, said: *"Only through **virtue/power (德)** can one move Heaven; nothing is beyond its reach. Sincerity touches the spirits—how much more so with the Miao?"* Yu then withdrew his troops, steadied his ranks, and spread **cultural refinement (文德)**. He performed the *"dry and feathered"* dance at the two stages, and after seventy days, the Miao tribes submitted. The Miao were positioned to the left of Dongting Lake and to the right of Pengli, within the **uncivilized frontier (荒服)**—a region two thousand five hundred *li* distant from the capital. Though summoned, they refused to comply; this passage speaks of pacifying them through **cultural refinement (文德)** and Daoist transformation, rather than force.»

The **dry (干)** follows the path, the **feathered (羽)** conceals—these are the implements held by the dancer.

After withdrawing the troops and steadying the ranks, without resorting to arms, Yu cultivated **virtue/power (文德)**. He performed the **dry-and-feathered dance** between the guest and host stages, suppressing martial affairs, and thus the Miao came to submit. *"Submit (格)"* means to arrive fully.

The *Rites* say: *"Dancing adorns joy."* Grasping the **dry axe (干戚)** and practicing the bowing, rising, bending, and stretching, one’s bearing becomes dignified. Following the measured steps and aligning with the rhythm, the ranks stand straight. The **feathered and dry axe** are the dance implements; bending and stretching, bowing and rising, are its posture; the arranged steps and varying speeds are its formation.

Thus, the Son of Heaven’s **eight ranks (八佾)**—eight men per row, sixty-four in total. The feudal lords have six ranks, great officers four, and commoners two. *"Rank (佾)"* means a row of two. *"He who holds the great symbol"* refers to the thirty-fifth chapter’s words. The **Great Stage (太阶)**—the three stars of the Three Enclosures and the six stars of the Six Symmetries form the six symbols of the Great Stage, rising from **Wenchang** to **Taowei**, governing the Three Excellents. When the ruler and ministers harmonize and laws are balanced, their stars shine brightly, their formations align. If the stars flicker—some dim, some bright, some narrow, some broad, some changing color, some vanishing—these are omens of calamity. If three stars vanish, there will be dynastic revolution and change of sovereignty. When the six stages shine evenly, the realm is at peace.

Now, if ministers rely on military schemes to assist the ruler, unable to use **virtue/power (文德)** to transform others, they invade and seek conquest, bringing war upon them—then they will surely retaliate, and victory or defeat is uncertain. Some may even self-immolate. *"Negative (负)"* means defeat; *"antagonize (抗)"* means to resist with hands; *"disorder (渎)"* means chaos. Where the army encamps, thorns and brambles grow. After a great campaign, there will surely be years of famine.

**Commentary:** Where the military encamps, war harms agriculture. If farming is neglected, thorns and brambles arise. Military **qi (兵气)** brings harm. Drought and flood follow. Agriculture fails first, and disaster follows—thus, years of famine will surely come as retribution for exhausting the military.

**Explanation:** *"Military (师)"* means the army. As the *Yijing* says: *"Military"* means multitude. When armies are raised and multitudes mobilized, people toil in service. Those who fast and march, or lodge and transport supplies, disrupt labor and harm farming. If agriculture is neglected, thorns and brambles grow. After a great campaign, accumulated expenditures are vast. Harmonious **qi (和气)** brings auspicious signs, but military **qi (兵气)** invites disaster. Drought and flood follow, crops fail, and thus years of famine arise as retribution for exhausting the military.

**Doctrine:** Ministers who use arms to assist the ruler will cause the ruler to rely on them. If the ruler covets unnecessary conquests and ministers seek boundless rewards, some may bully lesser states and invade neighboring territories. Once war is unleashed, the people suffer. Marching soldiers endure hunger; those at home bear the burden of transport. Men abandon farming, women neglect weaving—thus, *"a suspended army of ten thousand costs a thousand gold daily; the looms stand idle, the carts never cease, fields grow over with thorns, and famine follows."* Even without drought or flood, there is already the loss of tillage. Harmonious **qi (和气)** brings blessings; military **qi (兵气)** brings calamity. Epidemics and flight arise from this. The evils of exhausting the military—who can fully speak of them? Only rulers and ministers should deeply take heed.

Those who cultivate the self, if their desires encroach upon one another, are like a state with arms. **True qi (真气)** dissipates, just as the people are exhausted. Thus, if pleasures are unchecked, the spirit **qi (神气)** scatters and fades; when **qi** fades, diseases arise. If **qi** is lost and illness takes hold, what good fortune from virtue can be hoped for? What extension of life can be sought? For the state and for the self, this is deeply to be warned against.

Thus, the virtuous achieve their ends without arrogance. **Commentary:** The *Spring and Autumn Annals* says, *"Killing the enemy is called ‘achieving (果)’."* Now, if one clearly understands that killing the enemy is to stop them, to halt their violence, then one knows that *"killing the enemy"* is the same as *"stopping the enemy."* Laozi said: *"If war cannot be avoided, then the best use of arms is to stop the enemy, ensuring they do not become raiders. One must not use many to overpower few or bully others for strength."* To seek strength leads to repulsion—thus, one must be cautious and not dare to do so.

**Doctrine:** The sovereign transforms the people through **Dao and virtue (道德)**. If **Dao and virtue** are not yet widespread and trust is not yet established, and if external enemies invade, then war may be unavoidable. But responding to crises and subduing the enemy—does this lie in killing? If victory can be won through strategy, then one may hope to stop killing. Thus, the *Classic of Rites* says: *"Stopping the blade is martial."* It is enough to stop the enemy; killing is not required. This is truly *"stopping the blade."*

But if corpses are left unburied, blood flows, and blades clash—sometimes victorious in the front, sometimes defeated in the rear—then retaliation follows, and this is not true martial prowess. One does not dare to seek strength, and thus aligns with the **Dao (天道)**.

*"Killing the enemy is achieving"*—as in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, **Spring of the Second Year of Duke Zhuang**: The Duke of Zheng’s son, **Gui Sheng**, received a command from Chu to attack Song. **Hua Yuan** of Song led the defense, and battle was fought at **Da Ji**. The Song army was defeated, **Hua Yuan** was captured, **Le Ju**, the Minister of Works, was taken, along with four hundred and sixty armored chariots and two hundred and fifty captives. A hundred were mutilated. The Song ministers, **Kuang Jiao**, resisted the Zheng forces, who threw them into a well and pulled them out by their spears, capturing **Kuang Jiao**.

The **Junzi** said: *"They violated rites and commands—thus, they were rightly captured."* The martial spirit must be resolute and decisive in listening to orders. Always keep this in mind, let it take root in the heart, and imagine hearing its commands. *"Killing the enemy is achieving; achieving decisively is called ‘resolute (毅)’."* If reversed, it becomes *"slaughter (戮)."* One achieves without boasting, achieves without arrogance, achieves without pride.

The **Junzi** notes: *"The virtuous assistant who aids a ruler must decisively halt the enemy, yet his focus lies in calming the people and harmonizing the multitude, never daring to seek victory or force. Thus, though resolute in stopping the enemy, he must not act as a raider. He must be cautious not to boast of achievements or claim glory, lest he invite arrogance and overweening pride. Arrogance leads to ruin—this is a profound warning.*

The **Shu** says: *"The art of warfare lies in decisively halting the enemy. If one halts the enemy while boasting of it, this is not true virtue over them. Though capable of halting the enemy, one must guard against boasting. Boasting risks harming the pursuit of merit, so even when decisively stopping the enemy, one must be warned against claiming its glory. Claiming glory is itself arrogance and overweening pride. Arrogance and pride breed a love for killing—thus, defeat follows swiftly, and this is a stern warning. How can one not be cautious?"*

**Yi** explains: *"Boast (矜) means to exaggerate one’s deeds. Claim (伐) means to assert one’s own virtue as unmatched. Arrogance (憍) is contempt. The passage on calming the people and harmonizing the multitude is from the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Year 12 of Duke Xuan: The Chu ruler besieged Zheng. In the third month, he conquered it. The Zheng lord, bare-chested and leading a sheep, went to meet him. The Chu ruler intended to spare him, but his attendants said: ‘We cannot grant this—once a state is taken, there is no mercy.’ The Chu ruler replied: ‘His lord can humble himself before others; surely he can trust and use his people.’ He withdrew thirty *li* and granted peace to Zheng. Pan Jia entered the alliance, and Zi Liang went as a hostage. In the sixth month of summer, the Jin forces came to Zheng’s aid. Gu Lin commanded the central army, with Xian Gu as his assistant, and Zhao Xiao and Zhao Ying as his ministers. Shi Hui led the upper army, with Jing Ke as his assistant, and Gong Shu and Han Chuan as his ministers. Zhao Shu commanded the lower army, with Yue Shu as his assistant, and Guou Chu and Zhao Tong as his ministers. Han Yue was the General of War. They reached the River."*

「When it was heard that Zheng and Chu had made peace, Gu Lin wished to return, saying: *“Why should we attack the people of Zheng after we have already made peace? What use would that be?”*

Chu’s withdrawal would be swift, and they would not delay.

Shi Hui said: *“Excellent.”*

Hui heard that armies advance only after observing favorable omens, that their **virtue/power** and punishments, governance and affairs, and rituals remain unaltered—such a force cannot be defeated. He would not call this recklessness#1.

The Chu ruler attacked Zheng, angered by its **duplicity**#5 but pitying its **humility**#6. To punish it after rebellion was **just punishment**; to grant it peace after submission was **virtue**. Both were established.

In the past, when they invaded Chen, and now when they invade Zheng, the people are not weary, and the ruler harbors no resentment. Their governance has its principles. Chu’s **army formations**#7 are well-ordered.

When they march, the right chariot wheels advance, the left follow their **camp beds**#8, and the **front scouts**#9 are without fault. The center holds balance, the rear provides strength. The hundred officials move in accordance with their duties, and the military is prepared without warning.

They are able to uphold these principles. When the ruler selects leaders, he chooses **inner clansmen** from among his kin, and **outer clansmen** from among the old nobility. Promotions do not lose **virtue**, rewards do not fail to honor **labor**, the aged receive additional benefits, and the common people are given provisions. The **gentleman and commoner** each have their proper distinctions, the **noble** their fixed honors, and the **lowly** their due authority. The rituals are not inverted.

With **virtue** established and punishments enforced, governance complete and affairs timely, principles following rituals in order—how could such a force be resisted? To advance when opportunity presents itself and retreat when danger looms is the finest military governance. To **aid the weak and attack the blind**#10 is the finest strategy of martial virtue.

Zi Liang#11, you should instead focus on disciplining the army and upholding martial strategy.

Xian Gu said: *“It cannot be done.”*

The reason Jin has dominated is because its **General of War**#12 is **upright**, and its ministers are **powerful**. Now, Jin has lost the allegiance of its vassals—this cannot be called **power**. It has enemies it does not follow—this cannot be called **martial virtue**. If we fail to dominate, it would be better to die.

Moreover, we have already assembled the army to advance. If we hear of an enemy and retreat, that would not be a failure. But to be appointed as the army’s commander and yet retreat due to what is not a failure—only the **noble sons**#13 could do that. I will not.

Let me instead assist Gu Lin with the central army.

Guou Chu said: *“This commander is indeed reckless.”*
The *Book of Changes*#14 states: *“When an army advances with strict discipline, it prospers; when it does not, it perishes, and disaster follows.”* Obedience brings prosperity; disobedience brings ruin. If a commander is not followed, who will he face in battle? If he encounters them, he will certainly be defeated. Xian Gu will die in battle, and even if he escapes and returns, he will surely suffer great blame.

Thus, Gu Lin and Han Yue led the army and crossed the river.

The Chu forces marched north and encamped at **Ran**#15. Upon hearing that the Jin army had crossed, the Chu ruler wished to retreat. The Chu minister **Wu Can**#16 urged battle, but the **Prime Minister**#17, **Shu Ao**#18, said it was not possible.

Can replied: *“If our campaign is swift, then Sun Shu will be called without strategy.”*

The Prime Minister reversed the chariots and turned the flags, while Wu Can spoke to the Chu ruler: *“The officers of Jin’s army are new and have not yet learned to follow orders. Their assistant, Xian Gu, is stubborn and unkind, unwilling to obey commands. Their two other commanders#4, acting on their own, will not gain the people’s support—who will they follow? This march will lead to Jin’s defeat. Moreover, if you flee while your subjects fight, how will this affect the state’s **sacred altars and ancestral spirits**#19?”*

The ruler was troubled by this and instructed the Prime Minister to change the chariot direction and march north, encamping at **Guan**#20 to await them.

The Jin commanders **En** and **Hao**#21 were between **Zuo** and **Jing**#22 when the Zheng envoy **Huang**#23 was sent to the Jin army. He said: *“Zheng’s allegiance to Chu is for the sake of the state’s **sacred altars and ancestral spirits**#19—it has no **duplicity**. The Chu army, having won quickly, grew arrogant, and its soldiers are weary yet unprepared. I will strike them, and the Zheng army will take their place. The Chu army will surely be defeated.”*

Xian Gu said: *“Defeating Chu and submitting Zheng is certain. We must allow it.”*

Yue Shu said: *“Since the Chu ruler conquered **Yong**#24, he has never stopped punishing his people, teaching them that life is difficult and that disaster may strike at any moment. He keeps them in constant fear. In the army, he never ceases to inspect supplies and reinforce vigilance. Life depends on diligence—if they are diligent, they will not lack. They cannot be called arrogant. The *Book of Changes* also says: ‘An army that is **upright** is strong; an army that is **crooked** is weary.’ We are not **virtuous**, yet we provoke resentment in Chu. We are **crooked**; they are **upright**—we cannot prevail. If we prevail, it will be through **fortuitous circumstances**#25.”

Following **Zuo**’s words, the Chu ruler sent **Wei Xie**#26 as an envoy to Jin, requesting battle and then returning. **Zhao Zhan**#27 urged entry into Chu to summon the two allied commanders, all desiring Jin’s defeat.

The Chu **Minister of War**#28, **Bo Yi**#29, addressed **Le Bu**#30: *“Our young ruler has suffered misfortune and cannot yet govern with refinement. This expedition, he says, is meant to discipline Zheng and establish order—how dare he seek retribution against Jin? You three should not delay.”*

**Yue Shu**#31 replied: *“In the past, King Ping of Zhou commanded our ancestor, Duke Wen of Jin, saying: ‘Assist Zheng in jointly supporting the Zhou dynasty—do not neglect the royal mandate.’ Now Zheng does not comply, and our ruler sends his ministers to question Zheng. How dare he insult the vassals? We dare to accept the ruler’s command and its humiliation. Xian Gu considers this flattery and orders Zhao Biao to follow and correct him.”*

Zhao Biao said: *“The envoy has lost his words.”*
*“Our ruler commands his ministers to move the great state’s **footsteps**#32 onto Zheng, saying: ‘Do not avoid the enemy.’ The ministers have nowhere to flee for their lives.”*

The Chu ruler again sought terms with Jin, and the Jin people agreed, setting a date for the alliance. Chu granted **Bo Yi**#29 command over **Le Bu**#30, **Shu Ao**#18 as his second-in-command, to govern the Jin army.
