**Wei Xie**#26 of Jin was sent to Chu, requesting battle and then returning. Zhao Zhan urged entry into Chu to summon the two allied commanders, all desiring Jin’s defeat.»

The **Zhao Ke** said: *“The two regrets have departed, and without defenses, we shall surely be defeated. Xian Gu replied: ‘The people of Zheng urge us to fight; we dare not comply. The Chu people seek terms, yet we cannot favor them. The army lacks a clear mandate; why prepare defenses?’*

**Shi Hui** said: *“The defenses are well-prepared.”*
*“If the two allied commanders grow angry with Chu, the Chu people will exploit us, and our defeat will be swift. If Chu harbors no ill will, we should remove the defenses and renew the alliance.”*
Xian Gu refused.

Shi Hui sent **Gong Shuo** and **Han Chuan** to lead seven chariots against the enemy at **En** before, so the upper army remained undefeated.

**Zhao Yingzi** assembled boats at the **River**.

**Pan Dang** drove **Wei Xie** out, and the Chu ruler rode his left chariot to pursue **Zhao You**.

The Jin army deployed blunt-wheeled chariots to counter the two allied commanders.

The Chu forces feared the ruler’s entry into the Jin army, so they withdrew from the battle line.

**Sun Shu** said: *“Advance!”*
*“Better that we thin their ranks than that they thin ours.”*
The chariots sped forward, the soldiers fled, and they pressed into the Jin army.

**Lin Fu** was uncertain of what to do, so he beat the drums in the army, declaring: *“Whoever crosses first shall be rewarded.”*
The central and lower armies rushed to seize the boats, and the soldiers on the boats could be scooped up by handfuls.

The Jin army shifted rightward, while the upper army remained unmoving.

**Gong Yin Qi** led the right flank to repel and drive back the lower army.

**Pan Dang** and **Tang Hou** followed the upper army.

Zhao Ke wished to wait for them, but **Shi Hui** said: *“The Chu army is now strong; if they gather against us, we shall be exhausted. Better to rally and withdraw them.”*
He then ordered his troops to retreat, and they were not defeated.

As night fell, the Chu army encamped at **Zhi**. The Jin remnant forces could not fight, so they forded the river at night, yet their movements were still heard.

**Pan Dang** said: *“My lord, why not fortify the Wu Army and collect the Jin dead, displaying them as a warning to the capital?”*
*“I have heard that conquering an enemy must be shown to one’s descendants, lest the martial achievements be forgotten.”*
The Chu ruler said: *“You do not understand.”*
*“The Way of Culture is to halt the sword and make it a symbol of martial might. King Wu conquered Shang and composed the *Song* (Ode of Victory), saying: ‘Sheathe the spears and axes, store the bows and arrows. I seek virtuous power, and now I rule the Xia. The worthy ruler preserves it.’ He also composed the *Wu* (Martial Ode), whose final stanza reads: ‘May your descendants remember your deeds.’ Its third stanza says: ‘Spread the Way and refine thoughts; my purpose is to secure stability.’ Its sixth stanza says: ‘Pacify all lands, and bring abundant harvests.’*
*Martial might* is the power to curb violence, sheathe weapons, uphold the great, establish deeds, secure the people, harmonize the crowds, and enrich the treasury. Thus, it must be shown to descendants that they not forget its principles.

*Now* I have made the bones of the two states a spectacle—*that* is enough. Displaying the army to awe the feudal lords only stirs unrest among the soldiers. To make a spectacle without sheathing the weapons—how can I uphold the great? As long as Jin remains, how can I establish lasting deeds? The grievances of the people are still many; how can they be secure? Without virtue, yet striving to dominate the feudal lords—how can I harmonize the crowds? Seizing others’ opportunities while sowing chaos for their own glory—how can I enrich the treasury? *Martial might* has seven virtues; I possess none of them—how can I demonstrate them to my descendants?

*This* is merely the ancestral temple’s purpose: to proclaim the completion of the task. *Martial might* is not my achievement.”

The ancient sage-kings punished the disrespectful, seizing their tyrants and enshrining them as warnings—thus arose the *jingguan* [京观] to deter licentiousness and depravity. Today, there is no crime, yet the people exhaust their loyalty in dying for their lord’s command—how then could this be made into a *jingguan*?

Sacrificing at the River, constructing the ancestral temple, and proclaiming the task complete before returning.

In this campaign, the Duke of Zheng executed Stone Zhi and established Prince Yu Chen as heir. On the day *xinwei*, Zheng put Stone Zhi and Yu Chen to death.

The virtuous say: *"Do not complacently invite chaos"*—this refers to such cases.

To strike preemptively and achieve victory, to halt aggression and rescue the endangered—this is indeed virtuous. But if one boasts of one’s own merits and flaunts one’s achievements, indulging in fame while harboring arrogance, then *qiangtai* [憍泰] arises. *Qiangtai* dulls one’s perception, and domination breeds resentment. Disaster and ruin are inevitable; fame and merit cannot be preserved.

Han Xin was captured at Yunmeng, Bai Qi’s teeth were shattered at Duwei. Boasting of victory breeds arrogance, and arrogance invites calamity—this must be heeded.

*"Fruitful action"* when unavoidable: this is *fruitful action without coercion*.

**Note:** When the enemy advances and cannot be halted, one must use force to repel them. Thus, *fruitful action* lies in responding to the enemy, not in seeking dominance through force.

**Cushioning Explanation:** Those who act decisively to repel the enemy do not delight in victory or oppress others. The enemy’s advance is unavoidable, hence the necessity of action.

Thus it is said: *"Fruitful action without coercion."* *Yi* [已] means to halt.

When engaging the enemy, one does not seek victory for its own sake—those who act thus *are* victorious. Not relying on brute force, hence *"fruitful action without coercion."*

When things reach their peak, they decline—this is called *not in accord with the Dao*. *Not in accord with the Dao* leads to early ruin.

**Note:** When things rely on their peak strength, it is like an army relying on brute force. When things peak, they decline; when armies rely on strength, they meet defeat. This is called *not in accord with the Dao*—one must halt such actions early.

**Cushioning Explanation:** All things, at their peak, grow old; armies, at their strongest, meet defeat. Thus, an army relying on strength is like a thing relying on its peak—using peak strength only hastens decline and injury. These two cases are called *not in accord with the Dao*. Wise ministers and enlightened rulers, knowing this, must halt such actions early.

Thus it is said: *"Not in accord with the Dao, halt early."* *Yi* [已] means to cease.

**Doctrine states:** Armies that rely on brute force will inevitably meet ruin. The forces of Fu Jian at Leicheng, Li Mi at Luokou, Wang Jin at Kunyang, and Emperor Yang’s expedition to Liaodong—all numbered in the hundreds of thousands, truly vast in number. Yet, relying on *non-Dao* strength, they collapsed without recovery—because their armies were too strong. Just as things peak and then decline, relying on peak strength must bring harm.

In ancient times, Qin devoured the Seven States, unified the Nine Regions, its strength and armies unmatched, yet the empire crumbled in an instant. Fu Su died at the Great Wall, Zi Yin surrendered at Zhidao. What use were their hawk-like ambitions?

The Sage deemed this *non-Dao* foundation—better to halt early.

Cultivating the self, one restrains desires and returns to nature—just as with armies. If one abandons passions, purifies the spirit, and stills delusive thoughts, guarding the void and the mysterious, there will be no censure of peak strength—this is the essence of perfect harmony.

Armies too have their decline. The *Spring and Autumn Annals* says: *"A crooked army is old"*—meaning an army deployed without just cause, acting against principle, its logic defeated by the enemy, is also considered old.

Thus it is said: *"A righteous army is strong; a crooked army is old."*

---
*End of Volume Twenty-Five of the Broad Explication of the Daoist Classic by Master Guangcheng of Tang, annotated by Du Guangting.*

**Corrections:**
1. *"Paired"* [狂] should be *"Zheng"* [征] (per the *Zuozhuan*).
2. *"Teach as ruler"* [蔿教为宰] should be *"Enfeoffed as ruler"* [敖教为宰] (per the *Zuozhuan*).
3. *"Yet finally not lost"* [而卒非失也]—*"失"* should be *"夫"* (per the *Zuozhuan*).
4. *"The two commanders"* [其二帅者]—*"二"* should be *"三"* (per the *Zuozhuan*).

---
*Volume Twenty-Six of the Broad Explication of the Daoist Classic.*

The **Thirty-First Chapter on *Jiābīng* (佳兵)**—Explication:

The previous chapter expounds that a strong army prefers to return (in victory), and one must not indulge in its arrogance or conquest. This chapter clarifies that *jiābīng* (佳兵, "good/ideal arms") is an evil thing, to be used only when unavoidable. First, it sets forth warnings against its ominous nature, showing that those who follow the Dao do not dwell upon it. Next, it states that victory does not bring joy, illustrating that delight in killing is wrong. Beneath this, it cites examples to elucidate the point, concluding with the observance of funeral rites—thus demonstrating that war is not something to be rejoiced in.

Its meaning is this: First, it admonishes ministers that they should assist the state with the Dao, not with arms. Now it reveals that *jiābīng* (佳兵) is indeed an ominous implement. If one relies on arms to aid the state, it will inevitably lead to arrogance and conquest; if one indulges in arrogance and conquest, it will inevitably result in defeat and ruin. Therefore, it directly points to *jiābīng* (佳兵) as the thing that all detest. When the enemy comes to invade, one must use it only when there is no alternative. Those who follow the Dao do not dwell upon such things, nor do they take pleasure in victory over the enemy, but rather prioritize righteous killing. This is a warning against taking delight in killing. The observance of funeral rites in its place is not because one desires war.

**The ideal arms (佳兵),** indeed, are an ominous implement.
—Explication: *Jiā* (佳) means "good/ideal." Arms are of the category of *tāoliè* (韬略). *Xiáng* (祥) means "auspicious/good," and *qì* (器) refers to implements or talents. The virtuous person cultivates virtue and perfects their pursuits, ever cautious at the outset. They keep their implements hidden within, awaiting the moment to act. They should roam their thoughts within the Daoist *yòu* (囿, "enclosure"), browsing the wisdom of ancient edicts and classics, so that their light shines forth through the ages, and their guidance aids in great undertakings.

Its meaning is this: *Tāo* (韬) refers to the *Liùtāo* (六韬, "Six Stratagems"). **Qí Tàigōng Jiāng Zǐyá** (齐太公姜子牙), while fishing at the **Pánxī** (磻溪), split an fish and found a jade, within which was inscribed this book. It is called *Wéntāo* (文韬, "Civil Stratagem"), establishing the state and nation without transgressing Heaven’s order; *Wǔtāo* (武韬, "Martial Stratagem"), subduing calamities and chaos, dominating the eight directions; *Lóngtāo* (龙韬, "Dragon Stratagem"), harmonizing yin and yang, never exceeding the seasons; *Hǔtāo* (虎韬, "Tiger Stratagem"), skillfully employing claws and fangs, crushing all evil; *Bàotāo* (豹韬, "Leopard Stratagem"), seizing the moment to quell difficulties, with wisdom lying in adaptability; *Quǎntāo* (犬韬, "Dog Stratagem"), discerning the faintest sounds, sometimes achieving unexpected success.

*Tāo* (韬) means "to conceal." The stratagems and adaptations of arms are not to be lightly revealed to others. Hence, the meaning is to conceal and obscure them.

*Liè* (略) refers to the *Sānliè* (三略, "Three Strategies"). The *Sānliè* (三略) is what **Hàn Liúhóu Zhāng Zǐfáng** (汉留侯张子房) received in **Xiàpí Yíqiáoliáo** (下邳圯桥) from **Huángshí Gōng** (黄石公), who taught him: "With this, you may become a teacher to emperors and kings, or a master of the arts of stratagem and warfare." **Jiāng Zǐyá** (姜子牙) used it to assist **Wǔwáng** (武王), conquering **Shāng** (商) and overthrowing **Jiǔ** (纣), thus completing the royal enterprise. **Zhāng Zǐfáng** (张子房) used it to assist **Hàn Zǔ** (汉祖), annihilating **Xiàng Jié** (项籍) and securing the imperial ambition.

The cultivation of **virtue/power** (德) is such that one’s **virtue/power** (德) surpasses the Five Emperors, becoming the finest of moral conduct. The pursuit of learning encompasses the Six Arts, marking the foremost of scholarly endeavors.

Thus, the virtuous person attends to fundamentals—when the foundation is established, the *Dao/Way* arises. In the pursuit of learning, one must be cautious from the very beginning.

To study Confucian texts, morality, and the *Dao/Way* is to become a **junzi** (君子); to study greed, arrogance, cruelty, and violence is to become a petty person.

In days past, **Mèng Kē** (孟轲), when young and orphaned, lived near a burial ground and began practicing funeral rites. His mother, a virtuous woman, saw that his studies were not noble and relocated, moving near a potter’s home. There, **Mèng Kē** learned to shape clay vessels, so his mother moved again, this time near a school of Confucian scholars. Then **Mèng Kē** studied the classics and ancient texts, later becoming a great scholar, his *Dao/Way* rivaling that of **Zhōu Kǒng** (周孔), his reputation surpassing that of **Hàn Fēi** (韩非) and **Mò Dì** (墨翟).

In his youth, **Kǒng Zǐ** (孔子) had an elder brother who delighted in playing with ritual food vessels. Later, he became the founder of rites and music, his *Dao/Way* surpassing all sovereigns, his teachings harmonizing the Four Seas.

When **Hòuxī** (后稷) was a child, he took pleasure in imitating plowing and farming. Later, he became the master of agriculture, spreading cultivation and nourishing the people, his merits benefiting all under heaven.

When **Hàn Zhāng Táng** (汉张汤) was a boy, he witnessed a mouse stealing meat and was scolded by his father. **Zhāng Táng** smoked out the mouse, along with the remaining meat, flogged the mouse, and interrogated it as if it were a criminal, extracting a confession and recording its "testimony" like an experienced jailer. Later, he served the **Hàn** (汉) as a legal official, meticulously codifying laws and establishing enduring statutes.

Thus, those who cultivate good habits reap their rewards. The key lies in being vigilant from the very beginning—**guì** (厥), meaning "its" or "their"; **chū** (初), meaning "beginning."

「The one who keeps **virtue/power** (器) within himself, as the *Yì* ["**I Ching**"] (《易□下系》) says: *"The noble lord used his bow and arrows to shoot a falcon atop a high wall, and when he captured it, there was no failure."* The Master said: *"The falcon is a bird; the bow and arrows are **virtue/power** (器); the one who shoots is a man. The gentleman keeps **virtue/power** (器) within himself, waits for the right time, and then acts—how could there be any failure?"* This means that when the gentleman finds the right time, he will succeed; if he does not find the right time, his actions may lead to misfortune, and thus he will have no success.

The annotation explains that *"the noble lord"* refers to **impartiality** (无私), *"high wall"* symbolizes **high position** (高位). The falcon on the high wall is difficult to shoot, just as a man in a high position is difficult to remove. If one in a high position is greedy and cruel like the falcon, those who seek to remove him will succeed without fail when they find the right time. This also means that the gentleman with great **virtue/power** (德) and lasting achievements should act only when the time is right.

The *Shǐ Jì* ["**Records of the Grand Historian**"] states: *"When the gentleman finds the right time, he ascends to power; if he does not find the right time, he travels with humility."* As it says: *"When the state follows the **Dao/Way** (道), one speaks and acts with boldness; when the state does not follow the **Dao/Way** (道), one acts with caution and speaks with humility."* Finding the right time leads to success benefiting all under heaven; losing the right time means one can only cultivate oneself. This is how one discerns the proper course of action.

One’s mind should dwell in **moral cultivation** (道德), and one’s thoughts should range through **classical texts and ancient records** (典坟). **囿** (囿) means **enclosure/retreat** (园囿); **典** (典) refers to **sacred archives** (谟典); **坟** (坟) means the books of the **Three Sovereigns** (三皇之书), known as the **Three Canon** (三坟). **诰** (诰) means **edicts** (训语), such as the examples in *Táng Guāng* ["**The Edict of Tang**"] and *Jiǔ Guāng* ["**The Edict on Alcohol**"]. **林** (林) means **abundant writings** (丛木为林), speaking of the vastness of **history and literature** (书史). **光** (光) means **great** (大); **昭** (昭) means **clear** (明); **令** (令) means **good** (善). Thus, **"great and clear good reputation"** (大明善美之名) refers to fame that is both illustrious and virtuous.

As for **opening the way and achieving great undertakings** (开济成务), the *Yì* ["**I Ching**"] (《易□上系》) says: *"The **I Ching** opens the way and achieves great undertakings, for it is the **Dao/Way** of all under heaven."* This means that the **Dao/Way** of the *I Ching* can be applied universally—just as the **Dao/Way** of all under heaven opens the way and achieves great undertakings, so too the gentleman’s **virtue/power** (德业) shines brightly and clearly, serving as a model for the world. Only then can one dwell in the **enclosure/retreat** of **moral cultivation** (道德之园囿) and wander through the **abundant writings** of **classical texts and ancient records** (坟诰之丛林), with a good reputation spreading far and wide, fulfilling great purposes.

In the *Chūn Qiū* ["**Spring and Autumn Annals**"], **Sòng Mù Gōng** (宋穆公) said to his minister when appointing **Zhāng Dìng Gōng** (立殇公) as heir: *"My predecessor considered me capable and virtuous. My fame is great, clear, and good—this is it."* Those who cultivate the **Dao/Way** (修道之士) should also be cautious in their habits, dwelling in the **Great Dao/Way** (大道) and contemplating **non-action** (无为). Only then can they hope to attain the **Dao/Way**.

If one lingers in the realm of **right and wrong** (是非), binds himself to the ruins of **ritual teachings** (言教), wanders lost in the **path of indulgence** (嗜玩), or peeks through the **window of frivolity** (浮诞), his **Dao/Way** will only grow more distant.

When the ruler governs his state by following the **sacred traditions of the Yellow Emperor and the **Dao/Way** of the ancient kings** (皇风帝道), he can achieve **peace and prosperity** (升平). But if he emulates the **achievements of kings and schemes of conquerors** (王业霸图), he rarely attains **tranquility and purity** (清静). What then of **martial arts and strategies of war** (兵战之术)? These are what one should guard against.

The annotation says: *"Yet there are those who take delight in **military strategies and schemes of war** (兵谋韬略)."* The purpose of such schemes is to use **rectitude** (正) as **deceit** (奇), and the books of **warfare** (兵铃) emphasize **bluffing before striking** (先声后实), all centered on **attacking, seizing, slaughtering, and punishing** (攻取杀伐). Thus, they are **unauspicious tools of evil** (不善之村器).

The commentary explains: *"**谋** (谋) means **planning and calculating** (图度); **奇** (奇) means **deceit and trickery** (变诈); **攻** (攻) means **to strike** (击); **取** (取) refers to **ease of acquisition** (其易)."* The books of the *Liù Táo* ["**Six Tactics**"] and *Sān Lüè* ["**Three Strategies**"], as well as the **strategies inscribed on metal and jade** (金版玉铃之术), all focus on **planning and calculating** (机谋), not on **auspicious and virtuous methods** (祥善之道). Since **warfare values deceit**, it relies on **rectitude as deceit**, **striking with false pretense**, and **expanding treacherous schemes** (开张诡谲)—these are not what the gentleman should follow.

In the state, such **schemes lead to greed and cruelty** (贪残); in one’s own life, they result in **evil actions** (不善); toward others, they bring **hatred and malice** (憎恶). How could they be practiced or followed? Moreover, what one cultivates should ultimately lead to **success** (有成). When one’s undertakings are successful, he applies them; when he applies them, he seeks **fulfillment** (求达). Those who cultivate **auspicious tools** (善器) advance to benefit others, retreat to preserve themselves, act to achieve great merits, and shine to display their **virtue/power** (德). But those who cultivate **martial arts**, take **deceit and trickery** as their foundation, **deception** as their skill, **slaughter and conquest** as their merit, and **punishment and warfare** as their purpose—these lead to **lack of sincerity** (非信) and **lack of benevolence** (非仁). In the state, they make the ruler the **master of conquest and war** (征伐之主); in one’s own life, they lead to **becoming a deceitful trickster** (诡妄之徒). Such matters are clearly evil.

When **Lǎo Jun** ["**Old Master** (老子/Laozi)"] spoke of the **scriptures** (经), he only mentioned **combat and warfare** (战斗), which were the **strategies of the battles of Bān Quán, Zháo Lù, and Dān Pǔ** (版泉涿鹿、丹浦). At that time, there were no books like the *Liù Táo* ["**Six Tactics**"] and *Sān Lüè* ["**Three Strategies**"]. Yet even in **warfare**, the emphasis was on **seizing the right moment** (机讨) and **using deceit to undermine** (谲诈相倾), with **victory** as merit and **slaughter** as beauty—these are not the pursuits of those who follow the **Dao/Way**. Therefore, one must strictly guard against them.

Now, I cite the books of *Liù Táo* ["**Six Tactics**"] and *Sān Lüè* ["**Three Strategies**"] to illustrate the **near** (近) with the **far** (远). All things may **hate** (恶) it, so even those who follow the **Dao/Way** avoid it. The annotation explains: *"To take delight in **military strategies and schemes of war** (兵谋韬略) is to cultivate **unauspicious tools** (不祥之器). Since all things **hate** (恶) it, how could those who follow the **Dao/Way** (有道) place themselves within it?"* The commentary states: *"The gentleman who follows the **Dao/Way** (有道之士) nourishes **virtue/power** (德) within himself—this is what constitutes **true success** (能事). Since these are **unauspicious tools** (不祥之器), all things **hate** (恶) them. How much more would the gentleman who follows the **Dao/Way** avoid placing himself within such matters!"*

It further says: *"The gentleman who follows the **Dao/Way** (有道之士) cultivates **sincerity** (德) within himself, uses **goodness** (善) to save others, acts with **simplicity and rectitude** (动资简正), and remains **in harmony with emptiness** (静合虚无), never harboring thoughts of **slaughter and punishment** (杀伐). How could he take delight in **martial schemes** (兵谋)?"* **Warfare** is rooted in **slaughter and punishment** (杀伐), and all things **hate** (恶) it.

Those who cultivate **sincerity and proper speech** (修辞立诚) are like the words of the **乾九三** (乾九三) passage in the *Yì* ["**I Ching**"]. The gentleman is **loyal and trustworthy** (忠信)—this is how he cultivates **virtue/power** (德). He establishes **sincerity** (诚) in his undertakings—this is how he **dwells in his station** (居业). The gentleman values **the left** (阳) in dwelling, but **the right** (右) in **martial arts**. The annotation explains: *"**左** (左) means **yang** (阳)."*

「The **Dao/Way** of **yang** (阳) brings forth growth and flourishing, hence why **the left** (阳) is prized in peaceful dwelling. **The right** (右), being **yin** (阴), congeals into solemnity and slaughter, thus why it is prized in warfare. The annotation elucidates: *"**The left** (左) is **yang** (阳). **The right** (右) is **yin** (阴). **Yang** favors growth, **yin** favors slaughter; hence, **yang** is prized in dwelling for its nurturing, while **yin** is prized in warfare for its slaying."*

The **I Ching** explains: *"The Emperor emerges from **Zhèn** (震, Thunder), and all things are born in the east. Spring governs growth, summer nurtures to maturity. The **Dao/Way** of Heaven revolves to the left, thus **the left** (阳) aligns with **yang**, harmonizing with the **Dao/Way** of growth and flourishing. All things turn solemn and slaying in the west, autumn governing slaughter. They retreat and conceal in the north, winter governing concealment. The moon corresponds to **yin** (阴) and presides over punishment, while metal abides in the west and presides over warfare—thus **the right** (阴) aligns with **yin**, countering the **Dao/Way** of slaughter and punishment. The gentleman embodies **ren** (仁, benevolence) to benefit all things, hence why **yang** (the left) is prized in dwelling. In warfare, he upholds **yì** (义, righteousness) and values **criminal punishment** (刑), thus why **yin** (the right) is prized."*

Warfare is an **auspicious** (祥) yet **ominous** (不祥) instrument. The annotation clarifies: *"**Auspicious** (祥) means **good** (善)."* Those who delight in warfare favor slaughter, hence they are **unvirtuous** (不善) material. It is not the instrument of the gentleman. The annotation further explains: *"The gentleman values **moral cultivation and virtue/power** (道德) as his instrument, not martial schemes."*

The preceding passage stated: *"The ideal warrior is an **auspicious** (祥) yet **ominous** (不祥) instrument,"* thus clarifying that warfare prizing **yin** (the right) and favoring slaughter means the gentleman does not engage in it. This passage reiterates: *"Warfare is an **ominous** (不祥) instrument,"* reinforcing the prior text, declaring it not the gentleman’s tool. The gentleman’s instrument is **moral cultivation and virtue/power** (道德), hence he finds no benefit therein.

The **I Ching** explains: *"What the gentleman cultivates are the **virtues/powers** (德) of the **Thirteen Sovereigns and Five Emperors** (十三皇五帝), tracing the **benevolence and righteousness** (仁义) of the **Táng Yú, Xià Yīn, and Shǒu** (唐虞夏殷) dynasties, and establishing the **rites and music** (礼乐) of **Dà Wén, Dà Wǔ, Zhōu, and Kǒng** (文武周孔). He seeks to govern the world, benefit all things, guide future kings, and bless generations to come. When the times favor him, he opens the **Dao/Way** to nurture and complete undertakings; when the times do not, he withdraws and cherishes them within."*

Thus, there is nothing that cannot be beneficial.

The preceding passage states that *"a fine weapon is an ominous instrument"*, and that those who follow the **Dao/Way** do not engage with it. It now illustrates the initial focus of what the gentleman cultivates: his efforts lie in **virtue/power** (道德), not in military strategy (兵谋). Those who cultivate military strategy are not the gentleman’s true pursuits.

Once military strategy is mastered, it must inevitably be applied. The purpose of wielding arms is made clear in the following passage. When compelled to use force, the gentleman prioritizes **serenity and moderation** (恬淡).*
**Annotation:** *"Steadfastly subduing without strife"* (善勝不爭) and *"when pressed, then act"* (事不得已，然後應之).

The **Commentary** explains:
*"The **virtues/powers of culture** (文德) are the instruments of governance, while military strategy (兵谋) serves as auxiliary support. Hence it is said that **culture weaves the patterns of heaven and earth** (文則經緯天地), and **military force resolves calamity and disorder** (武則克定禍亂). Though heaven bestows the Five Strategies (五村), abandoning even one is unacceptable, yet the application of military force must be measured and disciplined. Thus, one knows that its use has its foundations and branches, its proper and improper courses, and depends on necessity—then alone may it be employed. When the barbarians (四夷) invade, the royal armies must strike with restraint, demonstrating **kindness and benevolence** (恩惠) and pacifying them through **virtue/power** (道德). Even when repelling minor threats like mosquitoes (蚊蚋), there is no room for anger. From this perspective, **serenity and moderation** (恬淡) are paramount."*

**Annotation:** *"The Sage’s governance and instruction"* (聖人制法垂訓) involve adjusting severity according to the times, like changing a carriage’s wheels or cleaning its axle.

*"The Sovereign of the highest rank transforms through the **Dao/Way** (道), the next through **virtue/power** (德), and the next through **benevolence** (仁). When **virtue/power** (道德) declines, the times grow chaotic, and the **Dao/Way** of **culture and military force** (文武) is then invoked. **Culture** instructs through **rites, music, benevolence, and righteousness** (礼乐仁义); **military force** instructs through **unconventional and orthodox tactics, authority, and strategy** (奇正权谋). **Culture weaves the patterns of heaven and earth** (文經天地), while **military force resolves calamity and disorder** (武定禍亂); **culture is the foundation** (文為本), and **military force is the application** (武為末); **culture is the essence** (文為體), and **military force is the function** (武為用).*

The Master said: *"Not to teach the people war is to abandon them."* Yet there are **cultural affairs** (文事), and there are also **military preparations** (武備). At the **Jiāgǔ Meeting** (夹谷之会), he proclaimed his military readiness and executed the rebellious **Cháng Yóu** (徘优), causing the Duke of Qí (齐侯) to fear him. The Duke returned the land of **Yīn** (阴) and **Tián** (田), and the Master completed the rites before withdrawing, thus demonstrating that **military force is the auxiliary to culture** (武为文之辅), and **culture is the master of military force** (文为武之主).

*"Weaving the patterns of heaven and earth"* (经纬天地) refers to the **south-north axis as the warp** (南北为经), and the **east-west axis as the weft** (东西为纬), probing the **emotions and states of ghosts and spirits** (鬼神之情状), and elucidating the **transformations of creation** (造化之变通). With the **Nine Schools** (九流) maintaining clarity and the **Hundred Methods** (百度) upholding rectitude, the **patterns of humanity** (人文) are observed to transform and civilize the world, hence the title *Wén* (文) was bestowed upon him.*

*"Resolving calamity and disorder"* (克定祸乱) means that **violence and cruelty** (凶暴) harming others are called **calamity** (祸), while **rebellion against virtue and law** (反德律逆) is called **disorder** (乱). To **inflict injury** (得伤) is to **subdue** (克). Thus, the **Yellow Emperor** (黄帝) exterminated **Chī Yóu** (蚩尤), **Shùn** (舜) exterminated the **Three Miáo** (三苗), **Tāng** (汤) overcame **Jié** (桀), the **Zhōu** (周) dynasty overcame **Zhòu** (纣), and **Qín** (秦) annihilated the **Six States** (六国), while the **Hàn** (汉) dynasty pacified the **Three Qín** (三秦). These were acts to **remove violent and harmful governance** (暴害之政) and **sever the roots of rebellion and disorder** (乱逆之根), to **rescue living beings** (拯活生灵), not to kill men for victory’s sake. Hence the title *Wǔ* (武) was bestowed upon him.*

This then clarifies the **foundation and application** (本末), distinguishes the **proper and improper courses** (逆顺), and shows that military force is employed only when absolutely necessary.

When barbarian tribes from the Four Quarters invade, during the reign of **King Xuan** of the **Zhōu**, the **Quán Róng** (犬戎) repeatedly encroached upon the Central States, and armies were dispatched to repel them—hence the *Shī Jīng* (《诗》) speaks of "smiting and slaying the **Róng** (猃狁)."

Heaven generates the Five Phases (五行)—gold, wood, water, fire, and earth. These Five Phases cyclically succeed one another, and the Sage-Kings wield them like tools, hence they are called the **Five Materials** (五材). Their use is interdependent; lacking any one, the system falters.

An army that follows the Sage-King’s mandate is called the **Royal Army** (王师). *Shī* (师) means "multitude." In the *Yì Jīng* (《易》), it is the **Shī** (师) hexagram—**Kūn** (坤) above, **Kǎn** (坎) below.

When an army is dispatched with formal declarations, it is called *fá* (伐); when it does so without such declarations, it is called *qīn* (侵). The Royal Army, when campaigning, first displays martial might to instill awe, then extends benevolence and trust to win their allegiance—not to indulge in wanton slaughter or vent rage through indiscriminate slaughter.

An army deployed with justification is *shùn* (顺); without justification, it is *nì* (逆). Observe the invasions of the Four Quarters: they are like mosquitoes and gnats biting the skin—no great calamity to the Central States, nor does it harm morality. What is proper is to pacify them with kindness and transform them through harmony, without harboring vengeful intent. This is the highest virtue of tranquility.

Thus, it is fitting to resolve conflicts through skillful diplomacy, as **Lúo Nóng** (僚弄丸) did, or to lay down arms in peace, as **Shū Ào** (叔敖) did, achieving victory without battle—this is the supreme way. To celebrate victory without shame is to delight in killing. **Cóng** (疏) explains: *"Unable to win them with virtue, yet resorting to arms for victory, though triumphant, one still feels shame for failing in virtue and should not take pride in it. Victory inevitably entails slaughter; thus, one who takes pride in victory is one who delights in killing."*

**Yì** (义) states: *"The Sage’s gentle subjugation of the Four Quarters, pacifying chaos and disorder, relies on cultural virtue to win their allegiance, transforming them for good—not through warfare. Now, if virtue proves insufficient and one must resort to martial might for victory, yet still rejoices in it, lacking inner shame or compassion, then one truly delights in killing."*

In days past, **Jì Zhá** (季札) observed the *Dà Hù* (《大护》) dance and remarked: *"The Sage’s magnanimity still carries a sense of shame."* **The *Lúnyǔ*** (《论语》) says: *"The martial virtues are indeed beautiful, yet not entirely good."* This refers to conquering the world through arms—hence, not entirely good.

Those who delight in killing cannot achieve their ambitions in the world. **Zhù** (注) elaborates: *"To vanquish an enemy inevitably costs lives, so victory should not be glorified. If one takes pride in victory, it is because they take pleasure in slaughter. Those who take pleasure in slaughter will never find followers. To seek dominance while spurning virtue is indeed difficult."*

**Cóng** (疏) continues: *"Heaven and Earth cherish life; all things nurture and sustain. The virtuous follow Heaven’s will, prioritizing salvation. How could one recklessly wield deceit and force to indulge in cruelty? The cruel will never find allegiance. To seek dominance while spurning virtue is indeed difficult. Thus, those who delight in killing cannot achieve their ambitions in the world."*

**Yì** (义) states: *"The benevolent heart measures responses, aligns with harmony, and nurtures with love. Toward all beings, they harbor pity, unwilling to see any suffer. The *Lǐ* (《礼》) says: 'Seeing them alive, one cannot bear to see them die; hearing their cries, one cannot bear to eat their flesh.' Further, they bury dogs beneath worn-out mats, horses beneath tattered canopies, and oxen beneath broken carts. **Chén Ānshì** (陈安世) refrained from travel in summer to avoid crushing insects, and refrained from cutting grass or trees. If the time for insects to hatch had not yet come, he would not burn the fields. These are all expressions of compassion. To follow Heaven’s nurturing and preserve life—this is the essence of virtue. How could one revel in slaughter for glory or delight in killing for wealth and honor?"*

If one glorifies slaughter and deceitful victory, indulging in cruelty and greed, becoming an object of fear, then who would dare to follow? Without followers, relying only on tyranny, to seek dominance in the world is indeed difficult. The downfalls of **Dōng Hūn** (东昏) and **Chāngyě Gāoyáng** (昌邑高洋) serve as warnings.

Auspicious matters are conducted on the left; inauspicious matters, on the right. **Cóng** (疏) explains: *"Left signifies life and auspice, hence auspicious matters are conducted on the left. Right signifies death and inauspice, hence inauspicious matters are conducted on the right."* The *Lǐjì* (《礼记·檀弓》) records: *"The Master stood with his disciples, clasping his hands and turning to the right. The disciples also turned to the right. The Master said: 'Your eagerness for learning stems from my sister’s recent death.' The disciples then turned to the left."* **Yì** (义) clarifies: *"Left represents Yang, the principle of life, so in daily life, the left is honored. In guest-host relations and clasping hands, the left is superior and respected. Right represents Yin, the principle of death. In funeral rites, the right is honored. When the Master had his sister’s funeral, he clasped his hands and turned to the right. The disciples, unaware of the reason, followed suit. Upon learning their devotion to learning, the Master had them return to the left. *Tán Gōng* (檀弓) is the fourth chapter of the *Lǐjì*."*

**Yán Huí** (颜回), who mastered the Master’s teachings and was ranked first among disciples as the **Yà Shèng** (亚圣), once asked the Master: *"When you speak, I speak; when you argue, I argue; when you remain silent yet are trusted, when you do not compare yet are comprehensive, when you lack tools yet achieve completion—I do not know how this is so."* Gazing at the dust, he sighed in admiration. *"Your disciples’ passion for learning is such, yet still they cannot fully grasp your teachings—how much less can the unlearned?"*

In military ranks, the **Piān Jiāngjūn** (偏将军) stands to the left, while the **Shàng Jiāngjūn** (上将军) stands to the right.

The annotations state:

The **Piān Jiāngjūn** (偏将军), though of lower rank, stands to the left because he does not hold sole authority over killing. The **Shàng Jiāngjūn** (上将军), of higher rank, stands to the right because he is entrusted with military strategy. This arrangement follows the rites of mourning.

The rites of mourning honor the right, yet the **Shàng Jiāngjūn** occupies the right—this is because the disposition is made according to mourning rites.

The *Cū* (疏) explains: If the **Shàng Jiāngjūn** held sole authority over killing, he would stand to the right; the **Piān Jiāngjūn**, as his deputy without sole authority, stands to the left. Now, though the left is honored and the right is lowly, the **Shàng Jiāngjūn** stands to the right, indicating that the Dao of war aligns with mourning rites. Since mourning rites honor the right, and the **Shàng Jiāngjūn** stands to the right, this is why he is placed accordingly.

The *Yì* (义) states: Mourning rites honor the right, as death belongs to *yin*. The **Shàng Jiāngjūn** holds sole authority over killing, thus overseeing matters of death. When a state sends its army, the **Shàng Jiāngjūn** ascends the platform, the Son of Heaven observes fasting and purification, and grants him the axe and battle-axe—this is to invest him with sole authority over killing. He breaks through the *xué* (凶) gate and departs, signifying his role in matters of death.

Thus it is said: *"War is a cruel instrument,"* and *"War is the arbiter of life and death."* If a general has strategy, the dead may return to life; if he lacks strategy, the living may perish. War is a perilous affair, casting men into death—how is this not akin to mourning rites?

The **Piān Jiāngjūn**, not holding sole authority over killing, occupies a fortunate position to the left. When many are slain, he weeps in sorrow and grief.

The annotation states: *"Because life is precious and war involves conflict, there is compassion for the slain, hence the sorrowful weeping."*

The *Cū* elaborates: *"To seek victory in battle necessitates the slaughter of many. Victory, though achieved, is not praiseworthy, hence the sorrowful weeping."*

For the people are the foundation of the state; if the foundation is secure, the state is at peace. Now, in war, the people are slain, so the compassionate heart feels sorrow, and thus they weep—is this not fitting?

The *Yì* states: *"Those who win through war slaughter many. Moreover, human life—nine heavens divide the qi, ten months nurture the spirit—embracing *yin*, exhaling *yang*, conforming to Heaven and mirroring Earth—among all things, humanity is the most refined. A state’s strength lies in its people, as fish depend on water. Thus the *Shàngshū* [recorded in the *Wǔzǐ zhī gē* (五子之歌)] says: ‘The august ancestor instructed: The people may be approached but not belittled. The people are the foundation of the state; if the foundation is firm, the state is at peace.’ This refers to the time of Tàikāng, who held office without virtue, indulging in unrestrained revelry. Yòu of Yǒuqióng, moved by the people’s suffering, resisted at the Hé River, for his loss of virtue caused the people to abandon him, making the state unstable. Thus, when the people are weak, the state is in peril; when the people unite, the state becomes dominant. Now, if one seeks glory and fame through war, covets land, and slaughters people, driving living souls into death—how can the virtuous and the wise not grieve and mourn?"*

Thus the following passage states: *"When armies clash, the one who weeps in sorrow shall prevail."* Weeping is grief.

Victory in war is treated with mourning rites.

The annotation states: *"Brave and heroic warriors, upon achieving victory, receive titles and stand in the honored right position. Though the right is not a fortunate position, it is treated with mourning rites, as war is an ominous instrument—why must it be marked with mourning attire?"*

The *Cū* explains: *"When a warrior wins through battle, he receives a title, and martial prowess is placed to the right—a position that is not fortunate. Hence it is said that it is treated with mourning rites, but war is merely an ominous instrument. Why must one don mourning garments and lean on a staff to truly call it mourning rites?"* Those who recorded this meaning all claimed such rites existed in antiquity, but upon examining ancient texts, there is no evidence. Thus, this is not recorded.

It further cites the example of *Qín Bó* (秦伯) weeping before his troops—this was grief over defeat, not victory in war.

The *Yì* states: *"Those who win and receive titles hold high rank as **Shàng Jiāngjūn**, also treated with mourning rites. War is an instrument of ill intent, and battle is the means of slaughter. Victory means killing the enemy; defeat means killing one’s own—both are the people."*

The Sage does not grieve without pain. The **Saint** takes this to be sorrowful, the **Noble** takes it to be compassionate—thus it should be treated with mourning rites. The **sāo-zhàng** (hempen mourning garments and staff) are mourning attire. But why must one grieve and pity only when donning such garments? Some claim that in antiquity, when armies marched forth, the **Son of Heaven** would wear plain white robes, weep, and send them off. Yet in the *Li Ji* (Rites) and the *Fen Dian* (Ancient Texts), there is no such account. Since this has no basis, I have clarified it plainly.

The *Dian* refers to the **Five Classics of the Five Emperors**, and the *Fen* refers to the **Three Classics of the Three Sovereigns**.

As for **Qín Bó** weeping before his troops—this is recorded in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, **Lí 32nd Year**: Qin Bó attacked Zheng. The Qin minister **Qí Zǐ** garrisoned Zheng and sent word to Qin: *"The people of Zheng have entrusted me with the keys to their northern gate. If you secretly advance your troops, the state can be taken."* Qin Bó consulted the minister **Jiān Shū**, who said: *"To weary your troops in a surprise attack on a distant land—this is not what I have heard. When your troops are exhausted and the enemy is prepared, how can this succeed? The enemy will surely know of your movements. Even if you march a thousand *lǐ*, who will not know?"* Qin Bó declined.

He summoned **Mèng Míng**, **Xī Qǐ**, and **Bái Yǐ**, ordering them to march from the eastern gate. Jiān Shū wept and said: *"Master Mèng, I see your army depart, but I shall not see it return."* Qin Bó sent a messenger to him: *"How do you know? You may yet live to see your grave’s cypress arch."*

Jiān Shū’s son accompanied the army and wept as he sent them off: *"The Jin will intercept you at **Guāi**, where there are two mounds. The southern mound is the tomb of **Gāo of Xià**, and the northern mound is where **Wén Wáng** took shelter from wind and rain. If you die here, I will gather your bones."*

The Qin army then marched east. Passing through the northern gate of Zhou, the officers removed their helmets and dismounted, with three hundred chariots leaping over the barrier. **Wángsūn Mǎn**, still young, observed this and reported to **Xiāng Wáng**: *"The Qin army is reckless and disrespectful—it will surely be defeated. Recklessness means few strategies; disrespect means arrogance. To enter peril while arrogant, and yet lack strategy—how can it avoid defeat?"*

At **Huá**, a Zheng merchant named **Xián Gāo**, who was traveling to Zhou for trade, encountered them. He sent a chariot covered in white oxhide and twelve oxen to provision the army, while urgently reporting to Zheng. Zheng’s **Mù Gōng** inspected the guest quarters and found them packed with supplies, weapons sharpened, and horses fed. He sent **Wǔ Zǐ** to decline:

*"Your Excellency has lingered in our humble state through winter. Our dried meat and grain are nearly exhausted. As you prepare to depart, Zheng has **Yuán Pù**, just as Qin has **Jù Yòu**. Take its deer and boar to relieve our scarcity—how could you refuse?"*

**Qí Zǐ** fled to Qi, while **Féng Sūn** and **Yáng Sūn** fled to Song. **Mèng Míng** said: *"Zheng is prepared—we cannot hope to succeed. We cannot take it by assault nor besiege it indefinitely. We should return."* They destroyed Huá and retreated.

**Yuán Zhěn** of Jin said: *"Qin defied Jiān Shū and exhausted the people through greed. Heaven aids us. We must not let this opportunity pass, nor spare the enemy. To spare the enemy breeds future calamity; to defy Heaven brings misfortune."* He attacked the Qin army.

**Lè Zhī** protested: *"How can we strike back at Qin before repaying their kindness?"* **Xiān Zhěn** replied: *"Qin did not mourn our late lord and attacked our kin. Qin has been without propriety—what kindness is there? I have heard: to spare the enemy once is a disaster for generations. Considering our descendants, how can this be called serving the dead?"* He issued the order, and the **Jiāng Róng** troops mobilized.

**Xiāng Gōng** donned mourning black, with **Liáng Hóng** as charioteer and **Lái Qíu** as right-hand man. On the **fourth month, xīn-sì**, they defeated the Qin army at **Guāi**, capturing **Bǎilǐ Mèng Míng**, **Xī Qǐ Shù**, and **Bái Yǐ Bǐng**, and returning them.

They then buried **Wén Gōng** in mourning black, and from then on, Jin adopted the mourning black.

**Wén Yīng** pleaded for the lives of the three generals: *"They truly provoked our two lords. If our lord were to eat them, he would not be sated. Why dishonor yourself by punishing them? Let them return to Qin to face execution, fulfilling our lord’s will—what could be better?"* The duke agreed.

**Xiān Zhěn** questioned the Qin prisoners. The duke said: *"The lady has requested their release; I have granted it."* Xiān Zhěn, enraged, said: *"A warrior binds them in the field, yet a woman’s plea sets them free in the capital. This undermines military strength and emboldens the enemy—ruin is inevitable. He spat and turned away."* The duke sent **Yáng Chǔ Fù** to pursue him.

When they reached the River, they were already aboard the boats. The left horse was released, and the Duke’s command was given to present a gift to **Mèng Míng**.

**Mèng Míng** knelt and bowed his head, saying: *"Your lordship’s grace spared me, though I had provoked your drums and bells, and sent me back to face execution in Qin. Even if my lord should slay me, my name would not fade. If, by your lordship’s mercy, I am spared, in three years I shall repay your favor with a bow."*

The **Qin ruler** wore mourning black at the riverbank, facing the departing army and weeping: *"I heeded not **Jiǎn Shū**’s counsel, bringing shame upon these officers. This is my fault alone. I should not have punished **Mèng Míng**. This was my error—what crime did the ministers commit? Moreover, I shall not let one misstep obscure a great virtue. **Jiǎn Shū**’s weeping foretold the army’s certain defeat. My own weeping mourns the defeat of my troops. Both wept not for victory, but for the ruin of their forces."*

The **True Scripture of Dao and Virtue** in the *Broad Explication of the Sage’s Intentions* (卷二十六) concludes thus:

*"To wage war is to delight in slaughter—this a gentleman would never do. The Dao cherishes life; sages follow this principle. Yet victory and defeat in battle both bring harm to men. One may simply restrain oneself and cease warfare—why wait to mourn after killing?*

*To cultivate one’s self: if the five desires assail within, the five spirits grow weary and scattered; if the six emotions surge unchecked, the six senses clash in strife. Qi is depleted, the spirit exhausted—death’s shadow looms near. One must firmly suppress desires and emotions, preserving tranquility and harmony.*

*So too the ruler who governs the realm should not prize the beauty of fine arms. The *True Scripture of Dao and Virtue* ends here."*

To summon the **Wu** [武] to decline: according to the *Zuozhuan* [《左传》], **"Wu"** [之] should be **"Huang"** [皇]. **My Lord** lingers in winter at our humble domain: according to the *Zuozhuan*, **"winter"** [冬] should be **"long"** [久].

---

**The Broad Explication of the Sage’s Intentions** (卷之二十七) – **Master Guangcheng of the Tang Dynasty** (唐广成先生), **Du Guangting** (杜光庭) expounds:

**Chapter Thirty-Two: The Dao/Way is Ever Nameless** (道常无名章)

**Explication:**
The previous chapter elucidates that fine arms bring ill fortune, hence the Dao/Way does not dwell therein.
This chapter reveals that if a sovereign lord upholds the Dao/Way, all things beneath him will submit in reverence.
First, it marks the nameless Dao/Way to clarify the Way;
Next, it speaks of guarding the Way and attaining celestial blessings,
Then it expounds broadly upon its governance and application,
And finally, it illustrates the Way’s descent to demonstrate its efficacy.

**Meaning:**
Though arms may be fine, they are the greatest calamity for all under heaven.
Though **Pu** [朴] is small, it is the greatest foundation for all under heaven.
If a sovereign lord can guard the Way, all things will take him as their revered model.
When the Way’s transformation takes effect, heaven and earth descend blessings.
No need for stern decrees—people naturally harmonize.
The sovereign preserves the power of governance; all things find their proper place.
Ten thousand nations flock in allegiance, like streams converging toward the sea.
Thus, the sovereign who cultivates benevolent transformation
Is not one who prizes the beauty of military might.

**The Dao/Way is ever nameless.**
**Annotation:**
The Way’s essence lies in its application—this is its constancy.
Constancy can respond to all things, yet its responses are not singular,
Hence, at its constancy, there is no name.
**Explication:**
Application of the Way is limitless,
Adapting only to what is sensed—this is the Way’s constancy.
Constancy exists in its application, yet its responses are not singular,
Hence, at its constancy, there is no name—thus it is said: *constancy without name*.
**Meaning:**
The Way’s function is to do nothing while achieving all.
It governs yin and yang, encompassing and nurturing all things.
The **Qian** [乾] moves through it; the **Kun** [坤] finds stability in it.
Its penetration into life is the most universal under heaven,
Its profundity is the most mysterious under heaven.
Application is boundless, circulation endless—
Even the finest blades of grass receive it and flourish,
Heaven and earth gain it to perfect roundness and squareness.
Yet the true constancy of the Way is serene and void,
Profoundly still, beyond all naming.
When words fail to grasp its essence, it is *constancy without name*.

**Pu** [朴], though small, none under heaven dare to subject it.
**Annotation:**
**Pu** [朴] is the wondrous origin.
The wondrous origin is pure and singular, hence it is called *small* yet responds to all.
When its application is perfected, it becomes the greatest, hence none dare to subject the Way to it.
**Explication:**
**Pu** [朴] is the wondrous origin.
When speaking of its universal generation, it is called the Way;
When discussing its pure singularity, it is called **Pu**.
The wondrous origin is pure and singular, hence it is called *small*.
Yet when its application is perfected and it generates all things, it is the greatest.
Hence none dare to subject the Way to it.

**Meaning:**
The Way’s true essence is tranquil and without action.
Hence it is called **Pu**.
What **Pu** generates and perfects through adaptation is called the Way.
The Way and **Pu** are one—
Not one yet one, this is called *true oneness*.
**True oneness** is the most refined of mysteries,
The purest of the pure.
Oneness is not manifold, hence it is called *small*.
With this true oneness, it transforms into myriad forms,
Its greatness is boundless, its height unparalleled—
Who dares to subject the Way to it?
The subject is one who is beneath the sovereign.

The *Spring and Autumn Annals* [《春秋》] states:
Heaven has ten suns, men have ten ranks.
The lower serves the higher; the higher nourishes the divine.
The male is called a subject; the female, a concubine.
Hence, the king’s subjects are the dukes,
The dukes’ subjects are the great officers,
The great officers’ subjects are the knights,
The knights’ subjects are the footmen,
The footmen’s subjects are the laborers,
The laborers’ subjects are the servants,
The servants’ subjects are the attendants,
The attendants’ subjects are the slaves.
Horses have their grooms; cattle have their herdsmen—
All to attend to myriad affairs.
Under all heaven, there is no land not the king’s;
At the king’s borders, there is no subject not his.
Yet from ancient times to this day,
None dare to subject the Way to them.

If a sovereign lord can guard the Way,
All things will naturally submit in reverence.
**Annotation:**
If a sovereign lord can guard the Way’s pure singularity,
Doing nothing yet transforming all,
Then all things will naturally submit in reverence.
**Explication:**
Speaking of a sovereign lord who embraces and guards the wondrous origin’s pure singularity,
Doing nothing yet achieving transformation,
Then the eight **feng** [埏] regions will look upward to his Way,
The four seas will return to his virtue—
Basking in his power and drinking in his harmony,
All will naturally submit in reverence.

**Meaning:**
The sovereign is the exalted one of the four seas.
The lord is the second rank of the five grades.
The Zhou Dynasty established five grades of nobility:
Duke, lord, earl, viscount, and baron.
Ancestral rulers’ institutions had:
The Son of Heaven, the feudal lords, the ministers,
The great officers, and the knights—
Also five grades, yet encompassing the sovereign’s authority.
Their governance of lands, their ceremonial rites, and their laws of punishment
Also had five grades.
Thus, the sovereign rules all under heaven,
The feudal lords govern their respective states,
The ministers, great officers, and knights serve as auxiliary subjects,
Aiding the sovereign.

Speaking of lords who can guard the Way:
Though they are merely holders of land,
If they guard the Way’s transformation of all things,
Then the eight **feng** [埏] regions and the four seas’ people
Will reverence their Way and virtue,
Return to their utmost benevolence,
Bask in their abundant power,
And drink in their harmonizing warmth—
Thus all will naturally submit in reverence.
**Feng** [埏] refers to the borders of sealed domains.
**Bin** [宾] means submission.
When foreign nations submit to civilization, they are treated as guests and submit in reverence.
**Fu** [附] means to follow and submit.

When heaven and earth unite,
They descend sweet dew.
**Explication:**
If a sovereign lord guards the Way to bring about peace,
There will be no disasters or calamities.
The earth is stable; heaven is complete—
The two *qi* [气] harmonize in balance,
Uniting to descend sweet dew in blessing upon the sovereign lord.

**Meaning:**
If feudal lords guard the Way within their states,
And the sovereign guards the Way over all under heaven,
Then they can bring about harmony between heaven and earth,
Without the fluctuations of disasters and calamities.
The earth is stable; heaven is complete—
The natural order is not lost,
The two *qi* [气] harmonize in balance and unity,
Thus descending blessings.
The *Yijing* [《易》] **Tai** [泰] hexagram’s *Tuan* [《彖》] says:
*"When heaven and earth harmonize in balance"* [天地交泰],
And again:
*"When heaven and earth unite, all things flourish"* [天地交而万物通],
*"When the upper and lower harmonize, their intentions align"* [上下交而其志同].

The **Dao** of heaven and earth—
Yin and Yang respond in kind,
Cold and warmth follow in succession,
When the *qi* [气] interact, all things flourish and transform,
Each attaining its proper place.

When all things attain their proper place,
The harmonious *qi* [气] unite in balance,
Then auspicious omens descend.

Sweet dew is the finest dew,
The essence of divine spirits,
The benevolent blessings of virtue,
Its condensation like fat,
Its sweetness like syrup.

One name is *Sweet Dew* [甘露],
Another is *Heaven’s Wine* [天酒].
The *Rites of Combat and Ceremonial Dignity* [《礼斗威仪》] states:
*"When a ruler governs with earthly sovereignty and brings about great peace,*
*Then sweet dew descends."*

The *Omen of the Mandate* [《稽命征》] says:
*"When posthumous titles are conferred with proper names,*
*Then sweet dew descends upon bamboo and cypress."*

The *Harmonizing with the Divine in the Classic of Filial Piety* [《孝经援神契》] declares:
*"When virtue reaches heaven,*
*Then sweet dew descends."*

Sweet dew is the *qi* of perfect balance.
The *Book of the Mandarin’s Crown* [《鹖冠子》] states:
*"The virtue of the Sage*
*Ascends to the **Taiting** [太清],
*Descends to the **Ta’an** [太宁],
*Penetrates all spirits,
*Then sweet dew descends and all things flourish abundantly.*
*To drink of it grants a lifespan of eight hundred years."*

The *Records of Celestial Phenomena* [《天文录》] notes:
*"The star **Tianyu** [天乳] in the **Dixiu** [氐宿] constellation’s north*
*Governed by the sweet dew star,*
*When it shines brightly, sweet dew descends."*

The *Lost Scriptures* [《逸书》] say:
*"Earth stable, heaven complete—*
*This is harmony.*
*It speaks of earth stabilizing its transformations,*
*Heaven fulfilling its decrees,*
*Upper and lower in accord—*
*This is proper balance.*
*When *qi* [气] is disordered, it is **Ling** [凌].*
*When *qi* is perverse, it is **Yi** [沴].*
*When *qi* brings calamity, it is **disaster** [灾].*
*When *qi* brings harm, it is **injury** [害].*
*When *qi* brings auspicious omens, it is **瑞** [瑞].*
*To **attain** [致] is for blessings to come without summoning.*
*None command it, yet it is naturally balanced."*

「Annotations: *注* (zhù) = commentary; *疏* (shū) = exposition; *义* (yì) = interpretation; *始制有名* (shǐzhì yǒumíng) = "first governs named things"; *有名之物* (yǒumíng zhī wù) = "named things/creatures"; *称物平施* (chēngwù píngshī) = "to measure things and distribute them evenly"; *裒* (póu) = "to gather"; *益* (yì) = "to aid"; *惠化* (huìhuà) = "benevolent transformation"; *大同* (dàtóng) = "Great Harmony"; *率土* (shuàitǔ) = "all lands"; *有声* (yǒushēng) = "resounding"; *辟雍* (bìyōng) = "Piyong (ancient educational complex)"; *始制* (shǐzhì) = "first governs"; *制御* (zhìyù) = "to govern"; *崇德* (chóngdé) = "to uphold virtue"; *将知* (jiāngzhī) = "shall know"; *依止* (yīzhǐ) = "to rely and abide"; *殆* (dài) = "danger"; *撝* (chēng) = "to practice humility"; *膺受* (yīngshòu) = "to bear and receive"; *矜功伐善* (jīngōng fáshàn) = "to boast of achievements and claim credit for good deeds"; *憍矜* (jiāngjīng) = "arrogant and proud"; *肆欲* (sìyù) = "indulgent in desires"; *造作多端* (zàozuò duōduān) = "to engage in excessive schemes"; *老君* (lǎojiūn) = "Laozi (the Old Master)"; *在宥* (zàiyòu) = "to be lenient and forgiving"; *副* (fù) = "to conform to"; *天心* (tiānxīn) = "Heaven’s will"; *淫刑* (yínxíng) = "excessive punishments"; *遂性* (suìxìng) = "to fulfill their nature"; *圣旨* (shèngzhǐ) = "imperial decree/sage’s intent».」

---

The commentary states:
*"When sovereigns and kings embrace and safeguard the **One** [精一],*
*Then earth stabilizes, heaven fulfills,*
*Their harmony **attains** [致] proper balance,*
*And thus sweet dew descends in abundance."*

*"The descent of sweet dew*
*Makes the **sagebrush** [萧] and **orchids** [兰] alike flourish,*
*Without need for instruction or command,*
*Yet all is naturally even."*

*"**Stabilizing** [平] means*
*To emulate sovereigns and kings who measure things and distribute them evenly."*

The exposition says:
*"None [莫] means ‘not’ [无].*
*It speaks of Heaven’s descent of sweet dew,*
*Benevolence bestowed without intent,*
*No human decree yet all is naturally balanced as one.*
*Just as sovereigns and kings measure things and distribute them evenly,*
*Without favoritism or partiality."*

*"When benevolent transformation reaches **Great Harmony** [大同],*
*All under Heaven submits without question,*
*From east to west—*
*Why would they not serve?*
*Just as the people of the four quarters*
*Delight in the **Dao/Way** [化] of the **Wen** and **Wu** [文武] kings."*

*"First governing [始制] has a name,*
*And when the name is established,*
*The commentary states:*
*‘When rulers **attain** [致] balance through the Dao,*
*They can first govern named things.’*
*Thus, all named things*
*Shall be fully governed by sovereigns and kings."*

The exposition further explains:
*"**Govern** [制] means **to control** [御].*
*Named things [有名] are those*
*That bear names across all lands.*
*Fully [尽] means complete possession.*
*It speaks of sovereigns and kings embracing and safeguarding the One,*
*Then Heaven descends auspicious omens,*
*Benevolent transformation without intent,*
*And all is naturally even as one.*
*Thus, they can first govern named things,*
*All creatures submit to virtuous rule,*
*And so named things are fully possessed by kings and sovereigns."*

The interpretation says:
*"Sovereigns and kings of the Dao,*
*Heaven and Earth unite in virtue,*
*Auspicious omens respond,*
*Upper and lower realms in harmony without division.*
*All four seas submit,*
*Named things all return to benevolent transformation.*
*The four seas are*
*The lands sovereigns and kings govern.*
*Expanding the Dao and establishing virtue,*
*All are transformed by it.*
*Within their borders,*
*And along the shores of their domains,*
*Who is not the sovereign’s and king’s subject?*
*Just as mountains and forests do not desire birds and beasts,*
*Yet their lushness and depth draw them to dwell there;*
*Just as rivers and lakes do not desire fish and dragons,*
*Yet their vastness and expanse invite them to abide;*
*Just as kings and sovereigns do not desire named things,*
*Yet their virtue and benevolence cause named things to submit;*
*Just as cultivating the self does not desire the Dao,*
*Yet its emptiness and tranquility invite the Dao to return.*
*All things respond and gather,*
*Depending on what is cultivated.*
*Natural balance and universal submission,*
*All under Heaven in peace,*
*Depend on what is transformed.*

*"The return of goodness to oneself,*
*The resonance of the Dao,*
*The compliance of things,*
*All depend on upholding virtue [崇德].*
*This is the knowledge of **stopping** [止].*
*Knowing **stopping** prevents **danger** [殆]."*

The commentary states:
*"If sovereigns and kings can govern named things,*
*Then those named things shall know*
*To rely and abide in sovereigns and kings of the Dao,*
*And thus avoid all perils and dangers."*

The exposition says:
*"**Danger** [殆] means perilous and precarious.*
*When sovereigns and kings abide by the Dao and transform the people,*
*All things submit as guests.*
*Then those named things shall know*
*To rely and abide in sovereigns and kings of the Dao,*
*And thus avoid all perils and dangers.*
*Hence it is said:*
*‘Knowing stopping prevents danger.’*

The interpretation says:
*"When the Dao of sovereigns and kings harmonizes with Heaven,*
*And inner and outer realms are at peace,*
*Within their borders,*
*All living and growing named things*
*Follow their lands and become the sovereign’s and king’s subjects.*
*Things submit to the realm of the Dao,*
*Thus there is no peril or ruin.*
*Following the **spring and summer** [春夏] to grow,*
*Conforming to the **autumn and winter** [秋冬] to decline,*
*Neither Heaven nor Earth will abandon them,*
*No northern blight nor southern pestilence will afflict them,*
*They will not be invaded by external foes,*
*Nor struck by excessive punishments,*
*Each fulfilling its nature—*
*What perils or dangers could there be?*
*This is the **imperial decree/sage’s intent** [圣旨].’*

*"Now, if sovereigns and kings*
*Transform the people through the Dao,*
*And respond to Heaven’s auspicious omens,*
*If the people submit to their transformation,*
*And all under Heaven is in balance,*
*Then sovereigns and kings must*
*Abide by the Dao, practice humility [撝谦],*
*Bear and receive the **auspicious omens** [符瑞],*
*Know stopping, and be cautious,*
*To conform to Heaven’s will,*
*And thus avoid all perils and dangers.*

*If they see Heaven’s auspicious omens,*
*And the people’s harmony,*
*Yet grow arrogant in their hearts,*
*Change their resolve,*
*And boast of achievements while claiming credit for good deeds,*
*Then the omens cannot withstand their pride,*
*And their own lives shall be in peril."*

*"In ancient times,*
*Zhou’s last king saw small birds giving birth to large birds,*
*And took it as an omen of national prosperity,*
*Yet his arrogance and indulgence led to excessive schemes,*
*And thus his downfall.*
*Laozi feared that future emperors and kings,*
*Relying on auspicious omens,*
*Would become proud and arrogant,*
*And thus warned them:*
*‘Know stopping, so as to avoid danger.’*

*"The Dao in all under Heaven*
*Is like rivers and streams to the great seas.*
*The commentary states:*
*‘Heaven descends sweet dew,*
*To bestow auspicious omens upon virtuous rulers,*
*And when it is lenient and forgiving to all under Heaven,*
*Heaven responds accordingly.’"*

The Dao in all under Heaven flows like rivers and streams to the great seas—such is its course.

**Commentary:**
Here, it concludes that if lords and kings uphold the Dao, Heaven will surely respond. Thus it says: *"If a virtuous ruler governs with benevolent virtue, he naturally brings about Great Peace. The harmonious qi moves Heaven, and auspicious omens will surely respond—just as rivers and streams flow into the seas."*

**Meaning:**
Lords and kings who uphold the Dao, their virtue harmonizing with Heaven, their benevolent transformations uniting all—this is how they inspire Great Peace. Heaven’s auspicious signs, like rivers flowing to the sea, are the will of the Sage.

Now, if a lord or king, moved by Heaven’s omens, wins the people’s hearts, and all under the Four Seas submit as subjects, yet he further, in response to these omens, remains vigilant night and day, ever cautious and diligent, each day more prudent than the last—then there will be no peril. Distant peoples will admire his virtuous governance, sending envoys as tribute-bearers, like rivers converging toward the sea, waves rushing to the ocean. Near and far, they will flock, and the nation’s fate will flourish.

For those who govern their bodies, the heart is the sovereign, the viscera the lords. If one calms the heart’s king, embracing and guarding the True Dao, then Heaven and Earth’s primordial essence-qi will be absorbed and transformed within the body, becoming jade nectar and sweet dew. The Three-in-One Spirit will drink with one’s own essence, blending and harmonizing within—inner and outer balanced, without need for forced breathing or cultivation. Dwelling in the Hall of Jade and the Chamber of Precious Stones, the thirty-six thousand yin-yang deities will stand complete, settled and undispersed. Then the body will know no perilous calamity, the life no untimely end—ascending to the Upper Pure, drifting freely like rivers flowing to the sea, without obstruction.

---
**Knowing Others: The Third Chapter of Wisdom**

**Commentary:**
The previous chapter showed how lords and kings upholding the Dao make all things submit. This chapter explains how those who submit serve a virtuous ruler—all because of self-knowledge and self-mastery. Self-knowledge brings clarity; self-mastery brings completeness and strength. It concludes with the warning: *"To die yet not perish, to act without violating Heaven’s order."*

**Meaning:**
Lords and kings uphold the Dao and transform all things, making them return to their source, because they possess clarity of self-knowledge and strength in self-mastery. Content yet not greedy, diligent in the Dao, they align with Heaven and Earth, never straying from their nature. Thus they fulfill their allotted measure, suffering no untimely death, and remain in perfect harmony, never violating Heaven’s decrees.

Knowing others is wisdom; knowing oneself is enlightenment.

**Commentary:**
Wisdom is the ability to discern and use knowledge of things; enlightenment is the radiant insight that perceives the subtle.

Wisdom has its limits; enlightenment knows no bounds.

**Commentary:**
Knowledge is recognition and discernment. When the heart aligns with its object, innate knowledge arises—this is called knowing the law.

**Meaning:**
The heart’s illumination is all-pervasive. Knowledge arises with phenomena; without phenomena, knowledge ceases. Thus, when one employs the heart’s wisdom, it is through engagement with phenomena.

If the object is pure, the heart and knowledge are pure; if the object is corrupt, the heart and knowledge are corrupt. Suffering, joy, life, death, fortune, misfortune, good, and evil—all stem from this.

Thus, entering an empty chamber, the heart of desire arises; entering a sacred temple, the heart of reverence arises. A thousand phenomena draw the heart, scattering it with them. How can one not be cautious, when good and evil are so intertwined?

Wisdom lies in knowing others—*The Book of Documents* says: *"To know others is to be wise."*

In knowing others, consider the Duke of Song’s wisdom. Song’s Duke Xuan abandoned his own son Ji to establish his younger brother Ru as heir, making him Duke Mu. In the third year of Duke Huan of Lu, Duke Mu of Song fell ill and summoned the Grand Marshal Kongfu, saying: *"My predecessor abandoned Ji to establish me as ruler. I dare not forget this. If, by your virtue, you can preserve your life to the end, and my predecessor asks why Ji was abandoned, what answer shall you give? I entrust you to uphold the state. Even in death, I will have no regret."*

Kongfu replied: *"The ministers wish to establish your son Ping as heir."*

Duke Mu said: *"No. My predecessor deemed me worthy to rule the state. If I abandon virtue and refuse to yield, I would betray my predecessor’s foundation—how could I claim wisdom?"* He sought to honor his predecessor’s virtuous decree, striving not to fail. He then sent his son Ping to reside in Zheng and yielded the throne to Ji, who became Duke Zang.

The Sage said: *"Duke Xuan of Song may be called one who truly knew others. He established Duke Mu, and his son inherited the throne, receiving the name Yi-fu. The* Shang Ode *says: ‘Receiving the Mandate of Shang, all was fitting; a hundred blessings were bestowed upon him.’ This is what is meant by supreme knowledge of others."*

The text reads:

*"The Commentary says: ‘When people employ their minds to discern the good and evil of others, the common folk call that wisdom.’ But if one reflects inward and examines without relying on the mind, perceiving the truth of things without contrived knowledge, and can thus be—this is called **‘mingliao’** (明了). Hence it is said: ‘He who knows others is wise; he who knows himself is enlightened’ (明了).

*‘Yi’* (义) says: ‘The worldly employ their minds in response to external circumstances, distinguishing others’ virtues and vices, measuring their own strengths and weaknesses, seeking what they do not know rather than what they do, abandoning themselves to emulate others, and flaunting their cleverness to gain favor—this is gathering the varied people of the realm to delight in the **‘yìyì’** (役役, servile flattery) of those who curry approval, discarding the **‘tiándàn wúwéi’** (恬澹无为, tranquil and effortless) to favor the **‘hēnghēng zhī yì’** (哼哼之意, petty scheming)—such men are the ones who disrupt the **Dao** (道) and bring chaos to the world. Their wisdom is indeed a flaw.

*Thus*, they blind the clarity of the sun and moon above, erode the essence of mountains and rivers below, disrupt the harmony of the four seasons within, and even the smallest creatures—worms, insects, and the tiniest of life—lose their natural ways. The Master said to **Yán Huí** (颜回): ‘Do not listen with your ears, but listen with your mind; do not listen with your mind, but listen with your **qi** (气).’ To forget wisdom in wisdom, to forget knowledge in knowledge, to observe the wonder and abide in the **‘wú’** (无, non-duality)—this is **‘mingliao’** (明了). This is the **‘Xīnzhāi’** (心斋, mental fasting) that **Zhuāngzǐ** (庄子) attributes to the Master’s words to **Yán Huí**.

*He who overcomes others has strength*; *he who overcomes himself is powerful* (强).
*The Annotation says*: ‘Those who can conquer others through **‘quánzhì’** (权智, cunning and expedience) may rightly be called strong.’ But those who can conquer their own minds, making them **‘róuruò’** (柔弱, soft and yielding), are the ones who truly preserve their **‘qiáng’** (强, power). Hence the passage below says: ‘To hold fast to softness is power; softness overcomes hardness, weakness overcomes strength.’ Thus it is said: *‘He who overcomes himself is powerful’*.

*‘Yi’* (义) says: ‘Some men wield the authority of their lords to dominate others, wielding their might over the people so that all stand in awe—this is called strength. Yet they do not know the **Dao** (道) of **‘wúwéi’** (无为, non-action), nor do they cultivate their own hearts. When the heart is without action, the will becomes soft and weak; when the heart is empty and the will feeble, no force dares intrude—this is true power. He who overcomes others exhausts his strength and loses his influence, and thus meets his end; he who overcomes himself enters the **‘míng’** (冥, profound stillness) of the **Dao** and aligns with its essence, and thus attains **‘xiān’** (仙, transcendence).

*He who knows contentment is rich*; *he who perseveres in action has resolve*.
*The Annotation says*: ‘He who knows to be content and does not covet may rightly be called rich. He who strives with unyielding effort, persevering in self-awareness and never wavering, may rightly be called one of firm resolve.’

*The Commentary says*: ‘Contentment lies in the heart. If the heart knows contentment, then there is no craving, even if one dines on coarse rice in a gourd and dwells in a narrow lane—unshaken, one finds sufficiency, and thus may be called rich. If one strives with tireless effort, never flagging, maintaining self-awareness and resolve without relenting, this is one of firm resolve.’

*‘Yi’* (义) says: ‘Greed and frugality, virtue and corruption—these all arise from the heart. He whose heart is content, whether **Yán Huí** (颜回) with his single gourd of drink or **Yáng Xióng** (杨雄) with his ten thousand pieces of gold, remains unchanged in his joy and ever content. But he whose heart is never satisfied, though he hoards the exclusive profits of **Shēn Hóu** (申侯) or fills his courtyard with the finest carriages and silks of **Sì Tài** (驷泰), has never truly known contentment. Thus **Yán Huí** and **Yáng Xióng** may rightly be called rich.

*He who perseveres in good deeds, guards the **Dao** without deviation, may be called one who overcomes himself and is powerful—one whose resolve never falters or changes*.
*True power lies in the practice of the **Dao***.
*When greatness has the **Dao**, it conquers without battle; when smallness has the **Dao**, it gains without strife*.
*To act with sincerity in the **Dao** and fortify one’s resolve—this is true power*.
*The **Yìjīng** (易) says: ‘The virtuous person strengthens themselves without ceasing.’*

**‘Zhuānshí’** (箪食, coarse rice in a gourd) refers to what *The Analects* say: ‘How excellent was **Yán Huí**! Coarse rice in a gourd, water in a ladle, dwelling in a narrow lane—others could not bear his hardships, yet **Yán Huí** remained unchanged in his joy.’ **Zhuān** (箪) is a small basket; **piáo** (瓢) is a gourd. The **‘lòuxiàng’** (陋巷, narrow lane) is a humble dwelling. It speaks of **Yán Huí**’s enduring poverty while he abides in the **Dao** and finds joy within.

*He who does not lose their place endures*.
*The Annotation says*: ‘If one knows contentment and strives with perseverance, never losing their true path, then they endure in the **Dao**.’

*The Commentary further explains*: ‘If one’s actions never stray from their proper place, then they can endure for long.’

*‘Yi’* (义) says: ‘He who knows contentment and does not covet, who finds joy in poverty and the **Dao**, who strives in good deeds and never deviates from their true nature—when all their actions align with the seasons and they find their place naturally, they dwell in harmony and thus endure for long.’ The **Yìjīng** says: ‘If one does not steadfastly uphold their **‘dé’** (德, virtue/power), they may face disgrace in what they inherit.’ Thus, one’s conduct must be rooted in enduring constancy, never losing their place.

*He who loses their place must invite misfortune*.
*As in the case of the **Tàishū Dāng** (郑太叔段, Duke Zang’s younger brother), who was indulged without restraint, and when **Zhuānggōng** (庄公) would not heed the warning of **Jì Zhōng** (祭仲), the great minister, who said: ‘It would be better to establish his place early, lest his ambition grow unchecked and become difficult to curb. Even creeping weeds cannot be easily removed—how much more so a favored younger brother!’
**Zhuānggōng** did not comply. Later, **Tàishū Dāng** (段) commanded the western and northern border regions to pledge allegiance to him, encroaching upon the land as far as **Bìnyán** (禀延). He then fortified his city walls, gathered his people, polished his armor, and prepared his chariots and soldiers, intending to attack **Zhèng** (郑). The duke ordered **Zǐ Fēng** (子封) to lead three hundred chariots and strike against **Tàishū Dāng** in **Yān** (鄢). The duke’s forces marched against him in **Yān**. In the fifth month, **Tàishū Dāng** fled to **Gōng** (恭), and the duke’s army defeated him.

*It was because of **Zhuānggōng**’s mother, **Wǔ Jiāng** (武姜), that he was born in a dream-like state and named **‘wùshēng’** (寤生, awakened birth). Thus she came to hate **Zhuānggōng** and love **Tàishū Dāng** (段). When **Dāng** (段) sought to attack **Zhèng** (郑), **Wǔ Jiāng** intended to aid him.
