But after **Zhuānggōng**’s victory over **Dāng**, he exiled **Wǔ Jiāng** to **Chéngyǐng** (城颖) and swore to her: ‘Until we reach the **‘Huángquán’** (黄泉, underworld), we shall never meet again.’"*

Later, **Zhuānggōng** regretted his actions. The **Yǐnggǔ** (颖谷) border official **Kǎochóu** (考叔), upon seeing him abandon the feast and leave the meat uneaten, advised **Zhuānggōng** to take back his mother. He dug a tunnel down to the spring, allowing **Wǔ Jiāng** to reunite with **Tàishū Dāng** secretly, restoring their mother-son bond as before.

The *Spring and Autumn Annals* recorded: *"The Duke of **Zhèng** subdued **Dāng** at **Yān**,"* criticizing his failure to uphold proper governance.

This passage argues that allowing **Tàishū Dāng**’s transgressions to escalate until they overflowed before acting was a mistake—one that failed to address the root cause. Had **Dāng** not strayed from his proper place, how could such calamity have befallen him?

*"To die without perishing is longevity."* **Annotation:** *"Death"* refers to the natural end of one’s allotted fate; *"perishing"* denotes untimely ruin; *"longevity"* signifies the fulfillment of one’s destined span.

*"He who knows others yet surpasses them will invite misfortune. He who knows sufficiency and strengthens his essence aligns with the Dao’s natural order. Those who align with the Dao’s order die without perishing—that is, they fulfill their destined span and may be called long-lived."*

**Exegesis:** *"Death"* refers to the natural end of one’s allotted fate; *"perishing"* denotes untimely ruin; *"longevity"* signifies the fulfillment of one’s destined span. It speaks of yielding to nature’s harmony, avoiding excess, and letting go in accordance with the Dao—thus completing one’s allotted time and being called long-lived. If one does not temper excess, even if **Shàn Bào** (单豹) retains the vigor of a child or **Zhāng Yì** (张毅) enjoys noble stature, they fail to complete their natural course—how then can they be called long-lived?

Thus **Zhuāngzi** said: *"None are longer-lived than the stillborn child, while **Péngzǔ** (彭祖) dies young."*

**Explanation:** Between heaven and earth, life must give way to death. Life is the harmony of heaven and earth; death is their natural fulfillment. To dwell in harmony and submit to nature is to align with the Dao. To oppose this is but untimely ruin.

The *Hé Tú* (河图) states: *"Man is granted a measure by heaven—forty-three thousand two hundred breaths, governing the day; one hundred twenty cycles, governing the year. This is the allotted span of mortal life. Those who attain the Dao of the Golden Elixir may extend beyond it. Those lacking cultivation suffer premature decline."*

The *Huángtíng Jīng* (黄庭经) declares:
*"A hundred twenty years may yet be reclaimed,
Beyond that, guarding the Dao is hard.
Only with the nine-refined, eight-essenced elixir,
And preserving the seven primal essences,
Can the radiance of sun and moon heal old decay."*

This shows that through cultivation, one may prolong life. But if one adheres to their natural endowment, yielding to heaven’s harmony, born in accordance with the Dao and departing in accordance with the Dao—this is life. If one resists, this is death. If one exhausts their allotted span, they may be called long-lived. Otherwise, they perish prematurely.

As **Zhuāngzi** says in *"Dá Shēng"* (达生):
*"Dàikāi* (田开) told **Zhōu Wēi Gōng** (周威公): ‘The diviner **Zhù Shèn** (祝肾) said: *Those who nurture life well do so like tending sheep—watching their rear and urging them forward.* There was a man named **Shàn Bào** in **Lǔ**, who lived in caves and drank from streams, sharing no gains with others. At seventy, he still had the complexion of a child—yet was devoured by a hungry tiger. There was **Zhāng Yì**, whose high-born family was renowned; none dared approach him. Yet he died of fever at forty. **Bào** nourished his inner self while his outer form perished; **Yì** cultivated his outer form while illness consumed his inner essence. These two failed to urge their rear—meaning they clung to one-sided practices, failing to harmonize with the Dao’s fullness. To urge the rear is to discard what is lacking. These two did not complete their natural course and thus perished young."*

To grasp the essence of life’s transformation, one should neither rejoice in living nor fear death—then the stillborn child is long-lived, and **Péngzǔ** dies young.

In *"Qí Wù"* (齐物), **Zhuāngzi** says:
*"Nothing is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet **Tàishān** (太山) is small. None are longer-lived than the stillborn child, yet **Péngzǔ** dies young. Heaven and earth coexist with me, and all things are one with me."*

The first autumn hair to grow is called *"autumn hair."* Those who die before nineteen are called stillborn. This illustrates how the Dao inverts conventional wisdom. In human affairs, the small seek to aspire, the great grow arrogant. But from the Dao’s perspective, there is neither excess nor deficiency—they are one in essence.

*"Death"* is called *"bèng"* (崩) for a **Son of Heaven**, *"hōng"* (薨) for a **marquess**, *"zú"* (卒) for a **high official**, *"bùlù"* (不禄) for a **scholar**, and *"sǐ"* (死) for commoners. Though death and life are decreed by fate, they also depend on one’s conduct. The virtuous observe their actions to discern whether their end will be long or untimely.

The *Yì Jīng* (易经) *Lǚ* (履) hexagram states: *"Observe the footprints and examine the omens."* This is the principle.

In the eleventh year of **Lí** (僖), the *Spring and Autumn Annals* records that **Zhōu Shàngwáng** (周襄王) sent **Nèishǐ Guò** (内史过) to confer a mandate on **Jìn Huì Gōng** (晋惠公). **Huì Gōng** received the mandate but dropped it in disrespect. **Guò** returned and told the king: *"The Duke of **Jìn** will have no heirs."* The king bestowed the mandate, yet he dropped it upon receiving the auspicious token—first abandoning himself, how could he expect succession?

*"Gift"* is the foundation of a state; *"respect"* is the vehicle of gift. Without respect, gift cannot be upheld; without gift, ruler and subjects fall into chaos—how then can the state endure?

In the fourteenth year, **Huì Gōng** fought **Qín** at **Hán Yuán** (韩原) and was captured. He died in the twenty-third year—just as **Guò** and **Shù Jiān** (叔詹) had foretold.

In the same year, **Chǔ** attacked **Sòng** and withdrew. The people of **Zhèng** entertained them with nine offerings, using the rites reserved for **Zhōu’s** highest nobles—each course featuring a hundred dishes, with six sets of **biān dòu** (笾豆). After the feast, at night, they secretly took two daughters of **Sòng Wén Gōng** (宋文公) back to **Chǔ**. **Shù Jiān** said: *"The King of **Chǔ** will not die of old age."* The rites concluded without proper distinction—this could not be called proper. How then could he subdue the other lords? Thus it was known he would not achieve hegemony. Later, he was indeed defeated at **Chéngpú** (城濮) and killed by **Shāng Shèn** (商臣).

Thus, the virtuous person examines the conduct of others, and thereby knows whether they will live long or die young. How much more so for those who cultivate the **Dao/Way** and nourish the **yuanhé** (元和)—how could they fail to attain longevity?

---

**Moral and True Scripture: Broad Explication of Sacred Meaning, Volume Twenty-Eight**
*Narrated by Master Guangcheng of Tang, Du Guangting*

**Chapter Thirty-Four: "The Dao Flows"**

**Exegesis:**
The previous chapter elucidates the sovereign who follows the **Dao/Way**, attaining self-knowledge and self-mastery. This chapter expounds that those who accomplish great and luminous deeds do so by adhering to the **Dao/Way**, forgetting their own contributions.

It begins with *"The Dao flows"* (大道泛兮), demonstrating that it transcends all boundaries, left or right. Next, it states *"The deed accomplished, yet not possessed"* (功成不有), clarifying that greatness and smallness alike cannot claim it as their own. Hence, the Sage, when uplifting the Sage, does not exalt himself, thereby achieving great and luminous deeds.

**Explication:**
Having clarified that the sovereign who follows the **Dao/Way** attains self-mastery and longevity, we now illustrate his virtue as vast as the **Dao/Way**, unobstructed—neither claiming its deeds, nor relying on its manifestations, nor boasting of its grandeur. Thus, he fulfills great undertakings.

The **Dao/Way** flows—its application is flexible, unbound by direction. *Feng* (封) means boundary; *zhěn* (畛) refers to the paths between fields. Things arise and complete themselves without refusal or possession, neither great nor small. The Sage’s conduct is all-encompassing, unconcerned with personal exaltation, thus achieving true grandeur.

**The Dao Flows, Left and Right:**
**Annotation:** The **Dao/Way** flows—unrestricted yet responsive to all things, neither favoring left nor right.

**Exegesis:** *Feng* (泛) signifies unrestrained. The **Dao/Way**, as a principle, is neither yin nor yang, neither soft nor hard. It flows unrestrained, responding to all phenomena, adaptable to left or right, without partiality.

Thus, *Zhuangzi* says: *"The **Dao/Way** was never confined to boundaries."*

**Explication:** The essence of the **Dao/Way**—congealed, it becomes the True; diffused, it manifests as myriad transformations. It flows without attachment. Like an empty boat, it lacks solid substance; though not obscured, it is not dim—this is not yin. Though not blazing, it is not bright—this is not yang. It sustains heaven and bears earth, vigorous yet fluid like a dragon’s movement—this is not softness. It harmonizes and adapts to all things, penetrating the finest details—this is not hardness. It can manifest or conceal itself, be subtle or evident, unrestrained in its applications. It shapes all forms without discrimination, responding to all phenomena. It permeates all realms without confinement, adaptable to left or right. Unified in its penetration, it serves as the model for all under heaven, without partiality.

Unbounded, it knows no limits—dissolving and dispersing. In emptiness, it returns. In non-possession, it generates all transformations.

*Zhuangzi’s* **"Equivalence of All Things"** states:
*"The ancient True Persons—how far did their knowledge extend? How did they reach such heights? Some say they arrived at the point where nothing yet existed—this is the ultimate, the complete, the unexcelled. Nothing yet existed.*

*Next, they recognized existence, yet no boundaries. This speaks to the initial division of heaven and earth, where life arose within, all things flourished, and pure nature remained unspoiled, untouched by artificiality—thus, no attachments formed.*

*Next, they recognized no right or wrong. Once distinctions arose, the **Dao/Way** began to falter. When the **Dao/Way** falters, partiality emerges.*

*The scholar who cultivates himself must embody the **Dao/Way**, maintaining an empty mind, free from attachments, to attain its subtlety. Governing the realm, he must act naturally, in accordance with the **Dao/Way**, aligning with the great and returning to ultimate principle."*

All things rely on it for life, yet it does not refuse.
**Exegesis:** All things under heaven depend on the **Dao/Way**’s generative function to fulfill their nature. Though the **Dao/Way** generates and transforms with wondrous spontaneity, it does not toil in exhaustion. It is as if things do not even acknowledge the **Dao/Way**’s labor.

**Explication:**
The height of heaven is sustained by the **Dao/Way’s qi**; the depth of earth is borne by the **Dao/Way’s qi**; the proliferation of all things is contained by the **Dao/Way’s qi**. Without the **Dao/Way**’s transformative **qi**, how could such vastness, grandeur, and abundance be achieved? Through the **Dao/Way**’s transformations, all things attain their being—generation upon generation, fully realized.

The **Dao/Way** generates things without action; it transforms things without effort. Though generation and transformation arise from the **Dao/Way**, the **Dao/Way** does not weary from its labor, nor do things repay it for its benevolence. It is like rain and dew—things are nourished below without gratitude, and the rain and dew do not claim credit for their giving.

Thus, the Sage-ruler governs the people, benefits the worthy, and aids all things, mirroring the **Dao/Way**’s generative power and the nourishment of rain and dew. The Sage forgets his deeds above; the people forget imperial might below—thus aligning with ultimate transformation.

**The deed accomplished, yet not possessed.**
**Annotation:** All things rely on the **Dao/Way**’s spontaneous operation for generation and transformation, yet the **Dao/Way** does not claim possession of them.

**Exegesis:** *Function* (功) refers to the **Dao/Way**’s generative power. Though the **Dao/Way**’s generative function is complete, it does not name the things as its own. Another interpretation: Though the **Dao/Way**’s generative function is fulfilled, it never claims possession—this is the meaning of *forgetting function*.

**Explication:**
Regarding possession—all things receive their forms from the **Dao/Way’s qi**. When things attain completion, it is the **Dao/Way**’s function. Were it not for the **Dao/Way’s qi**, the generative function would fail.

**The Dao’s wondrous essence is nameless and void of possession,**
**Its wondrous function is boundless and ceaseless.**

**When things are complete, the Dao does not rely on its own strength,**
**When things are born, the Dao does not claim their generative virtue/power.**
**It neither clings to things as its own virtue/power,**
**Nor seizes them as its own possession.**
**Possession and non-possession are both extinguished,**
**All virtue/power is utterly forgotten—**
**Not only is the virtue/power of generating things forgotten,**
**But all things’ very existence is forgotten as well.**

**It cherishes and nurtures all things without claiming lordship,**
**Yet this cannot be called small.**
**Annotation:** It cherishes all things, yet does not rule over them.
**Toward things, it has no desires—**
**Yet this cannot be called small.**

**Exegesis:** This is a *phonetic exegesis* (声解义).
When it is said *this can be called small*, it means *this cannot be called small*.
The Dao generates all things,
Cherishes and nurtures them to perfection,
Yet does not rule over them.
Toward all things, it harbors no desire—
Could this be the Dao’s narrowness?
Thus, when it is said *this can be called small*, it means *this cannot be called small*.

**Explication:**
The *phonetic exegesis* is like when scholars debate whether something *can* be named—
It is precisely *what cannot be named*.
Examining this further, the scripture says *this can be called small*—
It means *this cannot be called small*.
The Dao’s generative transformation encompasses myriad categories,
Its harmonizing *qi* pervades everywhere without omission,
Nurturing and sustaining them,
Bringing them to completion and growth,
Its loving protection is profound,
Its nurturing virtue/power is universal.
It does not rule over them,
Yet each thing fulfills its own nature,
It harbors no desire toward things—
The virtue/power of containing and nurturing is vast indeed.
This is the sage’s interpretation.

Now, I elucidate:
**All sentient and formed beings—**
**Flying, swimming, moving, and growing,**
**From the smallest blades of grass to the mightiest mountains—**
**The Dao’s *qi* covers and nurtures them,**
**Its strength knows no limits.**
**It cherishes and sustains without claiming lordship,**
**Things depend on the Dao yet do not acknowledge its virtue/power.**

**Though the great *peng* bird has a vast form,**
**It still rides the Dao’s transformation.**
**Even the tiniest moths and insects**
**Rely on the Dao’s shaping virtue/power.**

**Thus, even the smallest hair of autumn—**
**When the Dao’s *qi* abides, it is warm and tender, moist and nourishing;**
**When the Dao’s *qi* departs, it withers and decays.**
**The Dao does not abandon even the smallest hair—**
**This can be called small;**
**It fills the universe—**
**This can be called great;**
**It does not rule over things—**
**This can be called forgetting virtue/power.**
**This is the Dao’s function.**

**It can be called small, it can be called great,**
**Yet it is neither small nor great,**
**Nothing is not small, nothing is not great.**
**All things return to it without its ruling—**
**This can be called great.**
**Annotation:** It cherishes all things, thus all things return to it.
**Though there are myriad differences among things, it does not rule—**
**This can be called great.**
**It cannot be called great,**
**For it is neither small nor great,**
**Thus it is difficult to name.**

**Exegesis:** *All things return to it*—
They return to the Dao’s generative virtue/power.
It is said that all things return to the Dao,
Yet the Dao does not rule over them,
And yet all things exist.
It casts them off yet does not reclaim—
Could this be the Dao’s lack of vastness?
Thus, when it is said *this can be called great*, it means *this cannot be called great*.

**The scripture says *it can be named left or right*—**
**Hence it is neither small nor great.**
**Neither small nor great is indeed difficult to name.**
**The annotation says *myriad differences*—**
This is from *Zhuangzi*’s text.

**Explication:**
The Dao generates and transforms all things,
Things receive their generative virtue/power,
Each returns to virtue/power from the Dao,
Yet the Dao does not rule over them.
It allows things to follow their own nature,
This is not the Dao’s greatness—
Thus, the *phonetic exegesis* says *this can be called great*—
Yet it is not small,
And when it is said *this can be called great*—
It is not great either.
Neither great nor small is difficult to name—
This is what cannot be named.
*Myriad differences*—
From *Zhuangzi*’s *Tian Di Pian* (天地篇), where Confucius says:
*The Dao covers and sustains all things,*
**How vast and grand it is!**
**The gentleman must not fail to carve his heart to conform to it—**
**This is called *wuwei* (无为).**
**To act without action is called *Tian* (天),**
**To speak without speech is called *De* (德).**
**To love and benefit people is called *Ren* (仁),**
**To embrace differences yet remain unified is called great (大),**
**To act without extreme divergence is called broad (宽),**
**To encompass myriad differences is called *Fu* (富).**
**This means though all things differ,**
**The Dao alone remains unified—**
**This is the sage’s interpretation.**

Now, I elucidate:
**The great Dao conceals its virtue/power and hides its name,**
**Silent and formless—**
**This can be called small.**
**All things, when born, generate themselves,**
**When transformed, transform themselves,**
**The Dao allows each to fulfill its nature,**
**Yet does not rule over them—**
**This can be called great.**

**It is also like the sovereign,**
**Who by the Dao nurtures the people,**
**By virtue/power governs the citizens,**
**Observes the harmony of the six *qi* (六气),**
**Follows the commands of the four seasons (四时),**
**Strengthens benevolence with sincerity,**
**Guides conduct with righteousness,**
**Shows love with kindness,**
**Orders with propriety,**
**Teaches with trust,**
**Encourages with rewards—**
**Even when cutting a single blade of grass or felling a tree,**
**He adheres to its proper time,**
**Diligently and warmly,**
**Fearful they might lose their place—**
**This can be called small.**

**When things fulfill their nature,**
**The people find their fitting way,**
**Rulers and subjects rejoice together,**
**Heaven and earth harmonize in tranquility,**
**The sovereign is humble and reverent,**
**Yielding virtue/power to Heaven,**
**Not claiming it as his own,**
**Not ruling over them—**
**This can be called great.**

**Thus, the sage never claims greatness,**
**And so achieves true greatness.**
**Annotation:** Therefore, the sage follows the Dao and forgets virtue/power,
Does not exalt himself as grand,
And so fulfills his grandest deeds.

**Exegesis:** The sage who governs the world,
Spreads virtue/power and bestows blessings,
Establishes pure and harmonizing winds,
Things fulfill their nature in generation and transformation.
Following the Dao, forgetting virtue/power,
Not exalting himself as great—
Thus his vast achievements can be called great,
And his sage virtue/power can be called great,
Because he does not claim greatness—
Thus he attains this exalted greatness.

**The scholar who governs his body**
**Floats without attachment,**
**Like clouds without form,**
**Water without will,**
**He may turn left or right,**
**Follow square or round,**
**Not bound by fixed ways,**
**Yet reflects all that comes before him.**

**Though myriad things are broad, he does not constrain his mind to favor them,**
**Though countless benefits arise, he does not boast his virtue/power of rescue,**
**His kindness extends to all living things,**
**Never hoarding it for himself,**
**All good virtues converge in him,**
**Yet he does not claim them as his own.**
**Thus he reveals the virtue/power that is neither small nor great,**
**And is free from praise or self-deprecation,**
**So he may align with the Dao/Way’s full and true essence.**

**Chapter Thirty-Five: On Grasping the Great Symbol**

**Exegesis:**
The sage who governs the world does not claim greatness,
Yet achieves his grandest deeds—
For he grasps the **Great Symbol**,
And so the world submits to his rule.
Thus his vast achievements can be called great.

**The Great Symbol** is the Dao/Way,
Like the formless yet present in the **huanghu** [恍惚].
All under Heaven submit to it,
Each receiving its blessings.
The sage does not rule with **察察** [overt scrutiny],
Lest he harm them,
And so brings forth the harmony of Heaven and Earth.

**He who grasps the Great Symbol** draws people to him,
Like the lure of music and food—
Thus when the **Eight Sounds** [八音] play in unison,
Hearers delight in their hearts,
When flavors blend in abundance,
Tasters find satisfaction in their mouths,
Then travelers pause to rest.
So too, all under Heaven submit to the ruler of the Dao/Way.

**The greatest words are unadorned,**
**Uttered without relish,**
**The Great Symbol is formless,**
**No seeking in sight or sound.**
Yet through all ages its use renews itself,
Never exhausted.

**When the Great Symbol is grasped, all submit.**
**Annotation:** The Great Symbol is the Dao/Way.
**When the emperor holds the Great Dao/Way to govern the world,**
**All things submit to him.**

**Exegesis:**
*Grasp* means *hold*.
The Great Symbol is the Dao/Way.
This speaks of rulers holding the Great Dao/Way to govern the world,
With **wuwei** [无为] and **wushi** [无事],
Things fulfill their nature in growth.
Observing the winds and waiting for the sun,
All submit to the ruler of the Dao/Way.
Thus it is said: *All submit.*

**Exegesis (alternate interpretation):**
*Grasp* means *employ*.
The Great Dao/Way is without form,
And cannot be grasped as a possession.
The sage employs the Dao/Way to govern the people,
Acts without **wuwei** [无为],
Yet all—crawling, growing, flying, walking—
Fulfill their nature in life.
Then ships sail swiftly, swift steeds gallop,
Mountains are scaled, multitudes gather,
All submitting to the ruler who employs the Dao/Way.

**Observing the winds and waiting for the sun:**
In ancient times, the **Juyuzhou** [聚窟洲] was in the vast sea,
And its envoys paid tribute to the Han,
Reporting to Emperor Wu:
*"Our land is thirty million *li* distant.
There we always observe the winds and wait for the sun.
If the east wind blows in rhythm,
Hundreds of days without pause,
And the blue clouds ascend unbroken,
Months without dispersal,
Then the Central Kingdom will have a ruler of the Dao/Way."*

Thus the ruler of our land
Looks toward the Central Kingdom,
Admires the Dao/Way’s influence,
Values **lingwu** [灵物] over gold and jade,
And so tames fierce beasts in the **Tianlin** [天林],
Gathers rare treasures and divine fragrances,
Crosses weak waters and shifting sands,
To pay homage at the imperial gate.
Thirteen years of arduous travel!

This is the ruler of the Dao/Way—
His virtue/power moves Heaven,
The winds and clouds respond in omens,
And distant lands yearn for his virtue/power.
All submit without harm,
And so find peace in **Taiping** [Great Harmony].

**Annotation:** When all submit without injury,
They rest in **Taiping** [Great Harmony].

**Exegesis:**
It is said that people from all directions
Yearn for the sage’s rule,
Observe the winds and wait for the sun,
And submit to the sage.
The sage then **gluishui** [绥抚] and nurtures them,
Not enforcing teachings with demands,
Not punishing with laws,
And so the far and near find peace in his **Taiping** governance.

**Taiping** means **harmony and stability**,
**Ping** means **peaceful governance**,
**Harm** means **injury**,
And so when the four directions submit to our virtue/power,
Observe the winds and wait for the sun,
And converge with the sage,
The sage then **gluishui** [绥抚] and nurtures them,
Not enforcing teachings with demands,
Not punishing with laws,
And so the far and near find peace in his **Taiping** governance.

**Peaceful governance and harmony,**
**Stability and ease—**
Then his deeds shine grand,
And so it is called **Taiping**.

*The Analects* say:
*"When distant people do not submit,*
*Cultivate virtue/power and teach to bring them in.*
*Once they have come,*
*Nurture them in peace."*

Thus the imperial Dao/Way and its winds
Reach all, near and far.

**Music and food—**
**Travelers pause to rest.**
**Annotation:** Music gathers with sound,
Food gathers with flavor,
Travelers linger briefly,
Not for long.

Thus the **qilü** [蘧庐] cannot be dwelled in for long,
And those who come with **renyi** [仁义] bring many burdens,
So the ruler embodies the Dao/Way’s **qingjing** [清静],
**Dandan** [淡然] without flavor,
First discarding the **察察** [overt scrutiny] of governance,
Finally transforming the people in **chunchun** [淳淳].
And so the following text concludes: *Its use cannot be exhausted.*

**Exegesis:**
Music is sound,
Food is flavor—
This is a metaphor.
It is said that when the ruler grasps the Great Symbol,
All under Heaven submit to him,
Just as travelers pause when they hear music and taste food.

**Exegesis (alternate interpretation):**
The ruler of the Dao/Way—
All under Heaven yearn for him.
Like travelers who pause when they hear music and taste food,
*The Zhuangzi* [《庄子》] says in the **Zhaile** [至乐] chapter:
*"The music of the **Xianchi** [咸池] and **Jiushao** [九韶] was played in the **Dongting** [洞庭] wilderness,
And when people heard it, they turned back to gaze."*

Music is what all ages have employed,
And when played to symbolize Heaven,
On the **Yuanqiu** [圆丘],
The heavenly spirits descend.

When performed in the marshes, the earth rises in response;
When struck with harmony to the eight winds, it is embraced by the governance of the four seasons.

The Yellow Emperor had the *Xianchi* [咸池],
Yao had the *Dazhang* [大章],
Shun had the *Dasha* [大韶],
Yu had the *Daxia* [大夏],
Tang had the *Dagao* [大濩],
King Wen had the *Biyong* [辟雍],
and King Wu and the Duke of Zhou had the *Dawu* [大武].

Music harmonizes—
And thus, people find peace in their nature,
Which is why it is held in such esteem.

The Sage-King completes his work and creates music,
Establishes order and institutes rites,
Thus communicating with Heaven, Earth, and the spirits.

Yet this metaphor is given—
For the Dao/Way endures eternally.
Music and food are not lasting:
Music delights the ears, but when it ends, the people disperse;
Food pleases the palate, but when eaten, the crowd departs.
Though they may pause for a time,
They cannot be relied upon for permanence.

Only when ruling with *wuwei* [無為] does the people gather and cannot be parted.
When one embodies the Dao/Way in person,
The spirit remains whole and cannot be scattered.

Thus the text continues:
*"The Dao/Way spoken aloud is bland and tasteless,"*
And it is said, *"Its use cannot be exhausted,"*
For it is not like music and food, which have a limit to their enjoyment.

The *Zhunlu* [遵庐] is a thatched hut—
Not a place for long residence.
Ren and righteousness may foster mutual love,
Yet they cannot sustain lasting bonds.
Unlike embodying the Dao/Way and transforming people—
Where the people return to the Dao/Way,
Naturally and enduringly,
How could they ever scatter?

*Cháchá* [察察] is the governance of harsh laws;
*Chúnchún* [淳淳] is the wind of harmonious music.

When the Dao/Way is spoken aloud,
It is bland and without flavor.
**Annotation:**
The ruler teaches through virtue and purity—
When first spoken, the Dao/Way is bland and without taste,
Not like common teachings that carry praise, fear, or reproach.

**Exegesis:**
When the Dao/Way is spoken aloud,
It refers to the ruler’s strict adherence to the methods of virtue and tranquility,
Using *wuwei* [無為] as instruction.
When first spoken, it is bland and without taste—
How could it compare to the allure of common speech,
Which carries praise, fear, or reproach as its flavor?

**Exegesis (alternate interpretation):**
Sweet words and flattering speech—
This is what is called *having flavor*.
The principles of *wuwei*,
The teachings of purity,
The words of the ultimate Dao/Way—
When spoken, they are bland and without taste.
Where is the flavor?

The common teachings of praise and fear—
This is the language of the seventeenth chapter of this text:
*"With sweet words to win affection,
With flattering speech to earn praise,
Or with commands to inspire fear,
Or with insolent words to humiliate."*
Though they may have flavor,
They are not the ultimate Dao/Way.

To look upon it is insufficient to see,
To listen to it is insufficient to hear,
Its use cannot be exhausted.

The Dao/Way, through its tranquil stillness,
Initially requires no spoken teachings.
Thus, it is not seen when viewed,
Nor heard when listened to—
Yet pure winds prevail,
And all things flourish abundantly.

Annual calculations yield surplus,
Hence its use cannot be exhausted.
*Ji* means "exhausted."

The *Cushu* explains:
The Dao’s transformation through *wuwei*,
Dull and even, neither harshly scrutinizing
Nor excessively conspicuous in its decrees—
Thus it is not seen when viewed,
Nor heard when listened to—
Yet annual calculations yield surplus.

Pure winds flow harmoniously,
Cultivated and spontaneous things all thrive,
All beings radiant and prosperous—
Hence its use cannot be exhausted.

The *Yi* states:
The Dao’s wordlessness—
In speech, it has no taste to the palate.
The Dao’s formlessness—
In form, it is unseen by the eye.
The Dao’s soundlessness—
Unheard by the ear.
Thus, chewing reveals no flavor,
Gazing and listening perceive nothing.

It does not impose the rigid urgency of strict laws,
Nor the excessive visibility of proliferating edicts—
Lest it startle the people’s ears and eyes.

When things find their proper place, it is called *pingzhi* (even and straight),
When there is no partiality, it is called *zheng* (upright).
Laws that are overly meticulous are *ke* (harsh),
Taxes and levies imposed too swiftly are *ji* (urgent).
Overly explicit prohibitions are *cháchá* (scrutinizing),
Decrees beyond the law are *zīzhāng* (proliferating).
*Zī* means "many," *zhāng* means "manifest."

Thus, the people’s ears and eyes
Are daily exposed to sights and sounds.
They fear the extravagant, harsh, and violent punishments,
More than they fear stepping on thin ice;
They dread the scrutinizing, proliferating decrees,
More than they fear standing at the edge of a precipice.
Every movement of foot and hand is uncertain—
How can this compare to ruling through the Dao,
Where nothing is seen or heard?
Pure winds act subtly,
All things harmonize effortlessly—
Its use cannot be exhausted.

As for annual calculations yielding surplus,
*Zhuangzi* says:
Old Lao’s disciple, Gengsang Chu,
Obtained the Dao of Old Lao,
And dwelled on the *Yǔlěi* Mountains.
After three years, his people’s customs flourished greatly,
And they said among themselves:
*"When Gengrouzi first arrived,
We were astonished by his transformation.
Now, our daily calculations fall short,
But our annual calculations yield surplus.
Perhaps he is a sage!"*
This speaks of his virtue and grace subtly permeating all things,
Bringing about abundance and flourishing.

How much more so for the Emperor,
Who encompasses the Four Seas,
As the ruler of the world,
Governed through the Dao with effortless ease—
The world is transformed by his influence.
Truly so.

As for those who cultivate the Dao in their own lives:
When the mind harbors no scheming thoughts,
The vital *qi* and spirit remain whole.
When desires and aversions are extinguished,
Love and hatred cease.
Unmoved by sight and sound,
Unperturbed by tranquility,
The profound virtue fills silently—
The Dao may yet be attained.

*End of Volume Twenty-Eight of the Broad Exegesis on the Authentic Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue*
*Beginning of Volume Twenty-Nine of the Broad Exegesis on the Authentic Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue*

**Volume Twenty-Eight of the Broad Exegesis on the *Authentic Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue* by Tang Master Guangcheng (attributed to Du Guangting) concludes.**
**Volume Twenty-Nine begins.**

---

The chapter on *"To Those Who Would Collect"* (Chapter Thirty-Six) elucidates:
The prior chapter expounded the ability to embody the Dao and transform, drawing all to follow.
This chapter reveals that the Dao may employ **strategic measures** (*quan* 权), for when a state’s advantage lies in such measures, they must be kept in reserve—
advantages cannot be openly displayed.

First, it marks the **strategic measures** of contraction and expansion (*xī zhāng* 息張);
Next, it shows the **conduct of yielding and weakness** (*róu ruò* 柔弱);
Finally, it concludes with the parable of the **deep-sea fish** (*yuān yú* 淵魚),
To illustrate the signs of **strategic measures** in the Dao.

**Its meaning is this:**
The Dao’s transformation adapts to circumstances and responds to opportunity.
In the **Age of High Antiquity**, the sovereign entrusted himself to the Dao,
The ministers enriched themselves in **virtue** (*dé* 德),
And the people flourished in **harmony** (*hé* 和).
Thus, their actions were unseen, their words unheard,
Their governance complete without trace.

Yet as time passed, the **virtue** of the age grew thin and shallow,
Customs declined into error,
The profound mysteries of the Dao became obscure,
The rare and subtle were beyond measure.

When the Sage sought to restore simplicity and purity,
To abruptly discard the ornate and excessive,
To silence the clamor of voices,
To search for truth in distant reaches—
He taught the rulers of the age,
To grasp the **strategic measures** of transformation,
To demonstrate the **gates of contraction and expansion** (*xiē liǎn kāi zhāng* 息敛開張),
To curb deceit,
To reverse the **usurpation of power** and the **abandonment of merit** (*yǔ duó fèi xīng* 與奪廢興),
And to restrain corruption.

Thus, deceitful men may return to loyalty,
And wayward men may return to rectitude.

Though these **strategic measures** are not the ultimate truth,
They serve as auxiliary methods.

Hence, they are called **advantages** for the state.

Those who wield such advantages,
Like those who use armies and chariots,
Do so only when necessity demands.

They must conduct themselves with **yielding and weakness**,
Subtly reveal the **principles** (*jī* 機),
And not display their **strategic measures** to the unworthy.

As fish cannot lose water—
Fish lose water and die—
Men lose opportunity and are ruined.
The *Book of the Unadorned* (*Sùshū* 素書) states:
*"He who leaks his schemes is doomed to fail."*
The *Yijing* (*易*) says:
*"If the opportunity is not kept secret, it brings harm to oneself."*
This is precisely what is meant.

To those who would **collect** (*xiē* 息),
They must first **expand** (*zhāng* 張);
To those who would **weaken** (*ruò* 弱),
They must first **strengthen** (*qiáng* 強);
To those who would **abolish** (*fèi* 廢),
They must first **promote** (*xīng* 興);
To those who would **usurp** (*duó* 奪),
They must first **bestow** (*yǔ* 與).

**Commentary:**
*Xiē* (息) means **contraction** (*liǎn* 敛).

This reveals how the Sage employs **strategic measures** in the Dao
To transform and guide all beings.

Since men possess **blunt roots** (*dùn gēn* 鈍根) and **sharp roots** (*lì gēn* 利根),
Teaching must include both **strategic measures** (*quan* 权) and **substantial truth** (*shí* 實).

The Sage desires to measure the roots of men’s nature,
Thus he uses **strategic measures** and **substantial truth** in alternation to clarify their responses.

Men with **sharp roots** perceive goodness and turn from it,
See faults and amend them.
A mere hint of guidance suffices,
For they deeply grasp the **origin of roots**.

**Its meaning is this:**
The Sage establishes teachings,
Dividing them into two **gates**: **strategic measures** and **substantial truth**.

The **superior man** with a **sharp root** understands the **substantial truth** fully.
The **middle and inferior men** require the **gate of strategic measures**.
The methods of **strategic measures** are vast and varied.
According to the Classic’s judgment,
They may be broadly categorized into four **gates**.

**Roots** refer to the **roots of wisdom and nature** (*zhìxìng zhī gēn* 智性之根).
What men inherit is the **true primordial Dao-nature** (*zhēnyuán dào xìng* 真元道性),
Which generates all wisdom.
Like the roots of grasses and trees,
They produce blossoms and fruit,
Mutually giving rise—
Hence they are called **roots**.

The generation of wisdom from nature is likewise so.
What men inherit in nature is their **qi**.
There are **pure and impure** distinctions.
Men whose **qi** is pure and harmonious
Generate **sharp roots** naturally—
Their talents and wisdom surpass others,
Their understanding spans ancient and modern,
And when asked one thing, they know ten.

Since such men possess **sharp roots**,
They perceive and act with clarity—
They advance when opportunity arises,
Retreat when difficulties mount,
Pursue goodness as if fearing to miss it,
And recoil from evil as if touching scalding water.
Thus, they turn from goodness when they see it,
And amend their faults when they encounter them.
They grasp the **methods of expedient means** (*fāngbiàn* 方便),
And know the **paths of progress**.
Without awaiting the Dao’s **strategic measures** to lure them,
They naturally attain the **substantial truth** of its teachings.

The four **gates** are **contraction, weakness, abolition, and usurpation** (*xiē ruò fèi duó* 息弱廢奪).

**Commentary:**
Men with **blunt roots** are confused and stagnant for long.
Unless **strategic measures** are employed to transform them,
They cannot be led to follow.

Thus, to those who would **collect** and **contract** their desires,
First **expand** and **display** their extravagant hearts,
So they become ensnared in love and desire—
Then they will naturally **contract** and **restrain**.

The same applies to **strengthening and weakening**.
Extend this reasoning universally,
And it holds true without exception.

At first hearing, one may think this contradicts the Dao’s intent.
But when one penetrates to its **profound depths**,
Then the **origin of strategic measures** becomes clear.
Hence the annotation states:
*"The gentleman employs strategic measures, valuing their alignment with righteousness;
The petty man uses them, resorting to deceit."*

The later passage states:
*"They cannot be openly displayed,"*
Precisely because **strategic measures** in the Dao are difficult to grasp.

**Its meaning is this:**
Men with **blunt roots** whose **qi** is impure and mixed
Generate **obtuse and dull** nature—
Their wisdom is blocked, their understanding clouded,
They cannot distinguish right from wrong,
Much less know good and evil.
Some are greedy and cruel,
Following their desires without restraint,
Their actions always leading to guilt,
Their lives forever estranged from others.

The Sage is always good at rescuing beings,
Compassionate toward all life,
Thus he demonstrates the **gate of strategic measures**,
To guide them toward self-awareness.

Hence the four **gates** of **strategic measures** are employed to transform them.
The first—*"To those who would collect, they must first expand"*—
**Contracts** their hearts.
The second—*"To those who would weaken, they must first strengthen"*—
**Contracts** their nature.
The third—*"To those who would abolish, they must first promote"*—
**Contracts** their desires.
The fourth—*"To those who would usurp, they must first bestow"*—
**Contracts** their greed.

When the heart is **frugal**, the Dao is **buried** (*zàng* 葬);
When the heart is **extravagant**, faults arise.
By indulging in extravagance and gaining faults,
They naturally reflect and attain **frugality**.
This is the **strategic measure** of **contracting** the heart.

When nature is **weak**, **virtue** is **whole** (*quán* 全);
When nature is **strong**, disaster arises.
By indulging in strength and inviting disaster,
They naturally reflect and return to **weakness**.
This is the **strategic measure** of **yielding** to subdue strength.

When desires are **few**, conduct is **pure** (*qīng* 清);
When desires are **many**, the spirit becomes **impure**.
Deep desires lead to extreme impurity,
Yet they naturally reflect and return to **purity**.
This is the **strategic measure** of **abolishing** desires to **purify** the spirit.

When greed is **nonexistent**, one is **frugal** (*jiǎn yuē* 俭約);
When greed is **extreme**, calamity befalls oneself.
By indulging in greed and suffering calamity,
They naturally reflect and return to **frugality**.
This is the **strategic measure** of **cultivating frugality** to **usurp** greed.

All these methods first **expand** their extravagant hearts,
So they become ensnared in their own desires—
Then they reflect upon their nature and **cultivate** the Dao.

At first hearing, one may think this contradicts the principle of **non-action** and **spontaneous transformation**,
Yet there are distinctions between **sharp and blunt roots**,
And differences in the **gradual and sudden** paths to enlightenment.

Sudden enlightenment requires no reliance on expedient means,
While gradual transformation depends on skillful guidance.
Thus arises the distinction between expedient and fundamental truth.

The Dao of expedients teaches humanity,
Yet all must ultimately conform to the Great Principle—
Hence its emphasis on aligning with righteousness.

The petty-minded trifle with expedients through deceit,
And thus they must not be lightly shown to those unaligned with the Way.

The *Analects* says: *"One may stand with him, but not employ expedients with him."*
This speaks to the difficulty of using expedients.

The *Yinfu* states: *"The virtuous man, when he gains it, endures adversity;
The petty man, when he gains it, risks his life."*
Is this not what is meant?

This is called **subtle clarity**.

**Note:** The scripture says, *"Right speech seems reversed,"*
And the *Yijing* says, *"The compliant one acts through expedients."*
Expedients are those that reverse the norm yet align with righteousness.

Thus, the virtuous employ expedients by aligning with righteousness,
While the petty misuse them for deceit.

Confucius said: *"One may stand with him, but not employ expedients with him."*
Hence, the Master Lao previously demonstrated **embracing the Great Image**—this is the fundamental truth—
And now follows with **contraction and expansion**, which is the expedient.

To measure the capacities of all beings,
He employs expedients and fundamental truths to reveal their true nature,
So they may inevitably attain the realm of **nature and fate**.

Yet the confused claim this contradicts the **Dao and virtue**—
How deeply they err and fail to awaken!

To contract and restrain the desires of all beings,
First expand their extravagant hearts,
So they become ensnared in their own loves—
Then contraction follows naturally.

The principles of strength and weakness are similarly applied here.
This Dao is subtle, yet its effects are clearly manifest—
Hence it is called **subtle clarity**.

**Commentary:** The Dao of expedients subtly transforms.
Examining its application reveals its effects clearly—
Thus it is called **subtle clarity**.

**Explanation:** The Dao of expedients is most subtle;
When applied, its effects become evident.
Assessing its results proves its efficacy—
**Manifest** is the same as **clear**.

The Sage directs the thoughts of superior disciples toward the **Mystic Burial** of non-action,
In harmony with the ultimate Dao.
Yet why employ expedients and fundamental truths for them?

Expedients are established for those of middling and inferior wisdom.
It is like the art of war:
The superior strategist defeats through foresight,
Without raising an army—
Planning victories from afar,
Deciding battles a thousand *li* away,
While the inferior lack understanding of adaptability,
Waiting for battle to erupt—
Some sever necks, others split livers—
Only then do they discern victory or defeat,
And deliberate on advance or retreat.

Such ignorance of adaptability
Demands that expedient methods be shown to them,
So they may learn from expedients to correct themselves—
Thus no one is abandoned.

*"The compliant one acts through expedients,"*
And the meaning of *"one may stand with him"* has been explained elsewhere.

**The yielding overcomes the rigid.**

**Note:** The compliant and yielding can act through expedients.
When expedients are applied, they can control others.
Thus, the yielding and weak can overcome the rigid and strong.

**Commentary:** The *Yijing* says, *"The compliant one acts through expedients."*
This clarifies that compliance and humility enable one to act through expedients.
Thus, to contract, first expand;
To weaken, first strengthen—
Yet ultimately, they will contract and weaken,
This is the Dao of yielding,
Which can conquer the rigid and strong.

**Explanation:** The *Yijing* [missing character] says, *"The compliant one acts through expedients."*
**Compliance** means **yielding and humility**—
When one can yield to circumstances and act appropriately,
Then expedients can be applied.
If one cannot adapt to change, expedients cannot be employed.

**Compliance** is **harmonization** and **yielding**.
The southeast hexagram, at the intersection of spring and summer,
When the Dipper points southeast—
All things are purified and harmonized.
**Compliance** governs clarifying and promulgating decrees,
To establish laws—
Hence it is called *"the restraint of the compliant virtue."*

Again, **compliance** governs the wind—
The emperor’s decrees, like the wind’s movement,
Can proclaim edicts without boasting,
Remaining hidden and unassuming.
Thus it is said: *"The compliant proclaims yet conceals."*

From this, we see **compliance** embodies:
Yielding, purity, concealment, and non-arrogance.
With these four virtues,
And the ability to issue commands and adapt to circumstances,
Only then can one act through expedients.

From this perspective, the Dao of expedients must not be lightly discussed.
If one aligns with righteousness and acts accordingly,
They can transform vice into virtue,
Prosper the nation, and benefit the people.
If not, they harm nature, injure the body,
And ultimately become deceitful.

When a ruler teaches the wild and wicked to use expedients for adaptability,
Yet governs with yielding and humility,
The rigid and strong will all submit to his gentle virtue.

Fish cannot be removed from the depths,
And a nation’s sharp weapons must not be shown to others.

**Note:** *Det* means **loss**.
**Sharp weapons** refer to **expedients**.
This warns that expedients must not be revealed to the unworthy.

**Commentary:** *Det* means **loss**.
**Sharp weapons** are **expedients**.
Fish in water are like a ruler wielding expedients—
If fish lose water, they are captured by men,
And if expedients are revealed to the unworthy,
The petty will seize and misuse them for deceit.

**Explanation:** Fish in the depths—
If they lose water, they die;
If they retain water, they live.
A ruler using expedients—
If applied to the worthy, they bring benefit;
If misapplied, they bring ruin.

Fish can hide in deep pools,
Avoid bait, and refuse hooks—
Thus they avoid losing water.
A ruler can employ the worthy,
Delegate to the loyal,
Exile the deceitful,
And block treacherous paths—
Thus they avoid losing expedients.

If fish lose water, they are captured by men;
If a ruler loses expedients, the petty gain power.
Those who steal a ruler’s expedients and manipulate them
Will invert black and white,
Turn good into evil,
Unleash their wickedness,
And indulge in cruelty.

Thus, the **Jizhu** overthrew the legitimate heir to establish a concubine’s son,
And destroyed the **Muzi** clan’s reputation;
**Zhao Gao** slandered the loyal and harmed the virtuous,
And destroyed the **Qin ancestral foundation**.

The people suffer its calamities,
And the common folk resent their ruler—
When the people scatter and the state is in peril,
There is no hope of salvation.

The *Shuowen Jiezi* says: **"Deceit" (诈) is "to deceive."**
**"Guile" (谲) is to mislead the world with falsehoods.**

Guile, as in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*—
When Duke Wen of Jin provoked楚 to anger and war,
He captured the Lord of曹 and humbled himself before宋,
And楚 indeed attacked宋.
Duke Wen then turned to fight楚,
And the楚 army was routed.
Duke Wen then summoned King Shou of Zhou to河阳,
Presenting him to the assembled lords,
And had the king go on a hunt.
Thus, he united the lords under the pretense of honoring the Son of Heaven,
Yet secretly feared Zhou’s strength and dared not pay homage.
He feigned the Son of Heaven’s hunting expedition,
Gaining the opportunity to perform all the rites of君臣—
All these were guileful and improper acts.

Confucius said: **"To summon a君 as a臣 is unteachable."**
Thus the records say: **"The Son of Heaven hunted at河阳."**
This was not his proper domain.
Even this is called guileful deception—
How much more so when treacherous ministers and petty men manipulate power to deceive their ruler,
And do not heed warnings until they regret it?

Those who cultivate the Dao:
Within, they rectify their heart;
Without, they rectify their conduct.
Inner and outer as one,
Upright and without deceit,
Then their thoughts and intentions may resonate with the True Spirit.
But if their words and deeds contradict,
And they are crooked and improper,
Though they bow and stretch, adorn their appearance—
It is all in vain.

---
**Chapter Thirty-Seven: The Dao Ever Does Nothing**

**Commentary:**
The previous chapter showed how the Dao may employ expedients,
Illustrating the gathering and dispersing of the state of卫.
This chapter clarifies that expedients must align with righteousness,
To govern the unrefined essence (*pu*).
Thus, the Dao does nothing—
If lords and kings uphold it, transformation occurs naturally.
The unrefined essence, without desire,
Allows the world to settle and purify itself.

Laozi expounds this to clarify the ineffable,
Teaching while desiring to transcend teaching.
Thus, this chapter unfolds in the *Daodejing*’s upper sections,
Addressing those who grasp the mysterious enlightenment.

**Meaning:**
The ruler’s governance of the world
Uses genuine teaching to rectify the君子,
Expedients to subdue the petty,
And the Dao of non-action to harmonize both teachings,
Making them the foundation of transformation.

Genuine teaching means:
君 as君,臣 as臣,父 as父,子 as子—
Ritual, music, benevolence, and trust
To rectify all under heaven.
The ruler and君子 practice and uphold these,
Establishing laws for the four seas.

The petty, when advancing, do not embrace benevolence and righteousness,
And when retreating, fall into legal punishments.
If not guided by expedient methods to turn their evil to good,
And instead sink into ruin—
This is abandonment.

Laozi said: **"No one abandons people."**
Thus, expedient methods are set to teach them,
To return them to goodness,
And to universally benefit the world—
All may then recover their unrefined essence.

The unrefined essence is the wondrous origin of the Dao.
If lords and kings uphold and apply it,
All things transform naturally.
If they desire to alter this,
They must always govern with non-action,
And the world will settle and rectify itself.

Those who cultivate the Dao:
The Sage employs profound techniques to cultivate,
While the world is easily misled.
Thus, they establish rules, warnings, and models to rectify outward conduct;
They record meditative concentration and spiritual refinement to rectify the heart;
They refine qi and nurture the primordial embryo to regulate diet;
They offer prayers and thanks to the True One to purge transgressions.
Then, they pursue the path of *learning without learning*,
Attaining silent stillness,
Dwelling in the realm of *less and yet less*,
And aligning with non-action.
Thus, the gates of errant paths remain closed,
And the pure harmony of tranquility is achieved.

The Dao ever does nothing, yet nothing is left undone.

**Commentary:**
The Dao’s nature is pure and tranquil,
Its wondrous origin profound and still—
Thus, it ever does nothing.
All things rely on it to flourish and take form,
Responding to stimuli with certainty—
Thus, it does nothing yet leaves nothing undone.
What is done has limits to what is not done,
Thus, what is not done encompasses all.

**Meaning:**
The Dao’s nature is unadulterated, truly one and empty—
Thus, it is pure and tranquil.
Its depth is unfathomable, like a clear spring—
Thus, it is profound and still.
Silent and unmoving—this is non-action.
Responsive yet effortless—this is doing nothing yet leaving nothing undone.

Non-action is the essence of the wondrous origin.
Doing nothing yet leaving nothing undone is its function.
Essence and function interdependently give rise to all transformations.
If it cannot be penetrated or respond,
If it is silent yet formless,
Unable to generate—
Though it does nothing, how can it benefit the mysterious transformation?

If, instead, it cycles endlessly,
Acting without rest,
Exhausted and ceaseless—
This is mere doing—
Where can it find repose?

One must act yet do nothing to govern movement,
Do nothing yet act to regulate stillness,
Never straying from the true Dao,
Never obstructed by deceit—
Only then can one speak of the source of purity and tranquility.

If lords and kings uphold it,
All things will transform naturally.

**Note:**
The wondrous origin is pure and tranquil—
Thus, it ever does nothing.
Things rely on it to flourish,
Yet it leaves nothing undone.
If lords and kings uphold the Dao of non-action,
All things will transform naturally.
The ruler’s non-action makes the people pure and unrefined.

**Commentary:**
If lords and kings uphold the Dao of purity and tranquility,
Doing nothing yet leaving nothing undone,
All things will naturally transform and purify themselves—
This is the ruler’s good governance and the people’s purity.

**Meaning:**
The ruler governs all under heaven,
The lord governs his state—
If all uphold the Dao of non-action and purity,
Transformation arises from below,
While the lord remains tranquil above.
This is the ultimate principle.

Teaching leads to transformation—this is guided transformation.
Not teaching yet transforming—this is self-transformation.
Teaching and transforming means doing nothing yet able to transform things.
Not teaching yet transforming means non-action leading to natural attainment of transformation.

When transformation arises and desires to act,
I will govern it with the nameless unrefined essence.

**Note:**
Once people follow the ruler’s transformation,
Already in non-action and purity,
Yet still desire to move and act—
I will govern them with the nameless unrefined essence to tranquilize them.

The nameless unrefined essence is the Dao.

The *Commentary* explains:

The nameless unrefined essence is the Dao.
Those who act are those who move and engage in deliberate action.
*"I"* refers to the sovereign’s self-designation.
It states that when people receive virtuous teaching and transform,
the ruler’s virtue is in non-action and purity.
Yet if they still desire to move and act deliberately,
I will use the nameless unrefined essence to tranquilize them,
so that they remain pure and unmoving.

The meaning is this:
When the Dao is applied, it is given a strong name.
Returning to the unrefined essence means abandoning traces—
the essence is nameless.
The sovereign transforms people through the Dao,
and those who receive this transformation are all pure and tranquil.
If they are again drawn by external influences,
and their desires stir them to act,
the sovereign will use the Dao’s subtle origin—the formless, nameless unrefined essence—to tranquilize their minds,
preventing deliberate action,
so that they always align with the Dao’s pure transformation.

When cultivating the Dao,
if the mind merges and the spirit stills,
yet worldly delusions arise and external thoughts suddenly emerge,
leading one toward agitation or entanglement in disputes,
one should urgently retreat to a quiet chamber,
reflect on the profound and ponder the true,
using the Dao of non-action to tranquilize the mind and suppress false thoughts.
Like muddy water gradually clarifying,
the Three Corpses cannot disturb,
a hundred evils cannot unsettle,
and all demonic trials cease,
ascending to the stage of emptiness.
The nameless unrefined essence will also cease to be desired.

The *Commentary* continues:
Earlier, it spoke of common people desiring to act deliberately—
the ruler would use the nameless unrefined essence to tranquilize them.
Now it says that even the nameless unrefined essence itself should not be clung to.
For if one clings to the nameless,
traces will arise,
causing these beings to lose their origin and return to deliberate action—
no different from their original desires.

The meaning is this:
Once people have transformed into purity yet still act deliberately,
it is due to accumulated habits and prolonged confusion.
Like water that is hard to clarify but easily muddied,
nature that is hard to purify but easily obscured,
the mind that is hard to still but easily agitated,
or resolve that is hard to sustain but easily abandoned—
the sovereign must use the essence’s subtle origin to tranquilize and still them.
Once stillness is achieved,
one must further abandon all clinging,
until all traces are extinguished,
then the mind becomes profoundly silent and intuitively clear,
penetrating true mystery,
so that beings do not cling to traces,
and sages do not cling to emptiness.
With both emptiness and being forgotten,
one attains perfect observation.

The *Commentary* explains:
Thus, initially, the nameless unrefined essence is used
to tranquilize the people’s restless desires.
Once the people’s desires are removed,
the sage’s nameless essence is also abandoned.
It is like medicine curing illness—
when the illness is gone, the medicine is forgotten;
or a boat ferrying across water—
when the crossing is complete, the boat is left behind.
If one clings to the boat after crossing,
or continues taking medicine after recovery,
not only will one fail to reach the other shore,
but new afflictions will arise.

The meaning is this:
Having attained stillness in human nature,
one must further abandon the nameless.
Like forgetting the boat after crossing,
or the medicine after recovery—
this is the essence of true cultivation.

Boats and medicines are metaphors for teaching.
Beings cycle through the world’s entanglements,
confused by the duality of existence and emptiness,
gradually stained by the six dusts,
dragged by attachments into suffering.
The Venerable Master expounds the precepts of non-action,
narrates the great function of salvation,
and presents this true scripture as the supreme medicine for curing afflictions.
Through the scripture’s awakening,
delusions naturally disperse,
internal stains are washed clean,
external entanglements are severed,
and with afflictions healed and worldly bonds dissolved,
one must abandon teaching and forget words,
merging back into the Dao.

Moreover, the world’s sufferings,
the cycle of birth and death,
the wandering of true essence,
the sinking of pure nature—
are like drowning in the vast sea.
Beings follow currents and drift with waves,
with no way to transcend.
The Venerable Master, through this profound scripture,
governs the realm and saves people,
rescuing all beings from the sea of desire.
Through the scripture, they are delivered—
like a great vessel cutting across rapid currents,
ascending to the other shore,
where desire-waves cannot shake their nature,
and love-tides cannot drown their minds.
They exit the court of accumulated suffering
and step into the domain of eternal life.
Having crossed, one must forget the vessel they rode,
abandon the path they followed,
rest the spirit in the realm of nothingness,
and wander the heart’s natural home—
this is to preserve the true in emptiness,
contain all things in purity,
manifesting humanity while embodying the heavens,
floating effortlessly in harmony,
truly trusting in nature alone.

If one clings to the vessel or the medicine,
failing to transcend and instead generating new afflictions—
this is no idle warning.

*"Not desiring"* leads to stillness,
and the world will naturally align.
*Note:*
When the sovereign uses the nameless unrefined essence to tranquilize the people,
they must not cling to this nameless essence,
lest they seek traces and lose their origin,
returning to deliberate action.
Thus, even the nameless unrefined essence must be forgotten.
Not desiring to desire,
desire itself is forgotten—
tranquil and pure,
the world will naturally align.

The *Commentary* states:
When the nameless unrefined essence is no longer desired,
and the desire for non-desire is also forgotten,
then tranquil and pure—
this is called *liberation*.
The ruler governs through non-action, attaining supreme order above,
while people follow their nature, transforming below.
No decrees are needed, yet the world is rectified and peaceful.
Thus it is said: *"The world will naturally align."*

The meaning is this:
Once the people’s restless desires are stilled,
and the metaphors of boat and medicine are forgotten,
the nameless unrefined essence is also abandoned,
and even the desire for non-desire is extinguished—
then emptiness and being are transcended,
vast and unobstructed.
The ruler above speaks without words, yet is trusted.
The people below transform without instruction, yet act rightly.
Speaking without words is governing through non-action above.
Transforming without instruction is following nature below.
When transformation reaches this point,
what need is there for decrees?
The world is rectified and peaceful,
returning to the Dao of antiquity.

「The *Dao* is the essence of *virtue*, and *virtue* is the manifestation of the *Dao*.
Thus it is said: *"The chapter first marks the name of virtue’s function, intending to reveal the transformation of virtue’s completeness."*

When *virtue* is complete, the pure and unrefined essence does not disperse, and there are no traces of artificial influence.
If the *Dao* is neglected, then benevolence and righteousness will prevail, and the people will suffer from superficial corruption.
To restore the original state, the Sage first expounds on the *Dao*’s non-action of supreme *virtue*,
then describes the retreat of benevolence and righteousness,
and concludes with "discarding ornament and embracing reality" to lead them back to simplicity and purity.

○ *Explanation*: The *Dao* is the substance of *virtue*, and *virtue* is the function of the *Dao*.
Hence, *"the chapter first marks the name of virtue’s function, pointing to supreme virtue."*

Supreme *virtue* is the *virtue* that does not rely on *virtue*—
it is the means by which *virtue* is fully realized.
When supreme *virtue* is complete, the pure and unrefined essence does not disperse.
The pure and unrefined essence undispersed means that *virtue* and transformation merge indistinguishably,
like fish in the waters, each fulfilling its nature—
thus there are no traces of mutual reliance or artificial influence.

Next, it states that when *virtue* is lost, benevolence and righteousness arise instead.
Benevolence carries the bias of partial affection,
and righteousness imposes rigid distinctions—
thus the people follow their ruler, yet become superficial and corrupted.

When elaborate customs become excessive and formal rituals grow chaotic,
their proliferation worsens, and disputes inevitably flourish.
Therefore, the Sage seeks to return to the original state,
discarding ornament and embracing reality—
this is to block the source of chaos and reopen the gate to simplicity.
Hence it is said: *"To restore them to simplicity and purity."*

Supreme *virtue* does not rely on *virtue*—
yet it is *virtue* itself.
*Explanation*: "Supreme" refers to the early ages.
*Virtue* is the manifestation of the *Dao*.
It is said that in the ancient past, simplicity and purity were the natural order,
and the sovereigns who embodied the *Dao* entrusted all to spontaneous manifestation—
this was the supreme *virtue* of antiquity, hence *"supreme virtue."*

The profoundest *virtue* operates silently,
beyond human naming,
hence *"does not rely on virtue."*
The wind of purity was harmonious,
all things flourished naturally,
and *virtue*’s function remained ever complete—
hence *"yet it is virtue."*

*Commentary* says: *"The term ‘virtue’ refers to the spontaneous manifestation of things,"*
a phrase from the *Zhuangzi*’s miscellaneous chapters.

*Explanation*: The text raises the complete *virtue* of the ancient sovereigns,
who did not regard *virtue* as *virtue*—
yet it was *virtue*.
This introduces the decline of later ages, thus beginning with supreme *virtue*.

In the age of the profoundest *Dao*,
*virtue* was not openly displayed.
The sovereign of supreme *virtue* was akin to the *"Supreme"* sovereign of the *Upper Scripture*—
silently merging with the utmost transformation,
all things spontaneously manifested,
without the sovereign’s *virtue* being openly proclaimed—
yet his *virtue* shone all the brighter,
hence *"yet it is virtue."*

However, the *Dao* and *virtue* that all things under heaven inherit
have the *Dao* as their root and *virtue* as their beginning.
The *Dao* varies in depth,
hence there is the *Dao* that can be spoken of and the constant *Dao*;
*Virtue* varies in richness,
hence there is supreme *virtue* and lesser *virtue*.
Thus, the *Dao* and *virtue* are not confined to emperors alone.
Those who practice the *Dao* are *Dao* practitioners,
those who practice *virtue* are *virtue* practitioners—
their depth differs, hence the distinction between supreme and lesser.

*Zhuangzi* says:
*"To be empty and do nothing,
opening the *Dao* for all things—
this is called a *Dao* practitioner.
To be serene and respond naturally—
this is called a *virtue* practitioner."*

*Virtue* has degrees of excellence,
the world experiences flourishing and decline—
thus when the sovereign of supreme *virtue* merges with transformation,
embodies the *Dao* and remains,
his *virtue* moves through the mysteries of the unseen,
and all under heaven turn to him,
without seeing or hearing him.
When *virtue* returns to all things,
they all say it is natural—
hence *"The Supreme holds *virtue* in highest esteem."*

*Zhuangzi*’s miscellaneous chapters state:
*"All things follow their natural course,
each attaining its own life—
this is what is called *virtue*."*

「Thus, those who grasp the *Dao* possess complete *virtue*,
those with complete *virtue* preserve their form,
those who preserve their form attain fullness of spirit,
and this is the *Dao* of the Sage.

The lesser *virtue* does not lose its *virtue*,
yet it is called *without virtue*.
**Annotation:** *Virtue* is the application of the *Dao*.

*Zhuangzi* says:
*"All things attain life through *virtue*—
this is called *virtue*.
Yet *virtue* has degrees of excellence,
so its application varies in rank.
In the days of old, *virtue* was pure and unadorned,
its application not manifest,
no *virtue* to be praised—
thus it is called *without virtue*.
Yet pure *virtue* does not disperse,
and through non-action, its essence remains clear—
thus it is called *possessing virtue* after all.
When *virtue* declines below,
its functions become slightly apparent,
though the heart still embodies the *Dao*,
its traces lean toward action.
Since *virtue* can now be named,
it is called *not losing virtue*.
Yet when traces lean toward ostentation,
it is coarser than the *virtue* of the Supreme,
thus it is called *without virtue* after all.

**Exegesis:** This speaks of how pure customs gradually fade,
and *virtue* declines accordingly.
Thus, the Sage praises the wind of non-action,
while common folk still follow its traces.
To follow traces is inferior,
hence *lesser virtue*.
When traces become apparent,
*virtue* can be named—
thus *not losing virtue*.
Though *virtue* is named and not lost,
its traces lean toward ostentation,
and ostentation with adherence
is far from the *Dao*.
Since it has traces of action,
compared to the *virtue* of the Supreme Sage,
it is *without virtue* indeed.

The *virtue* of the Supreme Sage is non-action yet without pretense of non-action.
**Annotation:** Those who know non-action as beautiful
yet practice non-action are not yet perfect.
But those who practice non-action
without pretense of knowing its beauty—
this is perfection.
Thus, the non-action of Supreme *virtue*
is not feigned for its beauty,
but simply contains and nurtures purity,
naturally arriving at non-action.
Thus it is said: *non-action yet without pretense of non-action*.
This is the heart and trace both in non-action.

**Exegesis:** This elucidates Supreme *virtue*.
The Supreme Sage’s *virtue* operates subtly,
achieving harmony through non-action,
purity never dispersing—
thus no name or trace.
Now, when speaking of Supreme *virtue*’s non-action,
it is only that purity is contained and nurtured,
naturally arriving at non-action,
not that it knows non-action as beautiful
and thus practices it.
Hence it is said: *non-action yet without pretense of non-action*.
Not only does it lack traces to boast of,
but the heart itself transforms without effort.
Thus the **Annotation** says: *This is the heart and trace both in non-action*.

**Exegesis:** The Sage of Supreme *virtue*,
whose nature aligns with the *Dao* and whose fate harmonizes with the One,
embodies naturalness as function,
operates the Great Unity as spirit,
moves in accord with Heaven,
rests in accord with Earth,
and thus finds perfect resonance with the *Dao*—
without doing anything.
The Sage whose spirit has no thought,
whose will has no concern—
this is the heart’s non-action.
Not displaying its function,
yet its function is like that of Heaven and Earth,
not proclaiming its brilliance,
yet its brilliance rivals the sun and moon—
this is the trace’s non-action.
This non-action is not feigned,
imitating the beauty of non-action while practicing it—
it is truly *without pretense of non-action*.
The *Dao* employs yin and yang as its agents,
the spirits and gods as its strategists;
advancing and retreating, shifting and yielding,
it blends with transformation without end,
mysteriously silent and boundless,
yet moving with transformation as one—
this is called the heart and trace both in non-action.

Yet *virtue*’s nourishing embrace of all things
is also how its traces become manifest.

The lesser *virtue* acts yet has pretense of non-action.
**Annotation:** Those who practice lesser *virtue* act,
for though the heart lacks the brilliance of function,
its traces involve action—
thus it is said: *acts yet has pretense of non-action*.
This speaks of lesser *virtue*’s non-action
having a reason for its existence.
This is the heart in non-action,
while the traces are in action.

**Exegesis:** This elucidates lesser *virtue*.
Those who practice lesser *virtue* act,
for though the heart admires non-action’s transformation,
it still practices this non-action—
thus it is said: *acts yet has pretense of non-action*.
Though the heart is said to be in non-action,
when examining its traces,
they involve ostentation and effort.
Thus it is said: *while the traces are in action*.
**Annotation:** This is the heart in non-action,
while the traces are in action.

**Exegesis:** In ancient times, when *virtue* declined,
the heart and traces became clear and apparent.
The sovereign knew that action was wrong,
that non-action was right—
action made things shallow,
non-action made them pure and harmonious.
With this distinction,
he concealed his heart and hid his function,
practiced non-action’s affairs,
and restrained action’s *doings*—
thus it is said: *acts yet has pretense of non-action*.
His heart desired non-action,
wandering in non-action,
yet in traces, he still leaned toward ostentation.
Knowing non-action as beautiful,
action as evil,
he abandoned evil for good,
admiring non-action’s distinction—
thus it is said: *there is a reason for this action*.
Hence, when speaking of Supreme Benevolence,
though it acts, it has no pretense of non-action.

**Annotation:** Benevolence is the name for universal love.
When lesser *virtue* declines and Supreme Benevolence appears,
it is the universal love of Benevolence—
thus it is said: *acts yet has pretense of non-action*.
To practice Benevolence while forgetting Benevolence,
this is also to seek non-action—
yet the heart still has deeds to attend to.
Though traces approach non-action,
this is the heart in action,
while the traces are in non-action.

**Exegesis:** Though Supreme Benevolence is named for non-action,
it is based on the desire for non-action
while still adhering to its principles—
it cannot yet speak to lesser *virtue*’s action.
**Exegesis:** This clarifies how, when the *Dao*’s practice fades,
Benevolence and righteousness are then upheld.

Supreme Benevolence is said to act yet have no pretense of non-action.
**Annotation:** Benevolence is the name for universal love,
and when lesser *virtue* declines while Supreme Benevolence appears,
it is the universal love of Benevolence—
thus it is said: *acts yet has pretense of non-action*.
To practice Benevolence while forgetting Benevolence,
though there is giving, there is no expectation of return—
yet universal love is hard to achieve,
and ultimately, it remains limited kindness without trust.
Thus, though the heart is always engaged in affairs,
it is said: *acts yet has pretense of non-action*.
When examining its traces,
they are close to non-action—
thus it is said: *while there is no pretense of non-action*.
**Annotation:** This is the heart in action,
while the traces are in non-action.

**Exegesis:** Benevolence is the name for universal love.
The practice of the Great *Dao* favors no private gain,
and as pure customs fade,
universal love naturally emerges.
Now, it is clarified why this is called Benevolence’s universal love—
thus it is said: *Supreme Benevolence acts yet has pretense of non-action*.
To practice Benevolence while forgetting Benevolence,
though giving exists, there is no demand for repayment—
yet universal love is difficult to realize,
and it remains limited kindness without sincerity.
Thus, though the heart is always in action,
it is said: *acts yet has pretense of non-action*.
When examining its traces,
they are close to non-action—
thus it is said: *while there is no pretense of non-action*.
**Annotation:** This is the heart in action,
while the traces are in non-action.

**Exegesis:** Benevolence is the name for universal love.
The *Book of Plainness* says:
*"Benevolence is what people cherish,
possessing a heart of compassionate kindness and pity,
to nurture all things to their fullness—
this is Benevolence."*

The Benevolent one, in bestowing broadly upon all things,
is the very source of partiality.
When compared to **virtue/power (德)**, it is inferior.

In the age of the **Dao/Way (至道)**, all actions are encompassed,
without partiality or distinction—
thus it is silent, tranquil, and boundless.
That which gives birth yet does not govern is the **Dao/Way (道)**.
All things receive its transformation and attain their own fulfillment—this is **virtue/power (德)**.
To complete, to mature, to nourish, and to cultivate—this is **Benevolence (仁)**.
Birds and beasts, plants and movement—
each fulfills its proper nature—this is **Righteousness (义)**.
Sentient and insentient alike—
each is endowed with its inherent nature—this is **Wisdom (智)**.
To arise when it is time to arise,
and to rest when it is time to rest—this is **Faithfulness (信)**.
To follow the rhythms of Heaven and Earth,
and to regulate the four seasons—this is **Rite (礼)**.
To harmonize the resonance of Heaven and Earth,
and to delight all things—this is **Music (乐)**.

Thus, in **serene stillness and non-action (恬澹无为)**,
there is nothing it does not accomplish.

When the **Great Dao (大道)** recedes,
**virtue/power (德)** takes its place in transformation.
The transformation of **Great Virtue (至德)**,
also encompasses **Great Benevolence, Great Righteousness, Great Rite, Great Wisdom, and Great Faithfulness**,
and together they transform.

But when **virtue/power (德)** declines,
**Benevolence (仁)** stands alone as **Benevolence (仁)**,
**Righteousness (义)** stands alone as **Righteousness (义)**,
and they can no longer transform together.

Why is this so?
Those who practice **Benevolence (仁)** take compassionate love as their heart,
and thus lack the firm resolve to act—
therefore, **Righteousness (义)** is absent.
Those who practice **Righteousness (义)** judge and cut away what is wrong,
taking and discarding—
therefore, **Benevolence (仁)** is absent.

Thus, when the seven stand alone—
**Benevolence (仁)** as **Benevolence (仁)**, **Righteousness (义)** as **Righteousness (义)**—
they cannot transform together.

Yet the **Supreme Benevolent (上仁)**,
though it may appear to have traces of partiality,
when it forgets **Benevolence (仁)**,
forgets its traces as well.
Though the traces may vanish,
the heart retains the thought of broad bestowal,
circulating with pity for all things,
all desiring their well-being—
thus the heart still engages in action.
The **Supreme Benevolent (上仁)** forgets its traces,
so its traces are in non-action.

*"Small kindnesses do not inspire trust"*—
this is what **Zhuo Ge (曹刿)** said to **Duke Zhuang of Lu** in the tenth year of his reign.
That year, in the first month,
the Duke defeated the Qi army at **Changsuo (长勺)**.
Before the battle, **Zhuo Ge** requested an audience.
His fellow villagers said: *"The lords of the land deliberate these matters—what need have you to hear them?"*
**Zhuo Ge** replied: *"The lords are narrow-minded and cannot think far ahead."*
He then entered to see the Duke,
who asked why he wished to fight.
The Duke said: *"Food and clothing are what sustain life—I dare not keep them for myself alone,
but must share them with others."*
**Zhuo Ge** replied: *"Small kindnesses do not reach all—
the people will not follow you."*
The Duke said: *"Sacrificial offerings and jade and silk—I dare not add to them,
but must act with sincerity."*
**Zhuo Ge** replied: *"Small sincerity does not inspire divine favor—
the spirits will not bless you."*
The Duke said: *"In great and small cases of justice,
though I may not discern them fully,
I must act according to what is proper."*
**Zhuo Ge** replied: *"This is loyalty—
with this, we can win the battle."*
He then asked to join the battle.
