**Volume Thirty-One of the *Extensive Scripture on the True Dao/Way and Virtue/Power* [《道德真经广圣义》]**
**Narrated by Tang Guangcheng Master Du Guangting [唐广成先生杜光庭述]**

---

**Chapter Thirty-Nine of the *Obtaining the One* [昔之得一章]**
**Commentary:** The previous chapter elucidates the distinctions between the upper virtue and lower rites—one pure, the other refined. Therefore, it presents the conduct of the mature man in taking and leaving to show the direction of things. This chapter clarifies that when things obtain the Dao/Way, they manifest its use and thus come to fruition; adherence to the Dao preserves them, while arrogance causes their loss. Hence, it enumerates the humble and modest virtue of the feudal lords and kings as a warning.

**Explication:** The Dao/Way is the divine essence of heaven and earth, the source from which all things obtain the *One*. This serves to illustrate that when the Dao is employed, there is tranquility, but when it is lost, there is peril. It warns the feudal lords and kings that adherence to the Dao brings fortune, while transgression brings misfortune. Yet the feudal lords and kings adhere to the Dao through humility and restraint, accumulating virtue as their foundation. They do not desire to be like jade—its brilliance is held up as the ultimate warning.

**Those who obtained the One in antiquity:**
**Annotation:** The *One* refers to the harmonious *qi* of the Dao/Way.

Because its wondrous use in all things is unified, it is called the *One*. Thus, the *Commentary* states: In antiquity, the *One* was the harmonious *qi*. It is called the *One* because it is identical with all things, unchanging from ancient times to the present. This is what is meant by the *One*. Hence, the *Systematic Commentary of the Yijing* [《易□系》] says: "The alternation of one *yin* and one *yang*—this is called the Dao/Way." It reveals that the Dao/Way’s *qi* is harmonized with *yin* and does not merge with *yin*, nor does it merge with *yang* and *yang*—this is what is meant by the *One*.

Speaking of antiquity, it is to trace the origin and reach the end, to suppress the superficial and return to the fundamental, and to draw upon past attainment to verify present attainment. The principle of the *One* will be briefly expounded below.

**Explication:** The Sage Laozi, wishing to elucidate the harmonious Dao/Way’s *qi*, which permeates all things, and to expound the wondrous attainment of the *One*, does so to clarify the source of generation and transformation. The Dao’s generation and transformation have neither end nor beginning; borrowing the meaning of antiquity’s enduring expanse, it serves as the origin for the dissemination of its transformations.

The reason the Dao is called the *One* is that in the generation of all things, the Dao’s *qi* descends uniformly. When the *qi* exists, things are born; when the *qi* vanishes, things die. The way in which things receive the Dao’s *qi* is no different; in all things, it is the *One*. Though ancient and modern times may change, the *One* itself remains unaltered. Hence, it is said to be unchanging—this is what is meant by the *One*.

The Dao is neither *yin* nor *yang*; in *yang*, it is *yang*; in *yin*, it is *yin*. It is also like this: in heaven, it is clear; on earth, it is tranquil. Wherever it resides, it harmonizes. The Dao is not confined to *yin* and *yang*, yet it can be *yin* and can be *yang*; it is not limited to heaven and earth, yet it can be heaven and can be earth. It is not singular, yet it can be singular. It revolves and returns, and there is nothing it cannot do.

Since antiquity has obtained it, the present still follows it. Thus, it is known that a vacant mind brings the Dao’s harmony, and profound stillness returns to the *One*. Those who can achieve profound stillness and a vacant mind—this is what is meant by suppressing the superficial and returning to the fundamental.

"The alternation of one *yin* and one *yang*—this is called the Dao/Way," are the words of the *Systematic Commentary of the Yijing* [《易□系》]. The *One* is called the *Non-One* [无], for without *yin* and without *yang*, it is the Dao. The *One* attains the *Non-One* because it is the boundless void, indivisible, and only the *One* exists. Hence, the *One* is the *Non-One*.

If there were boundaries, distinctions between opposites, then there would be two or three, and it would not be the *One*. Therefore, when the Dao is in *yin*, it does not appear as the function of *yin*; when the Dao is in *yang*, it does not appear as the power of *yang*. *Yin* and *yang* are natural, without contrivance—this is the Dao.

The *One* is spoken of as a number; numbers are spoken of as the *One*. In terms of substance, it is the *Non-One*, yet things obtain the Dao’s interpenetration. Its subtlety is beyond measure—this is called the *Divine* [神]; its transformations respond to circumstances—this is called the *Yijing* [易]. In summary, all things without distinction are called the Dao. Hence, the Sage establishes the names and titles of human affairs in accordance with its principles, not singular yet singular, thus able to remain constantly singular. Constantly singular is not singular, nor is it not singular. Yet it is the *One*, for it is the beginning of heaven and earth, the origin of all things, the foundation of generation and transformation, and the revered source of life.

From the *One*, it can be *yin* and can be *yang*—this is how the *One* generates the *Two*. Tracing the origin and reaching the end means that *yuan* [原] is the foundation, and *yao* [要] is clarification. The *Systematic Commentary of the Yijing* [《易□系》] uses these terms.

Heaven obtains the *One* and thus is clear,
**Commentary:** There is no greater manifestation of *qi* than the *Great Primordial* [乾元]. Hence, it is first marked as the foremost attainment of the *One*. The pure *yang* *qi*, because it obtains the *One*, can thus be vast and encompassing, providing the beginning for all things.

**Explication:** The *yang* *qi* is expansive; the *Great Primordial* [乾] is vast and primordial, generating all things. All things rely on the *Great Primordial* for their birth, hence the *Yijing* says: "Great indeed is the *Great Primordial*! All things draw their beginnings from it." Heaven is the accumulation of *qi*, hence it is the greatest manifestation of *qi*, its form like a tilted canopy, thus it is said to be vast and encompassing. This gives rise to the saying of the "Tilted Heaven" [穹天].

Speaking of heaven as vast and encompassing, high and round, it envelops all things. Heaven is the embodiment of pure *yang* and the void, not a material obstruction. Yet heaven, without the operation of the harmonious Dao/Way’s *qi*, could not be clear and floating without rest.

The *Systematic Commentary of the Yijing* [《易□系》] says: "The *Great Primordial* [乾] is the most robust vitality under heaven." The *Great Primordial* clearly manifests itself to people—this is easy to understand. The *Systematic Commentary of the Yijing* [《易□系》] says: "The *Great Primordial* is firm and clearly shows people its harmony. Because it obtains the *One* and does nothing, all things are thereby generated, and it shows people its ease."

If the *Great Primordial* were not firm, or if it were to collapse or fracture, it would not be able to demonstrate its attainment of the *One* and its simple, easy Dao/Way.

Earth obtains the *One* and thus is tranquil,
**Commentary:** There is no greater manifestation of form and substance than the *Receptive* [坤仪]. The pure *yin* substance, because it obtains the *One*, can thus be vast and thick, bearing and nurturing all things.

**Explication:** The *yin* *qi* is expansive; the *Receptive* [坤] is vast and thick, bearing and nurturing all things, merging and uniting without limit. Earth is the accumulation of form, hence it is the greatest manifestation of form and substance, soft and yielding, tranquil, and all things draw their growth from it. Yet earth, without the operation of the harmonious Dao/Way’s *qi*, could not be thickly bearing and tranquil.

The *Systematic Commentary of the Yijing* [《易□系》] says: "The *Receptive* [坤] is the most yielding under heaven."

The *Receptive* [坤], indeed, is **simply** shown to all—
**Commentary:** This explains how the Earth obtains the *One*.

Because it obtains the *One*, the *Receptive* [坤] is thus **simply** yielding and soft, naturally effortless, and thereby fulfills all things. Hence, it is simply shown to all.
If the *Receptive* [坤] were not simply yielding, but instead **rigidly** firm, it could not simply be shown to all—this would contradict its obtaining the *One*.

The **Spirit** [神] obtains the *One* and thus is **responsive**.
**Commentary:** The *Spirit* [神] is the subtle principle that animates all things. Because it obtains the *One*, it can **respond** without limit, defying form and definition.
**Explication:** In Heaven, it is called *Spirit* [神]; on Earth, it is called *Only* [只]; in Man, it is called *Ghost* [鬼].
Generally speaking, it is termed *Spirit* [神].
The *Spirit* [神] is the **unfathomable interplay** of *yin* and *yang*, with **boundless** concealment and revelation.

Yet the *Spirit* [神], without the operation of the harmonious Dao/Way’s *qi*, could not **respond** with boundless transformation and unfathomable responsiveness.
To fail in boundless transformation and unfathomable responsiveness is to contradict its obtaining the *One*.

The **Valley** [谷] obtains the *One* and thus is **abundant**.
**Commentary:** Water flows into streams, and streams into valleys. The Valley obtains the *One*, hence its springs flow endlessly, abundant and inexhaustible.
**Explication:** The Han Valley obtains the harmonious Dao/Way’s *qi* in operation, and thus water flows abundantly.
Should the Dao/Way’s *qi* depart, the deep valley would become a mound.
If the deep valley becomes a mound, the waters dry up and the streams run empty—this contradicts the Valley’s obtaining the *One*.

All things obtain the *One* and thus **are born**.
**Commentary:** *Things* [物] encompasses all animate and inanimate beings, from plants and animals to sentient and insentient forms.
Because they obtain the harmonious Dao/Way’s *qi*, they are born and grow, never ceasing or perishing.
**Explication:** *All* [万] signifies the greatest multitude.
The *Spring and Autumn Annals* [《春秋》] states: "All [万] is the largest of numbers."
*Things* [物] refers to all forms with substance and visibility.
*Encompasses* [该] means *includes* or *approximates*.
*Animates* [动] refers to creatures like fish, insects, birds, and beasts, as well as those that crawl or fly.
*Plants* [植] refers to mountains, rivers, grasses, and trees.
*Sentient* [有情] refers to beings with both form and consciousness.
*Insentient* [无情] refers to beings with form but lacking consciousness.
Though these things number in the billions and trillions, without the harmonious Dao/Way’s *qi* in operation, they cannot be born or fulfilled.

The **Noble Lords and Kings** [侯王] obtain the *One* and thus **uphold** the Dao/Way for all under Heaven.
**Commentary:** Noble Lords and Kings are the sovereigns of the people. *Noble Lords* [侯] are the highest of the five ranks of nobility. *Kings* [王] are rulers of the myriad chariots.
Because Noble Lords and Kings obtain the *One*, they can **endure** as rulers of all under Heaven, without thought, all submit, and thus **uphold** the Dao/Way’s harmony.

The original text sometimes uses the character **uphold** [贞], which is the same as **Dao/Way** [正].
**Explication:** *King* [王] is the general title for a ruler.
*Guanzi* [《管子》] says: "Universal virtue is called *King* [王]."
The ancient practice of creating characters used three strokes to symbolize Heaven, Earth, and Man, connecting the middle stroke to represent the harmonious Dao/Way, hence *universal virtue* [通德] is called *King* [王].
It is also said that *King* [王] is the title to which all people turn.
The *King* [王] occupies the highest position, unifying the Three Powers [三才].
The character *King* [王] uses three strokes with the middle stroke connected, symbolizing the ruler who unites Heaven, Earth, and Man.
The *Spring and Autumn Annals* [《春秋》] states: "The kings of today are the emperors of antiquity."
In times before Yao and Shun, all were called *Emperors* [帝].
Shun passed his rule to Yu, but Yu humbly declined, saying his virtue did not match that of the *Emperors* [帝], so he abandoned the title of *Emperor* [帝] and took that of *King* [王].
It was also said that after Yu’s death, he passed his rule to Yi, but Yu’s son Qi resided on Mount Ji. Qi was virtuous, so the feudal lords abandoned Yi and paid homage to Qi. Though Yu had the title of passing rule to Yi, all under Heaven turned to Qi.
Qi, considering his virtue did not match that of the Five *Emperors* [五帝], took the title of *King* [王].
From then on, all rulers took the title of *King* [王].
When Qin unified all under Heaven, it swallowed the feudal lords and became the sole ruler. It then took the titles of the Three August Ones [三皇] above and the Five *Emperors* [五帝] below, combining them into the title of *Emperor* [皇帝].
The title of *King* [王] today is the highest of the five ranks.
Under Han law, only the Liu family could be *Kings* [王], and only meritorious officials could be *Noble Lords* [侯].
This custom was followed thereafter, with the sons of the Heavenly Son [天子] being made *Kings* [王], and the eldest son being the *Heir-Apparent* [太子].
From the time of the Zhou dynasty, the *King*’s [王] sons were called *Prince* [王子], and the *King*’s [王] grandsons were called *Grand Prince* [王孙].
The Tang dynasty established the law that the *Emperor*’s [皇帝] grandsons and nephews were to be called *Duke* [郡王], and their successors were called *Heir-Duke* [嗣王].
Those of other surnames with merit were sometimes also made *Kings* [王], or given honorific titles, or made *Duke* [郡王].
Yet none of these held the position of ruling land.

The *Noble Lords* [侯] are the second rank of the five ranks: *Duke* [公], *Noble Lord* [侯], *Earl* [伯], *Viscount* [子], *Baron* [男].
The term *Noble Lords and Kings* [侯王] takes the *Noble Lords* [侯] as the representative of the five ranks, the rest being implied.
Yet the Noble Lords and Kings, though they occupy the highest rank and possess the wealth of all the people, must employ the harmonious Dao/Way’s *qi* and the principle of **non-action** [无为] to guard their position, and only then can they endure as rulers and maintain harmonious governance.
Hence the Classic says: "The Sage holds the *One* and thus serves as a model for all under Heaven."
*Without thought, all submit* [无思不服] is from *The Odes of King Wen* [《诗□文王之风》], which speaks of King Wen’s virtue:
All people, east, west, south, and north, are moved by his virtue, their hearts without fail submitting to him.
This is how he **achieves** it.

**Commentary:** Things obtain the Dao/Way’s operation, and thus names are established based on their use.

The Dao/Way endures, and thus names are established; when its use is lost, reality is forfeited.

Hence, when the heavens are clear, the earth serene, the spirits manifest, and the granaries full—all these arise from attaining the marvelous operation of the Dao/Way. Thus it is said: *"This is how it is achieved."*

**Commentary:** This summarizes the preceding meaning and introduces what follows. *Achieve* means *obtain*. How do the heavens attain their clarity, the earth its tranquility, the spirits their luminous transformations, the granaries their abundance, all things their flourishing, and the lords and kings their rectitude? All obtain it through the marvelous operation of the Dao/Way. This demonstrates the benefit of attaining the Dao/Way. The following text elucidates the harm of losing it.

The *Explanation* states: The six—heaven, earth, spirits, granaries, all things, and lords and kings—how do they preserve their constancy and remain steadfast in their place? It is because they attain the harmonious *qi* of the Dao/Way and each reach its perfection. The heavens become clear through it, the earth serene, the spirits luminous, the granaries full, all things flourish, and the lords and kings govern with rectitude. If they do not lose the Dao/Way, each fulfills its proper role. Those who fail are as the following text makes clear.

If the heavens lack clarity, they risk fracturing.
**Commentary:** *Lack* is an expression of sincerity. *With* means *through*. Those who cling to existence perish; those who grasp at possession lose. The heavens, through the Dao/Way’s operation, attain clear and floating purity. If they do not uphold the harmonious *qi* of the Dao/Way but instead cling to their clarity, they risk breaking apart, failing to manifest their form.

The *Explanation* states: The heavens are *yang qi*; the sovereign mirrors them. When *yang qi* reaches its extreme, it brings calamity and decline; when the harmonious *qi* disperses, it leads to fracture. Thus the divinations say: When the heavens split, it is because *yang qi* is insufficient, the sovereign’s virtue decayed, and the heavens crack. During the Jin Dynasty’s Emperor Hui’s reign in the Yuan Kang era, the sovereign’s virtue declined, and the heavens displayed omens of disaster. A fissure several *zhang* wide appeared in the sky, with a resounding sound—this was the loss of the harmonious *qi* of the One. From then on, the Western Jin collapsed, and both Emperor Hui and Emperor Ai bore its blame. The sovereign truly mirrors the responsive *qi* of the heavens.

If the earth lacks serenity, it risks erupting.
**Commentary:** The earth, through the Dao/Way’s operation, attains political tranquility, yet one must forget its tranquility. If one clings to its serenity, it risks erupting and failing to maintain its form.

The *Explanation* states: The earth is *yin qi*, mirroring the ministers, consorts, and female rulers. When *yin qi* reaches its extreme and the harmonious *qi* disperses, eruptive changes occur. *The Records of the Grand Historian* states: In the second year of King You of Zhou (sin-xu), the three rivers of Western Zhou trembled, and Mount Qi collapsed. Laozi said: The *qi* of heaven and earth, if not kept in order, is disrupted by human affairs. When *yang* is suppressed and cannot emerge, and *yin* is oppressed and cannot nourish, thus there is an earthquake. Now the rivers truly tremble—*yang* has lost its place and oppresses *yin*. When *yang* is lost in *yin*, the source must be blocked. The source blocked, the state must perish. Water and soil spread to benefit the people. If the soil has no spread, the people lack resources—what need is there to wait for ruin? This is the loss of the harmonious *qi* of the Dao/Way’s operation.

During the Spring and Autumn period’s 242 years, there were five earthquakes, along with disasters like the collapse of Liang Mountain, Sha Lu, and Stone Speak omens. From the Qin and Han dynasties onward, such events are innumerable. The greater ones submerged cities, the lesser ones toppled bridges and huts. All were regional calamities, and the people bore their blame.

If the spirits lack luminosity, they risk fading.
**Commentary:** The spirits, through the Dao/Way’s operation, attain boundless transformations, yet one must forget their precision. If one clings to their luminosity, they risk fading and failing to operate marvelously.

The *Explanation* states: The essential forms of heaven and earth, the shapes of all things—all are governed by luminous spirits. The luminous spirits are the refined and vital *qi* within, responding and transforming into spirits. The great govern heaven and earth; the small govern states, mountains, and rivers. If they uphold constancy and follow harmony, they can transform beyond measure. If they indulge their power and appear monstrous to people, violating the Dao/Way’s *qi*, they risk extinction.

In the thirty-second year of Duke Lǐ of *Spring and Autumn*, in the seventh month, a spirit descended upon Xīn. The Duke of Guo entertained it. Duke Hui of Zhou asked the Inner Historian Guò: "What is the meaning of this?" He replied: "When a state is about to prosper, a luminous spirit descends to inspect its virtue. When it is about to perish, a spirit also descends to observe its wickedness. Thus there are those who attain spirits and prosper, and those who attain spirits and perish. Yu, Xia, Shang, and Zhou all had such cases. The Duke of Guo’s name was Liáng, and his virtue was cold—was he about to perish?" Later, the State of Guó was indeed destroyed.

In ancient times, the River Spirit was tyrannical, taking brides from mortals. Xīmén Bāo cast the witch into the river, and the harm ceased; the spirit also faded. This was the spirit, not guarding the Dao/Way’s *qi*, inflicting harm upon people, and thus bringing about its own annihilation.

If the granaries lack abundance, they risk drying up.
**Commentary:** The granaries, through the Dao/Way’s operation, attain receptivity without depletion, yet one must forget their fullness. If one clings to their abundance, they risk drying up and failing to flow and nourish.

The *Explanation* states: The granaries’ ability to receive without depletion comes from attaining the harmonious *qi* of the Dao/Way. When the Dao/Way’s *qi* departs, it leads to monstrous changes, tied to the rise and fall of states. Laozi said: When the Luo River dried up, Xia perished; when the Yellow River dried up, Shang perished. In the sin-xu year of King You of Zhou, the rivers dried up and mountains collapsed—this was the omen of Zhou’s destruction. Destruction came within no more than ten years, as fate decreed. When the count reached ten, it was the extreme. In the eleventh year, regen-shēn, Western Zhou was destroyed by the Rénzhōng. The Eastern Derivation of the King followed.

If all things lack vitality, they risk annihilation.
**Commentary:** All things, through the Dao/Way’s operation, attain life. If one clings to them, they risk death and failing to be living beings.

The *Dao/Way*’s principle states:

All formed things—sentient and insentient alike—draw upon the harmonious *qi* of the Dao/Way to live, and lose it to die.

*The Western Ascension Scripture* says: *"When the vital *qi* disperses, life perishes."*
*The Inner Observation Scripture* declares: *"When *qi* enters the body, it is called life; when the spirit departs from form, it is called death."*
Spirit and *qi* are both manifestations of the Dao/Way.
When the Dao/Way abides, life persists; when it departs, death follows.
Truly so.
Even sovereigns, though exalted, risk ruin if they overreach.

**Commentary:** Those who attain the Dao/Way must not boast of its use.
Thus, the heavens must not pride themselves on their clarity, lest they fracture;
the earth must not pride itself on its stability, lest it erupt;
the spirit, if proud, will lose its luminosity;
the valleys, if proud, will dry up;
all things, if proud, will perish.
Sovereigns who pride themselves in their nobility risk collapse.

The sacred teachings endure through ages, fundamentally for the sake of living beings.
Though they speak of the heavens’ purity and the earth’s tranquility,
their ultimate lesson lies in sovereigns guarding humility and embodying the Dao/Way.
Thus, it follows:

The *Dao/Way*’s principle states:
Sovereigns govern through the Dao/Way to secure their exalted station, to rank above all, and to stand supreme.
If they uphold a spirit of humility, avoid excess, align with the people’s hearts, and practice serene governance,
they will enjoy enduring prosperity, and the realm will willingly revere them.

*The Book of Changes*’ *Humility* hexagram says:
*"The humble noble, through humility, preserves himself."*

If one defies the Dao/Way, reverses natural order, indulges in tyranny, loses the harmony of balance, or abandons the principle of unity,
they will meet ruin—both person and state.
Examples include:
Sovereigns—Jin’s Duke Linggong (夷皋), Song’s Duke Zhao (杵白), Qi’s Duke Yi (商人), and Chen’s Duke Ling (平国);
Kings—Xia’s Tai Kang, Yin’s Wu Yi, Zhou’s You and Li, and Han’s Emperors Huan and Ling.
All transgressed Heaven’s order, defied the Dao/Way, and courted annihilation.

**Commentary:** The sacred teachings, as recorded in the *Book of Documents*, declare: *"Heaven creates all things, but only humans are endowed with sentience."*
The sovereign, as parent to the people, must embody the Dao/Way’s governance, nurturing them as parents nurture their children.
First, it warns of Heaven and Earth’s fragility when severed from the Dao/Way’s *qi*—how much more so for sovereigns?
Thus, nobility must root itself in humility, and elevation in submission.

**Commentary:** Sovereigns’ grandeur depends on the people’s foundation.
Those who govern must labor to unite them through humility, fostering harmony.
Otherwise, they will scatter.

**Commentary:** The exalted refers to sovereigns; the lowly, to the common folk.
Sovereigns derive their nobility from the people—thus, the lowly are the true foundation of the exalted.

The *Dao/Way*’s principle states:
Those who govern a realm wield power through one, yet cannot govern alone.
They must rely on the multitude to secure their throne, uphold their authority, enforce decrees, and extend benevolence and awe—
thus ruling over the people.

The common folk are the multitude.

**Commentary:** The *Book of Documents* says: *"The people are the root of the state; if the root is firm, the state endures."*
Sovereigns must prioritize humility and unity—truly the foundation of a stable realm.

The *Dao/Way*’s principle states:
*"The people are the root of the state"*—as in the *Five Sons’ Song* of the *Book of Documents*:
Tai Kang, in his thirteenth year, hunted recklessly beyond Youle for ten moons without return.
His five younger brothers escorted their mother to follow.
They recounted the warnings of the August Yu:
*"The people may be approached, but not dominated.
The people are the root of the state; if the root is firm, the state endures.
I survey the realm—even the most foolish woman or man can surpass me."*
The sovereign must revere the common folk to win their hearts.
Tai Kang, eldest son of Yu’s heir Qi, lost his virtue and was swiftly overthrown by the Youyong clan.
Exiled beyond the Yellow River, he never regained his throne, and Xia’s dynasty perished.
Only when Minor Kang came of age was the state restored.

Thus, humility is the sovereign’s duty.
*The Book of Changes* says:
*"Humility is the handle of virtue—humble and exalted, it shines.*
*The Heavenly Way diminishes excess and honors humility;
the spirits harm excess and bless humility;
human nature abhors excess and cherishes humility.*
Humility subdues others—it is the grip of virtue,
like the handle of an axe, by which one wields power.
The sovereign who embraces humility can govern the world."*

The sovereign’s position is already exalted, yet if he can maintain humility, his governance will shine ever brighter. Humility draws the people’s allegiance—thus it is called *"gathering the people."*

A state is the people; its foundation is its people. How can one fail to cherish and nurture them?

**Commentary:** The *Odes* say, *"Joyous and kind, the virtuous one—
the people’s father and mother."* *Joyous* means delight, *kind* means ease. When a ruler embodies these virtues, loving and nurturing his people, they hold him dear as children do their parents. But if his conduct is the opposite, the people will scatter and depart.

**Explanation:** The *Odes* refer to the words of *"Great Odes—Dongzhao"* [incomplete]. Chuo Kang Gong admonished King Cheng, saying: *"The Heavenly Sovereign nourishes those with virtue and honors those who follow the Way. If a lord has the Way, Heaven nourishes him; if he has virtue, Heaven draws near to him. When one aligns with Heaven, the people rally to him as children to their parents. But if he defies the Way and corrupts virtue, the people will rebel and abandon him, and he cannot long retain his position.*

Thus, lords call themselves *"lonely"* (*gu*), *"widowed"* (*gua*), or *"not-grain"* (*bu gu*),—is this not treating humility as their foundation? Is it not so?

**Commentary:** *"Lonely," "widowed," "not-grain"*—these are terms of self-debasement that lords adopt, taking humility as their root. If not, then they treat lowliness as their foundation.

**Explanation:** This concludes the prior meaning. When lords call themselves *"lonely"* with their ministers, it is as in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, where in the seventh year of Duke Zhao, the Chu ruler built the Cheng Hua terrace and wished to invite the lords to attend its completion. When the structure was finished, he held a sacrifice called *"Luo."* The Grand Steward, Ji Chang, said, *"I can secure the Duke of Lu."* Ji Chang went to invite the Duke of Lu, who declined, saying:

*"Long ago, our former lord, Duke Cheng, commanded my minister Ying Qi: ‘I shall not forget our former lord’s kindness. I will send Heng Fu to oversee Chu, to stabilize its state and pacify its people, thus bringing order.’ Ying Qi received this charge at the Shu Alliance in the second year of Duke Cheng. Since then, I have never failed to uphold it, and now it has been passed to the ancestral temple. From our former lord, Duke Gong, onward—waiting in vain for the sun and moon—four kings have succeeded: Gong, Kang, Jiao Ao, and Ling. Their blessings have not yet reached us, save for Duke Xiang’s gracious attendance at my lord’s funeral. I, with my ministers, grieve that our plans have failed, and the state is in disarray. How can we dare to long for your lord’s favor? If your lord would deign to visit, we would be honored, and Chu would be blessed, fulfilling the Shu Alliance’s intent and your lord’s benevolence. Then my lord would have received his reward—what more could Shu desire? The spirits of our former lords would rejoice, not just my lord alone. If you do not come, let me ask when you might travel, so my lord can present silk and meet you at Shu to receive his reward."*

The Duke dreamed of Duke Xiang’s spirit before departing. Zao Shen said, *"Do not go."* Duke Xiang, when visiting Chu, had dreamed of the Duke of Zhou’s spirit before setting out. Now Duke Xiang’s spirit truly appeared—your lord should not go."

Zi Fu Hui Bo said, *"Go."* *"Our former lord never visited Chu, so the Duke of Zhou’s spirit guided him. Duke Xiang has already gone, and his spirit now guides you. If you do not go, where will you go?"* In the third month, the Duke traveled to Chu. The Duke of Zheng greeted him at Shi Liang. Meng Xi Zi acted as his attendant but failed in proper etiquette. Upon arriving in Chu, he could not properly respond to the welcoming rites. In the fourth month, the Chu ruler hosted him at the New Terrace, assigning a long-bearded official as his attendant. He favored a large, curved bow. Later, he regretted this.

Ji Chang heard of it and saw the Duke. The Duke spoke to him, and Ji Chang bowed in congratulations. The Duke asked, *"What do I have to congratulate?"* Ji Chang replied, *"Qi, Jin, and Yue have long desired this. My lord has no equal, and the favor has passed to you. May you defend against the three neighboring states and guard your treasures well—how could I not congratulate you?"* The Duke, fearful, returned home.

This shows Chu Ling’s lack of trustworthiness, which is why his reign did not endure. In the ninth month, the Duke returned from Chu. Meng Xi Zi was ill and could not perform the rites properly. He then began studying, and those who could perform the rites followed him. Thus, Nan Gong Jing Shu and those below him studied the rites with Confucius. Confucius and Jing Shu went to Zhou to inquire about the rites from Lao Jun.

**Commentary:** Those who call themselves *"not-grain"* do so because they detest insincerity and lack of virtue.

**Explanation:** In the eleventh year of Duke Cheng of the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Qin and Jin formed an alliance at Cheng, and they planned to meet at Ling Hu.

The Duke of Jin arrived first, but the Qin Marquis refused to cross the River. These were the Duke of Jin’s **Lì** (厲) and the Qin Marquis’s **Huán** (桓).

The Qin Marquis then proceeded to **Wángchéng** (王城), and sent his minister **Shǐ Kē** (史颗) to make a pact with the Duke of Jin at the River’s eastern bank. The Duke’s **Jì Wèi** (郄犨) made the pact with the Qin Marquis at the River’s western bank. **Fàn Wénzǐ** (范文子) remarked: “What good is this pact? The **Qí** (齐) alliance was meant to guarantee sincerity. A **huì** (会) is where sincerity begins. If one does not follow at the beginning, how can it be guaranteed?”

The Qin Marquis returned and broke the pact with Duke Cheng of Jin. In the fourth month, on the day **wùwǔ** (戊午), the Duke of Jin sent **Lǚ Xiàng** (吕相) to sever relations with Qin. At that time, the Qin Marquis had already made a pact with the Duke of Jin at Ling Hu, but he also summoned the **Dí** (狄) and **Chǔ** (楚), intending to lead them against Jin. Thus, the other lords sent their envoys to Jin as a sign of respect.

Lǚ Xiàng spoke to the Qin Marquis: “The people of Chǔ despise your divided **virtue/power** (德), and they have also come to tell me: ‘The Qin Marquis has broken the Ling Hu pact and now seeks a new pact with us. We solemnly declare to the **Hàotiān Shàngdì** (昊天上帝), the Qin **Three Dignitaries** (三公), and the Chǔ **Three Kings** (三王): Though we engage with the Duke of Jin, we only seek our own advantage.’ **Not-grain** (不谷) detests their lack of sincerity and **virtue/power** (德), so we proclaim this to warn against inconsistency.

When all the lords heard these words, they deeply regretted and were earnestly concerned, flocking to our humble ruler. Our humble ruler, in turn, eagerly obeys their commands and only seeks their favor. If you, my lord, would graciously consider the lords and grant them a pact, we would accept peace, and the lords would withdraw. If you do not extend great favor, we are unworthy, and cannot make the lords withdraw.

We dare to present this fully to your officials, so that they may deliberate and act accordingly.

The Jin **Lè Shū** (乐书), **Shì Xiè** (士燮), **Hán Jié** (韩厥), and **Zhào Zhān** (赵旃) led the four armies, with **Jì Yì** (郄毅) commanding the chariots and **Lè Zhēn** (乐针) as the right-hand officer. In the fifth month, on the day **dīnghài** (丁亥), the Jin forces, along with the allied lords’ armies and the Qin forces, fought at **Má Sūn** (麻隧). The Qin forces were utterly defeated. They captured **Qín Chéngqiāng** (秦成羌) and **Bù Gēngsǐ Fù** (不更汝父).

This shows that the Qin Marquis broke the pact—Qin was wrong, Jin was right—and so this defeat occurred.

**Commentary:** Furthermore, according to ritual, one who lacks a father calls himself **gū** (孤), and one who lacks a husband calls herself **guǎ** (寡). **Gǔ** (谷) means good, so **bù gǔ** (不谷) is like saying "not good." These three titles—**gū** (孤), **guǎ** (寡), and **bù gǔ** (不谷)—are terms people despise, yet kings and lords adopt them as their self-designation. This is because they cultivate humility and do not boast of their exalted status.

**Explanation:** The terms **gū** (孤), **guǎ** (寡), and **bù gǔ** (不谷) are not beautiful titles. Kings and lords base themselves on humility, so they use these unworthy and unlovely titles as their own designation and apply them to others. To **cultivate oneself** (自牧) is to nurture, as the *Yì* (易) **Qián** (谦) hexagram states: *"The modest and virtuous person, through humility, nurtures himself."* **Qián** (矜) means to boast. Those who hold positions of power but do not rely on arrogance, who lead yet do not harm others, will be joyfully followed by all without being resented. This is what it means.

The ancients said: *"The ruler who follows the Dao/Way delights in bringing delight to others, while the ruler who lacks the Dao/Way delights in his own pleasure. The one who delights others is cherished by the people and finds security in himself; the one who delights himself is hated by the people and meets his doom."* For one who governs the state and the people, should he not take warning from this?

**Commentary:** This is where they say "to base oneself on lowliness" (以贱为本). If one says this, is it not indeed to base oneself on lowliness?

**Explanation:** The **Lao Jun** (老君) wished to clearly demonstrate that nobility is rooted in lowliness, and that humility is the foundation of exalted status. Thus, he posed a question and answered it himself to emphasize this meaning.

There is a question, and there is an answer; there is a call, and there is a response. Just as a body is divided and its shadow appears, or a sound is made and its echo follows, the question and answer are a pretext to repeatedly stress the warning and exhortation. Therefore, he led to the discussion of counting carriages, yet there are no carriages.

**Annotation:** Counting carriages yet finding none is because the wheels and axles are the essence of carriages. Counting nobility yet finding none is because lowliness is the root of nobility. Wheels and axles are the basis of carriages—if the basis exists, carriages will be present; if not, there will be none. Lowliness is the root of nobility—if the root is preserved, one will have status; if not, one will have none.

This is said to warn kings and lords to base themselves on lowliness, so they should not neglect or abandon the solitary and vulnerable.

**Explanation:** The sages expounded on the **sutras/dharmas** (经) with many meanings. Sometimes they directly point to the truth of things, entering the path of principle without detour;

「Sometimes they use metaphorical language to convey profound meaning, aligning with the subtle and mysterious.

To clarify that the noble status of kings and lords is rooted in lowliness: wheels and axles are the collective names for carriages, yet the essence lies in preserving the wheels and axles to uphold the grand title of "carriage." Likewise, preserving humility ensures the exalted name of "kings and lords." If one does not forget its origin or abandon its root, then the grand title of "carriage" and the noble name of "kings and lords" will endure. What is said about "nobility without fixed form" means that from the beginning of chaos to the end of the Xia dynasty, changes were manifold—establishing titles and names, with virtue varying in quality, the world experiencing rise and fall, people’s fates differing, and customs diverging. Thus, there are times of profound silence, where no names or titles are set, and no virtue or status is recognized.

Even in cases where there is vast and boundless **Dao/Way** (鸿蒙) called "the **August** (皇)," or where there is the **mystic inundation** (潢然沐浴) called "Emperor" (帝), or where there is radiant clarity called "King" (王), or where there is broad influence and intermingling called "Hegemon" (霸), and below them, the ranks of **Marquis** (后辟), **Duke** (公), **Earl** (侯), **Viscount** (子男), **Minister** (卿), **Noble** (相), **Great Official** (大夫), and **Commoner** (元士)—all these titles arise with the times and are named according to the **era**. The distinctions of rank and status are varied, yet all are noble and govern the people.

Though they hold high positions and rule over others, they should not elevate themselves with arrogance or belittle others to exalt themselves. Elevating oneself leads to downfall; scorn for others brings danger to oneself. Instead, they should cultivate humility in their hearts and make self-restraint their aim.

Thus, the sages established titles and warnings, using terms like "solitary," "widowed," "orphaned," and "vulnerable" (孤、寡、不谷) to signify that nobility must not forget lowliness, and exaltation must not forget humility. Only then can they enjoy eternal blessings and lasting good fortune. Those who violate this principle have never failed to be forgotten.

Again, the saying "no carriages" (无舆) or "carriages without carriages" (车无车) points to the reality of carriages by examining their components—only when the parts like wheels, axles, and carriages are assembled does the whole become a "carriage." This aligns with the meaning in *Zhuangzi’s* **"Equilibrium of Yang"** (则阳篇), where the **Master Taigong** (太公) instructed **Young Zhizhi** (少知):

*"Unite the disparate to make them one, disperse the one to make them disparate again. Now, if you point to the hundred parts of a horse yet cannot find the horse itself, set the horse before you and gather its hundred parts to call it a horse. This shows that combining skin, fur, hoofs, and tails makes a horse, just as assembling wheels, axles, and carriages makes a carriage."*

Some say "praise without praise" (誉无誉) means that those seeking noble status should value sincerity over empty flattery. Though this meaning differs, it still carries the intent of warning and exhortation. The *Xiang Er* commentary further states:

*"Thus, the pursuit of praise leads to people craving fame. 'Praise without praise' means one should not let people be without their own lack of praise."* This parsing of the sentence also reinforces the warning and exhortation, urging individuals to be reverent and humble, to love others and care for all things, thereby following the teachings of the **Mysterious Primordial** (玄元).

They should not be dazzling like jade nor rough like stone.
**Annotation:** *Dazzling* (琭琭) refers to the polished appearance of jade; *rough* (硌硌) refers to the coarse texture of stone. The point is to remain rooted in lowliness.

The **Commentary** (疏) explains:

*"Jade is noble while stone is lowly. To be 'like jade' is to exalt oneself; to be 'like stone' is to humble oneself. Since kings and lords base themselves on lowliness, they should not be dazzling like jade—elevating themselves in nobility—but instead should be rough like stone, guarding their humility."*

The meaning is this: jade and stone are used to illustrate nobility and lowliness. Carriages and chariots are used to explain the gathering of many into one. These two sentences reiterate the warning that kings and lords should root themselves in lowliness.

The **highest virtue** (上德) of a ruler embodies the **Dao/Way** of the **Great Void** (太虚), concealing their appearance in **mystic stillness** (玄冥), acting with **gentleness and weakness** (柔弱), and remaining at **harmony and peace** (和平). They follow **rules and measures** (规矩), reflect upon the **Supreme Clarity** (太清), yet do not exalt themselves through titles or names.

In later ages, as virtue declines, rulers possess **nine-tiered nobility** (九重之尊), the **prestige of ten thousand chariots** (万乘之贵), the **wealth of the four seas** (四海之富), and the **prosperity of the six directions** (六合之殷). Their majesty rivals that of the **Heaven and Earth** (天地), their brilliance matches that of the **Sun and Moon** (日月), their decrees resemble the **cycles of cold and heat** (寒暑), and their awe-inspiring power mirrors the **thunder and lightning** (雷霆). Yet they do not take all beings as their concern nor reflect upon the lives of the people. They indulge in **excessive luxury** (繁奢), exalt themselves in grandeur, and though they hear the terms "solitary," "widowed," "orphaned," and "vulnerable," they do not grasp their true intent.

From the **First Emperor of Qin** (秦始皇), who devoured the world like a tiger and swallowed the **lords** (诸侯) like a whale, unifying all under heaven and dismissing the names "solitary," "widowed," "orphaned," and "vulnerable," he instead proclaimed, *"I"* (朕). *"I," "myself," "me," and "also"* (余、吾、我也) became his titles, losing the original intent of humility and instead displaying his **exalted arrogance** (尊大). From this point onward, rulers began to prize empty flattery, comparing themselves to **Emperor Yao** (尧) and **Emperor Shun** (舜) for honor. They scorned humble names, treating them like discarded tiles and stones. This path leads to **ruin and downfall** (辗败亡、践凋落), and it should be lamented deeply.

The **highest precepts** (太上格言) earnestly warn: one should remain **balanced between jade and stone**, neither too much nor too little, neither noble nor lowly. With **unity** (一) as the **foundation** (纪纲) and the **Dao/Way** as the **mainstay** (桢干), they govern the world with virtue yet do not claim ownership of it.

For those who embody **Dao/Way** in their conduct, their aspirations should be thus: to enjoy nobility without delight, to bear lowliness without sorrow, to ascend without peril, and to descend while ever more serene. How could one not strive for such attainment?

**End of Volume 31 of *The Extensive Commentary on the Daoist Canon of Virtue and the Sacred** (道德真经广圣义卷之三十一竟). #1 **Universal Embracing of Thoughts on Ruler’s Virtue** (泛能怀思君德): In *The Zuo Tradition*, "泛" (universal) is rendered as "况" (metaphorical), extending its meaning.

**Volume 32 of *The Extensive Commentary on the Daoist Canon of Virtue and the Sacred*** (道德真经广圣义卷之三十二) is narrated by **Master Guangcheng of the Tang** (唐广成先生), **Du Guangting** (杜光庭).」

**Chapter 40: The Movement of Dao Through Reversal**

**Commentary:**
The preceding chapter warns against arrogance and rigid adherence by illustrating how Heaven and Earth achieve harmony through *One*. This chapter expounds upon the interplay of *power* (权) and *reality* (实), further elucidating the beauty of reversing the *Dao/Way*—for without arrogance, perfection is attained.

When nobility aligns with righteousness, only then may one employ *power*. To deepen understanding of the Dao’s essence, the principle of *emptiness-in-use* (冲用) is reiterated once more.

**Exposition:**
The Dao of *emptiness-in-use* is the subtle origin of all things. It encompasses both existence and nonexistence, permeating Heaven and Earth. Through it, Heaven and Earth attain tranquility and permanence; all things thrive and fulfill their nature. A ruler governing by the Dao’s transformation must practice *wuwei* (non-action), never clinging to titles or rigid dogma. Thus, he is warned: to base oneself in humility, lest one abandon the origin and lose the root. Therefore, *power* is demonstrated as a means to return to the root—harmonizing *emptiness-in-use* with mystical practice. This is the chapter’s core intent.

**Reversal is the Dao’s movement.**
**Annotation:** This elucidates *power*.
Reversal refers to aligning with the Dao while conforming to its principles. Reversing the conventional to harmonize with righteousness is the Sage’s exercise of *power*. To exercise *power* is to set the Dao in motion. Hence, it is said: *Reversal is the Dao’s movement*.
**Commentary:** Reversal signifies countering worldly norms; *movement* denotes transformation—speaking of *power* in the Dao. It is said that creatures cling to life yet lose the Dao through their attachment. Therefore, the Sage employs transformation and *power* to guide beings away from convention and toward the Dao.

**Exposition:**
When things conform to the Dao, they live; when they stray, they die. Why so? The Dao is naturally without action or doing; yet humans act and contrive. The Dao is without desire or emotion; yet humans crave and feel. Thus, convention opposes the Dao, leading one from life toward death.

The *Classic* states: *"Drive it to the brink of death, so that its vitality may flourish."* Again: *"Men lightly court death because their desire for life is excessive."* Therefore, those who court death through excessive desire for life—pursuing wealth, conforming to worldly norms, exhausting their nature, laboring their spirits, seeking glory and rewards—though these are meant to sustain life, they unknowingly transgress their proper measure and thus forfeit existence.

Master Wu said: *"Heaven and Earth nurture birds and beasts with feathers and fur, providing them with insects and grains. How much more so for humans?"* Though clothing and food are essential to life, one may entrust oneself to fate rather than frantically seek them. To fail in embodying the Dao and preserving life, yet surrender to fate and follow one’s destiny—this is to cling to life while losing the Dao.

If one abandons frantic seeking and rests in tranquil acceptance, aligning with serenity and contentment, life may yet be preserved. A ruler governs by nurturing the natural inclinations of things, aligning with Heaven’s timing, easing harshness to benefit the people, lightening taxes to nourish life, and refraining from territorial expansion or arms buildup. He avoids extravagant palaces and excessive bureaucracy, elevating all living beings to domains of longevity. Only then may one say they have reversed convention and followed the Dao.

**Commentary:**
The annotation states: *"Reversing the conventional to harmonize with righteousness"*—*conventional* refers to fixed norms; *righteousness*, to universal principle. Thus, nobility is rooted in humility, elevation in lowliness, and substance in emptiness. Initially, this seems contrary to natural inclination, yet ultimately it aligns with the Dao—hence, it is called *movement*.

**Exposition:**
*Conventional* refers to enduring principles, established as teaching yet unchanging. *Righteousness* refers to adaptable reason, applied flexibly as circumstances demand. The world values high status as weighty and lowliness as trivial, all aspiring to elevation while spurning humility, discarding lightness for heaviness. The *Classic*’s teachings declare that elevation is revealed through lowliness, nobility through humility—thus, humility becomes the foundation of nobility. Even sovereigns, though exalted, must not forget their origins; those who receive blessings endlessly must not forget their lowliness, lest they court peril. This is the Dao’s movement—turning worldly convention back to natural harmony.

**Commentary:**
Confucius said: *"One may stand with him, but not yet exercise power with him."* The Dao, reversing convention, is difficult to grasp. Thus, the analogy of the commoner is invoked: *"The *tángdì*’s* flower turns inward before unfolding—how could you not ponder it? Its chamber is distant."* This lost poem likens *power* in the Dao: first inverted, then aligned, first contrary, then harmonious. Those who think of a person yet cannot see them dwell in a distant chamber—likewise, those who ponder *power* yet fail to grasp the Dao dwell far from it. The Master said: *"You have not yet pondered it—how distant could it be?"* Meaning: in reversal, the failure to ponder is what makes it seem distant. If one ponders reversal, what distance remains? Thus, *power* is knowable through thought—only the unthinking fail to see. Thought follows its order, and thus it may be understood.

Therefore, *power* in the Dao is the ruler’s sharpest instrument. Its use requires the right person—one who reverses convention and aligns with the Dao. Without such a person, reversal becomes chaos.

**Weakness is the Dao’s application.**
**Annotation:** This elucidates *reality*.
*Weakness* signifies yielding, softness, receptivity, and stillness—these are the Sage’s true abode, the Dao’s constant practice. Hence, it is said: *Weakness is the Dao’s application*.
**Commentary:** This clarifies *reality* in the Dao. All revere strength yet despise weakness, unaware that rigid force and arrogance are the tools of convention.

「The Dao triumphs through harmonious softness over rigid hardness. Thus, it is known that yielding, softness, receptivity, and stillness are the Dao’s constant practice.

Therefore, it is said: *Weakness is the Dao’s application*.
**Commentary:** The Dao first embraces softness, yet convention reveres rigid strength. Softness preserves life, while rigid strength brings ruin. The *sutra* states: *"Those who rely on rigid strength shall not attain their natural end"*—I shall take this as my guiding principle. Holding to this teaching, one may guide people to abandon strength and embrace softness, to forsake agitation and return to stillness.

For teaching, there are two paths: *power* and *reality*. The superior scholar discerns *reality* and is instructed through it, naturally aligning in harmony with the Dao and attaining *Dao-wisdom*. The lesser scholar is awakened by *power*’s teachings—just as one who would take away must first give, to make them appreciate its value.

The Dao of governing lies in first cherishing the people, for the people are the foundation of the state and must never be abandoned. Yet in the ancient purity, the people aligned with the Dao, so *reality*’s teachings were applied. In the corrupt later ages, deceit and guile flourished, so *power*’s teachings were used instead.

*Power*’s teachings proceed as follows: first, lure them with the *Way* of goodness; if they do not comply, encourage them with favors and rewards; if encouragement fails, regulate them with laws and decrees; if regulation fails, threaten them with penalties and statutes; if threats fail, restrain them with punishments. These punishments are the five *criminal penalties*: branding the forehead and staining it black (*mòxíng*—ink punishment); cutting off the nose (*yìxíng*—nose punishment); castration for men and imprisonment for women (*gōngxíng*—prison punishment), prohibiting licentiousness; amputating the feet (*chùxíng*—foot punishment); and execution (*dàbì*—capital punishment).

For the five *criminal penalties*, first the testimony of both parties must be established. When both have been heard, judgment is passed among the five *executions*. If the five *executions* are not clear, punishment is applied among the five *penalties*. If the five *penalties* are not accepted, *offenses* are corrected among the five *transgressions*, and those not deserving punishment are pardoned. The faults of the five *transgressions* are balanced in guilt, and when doubt arises, punishment follows *criminal penalties*, while mercy follows *transgressions*.

「Nature and form arise together, both emerging and vanishing in unison—how could they rely on each other in sequence and thus differ?

It is not to say that shadows arise because forms move, or echoes emerge because sounds arise, but rather that all things respond to each other naturally, following the principle of mutual dependence.

The Dao/Way, through its wondrous and formless *qi* (氣化), gives rise to all things, and this is called *nature* (自然). The arising of things from things, and the generation of forms from forms, is called *cause-and-condition* (因缘).

Though the manifestations of things, whether grand like the heavens and earth or minute like insects, all depend on the Dao/Way’s wondrous *qi* (氣化) and its transformative power to come into being, yet they arise from forms and conditions, generating and completing each other in turn.

Those who cultivate the Dao/Way, letting their minds embrace the vast emptiness, holding fast to the One and returning to their original nature, can preserve their existing form and attain boundless longevity. When form aligns with the Dao/Way, it returns to the formless, adapting its transformations as fitting—death and life cannot burden it—then it may be said to have attained *self-sufficient existence and return to the void* (自有而归无).

Master Wu said: Those who cultivate the Dao/Way, the Dao/Way opposes the mundane. From oldness, they return to vigor; from vigor, they revert to infancy; from infancy, they attain the Dao/Way. This is what is meant by abandoning their coarse existence and returning to its wondrous void, restoring the original essence.

Ordinary people cannot perceive the Dao/Way’s original essence or exhaust its fundamental source, thus they fall into death, their transformations following the passage of time—this is truly lamentable.

The Sage pities them, establishing *temporary teachings* (權教) to guide them: to abandon excess and embrace frugality, to abandon falsehood and embrace truth, to abandon desire and action, and to practice *non-action and non-desire* (無為無欲). Following these temporary teachings, they gradually ascend to the true Dao/Way, silently attuning to genuine cultivation—then they may attain the Dao/Way.

Governance of the people relies on *temporary measures* (權), transforming the mundane through the interplay of *temporary and essential* (權實). The Dao/Way is likewise.

The commentary further states: The supreme Dao/Way is boundless and silent, transcending names and labels. All *dharma* (法) are inherently empty in nature, not dependent on each other. This means that the Dao/Way in its utmost essence is void and still, neither *temporary* (權) nor *essential* (實)—how could it be named?

All *dharma* (法) lack inherent existence in their true nature; they are neither present nor absent, and their essence is free from cause and condition. When it speaks of things arising from existence and existence from the void, it is merely a provisional explanation for the sake of discourse.

If one understands that *existence* (有) is *non-existence* (無) and *non-existence* (無) is *existence* (有), then one knows that all *dharma* (法) are empty and that emptiness transcends all *dharma* (法)—how could one speak of *temporary* and *essential* generating each other? Those who grasp this principle may be said to have truly awakened.

The meaning is this: The Dao/Way alone is boundless and silent, beyond naming. It follows the transformations of the age and guides the common folk through provisional teachings. These teachings are the *dharma* (法) themselves.

*Dharma* (法) are applied to people, leading them to abandon vice and embrace virtue. They are passed down to instruct the masses, with many practical applications—hence, it is said, *these are the dharma* (法). Through the *dharma* (法), one attains enlightenment in the Dao/Way; once enlightenment is gained, all *dharma* (法) are transcended.

Teachings establish *provisional methods* (權門); states propagate *provisional laws* (權法). The provisional serves to transform the common folk, eradicating their roots of evil. When evil is removed, the masses return to true principles. Following these principles leads to virtue, and the provisional laws are forgotten.

If one clings to the *temporary and essential* (權實) without letting go, or fixates on the teachings without reforming, then one cannot speak of the Dao/Way with them. Those who forget the *temporary and essential* (權實) and reach the Dao/Way may be said to have fully awakened and ascended to the true—transcending the age and attaining authenticity.

In the *Chuang Tzu*’s *Autumn Water* (秋水) chapter, the Sea Lord speaks to the River Spirit: Those who understand the Dao/Way must penetrate its principles; those who penetrate its principles must grasp its provisional methods; those who grasp its provisional methods will not let things harm themselves. This means that the Dao/Way follows eternal principles, while the provisional adapts to circumstances and establishes changes.

The enlightened one comprehends principles—who could harm them?

**Chapter 41: The Superior Scholar Hears the Dao/Way**

The commentary states: The previous chapter illuminated the dual aspects of *temporary and essential* (權實) as the Dao/Way’s dynamic functions. This chapter clarifies that the Dao/Way, though profound, is only fully grasped by the superior scholar through diligent practice.

Initially, it distinguishes the three types of scholars by their varying responses to the Dao/Way—faith or doubt—then establishes the *path of cultivation* (行門) for the inferior and the *path of virtue* (德) for the enlightened, concluding with the *benefits of proper guidance* (善贷) and its applications.

The meaning is this: The supreme principle is profound and mysterious; the inferior cannot fathom it. The Dao/Way’s clarity is obscured, only the wise can diligently practice it.

Since innate knowledge and discernment differ among people, their faith or doubt in the Dao/Way cannot be swayed—yet the key lies in setting forth provisional teachings to guide them toward virtue, lest they be trapped by their limited nature, seeking only to sink into ignorance without instruction.

Thus, the following passage opens the path to enlightenment, which is the function of proper guidance. The superior scholar hears the Dao/Way and practices it diligently.

The annotation says: Enlightenment leads to diligent practice.

The commentary states: The superior scholar, with deep insight and penetrating wisdom, hears the Dao/Way’s provisional teachings and understands their true essence—though the provisional appears subtle and the essential gentle, they practice it without pause.

Hence, it is said: *The superior scholar hears the Dao/Way and practices it diligently.*

The meaning is this: Though people are born with varying *qi* (氣)—some pure, some turbid—and differing natures—some wise, some foolish—though the Great Unity (大块) initially divides them, and the Original Essence (元精) nurtures all things, bestowing wealth, poverty, longevity, or early death, beauty or ugliness, all according to their fixed portions, these are given by nature and cannot be altered.

Yet the Dao/Way does not abandon any being; it always seeks to save them. Thus, teachings must be established to guide them, laws must be imparted to instruct them, so that they may awaken the confused and deluded, and penetrate the true and authentic.

This is like carving jade to make a vessel or sifting sand to find gold—such is the way.

As Confucius said: Those born with knowledge are the superior; those who learn and gain knowledge are the next; those who, despite their struggles, do not learn, are the lowest of the people. This aligns with the three scholars’ varying grasp of profound principles.

Again, in the *Analects*’ *Yong Ye* (雍也) chapter, it is said: The Master said: For those of average or above intelligence, one can speak of the superior; for those below average, one cannot. This refers to the methods of teaching and transformation.

The *Master’s Sayings* (師說) states: When dividing people by their innate qualities and discernment, there are three broad categories—superior, middle, and inferior. Further refined, there are nine ranks. The highest of the superior ranks are the Sages.

The Sage knows themselves and does not labor under the need for teaching. The lowest of the inferior ranks are the fools. The fool cannot be moved; teaching has no effect on them. Those who can be taught are the middle and inferior ranks below the superior, and the inferior ranks above the middle—seven ranks in total—who may be guided by instruction.»

What is meant by *"those of average or above intelligence can be taught the superior"* is that one speaks of the Dao/Way to those of the superior rank. This is how Confucius taught Yan Hui with the Dao/Way of the superior, and how Yan Hui taught Min Ziqian—thus, those of average or above intelligence can be taught the superior.

As for *"those below average cannot be taught the superior,"* they may still be taught the middle or those below it. For instance, Min Ziqian’s Dao/Way could teach those of the middle rank above, which is why even those of average rank can be taught the superior.

Again, teaching the middle rank above with the Dao/Way of the middle rank above, and the middle rank above with the Dao/Way of the middle rank below—this is how one teaches those of average rank the middle.

Further, teaching the middle rank below with the Dao/Way of the middle rank below, this is how one teaches those below average the middle.

And teaching the lower rank above with the Dao/Way of the lower rank above—this is how one teaches those below average the inferior.

This is a broad classification of those below average.

Since there are nine ranks, the fifth rank is the true average person. The second, third, and fourth ranks are superior, while the sixth, seventh, and eighth are inferior. Only the lowest of the inferior ranks, when taught, remain unmoved and laugh at the Dao/Way.

Master Wu said: The superior person knows without being taught; the inferior person, though taught, remains unmoved. The Dao/Way sets teaching for the average person.

The average person, when spoken to with virtue, inclines toward virtue; when guided toward vice, inclines toward vice. Thus, the purpose of teaching is to guide the average person, who may rise or fall.

The highest teaching entices through many methods, instructs in the virtuous Dao/Way, and gradually transforms them, freeing them from ignorance and delusion, so they may enter the path of progress and virtue. Thus, no person is abandoned.

The superior person naturally attains enlightenment, so their practice is unremitting.

The average person, upon hearing the Dao/Way, is uncertain—sometimes receptive, sometimes not.
*Note: The average person may rise or fall, hence their uncertainty—sometimes receptive, sometimes not.*
*Explanation: The average person’s clarity and obscurity are undetermined. Upon hearing the profound Dao/Way, they may believe or doubt. If clear, they are receptive and faithful; if obscure, they doubt or reject it. Without firm resolve, they are swayed by worldly desires—lured by wealth and status, bound by gain and loss, entangled in pleasures, indulging in arrogance and excess. Hearing the silent Dao/Way, who would labor to cultivate it? Thus, they blind themselves to the five colors, deaf to the five sounds, lost in emotion and drowned in nature. If they could instead fear evil as touching scalding water, crave virtue as if it were beyond reach, acknowledge faults and amend them, emulate the virtuous and strive to equal them, abandoning the average’s indulgences and following the superior’s path, they could ascend to the lofty and attain the void.*

The inferior person, upon hearing the Dao/Way, laughs derisively.
*Note: They are deluded and disbelieving, hence the laughter.*
*Explanation: The inferior person’s understanding does not grasp the principle. Hearing the Dao/Way, they dismiss it as false, scoffing in ridicule—just as the *zhāngfú* hat was deemed vulgar by the Yue people, or the jade *hé* was discarded in Chu. Hence, Zhuangzi said, *"The perverse scholar cannot be spoken to of the Dao/Way."*

*Explanation: The derisive laughter comes from the foolish and ignorant, whose dull minds cannot comprehend the words of the Sage. Though they hear, they do not understand; though they see the teachings of the ancient kings, they do not recognize them. This is what is meant by *"their understanding does not grasp the principle."*

Hearing the true and authentic Dao/Way—how it generates heaven and earth, nurtures the cosmos, encompasses yin and yang, and weaves the transformations of nature—how it prolongs life through self-cultivation and governs the realm with effortless virtue—yet they dismiss it as absurd, laughing in unison. Hence, it is said they laugh derisively.

The *zhāngfú* was the cap of Zhou and Lu. The Yue people were the states of the Hundred Yue. In ancient times, Yu the Great tamed the floods, reaching as far as the eastern barbarians, whose descendants settled there and established their state. Their ancient custom was to wear their hair unbound and tattoo their bodies, until Goujian subdued Wu and they began to assimilate with the Central Plains.

The *zhāngfú* being held in no esteem, it was not a cap they would cherish—thus, it is said, *"to degrade you thus."*

The *hé pǔ*—Coyness and Crudeness—refers to Běn Hé, a man of Chu.
Dwelling beneath the Jing Mountains, he found a jade rough-hewn (*yù pǔ*) and presented it to the Chu king.
He sent artisans to examine it, who declared it stone, accusing him of deceit, and had one foot severed.
Thus, through two successive kings, he presented it twice more, losing both feet.
Běn Hé wept, clutching the rough-hewn jade beneath the Jing Mountains, until the Chu king, hearing of it, summoned him. The artisans carved the stone and found jade within, which the king then treasured.
Later, it passed into Zhao, then into Qin.
When the Qin Emperor unified the realm, abolishing feudal states in favor of commanderies and prefectures, he had the jade carved into the *transmission seal of state*.
It is said that only when Běn Hé presented his rough-hewn jade three times did the ruler of his time recognize its worth.
Thus, it is said, *"he was cast aside in Chu."*

In the *Zhuāngzǐ* [*Qīu Shuǐ*], Hǎi Ruò spoke to Hé Bó, saying:
*"A well-frog cannot be spoken to of the sea—it is confined to its pit.*
*A narrow scholar cannot be spoken to of the Dao—he is bound by doctrine."*

By *narrow scholar* is meant one who clings to the partial views of a single school, entangled in contrivance.
Hé Bó, relying on the autumn floods’ surging flow, did not know his own smallness.
Hǎi Ruò said:
*"The waters of the world have none greater than the sea. All rivers flow into it, yet one does not know when it will cease to fill;
its outlet drains it, yet one does not know when it will cease to empty.
Spring and autumn remain unchanged, and it knows no drought or flood.
Its surpassing the currents of rivers and streams cannot be measured.
Yet I have never boasted of this—
I take form within heaven and earth, drawing qi from yin and yang.
The four seas, as they exist between heaven and earth, are but a drop in the great marsh.
Though the customs of the Yue hold the cap in contempt,
and Chu cast aside the rough-hewn jade,
though the Qin Emperor engraved his seal upon it,
and the Central Plains donned its adornments,
setting the standard for later kings,
unifying the six directions—
what degradation is there in the *hé pǔ* and *zhāngfú*?

The principles of transformation and nurture adapt to circumstances, teaching as the moment demands.
The Dao leads to goodness, guiding toward the right path."*

The lowly scholar, though most foolish,
may still speak of the Dao.

If it does not invite laughter,
it is not worthy to be called the Dao.
**Annotation:** If it is not laughed at by the lowly scholar,
it is not worthy to be the profound and mysterious Dao.

**Commentary:** The profound Dao is deep and unknowable,
bright yet like darkness, its logic contrary to common sense—
thus it provokes laughter.

If it is not laughed at by the lowly scholar,
it has not yet reached the subtle essence—
merely a shallow, vulgar method,
unworthy to be called the Dao.
The Dao is not a law for the ages,
so it is scorned by the common and foolish.

Thus it is the true wondrous Dao.

**Meaning:** The Dao is hidden and returns,
silent and serene, its mystery profound.
It does not bind people with rigid judgment,
nor does it display itself in brilliant form.
Those who embody the Dao walk likewise—
within, they align with emptiness,
without, they blend with dust and filth.
Thus, though supremely bright, they appear as darkness,
unseen by the masses.
Is it not that they also follow the customs,
guard humility, and dwell below,
so the lowly scorn and laugh at them?
Yet even the Sage, in concealing his person and refining his Dao,
is not free from the lowly’s laughter,
for he has not yet fully attained the Great Dao.

**Meaning:** To govern the realm and transform customs,
one must also be clear and unassuming,
allowing things to unfold naturally,
with kindness and gentleness subtly spread,
and benevolence flowing without trace.
Thus its people rise with the sun and rest at dusk,
dull and silent, unaware of the Emperor’s power,
unaware that there is a ruler above them.
Though the common folk know not the Emperor’s might,
the Sage’s virtue extends far,
and the mysterious winds pervade all—
this is the ultimate transformation.

**Establishing this teaching:** **Annotation:** *Jiàn* means "to establish."
Before setting forth this teaching,
it clarifies the three types of scholars’ differing relations to the Dao.

**Commentary:** *Jiàn* means "to establish."
Before establishing this teaching,
it explains the diligent practice of the superior scholar,
the fluctuating grasp of the middle scholar,
and the cause of the lowly’s laughter.

**Meaning:** The Sage of the Highest Order
establishes this teaching to reveal the Dao,
and to explain why the three types of scholars differ—
thus this passage.

**Brightness like darkness:**
**Commentary:** *Míng* means "illuminated."
*Mèi* means "dim."
The virtuous practitioner
nourishes brightness through darkness,
discards form and abandons wisdom,
yet remains truly illuminated.
Thus it says "brightness like darkness."

The superior scholar practices diligently,
yet outwardly appears as dim—
the lowly do not understand,
so they laugh.
The middle scholar, upon first hearing of the bright Dao,
appears to grasp it—
later, as he fails to comprehend,
it seems as if he has lost it.
**Meaning:** The Sage who rules by the Great Dao
embodies the Dao and remains,
his spirit merging with transformation,
dwelling in the natural.
All things follow their true nature,
with no perception or awareness.
His essence aligns with the Dao’s mystery,
his life attuned to the subtle One.
His actions accord with the Great Harmony,
his taking and discarding with Heaven’s principle.
Without thought or deliberation,
he is silent and vast as the Original Chaos.
Equal to the sun and moon in their radiance,
yet the people do not recognize it as brightness.
Balanced in the rain and dew’s favor,
yet the people do not see it as grace.
Though supremely bright,
he appears as darkness and silence.

The superior scholar refines the Dao,
conceals wisdom and dims his splendor,
contains perception and hides knowledge,
turning his gaze inward while outwardly appearing as a helpless infant.
This is beyond the middle scholar’s grasp,
and the lowly deride it with laughter.
As for the fluctuating grasp of existence and loss,
it is also a form of dimness.

Again, it speaks of Heaven’s virtue—
though resplendent above,
it is ever as darkness and dimness.

**Advancing in the Dao like retreat:**
**Commentary:** Those who advance in the Dao
do not stir within,
forget all external affairs,
daily diminish their worldly concerns,
yet achieve greatness as if lacking.
The lowly observe them and think them in retreat.

**Meaning:** The Sage who upholds the Great Dao
lets the world be as the Original Chaos,
unifies the four seas into one,
pursues only what diminishes,
never adding to his own affairs.
He acts little, guards few things,
yet his people are loyal and sincere,
the world harmonious and simple.
The ruler is like heaven and earth,
the people like grass and trees.
He does not prize the myriad chariots as honor,
nor the ninefold palaces as joy.
Humble and weak, he appears to retreat,
tranquil and yielding, without desire—
yet his Dao spreads widely,
his virtue vast and boundless—
this is the Dao of retreat.

The superior scholar applies this principle to himself,
and though his hidden virtue is subtly manifest,
he does not boast or display it.
His deeds are unseen, his merit unrecognized,
yet he yields goodness to others,
retreats from his own name,
and though his alchemical talismans are not proclaimed,
his refined essence ascends in fame.

Li Yiqi begged for food among the world,
Yin Changsheng endured humiliation in the marketplace,
Hou Huanyu dwelled in obscurity as a servant,
Huangfu Shitai feigned illness in the hills—
Shengzi accompanied the mad,
Fu Gong concealed his brilliance.
All humbled themselves and diminished their pride,
yet these were the very means by which they cultivated their true nature.

Again, it speaks of Earth’s virtue—
though it steams below,
it is ever humble and retreating.

**The Dao’s simplicity like its flaws:**
**Annotation:** The superior scholar’s diligent practice
makes him appear as if advancing like retreat,
and as if his simplicity has defects.

Thus the middle scholar doubts,
and the lowly laugh.

**Commentary:** *Yí* means "level."
*Zhǎn* refers to uneven threads in silk.
The mind is clear and pure,
with no attachment to dust or desire,
truly level and easy,
boundless with all things—
yet outwardly, it seems as silk with uneven threads.

**Meaning:** Silk without flaws
is used by people.
Fine as *Zhēn* and *Liàn*,
delicate as *Wùgǔ* and *Yúnluó*—
all enter the realm of transformation,
forgetting their original nature,
until they fade and dissolve,
no longer silk at all.

People who abandon the Dao
are driven by the vulgar world,
each competing for wealth and rank,
indulging in sounds and colors,
wandering in evil paths,
losing their true nature,
until they sink and perish,
no longer preserving their lives.

The enlightened scholar, in refining himself,
is inwardly level and easy,
yet outwardly blends with the dust,
endures suffering while meeting joy,
adapts to the times and follows their traces—
like silk with its flaws.

Zhongni, the Sage of great virtue,
yet felled trees and marked his passage,
traveled to visit the states of the world;
Xuan Yuan, the Sage of supreme honor,
yet knelt at the pillar and hid his writings,
refined his Dao in distant lands.
Though inwardly they harbored the ultimate Dao,
outwardly they appeared as silk with flaws.

Again, it speaks of the ruler’s virtue—
though he follows Earth’s pattern and Heaven’s law,
he does not dare to stand out,
always appearing as if he had flaws.

The highest virtue is like a valley.
*[Annotation: Empty yet receptive, containing all things.]*
*[Commentary: The diligent practitioner of the Dao is called one of highest virtue—his virtue is fully manifest, yet contains all without distinction, hence "like a valley."]*
*[Meaning: The sagely ruler rests in boundless mystery, veiling his form in profound obscurity, embodying the Dao and containing virtue without limit. The vastness of myriad states is held within his breast, yet he does not rely on his own possession; all things transform spontaneously within his domain, yet he does not boast of its greatness. How could one liken this to a valley?*
*[Also: The ruler bears defilement as a valley receives filth.]*

The superior man embodies virtue and the Dao without omission—thus it is so.

Great purity is like shame.
*[Annotation: Pure yet bearing defilement.]*
*[Commentary: "White" means pure; "shame" means dust and filth. Those who attain pure Dao blend with the common, hence "like shame," yet remain truly pure and complete.]*
*[Meaning: The virtue of Yao and Tang was supremely bright, yet they endured calamities like Shixiang’s floods and the melting of stones—times when the people faced no hunger or famine. Even the purest white bears dust. The practitioner of the Dao, outwardly stained like a man of lowly station or a beggar, conceals his sharp teeth and sword-like demeanor, sinking his traces like a submerged spring, while inwardly perfecting his Dao, blending with the muddy world—this too is its meaning.]*

Broad virtue is like insufficiency.
*[Annotation: Great achievement yet practicing humility.]*
*[Commentary: The sage’s virtue extends without limit, yet he guards softness and practices humility, ever appearing insufficient.]*
*The* Records of the Grand Historian *says: "A skilled merchant hides his wealth as if empty; the man of great virtue appears foolish in bearing."*
*[Meaning: The ruler of highest virtue transforms the Nine Regions without relying on his own virtue—they transform of themselves. Unaware of his deeds, he seems ever insufficient. The practitioner of the Dao accomplishes both hidden and manifest deeds, his virtue extending to all creatures; ceaseless in his labors, tireless in his virtue, yet ever appearing insufficient.]*
*The* Records of the Grand Historian *also recounts: When Confucius and Nanrong Jingzhu visited Zhou, they asked about rites from Laozi.
