**beacons and alarms are not lit**,
**drums and gongs are not sounded**—
within the **four seas**, all dwell in **tranquility**.

This is **stillness overcoming**—**victory**.

When **transformation reaches its peak**,
then **singing and dancing flourish**,
**respect and yielding arise**,
**nine clans are harmonious**,
**four gates are orderly**,
**rites and music are established**,
**virtuous and capable ones are employed**—
**carriages and boats** come in **expectation of welcome**,
**writings and laws** follow **proper order** in **receiving transformation**,
**eight regions gather**,
**all directions rush forward**,
**Heaven and Earth respond in harmony**,
**humanity and spirits communicate freely**—
**joyous and radiant**, all **transform within the Dao**,
**cutting off the evil of peering and scheming**,
**no neighbor lurks for advantage**—
they **sing and recite**, **dance and tread**.

This is the **result of stillness and effortless principle**.

**If the ruler acts with excessive motion**,
**ministers resort to deceit and flattery**,
**agitating arms and displaying force**,
**a million-strong army ascends** to the **Single Sovereign’s platform**,
**banners and flags stretch a thousand *li***,
**crossing vast and distant shores**—
**the aged and weak are burdened with labor**,
**women and children aid in transport**,
**the four seas boil in unrest**,
**the six directions are disturbed**.

When **people’s exhaustion reaches its limit**,
**families are depleted**,
**lives are lost**,
**wilds are abandoned**, no **human trace remains**,
**daytime echoes with ghostly lamentations**.

This is the **fate of excessive motion overcoming**.

**Before, with stillness and effortless principle**,
**warmth and harmony** prevailed among people.
**Now, with excessive motion and force**,
**silence and coldness** follow—
**can one not be warned?**

**Serene stillness is the rectification for the world**.
*Annotation*: When **excessive motion overcomes**, it leads to **coldness**—
coldness, **thinness**.
When **stillness overcomes**, it leads to **heat**—
heat, **harmony**.
Thus **the bent is the greatest straightness**,
**the pure and empty is the true rectification**.

*Commentary*: This **concludes the previous meaning**.

The **Sage** observes the **advance and retreat of the Yang qi**,
knowing that **excessive motion** is the **root of premature death**,
and **stillness** is the **foundation of vitality**.

In governing **human affairs** and **nurturing all living beings**,
**holding to the root** to **unify the branches**,
and **pursuing the Dao of serene stillness**,
then one may **rectify the world** indeed.

**The Meaning states**:
The **Sage** knows that **the unrestrained course** (冲缺)
can **preserve fullness**,
and **the method of serene stillness** (澄静)
can **restrain movement**.

When **movement is perfected**, **serene stillness** naturally **manifests**;
when **excessive motion is suppressed**, **gentle harmony** naturally **shines forth**—
thus one may **lead the world to non-action** (無為),
and **return all directions to rectitude** (貞正),
following the **cyclical interplay of Yin and Yang, cold and heat**,
and **discerning the sources of life and death, gain and loss**—
this is now **clearly illuminated**.

**The *Daode Jing* – *Guangsheng Yi* (廣聖義) Scroll Thirty-Four** concludes.

#1 *兼受选士*: According to *Han Records* (漢志), **"受"** should be read as **"爱"**.
#2 *生於陂*: According to the following text and *Zhuangzi* (莊子), it should be read as **"生於陵陂"**.

**The *Daode Jing* – *Guangsheng Yi* Scroll Thirty-Five**
Attributed to **Master Guangcheng of Tang** (唐廣成先生),
Narrated by **Du Guangting** (杜光庭).

**The *Daode Jing* – *Guangsheng Yi* Scroll Thirty-Six**
Attributed to **Master Guangcheng of Tang** (唐廣成先生),
Narrated by **Du Guangting** (杜光庭).

**Chapter on the Dao of the World** (天下有道) **Forty-Sixth**
*Explanation*: The previous chapter elucidates the operation of the **Five Great Elements** (五大), opening the path to broad cultivation. This chapter reveals the **Three Great Faults** (三大之愆), to expose the harms of what is sought after.

First, it marks the **losses and gains** (损益) of **having the Dao** (有道) and **lacking the Dao** (無道); next, it clarifies the **origins of crime and blame** (为罪为咎); finally, it concludes with **knowing contentment as virtue** (知足之为德), warning against **greed as calamity** (贪求之为患).

**Meaning**:
The world (天) is the **domain of the Sage** (圣人之御宇).
With **axe and banner** (斧扆) held before him, he faces south,
**diviners and seers** (巫史) at his fore and rear,
**soothsayers and musicians** (卜筮瞽侑) arrayed on either side—
**non-action** (無為) while **upholding absolute rectitude** (守至正).

The **Three Ministers** (三公) preside in court,
the **Three Elders** (三老) instruct in learning,
the **hundred officials** (百辟) fulfill their duties,
**cultivating virtue and culture** (修文德) to **win over the distant** (怀远),
**propagating the Dao’s transformation** (敷道化) to **nurture the people** (育人).
Thus, customs become **smooth and harmonious** (洽和平),
families flourish with **ritual and yielding** (礼让),
**tribute and offerings** (琛赆) come from the **four barriers** (四塞),
**military expeditions cease** (息征戌) at the **three borders** (三边),
**weapons are inverted** (倒载干戈),
**oxen rest and horses return** (休牛归马),
and then the people **take joy in tilling and hoeing** (乐耕耨),
**manuring the fields** (粪田畴),
**plentiful crops rise like clouds** (多稼如云),
with **surplus grain stored in granaries** (余粮栖亩).

If any **deviate from this**, then **grievances and foes multiply** (怨敌交侵),
**warhorses gallop ceaselessly** (戎马载驰),
**armor and arms are used again** (甲兵复用).
Why does this happen?
Because the **rulers above harbor the vice of covetous desires** (上有贪得可欲之非),
indulging in **unrestrained expansion of lands** (恣拓土无厌之祸).
**Exhausting armies and waging wars** (穷兵演武) will **inevitably lead to self-destruction** (必致自焚).
**Laozi warns through the text of knowing contentment** (老君戒以知足之文),
to **settle them in their proper measure** (欲使安其分).
Once **measure is always content** (分既常足),
then **one may speak of the Dao and its principles** (可以言於理道).

When the world **has the Dao** (天下有道),
**warhorses are turned away to manure fields** (却走马以粪).
*Annotation*: The ruler of a world **with the Dao** (天下有道之主)
**allows the Dao’s transformation to flourish** (無為化行),
**not coveting**, thus **no wars occur** (固无交战),
**repelling the use of warhorses** (屏却走马之事).
People **gain from manure to clear their fields** (人得粪除田园).
*Explanation*: **Repel** (却) means **to block and repel** (屏却).
**Manure** (粪) refers to **cultivating the fields** (理田).
The world **with the Dao** (天下有道) means
**governing by the Dao** (以道为理),
**allowing the transformation of non-action to prevail** (無為化行),
**keeping the borders at peace** (守在四夷),
with **no military conflicts** (疆场无事),
**not seizing more lands to burden the people** (不得多贪土地以困黎元),
thus **blocking the use of war chariots and warhorses** (所以屏却兵车走马之事).
People **begin to till the southern fields** (得俶载南亩),
**manuring and clearing their gardens** (以粪理田园).

**Meaning**:
The ancients said:
*The ruler is like a boat (舟), the people like water (水).*
People **cannot be governed without a ruler** (非君不理),
a boat **cannot move without water** (非水不行).
Boat and water **depend on each other** (相须),
**never to be momentarily parted** (不可暂失).
Thus, the **foundation of governing the realm** (理国之本)
is **to nourish the people** (养人为先).
The **ruler with the Dao** (有道之君)
**maintains peace at the borders** (守在四夷),
**no external wars or raids** (外无兵寇),
**no weapons are employed** (戈楯不用),
**no blades are sharpened** (锋镝不施),
**armor and horses are repelled** (却甲马於三边),
**fields are plowed in the four wilds** (辟田畴於四野).
**Deep plowing and sparse sowing** (深耕浅种),
**abundance for families and prosperity for the state** (家给国肥),
**food as the shared duty of heaven and earth** (食为人天),
**the greatest concern of the realm** (邦之大务).

The phrase **"begin to till the southern fields"** (俶载南亩)
comes from the **Book of Songs** (《诗□小雅□甫田篇》).
**Begin** (俶) means **commence** (始),
**till** (载) means **undertake** (事).
When **spring planting is already begun** (春作既兴),
they **commence tilling the southern fields** (始事南亩).
The **southern fields** (南亩) are the name of a field.
The **Book of Songs** says: *"plow to the east of the field"* (南东其亩).
A **field** (亩) is **one hundred paces** (百步).
Wide **six feet**, long **six hundred feet** (广六尺, 长六百尺),
**able to sustain life** (可以母养於物),
thus it is called a **field** (亩).

**Cultivators of the Dao** (修道之士),
**take intention as their horse** (以意为马),
**take emotion as their field** (以情为田).
If they **repel the galloping of the horse of intention** (却意马之奔驰),
**the spirit will become tranquil** (神将静矣);
If they **allow the field of emotion to rest** (使情田之逸暇),
**the mind will become at ease** (心将泰矣).
Then **the Dao may be cultivated** (而后道可修).

The **Book of Rites** says:
*The human is the **virtue of heaven and earth** (天地之德),
the **interplay of Yin and Yang** (阴阳之交),
the **convergence of spirits and gods** (鬼神之会),
the **refinement of the Five Phases** (五行之秀).*
Thus, when the **Sage sets the standard** (圣人作则),
he **must take heaven and earth as the foundation** (以天地为本),
**Yin and Yang as the pivot** (阴阳为端),
**the four seasons as the handle** (四时为柄),
**the sun and stars as the markers** (日星为纪),
**spirits and gods as his attendants** (鬼神以为徒),
**the Five Phases as his substance** (五行以为质),
**ritual and righteousness as his vessels** (礼义以为器),
**human emotions as his field** (人情以为田),
**the four spiritual creatures as his livestock** (四灵以为畜).

Thus, **human emotions are the field of the Sage King** (圣王之田).
The **field of emotion, left to non-action** (情田无为),
**nears the Dao** (几於道矣).
The **world** (天下) is the **collective term for governing the realm** (统言理国).

When the world **lacks the Dao** (天下无道),
**warhorses breed in the suburbs** (戎马生於郊).
*Annotation*: The ruler of a world **lacking the Dao** (天下无道之君)
**indulges in desires and conquests** (纵欲攻取),
thus **soldiers and warhorses thrive at the borders** (兵士戎马寄生於郊境).
*Explanation*: **Suburbs** (郊) mean **borderlands** (交),
the **crossroads where two states meet** (二国郊境之际),
the **places of defense** (拒守之地).
The ruler of a world **lacking the Dao** (天下无道之君)
**leaves wastelands ungoverned** (荒塞有不宾之虏).
Thus, **soldiers and warhorses breed in the borderlands** (兵戎军马生育於郊境),
**remaining there for long** (谓久而不还).

**Meaning**:
If one **governs the realm without the Dao** (理国不以道),
then **borderlands are expanded** (开拓边土),
**raids are launched against the barbarians** (侵伐戎夷),
**territories are not at peace** (封域不宁),
**military campaigns never cease** (征役无已).
Some **covet fine foods and provoke the wars of Fan-Yu** (贪蒟酱起番禺之役),
others **love fine horses and raise the army of Da-Yuan** (好名马起大宛之师),
**bones are abandoned in desolate wastes** (骨委穷荒),
**blood stains the wild grasses** (血涂草莽),
**soldiers’ spirits wander in foreign lands** (营魄流飘於异域),
**war chariots stagnate in distant suburbs** (戎车沦滞於远郊),
**years stretch endlessly with prolonged campaigns** (绵岁月以长征),
**until harvest time comes and they do not return** (及瓜时而不返),
**supply lines never rest** (转输莫息),
**the looms and spinning wheels stand idle** (杼轴其空),
**the people grieve and the state collapses** (人怨国亡).
This calamity is **not decreed by heaven** (非天与),
**worthy of deep reflection** (所宜深戒).

How much better it is
when **the world is undisturbed** (宇内不扰),
**all feudal lords come as guests** (诸侯咸宾),
**ruler and people live in harmony** (君民协和),
**superior and inferior mutually protect** (上下相保).
Thus, **valiant warriors have no place to expend their strength** (壮士无所施其力),
**eloquent scholars have no chance to display their words** (辩士无所衒其词),
**martial men have no need to sharpen their blades** (武士无所锐其锋),
**wise strategists have no opportunity to implement their plans** (智士无所申其策).
**Molds and spears are cast into plows and hoes** (铸剑戟以为犁锄),
**treasures and jade knives are exchanged for oxen and calves** (货佩刀而市耕犊).
**Non-action and no labor** (无为无役),
**to preserve the enduring vision** (以全永图).

**No greater crime exists than covetous desire** (罪莫大於可欲).
*Annotation*: **Desire** (可欲) is a **great crime** (罪大).
*Explanation*: **Crime** (罪) means **transgressing laws** (犯法),
**covetous desire** (贪求) means **lust** (欲).
The **crime of warhorses breeding in the suburbs** (戎马生郊之罪)
**arises from the ruler’s noble pursuit of lands** (由人君贵求土地),
**seeing lands as desirable** (见土地可欲),
**desire stirring and noble pursuit about to begin** (欲心兴动将起贵求).
Thus, **no greater crime exists than covetous desire** (罪莫大於可欲).

**Meaning**:
**Law** (法) is what **restrains the people and suppresses chaos** (所以禁民戢乱),
**punishes evil and binds transgressors** (惩恶绳违).
If one **boldly violates it** (干而犯之),
then it is **crime** (罪).
The character **罪** (crime) has **罔** (net) beneath **非** (wrong),
indicating **nets to ensnare the unlawful** (网罗以制其非法).
The **greatest crime** (罪之大者)
is **no greater desire than that which arises from the heart and leads to greed** (欲莫大乎因心起贪),
which is called **lust** (谓之欲).

The **arising of covetous desire in those of noble rank**
leads to **carved walls and towering halls**,
**squandering wealth and boasting of arms**.
The **excess of external allure and internal lust** plunges one into **madness from which there is no return**;
**campaigns to the Yanshan and Longdu passes** exhaust the people **without respite**.
Until **the realm’s hearts turn asunder**,
**ships become enemy strongholds**,
then **ruin follows**.
What greater delusion is there?

The **arising of covetous desire within oneself**
drives one to **pursue profit and chase renown**,
**indulge in sounds and linger over colors**,
**delight in embroidered finery and ornate splendor**,
**blinding the eyes so they cannot turn away**;
**to yield to the pleasures of light fare, music, and wine**,
**until death without awakening**.
Until **the sinews and bones grow weary and wasted**,
**ears grow deaf and eyes blind**,
then **the self is lost**.
How great is this folly?

Thus, in the **Spring and Autumn Annals, Duke Li of the 20th year**,
when **Song Xiang Gong sought to unite the feudal lords**,
**Zang Wen Zhong, a minister of Lu, said**:
*"If one follows others’ desires, it may succeed,
but if one makes others follow one’s own desires, few will be saved."*
This means **bending one’s own desires to align with the virtues of many**.
The following year, **Song Gong formed the Alliance of Lu Mountain**.
**Song Gong’s son, Mu Yi, remarked**:
*"Small states vie for alliances—
fortune may bring ruin."*
That autumn, **the Chu army captured Song Gong and ravaged Song**.
This illustrates **how following desire defies the Dao**.

**Laozi’s teachings and admonitions** reveal the **root of this crime**,
urging the **excision of covetous desire**—
**only then may one enjoy boundless blessings**,
**govern the realm as the Sage-King**,
**and cultivate the self toward immortality**.
**Diligently practicing the Dao’s essence is the key**.

**No greater calamity exists than insatiability**.
*(Note: Unceasing pursuit brings great ruin.)*
*(Commentary: Calamity is harm; the divine does not aid it.)*
**How does great ruin arise?**
From **greed for land**, **pursuit without satisfaction**,
**ignoring the limit of sufficiency**,
**invoking divine wrath and inviting disaster**.
Human errors are manifold,
but **greed’s ruin is the greatest**.

**Crime and calamity both originate in the self**.
**The self’s generation of evil stems from the mind’s thoughts**.
Thus, **body, speech, and mind are the three actions**.
Within these three actions, **ten evils arise**.
Among these ten evils, **greed’s guilt deepens**.
Thus, **life-and-death strife and contention all stem from greed**.
Greed is **one of the mind’s actions**.
If a ruler is greedy, **externally he ravages the borders**,
**internally he burdens the people**.
If he **unceasingly seeks above**, then **below, supply falters and governance weakens**,
**the people resent and the divine grows angry**—
thus **the state’s ruin begins**.
If one is greedy in **cultivating the self**, then **lusts know no satisfaction**,
**the spirit wanders and the vital essence dissipates**,
**virtue’s blessings withhold aid**, and **life is cut short**.
Yet if one **internally restrains the source of greed**,
**externally halts its pursuit**,
then **no enmity arises**, the **self is secure**, and the **state prospers**—
**this is the ever-sufficient sufficiency**.

**No greater fault exists than desiring what one desires**.
*(Note: The greatest misfortune is demanding that all desires be fulfilled.)*
*(Commentary: Fault is misfortune. The greedy tyrant’s desires grow ever more extravagant;*
**if obtained unjustly, ruin follows swiftly**—
**self-inflicted misfortune is inevitable.)*

**Covetous desire** refers to **desire not yet attained**—
**when greed first stirs, guilt is lighter than calamity**.
But **the insatiable**, once obtained, **invite calamity graver than guilt**—
**none surpass the fault of desiring what is already desired**,
for **when desire is fulfilled yet still unquenched**, then **fault exceeds calamity**.

**To take and still seek more**,
**to pursue without end**—
**the people respond with anger**, and **war and bandits arise**.
**Misfortune and fault become great crimes**,
for **when one violates prohibitions**,
**the first transgression is called guilt**.
As **Laozi’s *Scripture of Regret* states**:
*"The first offense is guilt, also called error."*
**Error means mistake**; **eighteen hundred offenses become calamity**—
**calamity is graver than guilt**.
**Twelve hundred sixty offenses become fault**—
**fault is graver still than calamity**.

**No desire surpasses lust**—
**for love is heavy and desirable**.
**No calamity surpasses wealth**—
**for greed knows no sufficiency**.
**No fault is greater than fame**—
**for it demands the fulfillment of desire**.
Human errors and crimes are countless,
but **wealth, lust, and fame** are the three greatest.
**Ruining households, losing lives, toppling states, and destroying selves**—
all stem from these.
**This is a clear warning**.

**True sufficiency is ever-sufficient**.
*(Note: Material abundance is not sufficiency;*
**sufficiency lies in the heart’s contentment**—
**if the heart knows sufficiency, then sufficiency is eternal.)*
*(Commentary: This concludes the chapter on the virtuous ruler.)*
**The virtuous ruler’s desires are vast yet restrained**,
**not greedy for land**, and thus **within his proper bounds he knows sufficiency**,
**winning the people’s joyful allegiance**,
**securing the self and ordering the state**.
This **sufficiency of sufficiency** extends to **reciprocal yielding and eternal contentment**.
*(Note: Material abundance is not sufficiency;*
**sufficiency is in the heart, not in things**—
**to follow the shore and guard one’s measure**,
**though little, is much**;
**though many desires go unfulfilled, even abundance is insufficient**.)

**Greed and sufficiency both emerge from the heart**—
**if the heart is sufficient, then things are ever abundant**;
**if the heart is greedy, then things are ever lacking**.
The greedy, though **possessing the four seas and ten thousand chariots**, still **seek beyond**;
the sufficient, though **with but a bowl of rice and a single room**, **forget not their joy**.
**Appropriate measure and sufficiency lie in the heart**—
**this is what must be exhorted**.

---
**Chapter 47: The Teaching That Does Not Leave the Door**
*(Commentary: The previous chapter illuminated*
**the Way of the world and eternal sufficiency**;
**this chapter expounds the teaching that requires no exit**,
**demonstrating how the unacted achieves completion**.)*

**If one does not leave, then one may know**—
**if people are harmonious, then Heaven is in accord**—
**the more one exits, the greater the loss**—
**thus, through non-action, transformation is complete.**

「○ This is the principle: The Sage’s perception is boundless,
yet he does not step beyond his door or courtyard;
the superior scholar stills his heart,
**harmonizing in secret with Heaven and Earth**—
**harmonizing in secret, he perceives no distance unobserved**,
**his gaze fixed, yet the farther he sees, the clearer it becomes**,
**he acts not yet knows**—
this is what is meant.

**Not leaving the door, yet knowing all under Heaven.**
*(Commentary: The Sage-King with the Dao,*
**who governs through non-action**,
**does not issue decrees beyond his door**—
**pure virtue spreads naturally across the world**—
this is truly knowing the Way to govern all under Heaven.)

Another interpretation says:
If the ruler teaches well,
then all under Heaven responds with goodness,
and he need not trouble himself to leave his door to know them.
Thus, the *Yijing* says:
*"The gentleman speaks his words,
and if they are good, they resonate even beyond a thousand li;
how much more so for those nearby?"*
This is what is meant.

This principle says:
The Sage’s governance
**is to observe himself by himself**—
**if his own body is upright, then all under Heaven is upright**,
**if his own governance is correct, then all under Heaven is governed correctly**.
Thus it is said:
*"To be reverent within oneself and face south is all that is required."*

What need is there for further action?
Since he has already **cleared the chaos of the Supreme Origin**,
**giving birth to all things**,
**each kind finds its proper place**—
**fish sink, birds soar, distinctions of high and low are fixed,
Heaven and Earth are set in their courses**.
Though the **six directions** are vast,
and the **nine regions** are broad,
they are but like the four limbs and hundred bodies.
**One can discern them by the heart alone**—
why must he move his feet to know them?
**To know without leaving the door is indeed true.**

The gentleman’s words, if good,
**are the words of the *Yijing*’s "Upper System" (上系).**
It is said:
**His words and deeds issue from himself and benefit the people**—
**actions begin nearby yet are seen afar**,
**words and deeds are the pivot and mechanism of the gentleman**.
When the pivot and mechanism are set in motion,
**they determine honor and disgrace**.
If even the distant respond thus,
how much more so the near?
**Without peering through the window, one sees the Dao of Heaven.**

*(Annotation: **Through reverent stillness and non-action**,
he does not issue decrees beyond his door—
this is truly knowing the Way to govern all under Heaven.
When human affairs are harmonious,
then the patterns of Heaven align accordingly,
so he need not strain to peer through the window
to perceive the Dao of Heaven.)*

*(Commentary: The correspondence between humanity and Heaven,
**the interflow of refined essence and vital qi**—
if the ruler governs with **virtue/power (德)**,
then the **symbols and patterns (象纬)** follow without confusion;
**if he dishonors the Five Phases (五行)**,
then **yīn and yáng** will err accordingly.
Thus the *Shūjīng* says:
*"When auspicious omens appear, the timely rains fall in reverence;
when inauspicious omens appear, the constant winds blow in darkness."*
This means the ruler’s actions—whether reverent or dark—
**already manifest in Heaven’s symbols and patterns**,
**why wait to peer through the window before they can be seen?**

The *Yijing* says:
*"Words and deeds—
this is how the gentleman moves Heaven and Earth."*
This principle says:
The governance of **emperors and kings**
**follows Heaven’s canopy and Earth’s load**—
**they mark the passage of sun and moon**,
**reverently instructing the people in the seasons**,
**using the jade pivot and jade balance**
to align the **seven luminaries (七政)**,
**thus harmonizing with Heaven’s Way**.
Heaven **hangs forth its symbols (垂象)**,
and the Sage **follows them**—
this is how he **models Heaven’s actions**.
Having already **harmonized and followed Heaven’s symbols**,
if he corrects himself and acts accordingly,
then the ruler’s every deed
**will resonate with Heaven’s Dao**—
**auspiciousness and inauspiciousness rest with him alone**,
**order and chaos lie within his heart**.
Why must he **toil ceaselessly (乾乾)**,
**ever vigilant at dusk (夕惕)**?
**Symbols and patterns (象纬)**—
**those that record texts are called symbols (象)**,
**those that divinate and measure are called patterns (纬)**.
**From the Great Insult (大慢法), it is called dishonoring (威侮)**;
**if they shift and disorder, it is called erring (舛侯)**.
This is caused by the ruler’s actions.

*"Rains fall in reverence" and "winds blow in darkness"*
**are found in the *Shāngshū*’s "Transmission of the Hong Fan" (洪范传)**,
which says:
*"When auspicious omens appear, the timely rains fall in reverence."*
**Auspicious (休) means good (善).**
It says that when the ruler acts with reverence,
the timely rains follow in order.
**Reverent (肃) means respectful (敬).**
*"When inauspicious omens appear, the constant winds blow in darkness."*
**Inauspicious (咎) means inauspicious (凶)**,
**darkness (蒙) means obscured (暗)**,
**constant (恒) means enduring (常)**,
**order (若) means follow (顺).**
It says that when the ruler’s actions are dark,
the constant winds follow in darkness.

*"Words and deeds move Heaven and Earth"*
**is found in the *Yijing*’s "Upper System" (上系),**
which says:
*"Words and deeds—
this is how the gentleman moves Heaven and Earth;
can one not be cautious?"*
This means:
**Though the gentleman’s words and deeds appear varied in form**,
**if his Dao is the same, then the response will be the same**.
The farther his words reach,
the less they are truly known.

*(Annotation: If one cannot govern through non-action,
and must instead issue decrees that spread far,
then his understanding of the Way to govern all under Heaven will be all the more limited.)*

*(Commentary: This elucidates the ruler who has lost the Dao.
Unable to still himself in non-action and be reverent within,
he would issue decrees to transform the people—
the farther his decrees spread,
the more he loses the Way of non-action,
and the fewer his methods of governance become.)*

This principle says:
**If his own body is upright, his decrees need not be issued yet they are followed**,
**if his own body is not upright, though he issues decrees, they are not obeyed**.
The ruler cannot **reverently still himself**,
**merge his heart with the Dao**,
**and govern all under Heaven through non-action**—
even if he widely issues threats and commands,
the people will not follow them.
**How much more so if he entrusts worthy ministers without doubt**,
**follows goodness without weariness**,
**is reverent within himself and extends sincerity to the people below**,
**transforming without words, guiding without decrees?**

Thus, the Sage **knows without action**,
*(Annotation: **Not leaving the door**, hence it is said **without action**.)*
**through pure and simple non-action**,
**yet knows the Way of governance**.
*(Commentary: This is the full explanation of **knowing all under Heaven without leaving the door**.)
**When there is no action, no governance is needed**—
why must he issue words and decrees beyond his door
**before calling it knowing?**

This principle says:
The Sage who governs the state
**leads by his own person, following the Dao**—
**the Dao merges with Heaven**,
**he harmonizes in secret with the Supreme Mystery (上玄)**,
**and all directions submit to him**,
**responding like echoes to calls**—
**he need not act or transform before they can be known**.

***"Nearly taking from oneself"***
**is found in the *Yijing*’s "Lower System" (下系),**
which says:
*"In ancient times, when Pòuxī (庖羲) ruled all under Heaven,
he looked upward to observe Heaven’s symbols (观象於天),
and looked downward to observe Earth’s patterns (观法於地).
He observed the markings of birds and beasts,
and the suitability of the land below—
**nearly taking from oneself, distantly taking from things**.
He first made the **Eight Trigrams (八卦)**,
to **communicate the virtue/power (神明之德) of the luminaries**,
and to **categorize the emotions (情) of all things**.
This means his **ears, eyes, nose, and mouth**
**correspond with the Eight Trigrams**—
**his actions, if auspicious, are answered accordingly**,
**if inauspicious, are opposed accordingly**.
**Misfortune and fortune have no fixed gate**—
they are summoned solely by the person.***

«When I take no action yet people transform themselves,
this is the language of the *Fifty-Seventh Chapter* of the *Classic*.

**Not seeing yet naming.***
*Note: He does not peer through windows, hence it is said "not seeing."*
When a person is in harmony with Heaven, he can name its **Great Peace (太平)**.
*Commentary: This explains the phrase "not peering through windows" by revealing the Dao of Heaven.*

When a crane calls, its offspring responds in tune;
when one acts with sincerity, Heaven moves accordingly.
From the small one can discern the great,
by examining oneself one can understand things.

**Fortune and misfortune are summoned by the person**—
then the transformation of **Great Peace** can be achieved and spoken of.
Why must one peer and see before naming it?
Thus it is said: **Not seeing yet naming.**

*The meaning is this:*
The **Dao of Heaven (天道)** is vast and open,
not distant from the self.
Heaven and humanity resonate together,
with no separation between their influences.
**Misfortune and fortune align in accordance**—
this is determined by one’s actions.
If the self is already in order,
then it is naturally fitting.

Heaven responds to human harmony,
**without needing to peer through windows.**
When a crane calls from the secluded dark,
its offspring still harmonizes.
When a person deceives in private,
things will surely know it.

**Worry, regret, and stinginess**
reside in the minutiae,
**determining gain and loss**
lies within the pivotal mechanisms.

The **gentleman contemplates before speaking,
considers before acting**—
this is the principle of **caution in the subtle (慎微之理)**.
Though subtle, it must be answered;
how distant can it be?

**Not seeing yet naming**—
since the **Dao is already mysterious and unified**,
and the heart aligns with the Dao,
all things correspond and resonate accordingly.
Thus, one does not need to see before naming it.

**Achieving without action.**
*Note: He does not speak of governance,
yet the world transforms itself accordingly.*
*Commentary: This summarizes the meaning of "not peering nor acting."*

If the **above (the ruler) has actions to perform**,
the **below (the people) will have grievances**.
Now, the **Sage concentrates his spirit and remains solemn at the throne (凝神端扆)**,
**mysteriously silent in the hall of audience (玄默朝堂)**,
**the ruler takes no action, the people have no burdens**,
and the populace lives in **prosperity and sufficiency (家给)**,
while all transformations occur naturally.

*The meaning is this:*
**Concentration and stillness (凝静)** are **calmness (定)**;
**solemn composure (端庄)** is **austerity (肃)**;
**the throne’s screen (扆龙)** is a **barrier (屏)**;
the **hall of audience (朝堂)** is where governance is heard.

The **Sage governs by non-action (无为致理)**,
transforms people without exertion (无事化人).
**He knows all without leaving his door (不出户而自知)**,
**sees all without peering through windows (不窥牖而自见)**.
**His spirit merges with the Dao (融神观妙)**,
and **creation arises from his person (造化生乎身)**.

With **mere gestures and dignified adornments (垂拱端旒)**,
the **entire cosmos is held in his hands (宇宙在乎手)**.
The people do not know their ruler exists above,
the ruler does not demand anything from the people below.
**Granaries are full, households are content—**
how is this possible?
Because **the ruler takes no action, yet the realm is at ease (国泰)**.»

The **spirit once congealed and still**,
thus **without speech, transformation is complete**.

The **screen (扆)**, is said to be **leaning (倚)**.
Its **form resembles a screen**—by day, it is the **axe-handle pattern (斧文)**,
placed within the **Bright Hall (明堂)**, where the **windows are opened** and set.

In times past, **the Duke of Zhou** assisted **King Cheng** in the **Bright Hall**,
to receive the **feudal lords (诸侯)**.
**He leaned on the axe-handle screen (负斧扆)**, **facing south while standing (南面而立)**,
to **rectify the positions of sovereign and minister (正君臣之位)**.

---
**The *Dao De Jing*’s *Extensive Virtue/Power* Scroll, Volume Thirty-Five** concludes.
**The *Dao De Jing*’s *Extensive Virtue/Power* Scroll, Volume Thirty-Six**—
**Master Tang Guangcheng (唐广成先生)**, **Du Guangting (杜光庭)** expounds,
**Chapter Forty-Eight of *For Learning, Daily Increase***—
**Commentary (疏)**:
The **previous chapter** elucidates **non-exertion in governance (不出不窥)**,
the **Dao of knowing without interference (不以知政理)**.
This **chapter** clarifies that **for learning, daily increase (为学日益)**,
and **for the Dao, daily decrease (为道则至乎无为之事)**.

The **first two sentences** show **the gradual stages of cultivation and dissipation (进修息遣之渐)**,
the **next three** reveal **the advantage of diminishing the self to return to non-being (损有归无之益)**,
and the **last four** conclude its meaning,
**warning that exertion (有事)** is insufficient to **transform the people (化人)**.

---
**The *Commentary* (义曰)** says:
**The teaching of governing the world (理世之教)**,
is **to diligently study and achieve success (以勤学而成功)**.
**The stages of cultivating the self (修身之阶)**,
are **to diminish knowledge and align with the Dao (以损知而契道)**.
**Diligent study brings daily progress (勤学则日益而进业)**,
**aligning with the Dao brings daily decrease to non-action (契道则日损而无为)**.

**Leaning and yielding are inherently distinct (倚伏本殊)**,
yet **words and silence mutually achieve their purpose (语默互致)**—
this **is the lesser excellence of daily increase (此明日益之为劣)**.
**To dwell in the world yet transcend it (局世居常)**,
**daily decrease is the superior approach (日损之为优)**.

**To transcend the mundane and verify the Dao (超凡证道)**,
one must **conform to the profound stillness of non-exertion (符合於不出不窥之冥寂)**.
**Beware the distractions of excessive knowledge (戒弥远弥少之烦劳)**,
**for non-action suffices to grasp the cosmic pattern (示无为可以握图)**—
**exertion cannot govern the realm (有事不足理国)**.
This **is its intent (此其旨也)**.

**For learning, daily increase (为学日益)**;
**for the Dao, daily decrease (为道日损)**.
**Annotation (注)**:
**The seeker of learning daily accumulates knowledge (为学者日益见闻)**,
**the seeker of the Dao daily diminishes deeds (为道者日损功行)**.
**Daily increase in knowledge is the stage of cultivation (益见闻为修学之渐)**,
**daily decrease in deeds is the gateway to enlightenment (损功行为悟道之门)**.
Thus, **one accumulates merit through increase (因益而积功)**,
and **forgets deeds to embody the Dao (忘功而体道)**.

---
**Commentary (疏)**:
**修为 (For),** refers to **cultivation (修为)**;
**忘损 (Decrease),** refers to **forgetting and diminishing (忘损)**.
It says: **The beginner in cultivation first seeks knowledge (初修学者日求闻见以为益)**,
**then, through this knowledge, aligns with the Dao (因益为道)**,
**and finally forgets deeds to diminish (则忘遗功行以为损)**.
Why is this so?
**The seeker of learning (为学者)**,
**all begin with daily study to grasp the Dao (初则日学以知道)**,
**cultivating deeds to rectify faults (修功而补过)**,
**until they enlighten to the principle and forget words (终则悟理而忘言)**,
**dissipate deeds and abandon attachment (遣功而去执)**.
Thus, the **annotation says: daily increase in knowledge is the initial stage of cultivation (益见闻为修学之渐)**,
**and daily decrease in deeds is the final gateway to enlightenment (损功行为悟道之门)**.

---
**The *Commentary* (义曰)** says:
**The person who studies the Dao first establishes deeds (学道之人先立功行)**,
then **forgets them (后忘其心)**,
thus **aligning with the Dao of non-action (所以契无为之道)**.
**The Dao of governing the realm (理国之道)**,
first **broadens virtue and transformation (先弘德化)**,
then **forgets progress (后忘其进)**,
thus **laying the foundation for the Great Peace (所以成太平之基也)**.
This **is also in harmony**.

**The Dao of establishing oneself (立身之道)**,
cannot **be neglected in study (不可不学)**.
*The Spring and Autumn Annals* says:
**The scholar, is one who cultivates (学者，殖也)**.
**Without study, one will decline (不学将落)**.
Thus, **the lowly become even lower, the noble fall (下陵上替)**—
how can **chaos be avoided (能无乱乎)**?
*The White Tiger’s Elegant Discussion* says:
**The scholar, is one who awakens (学者，觉也)**,
**and one who comprehends (悟也)**.
It means **the sage-kings’ Dao illuminates the nature and emotions (以先王之道开道情性)**,
**to awaken and comprehend**.

In **youth, one is confused and unaware (幼则迷昏而不悟)**,
**and cannot yet study (未可以学)**.
In **adulthood, one becomes obstinate and difficult to teach (长则悍格而难入)**,
**and cannot yet be instructed (不可以教)**.
**Study has three stages (学有三时)**.

**First, the stage within a person’s lifespan (就人身中为时者)**:
After **thirteen years of age (十三岁之后)**, one can **practice one’s profession (可以习业也)**.
Thus, *The Records of Learning* says:
**If one is not disciplined after awakening (发然而后禁)**,
then **obstinacy prevails and cannot be overcome (则悍格而不胜)**;
**if one is not aware until time has passed (时过而后觉)**,
then **diligent effort becomes difficult to achieve (则勤苦而难成)**.

**Second, the stages within the year (就年中为时者)**:
*The Inner Canon* says:
**In nurturing a child (人之养子)**,
**at six years, one teaches numeracy (六年教之数)**,
**counting up to ten, then ten to myriad ten-thousands (一至十，十至百千万也)**;
**and names the directions (与方名，东西南北也)**.
**At seven years (七年)**,
**boys and girls do not sit together (男女不同席)**,
**nor share food (不共食)**.
**At eight years (八年)**,
**when entering and exiting doors (出入门户)**,
**and when seated to eat (及即席饮食)**,
one must **follow the elders (必后於长者)**,
**to teach deference (教之让也)**.
**At nine years (九年)**,
**one teaches the days of the month and lunar phases (教之数日朔望)**,
**and the six celestial stems (与甲乙至壬癸六甲也)**.
**At ten years (十年)**,
**one goes forth to external tutors (出就外傅)**,
**lodging outside (居宿於外)**,
**to learn writing and computation (学书计)**.
**At thirteen years (十有三年)**,
**one learns the dance of the *sháo* vessel (学舞勺)**,
**to recite poetry and commit texts to memory (诵诗背文)**,
**and reading is called recitation (而读曰诵也)**.
**At fifteen years (十五年)**,
**one becomes a youth (成童)**,
**and learns the dance of the *xiàng* vessel and archery (舞象学射御)**,
**first the dance of the *yuè* vessel (先舞钥)**—
**the *yuè* resembles a flute (钥似笛)**—
**holding it to perform graceful movements (执而文舞也)**—
**then the dance of the *xiàng* vessel (后舞象)**,
**a martial dance (武舞也)**.
**At twenty, one is capped (二十而冠)**,
**and begins to learn ritual (始学礼)**.
**At thirty, one has a household (三十有室)**,
**and attends to male affairs (理男事)**,
**studying without limit (学无方)**.
**At forty, one enters officialdom (四十而仕)**,
**offering counsel and deliberation (出谋发虑)**.
**At fifty, one serves in governance (五十，服官政是也)**.

**Third, the stages within the day (就日中为时者)**:
It says **one should study according to the seasons and *qi* (随时节气受业易入)**.
*The Royal Institutions* says:
**In spring and summer, one studies poetry and music (春夏习诗乐)**.
It means **spring and summer are yang (阳)**,
**and yang embodies clarity (阳体清)**—
**poetry and music are sounds (诗乐是声)**,
**and sounds are light and clear (声以轻清故也)**.
**In autumn and winter, one studies writing and ritual (秋冬习书礼)**.
**Autumn and winter are yin (阴)**,
**and yin embodies heaviness (阴体重)**—
**writing and ritual are matters (书礼是事)**,
**and matters are weighty and turbid (事以重浊故也)**.
**To study light and clear matters in light and clear seasons (以轻清之时习轻清之业)**,
**and to study weighty and turbid matters in weighty and turbid seasons (以重浊之时习重浊之事)**,
thus **their *qi* resonates and all is easily absorbed (故其气相感，皆易入也)**.
Yet **though the three stages of study have fixed rules (然三时之学虽有定规)**,
**if one studies the good Dao (所习善道)**,
**one must never neglect it daily (日不可废)**—
how can one **be confined to these three stages (岂可拘於三时哉)**?
Thus, *The Records of Learning* says:
**Cultivate, then rest; rest, then play (斯焉修焉、息焉游焉是也)**.

**If the cultivator of the Dao (若修道之士)**,
first **pursues extensive knowledge (先务博闻)**,
then **diminishes it daily (后乃日损)**,
**returning to profound stillness (反乎冥寂)**,
**to attain cosmic penetration (以期通玄矣)**.
**Hiding is also to possess and then return to non-being (藏亦自有而归於无也)**.
**Decrease, then decrease again (损之又损之)**,
**until one reaches non-action (以至於无为)**.

---
**Commentary (疏)**:
**Decrease (损之者)**, refers to **diminishing the deeds of the Dao-seeker (损为道者之功行也)**.
**Decrease again (又损之者)**, refers to **eliminating the heart of forgetting deeds (除忘功行之心也)**.
This **is first to diminish traces (前损忘迹)**,
then **to forget the heart (后损忘心)**.
**When both heart and traces are forgotten (心迹俱忘)**,
**one has reached the ultimate (可谓造极)**,
**and thus attained non-action (则以至於无为矣)**.

---
**The *Commentary* (义曰)** says:
**The stages of cultivating the Dao (修道之阶)**,
gradually **approach its subtlety (渐臻其妙)**.
Initially, **one awakens through study (则由学而开悟)**,
**then follows cultivation through comprehension (因悟而遵修)**,
**and cultivates by establishing deeds to rectify faults (修则以立功补过)**,
**accumulating the minute to form the profound (积微成着)**.

功不在大，遇物斯拯；
过不在小，知非则恢。
过在改而不复，
为功在立而不倦。

*The Dunxuan Scripture* (《洞玄经》) says:
功满三千，白日升天；
修善有余，坐降云车。
These are all exhortations to those of common origin who aspire to the Dao,
to encourage them in establishing deeds.

The meaning of establishing deeds is manifold:
some rescue the drowning and support the perilous,
save lives and guide the dying—
if it benefits beings, one should diligently practice it.
Others cultivate inwardly by nurturing the spirit,
practicing exhalation and inhalation, refining and storing [qi],
taking elixirs and guiding movements—
monkey-like flexibility, bird-like extension—
abandoning gain and forgetting fame,
retiring the self and yielding to others—
all these are the initial gates of Daoist cultivation.

Once one has entered these gates,
the key lies in perseverance and endurance.
With perseverance and endurance,
one can accumulate virtuous deeds.

When virtuous deeds are accumulated,
one must not arrogantly rely on them,
boast before others, or claim them as one’s own.
Establish them, then forget them immediately—
when deeds are forgotten as soon as they are established,
the heart remains unobstructed.
This is called the ultimate of *double abandonment and simultaneous forgetting*.

The *Classic* says:
上德不德，是以有德；
Forgetting virtue does not mean lacking virtue—thus virtue is all the more manifest;
忘功不居，其功益广。
Forgetting deeds does not diminish them—thus deeds are all the more expansive.
This aligns with the principle of *non-action*,
establishing the foundation for immortality in one’s person.

Non-action yet nothing remains undone.

**Annotation:**
For the practitioner, deeds are accumulated;
for the Dao-seeker, deeds are diminished and forgotten.
Though one diminishes deeds, there remains the desire to diminish them.
When even this desire is forgotten,
one attains the tranquil state of non-action.

Like a mirror reflecting all forms without obstruction,
it responds to all things—
thus, nothing remains undone.

**Commentary:**
Action brings obstruction;
obstruction means there are things one cannot do.
Now, since there is non-action,
non-action means no obstruction—
thus, one can do all things.
This is called aligning with the Dao,
responding universally and comprehensively.
Hence, the upper scroll states:
*The Dao is ever non-action yet nothing remains undone.*

**Meaning:**
When deeds and the heart of forgetting are both abandoned,
the wisdom of non-action becomes self-evident.
Having attained *double abandonment*,
one merges with the Dao.
In harmony with the Dao,
one understands all things,
knows all things,
can do all things—
from the minutest grain of millet to the grandest harmony of yin, yang, and the cosmos.
Neither non-being nor being,
neither being nor non-being—
unconstrained and unrestricted,
one may then speak of the Dao.

*The Dao is ever non-action yet nothing remains undone*—
these are the words of the *Upper Scripture*, Chapter Thirty-Seven.

Take the world with *non-action*.
**Annotation:**
Non-action and non-affairs—
the world returns to harmony,
thus one can take the world.

**Commentary:**
This exhorts the sovereign to practice non-action.
"Take" means to govern by transformation.
To govern the world,
one must practice non-action,
do nothing yet govern—
when there are no affairs, the people are undisturbed;
when there is non-action, the people are naturally at ease.
With this approach,
what cannot be achieved?

"Constant" means
governing with non-affairs must never be abandoned for an instant.

**Meaning:**
"Take" means to gather.
When a state loses the Dao,
the people rebel and depart.
When a state governs by the Dao,
the people willingly submit.
Departure leads to dispersion;
submission leads to gathering.
Gathering brings prosperity and flourishing;
dispersion brings emptiness and ruin.

The method to gather the people
is always to prioritize non-affairs.

"莅" (Lì) means to govern;
"御" means to regulate;
"摄" means to attract.

As the *Commentary on the Yi Jing’s* (《易》) *Cui Hexagram* states:
萃 (Cùi), to gather.
Emotions align, then gathering occurs;
qi harmonizes, then groups form.
Thus, things of the same kind gather,
and beings form groups.
Without a leader, gathering leads to chaos—
only those with great virtue
can uphold the correct path,
achieve constant harmony,
and benefit the proper order.

The sage as leader,
the Dao fully gathered—
this is how the sage governs the state with virtue and morality,
bringing peace to the world—
thus it is called "take."

If one speaks of taking the world,
is it not beyond human strength?
Yet when affairs arise,
it is insufficient to take the world.

**Annotation:**
Affairs bring labor and turmoil;
labor and turmoil lead to exhaustion—
thus, it is insufficient to take the world.

**Commentary:**
"Affairs" refers to harsh decrees and dense prohibitions.
Harsh decrees disturb the people;
dense prohibitions multiply punishments—
the people are restless,
the four quarters disperse—
how can one then hope to govern by transformation?
Thus, when affairs arise,
it is insufficient to take the world.

**Meaning:**
The Dao and virtue form the foundation of a state.
Non-action and non-affairs are the root of gathering the people.
When affairs arise,
the people are not pacified—
only rebellion and departure follow—
thus, it is difficult to win their loyalty.

The Qin Emperor’s laws were severe, yet the people rebelled,
unifying the realm only to bring about its downfall;
The Han Emperor’s decrees were rigid, punishments frequent—
thus, the frontier regions rose in resentment.
Hence, in Qin’s later years,
laws were as strict as autumn’s scrutiny,
prohibitions as dense as congealed fat—
the wretched people had no place to rest their hands and feet.
Thus, the land collapsed like crumbling earth,
and the empire fell in a single day.

苛 (Kē): strict, minute.
烦 (Fán): urgent, chaotic.

「Thus, he who governs his body must always maintain non-action,
then his heart will be at ease and his spirit serene.
When affairs arise,
his spirit will be strained and his heart disturbed.
Disturbance leads to the loss of the Dao,
ease aligns with the True—
one must be ever vigilant.

**Chapter Forty-Nine: The Sage’s Unchanging Heart**
**Commentary:**
The previous chapter elucidated the daily depletion of the Dao,
demonstrating the path of cultivation and forgetting.
This chapter reveals the Sage’s lack of a fixed heart,
illustrating the application of an open mind to respond to all things.
The first six words establish the Sage’s unchanging heart in responding to all things;
the next two show the Sage blending with the common and yet employing a heart;
the final two conclude with the reason why the people return to goodness,
clarifying the Sage’s virtue of nurturing them all.

**Meaning:**
The governance of a state lies in maintaining non-action,
responding to transformations lies in an open heart.
An open heart means responding to all things without constancy,
non-action means enduringly facing the people.
Thus, whether good or not good,
one responds with goodness;
whether transforming or not transforming,
one guides with sincerity—
trustworthy or untrustworthy,
one responds with trust—
trust without fail.
This is the so-called harmonizing heart and blending transformations,
where all nations find peace and are soothed,
all as infants.
This is the Sage’s grand intent.

The Sage’s heart is without constancy,
for his responses arise from the stirrings of things.
Responses emerge from those stirrings,
thus his heart is without constancy.
Though his heart is not fixed,
it lies in transforming goodness,
constantly taking the hearts of the people as his own.

**Commentary:**
The Sage’s heart is open;
when things stir, he responds.
Response must come from profound intuition.
Since intuition varies,
his responses lack a fixed heart.
Though his heart is not fixed,
his intent remains in compassion and salvation.
For the people have hearts of distrust and unkindness,
thus he blends with them and guides through transformation.
Hence, it is said: *The Sage’s heart is without constancy.*

**Meaning:**
The Way is vast, yet it encompasses all;
subtle, yet it penetrates everywhere—
this is the Great Dao.
Transformations are all-encompassing,
responses arise without fail—
this is the Sage.
Since the Sage’s transformations are universal,
his heart is without constancy.
Those who follow goodness naturally respond through intuition,
those who do not are also led to enlightenment.
Only virtue aids this,
no one abandons another,
spreading compassion universally,
leaving no trace unnoticed—
thus, the Sage’s heart is without constancy,
yet never obstructed.

*To the good, I respond with goodness.*
**Commentary:**
This is the meaning of responding through intuition.
*I* refers to the Sage.
The good are those whose minds return to the True Dao;
the Sage encourages their cultivation,
fulfilling their actions,
leading them to the ultimate goodness—
forgetting goodness itself.

**Meaning:**
Goodness arises from the heart,
its name defined by contrast to evil.
Goodness is revealed through evil,
and when goodness prevails, evil perishes.
Since the people are good,
the Sage responds with goodness,
thus drawing them forward.

*To the ungood, I respond with the virtue of goodness.*
**Commentary:**
The ungood are those steeped in corrupt habits,
clinging to falsehood and abandoning the Dao.
The Sage also leads them with goodness,
drawing them toward enlightenment.
The virtue of goodness means
transforming their hearts to align with the Sage’s virtuous teachings.

**Meaning:**
The people do not know goodness can be cultivated,
evil can be changed—
accumulated habits breed corruption,
and they are lost in delusion.
The Sage pities their stubborn ignorance,
using goodness to guide and transform them.
Only through the Sage’s great function can evil be turned to goodness.
No one is abandoned—
this is where it lies.

Those who cling to falsehood
are like the world’s people who do not know the True Dao,
lost in the depths of error—
like the summer insect doubting ice,
or the well-frog scornful of the sea—
their fixed views seal their errant hearts.
The Sage also entices and teaches them,
distinguishing falsehood from truth,
leading them to goodness.

*To the trustworthy, I respond with trust.*
**Commentary:**
Trust refers to those who hear the Dao and diligently practice it,
holding no doubts in their hearts.
The Sage responds with sincerity,
praising their goodness,
until they reach deep trust.

**Meaning:**
Trust also arises from the heart,
its contrast defined by doubt.
Trust is established through doubt,
and when trust prevails, doubt is forgotten.
Since the people are trustworthy,
the Sage responds with trust,
thus encouraging their resolve.

*To the untrustworthy, I respond with the virtue of trust.*
**Annotation:**
To those who desire goodness and trust,
I respond with goodness and trust;
to those who do not,
I also teach them with goodness and trust.
I wish the people to be moved by my virtue,
thus cultivating goodness and trust.

**Commentary:**
The untrustworthy are those obstinate and rebellious,
rejecting teachings.
The Sage also leads them with equal and true trust,
transforming them to abandon falsehood and return to trust.
Thus, it is said: *the virtue of trust.*
**Meaning:**
The people’s stagnation in worldly ways
breeds doubt from accumulated habits—
they do not know trust can be practiced,
doubt can be discarded,
clinging to doubt and delusion,
distrusting the True.
Like those who forget their return,
or the lower scholars’ great laughter,
the Sage also gradually opens their understanding
with the principles of true trust.
Knowing to trust and discard doubt
relies on the Sage’s virtue.
The virtue of trust, the virtue of goodness—
here lies their essence.

Those who stubbornly cling to falsehood
believe doubt is right,
trust is wrong—
like the summer insect doubting ice,
or the well-frog scornful of the sea—
their fixed views seal their errant hearts.
The Sage also entices and teaches them,
distinguishing trust from doubt,
leading them to trust.

Thus, to draw them toward goodness and trust,
the Sage fears they may incur guilt through doubt,
suffer calamity from clinging to evil.
He encourages and exhorts them,
out of profound pity for all beings and compassion for things.

The Sage moves through the world with anxious care,
blending the hearts of all under heaven.
**Annotation:**
The Sage, in governing the world,
transforms and leads the people—
his heart is always anxious and diligent,
guiding them toward goodness and trust.
Yet the Sage remains still and serene,
his virtue radiant like a full moon,
his heart blended and unified,
all for the sake of the people—
thus, it is said: *he blends the hearts of all under heaven.*

**Commentary:**
This reveals the Sage’s blending and diligent use of his heart.
*Axious care* means anxious and diligent.
The Sage governs with tolerance,
unifying all within the world—
fearing the people do not return to goodness and trust,
thus his anxious care.
Yet the Sage’s heart is without constancy—
what then does he fear or rejoice in?»

The Sage’s anxious care today arises only because the people of the world have yet to embrace goodness and trust. Thus, the Sage blends himself with all things, yet his heart remains ever engaged. Therefore, it is said: *"For the sake of the world, he blends their hearts."*

Its meaning is this: The Sage responds to Heaven and governs the times, follows the people and reaches the utmost limits—his carriage adorned with yellow canopies and green banners, his robes trailing with pendants. Though his body rests within the nine palaces, his heart extends to all ten thousand realms. He discerns the crooked and upright among ministers and subjects, understands the toil of farming and harvest, pardons faults and lightens punishments, reduces taxes and levies. Though his spirit is deep and unyielding, his heart is ever anxious and burdened with care, guiding the wicked and transforming doubt, leading them to return to goodness and trust. Yet the Sage remains serene and still, as if without thought—because his mind is without attachment, all things settle and transform of their own accord.

*Yòu* means to be wide and simple in governance. Because of this breadth and simplicity, the Dao flows freely.
*Hùn* means the inner and outer merge and blend, without distinction.

The people all turn their ears and eyes toward him.
**Annotation:** The people, transformed by the Sage’s virtue, incline their ears and eyes, all listening and observing the Sage.
**Commentary:** The people, moved by the Sage’s pure virtue, turn to his teachings and emulate his conduct. Thus, they all incline their ears and eyes to listen and observe him.

Its meaning is this: Where the Sage’s virtue reaches, all follow suit, the ruler sets the example and the subjects respond. All creatures under the four seas strain their ears to hear his words and their eyes to witness his deeds. This is how they align with the Dao.

*Tīng* means to listen attentively.
*Guàn* means to observe thoroughly.

The Sage treats them all like infants.
**Annotation:** The Sage pities the common folk as a mother pities her children. In all his gaze upon the people, he sees them as infants.
**Commentary:** Since the people have turned their ears and eyes to the Sage, when he looks upon them, it is as a mother looks upon her children. Hence, it is said: *"He treats them all like infants."* Another interpretation: The people have discriminating minds, but the Sage transforms them to follow goodness, making them like infants—without distinction.

Its meaning is this: The Sage of the Dao nurtures all things with compassion, and all things respond to him as to a mother. The Sage regards them as infants. Thus, virtue and the Dao circulate freely, the upper and lower realms resonate in harmony, and the people live in peace and prosperity—how could this not be fitting?

For those who cultivate their own bodies: treasure *qi* and conserve spirit. When *qi* is whole, spirit reigns. If form and spirit are firmly united, then life’s measure extends, and the way of immortals may be attained.

The Sage transforms them to do good, enticing them to cultivate the True. First, he dispels unwholesome thoughts and records their virtuous deeds. Once virtuous actions take root, he forgets the necessity of doing good—without knowing, without doing, unassuming and unboastful, pure and silent, inner and outer merged, like infants without distinction—this is truly in accord with the Dao.

---
**Chapter Fifty: On Birth and Death**

**Commentary:** The previous chapter expounds on the Sage’s blending and unity, responding to the actions of goodness and trust. This chapter elucidates birth and death, opening the gate to transcending suffering and entanglement. The first five sentences mark those who dwell in ease and harmony with the times; the next five clarify those who explore change and transformation; the final eight conclude the practice of virtue, demonstrating the path to longevity and clear vision.

Its meaning is this: The virtue of Heaven and Earth is greatest in birth. Having attained life, one must uphold the Dao to preserve it, nourish spirit to sustain it. Coming is not met with pride, going is not met with fear. One does not cling to life at the cost of the Dao, nor exceed one’s measure and harm life—this is to dwell in ease and harmony with the times.

Those who are confused seek life too greedily and thus lose it. Those who practice virtue arrive at life through the Dao, secure from harm, for they dwell beyond the realm of death. Truly, this is the way.

Speaking of dwelling in ease and harmony with the times, *Zhuangzi*’s *"Great Master"* chapter has Zixi saying to Ziyu: *"To gain is to follow the times; to lose is to follow harmony. Dwelling in ease and harmony with the times, sorrow and joy cannot enter."* This is what the ancients called *suspension of entanglement*—yet those who cannot free themselves are bound by things.

This speaks of those who attain life: life is given by the times. Those who lose death: death is met through harmony. To dwell in life and embrace life is to grasp life’s principle; to dwell in death and embrace death is to grasp death’s principle. When there is neither life nor death, how can there be joy or sorrow? This is the ancient *True Person*, unbound by anything.

If one clings to life while fearing death, the sorrow of excess will come. Those who know this are ensnared by the sorrow and joy of life and death.

The way of longevity and clear vision is the language of this text’s fifty-ninth chapter: *Birth and Death*.
**Annotation:** Enlightenment brings birth; delusion brings death. This is the heading.
**Commentary:** To awaken to life and death, not to cling to life excessively—this is birth. To be ensnared in the illusions of self and other, moving toward death—this is death. This marks the chapter’s theme.

Its meaning is this: Original essence spreads *qi*, the Great Alchemist shapes form. Drawing from the Yang harmony, one attains birth; returning to the Yin stillness, one enters death. Now to clarify the path to halt death and prolong life, and the causes that lead to losing life and hastening death. This heading seems like a question, answered fully in the following sentences.

There are thirteen types of those who attain life.
**Commentary:** *Tú* means "kind" or "category." Here, it broadly discusses those who can dwell in ease with the times, grasp life’s principle, and have no attachment to coming or going. Such people are few—only three in ten.

Its meaning is this: Those who do not take life as joy but dwell in ease with it—these are the types who attain life. When life is upon them, they do not let desire or profit disturb their hearts, nor do they harm their nature through excessive nourishment. Dwelling in simplicity and silence, following the natural flow, their spirit guards their form, their *qi* preserves their spirit, their will harmonizes with their *qi*, their heart stills within their will. Thus, they do not seek to prolong life—life prolongs itself.

There are thirteen types of those who attain death.
**Commentary:** *This broadly discusses how all beings, when facing life, dwell in ease and grasp life’s principle, and when facing death, follow it and grasp death’s principle. Such people are few—only three in ten.*

**Exposition:** *This also broadly discusses the Dao of dwelling in death without resistance, accepting transformation, and finding harmony in departure. Such people are also few—only three in ten.*

Its meaning is this: When death approaches, one does not regard it as sorrow but follows it, and these are the types who attain death. The enlightened in their worldly affairs understand the cyclical nature of existence and nonexistence, knowing how the Dao’s transformations unfold with natural ease. Those who are endowed with a thick constitution of *yang* and harmonizing *qi* will live long, while those whose constitution is thin and lacks purity will die young.

If one knows that longevity and early death both arise from one’s inherent constitution, then life and death can be balanced.
When life and death are balanced, then sorrow and joy do not intrude, and one remains composed without hindrance to body or mind.

Moreover, the *Skull-and-Crossbones* passage in *Zhuangzi* says:
*"In death, there is no lord above, no subject below, no affairs of the four seasons—one floats freely, taking heaven and earth as spring and autumn. Though ruling with the south facing, no joy could surpass this."*

*Zhuangzi* did not believe this, saying:
*"I wish to make the Lord of Life restore your vitality—is that possible?"*

The *Skull-and-Crossbones* replied with furrowed brow and knitted brows:
*"How could I abandon the joy of ruling with the south facing and return to the labor of being a living person?"*

Though this is a metaphorical illustration of a principle, *Zhuangzi* considered that those who delight in life are enslaved by life, while those who delight in death are bound by death. They are entangled in life and death, and only the *reach* (至人) transcends them—living without life, dying without death. They are not enslaved by life nor bound by death.

Since they are neither bound nor enslaved, they can transcend life and death.
Yet, transformation into life cannot be stopped, nor can transformation into death be delayed—only by aligning with the Great Dao can one attain true mastery over life and death.

As for those who emerge beyond death’s grasp and seek eternal life, it lies in cultivating the *True* (修真) and refining the form (炼形). One may discuss its profound mysteries with them.

Life is perilously close to death—thirteen types.
**Commentary:** *Those who overindulge in life’s nourishment harm their vitality through excessive care, and since they cling to this life, they court death’s domain. Thus, they lose both life’s principle and death’s principle. Such people are also few—only three in ten.*

**Exposition:** *This explains those who, in their delusion, cannot grasp the Dao of life and death and thus fall into death’s domain. Though they seek to preserve life, they fail to understand its principle. The principle of dwelling in life is lost, and the Dao of following death is abandoned. Such people are also few—only three in ten.*

Its meaning is this: The foolish and deluded do not know that those who nurture life without understanding its true nature do not attain life, nor do those who transform without insight grasp transformation. They take life as joy and death as sorrow, fearing death and craving life, thus overindulging in life’s preservation. If they seek life contrary to its Dao, they only hasten their own demise—three in ten, roughly speaking.

Another explanation states: Human life is shaped by three *karmas* (业) and ten *evils* (恶). The three *karmas* are:
1. *Body* (身),
2. *Heart* (心),
3. *Speech* (口)—these are the *karmas*.
The ten *evils* are:
- *Body-karma* has three evils: 1. killing life, 2. theft, 3. licentiousness (邪淫);
- *Heart-karma* also has three evils: 1. greed, 2. anger, 3. ignorance;
- *Speech-karma* has four evils: 1. two-tonguedness (两舌), 2. foul speech (恶口), 3. falsehood (妄言), 4. frivolous talk (绮语).
These three *karmas* and ten *evils* together form thirteen.

If one can master and subdue the three *karmas* and ten *evils*, then the Dao of eternal life may be attained—these are the types who attain life, from these thirteen.

If one indulges in the three *karmas* and ten *evils*, then they rush toward death—these are the types who attain death, from these thirteen.

Moreover, beings’ virtues are hard to cultivate, but evils are easily formed. The three *karmas* and ten *evils* are daily transgressed, and each transgression is a path to death.
Thus, it is said that life’s perilous proximity to death arises from these thirteen.

The three *karmas* and ten *evils* are the roots of all offenses. Abandoning them allows one to transcend life, while practicing them leads one into death. The precepts for cultivating the body are the most urgent.

These ten *evils* each have four *causes* (缘), all serving as the basis for affliction and suffering. Which are these?
- In the offense of killing life, there are four causes: 1. the being is truly alive, 2. the thought of the being arises, 3. the intention to kill arises, 4. the act of severing another’s life is carried out.
- In the offense of theft, there are also four causes: 1. the object is truly another’s, 2. the thought of the object arises, 3. the intention to steal arises, 4. the object is moved from its rightful place.
- In the offense of licentiousness, there are four causes: 1. the setting is truly licentious, 2. the thought of the licentious setting arises, 3. the licentious desire is kindled, 4. the body partakes in tainted, pleasurable deeds.
- In the offense of two-tonguedness, there are four causes: 1. the person heard is real, 2. the thought of that person arises, 3. the intention to separate arises, 4. divisive and slanderous speech is uttered.
- In the offense of foul speech, there are four causes: 1. the person reviled is real, 2. the thought of that person arises, 3. the intention to revile arises, 4. foul reviling speech is uttered.
- In the offense of falsehood, there are four causes: 1. the person deceived is real, 2. the thought of that person arises, 3. the intention to deceive arises, 4. false and contradictory statements are made.
- In the offense of frivolous talk, there are four causes: 1. the person addressed is real, 2. the thought of that person arises, 3. the intention to speak frivolously arises, 4. unrighteous words are spoken.

In total, these ten *evils* and three *karmas* comprise fifty-three conditions. Each transgression of these offenses leads one to death’s domain.
Beware! Be cautious!

Why is this so?
**Exposition:** *This poses a question about the causes of life’s proximity to death.*

Its meaning is this: To grasp the essence of transformation and the reasons leading to death, one must examine the following:
- The thickness of one’s constitution in life.
**Commentary:** *The reason life is so perilously close to death is due to these causes.*

But it is because their attachment to this life is too excessive. **Commentary:** This directly answers why mortals are drawn to death’s domain: for they indulge in transient existence, drown in emotional desires, and lavishly nourish themselves to preserve life. When their constitution is too thickly sustained, they are thus drawn to death’s domain.

**Exposition:** The heavens bestow upon humankind with great affection:
- The five flavors nourish them,
- The five colors adorn them,
- The five sounds delight them,
- The five fragrances amuse them,
- The five utilities serve them,
- The five *qi* harmonize them,
- The five senses govern them,
- The five *Wei* (celestial patterns) oversee them,
- The five teachings exhort them,
- The five constants (of human nature) they inherit,
- The five blessings attend them.

They dwell at the head of the five *Ling* (spirits), and are the sovereign of all things. Yet do they not cherish themselves and preserve this love? Instead, they yield to desires and gratify their emotions, fearing death while loving life. When nourishment is excessive, they invite death upon themselves—not through Heaven’s wrath or the gods’ reproach, but by the very excess of their attachment to life.

Thus, the prior fifty-three conditions of the ten *evils* and three *karmas*—when violated, can there truly be no transgression?

Moreover, those who rush forward perish, while the boldly retreating are wounded. Only those who strike a balance can deliberate upon refining their conduct.

For those who excel in preserving life:
**Commentary:** *Sui* (to preserve) is also *wei* (to guard). It refers to those who skillfully guard life with the Dao, subtly observing its origins. Originally pure and tranquil, they forget life in life itself, not letting emotional desires disrupt their harmony. They cultivate their nature through emptiness and spontaneity, and nothing can harm them.

Thus, they are called "excellently preserving."

**Exposition:** Life has limits, yet worldly affairs do not. With life’s finite nature enslaved to boundless pursuits, how can one avoid harm?

Those who excel in preserving life treat affairs as nonexistent, thus preserving their harmony. They do not ensnare their hearts with desires nor injure themselves with gain. They entrust their spontaneity and emptiness to natural flow, resting in stillness to embrace the true essence. Forgotten in life, life is fully preserved; aligned with the Dao, the Dao governs itself. In the chamber of emptiness, purity arises; in the heart of stillness, the mysterious is attained. This is the excellence of preserving life.

When traveling by land, they do not encounter rhinoceros or tigers; when entering battle, they are not harmed by armor or weapons.
**Commentary:** *Encounter* (*yu*) means to meet unexpectedly. According to the *Shan Hai Jing* (Classic of Mountains and Seas), the rhinoceros (*si*) emerges from the south of the Xiang River, blackish-green in hue. The *Er Ya* (Erya) states: "Its form resembles a wild ox, with a single horn weighing a thousand *jin* (pounds)."

Those who excel in preserving life do not harbor malicious intent toward creatures. Thus, when traveling by land, they do not seek to meet rhinoceros or tigers; when entering battle, they are not struck by armored soldiers or weapons. This is why tigers, rhinoceros, and weapons cannot harm them.

**Exposition:** The Xiang River and the Liu River flow from the Nine Doubt Mountains and Lingling, where rhinoceros and tigers reside. Both tigers and rhinoceros are creatures that harm humans. The rhinoceros harms with its horn, the tiger with its claws, and weapons wound in battle. To encounter them is to invite harm; to confront them is to risk injury. Yet those who excel in preserving life do not intervene in battles or weapons, so they are not wounded by them. Nor do they seek to meet tigers or rhinoceros, so they are not harmed by them.

In ancient times, the Jin scholar Guo Wenzhi (文举), residing in the Da Di Mountain (大涤山) of Yu Hang, coexisted with a fierce tiger. Whenever he left the city, the tiger would follow. Someone asked him: "Master, do you possess the Dao? Why does the beast submit to you so docilely?"

Wenzhi replied: "Humans have no intent to harm the beast, and the beast has no intent to harm humans. What else is there to it?"

The rhinoceros has no place to thrust its horn, the tiger no place to strike with its claws, and weapons no place to lodge their blades.
**Annotation:** Those who excel in guarding life’s principles, with their hearts illuminated by purity, harbor no greed or malice. Thus, all external creatures cannot harm them. When traveling by land, they do not seek to meet rhinoceros or tigers; when entering battle, they are not struck by armored soldiers or weapons. This is because they do not provoke harm, so creatures have no means to harm them.

**Commentary:** Earlier, it was shown that those who excel in preserving life have no malicious intent within. Thus, externally, they do not seek to meet rhinoceros or tigers. If they were to encounter them, their lack of harming intent would naturally prevent the creatures from having any place to strike or lodge their weapons. Therefore, one knows that if emotions are forgotten toward creatures, then even seafaring gulls can be tamed and played with, and land-dwelling beasts can be leashed and ridden—how much more so when harm is not intended?

Thus, there is no such harm.

**Exposition:** Those who excel in preserving life align their nature with the Dao. Their benevolent hearts extend broadly, and they harbor no intent to harm others. Their harmonious *qi* fills them internally, so creatures do not seize upon them to harm. Even if they meet rhinoceros or tigers, there will be no claw or horn wounds; or if they face battle, there will be no blade injuries. For their virtue and power are complete, all creatures submit to them in gentleness.

There was a man who lived by the sea, and his son often played with seafaring gulls at the shore. His father found this strange and went to observe. The son arrived first at the place where they had played before, and the gulls, seeing him, flew about but did not alight. Because he had no scheming heart, the gulls approached him. But now that he has scheming intentions, they do not alight.

Thus, if one has the intent to harm creatures, will tigers and rhinoceros not strike or wound them? What is not wounded is the absence of scheming intent within.

According to the *Transmission of the Immortals* (《神仙传》), Liu Gang (字伯鸾), with his wife, Lady Fan (樊夫人), both attained the Dao of the immortals. When Liu Gang was the magistrate of Shangyu, he visited the Sifang Mountains (四明山) and encountered a tiger. The tiger, seeing him, bowed and did not dare rise, and he told his wife about it. Lady Fan went straight toward it and, with a rope, bound the tiger and brought it home, treating it like a household dog. This was the power of virtue and Dao.

*Diao* (to place) means to set; *rong* (to contain) means to receive; *xia* (to tame) means to approach closely and familiarize.
There is no place for claws to strike or blades to lodge.

**Why is this so?**
**Commentary:** This asks why tigers, rhinoceros, and weapons—harmful to humans—do not strike, place, or lodge their claws, horns, or blades against those who excel in preserving life. It is a rhetorical question to enlighten humans.

**Exposition:** To further clarify that those who excel in preserving life are not drawn to death’s domain, the question is posed again, urging them to strive in their cultivation.

Because there is no place of death.

**Annotation:** *Why* do rhinoceros, tigers, armor, and weapons have no place to strike or lodge their claws, horns, or blades? It is because they follow the natural order without selfishness, not treating death as death. Thus, things cannot harm their life. Hence, it is said there is no place of death.

**Commentary:** This is the direct answer. Those who see the burden of their physical form as a hindrance to life’s continuity perish. But those who excel in preserving life perceive the emptiness of inherent existence (*dharma-nature*), understand the illusory nature of the self, and thus forget life in the act of living. They do not overindulge in nourishment, follow the natural order without selfishness, and thus have no place of death to dwell in. If the mind harbors no place of death, how could tigers, rhinoceros, or weapons harm their life?

**Exposition:** The great Sage expounds this scripture, broadly proclaiming the essentials of the Dao/Way, wishing all to cultivate virtue. If all cherish life and cultivate virtue, they will have no faults or blemishes. Cherishing life means embracing Dao and virtue, while lacking faults or blemishes means avoiding death’s domain. Embracing Dao and virtue leads to longevity, and thus there will be no injuries from weapons, claws, or horns—one may attain the pure and tranquil Dao of the Immortal Adept.

A ruler who governs by virtue does not rely on the might of arms; the four borders remain in harmony, and even the three-sided nets of the hunt are opened, with beasts dancing in submission—what harm could they inflict?

*Completion of Volume Thirty-Six of the Broad Explication of the True Scripture of Dao and Virtue*
*Commencement of Volume Thirty-Seven of the Broad Explication of the True Scripture of Dao and Virtue*

「The *Broad Explication of the True Scripture of Dao and Virtue* by Master Broad-achievement (Du Guangting) of the Tang Dynasty—Explication of Chapter Fifty-One on *Dao-Generating Virtue*:

The preceding chapter elucidates the birth and death of the Dao, skillfully guiding one beyond the gates of suffering and entanglement. This chapter clarifies how the Dao generates virtue and nurtures life, without slaughtering what is naturally noble.

First, it extols the wondrous origin of the Dao, which gives rise to the marvel of life’s creation. Next, it reveals why all things hold the Dao and virtue in highest esteem, for the Dao generates life. Finally, it praises the function of nurturing life, which the Dao accomplishes without possession.

*Explication*:

The Dao is the wondrous origin, capable of generating all beings. Virtue is the manifestation of the Dao, able to nurture all forms. Moving creatures belong to Heaven, while rooted plants align with Earth. What Heaven and Earth cultivate, what the Transformations create—none can arise without the Dao’s *qi*, none can flourish without the Dao’s virtue. All things stand by the Dao and rely on its power.

Among those with feeling and awareness, and those without, all revere the Dao and honor virtue, never forgetting that the Dao is their ultimate source. It is the most revered by all things—not because of noble titles or the weight of authority, but because abandoning the Dao leads to ruin. How much more so for the sovereign who faces south: without the Dao, there is no peace.

The labor of cultivating true refinement in all lands depends on the Dao. Yet the Dao, among all things, never boasts of its own achievements; its virtue and power grow ever more profound and mysterious.

The Dao generates life—
*Annotation*: The wondrous origin moves and harmonizes the *qi* of all things.

Virtue nurtures life—
*Annotation*: Things receive the Dao’s virtue to sustain and nourish all forms.
