Zhèng will seek refuge with Chǔ.

When a state’s commands have no bounds,
its ruin is already known—
it will exhaust its tribute to await sudden collapse.
This was the fate of **Chǔ Jìn’s** domain.

To dwell between great states yet submit to coercion—
is this truly a crime?
It arises because great states cannot soothe the hearts of the lesser ones,
and thus provoke rebellion.

Therefore, a great state toward lesser states
should be **humble and yielding**, to win their hearts,
**gentle and tranquil**, to embrace them.

*"Taking"* means **gathering**—
gathering others to oneself.
When lesser states submit to greater ones,
they seek to **take** from the greater ones.
**Annotation:** The greater takes the lesser as subjects and servants;
the lesser takes the greater as **allies and support**.

**Exegesis:** When the sovereign of a great state uses humble submission
to subdue a lesser state,
the sovereign of the lesser state will attend court, pay homage,
and dare not rebel—
offering deference in service to the greater state,
seeking its might as **support**.

**Meaning:** If a lesser state humbly devotes itself with loyalty,
exhausting its respect in serving the greater state,
then the greater state will cherish and pacify it,
soften and subdue it.
But if a lesser state cannot render proper rites or sincerity
in serving the greater state—
as when the people of **Sòng** made the **Lùshàng Alliance**
to seek the **Hé** states’ aid from **Chǔ**,
and **Chǔ** agreed—
**Sòng Gōngzǐ Mùyí** said:
*"A lesser state making alliances—this is disaster.*
**Sòng will surely perish.**"
Fortunately, defeat came later.
At the alliance, Mùyí said:
*"Disaster lies here.*
The ruler’s demands are too extreme—
how can they endure?"
Thus, **Chǔ seized Sòng Gōng**.
In winter, they assembled at **Bó** and released him.
Mùyí said:
*"Not yet.*
This is insufficient to warn the ruler."
This was the case of a lesser state failing to serve a greater one.

But when a lesser state serves a greater one well—
as in **Yǐn Wén Gōng’s** first year, third month,
when **Zhū Yí Fù** made an alliance at **Mì Lǔ**,
**Zhū** being a vassal prince not yet under royal command,
hence its name was recorded—
yet the lesser state could properly attend the greater one,
renewing goodwill and calming the people,
its name was honored in the records.

**Court attendance**—when a great state visits a lesser one as **plenipotentiary**,
it is the greater serving the lesser;
when a lesser state visits a great one as **tribute-bearer**,
it is the lesser serving the greater.
**Renewing goodwill** and **binding trust**—
**consulting on affairs** and **supplementing deficiencies**—
these are the greatest of rites.

**Mèngzǐ** said:
*"Only the virtuous can serve the lesser with the greater,
as **Tāng** served **Gé Bó** and **Wén Wáng** served **Kūn Yí**.*
Only the wise can serve the greater with the lesser,
as **Dà Wáng** served **Xūn Yú** and **Gōu Jiàn** served **Wú**."

Serving the lesser with the greater is called *"rejoicing in Heaven,"*
serving the greater with the lesser is called *"fearing Heaven."*
Those who rejoice in Heaven **preserve the world**,
those who fear Heaven **preserve their state.**

The *Odes* say:
*"Fear Heaven’s fear,#2*
In its time, it preserves [us]."*
This is the *Zhōu Preface* praising **Chéng Wáng**,
who feared Heaven’s might and secured lasting peace.

Thus, sometimes one submits to **take**,
sometimes one submits **and is taken**.
**Annotation:** *"Take"* refers to the greater taking the lesser;
*"and is taken"* refers to the lesser taking the greater.

**Exegesis:** The *Spring and Autumn Annals* says:
*"When an army can maneuver it at will, it is called ‘take.’"*
When one submits to **take**—
the greater state uses humble submission
to **take** the lesser state,
making it obedient in all directions—
hence *"take."*
When one submits **and is taken**—
the lesser state uses humble submission
to serve the greater state,
only able to receive support,
not to command at will—
hence *"and is taken."*

**Meaning:** An army that can maneuver at will—
as in **Lǐzǐ Gōng’s** twenty-sixth autumn,#3
when **Sòng** rebelled against **Chǔ** but aligned with **Jìn**.
**Chǔ**’s **Yīnzhěng** and **Sīmǎ** led troops to attack **Sòng**,
besieging **Mián**.
The **Gōng** used **Chǔ**’s army to attack **Qí**, seizing **Gǔ**.
In general, when an army can maneuver at will, it is called *"take."*
This means advance and retreat are at its command.
**Huan Gōng’s** son **Yōng** was placed in **Gǔ** as a hostage for **Lǔ’s** support.
**Chǔ**’s **Shēn Gōng** secured the alliance.
**Huan Gōng’s** seven sons became **Chǔ’s** great ministers,
because **Qí Xiàogōng** could not pacify them.
In the twenty-eighth year, **Chǔzǐ** sent **Shēn Shū** to release **Gǔ**.
This shows maneuvering is at one’s disposal,
and taking or releasing is as circumstances demand.

A great state seeks only to **nurture and dominate** others,
a lesser state seeks only to **enter and serve** others.
**Annotation:** When a great state humbly submits to the lesser,
it seeks only to **nurture and dominate** the lesser as subjects and servants.
When a lesser state presents tribute and submits to the greater,
it seeks only to **enter and serve** the greater for support.

**Exegesis:** The great state, through humble virtue, submits to the lesser,
seeking nothing more than to **nurture and dominate** the lesser as its subjects,
as its sovereign’s vassals.
The lesser state, through humble offerings and tribute,
seeks only to **enter and serve** the greater state,
to gain its support.

**Meaning:** The great state takes the lesser as subjects and servants,
the lesser state takes the greater as allies and support.
These are the two ultimate intentions.

*"Upshot"* means **offering**,
*"tribute"* means **presenting**,
*"currency"* means **silk**.
When princes pay homage to the **Sovereign**,
or states exchange envoys,
they must **display** jade, silk, and goods,
**hold them as rites**—
hence *"accreditation and tribute."*

When a lesser state seeks the greater’s support—
as in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, **Wén Gōng’s** fourteenth autumn,#4
when **Zhēng Bó** and **Lǔ Gōng** feasted at **Cuī**,
**Zhēng’s** minister **Guī Shēng** recited *"Hóng Yàn"*,
taking its meaning of **pitying widows and orphans**
to move **Lǔ Hóu** to compassion.
He also recited *"Zǎi Chí"*’s four chapters,
speaking of **Zhēng’s** weakness,
taking its meaning that a lesser state in distress
seeks to draw the greater state as support.

Both sides thus obtain what they desire,
hence the greater should **humble itself**.
**Annotation:** One seeks subjects and servants,
the other seeks allies and support—
both obtain what they desire.
Yet great states must always guard against arrogance,
hence it is said the greater should **humble itself**.

**Exegesis:** The great desires to **nurture and dominate**,
the lesser desires to **enter and serve**—
both fulfill their wishes,
hence *"each obtains what they desire."*

The greater must **humble itself** before the lesser,
for though things are commonly light when small and heavy when great,
it is inevitable that the great will **overwhelm** the small—
lest the ruler of a great state grow arrogant from strength and invite calamity,
few being able to **submit to submission**.

Thus, the great are warned to **practice humility** above all.

**Annotation:** The great must **humble itself**—
this is the Way of **concealing virtue** and **nurturing weakness**.

**Exegesis:** Even to stand above an ordinary man is difficult.
How much more so to rule over a state?
One who governs must **align with Heaven and Earth**,
**comfort the people and harmonize the populace**,
not **exalt oneself** because of the state’s grandeur,
nor **rely on strength** because of its mighty arms.
Let **humility and gentleness** be one’s resolve,
let **caution and reverence** dwell in one’s heart—
like walking on thin ice,
or guiding a rotting rope,
with **vigilant diligence**,
**solemnly respecting** the **mysterious Dao**,
and thus one may **preserve their realm**.

The **Laozi** feared that **relying on strength** would lead to ruin,
hence he **especially warned** against this.

For those who govern their own bodies,
it is to **avoid arrogance in wealth and power**,
to **guard against fullness and excess** in governance,
and to **restrain oneself and moderate desires**,
so that one may **attain a peaceful end**.

If a great state cannot **humble itself**,
it may **indulge in extravagance** or **display insolence**,
and the people will **forsake it**.
King **Jie of Xia** held the **Rúyīng Assembly**,
and the people **rebelled** against him;
King **Zhòu of Shang** held the **Líhunting Expedition**,
and the **Eastern barbarians rebelled**;
King **Yōu of Zhou** held the **Tàishì Alliance**,
and the **Róng and Yí tribes rebelled**;
Duke **Shuāng of Sòng** held the **Assembly at Lùshàng**,
and the **feudal lords rebelled**;
King **Zǐ of Chu** held the **Assembly at Shēn**,
and the **people’s hearts turned away**.

One who **harbors resentment** does not **win loyalty with virtue**,
one who **relaxes discipline** does not **secure obedience with rites**—
how can such a ruler **expect submission**?

**Dao** is the **ultimate mystery** of all things. **(Chapter 62 of *Dàodéjīng*)**

**Exegesis:** The previous chapter showed that **virtue/power** can **draw down** others,
so that both great and small **fulfill their desires**.
This chapter reveals that **Dao/Way** can **transform and govern** all things,
so that both good and evil **are encompassed by its influence**.

First, it **proclaims the essence of Dao**.
Next, it **illustrates the establishment of teaching** to transform people.
Finally, it **lamented the ancient rulers’ neglect of Dao’s function**,
which can truly be called **the most noble of all**.

**Annotation:** **Noble**—this means **revered and exalted**.
**Exegesis:** Dao is the **mysterious essence** of all things,
**the source from which they draw their origin**.
Hence it is called the **ultimate mystery** of all things.

**Mystery** means **the inner realm**—
**Dao** contains all without exclusion,
**encompassing** all as their **origin and foundation**.
Thus it is the **ultimate mystery** of all things.

The *Xīshēng Jīng* states:
*"Dao is profound and most mysterious,
the abyss of the void and formless."*

This is precisely what is meant.

**Exegesis:** The **depth of Dao** is such that it **swallows all** and **encompasses all**.
The **height of the dome** and the **breadth of the earth**,
the **illumination of the sun and moon**,
the **flourishing of the living and the growing**—
all are **nurtured by Dao’s qi**,
dwelling within the **Great Dao**,
hence it is the **ultimate mystery** of all things.

The *Xīshēng Jīng* is the **Laozi’s** teaching
given in the **25th year of King Zhāo of Zhou (癸丑)**,
in the **4th month**,
at **Yīnxí’s grass hut** in the **shadow of Zhōngnán Mountain**,
after **delivering the two *Dàodé* Scriptures**.
Then, **to transform the Western lands** and **pacify the drifting sands**,
Yīnxí asked about **the method of preserving the Three Treasures** and **one’s essence**,
and the **essentials of Dao practice and self-cultivation**.
Later, he **compiled and recorded** these **sacred words**,
and **ascended to Tàiwēi**—
the **meaning of transforming the Western lands** and **pacifying the drifting sands**.

The *Xīshēng Jīng* consists of **36 chapters**,
**972 sentences**,
and **4,278 words**.
Its **core meaning** aligns with the *Dàodéjīng*,
stating that the **Great Dao is profound and mysterious**,
the **haven of the void and formless**.

The **treasure of the virtuous**—
**Annotation:** The virtuous know that those who **guard Dao** flourish,
while those who **lose Dao** perish,
hence they **reverence and cherish** it without **suffering harm**.

**Exegesis:** **Treasure** means **precious and valued**.
The **virtuous** embody **Dao’s effortless action**,
their **body and mind pure and tranquil**,
hence they **reverence and cherish Dao** without **ever forgetting it**.

**Exegesis:** The virtuous **reflect on Dao** and **harmonize their hearts**,
thus they **constantly cherish Dao**.

Zǐhǎn said:
*"Men value jade as treasure,
I value **non-greed** as treasure."*
And for rulers who govern their states,
**virtue** is their treasure—
how much more so for the virtuous,
whose hearts **never forsake Dao**,
thus **Dao itself is their treasure**.

The **treasure that the unvirtuous cannot guard**—
**Annotation:** **Guard** means **to rely upon**.
The unvirtuous **cannot treasure Dao**,
and when **calamity befalls**,
they **seek to rely on Dao with their bodies**,
**praying for deliverance**.

**Exegesis:** **Guard** means **to rely upon** or **lean upon**.
The unvirtuous **lack wisdom**,
**bewildered by their habits**.
In times of ease, they **neglect Dao**,
but when **disaster strikes**, they **turn to it with their bodies**,
**relying on Dao** to **seek safety**.

**Exegesis:** The unvirtuous **act contrary to teaching**,
thus they are **far from Dao**.
Even if they **seek to guard their bodies** and **rely on Dao**,
to **resolve difficulties** and **save peril**,
they **cannot succeed**.

The Scripture also says:
*"The treasure that the unvirtuous do not guard"*—
meaning the unvirtuous **violate Dao**,
hence they **do not treasure Dao**.

**Why?** Dao **loves gentleness and weakness**,
but the unvirtuous **love strength and hardness**;
Dao **loves tranquility and harmony**,
but the unvirtuous **love rigidity and agitation**;
Dao **loves emptiness and stillness**,
but the unvirtuous **love noise and clamor**;
Dao **loves humility and lowliness**,
but the unvirtuous **love defiance and resistance**;
Dao **loves non-action**,
but the unvirtuous **love scheming and interference**;
Dao **loves life and creation**,
but the unvirtuous **love destruction and harm**.

Their **actions contradict Dao**,
hence the unvirtuous **do not treasure Dao**.

**Sweet words can earn honor**,
**noble deeds can elevate others**—
**Annotation:** If one **makes their words sweet and pleasing**,
they can **seek honor through exchange**;
if one **raises their conduct**,
they can **add to others’ virtue**.
This is like the **sage’s** offering of **sweet and refined Dao-teaching**,
and **exalted, tranquil conduct**,
to **transform the unvirtuous**—
just as merchants **sell goods** and the people **follow in obedience**.

Hence the following text says:

「**Exegesis:** This is a parable in explanation.
It means that even the unvirtuous are included within the scope of teaching.
**Elucidation:** The Dao’s words are plain and unadorned,
lacking sweetness and appeal—
how could the unvirtuous ever take delight in them?
Thus, the sage employs sweet words to entice them,
and those who follow are like merchants flocking to the market for profit.
The sage demonstrates noble and elevated conduct to transform them,
and those who respond are like travelers drawn to fragrance and returning in reverence.
Through this transformation, even the unvirtuous refine themselves,
all becoming practitioners of the Dao—
this is the saying that **"the Dao does not abandon anyone."**
How could the unvirtuous be abandoned?
**Elucidation:** Even when people’s words and deeds are unvirtuous,
how could they be abandoned?
They should be guided by the good Dao,
hoping they will follow the teaching and abandon their evil ways—
one cannot abandon them without first transforming them.
Hence the saying: **"How could they be abandoned?"**
**Elucidation:** The sage’s benevolence is vast,
the Dao does not cast aside any being.
Though the unvirtuous may be unvirtuous,
pitying their lack of understanding of the Dao,
the sage offers sweet words to entice them,
good teachings to encourage them,
leading them toward virtue without abandoning any.
**悛 (quān)**, means to change.
Thus, the institution of the Son of Heaven and the Three Ministers is established.
**Elucidation:** To collectively teach the unvirtuous.
**Exegesis:** Thus, the Three Ministers are appointed—
namely, the Grand Teacher, the Grand Tutor, and the Grand Guardian.
The Son of Heaven practices non-action,
while the Three Ministers expound the Dao,
all methods to impart instruction and establish teaching,
transforming the unvirtuous.
The *Book of Documents* says: **"The workings of Heaven, and humans follow in response."**
This is the very meaning.
**Elucidation:**」

The vastness of the Four Seas,
the abundance of all things,
when humans first emerged,
they could not lack a sovereign,
so the Son of Heaven is established to nurture them.
The Son of Heaven,
revering the Supreme Dao,
serves Heaven as a father,
serves Earth as a mother,
is called the Son of Heaven.

One person cannot govern broadly,
so the Hundred Officials are appointed to oversee them.
Among the Hundred Officials,
the Three Ministers hold the highest rank.
The *Book of Documents* and *Zhou Officials* state:
**"It is the Three Ministers who expound the Dao and guide the state."**

The Grand Teacher,
wise enough to be a wellspring of knowledge,
conducting enough to serve as a model,
when consulted, responds appropriately,
when sought, yields results.
He is called the Grand Teacher,
also known as the Grand Father.
*Tai* signifies greatness,
and he is the teacher of the king.
He rides in a **carriage of state** with green canopy,
wears a **golden seal and purple sash**.

The Grand Tutor,
teaches and safeguards.
The *Greater Dai Li* says:
**"He instructs the Son of Heaven in virtue and righteousness."**
If the Son of Heaven
lacks filial piety toward his parents,
shows no kindness to the common people,
offends the great ministers,
or fails in the administration of justice,
then the Grand Tutor has neglected his duty.

The Grand Guardian,
safeguards, supports, and bears responsibility.
The *Greater Dai Li* says:
**"If the Son of Heaven occupies his position improperly,
receives the classics without reverence,
speaks without proper tone,
his music does not conform to the laws,
and his movements lack the rites of respectful elevation and lowering,
then the Grand Guardian has neglected his duty."**

Additionally, there are the Three Assistants—
the Grand Marshal, the Grand Minister of Instruction, and the Grand Minister of Works,
who help the Son of Heaven govern **yin and yang**,
personally serve the people,
and promote teachings and transformations.
This is their role.

The *Book of Documents* (in the **□ Caoyu Mó** section) says:
**"One day, two days, myriad affairs—
do not neglect the Hundred Officials,
for humans must follow Heaven’s work."**
*Edang* means to leave empty,
*shu* means the multitude.
The one who holds the position must be the right person;
if not, then the office is left vacant.
This means that humans should govern in Heaven’s stead,
but they cannot use Heaven’s offices for private gain,
nor employ those unfit for the task.

Even if one presents
a **jewel of great worth** (拱璧)
and a **team of four fine horses** (先驷马),
it is not as valuable as
sitting and offering this Dao of non-action.
**Elucidation:** Even the Three Ministers, though they assist the Son of Heaven,
would find that even presenting a jewel of great worth
and a team of four fine horses as tribute
is still not as precious as
sitting and offering this Dao of non-action,
so that the transformations of evil to virtue may take place.

The **jewel of great worth** and the **team of four fine horses**,
in ancient times,
when nobles paid homage to the Son of Heaven,
or when states held assemblies,
the lesser state would present tribute first—
a jewel as the guide,
followed by a team of four horses.
This is why it is called *xian* (先).
The *Spring and Autumn Annals* records cases like
the **Wei carriage leading twelve oxen** (乘韦先牛十二)
to entertain the troops.

**Elucidation:** *Hequan* (合拱) means,
as the *Shuo Wen* says,
two hands clasped together as a gesture of respect.
*Bi* (璧) is a **auspicious jade**.
A **jewel of great worth** refers to the largest jade presented.
*Si che* (驷马) means four horses harnessed together,
driving a single carriage.
In ancient times,
when nobles paid homage to the Son of Heaven,
or when states held assemblies at great or lesser courts,
or met in the wild,
when two rulers faced each other,
they would exchange gifts of tribute.
The first gift presented was called *xian* (先).
Now, the Three Ministers should focus on
expounding the Dao and guiding the state.
Though they might wish to present
a **team of four fine horses** and a **jewel of great worth** to the Son of Heaven,
such gifts only encourage excess and luxury,
but do not aid in governance or administration.
It is better to offer this Dao of non-action and tranquility,
so that it may transform the world.
Let the unvirtuous follow virtue,
let the unrepentant change their hearts—
when the Dao’s transformations spread far and wide,
the Son of Heaven’s virtue reaches everywhere.
What need is there for such gifts as the **jewel of great worth** and the **team of four fine horses**?

*Fuxiang* (辅相) means
to **support and assist**.
It also means
to **observe their virtues and vices**.
The Son of Heaven takes the **Four Assistants constellation** as a model
for establishing his ministers of support and assistance,
to correct his deficiencies,
to uphold proper rites,
to guide him with morality,
and to aid him with governance and transformation.

The **Wei carriage leading twelve oxen** (乘韦先牛十二),
as recorded in the *Spring and Autumn Annals* during Duke Li of the Lu State, thirty-third year:
The Jin army attacked Zheng,
and reached the city of Hao.
A Zheng merchant named Xian Gao,
who was selling goods in the Zhou state,
encountered them on the way.
He presented a **Wei carriage** (乘韦) as the guide,
followed by twelve oxen (牛十二),
to entertain the troops, saying:
**"My humble lord heard that your forces were about to march through our state,
and I dared to offer this small tribute to those who follow you.
Though I cannot afford much in gifts,
I can provide one day’s worth of provisions for those who stop,
and one night’s worth of guard for those who move on.
Moreover, I will send an urgent message to Zheng,
so that they may be prepared."**

The ancients honored this Dao for what reason?
*Note: "何" as an interrogative particle.*

*Commentary:* To establish trust in the present by citing the past.

The ancients refer to those who previously treasured this Dao.
Why did they value it so?
*Commentary:* "Why?"—to inquire into the reason for cherishing this Dao.

A single *archer’s jade* is not enough to make it precious,
A team of *four horses* cannot suffice to make it rare.
From antiquity to the present,
Only what is precious in the Dao—why?

The *Laozi* sought to illuminate the Dao’s efficacy:
To harmonize and bring peace to Heaven and Earth,
To align and assist the states and families.
Practicing it brings order,
Defying it brings chaos.
He emphasized its profound benefit to all beings.

Now, further questioning why the ancients honored this Dao:
Is it because it cannot be daily sought yet obtained,
Or because it can absolve one of guilt?

Therefore, it is honored by all under Heaven.
*Note: The Dao lies in enlightenment, not in seeking. Unlike wealth, which can be daily sought and acquired, hence it cannot be "daily sought yet obtained." Once enlightened, there is no burden of guilt—why would one seek release from guilt only after committing it? Thus, it is truly worthy of all under Heaven’s honor.*

*Commentary:* This response elucidates why the Dao is precious.
The phrase "not daily sought yet obtained" means
That the Dao lies in enlightenment,
And enlightenment arises from clarity of mind—
Not like the methods of deliberate action,
Where one calculates days and years,
Striving and scheming to attain it.
But when the heart is pure and worldly thoughts are stilled,
The natural luminosity of truth emerges.
Thus, it is said, "not daily sought yet obtained."

As for "absolve one of guilt,"—
When deluded thoughts arise and defilements cling,
The karmic burden naturally follows.
If one attains enlightenment through the Dao,
And the heart is pure and empty,
Then the cause of guilt is extinguished.
How could it be like the stubborn-minded,
Who, at every movement, generate regret and remorse,
Entangled by guilt and punishment,
Only then seeking release?

For this reason,
It is treasured by all virtuous under Heaven.

*Commentary:* The Dao is precious to all under Heaven
Because one attains it through sudden enlightenment,
Not through striving and seeking.
Once deluded thoughts are dispelled,
One naturally enters the true Dao.
With deluded thoughts removed,
The defilements of worldly concerns also vanish.
Thus, one can obtain it,
And be freed from guilt—
Hence, it is universally cherished.

The *Laozi* spoke of the Dao’s profound and mysterious nature,
For few are those who truly comprehend it.
He posed this question to praise and clarify,
Hoping they would attain enlightenment.

Moreover, he addressed those who still cling to worldly studies,
Who value a single *archer’s jade* more than a moment of precious time.
Would the sovereign of the Dao not exalt the wondrous and subtle roots of virtue,
And instead revere those trifling, clamorous, and material things?

---

*The Daoist Classic of Broad Virtue and Sacred Meaning, Volume 43*
*Attributed to Master Guangcheng of the Tang Dynasty, Du Guangting*

*Annotations:*
1. "供" (*supply*) should be read as "佚" (*lost*).
2. "畏天之畏" (*fear of Heaven*) should be read as "畏天之威" (*fear of Heaven’s awe*).
3. "成" (*accomplish*) in "楚申公叔侯成" should be read as "戍" (*fortify/guard*).
4. "文公十四年秋" (*Autumn of Duke Wen’s fourteenth year*) should be read as "十三年" (*thirteenth year*).

For the Chapter on *Non-Action* (Chapter 63) – *Commentary*:
The preceding chapter expounds the wondrous origins of the Dao’s profundity,
And the path of seated enlightenment as the gate to the *auxiliary ministers*.
This chapter elucidates the silent, effortless *Non-Action*,
And the cultivation of tranquility to extinguish resentment.
First, it marks the practice of *seated-forgetting* and severing desire,
Then demonstrates how to avert calamities by preventing their sprouts.
Finally, it illustrates the sovereign’s virtue through the *Way*,
To conclude and exhort thee.

**Meaning:**
Before, through not esteeming *archer’s jade* or *fine steeds*,
It advanced the Dao as the source of *cosmic transformation*,
And declared that sudden enlightenment leads to the *Mystic*—
The *Mystic* being without blame.
This is the *Non-Action* of *Non-Action*,
The savoring of the Dao in its unchanging constancy,
Naturally free of grievance or reproach,
For virtue’s reward is enduring, not the toil of trifling excess.
Thus, in harmony with the Dao, there is no transgression.

This exhorts the ruler to honor the Dao
And embody *Non-Action*,
To lead by example and magnify *purity and stillness*.

**Non-Action is Action,**
**Non-Affair is Affair,**
**Non-Savor is Savor.**
*Commentary*:
**Action**—here, *crafting*.
The cultivator of the Dao,
Through *seated-forgetting* and abandoning desire,
Has a mind that crafts nothing.
Whatever they undertake,
Their works align with *cosmic transformation*—
Not *doing* yet *doing*,
Hence called *Non-Action*.
This clarifies the mind.

They cling not to affairs,
Hence in affairs there is *Non-Affair*—
This clarifies the body.

They indulge not in tastes,
Hence in tastes there is *Non-Savor*—
This clarifies the speech.

The Three *Karmas* purified,
Then the Six *Senses*’ dust naturally subsides.

**Meaning:**
Mankind’s inherent nature,
From birth, comprises the Three *Karmas*.
The *Karma of the mind* arises,
With utility yet no form—
All deeds originate in the mind.
*Non-Action* purifies the *Karma of the mind*.

The *Karma of the body* arises,
With utility yet substance—
Affairs undertaken bind to the body.
*Non-Affair* purifies the *Karma of the body*.

The *Karma of speech* arises,
With words and tastes—
The known tastes are not the Dao’s speech,
But spring from the mouth.
*Non-Savor* and *forgetting speech* purify the *Karma of speech*.

Once the Three *Karmas* are abandoned,
All dust subsides of itself.
Dust clears, stillness prevails,
Lips seal the true Dao—
This is the cultivator’s practice.

The ruler who governs by *Non-Action*,
Does not cling to *crafting*,
Thus the three seasons are unobstructed,
And the myriad folk untroubled—
*Leaning on the lintel, holding the map*,
They transcend in ease and repose.

The one who *Non-Affairs*
Does not toil in labor or war,
Seeks no *jade terrace* or *palace of pearls* in splendor,
No *Hall of Eternal Tranquility* or *Tiger’s Mound* in grandeur—
Then, in humble halls of thatch and wood,
Human effort is preserved.

The one who *Non-Savors*
Does not indulge in wine or delicacies,
Lives freely, fulfilling their nature,
Preserves life on land and water,
Finds contentment in simple fare—
This is the way of *Non-Savor*.

The one who *forgets speech*
Upright in form, transforming below,
Issues commands without vexation,
Unassuming yet all is transformed—
Thus, they accord with the *Non-Action* of the Dao.

Great or small, many or few,
Virtue alone repays resentment.
*Annotation*:
In *Non-Action* there is Action,
In *Non-Affair* there is Affair,
In *Non-Savor* there is Savor.

If great and small, many and few,
Do not exceed their bounds,
Then no resentment arises.
If one follows the *sense-fields* and stirs the mind,
Violating boundaries and harming nature,
Then great and small alike become resentment’s match.
Now, since they guard their bounds and preserve harmony,
This is the repayment of resentment with virtue.

*Commentary*:
Greatness and smallness, many and few,
If they touch the *sense-fields* of *Action*,
Are naught but the vastness of resentment’s foes.
If one embodies *Non-Action*,
Abandons these desires,
Realizes the true and actual,
And quells the mind of arising and ceasing,
Then resentment’s foes do not arise—
This is the repayment of resentment with virtue.

**Meaning:**
The ruler, in *Non-Action* yet *Action*,
In *Non-Affair* yet *Affair*,
Serene and self-satisfied,
Alone wanders with the Dao,
Below, no grievances or queries,
At the borders, no arms or armor.
Should any dare to rebel,
They must be tamed of their own accord—
*Dance with the dry bones and the withered branches,*
And the *Miao* tribes will submit.
This is the repayment of resentment with virtue.

The cultivator of the self,
With the Three *Karmas* purified,
No evils arise,
No things can intrude—
How could resentment or anger take root?
Since resentment and anger are nonexistent,
They devote themselves wholly to *purity and emptiness*—
This too is the repayment of resentment with virtue.

**Difficult things must be addressed when they are easy,**
**Great things must be undertaken when they are small.**
*Annotation*:
To clarify the prior admonition to preemptive planning.

*Commentary*:
**Address**—here, *plan and resolve*.
**Undertake**—here, *pursue*.
Passion and desire harm nature,
All arise gradually—
No difficulty is not first easy,
No greatness is not first small.
If one plans to address difficulty when it is already difficult,
And undertakes greatness when it is already great,
Then calamity has already taken form—
Even if they plan and act thereafter,
It will avail nothing against the calamity.

**Meaning:**
*Non-Affair* and *Non-Action*
Naturally avoid great and difficult things.
They extinguish the mind’s stirrings before they arise,
And thus do not await suppression when small and easy—
This is to clarify the mind and *cosmic transformation*,
To attain tranquility and steadfastness.

**Difficult things must arise from ease,**
**Great things must arise from smallness.**
*Annotation*:
To explain the prior admonition on preemptive planning.

*Commentary*:
**Arise**—here, *begin*.
This follows the prior text,
To trace the origins of calamity.
Difficult things must begin in ease,
Thus they should be addressed while still easy.
Great things must begin in smallness,
Thus they should be extinguished while still small.
Their kinds are indeed manifold,
Too numerous to enumerate—
Hence the summary: *all difficult things under heaven, all great things under heaven*.

**Meaning:**
To prevent calamity before its signs appear,
To extinguish it before its sprouts arise—
This is the utmost caution.
Calamities are born from slight neglect,
Disasters from subtle beginnings.
If one guards against them early,
How could great or difficult calamities ever manifest?

The general phrase *all under heaven*
Is meant to prompt both action and inaction in guarding against the subtle.

Thus, the Sage never undertakes what is great,
And so is able to achieve greatness.
*Annotation*:
Since it was said that *great things must arise from smallness*,
This explains how the Sage can achieve greatness—
By not undertaking what is difficult or great,
They thus fulfill their *august and grand* purpose.

The *Commentary* explains that ordinary people commonly undertake difficult and great matters, thus incurring many failures and calamities. Therefore, it is said that the Sage never undertakes difficult or great matters, and thus achieves the august and grand.

**Meaning:**
Ordinary people are led astray by circumstances, their thoughts drift into error, and when difficult matters arise, their faults cannot be erased; when great matters arise, their crimes cannot be absolved. The Sage comprehends the emptiness of illusion and penetrates the eternal truth, thus never engaging in what is great or difficult, and so attains the august and grand.

Light promises lead to few fulfilled words,
Many reckless actions bring many calamities.
**Annotation:**
Lightly promising others leads to few fulfilled words;
Acting recklessly in many things brings later calamities.

**Commentary:**
This concludes with an analogy.
Those who speak without threefold consideration,
Lightly agreeing without thought,
Will surely lack loyalty and trustworthiness.
Those who do not plan the beginning but are cautious at the end,
Who undertake many reckless deeds,
Will later generate calamities and burdens.

**Meaning:**
Before establishing oneself, loyalty and trustworthiness are paramount.
To remain steadfast as one begins,
No calamity can intrude.
If one lightly promises others,
Or recklessly undertakes deeds,
The burdens of calamity will surely follow—
This is indeed the natural order.

Thus, the Sage resolves to avoid such errors,
And so never encounters difficulty.
**Annotation:**
Difficulty arises from light promises and reckless actions,
Thus the Sage never encounters difficult or great matters.

**Commentary:**
The Sage refers to the enlightened ruler.
He hesitates over light promises and reckless actions,
And so never undertakes difficult or great matters.

**Meaning:**
The enlightened ruler and the cultivated scholar
Do not bind themselves to light promises,
Maintaining stillness and following the constant Way.
They do not indulge in reckless desires,
Remaining serene and harmonious in response to things.
Thus, in governance, all are sincerely convinced;
In conduct, they avoid external faults and excesses,
Self-eliminating the flaws of difficulty and greatness,
And aligning with the Dao of *wuwei*.

---

**On the ease of maintaining stillness and restraint (Chapter 64)**

**Commentary:**
The previous chapter expounds the difficulty of *wuwei* and silent mystery,
Illustrating the path to quelling resentment and cultivating the Dao.
This chapter elucidates preemptive foresight and prevention,
Marking the conduct of severing emotions and desires.

The first six sentences repeatedly clarify the gradual nature of preventing calamities.
The next six sentences cite analogies for the origins of calamities.
Two sentences then discuss the delusion of attachment.
Six more sentences contrast ordinary conduct.
The final seven sentences expound the Sage’s reluctance to act and the ease of ordinary people’s scheming.

**Meaning:**
The previous chapter warns against the difficulty of twofold action,
Thus avoiding calamities and burdens.
This chapter now clarifies the fourfold ease of conduct,
Urging meticulous cultivation and guarding against the slightest errors,
Abandoning attachment and delusion,
To exemplify the Sage’s conduct and block the common people’s transgressions.
When all desires are eliminated and noble affections remain unstained,
This fulfills the intent of the next chapter: *Goodness is the Dao itself*.

**On the ease of maintaining stillness and restraint:**

**Commentary:**
*An* (安) means stillness; *chi* (持) means restraint.
Humans, upon receiving life, possess an innate purity and stillness,
But when moved by external things, they chase desires endlessly.
Now, when desire has not yet arisen,
And one is in a state of tranquil stillness,
If one guards it and restrains it,
Preventing it from scattering and becoming disordered,
Then restraint becomes easy.
Thus, it is said: *Its stillness is easy to maintain.*

**Meaning:**
The innate nature is tranquil and still,
Desires not yet having sprouted.
If one attends to it and restrains it,
Holding fast becomes effortless.
To sever the firm ice at the first sign of frost—
This is naturally not difficult.
To return to the uncarved block before the wheels are mounted—
The simplicity is still visible.
It depends on cultivation and refinement,
And the preservation of the eternal truth.

Those moved by external things—
This is the language of the *Rites of Zhou, Music Canon*.

**On its incipient state being easy to plan:**

**Annotation:**
When one is in a state of innate stillness,
And desires have not yet taken form,
If one plans and measures to eliminate them,
Preventing their very rise,
This is indeed very easy.

**Commentary:**
*Fu* (兆) means the gradual emergence of a tendency.
*Mou* (谋) means to plan and measure.
When desire is about to arise but has not yet shown signs,
Planning to eliminate it is also very easy.
Thus, it is said: *Its incipient state is easy to plan.*

**Meaning:**
When desire is about to sprout but has not yet taken form,
Planning to eliminate it—
Its ease is evident.
Yet clarity lies in discerning the subtle,
And power lies in suppressing desire.
To discern and suppress—
No greater virtue exists.

**On its fragility being easy to shatter:**

**Commentary:**
When desire has already stirred but remains soft and fragile,
If one seeks to eliminate it,
It is easy to break and disperse.

**Meaning:**
When desire’s signs are already apparent but have not yet hardened,
To attack the soft and shatter the fragile—
This is not difficult in principle.
It depends on sincere self-discipline and clarity,
Restoring purity and simplicity.

**On its subtlety being easy to disperse:**

**Annotation:**
When desire first takes root, it remains perilously fragile.
Those who can eliminate it—
Its fragility makes it easy to break.
When calamities first arise, their signs are still subtle.
If one seeks to prevent them,
Their subtlety makes them easy to disperse.

**Commentary:**
*Wei* (微) means subtle.
When calamities are still subtle and have not yet grown great,
If one prevents them at their onset,
Dissolving them is also very easy.

**Meaning:**
When desire has already solidified but the matter remains subtle,
To suppress emotions and disperse them,
To curb desire and arrange them properly,
To purify thoughts and cleanse the heart—
The Dao is not far off.

The preceding four sentences collectively illuminate the conduct of preventing the subtle.
They state that governing the state and cultivating oneself
Requires prioritizing the prevention of calamities and forethought of disasters.
When calamities have formed and must be remedied,
When disasters have arisen and must be attacked,
The effort is greater, yet the calamities remain unresolved.

**To act before they manifest:**

**Annotation:**
This reverses the earlier statements on ease of maintaining and planning.
The reason it is easy is that one acts to prevent them
Before they take form or show signs.

**Commentary:**
*Wei* (为) means to cultivate and eliminate.
This sentence elucidates the earlier statements on ease of maintaining and planning.
The reason it is easy is that one cultivates and eliminates desires
Before they arise or take form.

**Meaning:**
*Wei* (为) means to prevent beforehand.
Though it reverses the explanation of ease of maintaining,
It also elaborates on the principle of preventing beforehand.

「The *Wenxuan* (文选) poem states: *"The junzi (君子) prevents what has not yet occurred,"*
This is what is called **preventing calamities and avoiding suspicions**.

**To remedy before chaos arises:**
*Annotation:*
This reverses the earlier statements on ease of breaking and dispersing.
The reason it is easy is that one eliminates what has not yet become calamity or disorder.

*Commentary:*
This sentence elucidates the earlier statements on ease of breaking and dispersing.
The reason it is easy is that, though desires and evils may exist,
They are still fragile and weak, not yet having formed into calamity or disorder,
Hence the principle of ease is clear.

*Meaning:*
**To remedy (理)** means to rescue and rectify.
When desires arise, they disrupt the upright nature (正性),
And the upright nature, once restored, is the primary remedy.
Once the remedy is understood, calamities and disorders cease.
Though this reverses the explanation of ease of breaking and dispersing,
It also retains the essence of rescuing and rectifying.

These six sentences apply to the **self**:
As desires grow gradually, the path of cultivation and mastery lies in
Severing desires and defying emotions,
Averting calamities and eliminating disasters—this is the way.

When applied to the **state (国)**:
Safety must not forget danger—this is maintaining ease.
Order must not forget disorder—this is remedying before chaos.
Anticipate calamities in their hidden stages—this is acting before they manifest.
Guard against disasters in their subtle beginnings—this is dispersing what is minute.
Prevent sprouts and stop gradual growth—this is planning when signs are not yet apparent.
Nurture small virtues and eliminate small vices—this is breaking what is fragile.

Do not neglect small virtues as insignificant and fail to cultivate them,
Nor dismiss small vices as harmless and fail to remove them.
These six principles are indeed the essentials for governing the state.

A tree thick enough to encircle with both arms begins as a tiny sprout (毫末),
A nine-tiered tower rises from a single basket of soil (累土),
A journey of a thousand *li* (千里) begins with a single step (足下).
*Annotation:*
These three examples illustrate the consequences of not acting early,
Leading to later afflictions.

*Commentary:*
This speaks of disasters arising from subtleties,
Yet growing when left unchecked.
Like a tree beginning as a fine hair's tip—this shows their origin in inherent nature.
A nine-tiered high platform starts with a single basket of earth—this shows their formation through accumulated habits.
A thousand-*li* distant journey starts with raising one's foot—this shows their progression from near to far.

Thus, all matters under heaven truly begin with subtleties,
Yet people often neglect them, allowing them to become the root of disasters.
Hence, these three analogies are presented to confirm the preceding text.

*Meaning:*
The reason people fail to prevent disasters,
And states fail to guard against subtleties,
Is that they only address calamities after they have formed,
And only remedy disorders after they have taken shape—
This is all far too late.

From a sprout to a tree thick enough to encircle with both arms,
From small to great.
From a single basket of earth to a nine-tiered tower,
From low to high.
From a single step to a thousand-*li* journey,
From near to far.

When people see only the greatness of the encircled tree,
The height of the layered tower,
The vastness of the thousand-*li* journey,
They then wish to grasp the axe to fell it,
To gather tools to demolish it,
To gallop in pursuit to catch it—
Their labor is indeed great.

Yet calamities cannot be saved, like
Leaning against the capital gate and long sighing—
Ultimately leading to the chaos of the Jin Dynasty (晋朝);
Or bowing to the sand and deer, leaving gifts for the Xiongnu (祆)—
Almost toppling the Han Empire (汉室).

Silent understanding and distant foresight (默识远鉴) are indeed worthy of careful attention.

**To act (为) is to court failure; to grasp (执) is to court loss.**

The annotations and commentaries on the *Way* state:

*"All emotions cannot follow their natural course; when one schemes beyond one’s proper nature, and strives to achieve external matters, disaster will inevitably follow. In affairs, one cannot neglect to let go—every action breeds attachment, and where attachment seeks possession, loss is certain.*

*The commentaries explain: ‘For’ (为) refers to scheming; ‘executing’ (执) refers to attachment. It means that people cannot act before things arise or prevent disorder before it occurs, yet still scheme beyond their inherent nature and cling to the dust of the world—thus they court ruin and loss.*

*The meaning is: People do not understand the *Dao*, yet recklessly act and scheme. If one schemes contrary to the *Dao*, collapse is inevitable. Some cling to teachings, fixating on existence and nonexistence, unable to trust in spontaneity or abide by their true nature. Where there is attachment, there is loss; where there is scheming, there is failure. This is the natural order.*

*To make the sovereign of transformation act without scheming is to avoid failure; to make the cultivator of the *Dao* abandon attachment is to avoid loss. Thus, the Sage acts without scheming and so avoids failure; holds no attachment and so avoids loss.*

*The commentaries explain: The Sage remains still and unforced, thus preserving their innate nature whole and avoiding failure; empty and unattached, their true essence remains ever-present and they avoid loss.*

*The meaning is: The Sage knows that scheming defies the *Dao*, so without scheming, there is no failure; knows that attachment betrays the true self, so without attachment, there is no loss. Thus, they quiet their mind in silent stillness, merging with the *Dao*. Since the *Dao* values emptiness and stillness, those who cultivate it must embody the Sage’s heart—serene, tranquil, without thought or deliberation, without scheming or action—only then does the empty chamber birth the pure.*

*When the people engage in affairs, they often fail just as success nears.*

*The annotations explain: When people first undertake good deeds, they often fail just as they near completion.*

*The commentaries explain: ‘Near’ (几) means ‘close.’ It says that common folk, when following good deeds, often achieve near-success but cannot guard the end, thus inviting failure.*

*The meaning is: The world is tumultuous, and true heart is hard to preserve. Lusts and desires ensnare, and the subtle *Dao* is easily forgotten. One begins with earnest effort but falters in retreat, falling into confusion. This stems from scheming and attachment—thus, failure comes at the brink of completion. If one remains as vigilant at the end as at the beginning, there will be no failure.*

*The annotations explain: If one guards the end as carefully as the beginning, maintaining constancy from start to finish, their affairs will never fail.*

*The commentaries explain: This is Laozi’s repeated admonition. If people can treat the end as they did the beginning, remaining consistent throughout, their affairs will never fail.*

*The *Odes* say: ‘None lack a beginning, but few achieve the end.’*

*The meaning is: Those who cultivate the *Dao* cannot commit their hearts to it, yet scheme beyond their nature. Where there is attachment, the true self is lost; where there is scheming, collapse follows. Thus, cultivating the *Dao* as at the start—with surplus in attainment, boundless in propagation—leads to immortality. It is pitiful that though they begin with diligence, they grow slack in the middle and fail to persevere. To always treat the end as the beginning, to never waver from goodness, is rare. Hence, this stern warning.*

*‘None lack a beginning’ is from the *Odes*—the *Great Odes* of *Dang* (《诗□大雅□荡》). It speaks of how the people were first taught sincerity, loyalty, and benevolence, yet now transform into corrupt customs. It says that those who do good cannot complete it.*

*‘None’ (靡) means ‘without.’ ‘Few’ (鲜) means ‘little.’ ‘Achieve’ (克) means ‘able.’*

*Thus, the Sage desires not to desire, and does not value treasures that are hard to obtain.*

*The annotations explain: Treasures that are hard to obtain are those beyond one’s inherent nature. The Sage, in not desiring what they do not desire and not scheming beyond their nature, preserves their spontaneity—thus they do not value treasures that are hard to obtain.*

*The commentaries explain: This clarifies the Sage’s conduct to contrast with the common. Treasures that are hard to obtain—internally, what lies beyond one’s nature; externally, pearls, rhinoceros horn, and precious gems. The Sage, in not desiring what they do not desire, does not labor to acquire what their nature lacks, nor does it scheme for treasures that accumulate virtue. Hence, it is said they do not value treasures that are hard to obtain.*

*The meaning is: The conduct of the great Sage transcends worldly concerns. Lust and desire cannot sway them; prosperity and decline cannot pressure them. Externally, they seek no gain; internally, they seek nothing beyond their nature. It is to advise rulers to value only the virtuous, and to urge cultivators to follow only the *Dao*."*

---

**On Treasures and Learning**

**Pearls**—when large, with a diameter of an inch, their radiance illuminates twelve chariots—were treasures prized by the ancients.

**Rhinoceros horn**—beyond the southern marches, there is a beast resembling a cow, weighing over a thousand *jin*, with a single horn at its snout, which may be made into a treasure. If its horn is broken in the middle, some display intricate patterns like flowing script or complete figures, others repel dust, and still others repel water. When ground into powder and ingested, they can dispel the ailments caused by witchcraft. Chickens, seeing them at night, are startled—thus they are called *haojī rú* (rhinoceros that terrify chickens). These too were treasures valued in both ancient and modern times.

**Precious gems**—gold and jade, rare plants, feathers, and furs—whatever is held in wonder and esteem by the multitude, all are called *treasures*.

**Cowrie shells**—found in the eastern seas, resembling conch shells, some bearing intricate patterns, with the largest reaching a foot in length—these too can be made into treasures. In the sea, they are called *shellfish*; on land, they are called *feng*; in water, they are called *tuó*. In ancient times, cowries were used as currency, and tortoiseshells were treasured. The Zhou Dynasty minted coins with cowrie motifs, and by the Qin, cowries were abandoned in favor of metal currency. The character *bèi* (贝) is pictographic in origin.

Today, all transactions—gifts, rewards, bounties, and bestowments of wealth and adornments—are derived from the radical of *bèi* (贝). The ancient verse states:
*"To hoard wealth is the folly of the ignorant."*
This makes clear that excessive wealth burdens one’s virtue.

In antiquity, there were three currencies: pearls and jade were the highest, gold was intermediate, and bronze and cloth were the lowest. These were used by emperors to govern the Four Seas.

**On Learning and Not Learning**
The common man prizes treasures that are hard to obtain, thus indulging in artificial pursuits and striving for what lies beyond their natural endowment. The Sage does not seek knowledge beyond their nature, always preserving their innate essence. Therefore, the admonition *"learning and not learning"* is meant to return the multitude to their excesses in study.

**Explanation:**
The Sage’s mind is vast as the void, the *Dao* permeates heaven and earth. They do not labor for knowledge beyond their measure, hence the warning against learning what is unnecessary. This is to caution the common man against their vain and excessive desires.

If travelers can grasp the Sage’s intent, abandoning such arrogance and greed, they will avoid the transgression of overreaching for wealth and ability.

To aid all things in their natural state, yet not to act artificially.

**Annotation:**
The Sage does not seek knowledge beyond their nature, thus the admonition *"learning and not learning"* is to return the multitude to their excessive studies, aiding their innate essence. Therefore, they dare not engage in vulgar learning or excessive desire.

**Explanation:**
Vulgar learning, with its elaborate theories, is difficult to reconcile with *wuwei* (non-action). Excessive desire, tangled and chaotic, further obscures true nature. The Sage commands *"learning and not learning"* to cultivate simplicity, *"desiring and not desiring"* to attain serenity, gradually glimpsing the light of the true *Dao*, thereby aiding nature’s essence.

Not coveting treasures that are hard to obtain, nor striving for abilities beyond their measure—self-defeating yet ultimately successful, cautious to the end as at the beginning, observing subtleties and warding off harm, returning to the ease of simplicity. Thus the realm is at peace, the self steadfast, and only then may one approximate the ancient masters of the *Dao*.

*The Broad Explication of the Dao De Jing’s Sacred Meaning, Volume 43 and 44 concluded.*

**The Broad Explication of the Dao De Jing’s Sacred Meaning**
*Volume 45 – Chapter 65: The Ancient Masters of the Dao*

**Exposition:**
The preceding chapter elucidates foresight and preemptive caution, advocating the eradication of emotional attachments and desires. This chapter reveals how excessive intelligence breeds misfortune, demonstrating the profound virtue of aligning with the natural order.

First, it clarifies the transformative power of the Dao.
Next, it refutes intelligence as a corrupting force.
Knowing this, it then advocates simplicity as the guiding principle.
The passage concludes with a sigh of admiration for its efficacy, urging cultivation.

**Meaning:**
The ancient masters of the Dao did not seek to enlighten the people openly, lest their brilliance provoke ambition and invite calamity. Instead, they concealed their wisdom, guiding the people across the boundless expanse of non-being. Thus, governing through intelligence breeds chaos, while obscuring it brings fortune. When deceitful cunning arises, governance becomes arduous; when it ceases, the mysteries deepen. As virtue becomes profound, the people return to simplicity, abandoning artificiality for the natural order—just as they shed the burdens of excessive learning and desire, attaining the harmony of all things converging toward the root.

The ancient masters of the Dao did not enlighten the people; they sought to make them ignorant.

**Annotation:**
The virtuous ruler who masters the Dao does not flaunt his teachings but leads with harmony, restoring them to their original simplicity—like the unknowing.

**Exposition:**
The ancient sage-rulers of the primordial age—when the world was still veiled in mystery—were profound in their intentions, their hearts obscured like the depths of the void. In their governance, there were no laws nor rewards; in their actions, no coercion nor enticement. Their presence was invisible, their voice inaudible. Their people were like those of the Maoshu Mountains, their customs akin to the dreamlike simplicity of Huaxu. The people did not reckon time, did not resist the natural cycles of fullness and emptiness, did not distinguish between familial and self. They wandered in ignorance, as if in a boundless dream. The rulers did not instruct them with conventional teachings but transformed them through non-action, so that the world became pure and unadulterated, as if the people were truly simple.

The difficulty in governing arises from their excess of intelligence.

**Annotation:**
When the ruler openly displays the Dao to govern below, the people must strain their intelligence to comply. The more they rely on cunning, the more deceit flourishes—making governance all the harder. This is because the ruler’s clarity compels the people to employ their intelligence, breeding fraud.

**Meaning:**
When the ruler governs by revealing the Dao, the people respond with artifice to serve him. Originally, governing through clarity should be straightforward, but when intelligence curdles into deceit, the source lies in the ruler’s own scrutiny. To seek tranquil governance is thus difficult. This lesson urges rulers to emulate the ancient sage-kings, who guided the people toward simplicity—making governance effortless. To rule through intelligence is to invite ruin; to rule through ignorance is to invite blessing.

**Annotation:**
*Yong* (用) here means "to employ." When a ruler relies on cunning ministers to govern, their schemes will proliferate, and with schemes, deceit arises—thus becoming the state’s undoing.

**Exposition:**
*Yong* (employ), *zei* (harm). When a ruler employs clever ministers to govern, their machinations will spawn, and with machinations, falsehoods emerge—corrupting the Dao and harming the state. Hence, it is called the state’s ruin.

**Meaning:**
Governing through intelligence aims to order the people, but when intelligence curdles into deceit, calamity and disorder follow. Thus, the rise of falsehood and harm becomes inevitable. When Cao Parameter adhered strictly to law, the Han dynasty flourished; when Shang Yang altered the laws, Qin declined. Hence, the *Classic* states: *"When cleverness emerges, great falsehood follows."* Not employing intelligence is the state’s blessing.

**Annotation:**
If the ruler does not employ deceitful ministers but instead selects virtuous officials—those who remain tranquil, nurturing the land like the stillness of a sleeping warrior, resolving conflicts with ease—then naturally, deceit will wane while simplicity flourishes. When the people are harmonious, the years will be bountiful—this is the state’s blessing.

**Exposition:**
The ruler is like a mirror: if the mirror is upright, its reflection is straight; if the mirror is crooked, its reflection is distorted. When the ruler is upright, the people follow suit; when he is corrupt, the people conform to his vice. The purity or corruption of the people stems from nothing else. Employing clever strategists spawns scheming; employing honest and thick-hearted men fosters virtuous customs. When the people are transformed into harmony, the state prospers—this is the blessing.

*Pianshi Fanwei* (偃息蕃魏) refers to Dan Ganmu, the teacher of Duke Wen of Wei, who prioritized tranquility and moral cultivation, ensuring the stability of Wei like a protective barrier.

*Pianshi* (偃息) means to rest in stillness; *Fanwei* (蕃魏) signifies the flourishing defense of Wei.

*Nongwan Jiedan* (弄丸解难) refers to the incident where the two great houses of Chu—White Gongsheng and the minister Xi—clashed in arms. Their envoys sought out Yiliang Yeliao, a recluse of the market south, who was said to be a master of *wuwei* (non-action). When the envoys arrived, he lay with his head propped up, unmoved by their plea.

「Lying motionless and not rising, he played with the ball between his two hands without ceasing, holding it up to a drawn sword—yet he did not flinch. The two ministers’ envoys each returned, fully recounting Yiliao’s demeanor.

The two ministers said: *"The reclining with a high pillow signifies his embrace of non-action (wuwei).*
*The sword held above him without movement shows that arms are not to be relied upon.*
*His two hands represent the two houses.*
*The ball is a round object, embodying non-action.*
*Both hands manipulating it endlessly means they will both cease only in exhaustion.*
*Thus, it is clear that if both houses persist in their armed strife, they will surely meet with destruction.*
*Yet the ministers laid down their arms and returned—this proves their conflict was difficult to resolve.*
*This account appears in *Zhuangzi* (《庄子》).*

*When non-action (wuwei) flourishes, action (youwei) naturally fades away.*
*When purity and simplicity are manifest, cleverness and deceit perish of their own accord.*
*This is the inevitable outcome of circumstances.*
*Is this not the blessing for a state?*
*To grasp these two principles is to establish a model.*

*Note: Employing cleverness and deceit harms others, while trusting in pure virtue benefits the people.*
*The ruler who always knows whom to entrust is said to possess profound and mysterious virtue (shenxuan zhī dé).*

*Commentary: These two refer to the use of cleverness and the avoidance of it.*
*They are models (kǎimó) and standards (shì, law).*
*Cleverness, if used, becomes a thief for the state; if avoided, it brings blessings.*
*The ruler must discard the thief and embrace the blessings.*
*Thus, one who does so can serve as the model and standard for governing the state.*

*Meaning: Using cleverness leads to chaos in the state, while avoiding it brings peace to the people.*
*To abandon chaos and seek peace is the essence of governance.*

*Those skilled in strategy and eloquent in debate adorn cleverness to deceive the lords,*
*and indulge in rhetoric to sow discord among rulers.*
*They split the firm and unite the disparate,*
*turn white into black,*
*striving only for fame and reputation,*
*for flattery and honor,*
*for petty disputes and personal gratification,*
*never considering security or the harm they cause.*
*If they gain the opportunity to indulge their flattery and empty words, they will take pride in it.*

*The ruler governing the state must discern and reject them,*
*then purity and simplicity will prevail,*
*and the people will return to their natural state.*

*To always grasp these models is called profound virtue (xuándé).*

*Note: Those with virtuous power (fúdé zhī chén) are also models for the ruler,*
*to be entrusted for the benefit of the people.*
*The ruler who understands this can rely upon them.*

*Commentary: Profound (xuán) means deep and wondrous.*
*If the ruler always understands this,*
*then these two principles become models,*
*and this is called profound, far-reaching, wondrous, and mysterious virtue.*

*Meaning: The ruler who knows to use cleverness or virtue,*
*to determine security and danger,*
*and who consistently follows this principle,*
*will possess virtue that is profound and far-reaching.*

*Profound virtue is deep and far-reaching,*
*contrary to the ways of things,*
*and only then does it attain the utmost harmony (dàshùn).*

*Note: Profound virtue, deep and far-reaching,*
*can reverse the course of things and return them to their original state,*
*allowing all things to reach their utmost harmony in natural disposition.*

*Commentary: This is a concluding sigh.*
*The ruler with profound virtue governs from above with non-action (wuwei),*
*his influence unfathomable—this is depth.*
*His blessings extend without limit—this is far-reaching.*
*Thus, he can return all things to their wondrous origin,*
*and only then do they attain utmost harmony in their true, natural nature.*

*Meaning: The utmost harmony (dàshùn) is rooted in human nature.*
*The *Records of Rites* (《礼记》) in the *Gongyang* (□礼运篇) says:*
*"Human nature is the field of the sage-kings."*
*Therefore, the sage-kings refine the principles of righteousness (yì),*
*establish the order of rituals (lǐ) to govern human nature.*
*They cultivate the field of human nature with rituals,*
*plow it with harmony of firm and yielding,*
*sow it with righteousness,*
*and nurture the Dao of goodness.*
*They weed it with recitation and learning,*
*preserving truth and discarding falsehood,*
*gather it with the foundation of humanity,*
*uniting what is formed,*
*and harvest it with music to bring peace,*
*stirring and solidifying the people’s hearts.*

*To govern the state without rituals is like plowing without a hoe.*
*To establish rituals without grounding them in righteousness is like plowing without sowing.*
*To practice righteousness without teaching it through learning is like sowing without weeding.*
*To teach it through learning without uniting it with humanity is like weeding without reaping.*
*To unite it with humanity without securing it with music is like reaping without eating.*
*To secure it with music without attaining harmony is like eating without nourishment.*

*When the four limbs are at ease and the skin and flesh plump, this is true nourishment for the body.*
*When father and son are devoted and brothers are amicable,*
*when husband and wife are harmonious, this is true nourishment for the family.*
*When great officials uphold the law and lesser ones are honest,*
*when ranks and duties are properly ordered,*
*and when ruler and subject align in correctness, this is true nourishment for the state.*
*The Son of Heaven uses virtue as his chariot and music as his reins,*
*the feudal lords interact with one another through rituals,*
*the ministers are bound by law,*
*the scholars are judged by their integrity,*
*and the common people are protected by mutual goodwill—this is true nourishment for the world.*
*This is called utmost harmony (dàshùn).*

*Therefore, when the Son of Heaven governs with harmony (shùn),*
*heaven does not hoard its Dao,*
*earth does not hoard its treasures,*
*and people do not hoard their nature—*
*abundant blessings emerge.*
*Harmony is the treasure of harmony.*

*The ruler who dwells above with profound virtue (xuándé),*
*and whose ministers below abide by loyalty and sincerity,*
*will have a transformation vast, deep, and thick,*
*returning all things to the pure customs (chúnfēng).*
*This is called attaining harmony with the Dao.*

*The ancient emperors and kings all revered and followed the ancient Way,*
*issuing their teachings and orders with sincerity,*
*relying on simplicity and humility,*
*and shepherding their people with modesty and harmony.*
*Thus, the *Book of Documents* (《书》) speaks of "investigating antiquity" (qǐgǔ),*
*and this is the example of Emperor Yao.*

*When the world attains utmost harmony (dàshùn),*
*all under heaven return to it.*
*When the rivers of the sea are modest and harmonious,*
*all streams flow toward them.*
*Thus, the chapter *Jianghai* (《江海》) can follow upon the virtue of utmost harmony.*

*Jianghai as the king of all streams, Chapter Sixty-Six*

*Commentary: The previous chapter illustrated that cleverness brings misfortune,*
*and demonstrated the profound virtue of attaining utmost harmony.*
*This chapter shows that goodness in the lower ranks makes one a king,*
*and sets forth the sage’s virtue of non-contention.*

*First, it uses the analogy of Jianghai,*
*showing that goodness in the lower ranks makes one a king.*
*Next, it explains the sage’s practice of modesty,*
*taking pleasure in promoting others without indulgence.*
*Finally, it concludes with the virtue of non-contention,*
*to indicate the path of cultivation.*

*Meaning: Jianghai rests below, yet all streams return to it.*
*The ruler who practices modesty will have all nations come to him in homage.*
*Thus, to rest above while the people do not revere,*
*or to step back while the people willingly promote,*
*is the profound virtue of the sage.*

The Jianghai rests as king through this virtue,
the Sage attains dominion through it,
forever aligning with the Way’s sovereign,
fulfilling the grand harmony’s rule.

It responds to the unworthy’s words,
yet ever follows the training of benevolence.

Jianghai becomes king of all streams
because it excels in humility—
thus it rules all streams.
**Annotation:** Jianghai commands the hundred valleys
because it excels in humility,
so all rivers converge in homage.

**Cushion:** It explains how Jianghai
makes rivers flow toward it as king—
because it dwells in the lowly current’s place.

Thus the *Yijing* says: *"The Earth’s Way transforms fullness into humility, flowing in modesty."*
This is the analogy invoked.

The Earth’s Way, through humility,
makes rivers converge and return.
The Sage, through humility,
makes the common folk come willingly without exhaustion.

**Meaning:** Humility is the foundation of elevation,
modesty the root of virtue.
Rivers flow eastward as if returning home—
homage to the virtuous in humility.
Ten thousand households face north in reverence—
the Sage’s virtue lies in modesty.

The common folk come naturally—
this is the principle.

Yan Junping said: *"Heaven and Earth do not abandon all things,
and all things abandon them to myriad creatures.
They do not seek to rule, yet all things come to them.*
Thus, though Heaven and Earth are vast,
the Great Dao rules them;
though yang-qi blazes,
Heaven rules it;
though yin-qi is solemn,
Earth rules it;
though living beings are countless,
the Sage rules them;
though winged creatures soar in the void,
the divine phoenix rules them;
though furred creatures tread the earth,
the qilin rules them;
though scaled creatures dwell in water,
the divine dragon rules them;
though shelled creatures dwell in marshes,
the spirit tortoise rules them;
though all rivers flow together,
Jianghai rules them.

These nine kings do not claim dominion,
yet all things come to them;
they do not impose laws,
yet all things are ordered;
they do not rely on trust and faith,
yet all things attach to them;
they do not depend on kindness and love,
yet all things grow close;
they do not wield intelligence and strength,
yet all things stand in awe.

Why is this?
They embody the Dao and harmonize with virtue,
entrusting to nature—
thus all things revere them.

Jianghai rules not through cleverness to please,
nor kindness to embrace,
nor commands to bind,
nor laws to exhort,
nor schemes to control.

Rivers converge because it rests low—
things naturally comply.

Thus, when a person dwells in humility,
with a modest, respectful, non-contentious heart,
they gather people and rule—
this is essential.

The Earth’s Way transforms fullness into flowing modesty—
the *Yijing*’s *Cong* hexagram’s *Simian* text states:
*"Hills and valleys, the high gradually descend,
the low gradually ascend—
changing fullness, flowing in modesty."*

**Annotation:** *"The common folk come"*—
from the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Duke Zhao 10:
Chu Sun Zhaozi said:
*"The *Odes*—the *Great Odes*—say:
*'Begin with care, do not rush—
the common folk come as sons.'*
Meaning King Wen began the Lingtai,
with urgency in his heart,
and the people came willingly, joyful."*

Thus, the Sage desires to be above others
by speaking in humility.

**Cushion:** This merges the analogy.
The Sage does not truly desire to be above others,
yet speaks in humility.
The Sage knows fullness invites loss,
so in speech, they are modest and gentle,
adopting names of solitude and poverty to be below things,
while vast virtue and grand achievements
are naturally revered by all.

**Meaning:** The Sage humbles themselves,
without embellishment,
using names of solitude and poverty to display
that humility is fundamental,
and blaming themselves to fill the gaps—
revealing their self-reproachful heart.

Thus, great virtue grows ever more exalted,
and mighty deeds grow ever more steadfast.

*Hong*—great.
To go before others, they place themselves behind.

**Cushion:** The Sage does not desire to go before others,
only to practice humility,
placing themselves behind things—
thus things place them before.

**Meaning:** The Sage does not desire to go before others,
yet curiously places themselves behind.
Because they diligently follow the Dao,
not placing themselves before things,
they are pushed forward by all things.

Thus, though they dwell above, people do not grow weary of them;
though they stand before, people do not harm them.

**Annotation:** Humility is the handle of virtue,
and the more it is used, the brighter it shines.
By speaking in humility,
the people joyfully uphold them—
thus, though they dwell above, people do not see them as burdensome.
By placing themselves behind,
the people come as sons—
thus, though they stand before, people do not see them as harmful.

**Cushion:** This concludes the previous section.
The Sage, in the supreme treasure’s position,
at the utmost height of honor,
labors for themselves while resting others,
depletes themselves while enriching things—
those above gain life,
so they are not seen as burdensome;
those before gain order,
so they are not seen as harmful.

**Meaning:** The ruler’s virtue is humble and empty,
worthy of all’s reverence—
thus, though they dwell above, they are not burdensome.
The ruler’s virtue is bright and clear,
shared in reverence—
thus, though they stand before, they are not harmful.

If their merit is flourishing above,
people all uphold them,
gazing upon them like the sky.
If they are sinful and wicked before,
people all abandon them,
viewing them as enemies.
This is to say: *With the Way, they flourish; without it, they perish.*

Thus, the world delights in promoting them without exhaustion.

**Annotation:** Because they are neither burdensome nor harmful,
the world’s people joyfully uphold them as sovereign,
without growing weary.

**Cushion:** The Sage’s virtue is vast and beneficent, without selfishness,
bringing spring to all things,
gazed upon like the sun—
neither burdensome nor harmful—
thus the world’s people joyfully uphold them without weariness.

**Meaning:** When Yao governed the world,
the eight directions and all living beings gathered like clouds,
gazed upon like the sun,
promoted as sovereign without exhaustion.
When he departed the world,
the people mourned him as if losing parents,
and for three years, the music was suppressed.

Why is this so?

It is because **virtue** is rooted in humility, and **transformation** in *wuwei* [non-action].
Since they do not contend, none under heaven can contend with them.

**Annotation:** The Sage is humble and retiring, not contending with things. The world delights in promoting them—who would dare to contend?

**Cushion:** Now, why does the world joyfully uphold the Sage without exhaustion?
Is it not because the Sage, in speech, places others first, and in conduct, follows behind?
Since they do not vie for precedence with things, none under heaven can vie for precedence with the Sage.

**Meaning:** The Sage governs the world—**virtue** and **transformation** spread universally,
illumination reaching the four quarters, beneficence encompassing the nine regions.
With humility, they do not lead things;
with gentleness, they do not place themselves above them.
The people naturally acclaim and enthrone them—who would contend?
Thus, their blessings endure far and long, their lineage flourishing and vast.

Like the great sea receiving all rivers,
neither overflowing nor deficient,
like the Most High holding the Three Treasures,
with compassion and frugality.

Therefore, the next chapter follows with the Three Treasures.

*End of Volume Forty-Four of the Broad Explication of the Dao-De Jing*
*Beginning of Volume Forty-Five of the Broad Explication of the Dao-De Jing*

---

**Volume Forty-Four of the Broad Explication of the Dao-De Jing** concludes with the words of the Sage.

**Volume Forty-Five of the Broad Explication of the Dao-De Jing** begins:

The world all says my Dao is vast, yet it seems unmatched.
**Meaning:** The Dao is vast, yet it appears unlike anything else.

**Annotation:** *Not matched* means *unlike*.

The Laozi says: "The people of the world all say my Dao is vast, with nothing to compare it to."
I then respond.

**Explication:** *Not matched* means *unlike*. The Laozi states: "The people of later generations all say my Dao is vast and formless, unlike anything that can be compared." The following text answers this.

**Meaning:** The heavens and earth are vast, yet they have forms of clarity and turbidity;
the sun and moon are vast, yet they have radiant illumination.
But the Dao’s vastness is without scent or sound,
without form or likeness—
thus it cannot be imitated or discussed,
and that is why the world’s people all say the Dao is unlike anything else.

Only because it is truly vast does it seem unmatched.
If it were matched, it would long ago have been diminished to triviality.

**Annotation:** Only because my Dao is supremely vast does it have no likeness or comparison.
If it were like the myriad laws of past ages,
it would not be called "vast" for long—
it would already be petty and shallow.

**Explication:** This explains why it seems unmatched.
Only because my Dao is vast and transcends all things
does it escape the grasp of ordinary understanding,
and thus it can be called truly vast.
If it had likeness or comparison,
like the myriad laws of past ages,
it would lose its claim to vastness.
Such petty and shallow laws
differ little from the common ways—
how could they be called truly vast?

*This* is an auxiliary particle for emphasis.

**Meaning:** The Dao encompasses all things,
its vastness without comparison—
that is why it is called "vast."
If it were like the heavens and earth,
with fixed forms and positions,
or like the sun and moon,
with discernible radiance,
then it could be named, spoken of,
measured or calculated—
but then it would not be called the "Great Dao,"
for such would merely be the ordinary state of things,
and that has long existed.

I have Three Treasures,
which I preserve and uphold.

**Annotation:** Though my Dao is vast and without comparison,
it still contains these Three Practices,
which are most precious.
If one steadfastly preserves and upholds them,
they can govern oneself and the nation.

**Explication:** This clarifies why it seems unmatched—
for it possesses these Three Practices,
which differ from the common ways.
Thus the Laozi says: Though my Dao is vast and without comparison,
it still contains these Three Treasures,
which are most precious.
For those of your age, you must preserve and uphold them,
to cultivate yourself and govern the nation.

**Meaning:** The Dao, though it embraces all laws and practices,
transforms the heavens and earth,
and its benefits reach beyond measure.
Yet the Three Treasures cherished by the Most High
and taught to the world are these:
the first is **compassion**,
the second is **frugality**,
and the third is **not daring to lead the world**.

**Annotation:** *Compassion* means universal aid;
*frugality* means sufficient resources without waste;
*not daring to lead the world* means harmony without domination,
so that others willingly follow without complaint.

**Explication:** This enumerates the Three Treasures.
To embody benevolence and extend broad aid,
to love and nurture all beings—
that is **compassion**.
To regulate use and benefit others,
to avoid depletion of resources—
that is **frugality**.
To not initiate action,
to harmonize without asserting—
that is **not daring to lead the world**.
Their expansive benefits are detailed below.

**Meaning:** The Dao preserves love and nurtures life,
and thus **compassion** is its first principle.
To nourish people while sparing expense,
**frugality** is its second check.
To place others before oneself,
**letting** is its final virtue.

**Compassion** follows the Way of Heaven,
its beneficence extending without limit;
**frugality** follows the Way of Earth,
its great trust never deceiving;
**letting** follows the Way of humanity,
its reverence and humility unchallenged.
These three are the foundation of governance,
the root of personal conduct—
treasures of the highest worth.
